name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on Ernest Urtasun's report, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the 2013 annual report of the European Investment Bank (2014/2156(INI)) (A8-0057/2015). I welcome Werner Hoyer, President of the European Investment Bank.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President; I would like to thank Mr Hoyer for his presence, the European Investment Bank for their cooperation in drafting this report and the shadow rapporteurs, who are also here today, for the constructive attitude and good work done with their proposals. The Bank – in our view – is destined to play a much more important role in the future of the European Union because of the need to urgently abandon recession and austerity and to move towards investment and higher welfare quotas. That is why the role of the EI will be essential and this is especially the report this year, also because we are on the doorstep of the start of the so-called Juncker Plan. I will divide my intervention into four blocks, which are basically the blocks covered by the report, the first being investment. The fact that this report was drafted in parallel , as I said - to the Juncker Plan has made this obviously our attention. As you know, my group and I are skeptical of private equity leverage of such a proportion as proposed, from 1 to 15, because, from what we have seen, we have no precedent with such a high factor. In the report, we stress that, moreover, the guarantees for EFSI do not correspond to new funds, but to allocated resources, and we would like an assessment of the reallocation of these resources to see if, in fact, that is better than being earmarked for other use. We also note that the project selection process should be intended to avoid the effects of expelling private capital from projects that are already being done or would have been done the same. We also look forward to the plenary's support for our reference to the fight against unemployment to become a central activity of the European Investment Bank and we also support – because I think it is necessary – that the European Central Bank can go to the purchase of bonds to be issued by the EI UNDER EFSI. The second block of issues covered in the report is the evaluation of the Project Bond Initiative, which has been a good part of our work. I would like to begin, of course, by the first pilot project, which was, of course, the Beaver project. On 26 January you yourself, Mr Hoyer, said in the European Parliament that the Beaver project became a tragedy and I share your assessment. Today we are also joined here by representatives of the Platform in Defense of les Terres del Sénia, whom I would like to pay tribute to for their tireless struggle for the paralysis of the project and compensation. This, of course, was not a project that responded to the common interest. It was paralyzed by more than a thousand earthquakes and a lousy environmental assessment that ignored the expert reports and ended with the intention of compensating a private company with 1.3 billion for paralyzing the work, compensation that the Spanish government now intends to be paid by Spanish citizens in its gas bill for 30 years. We believe – and that is one of the issues covered in the report – that the European Commission and the European Investment Bank must act to avoid this waste. I would also like to transfer to you, Mr Hoyer, a certain unease of the citizens who are joining us here today because of the lack of response to the complaints mechanism office of the Bank. The third block I would like to point out is the energy policy bloc. In this section we recognize the steps taken by the EI in its new policy, with the gradual abolition of aid for coal projects, and insist in this regard on the need to present a plan to end such projects. Finally, the climate assessment that you are going to initiate also seems to us to be a good initiative. And the fourth and final bloc is transparency and accountability. We welcome efforts to improve transparency, but we have been a little disappointed by the results of the transparency policy review. We believe that the European Investment Bank's old culture of secrecy should be left behind – and this is usually pointed out – and that it should be published on the basis of the principle of publication, that is, that confidential should be the exception and not the norm. Finally, I would like to point out that we would like the issue of the use of tax havens in financial intermediations and also the new tax policy to be an important element of the work of the European Investment Bank, and we call on the Bank to refrain from cooperating with financial intermediaries with a negative track record of transparency , tax evasion or tax planning practices fraud, corruption or environmental and social impact. That is why, Mr Hoyer, I would like to end by thanking you for the bank's cooperation and waiting for you to follow the recommendations that the European Parliament will give you.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: President of the European Investment Bank. – Madam President, let me first of all say that I am very grateful to have been invited to contribute to this debate here today and to comment on the report of the rapporteur and his colleagues on the EIB’s Annual Report for 2013. It is always a little bit awkward to be in 2015 and then discuss the report of 2013, because many issues that are very current in the minds of people and the issues that also the rapporteur has just mentioned go beyond 2013. They are going into last year, this year and then into the future. This is why I will not limit myself only to 2013, if you agree. The Treaty does not provide for this exchange of views, but I think it is only proper that the Bank, given its size and relevance in the global financial landscape and its role within the EU institutional framework, comes to the European Parliament to explain what it is doing, especially with EU budgetary funds, where that is applicable.  First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur and his colleagues for the 2013 Annual Report. I appreciate the support you give us – and have given us – to ensure that the EIB, the EU Bank, will continue to deliver benefits for the EU economy and for EU citizens as well as contribute to economic development in our external activities.  Notably, I appreciate your explicit support in the report: on the EIB as a catalyst for financing sound public and private long-term investments; on continuing to implement best prudential banking practices; on maintaining the very strong EIB capital position, and on selection of EIB projects based on their viability, added value and impact on economic recovery. These factors you mention and support in the report are of fundamental importance for the Bank.  Let me start by recapping on what we have achieved since 2013 – the year under review – and look forward into the future, even if that is always a risky exercise. 2013 was very important for the Bank: the first full year of operations following the EUR 10 billion capital increase in paid-in capital approved by the shareholders in 2012. Thanks to this capital injection, the EIB promised to increase its volume of loan signatures every year, over three years, by EUR 20 billion, or nearly 40% in comparison to the year before. I am pleased to be able to report that last year, in 2014, EIB signatures increased further to EUR 77 billion – EUR 27 billion more than would have been achieved without the extra capital and substantially higher than the figure in the report for 2013.  We are now only a third of the way through 2015, but I can already announce that we have completed the additional EUR 60 billion of lending we promised to deliver at the June 2012 European Council. That means, to be clear, when we asked the shareholders to agree to the capital increase that we needed, made in this very Parliament, we said that we would be able to trigger additional investment to the volume of EUR 180 billion for over three years out of a capital increase of EUR 10 billion. The deadline for achieving this is December 2015. We have already achieved it today, and this shows the multiplier which has been there – the multiplier was 18. If we continue to the end of the year, the achieved multiplier will be far beyond 20. We are now in a situation where we have discussed the assumed multiplier for the Juncker Plan and, since we know that we are going to go into more risky business, it is obvious that we have to be a little bit more careful and cautious. Therefore, we have calculated on a very sound basis: 15. We have to be on the safe side, but we are extremely confident that we will be able to deliver, and better. More importantly, because we rarely support more than a third of a project’s total cost, this extra lending has helped mobilise at least EUR 180 billion of additional investments, and that is important. The EU Bank crowds in the private sector in two ways: number one, on the basis of the capital increase, we were able to borrow more from the markets. We go to the markets to borrow EUR 60 to 80 billion every year by selling EIB bonds. The capital increase has enabled us to do much more on this. The second part of the multiplier is the fact that we never finance roughly more than a third of a project, so two-thirds come from other sources. That brings about the multiplier, which we calculated cautiously at 18 for the capital increase and at 15 for the Juncker Plan.  Thus the EIB has delivered the capital increase faster than expected, which enables us to further support the economic recovery in Europe going forward. I do expect EIB lending volumes to be above EUR 70 billion annually for this year and the two next years, thanks to the guarantee in the context of EFSI, if it comes about. This decision lies in your hands, or now in the hands of the trilogue.   Let me turn to some important broader issues mentioned in the report. As the EU bank, we know that the finance we provide is a means to an end. We provide for viable and sound projects where it makes a difference. Unlike a commercial bank, our objective is not profit, but economic and societal outcomes. This is why our lending, anchored within the priorities of Europe 2020, has gone in particular to infrastructure – that is, to strategic infrastructure – climate action, innovation and skills and, above all, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which, as your report rightly points out, are the backbone of Europe’s economy. In 2013 and 2014, the EIB Group – that is the EIB and the European Investment Fund together – provided some EUR 50 billion of new finance for SMEs, supporting over EUR 100 billion of financial investment by more than 500 000 companies that together employ more than six million people. We are conscious that many firms still struggle to get loans at reasonable conditions, and therefore we will continue to expand our offering.  New, targeted initiatives taken recently include the ‘SME Initiative’ signed with Spain, which will combine EIB/EIF finance with EU budgetary funds to support more than EUR five billion of lending by local financial intermediaries. Let me also mention the ‘Jobs for Youth’ pillar, one of the two strands of our ‘Skills and Jobs’ programme, which aims at stimulating job creation for young people by SMEs, with a specific focus on European regions most impacted by high youth unemployment. As a matter of fact, at the informal European Summit in Paris in July 2013 we promised to make available an additional EUR six billion for the fight against youth unemployment within the year 2013, and by December 2013 we had delivered EUR 9.3 billion. It has therefore been a big success story, not only in terms of volumes, but also in terms of the impact it has had on the real employment of young people.  Support to SMEs will continue at a sustained pace in 2015 through our normal business, but also under the Investment Plan for Europe. And this is not only via EIF, but also by EIB. Let me remind you that at least one in every four euro of capacity of EFSI will be dedicated to SMEs and midcaps.  At the end of 2013, the EIB published an evaluation of its SME lending over the period 2005-2011, and we of course stand ready to provide you with further information.  The EIB is committed to supporting the EU’s ambitious energy and climate policy goals. For the last six years, more than 25% of our annual lending has contributed to climate action. Since 2013, we have set stringent energy performance standards that effectively close the door on financing unabated coal power plants. With the encouragement of this House, we were able, in 2011, to launch the European Energy Efficiency Fund, which has already helped mobilise more than EUR 400 million of final investment for a technical assistance budget of just under EUR 20 million. I would also like to highlight the European Local Energy Assistance facility ELENA. With EU grants of EUR 69 million over the past five years, ELENA is well on the way to mobilising EUR 3.7 billion in final investment in energy efficiency and renewable energy schemes in cities across Europe – including this year’s Green Capital, which is Bristol. Together with the Commission, we have recently launched a number of additional products to encourage more private-sector lending for energy efficiency and small renewable investments, and a new natural capital facility to support biodiversity projects.  As a follow-up to our energy policy review last year, the Bank has also this year concluded a public consultation on its approach to climate action. We aim to have reached and published the conclusions before the Paris negotiations – underlining Europe’s strong commitment.  Lending to education is a key pillar of the EIB’s Innovation and Skills programme and is crucial to address the competitiveness gap in the EU. Between 2000 and 2014, the EIB’s lending to education represented around EUR 30.6 billion, corresponding to more than EUR 2 billion on a yearly basis. Our support for education has been strengthened with the launch, in July 2013, of the ‘Skills and Jobs – Investing for Youth’ programme which I already mentioned. The Bank will continue to assess, throughout 2015-2017, how it can best contribute to increasing the availability of state-of-the-art training opportunities for young people, and increase the competitiveness of SMEs and Midcaps which provide employment or training opportunities to young people. In doing so, it strives to complement national measures and the Youth Employment Guarantee programme of the Commission. The EIB is committed to working even more closely with national promotional institutions (NPIs), banks and similar institutions and banks in all EU Member States, benefiting from the NPIs’ local presence and local market knowledge to contribute to EIB lending. Following the European Council request, the cooperation with National Promotional Banks has further intensified. The EIB, together with the Commission, has initiated and enhanced cooperation in four working groups. These working groups are expected to deliver concrete proposals in time for the June Ecofin Council.  In your 2013 report, you stressed that the EIB must continue to be a financial institution of good practice. I can assure you that we do put a very strong emphasis on being a leading financial institution, no – the leading financial institution – when it comes to issues such as due diligence, compliance, good governance and accountability. We are continuously in contact with other international financial institutions, international organisations and relevant authorities to ensure that we apply best banking practices. It is particularly true for the Global Forum initiatives. We cannot afford to slip behind. We need to make sure that our financing is contributing to its aims in the best possible way. We need to lead by example, and we are able and ready to learn. Every year we finance approximately 500 operations, and some of them have many different projects underneath. In a few isolated cases, projects go wrong – sometimes for reasons beyond our control. However, I am very proud that these few cases of failure rarely result in any losses for European taxpayers. Europe also has global responsibilities. This year we will see the adoption of the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals. This was a focus of our discussions in Washington this month with other multilateral development banks. We are very much looking forward to the financing for development conference in July. Ahead of the Paris UNFCCC (United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change) talks in December, climate action will also remain a cross-cutting concern in our activity, both inside and outside the EU. The EIB is already the world’s leading public financier of climate action projects and has pioneered the market in Green Bonds. The EIB is willing to do more in its external action and will engage with the European External Action Service, the Commission, Member States and other financial institutions on ways to maximise our impact. Maybe the limiting of our activities outside the European Union to 10% of the business volume will not be the last word. At least, I personally hope so. The successful implementation of the EIB capital increase has put the EIB in the position to contribute strongly to the Investment Plan for Europe, and notably EFSI. We are now committed to mobilise EUR 315 billion in EU investment over the next three years. Providing EFSI with an EU guarantee will allow the Bank to conduct more operations with a higher risk profile than it does currently, but we will maintain our high standards of due diligence.  Let me assure you that we are willing to live up fully to our institutional responsibilities in setting up the European Fund for Strategic Investments and reporting back to you regularly on the impact it has had for Europe and its citizens.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission welcomes Parliament’s report on the European Investment Bank and shares its recognition of the important role the European Investment Bank (EIB) plays in supporting Europe’s recovery from the financial and economic crisis. The Commission is glad to see that the EIB delivered and indeed exceeded the objectives of the Growth and Employment Facility and that the EIB commits to continue its important catalytic role to resolve the current investment and competitiveness challenges in the European Union. The Commission understands that EIB financing is geographically distributed according to demand from respective Member States and the EIB’s business development considerations. Today I want to highlight the EIB’s efforts to support programme countries, which increased by 24.7 % in 2014 compared to 2013. I would also like to mention the innovative instruments such as the Trade Finance Facility and the SME Guarantee Fund.  The Investment Plan for Europe confirms the EIB’s central role in helping the EU deliver on the EUR 315 billion objective, in combination with EU budget resources and national promotional banks. The European Union Investment Plan and the European Fund for Strategic Investments lie at the core of these efforts to catalyse new investments for the EU economy.  Last week, I was pleased to hear that the European Investment Bank announced that it has approved up to EUR 300 million in financing for the first four projects as part of the Investment Plan for Europe, in which the EIB is the Commission’s strategic partner. These projects are in different sectors – research and development, healthcare, industrial innovation, and transport – and in different countries: Spain, Italy, Ireland and Croatia. They serve as examples of investments that the new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) may support in the near future. This means that until the EFSI is fully operational, the EIB is already pre-financing projects.  We look forward to finalising the legislative process for the EFSI together with Parliament and the Council and to realising its full potential in close cooperation with the EIB. The EFSI – at the heart of the Investment Plan – should be up and running by September this year. The EFSI is also a crucial opportunity to support infrastructure investments in line with EU policy priorities such as the Europe 2020 Strategy and the 2030 climate and energy package. The Investment Plan has highlighted a broad range of priorities, including renewables and energy efficiency retrofits, water and wastewater, improved rail connections, greening projects in the area of maritime transport, alternative fuel infrastructure and third generation bio-refineries.  Furthermore, the European Union has increased the level of ambition on climate actions, in particular with the adoption in October 2014 by the EU Council of the 2030 climate and energy targets. The Commission welcomes the EIB objective to publish its new strategy by the Paris Conference.  Access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) remains a pressing problem in several Member States. In 2014, the Commission welcomed the launch of the EIB group Risk Enhancement Mandate (EREM). We also welcome the EIB’s contribution to revitalising the European securitisation market and new product developments to promote financial inclusion under the Risk Capital Resources (RCR) mandate.  At the start of the new Multiannual Financial Framework running until 2020, the European Investment Bank and the Commission launched a new generation of financial instruments in favour of SMEs and midcaps such as InnovFin – EU Finance for Innovators – and risk-sharing products under competitiveness of enterprises and SMEs. On transparency policy, openness and accountability are key EU concepts. The Commission supports the EIB in being one of the frontrunners among other international financial intermediaries in access to information and transparency rules. In this respect, we value the EIB’s commitment to complying with EU policy initiatives and legislative framework on transparency and public disclosure of information and to following international best practice. We welcome the recent approval of the revised EIB group transparency policy, after a public consultation of civil society organisations.  On external actions, Parliament calls for a thorough assessment and a report on risks and control systems associated with EU blending facilities. The EU Platform for Blending in External Cooperation (EUBEC) has reviewed and compared the performance of different EU blending mechanisms.  As regards the alignment of EIB external lending activities with EU policies before the mid-term review, practical measures for linking the general objectives of the EU guarantee and their implementation will be set out in the updated regional technical operational guidelines. The Commission is currently reviewing these guidelines together with the EIB and in consultation with the EEAS, and the updated guidelines will be transmitted to Parliament and the Council in the coming weeks.  Your report calls for cooperation between the EIB and the EBRD to be enhanced and the Commission actively supports this approach, amongst others, under the Memorandum of Understanding between the European Commission, the EIB and the EBRD on activities outside the European Union. This Memorandum fosters a culture of regular exchange of information and the joint identification of co-financing opportunities based on each partner’s comparative advantage.  Thank you for your attention and I look forward to the debate on this report.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: draftss author of the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, Mr President of the EIB, i would like to thank you for your comments. Thirteen is a feral number, but just thirteen was not a terrible number for the European Investment Bank. This bank does not arouse negative emotions and is therefore to be congratulated. I think it is important to say, first of all, that the measure of the success of the bank you are leading will be the real impact on the economic development of the countries of the European Union, as well as the promotion of joint investment in the countries that have recently signed association agreements with us. I am thinking, for example, of the joint investments of Romania and Moldova and Polish and Ukraine. You must find a centre of gravity between transparency, sharing information about what you are doing and the interests of the bank. I wish you good luck and congratulations.

name: David CASA
text: Rapporteur ta' opinjoni tal-Kumitat gťall-Impjiegi u l-Affarijiet Soèjali – Grazzi Sinjura President. Ippermettili nibda dan l-intervent billi nfaťťar lill-kollegi tiegťi fil-Kumitat gťall-Affarijiet Ekonomièi talli addottaw-erti sużťeri essenzjali li tressqu fil-Kumitat gťall-Affarijiet tax-Xogťol. Allura, fl-opinjoni tiegťi dan huwa ta' żid fl-opinjoni final. Ir-rapport annwali urina li fl-2013 il-Bank Ewropew gťall-Investiment, ikkonèerna biss fuq temi li jikkonèernaw l-impjiegi u l-affarijiet soèjali. Id-EUR 9.1 miljun li ntefqu fi promozzjoni ta' taťrig fis-snajja u f'opportunitajiet ta' xogťol gťaż-żgżażagż huma żieda ta' 50 % tal-infiq oriżinali ppjanat. U allura meta wieťed jikkunsidra l-volum kbir ta' qgťad fil-klassi żagťżugťa madwar l-Ewropa wieťed xorta jista' jargumenta li dan gťadu mhux biżżejjed. Iżda min-naťa l-oťra, meta wieťed jikkunsidra l-prożetti li jew jiffokaw fuq finanzjament micro u fuq is-support tal-SME's, jidher- Sur President, nemmen li l-EIB gťamel xogťol siewi immens, ma xorta nibqa' nenfasizza li t-tibdil fil-klima u l-indipendenza fl-energija gťandhom bżonn attenzjoni partikolari u dejjiema.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I think we can all agree that, following the economic crisis in Europe, the Bank has become an essential tool to restoring growth in Europe. It helps us reach sustainable growth, improve our economy and make it more competitive, more crisis-resilient, knowledge-driven, and of course it is a tool for improving infrastructure in Europe. First, the capital increase and now, in the future, through the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), these instruments have enhanced the Bank’s role in ensuring investments in Europe. The EIB lending, coupled with structural reforms and fiscal consolidation in Member States, will be an essential tool for restoring growth in Europe. The Bank will see its role and its responsibility increase in the near future through the entry into force of the EFSI. We on the Parliament side want to see the EFSI become a success and are ready to play our role in that sense, but for the Fund to reach its goals, the EIB would definitely need additional human resources in order not to affect the existing operations of the Bank. Nevertheless, I must also draw attention to the fact that the current distribution of EIB lending still indicates important discrepancies between Member States. I agree that the best and economically most viable projects have to be supported but, on the other hand, I think the EIB should also focus on investments, especially as regards infrastructure, in areas and regions that lag behind from this point of view. Another point which I would like to raise is the external mandate of the EIB. Taking into account the recent developments in the Eastern Neighbourhood, I think countries in this region should benefit from extra lending within the current mandate of the Bank, which is of course of geo-strategic importance for the Union. That is why I support the activation of the additional EUR 3 billion under the EU Guarantee, following the mid-term review in 2016. Thank you for your attention and your cooperation. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – I think, and I think, that I am not alone in the fact that the bank is in the right place in terms of focus on the project set for the eradication of youth unemployment. However, Mr Member mentioned that there are very, very large geographical differences. Typically, what does this mean (already in use)? Do richer or poorer countries benefit from the Youth Guarantee?

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: blue-card answer. – The interpretation was hard to understand but, if I got the question right, on youth unemployment, of course it is up to the Bank to decide in which projects they invest. I think they should invest in the economically most viable projects.  My thought was also that, in order to fulfil the mission of the Bank and reduce discrepancies in Europe, including for social cohesion, the Bank should maybe consider regions in which infrastructure is not yet up to the level of other countries and possibly also social indicators like employment, youth unemployment, and therefore, possibly, increased investment in regions which lag behind in those indicators.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D- Madam President, Mr President Hoyer, ladies and gentlemen, I would first like, on behalf of the group, to thank our colleague Ernest Urtasun for the work done and to welcome the good momentum that has existed between the various shadow rapporteurs.  The report stresses, as you have seen, the need to change the European Investment Bank. While we can welcome a series of elements in the work and operation of the EIB, we also know that with the Juncker plan, the institution will occupy an even more important place in the European economy in the coming months. I therefore think that it is really necessary to discuss its role and how it should exercise it.  That is why the text calls , if I may mention a few things - to put priority on sustainable investments and those that are fully involved in reducing greenhouse gas emissions. I think we are three-way winners: we are preserving the planet while reducing our energy bill, and that is obviously a good thing for jobs. Public institutions must lead by example and the way forward. I therefore hope that the EIB will be able to support all the public-private projects that will be tabled in this framework.  The second priority for our group is, of course, the links between the EIB and certain intermediaries that are based in tax havens. We know that the EIB does not invest directly in products, that it relies on financial intermediaries. We do not have a problem with that, but what is not acceptable to our group is obviously that these intermediaries are based in tax havens. We therefore call on the EIB to do all it can to avoid such situations in the future. Finally, we know that the EIB has a huge investment capacity, especially since its recapitalisation in 2010 and 2012, but we also know that it is not using its full lending potential. Now is the time for the European economy to get back on track! We therefore hope that the EIB will mobilise this wool stocking even more to further support our European economies. It is still tens of billions of euros that could be available very quickly for the European economy and this seems to us to be more effective than a possible miracle leverage, even if we all join Mr Hoyer in hoping that this scheme works at its best.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In this year's EIB report, the European Parliament has focused on several important areas. Firstly, it was underlined that the strengthening of EIB financial instruments cannot replace national economic policies or structural reforms in the Member States. Secondly, the report draws attention to the EFSI proposal and stresses that the process of managing and monitoring the Fund, as well as the selection procedure and criteria used to identify projects suitable for inclusion in the list, should be as transparent and objective as possible. What makes me particularly happy? It was underlined that small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of the European economy and should be the main objective of investment. The report calls on the EIB to thoroughly examine what measures have been taken with regard to intermediary strategies to ensure better effective access to finance for SMEs. It was also underlined that there is still a lot of room for manoeuvre with regard to improving eib transparency.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – With the report on the Annual Report of the European Investment Bank, the European Parliament places emphasis on where it should be, namely investment, SMEs, sustainable energy policy and climate policy. After all, we all know that the financial and economic crisis that has plagued our continent for years is still not consumed. We can only move forward if we find a good balance between sustainable growth, strengthening competitiveness and attracting additional financial investment. The European Investment Bank is, of course, of strategic importance as the largest public investor in the European economy. We therefore believe that it is crucial that the EIB's investment policy is in line with this European growth strategy. The ecosystem of which the EIB is a part is subject to constant change and innovation. The question is therefore whether the EIB and the EIF are able to adapt to that changing world by becoming less bureaucratic, by simplifying and adapting barriers and procedures, and perhaps by daring to take more risks to achieve additional growth. This requires the EIB to be flexible so that it can truly respond to the needs of the market, and that it has sufficient skills and competences to select projects with a lead time that is acceptable, including to the market, so that companies do not miss opportunities to invest and stay active here in Europe. In our view, the report has a number of very strong aspects: the focus on SMEs, the emphasis on transparency, accountability and the use of financial intermediaries. The emphasis on climate and sustainable energy policy also seem to be a good point for us. But the real big test case has yet to come with the Juncker Plan, the EFSI, in which the EIB and the EIF will play a very important role and where it will also be necessary to mobilise genuine private investment. It won't just come from the public side. Private investors will also have to join in to encourage basic infrastructure in Europe, innovative companies and research and development. Our group supports the EIB and the EIF in this, and we will continue to follow them closely to make their function less bureaucratic and more economically oriented.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, the Urtasun report makes good points and suggestions, my group has contributed to its co-formation and we will therefore support it. Mr Hoyer, Mr Mimica, the Urtasun report is an opportunity to present your plans and your report to us. You seemed very satisfied with yourselves, but the figures say more needs to be done, investment in Europe is 15% lower than it was in 2009. Unemployment has risen, poverty has risen, youth unemployment has risen too much. Youth unemployment has risen enormously. There are countries where the reduction in investment, such as in my country Greece, is multiple, 50% of the disinvestment has risen in recent years. So it is necessary, instead of rest, to do more and to give more money for public intervention that will boost investment, and private capital, and we need to change the criteria so as to strengthen regions and countries such as Greece that are suffering from higher unemployment and greater disinvestment and, of course, more needs to be done for young people as well.  Finally, it is not enough to say that we want transparency, you must stop using and working with countries that work through tax havens and adopt tax fraud practices. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Lara COMI
text: Blue card question. I have listened carefully, so from Italy and Greece we are quite close. But you do not believe that the problem is often the Member States because the money is there as, as Italy in seven years, we have lost EUR 15 billion for investments that have not been requested and lost. So it is true that more needs to be done, but perhaps we must start from the Member States that are asking for them and investing them in the right way: what do you think?

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: GUE/NGL), "blue card" answer. I agree with you. And the money must be more, and the criteria must be more rigorous and transparent, and not only banking but also social indicators, and, of course, the Member States must, under the responsibility of their governments, not just absorb the money but make use of it, because some do not even absorb it and others absorb it without adding to growth.

name: Bas EICKHOUT
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I know that my colleague’s report is not about Mr Juncker’s investment plan, but I would like to touch on one issue which is really important for Parliament: it is about the additionality of new projects of the Juncker investment plan. To our great surprise, we saw the press release of last week, indeed of 22 April. If you look at the four projects, is this now really additionality? Is this really ‘no more business as usual’? Is this really the innovative Europe that the Juncker investment plan should be working on?  You admitted yourselves that these projects would have got the money anyhow and that these projects were not indeed new. We are talking about the enlargement of an airport in Croatia and about the green economy, but still the Commission is saying these are examples of the Juncker investment plan. Well, this stresses the need for Parliament to be far more clear on additionality in the negotiations because, otherwise, it is just business as usual.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Madam President, Mr Hoyer, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has Let me briefly highlight once again the economic policy guidelines that characterise the 2013 annual report and the image of the European Investment Bank, which the rapporteur has also highlighted very well. These are the 37% increase in lending to EUR 75.1 billion after the capital increase, the 18% decline in public and private investment compared to 2007 levels, and the dramatic 35% drop in lending to small and medium-sized enterprises in the period 2008 to 2013. , that the allocation of funds, the financial instruments provided by the EIB, are, of course, no substitute for national economic policies, structural reforms and for the budgetary consolidation of the Member States. Unfortunately, this does not work to the extent that we would like it to be. We know that only 10% of the country-specific recommendations are implemented, and that will lead us to the fact that, despite the EFSI, which is the central issue we are talking about today, we are unlikely to be able to achieve the growth we want.

name: Tom VANDENKENDELAERE
text: – When an economy shows tentative signs of recovery after a long recession, one of the biggest challenges is building and, above all, building confidence. That's why the emphasis on smart investing is so important. Smart means with a definite goal, focused and productive. But smart also means that these investments cannot always stand on their own. On the contrary, smart investments are embedded in a well-thought-out multi-track policy. The European Investment Plan is an inseparable part of this multi-track policy and the European Investment Bank plays a crucial role in this, through its immense expertise. I therefore welcome the EIB's recent proactive approval of a first set of projects that would be eligible for the EFSI guarantee. A rapid start-up of this investment offensive is essential to ensure its success. In particular, I look forward to the EUR 5 billion earmarked in the investment plan for SME and mid-cap financing. These companies are the economic DNA of Europe. Unfortunately, many companies still face financing difficulties. 66% of the young companies that applied for bank credit in my country, Belgium, in 2014 got the lid on all or part of the nose. The EIB's efforts through, among other things, the European Progress Microfinance Facility are commendable, but I share the view from the report that the EIB may continue to increase its lending capacity for SMEs and innovative start-ups. Like the 'Skills and Jobs - Investing in Youth' initiative, this shows a much-needed confidence in young people.

name: Elisa FERREIRA
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Hoyer, the European Fund for Strategic Investments, EFSI in English, or the Juncker Fund, is a positive effort to relaunch investment in Europe, as the Socialist group has demanded. But it is important to make it clear that if Parliament accepts, as expected, that the European budget gives a guarantee of EUR 16 billion to EFSI, this Parliament, we will want to have a very serious say in both governance and the definition of investment policies. We will not give up that right. I must regret in the meantime that, in the week when Parliament and the Council were starting negotiations on EFSI, the EIB announced the first EUR 300 million in project funding, using the EFSI seal in advance. Are we negotiating something that already exists? Of course, the EIB can take the risk of these projects, but my perplexity increases with the announcement made by the President of the EIB that the projects now approved will go ahead anyway, even if the EFSI guarantee is not approved. But if these are projects for which the EIB can take the risk alone, why spend efsi support on them? So I ask, what guarantee does this Parliament have that EFSI will meet and implement according to the strategic objectives we are setting? Will you fulfill your mission of additionality? Or will you use EFSI just to enhance your ability to maintain the maximum triple A rating as it has been doing so far? The EIB, it is important to recognise it, is a key partner for strengthening investment, particularly during the crisis. However, it fell far short of what could be done, without any clear anti-cyclical role against the brutal fall in investment in Europe, particularly in the most fragile countries. And a final note so that 2013 is not compared with 2012. The important thing is to compare 2007 with 2012 and there is a brutal fall in investment.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The report on the European Investment Bank does not raise the crucial questions. The report on the European Investment Bank deplores an investment gap in the euro area. But he doesn't ask: Why do we have this gap? He does not ask: Why is this gap so unevenly distributed? Why do we find, for example, that there is no problem with investment in Germany, while there is a large investment gap in the southern European countries? He does not ask: why do we not have a demand for European products? It does not ask the question: why is the competitiveness of individual European states so low that their products are not in demand? It does not raise the question of the single currency, which prevents states that cannot be competitive under the current conditions, under the single exchange rate. The report on the European Investment Bank does not cover the causes of the crisis. In a blind faith in the euro, he closes his eyes to the realities. That is the cardinal error of European economic policy today. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Lucke, thank you very much for accepting the card. You said that Germany has no investment problems. I wonder, what is the situation of a country with a current account surplus of 7%? Is it oversa savings?  How can you say here that Germany does not have an investment problem when the country's own potential growth is very limited and excess savings is overwhelming, complicating the current account management of the rest of the countries, of the Southern countries?

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. – Sorry, the problem in Europe is not that too much is being saved, but that too much debt is being made. Germany has a current account surplus, as you have rightly pointed out, because German products are competitive. Germany shows that demand is by no means something that must be generated by government programmes, Juncker packages and similar things, but that demand can come from exports. The question arises: why can't the other European states export to the same extent? Why are they not so competitive? Mr President, you must answer these questions.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to start by welcoming the EUR 9.3 billion spent by the EIB to promote skills training and employment opportunities for young people and the launch of your Skills and Jobs: Investing in Youth initiative. It is certainly a step in the right direction. While it is positive to hear Mr Hoyer say that the EIB has exceeded its targets of an additional EUR 180 billion investment, youth unemployment still remains unacceptably high and we have to redouble our efforts. In the context of SMEs, we in ALDE believe they should be the main target for investment. However, I am pleased to see that my suggestion on midcaps is part of the report. Your focus on midcaps, through your Midcap Initiative and Growth Finance Initiative, is important, as many SMEs of course want to grow to be midcaps. But I also want to mention one particular EIB instrument, and that is the Microfinance Facility. Recently, I took the opportunity to visit the microfinance offices in Dublin, in Ireland, and I was really pleased to see that Microfinance Ireland had already supported 1 000 jobs in its second year in operation, and they have targeted a further 1 000 jobs by the end of this year. Over 430 microenterprises with fewer than ten employees have benefited from loans, and what is really important is that these enterprises were unable to secure funding elsewhere. So that clearly shows the added value of the Microfinance Facility. One other positive aspect was that 75% of the investment was within the regions. Finally, I would like to say that my suggestion on supporting the virtual economy is part of this report and hopefully the EIB will take it into consideration.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, international development finance institutions are under increasing pressure for their transparency and accountability. I am extremely concerned and dismayed that the Bank's new transparency policy does not even seem to meet legal requirements for transparency. I would therefore like to ask the Director-General and the Commissioner the following question: 'Do you intend to agree to a reform of transparency policy?'  The European Ombudsman, for example, has paid serious attention to this issue. It is truly incredible that the Bank could now undermine the transparency of its operations. This would be done in such a way that, under the new transparency policy, new confidentiality provisions can be applied to internal documents. I believe that, at some point, we will also have to look at these issues in a court that will decide once and for all what the EU's transparency requirements are.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for always being open and open to dialogue and for insisting on highlighting certain issues relating to the EIB's work.  I am thinking, for example, of the resounding failure of the Castor project financed through the Project Bond Initiative or of all the scandals related to the construction of the Mestre through. In this text we strongly demand that the EIB should not further finance this project, even though the words of Vice-President Scannapieco last week are not very reassuring. He has confirmed that by the summer he would like to leave with project bonds for the Mestre passer-by, but I hope that the voice of this Parliament will not go unheeded. The EIB should once again prioritise credit support for SMEs operating in Europe, which is why I am also very sceptical about external mandate activities.  One final point concerns the EIB's new policy of transparency.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the economic crisis in Europe is serious and requires an ambitious response. Since 2007, public investment has fallen by more than 18%, which has a very negative impact on the economic dynamism of the EU countries. While the EIB's financing activities are to be welcomed by 37%, several problems remain. First, the report proposes that priority be given to projects with European added value. However, you are aware that many investments do not necessarily have a European dimension. This priority criterion therefore risks making it more difficult for many SMEs, PMIs and local authorities to access EIB financing. In addition, at a time when French and European companies are facing increasing difficulties in order to receive financing, the EIB has granted EUR 8 billion in loans to projects domiciled outside the European Union in 2013. The EIB must put in place the European priority in the provision of financial instruments.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking mr The European Investment Bank plays a key role in financing Europe's economic development. This particular position follows from the fact that the bank supports investment projects which would not be financed by commercial banks due to increased market risk, large-scale measures involved or a long investment horizon. At the same time, the bank meets all prudential and capital requirements and is thus an institution with the highest level of credibility and trust. By strengthening its capital base in 2013, the EIB has significantly increased its investment commitment. Loans increased by €15 billion. Funding for European projects and for small and medium-sized enterprises grew particularly rapidly. It should be emphasised that eib loans have acted countercyclically, supporting European economies in a difficult downturn. Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking mr I would like to pay tribute to you for these actions.  Against the background of these undoubted achievements, I consider mr Urtasuna's report to be overly critical and one-sided. Firstly, it puts many additional tasks before the bank which do not have much to do with the bank's formal mandate. An example is the demand that the bank take on additional obligations related to the monitoring of the tax liability of the bank's customers. Secondly, too little is written in the report on the bank's statutory tasks, including in particular the need to finance the development of innovative projects and support for research and development. Only one short paragraph has been devoted to this topic. I believe that the bank should focus on the activities that have the greatest development potential.

name: Anneliese DODDS
text: – Madam President, may I respond directly to Mr Rosati. The Bank is of course required to employ its funds as rationally as possible in the interest of the European Union. It is in all of our interests, for example, that the fiscal capacity of Member States is preserved, and that the EU’s aid policy is not undermined by tax leaking away from developing countries. It is that point which motivates many of the requests that have been made of the Bank.  The Bank did, in 2009, become a pioneer when it adopted a policy against non-cooperative jurisdictions, but as we all know, that policy has lost many of its teeth as those jurisdictions have creatively complied with the letter of OECD requirements, rather than complying with their spirit. So the time really has come for the Bank to adopt an up-to-date responsible taxation policy and that would involve three measures during the exercise of the Bank’s due diligence, particularly for intermediaries which, as my colleague Hugues Bayet said, are a particular problem.  Firstly, we need the Bank to make use of the measures contained within the Anti-Money-Laundering Directive and particularly to access the new registers of beneficial ownership of companies. Secondly, it must require its partners and clients to publish their accounts in detail, the so-called country-by-country reporting, and finally, rather than using restricted information from the Global Forum on Transparency, it must use the broader range of criteria to assess tax compliance and openness such as that contained within the Financial Secrecy Index.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, since the European Investment Bank is not a commercial bank, it must continue to play a key role in financing long-term investments in infrastructure, energy, research, transport and innovation. Austerity has filled the European Union with armies of unemployed people and the European Investment Bank is now being called upon to move as a purely development bank to finance investments in member states with a high level of unemployment, such as impoverished Greece, with the aim of social benefit and the creation of new jobs. The EIB's initiative to issue bonds for the financing of sustainable infrastructure projects and the decision of the European Central Bank to buy EIB bonds are moving in the right direction. Given that small and medium-sized enterprises have created 85% of the new jobs in Europe, the EIB must drastically increase the financing of medium-sized enterprises. Finally, the financing of initiatives to reduce youth unemployment must be an important area of action for the EIB.

name: Michał MARUSIK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! The good work and performance of the European Investment Bank does not necessarily have to be a cause for our joy, because we must remember that the activity of such a bank is only an instrument, a tool for market intervention. When we see companies that have been established and are growing with the support of the Investment Bank, we are pleased. However, the absorbency of the European market has not changed at all, which means that somewhere else in the market, a huge number of companies without this support had to collapse. We just don't notice that. After all, the preferences for some participants in the struggle are at the same time discrimination against all other participants in these struggles. And this support only increases the lending and burdens the real economy, necessitating loan repayments, which raises prices and rather translates into impoverishment of societies, because for the same money we will be able to buy less.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Madam President, I welcome this report and I also welcome to the Chamber President Hoyer and his team from the EIB.  It is crucially important, as countries move from being a programme country back into the international lending market having completed structural reform and having got their deficits down, that they obtain the support of the European Investment Bank. I was really delighted to hear from the Commission today that there is an increase in lending to programme countries from 2013-2014 in the order of 27 %. In the case of Ireland, which has gone through an enormous shock, in 2010 the EIB lending to Ireland was EUR 210 million; last year, 2014, it was EUR 850 million. Here is an example showing that we can invest more and lend more to countries who have improved their own position as a result of structural reform and as a result of getting an appalling deficit down. That is where measures to address the gap in investment need to be encouraged and supported – especially in the case of former programme countries, or those countries currently in the midst of a programme. Finally, can I make this point: the European Investment Bank needs to be given, in my view, a much more structured dialogue in this House, especially through the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON). While our engagement here is very useful, I do think on a quarterly basis, at the very least, that the EIB – and I know they welcome this and would encourage this – should be before this House to ensure that these issues are gone through in a more detailed way.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: blue-card question. – Mr Hayes talks about filling a hole. I have a question for Mr Hayes: would it not be easier to fill that hole that was created by institutions like the ECB when they forced us to save non-systemic banks and left us with odious debt to the tune of tens of billions of euros? Would it not be better to give us back the money that was robbed of our country, than to have us going begging for a pittance in return?

name: Brian HAYES
text: blue-card answer. – Unfortunately the Member opposite does not really understand the problems that Ireland has gone through. The problems that Ireland unfortunately went through were as a result of an appalling decision taken by the Irish Government in terms of a bank guarantee. That was not a decision imposed on the Irish people but unfortunately the government of the day took that decision. We have been living with the consequences of that ever since. That is why it is crucial that we get enhanced lending opportunities from the European Investment Bank – which we have – and we have shown, in that way, that we can improve our prospects by making those decisions work for Ireland.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the ESE President and the Commission for the work of the rapporteur, Ernest Urtasun, and the other shadow rapporteurs, including Our Colleague Bayet, for the Socialist Group, in preparing this document, this report, which I believe clearly addresses the work of the European Investment Bank. In any case, I would like to echo the concern about the extraordinarily conservative credit policy that the European Investment Bank has carried in recent years. I believe that the European Investment Bank , on many occasions – has behaved more like a commercial bank than as a genuine development bank; which has financed projects where private funding was available and under the objective of maximise triple A, when the Bank's real objective should be to maximise the impact on growth in the Union. And this concern is important when we have placed EFSI in the framework of the European Investment Bank's action. If EFSI is going to be, or we're going to get it to be, the real development bank that the EI isn't, welcome! May the spirit of EFSI reach, implore, the whole European Investment Bank.  But some of us are afraid, we are afraid that the conservative culture of the ELYD will end up capturing efSI's performance and that the additionality that my colleague Elisa Ferreira was talking about earlier, by virtue of the advancement that has been announced, because it ends, anyway, in little more than in guaranteeing you not triple A but, maybe, maybe , quadruple A if possible.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I believe that the EIB must rethink its role at a time when neoliberal ideology is at an end and do much more to support the abolition of the economic divide of Europe that we are facing. It is no coincidence that countries opening up their markets during the period of neoliberal ideology have not produced independent industrial structures. This applies primarily to the east of Europe, but also to the south of Europe. This trend must be reversed if we want to build a Europe of equal opportunities. This requires verification of the criteria for providing financial support and the structures governing the bank. The criteria for allocating funds must take into account the need to build businesses with country-specific decision-making centres and not support the creation of entire regions managed externally by corporations. In order to develop together, Europe must also develop sustainably in all Member States in this respect. The EIB must take this into account.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: NI). Madam President, the anti-labour arrangements for wages, pensions, taxes, labour rights, for the surpluses paid by the people, create the friendly investment environment of a development that is in the foot of popular misery. These are the investment priorities of the European Investment Bank - they have nothing to do with popular needs, but only with the concentration of EU capital at their expense, in priority sectors for its competition with other powers. This is how the Juncker investment package works. These are investments for the capital, with its losses covered and its profits guaranteed. Small and medium-sized enterprises are christened the big monopolies with three thousand workers to qualify for funding, there are many examples that the European Investment Bank is an investment tool of the unpopular European Union that is not changing. In this direction are moving the new unpopular measures announced these days and the new Greek co-government, measures to finance the capital and not the popular needs, measures to continue and intensity the memorandums in Greece.

name: Thomas MANN
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Member States in difficult economic conditions are supported effectively and thoughtfully by the EIB. Unlike Mr Lucke – who has already left the Chamber – I note that, Yes, Mr Hoyer, you are promoting growth and competitiveness, you are promoting investment in full compliance with the Europe 2020 strategy. The €9 billion , 50% more than originally planned, was particularly successful for the European Youth Initiative. Clearly, we do not want to leave people alone in the event of unemployment or lack of prospects. The Skills and Employment Programme - Investment in Youth - will be supported. Vocational education and training, mobility for students to facilitate integration into the labour market. The EIB is particularly supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, the backbone of our common European economy. EUR 22 billion for 230 000 SMEs is essential. There is a Europe-wide decline in investment, but we must ensure that these investments can be made. I see a need for improvement in the allocation of funds. Application and administration should be simplified. You will certainly play your part in this. And more flexibility is needed. But one thing is also clear: even increased European funding cannot replace measures in the Member States, both active economic policies and necessary structural reforms. Mr Hoyer, thank you very much. Keep going!

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for The European Investment Bank is to divert funds into the so-called Juncker Plan. This House is today discussing how we can boost the European economy, particularly with state and semi-public funds. You completely forget that we are constantly increasing the state quota in Europe. We are talking about managed investment. We are talking about divisions into good and bad investments, which you presume here. They believe they know what investments are good in Europe. We are quite used to this from the left of Parliament, and I am not at all surprised by that. But if so-called conservatives, let alone so-called liberals, explain to us what the state needs to invest in, then that is only a clear sign that the EIB is part of a budgetist effort in Europe and that this House is full of budgetists. And I say to you: for all the talk of investment, this is ultimately the downfall of the European economy.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: Madam President, the debate on the European Investment Bank plunges us into the heart of the political and economic schizophrenia of the European Union. On the one hand, we deplore, rightly so, in the Bank's annual report, a collapse of private and public investment of around 27% since 2009, on the other hand, the European institutions continue to advocate, report after report, a policy of austerity in the name of the euro - the sacred cow of Brussels - a policy which we know perfectly well that it kills investment and hinders the financing of small and medium-sized enterprises.  The European Investment Bank, in order to be effective, must act within a completely re-founded economic framework where the European Union and its policies no longer have a place. There will be no sustainable investment if the European Union persists in a policy that has deindustrialized the continent and demoralized entrepreneurs. Moreover, the EIB's investment allocation system seems to us to be very inadequate, as it leaves almost no room for manoeuvre for the Member States, which are the most able to determine the relevance of the projects. The Juncker plan, for example, will retain only the most profitable projects for the benefit of a few large metropolises and conurbations, and largely at the expense of rurality and medium-sized cities.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, considering the significant decline in public and private investment that has taken place in recent years, which severely affected European small and medium-sized enterprises, I welcome the fact that the report was adopted in the Committee by a vast majority. It is indeed necessary to strike a new balance between better evaluation and the best possible investment, and to steer the economy towards a path of sustainable growth and a job-rich recovery. The report puts forward a set of recommendations on the operational methodology of the European Investment Bank in terms of how the EIB should be ready to play its role under the investment package and of how investment needs to more specifically target the backbone of the European economy, namely small and medium-sized enterprises. The investment projects of the EIB need to be increasingly aimed towards sustainable energy and climate change, as well as infrastructural investments which are important for jobs and growth.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, expectations are high for the Juncker Fund, expectations are high for the European Investment Bank, especially when we talk about medium and small businesses and when we talk about youth employment.  Mr. President of the EIB, I would like to address you as rapporteur of this Parliament for the Adriatic and Ionian Strategy of the European Union and announce our safe need for the European Investment Bank to participate in important projects that will be implemented in the future in the Balkans, both in the Member States and in those that are candidate countries. Here I think first of all about the Adriatic-Ionian Corridor, which includes the highway from Trieste to Athens and which includes gas pipelines and other infrastructure-important projects for that part of Europe.  I also want to talk specifically about energy policy, within which we have the possibility of decarbonisation, diversification of the Energy Policy of the European Union in the Balkans and we have the possibility of energy independence, especially in hydropower potentials.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Madam President, I congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Urtasun, on his good work and for his efforts to include in his report the concerns of the united left, such as the importance of employment or the reporting of cases such as Castor's. We are concerned that speculative initiatives, such as this project, will now become widespread with the Juncker Plan, thereby undermining public coffers and the sustainability of the economy. The intermediation of private investment, the increasing financialisation of the European economy, is not a substitute for real support for public investment and social cohesion. Improving productivity and diversifying production, especially in those economies with higher unemployment rates, requires much greater planning and budgetary allocation than the European institutions allow Member States. Only then will the EI be able to support with its funds and experience a genuine development strategy, rather than patching — and sometimes new broken ones — an increasingly fragmented and divided European economy.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, I want to appreciate the work of the rapporteur, although I was not in the European Parliament in 2013. However, I can analyse the effects of what the EIB has done privately, because they come from SMEs. We must not delude ourselves, there were no excellent effects. It is not always the indicators by which a bank is analysed that have corresponding effects in private.  I am concerned about the principle of the redistribution of the Investment Fund. How funds will be redistributed will have a positive or negative influence on both the reduction of regional disparities, the development of SMEs and the social dimension. I do not believe in the technical procedure announced by President Junker - selection on the basis of only technical criteria by six experts. Maybe you can give us details, Mr. President, how you'll do it.  I believe that the EIB needs to show greater flexibility and greater risk-taking in relation to SMEs. If not, supporting SMEs, reducing regional, social disparities will only be nice statements, and we cannot talk about economic and monetary union.  My final proposal is, however, to meet more often with the committees in the European Parliament.

name: Emmanouil GLEZOS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, as far as I know, the European Investment Bank in Greece has not really helped the thousands of businesses that have closed. With the economic crisis that has hit our country, the organisations that had to be helped by the European Investment Bank have not been helped. The problem lies in who helps whom: did the fund want to help or the workers? Here is the big, huge difference from which the effort of both the European Union and the European Investment Bank is judged.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the economic and financial crisis with induced and persistent austerity has for years compromised European economic growth by spoiling macro and micro-economic fundamentals and worsening social conditions.  In this geo-economic landscape, the EIB is now called upon to act as an essential catalyst for healthy and long-term public and private investment with the desired positive effects on lending conditions. However, almost half of the Member States will not achieve national targets on education, reducing greenhouse gas emissions and reducing unemployment and poverty. This implies an even greater commitment to strengthening the EIB's financial instruments, which are therefore made in terms of essential commitment and not optional alternatives.  The 2013 report is therefore a good one, but my particular attention goes to SMEs, the real backbone of the European economy and the main investment target. I can only regret their current state of financial stress and urge the EIB, as the real engine of European entrepreneurship, to propose an intervention plan to ensure that SMEs throughout Europe have the right economic balance for stable and lasting use of EIB funding.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank you for this interesting debate here today. The current economic and financial situation requires decisive policy action, and we believe that the European Investment Bank’s activities are a crucial component of the EU’s efforts to bring back sustainable growth and employment to Europe, especially with the EIB and the Commission partnering in the challenging delivery of the investment plan for Europe. I am confident that Parliament’s assessment of the EIB’s activities in the year ahead will be as supportive as its opinion on the 2013 Annual Report, and I look forward to continuing our close and successful cooperation between the Commission and the Bank.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: President of the European Investment Bank. – Madam President, thank you very much for this interesting debate. It would take a lot of courage and endurance on your side if, in view of the diversity and variety of the questions and comments raised, I were to go into each and every detail, but I promise that I will come back to each and every one of you on the questions you have raised. Let me concentrate on a few points. Let me begin with the notion that maybe we are a little bit too satisfied with what we have done and that we might even be complacent. We are satisfied but we are definitely not complacent because, in view of the challenges in Europe, the situation of the labour markets and the lack of growth, in view of the investment gap and the innovation gap, there is no reason for complacency in the European Union for anybody and certainly not for the EIB.  On the other hand, in 2012 the EIB turned anti—cyclical. Until then it was clear that, according to all decisions taken, the Bank would have to reduce lending volume after the huge positive impact it had had on the mastering of the first wave of the crisis, but then we had to go down again. This is the reason why I then turned to the European Council and said that we needed either capital increase or we would behave procyclically, out of necessity.  So the European Council, with your support, decided in favour of the capital increase and we delivered on that. That turned the Bank anti-cyclical and we are proud of that achievement. The analysis last year was clear. The investment gap has been there since 2007, but in addition – and this should not be overlooked – we have had an innovation gap and an education expenditure gap in Europe for almost 18 years. These together are leading to a dangerous reduction in the competitiveness of European industry in the globalising economy. Sometimes we should look a little more outside Europe to see what is happening in this world. We have been in crisis mode for seven years and we are now finding out that, during those seven years, others around the world have done their homework and have advanced considerably.  Therefore we need to address the questions of competitiveness and this is the basic idea of the Juncker Plan. The Juncker Plan certainly does not only mean The European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). It also means regulation, continuation of sound fiscal policies and cutting red tape. We addressed that issue in detail at the European Finance Ministers meeting last week in Riga.  On EFSI, there is the continuous question of additionality and I want to address it very clearly. EFSI, the shift of budgetary means from subsidies to guarantees, if you so decide – it is your decision – means that we will be able to address risk dimensions which until now the Bank would not have been able to address in that volume. It is not true that we do not do very risky things. We have, under ‘special activities’, a window of between EUR 4 and 5 billion per year for these activities and we do them. With the Juncker Plan we will be able to do business in this field of far more than EUR 20 billion per year.  So it is a qualitative and quantitative change and that is what is meant by additionality. Additionality does not mean that each individual project is necessarily higher in risk than the portfolio will be. The portfolio will certainly be considerably higher in that respect so there is no reason to believe that this is going to be business as usual.  The second point in this context is that we have to make sure that the huge investment and innovation gap in Europe is addressed by attracting private funds. Otherwise it is never going to work. We conducted a study last year to identify the differences between the targets set by the European Council, and discussed in this very Parliament, and the means provided, privately and in public budgets, in order to achieve these goals. These differences are so huge it would never be possible to level them out with public money.  So we need to crowd in private money. The EIB is the crowding-in bank and there are the huge volumes that we get from the capital markets every year and the quality stamp that we put on projects which then leads to confidence among private investors that it makes sense to invest in these projects as well. We have been addressing the differences in economic development in the Member States. Look at the per capita figures we had in recent years for the Bankʼs activities. Cyprus per capita showed EUR 306 per person for activities of the Bank in Cyprus. In Spain it was EUR 258. These are the strongest countries. In Germany it is well over EUR 100 and that is quite justified because the economic situation in Spain is one thing and in Germany it is another. So we have to address the differences and I believe that we are doing this. In conclusion, you can be sure that we will use the funds provided by the European Union and the Member States with care and diligence and that we will try to preserve our strong position in the market. Of course triple A is not a fetish; triple A is a business necessity in order to be able to crowd in huge amounts of private capital at reasonable rates.  We are trying to do this in an effective way and also in an efficient way because the EIB is the leanest bank of its size in the world. Not only are we by far the biggest one – two and a half times the size of the World Bank – but we are also the leanest one. If you compare the employment figures of the EIB and, let us say, the EBRD or the World Bank, it is dramatic. From that point of view, you can be sure that we are trying not only to be effective and have an impact on improving the situation in Europe, but we are also trying to be efficient.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President; Mr Hoyer, first of all I would like to thank you for the contributions made to the debate, especially the contributions of the shadow rapporteurs. Four very fast points, Mr. Hoyer. The first, about EFSI. I would like to stress an issue mentioned by my colleague, which is that we respect the procedures. We did not think it was right for the Bank to announce projects when we have not yet completed the trilogs and, therefore, it would be important for the institutional dynamics to keep up with the rhythms. Secondly, we are very concerned in this Parliament , I think many of my colleagues have mentioned this - the question of transparency. I have not been able to mention the Glencore case before, but it is an important case, even a case in which the European Ombudsman showed interest. The conclusions of the review of the transparency policy already know how they have come out. We would therefore like you to pay more attention to this issue. Thirdly, I would like to say that, in your two speeches, you have never mentioned the issue of projects bonds and the first two have not gone well.
