My Italian colleague also quoted the Passante di Mestre, the motorway, which I have not been able to refer to at the outset for lack of time, but I stress once again the question of the Castor project. I do not think that you can let the question of the Castor project end as the Spanish Government intends, by doing a dance out and making Spanish citizens pay that. The Bank must have a greater involvement in these types of projects which it finances and it seems to me – and we hope – that from this Parliament you can intervene so that this does not end like this. And finally, I would like to tell you that I think it would be a good exercise if, once Parliament's report was adopted, we could develop a dialogue to see how the recommendations we will adopt this morning can be implemented at the Bank. I think it would be nice if that was established as a tradition and, in any case, I thank you for your presence.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, April 30, 2015, at 12 p.m. Written statements (Article 162)

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. – The European Union is dealing with difficult economic conditions and rising unemployment, which has serious consequences for our society, especially for young people. Extraordinary times obviously require extraordinary measures and a consistent European response to overcome the crisis. As a bank of the European Union, the EIB must play a key role in financing investment in growth and jobs. It is to be welcomed that the EIB has always responded to the specific needs of the regions most affected by the crisis and, according to its report, intends to continue to do so. In many cases, this bank is the only financier capable to play this role to a considerable extent. I think it is positive that, as an EU bank, they have focused on a countercyclical role and have acted as a reliable partner in economically sensible investments, both inside and outside the European Union. In agreement with the rapporter, I believe that investments with their funding can make a real difference in people's lives, whether it is jobs for hundreds of thousands of small businesses making progress in infrastructure investments in the regions most affected by the crisis, or maintaining cutting-edge innovations to help Europe maintain its global competitiveness and supporting clean energy, so I will support the constructive proposals contained in the report in tomorrow's vote.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. I strongly support the establishment of the European Investment Bank's 2013 Annual Report because I believe it is very important to highlight the key role that the EIB has in promoting growth, through the financing of major investment projects carried out or being carried out in European eegions. And in the future, because of the strategic role it is called upon to play in financing the strategic investment plan promoted by the Juncker Commission, of which the EFSI Regulation, which is being adopted, is the key financial instrument.  The decision on the capital increase, taken in 2013, enabled the EIB to play a key countercyclical role during the crisis. It would therefore be appropriate for the Member States to put in place a new capital increase, so that growth, the creation of quality jobs can be revived and private investment should be encouraged to a greater extent than in the past. The EIB plays a key role in supporting SMEs, especially in disadvantaged regions where unemployment and youth unemployment in particular have reached socially unsustainable figures. I therefore hope that it will give priority to investments in sectors that can have clear and positive external effects for society as a whole.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Today's debate is a very good opportunity to appreciate the activities of the European Investment Bank in recent years marked by the economic and financial crisis. It has played a significant role in mitigating the economic and social impact caused by the economic downturn. Despite the difficult situation of the credibility and stability of the markets, the European Investment Bank, as one of the few, continued to have a policy of borrowing money for economically and socially justified projects. As a non-commercial bank, the European Investment Bank plays a significant role as a catalyst for financial support for numerous private and public investments. We are therefore pleased to hear of the 37% increase in the EIB Group's financial performance and of the capital increase in 2013.  The European Union continues to face the challenges of the crisis. After a period of justified prudent fiscal and austerity policies, it is time to invest in growth and new jobs. Unfortunately, compared to 2007, investment in Europe has fallen by 18%. Today, all eyes are on the European Investment Bank, which will be one of the main contractors of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. Given the positive activity of the bank, we can hope that the funds from the Fund will be transferred to projects that will have a real impact on the European economy and generate long-term positive results.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. – Whereas Nearly two thirds of European Investment Bank lending to Africa, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries in the past ten years has been geared towards private sector operations and whereas the EIB Cotonou Investment Facility uses official development assistance to back this private sectors, it is crucial that achieving development objectives – mainly poverty reduction – are considered the ultimate goal of those investments. Therefore, ex-ante impact analysis on poverty and on debt sustainability must be conducted and made public before the implementation of the projects so ODA money is only use when clear development additionality is proven. In addition, the EIB must ensure that companies that receive EIB support do not participate in tax evasion via offshore centres and tax havens, undermining the domestic resource mobilisation capacities – essential for developing welfare – of developing countries.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: in writing. – Against the background of good WORK by the EIB in 2013, I would like to stress the need for greater involvement by the EIB, the European Commission and the Member States to expand the use of financial instruments to finance economic and social objectives in the Member States. It is very important to support the expansion of financing scombining non-refundable European funds with repayable funds and those that are constituted in the form of initial capital or capital increase. It is regrettable that many Member States did not wish to participate with part of the European Cohesion Funds allocated to them in the new EIB facility which ensures the multiplication of the financing potential of these European funds through financial instruments.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on the oral issue at the Commission on the 2015 World Expo in Milan: Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life, by Paolo De Castro, on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (O-000016/2015 - B8-0109/2015).

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, just tomorrow in Milan the 2015 World's Fair officially opens, the theme of which is 'Feeding the planet, energy for life'. The same title as our resolution, which we are about to vote on today. The European Parliament is the first to give its opinion on the Expo, setting out the framework of the policies needed at European and global level to effectively address the challenge of food security. The initiative for this resolution was born in the Committee on Agriculture, following a series of hearings and reflections on this subject, but then expanded to the contribution of many colleagues from many committees who wanted to integrate our work in a fruitful and effective way.  Food security is an issue that must concern us all, and we cannot shirk this global challenge that questions our agricultural and environmental policy, research, policies for international trade and development. The growing demand for food is due both to a continuous increase in the world's population and to a change in eating habits in developing countries.  We also note the paradoxical coexistence of hunger in the world – not forgetting that too many people still live below the poverty line in Europe too – and unbalanced food regimes that cause obesity even in poverty; at the same time, huge quantities of food are wasted in Europe and throughout the world – the European Commission itself estimates that 89 million tonnes of food are wasted in Europe alone. I would remind you that this Parliament, during the last parliamentary term, has already spoken out strongly in a resolution against food waste and in favour of mandatory targets to reduce it.  There are many things that we are asking of the Council, the Commission and the States participating in the Expo with the aim of being able to make real contributions to the global challenge of food security from the Milan event. We call for an effort to encourage the search for innovative agronomic practices that improve yields while reducing the environmental impact. We are calling for more information for citizens, accompanied by education in balanced food regimes and consumption that prevent obesity and erase malnutrition.  We must set ambitious and binding targets to combat food waste at every level of the food chain, from the field to the table. We must increase transparency and fairness within the agri-food chain, so that it can become truly sustainable and able to guarantee food security.  At international level, we must do more as the European Union to promote sustainable agriculture in developing countries and to combat land-grabbing, that is, land grabbing, particularly in Africa, without any rules. The European Union will also participate in the Expo with its own pavilion, and a steering committee set up ad hoc and chaired by former Commissioner Franz Fischler has produced an interesting document on the role of research in global food security.  But today we are asking for something more, a more ambitious commitment. We need a strong and sustainable agricultural sector within the Union, we need a development policy that is attentive to world agriculture, we need to combat food waste and do more research and innovation, but above all, we want the European Union to be the protagonist and leader of a global food policy. The challenge of food security in the world questions the conscience of all of us, we cannot back down: the European Union can and must do more.  Expo 2015 is an extraordinary opportunity for the European Union to strengthen its commitment to a more sustainable future.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission welcomes the opportunity created by Expo 2015 for an open debate on the global challenges related to food waste, sustainable agriculture and the need to fight hunger and eradicate obesity. We wish to reiterate our commitment to implementing EU policies and legislation to support sustainable food systems in close cooperation with the stakeholders, Member States and the European Parliament. The common agricultural policy has a great potential to make a real contribution to feeding the forecast 9 billion people by 2050, while taking care of natural resources. The principles of sustainability and producing more from less are well embedded in the long-term objectives of the common agricultural policy. Concerning the point of the scarcity of natural resources in the 7th Environment Action Programme to 2020, the European Union is committed to protect, conserve and enhance the Union’s natural capital. EU environment policy, and in particular the EU biodiversity strategy to 2020, the EU soil thematic strategy and EU legislation for the protection of water, air and natural habitats and species, aim at protecting, conserving and enhancing those natural resources to secure the provision of sustainable and healthy food production in the European Union. In addition, sustainable food security is one of the major cross-cutting focus areas identified for research under the Horizon 2020 Work Programme to continue until 2017. The Commission is currently preparing an ambitious work programme and call for proposals on sustainable food security that aim to build more resilient and resource-efficient production and value chains. By promoting international collaboration, notably with China and Africa, Horizon 2020 research funding is expected to contribute to global food security. The European Innovation Partnership for Agricultural Productivity and Sustainability is supported by the common agricultural policy and aims at closing the gap between research and practice. Since 2012, the European Commission has worked actively to identify the best possible action to take at EU level to fight food waste without compromising on food safety. The Commission is committed to supporting the Member States and stakeholders in their efforts to reduce food waste by helping to lift any obstacles and by promoting the sharing of best practice and transfer of knowledge and experience. At Expo 2015, the Commission will organise a conference dedicated to food waste prevention, focusing in particular on the importance of an effective intersectoral cooperation. The Commission is committed to supporting the Member States and stakeholders in strengthening resource efficiency in the food chain to prevent and reduce food waste from farm to fork. The Commission is currently reflecting on the scope of the new, more ambitious circular economy package to be published by the end of this year, and will consider possible opportunities for action in the food sector as for all other sectors. Any initiative taken at pan-European level has to have genuine EU added value. We will only take action where this can facilitate and augment ongoing action in the Member States. While the promotion of healthy diets and lifestyles is a matter of national competence, the Commission’s strategy on nutrition, overweight and obesity-related health issues and related implementing tools provide a framework and support to coordinate actions in the European Union. It also promotes organic production with clear labelling rules, enabling customers to make an informed choice when making their purchases. I look forward to a debate on this important topic and I thank you.

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent report A few years ago, when a theme was sought for Expo 2015 in Milan, which starts tomorrow, it would hardly have been possible to prove a happier hand. Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life is indeed a very central challenge of our time. Providing people with adequate and healthy food and, at the same time, sustainable agriculture are one of the major fundamental challenges we have in our day. This requires several tools: a successful agricultural policy is needed. We in the European Union also serve as role models worldwide. We have had an agricultural policy for decades which has been based on maintaining family farms. We are very successful. Today, we are a Union that can provide food to its people, 500 million people. But we are also the largest exporter of food out into the world and thus also make a significant contribution to feeding the world. But we also need research and development. I am convinced that research and development must be stepped up, particularly in the field of agriculture, and that it can or must operate free of political guidelines. That is why my group will certainly not support the amendments on which we are also going to vote today, which are aimed at setting guidelines for science as to what it is allowed to do and what it cannot do. Then there is the issue of eating habits and the distribution of food. It is sad that we are living at a time when overeating is increasingly claiming more victims and, fortunately, people's malnutrition is decreasing and fewer and fewer victims are claiming, which is a great achievement of our time. It needs functioning supply chains. I think it is a great challenge to present these things at the Expo on behalf of the European Union. (The speaker agreed to raise a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – Congressman, you have also praised the choice of subject, and let me also praise our Italian colleagues, in particular Mr Castro, who is a big engine of this matter in this House. But in the same house, we also find that fair access to food is greatly hampered by the huge amount of tax that falls on food. In this House, we are also dealing with the fact that large corporations do not pay taxes. I ask you: do you agree that governments should properly collect corporate taxes and thus reduce the public burden on food?

name: Herbert DORFMANN
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I do not know what exactly you are referring to, but it goes without saying that we have a common agricultural policy in the European Union, which is also co-financed by taxpayers. We spend around EUR 55 billion a year to produce sustainable food within the framework of our common agricultural policy. I think that this expenditure is very justified. I believe that we have also demonstrated with the common agricultural policy that we are able to feed this continent and to guarantee food to the people of this continent, including through the common agricultural policy.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the European Year of Development, the same year in which the United Nations updates the Millennium Goals, the Expo opens tomorrow on the theme of 'Feeding the planet, energy for life', and we feel a strong responsibility here to contribute to the global food challenge that undersoes the geopolitical issues of our time. , not only for countries ravaged by wars and dictatorships, from where an unprecedented exodus is taking place, but also in our Europe, where 79 million people are below the poverty line.  Expo 2015 is therefore our way to affirm that food must be considered a human right as life, as well as health, as water. Europe is mobilising to ensure that in a world that is able to provide food to everyone, not everyone has food, and with these priorities we are fighting against waste, defending agricultural land, spreading healthy food education; with the principle of sustainability we will finally safeguard the very survival of the earth.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I have always been of the view that we should never leave the next generation in a position worse off than the one in which we ourselves now live. The challenge of feeding the world’s rapidly growing population is one of the biggest threats to the same. Statistics show that there will be a 60 % increase in the demand for food by 2050 as the population expands. How are we going to meet this increased demand, and how are we going to use the resources we have more efficiently?  Expo Milano promises to provide a forum where we can begin to tackle these key issues and this is of course welcome, but I would caution against raising expectations that cannot possibly be met. The resolution itself takes a very broad and ambitious approach to what is achievable at the Expo, urging the Commission to make commitments on development aid, climate change, healthy soil and land-grabbing.  Nevertheless, while I support the general direction of the resolution, I would have preferred a more focused, streamlined approach that gives a clear and unambiguous message and I congratulate the rapporteur on his work.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – European agriculture is a world leader. We produce high quality food and meet the strictest requirements in terms of food safety, environment and animal welfare. Due to a rapidly growing world population, the demand for food is increasing rapidly. Agricultural land and raw materials, on the other hand, are becoming scarcer. So we have to produce more with less. With our innovations and the entrepreneurship of our farmers and gardeners, we can meet this challenge. Laws and regulations should encourage this and not slow this down. Too often we see regulations that do not fit in with practice. A good example is the innovation of turning animal manure into a mineral concentrate that can be used as fertilizer. It is incomprehensible that the European Commission is holding back this sustainable innovation. At the Milan World's Fair, the world comes together. It is therefore a great opportunity to show the world what our farmers and gardeners are capable of.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Food for the planet, energy for life. With such a theme, the World's Fair in Milan raises high expectations when it comes to sustainability and food security. But this event is in danger of being hijacked by big companies like Coca Cola and McDonalds. These food giants benefit from overproduction and are more concerned about their own market position than about food distribution. The resolution does not mention that. In addition to sustainability, it focuses on increasing and intensifying food production. But that food production is already very, very high. We already deliver more food than is needed worldwide. The earth offers enough for everyone's needs. Yet a billion people go to bed hungry every day. One billion people! How is that possible? Where's all that food going? Well, we're throwing away some of that food. In part, we make biofuels out of that. But most of our food is given to animals in the livestock industry. 70% of our fields are used for the production of animal feed. And if we were to give that to people, we could easily feed an extra four billion people. We do not need an increase or intensification of food production. We need a transition to sustainable, fairly produced local food, and above all a transition from animal to plant food. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are on the eve of the opening of the Expo, but unfortunately the premises are not good.  We are aware of cases of mismanagement and corruption, public money squandered on what should be a showcase of excellence for Italy and for Europe as a whole. It has been said that the European Union can and must do more. Of course we must insist on information and communication, promote healthy lifestyles, support a coherent and respectful agri-food chain, a supply chain that must see producers, distributors and consumers working together because consumers who are aware of the quality of their food and the impact of the environment of their production will make a difference.  We must give a voice to small producers, to small and medium-sized enterprises, because they are the real bearers of virtuous progress. Small and medium producers in Expo seem to have been forgotten. We have seen how the big groups are the masters. We hope to still be in time to change course and hope we don't experience the regret of a missed opportunity.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as with almost all the reports from this Chamber, we are once again witnessing the compilation of wishful thinking, recitals and nagging demands. Although the World Expo is worthy of major interest, particularly for Italy, there is a very deep gap between the assertions contained in this report and the policies actually pursued by the European Union authorities. I will take only one example, which renders all of these assertions in vain: the relentless will of almost all European leaders to bring about the transatlantic trade and investment partnership. Thus, your pious will to fight obesity and food imbalances, to defend family farming and food security is at odds with what will soon happen, namely GMOs, cloned meat and hormone beef, which the Commission has long supported and wants to impose on us.

name: Lara COMI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Expo Milano 2015 universal exhibition addresses a fundamental issue for the importance of Europe and the entire planet.  As a Lombard, I am glad that it takes place in my city and that it takes place in Italy, because there was born the Mediterranean diet declared today an intangible cultural heritage of humanity. Feeding the planet is one of the most important challenges we face. It is already necessary to take all the necessary measures to ensure food security, including from the point of view of production and supply. For me, there can be no food safety without good labelling rules, which the European Parliament has clearly approved and also the traceability of products that not only allows consumers to know what they eat and what they buy, but in a competitive market has a leverage effect by raising their quality levels. I call on the Commission to make the best use of the Milan Expo and everything that this universal exhibition will be able to highlight in order to contribute to improving the lives not only of Europeans but of all citizens. I will end with an appeal: Milan is a city that is now armored, it is a city where there will be many anti-Expo demonstrations and it is right to express and express one's idea, but I already condemn in advance those who will violently express these ideas because this is not democracy.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, all too often we hear about Expo only as a great exhibition, an opportunity for promotion dedicated above all to tourists.  Expo 2015 is also this but it is above all a political moment to discuss without hypocrisy the great issues related to food. We must dare in terms of content and seriously discuss the issues of inequality in the distribution of resources, which leads to malnutrition on the one hand and obesity and food waste on the other, to relations between north and the south of the world, we have talked a lot about this in recent days, to the fact that politics must take back the direction left too often in the hands of multinationals , the creation of an ever-increasing pact between producers, distributors and consumers, and the defence of biodiversity as a priority to guarantee everyone a future without hunger.  As members of our group in the Committee on Fisheries, we also wanted to emphasise the sustainability of fish collection and farming and the need to combat overfishing and illegal fishing globally.

name: Beata GOSIEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Dear! The European Parliament has repeatedly dealt with food safety problems, the effectiveness of the fight against food waste and the promotion of healthy eating. However, we must not forget that food safety problems are not only a question of quantity, but also of quality. Only healthy, unmodified, unschemised food can feed the planet and give energy to life. I am concerned about the trend that has started to dominate production in the European Union in order to produce a large amount of unhealthy, processed food at a cheap cost. The effects of low-quality products are not only severe for citizens' health, but also for Member States' budgets. The European Commission should develop policies that support the production of high-quality healthy food and protect human health. Every effort should be made to ensure that high standards also apply to imported food. The conditions negotiated by the Commission for GMOs or cloning in agreements with the US... (The President received the speaker's vote)

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Expo in Milan gives us the opportunity to have a broader discussion on how we cope with food safety, food supply and how we deal with antibiotics in meat production, which is a matter that some of us here are working on.  But it also gives us the opportunity to discuss, in a broader perspective, the imbalance that exists in the world, where we who belong to the richer part become larger and larger in scope while many people are still starving. It also provides the opportunity to discuss the price of food that we are prepared to pay in the Western world. We are clearly not prepared to spend more money on high-quality food, and are therefore pushing forward a low-cost market in perhaps the most important thing we have in our lives: healthy and safe food.  At the same time, however, we must ensure that we are able to feed all our mouths outside the rich West as well. It is therefore important that, in these discussions, we do not have an anti-technology or anti-development debate on our production for the agricultural market of the future.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for years there has been a criminal system in Italy that uses or invents events, great works to feed one of the largest corruption machines in the world.  Milan Expo, such as the Mose of Venice or the Turin-Lyon, is part of this logic. The Italian judiciary has already sanctioned through trials and convictions the existence around Expo of a political-industrial dome with strong Mafia ties that has inflated costs and illegally oriented contracts. To cite the Expo as an example of transparency, as is done in the report, sounds rather sarcastic. This Expo has betrayed the principles on which it was born: it has proposed to combat the damage of poor nutrition such as obesity and boasts the partnership with Coca-Cola, McDonald and Nestlé, which would be like convening a conference on world peace funded by Lockheed. Design sustainable economy scenarios and take advantage of the underpaid or free work of thousands of young people. My city, Milan, did not need this fair of hypocrisy.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Expo 2015 in Milan turned out to be an exposition of contradictions.  While organic farming is being promoted in words, GMOs are increasingly being promoted, especially in developing countries. We should favour the short supply chain, the zero kilometre, but in our cities the large shopping centres that devastate local economies and strangle small agricultural producers are proliferating. We would like to preserve the land and instead according to Ispra data in Italy from the fifties to today we have irreparably lost 7.3% of territory per year, equal to 8 square meters per second. The same land where Expo stands today was agricultural and was quickly transformed into buildings. And finally, the most striking contradiction: the lack of any reference in the Milan Charter to the theme of international financial speculation on raw materials and the phenomenon of land grabbing, as if these issues were not closely linked to food. It is an Expo that has among its sponsors international companies such as Coca-Cola and McDonald, an Expo that exploits an important theme such as nutrition to speculate and carry out mere greenwashing operations.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: – Madam President, in Milan we will face one of the most important debates on our planet in Milan in the coming months on the occasion of your Expo: the fact that some one billion people continue to go hungry in the world and that one person dies every two seconds from lack of food. The European Union must become a global leader in tacking a problem that affects all of us, not just the poorest countries. The fight for food and nutrition security requires a joint response from the international community, and in Europe we have the resources, experience, innovation and research capacity to help combat this scourge. Let us help promote sustainable forms of agriculture, maintain traditional agriculture, allow the livelihoods of millions of people in rural areas around the world, and foster agricultural innovation as a key to feeding the planet. And let's also stronger the commitment to a fishing model that ensures the sustainability of resources and our seas, as fish is not only a vital food, but also gives work and income to millions of people around the world. Let us also work to improve the supply chain and end the shameful waste of food. "Let us help cultivate the future", as the motto that will preside over the pavilion of Spain in Milan says. We must do this even if it is only for selfish reasons, because without food security there can never be peace or security in the world.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to congratulate my colleague Paolo De Castro on this initiative. The global context is worrying. The world's population is expected to exceed 9 billion in 2050. Demand for food will increase by 70%. Resources are limited and climate change is taking effect. The agricultural sector will have to satisfy the growing need of the population, to be supplied with safe and sufficient quantities of food, but in a sustainable way. On the other hand, in the 21st century, a significant part of the world's population cannot afford the basic food it needs. That is why the European Union needs to continue its support for famine-stricken countries. If in developing states the number one problem is access to food, in developed countries the disease of our century is obesity, which is wreaking havoc. The European Commission needs to take more seriously the fight against obesity and promote a healthy lifestyle.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. We are the world, we are the children. We are the world, we are the children. We are the ones who make the day brighter. Let's start giving up! It is our choice. We create the better day! You and me. Let us stand together in a uniform way! We can't pretend day after day that somebody will somehow make a difference. Sounds weird? But that's the way it is. And not by me, but by Michael Jackson. Sung for Africa. Now we are talking today about the EU's appearance at the Expo in Milan and the title 'Feeding the planet, energy for life'. This is an issue of particular interest to me as ECR coordinator for the ACP delegation. I wonder, Commissioner, whether we, as Europe, really play our global role in the fight against hunger? Do we not delude ourselves if we pretend that agricultural production in Europe can satisfy hunger in Africa? Do we have concepts that allow partners on an equal footing in world nutrition that allow progress to enable production and processing in emerging markets? In Europe, do we have internal market rules that preserve natural diversity – the key word: seeds? Are we doing our part to actively promote this diversity? I would like to say with Michael Jackson: let's get on with it! Every change comes only if we stick together like one, in Europe and in the world! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, you have said that we must not be under any illusions, that Europe cannot help, that it could not feed people from the planet in another area. I ask you: do you think it is normal for Europe not to show solidarity with other people in other corners of the earth?

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I do not think that is normal. Let me give you just one example: in Uganda, the cows could be milked, the milk could be packed in tetra-packs, flown by air freight, for example, to Germany and put on the shelves, and it would still be cheaper than the milk that we offer here if we did not subsidise it. We are destroying the world market and pretending that we are not involved in the food problem. In any case, I think that we, as Europeans, have a responsibility.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam Chairman, I expect this exceptional topic at expo 2015 on the diet of the world's population to go in two directions. The first course should be to solve this absurdity that we have so much food that we throw away, that we have the absurdity of great poverty, even in Europe and especially in Africa and on other continents, and we have the absurdity of food waste. Innovative agriculture, large investments and investments in agriculture and research of innovative agriculture and all that can feed this planet, I think it is extremely important and that expo must answer this absurdity and these questions how to have more efficient and sustainable agriculture.  Another important topic for me is the role of small and medium-sized enterprises, the role of traditional agriculture, the role of local products in the diet of the population, the protection of local products and all that we know is part of our European culinary gastronomic heritage.

name: John Stuart AGNEW
text: – Madam President, we are discussing feeding the planet and providing energy for life. The present CAP is an object lesson on how to fail to achieve this. The attitude towards the use of the obvious advantages of biotechnology in agriculture is a case in point. The Chief Scientific Advisor to the Commission can find nothing wrong with GM crops, so the Commission abolishes the post of Chief Scientific Advisor.  The Green lobby forced the banning of neonicotinoid seed dressings without the benefit of British field trials, and with the result that oilseed rape crops fail or need the life support of repetitive cypermethrin spraying. The EU Green lobby are forcing thousands of acres out of food production in favour of expensive energy from solar farms and AD plants, while being utterly opposed to the cheap shale gas that sits underneath those same fields. Furthermore, British farmers are being forced to abandon optimum rotations in favour of the 3-crop rule, and, at the same time, they are told to reduce omissions of CO2 – the very gas that makes their crops grow in the first place.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Milan Expo will not only be an extraordinary showcase for Italy and Europe, but also an opportunity to address vital issues such as the fight against food waste, such as food education focused on balanced and balanced diets and lifestyles, because we have heard that malnutrition does not only stem from the scarcity of food that unfortunately still causes millions of deaths , but also from the abundance of food.  I also hope that this will be a time to step up the fight against food fraud, a priority to protect our food heritage, which has an unri same economic and cultural value for the whole of Europe. But I would like to say to those who are contesting this Expo: look that it will be an extraordinary opportunity, for six months, to meet peoples, I am thinking of the clusters of the less wealthy countries that will proudly present their products, the Nepal pavilion which will probably be unfinished and beautiful and which I would like to set up in some way as a symbol of this collaboration between peoples in order to overcome the challenges , but together. No more destructive criticism!

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am a European citizen from Milan, so I look forward to this event with great enthusiasm.  However, we want the Expo to leave a moral and political legacy to the international community, new commitments and new concrete objectives to be achieved in order to live up to this great scenario, to be objectively able to make these commitments, as it is written in the Milan Charter, which is still open that we can fill with content.  The European Union, Commissioner, must be at the forefront and first objective, I will list them briefly. We have the opportunity to define the post-millennium objectives, well the fight against malnutrition must become a priority, the fight against hunger in all its forms – I am thinking of the so-called phenomenon of hidden hunger – and then we must work towards the affirmation of a right to food as a legally guaranteed right. To make food it takes land, water and energy. On earth we want the European Union to be at the forefront of defining the rules for combating land grabbing, and we always talk about it with some embarrassment. We want to work for water that must be part of the objectives of cooperation and for widespread and accessible energy.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: – Madam President, over time, humanity has been concerned with food security, building on the fact that the right to food is a fundamental one and that it is respected when people have permanent physical and economic access to adequate and safe food in order to meet the needs for a healthy life. The 2015 Milan exhibition is a good opportunity for the European Union to continue the process of raising public awareness of the need to be constantly concerned with food security, food production and distribution, but especially preventing food waste, all of which have the major objective of combating malnutrition. It is inadmissible that today, in the 21st century, there are people starving and, at the same time, more than 30% of the world's food being lost or wasted.  Last but not least, we must be constantly concerned about the development of agriculture, which also means identifying outlets for European products, and TTIP is certainly a good opportunity for agriculture in the European Union.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Madam President, 'Feeding the planet, energy for life', is the theme of the Milan World's Fair, and I welcome that. A large part of the world's population still fails to feed itself sufficiently and properly: one billion people are hungry and three billion are malnourished. Beyond enabling all Europeans to have access to healthy and quality food, accessible to all and responding to sustainability issues, the European Union must participate in the food balances of the rest of the world. But not in any way: by developing a more ambitious policy of cooperation and by accompanying the proliferation of small farms. All the peoples of the world must feed themselves, that is my vision. The fight against food waste must also be one of our major objectives. We must collectively find ways to regulate markets in order to address the problem of price volatility. I would add that financial speculation on agricultural raw materials must be firmly combated, because the situation is no longer tolerable. These are, from my point of view, the stakes of the Milan World's Fair.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that one of the most alarming issues in our society is the so-called food paradox.  We live in a world where 800 million people are undernourished while over 2 billion are obese and overweight. For every person suffering from hunger there are two obese or overweight. If we add to this the fact that more than 1 billion tonnes of edible food is wasted every year, that is, as much as a third of global food production and four times the amount needed to feed the 800 million undernourished people, we understand that this situation can no longer be tolerated.  I hope that Expo 2015 will be able to ignite a permanent reflection on these issues and to urge the national and European institutions to take concrete measures in this regard. I believe that the Commission should promote a culture of prevention around the role of nutrition, in order to put a stop to the increase in obesity, and at the same time, in order to reduce unacceptable food waste, it is necessary to introduce measures that improve the food supply chain with a view to efficiency in the use of resources, with particular reference to production and distribution, and that encourage companies and retailers to improve their coordination.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: – Madam President, first of all I would like to greet and greet the rapporteur, Mr de Castro. The motto of the Milan Universal Exhibition is food security at a time when there are 870 million malnourished people in the world. The target set at the 1996 World Food Summit, which was intended to reduce the number of hungry people by 2015, remains largely out of reach. The Milan Expo better warn you of this.  In parallel with hunger and malnutrition, food waste and obesity also grow. We produce more food than we need, contributing concomitantly to the degradation of the environment. This diachrony is the basis of social conflicts and injustices. It is urgent to take on the paradigm shift. Investment in fishing and farming practices should be invested in preserving natural resources for future generations. Food security for all also means creating local and regional subsistence capacities and contributing to a better allocation of resources and production on a global scale.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking Mr De Castro for this motion for a resolution, but also, and above all, to point out that the subject we are debating is an important issue.  We must produce more while maintaining environmental resources, we must improve the quality of the environment by increasing the overall level of production. That is the challenge we face. The world's population is increasing, consumption is increasing, the type of consumption with much heavier consumption in terms of agricultural production is also increasing, and this leads to strong environmental pressure. Expo will be an exceptional opportunity for scientific comparison between different cultures to be able to reach a conclusion, to be able to get to have a recipe for the future and this we hope that can be done in the coming months of work at Expo.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Madam President, the Milan Expo that will open its doors on 1 May deals with something that is one of the biggest challenges for today’s world: how to feed the increasingly growing population of the world in the years to come.  I appreciate the fact that the main focus of this resolution is food security and how to tackle the threats that put food security at risk. Being a Member of the Committee on Development I am especially concerned with how the issues of land-grabbing, land loss and degradation will be dealt with in the future. I believe that in the upcoming decades we will have to deliver a global strategy that must include sustainability in farming systems and in global food production through sustainable small-scale farming, organic, high-nature value or tree-based agriculture, as well as better resource efficiency and increased crop diversity. I congratulate my colleague Paolo De Castro and the shadow rapporteurs for their outstanding work.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the Milan 2015 report highlights the modern food problems of the world's poverty-stricken populations. We need sustainable agriculture, food security, a sustainable food system, safe food, tackling obesity. The Milan 2015 report should highlight the illegal land grab by large multinational companies in Africa and elsewhere. At the same time, austerity has led to the shift of the West's millions of unemployed to cheap and questionable food.  The memoranda and disastrous policies of austerity experienced by Greece and the cheap, calorific diet lead to weight gain above normal in adults and children, thus putting their health at increased risk, according to a World Health Organization survey presented in October 2014.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say that it is enough to name McDonald, Coca-Cola or Nestlé to make it clear that Expo is a showcase for feeding multinationals and certainly not the planet.  It is a showcase precisely for those who control food all over the world and produce that globalized food that determines both hungry and obese. Expo is a showcase that hides a bad story of procurement, corruption and mafia infiltration. Expo is a showcase that hides a model of exploitation, insecurity and free work and it is shameful, Mr President, that the European Parliament endorses all this with its own institutional presence.  I would like to say to Mr Comi, who was just fearing destructive demonstrations, that I will be taking part in the 'No Expo' event tomorrow on 1 May together with the precarious people who want to celebrate 'May Day' with the commons activists, with many citizens. Now, as in the days of Genoa, the movement is being demonized. I will stay with those who that ugly Expo showcase symbolically wants to break it.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the last speech really seemed to me to be a punch in the eye.  Would these be the ones who should help the development of the world? But let them go to a desert island and stay there forever, talking about the last colleague. As for the Expo, I thank the current President of the Lombardy Region Roberto Maroni for what he did for those who years ago had the foresight to choose Expo and Milan and managed to get the candidacy and it is a very important showcase for all of us.  However, I wanted to ask basically a question: but since we always talk about sustainable agriculture, for example when we go and ask for an orange soda (I first went to the bar an orange soda) but inside an orange soda there is not even an orange, that is, if we want sustainable agriculture we must also ensure that the fruits instead of being destroyed as happens very often around the world and also in Italy are instead used to produce exactly what is needed. So orange soda that has at least one orange, this would already be a great opportunity.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Madam President, I think this international food fair raises three priorities. Firstly, the fight against waste: remember that in Europe it represents 179 kilos per year per capita, i.e. 90 million tonnes per year of waste. What we will have to do in the future to feed everyone, before we think about producing more, will be to fight against waste.  Secondly, food education, which we will discuss again in the debate on the report on the distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools. Obesity is on the rise, especially among young people and children.  Thirdly, this resolution will be fully useful, it seems to me, if it also enshrines, alongside the existence of the agri-food industry, which has its relevance to transform agricultural production, subsistence agriculture in the countries of the rest of the world hit by malnutrition, which affects at least 800 million people. Subsistence agriculture must be recognised by amendments that should be voted on, in order to underline the conclusions of Olivier De Schutter, the UN rapporteur for food.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, we are discussing ways to increase food production so that the growing human population on earth can be fed. In reality, however much food technology evolves, the demographic dynamics in the third world are so explosive that hunger will not only not be eradicated, but spread in the 21st century. The governments of these countries must therefore be encouraged to promote long-term demographic policies, while at the same time we must actively seek to change food standards within the European Union. Consumption of foods that have a high cost to the ecological balance on the planet, such as beef and pork and free-fishing fish, must be restricted. The European Union must ensure that its citizens are informed through the education system of the need to eat mainly cereals, fruits and vegetables. Help save the planet!

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission welcomes the draft resolution. The European Union policies respond to a number of points raised. The common agricultural policy, for example, provides a comprehensive and inclusive support framework for the sustainable production of food. The strength of European agriculture is based on its diversity, its capacity to add value and its ability to adapt. These are the values we need to promote in order to meet the demands of food security in the wake of scarce resources. In that context, the Commission would encourage further reflection and discussion on some points of this resolution, particularly in relation to the proposed focus on specific agriculture models. As already explained in my opening remarks, the Commission is committed to supporting Member States and stakeholders in strengthening resource efficiency in the food chain and preventing and reducing food waste from farm to fork. It is also clear that Member States need to play a key role in the issues of nutrition and physical activity. The Commission agrees, and strongly supports additional cooperation between them so as to improve some of the trends mentioned in the resolution, particularly by promoting healthy diets and lifestyles. I also would like to wish all participants great success in tomorrow’s opening of Expo Milano.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: A motion for a resolution was submitted to me in accordance with Article 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure.  The debate is over. The vote will take place on Thursday, 30 April 2015 at 12:00. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: in writing. The resolution is a detailed manifesto of the main 'key issues' in the agri-food sector. The main 'political' issues relating to food and its agricultural production are mentioned, but never going into too much substance. Several unknowns remain on Expo, starting with how much it will be able to respond to the "real" theme, namely to chart a path for a sustainable response to the theme of food supply, towards which innovation by the agricultural and agro-industrial supply chain is urgently needed. The imbalances between the different actors in the supply chain and the access to food of the populations of developing countries, should be some of the issues to be addressed with great seriousness. It is in this direction that the European Parliament's commitment should move.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question referred by Czesław Adam Siekierski to the Commission on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development on the outbreak of Xylella fastidiosa infection affecting olive trees (O-000038/2015 — B8-0117/2015 — (2015/2652(RSP)).

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there is a phytosanitary emergency which is affecting the olive trees of a part of the Puglia region and which is worrying the whole of Europe.  The spread of the quarantine pathogen Xylella fastidiosa, pauca subspecies, puts Apulian olive growing at risk and has dramatic economic, environmental and social consequences. The European Parliament, through the Committee on Agriculture, therefore immediately took the initiative of wanting to discuss this issue in this House, to express its concerns and ask the Commission for clarification. Meanwhile, just this week, the European Commission's Plant Health Committee voted for a decision that clarifies some of the issues we have raised.  Firstly, this shows that the Xylella problem is a European problem and must be tackled by European decisions and not by national decisions. The first decision, which we welcome, is the ban on the import of ornamental coffee plants from Costa Rica and Honduras. This shows how it is now established that the source of access of the Xylella subspecies Pauca in Europe was precisely that type of plant coming from those countries, as also confirmed by the discovery of these infected plants also in France. The real vulnus on which we must reflect is precisely the need for closer control of imports of plant material from third countries, including for other types of disease. That is why we are asking the Commission to give its opinion on this matter. In addition, the Commission's decision takes strict measures which, while avoiding total eradication in the already infected area, which would have been not only useless but above all dramatic for an entire territory, its landscape, its economy and the rural environment, on the other, in order to block new outbreaks, calls, in accordance with international standards on quarantine pathogens. , the eradication of some healthy plants outside the aforementioned infected area (i.e. outside the province of Lecce to understand us).  The two problems which the Commission's decision does not solve and on which we would like to hear more commitments today are those of research and compensation for farmers. First of all, we need to continue studying this bacterium, of which not much is yet known and the possibility that we have of eradicating it. We need more public funds for this, and above all, Mr President and Commissioner, we need it quickly, how quickly this bacterium can spread. Farmers, for their part, have no responsibility for the spread of this pathogen, but suffer both direct and cost damage from the costs of implementing the measures necessary to contain the disease. That is why we are here today to ask the Commission what compensatory measures it intends to give to the farmers who are the real victims of this annoying Xylella.

name: Paolo DE CASTRO
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I welcome this opportunity to discuss with you the outbreak of a new plant disease which poses a very serious threat to the whole of our agricultural sector. Xylella fastidiosa is a bacterial disease which, following its first introduction into the European Union, is now heavily affecting olive oil production in southern Italy. The Commission is very concerned about this situation because there is no effective treatment to cure the plants once they become infected. It is the first time such a bacterium has been found in the EU and it affects a very large number of plant species, with devastating effects. The occurrence of this disease, regulated as a quarantine organism, was notified by the Italian authorities on 21 October 2013. The area affected is almost the entire province of Lecce, in the Apulia region. Emergency measures were first taken in February 2014 and further strengthened in July 2014. These measures lay down strict requirements for import and movement of host plants in the EU, timely identification and control in the affected areas in Italy and the removal of all infected host plants. The Commission’s Food and Veterinary Office carried out two audits in 2014. The second audit, conducted in November 2014, concluded that the situation had dramatically deteriorated since the first one conducted in February of the same year. A new outbreak has been confirmed recently in the province of Brindisi. This shows that the disease has already moved outside the originally affected area. Clearly, there is a high risk of a further spread if decisive measures are not taken as a matter of immediate urgency.  In addition, the European Food Safety Authority published in January this year a pest risk assessment with a list of potential host plants, including main agricultural crops such as citrus and grapevine. This list contains approximately 200 species – a much larger number than that covered by the previous EU emergency measures. Although not yet found in citrus and grapevine plants, the range of host plants affected by the bacterium found in Apulia is gradually increasing as investigations continue to unfold. Italy has, in the meantime, declared a state of emergency, nominated a Special Commissioner in charge of this file and announced a series of measures to be taken, including significant financial funding. In parallel, the Commission has reviewed the current EU emergency measures with great care in line with the precautionary principle. I can assure the honourable Members that the list of potential host plants to be covered, including citrus and grapevine, as well as restrictions on movements outside the infected zone and from infected third countries, has been considered from a strong precautionary perspective.  The new measures proposed by the Commission and endorsed by the Member States on 28 April this year foresee the following: for the heavily infected province of Lecce, it was finally agreed to restrict the measures to the felling of infected trees and intensive testing of the surrounding trees. For any outbreaks outside Lecce, including the one in the province of Brindisi, a more precautionary approach is being taken by preventable felling, not only of the infected trees but also other host plants within 100 metres. This is essential to prevent the further spread of this bacterium in the European Union. I want to be clear on one thing: the strict conditions applied on movements out of the demarcated areas in Italy are also applied to imports from affected third countries. Furthermore, given that recently coffee plants imported from Costa Rica and Honduras were intercepted in the European Union with Xylella fastidiosa, the Commission is now banning such imports. Lastly, let me reassure you that the Commission is in permanent contact with the Italian authorities to explore all possible tools available to support financially implementation of the eradication measures foreseen in our legislation. Compensation can be granted for eradication measures such as removal and destruction of plants, phytosanitary treatments, including for sampling and testing, on condition that all proposed eradication measures are fully implemented. At the same time, we are exploring any possibility of further support with the rural development programmes and Horizon 2020. Let me conclude by saying that maximum vigilance is essential now to preserve the agricultural economy in the area concerned and to prevent further spread in the rest of the European Union.

name: Esther HERRANZ GARCÍA
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I see you well informed and that is why I will be very direct. I ask the European Commission to facilitate the financing of a research project in Xylella fastidiosa under Horizon 2020 and therefore to promote means of prevention and early detection of bacteria and ways to mitigate the problem once it arises. Because the conclusions of last Monday's expert meeting are in the right direction, but they can be improved with effective measures and, above all, with research, development and innovation in this area. I believe that the closure of imports into countries where the bacteria is present is essential and I also believe in the positive lists of countries from which products can be imported, leaving out those where there is already infection. Because, between 2000 and 2007, the European Union has imported 150 million plants from recognized species from countries where the bacteria is present and diseases must be prevented from entering. That is why I tell you that this is not only the case with Xylella, but with all kinds of diseases, because this case demonstrates the great weakness of the European Union's import control system. In the Plant Health Regulation for the fight against pests – in process now – we are missing a very valuable opportunity to introduce more stringent import control, similar to that imposed by third countries on European exports. Commissioner, we have a great deal of concern about the serious risk of the spread of Xylella in the European Union. It could affect, as you said, not only the olive grove, but Mediterranean crops such as vines and citrus fruits.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President; Commissioner, we have seen these days, this week, just before this debate – welcome the result – that the Standing Committee on Plant Health has finally adopted more restrictive measures to prevent the spread of this pest, this bacterium throughout Europe. A year and a half later, Commissioner! The first alert communication was in October 2013. Palliative but not resolute or effective measures have been taken. It is finally taken seriously that this is an important pest, that this can cause serious damage not only to the olive grove, but – as it says – to the vine and citrus fruits and, therefore, action must be taken. I come from Spain, like my former colleague, and from Andalusia, and therefore we are concerned about the impact it may have.  I want to tell you clearly that border protection systems in Europe are not working and I hope the Commission will admit it. We have asked countless times for this to be dealt with more seriously.  In addition, the problem is the lack of effective treatments. Agriculture, therefore, has a double problem here, the farmer: there are no effective treatments to cure these plants, and therefore action must already be taken. Faced with this situation, which unfortunately is not unique, I would like to ask you what is going on with the plant health dossier, which is paralyzed in the Council, and whether you are going to take measures to improve border protection systems in Europe.

name: Bas BELDER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The Xylella bacterium has serious consequences for olive trees and has been spreading since 2013. In that year EFSA wrote, among other things: "To be effective, containment should include removal of infected plants." My first question to the Commissioner: Has this measure been implemented in a timely manner to prevent the spread? On international trade: The EU's import system is working well. Plants are allowed to cross the border unless they carry a disease. In the case of specific risks, controls can be tightened up. So that's risk-based. I would like to expressly ask the Commissioner to continue to take a risk-based approach, even in the future.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. – Madam President, I want to express my great concern about all this that is happening in the province of Lecce in Puglia and I want to express my regret towards farmers and the fact that there will probably be a large felling of centuries-old olive trees, thus changing landscapes, but also what is the economy of these people who live off it. I want them to be helped in the form of reparations and on behalf of the European Union.  What I would like to point out in particular is that Xyllela fastidiosa was already on the vine in kosovo, so it was on the other side of the Adriatic, and as rapporteur for the Adriatic-Ionian strategy I express further concern for olive growing, and especially for mandarins in the Neretva area and I believe that everything that is happening today in Italy and in a way that should be seriously considered , and here I ask italian friends, to check the nurseries in Italy, nurseries of all plants, especially olive trees, because Croatia is largely supplyed from nurseries from Italy.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I have to say, having listened to the Commissioner, that I do not think he has the faintest idea of the material, symbolic and cultural consequences of the decision that has been taken, on the landscape, on the ecosystem, on the lives of thousands of women and men. This is not just about compensation, it is about a devastated landscape, it is about a devastated economy.  On 1 April, I tabled a question asking to investigate whether there were possible causes of what is happening and alternative solutions to pesticide eradication. EFSA has made it clear that possible causes must be investigated, that eradication is not a solution, that pesticides would be devastating for the ecosystem. Now, I ask why all this is being ignored, it has been ignored by the Silletti plan, it has also been ignored by yesterday's decision, that is to say, a solution is being produced that will certainly have damage and very little will certainly be the solution.  I wonder whether we should not defend our olive trees not only from the scourge of Xylella or other causes, but also from the scourge of this Decision of the European Union.

name: José BOVÉ
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, what we are facing today is not just a disease: it is a plant pest that is coming to Europe! At present, no treatment is possible, either against insects or to care for trees. We are in an absolutely dramatic situation. Today, in Europe, we are dealing with only one strain: Xylella pauca. There are three others that, if they arrive on our continent, will cause an even greater catastrophe. They will affect citrus fruits, vines and many other species: more than 309 in all will be affected. The first step is to extend entry bans to products from all areas where Xylella strains are present. I am thinking not only of Central America, but also of Florida, California and Mexico. All products from these regions must be quarantined. Secondly: in the measures adopted today, there is no provision for support for small producers. In Puglia, for example, the average area is 1.5 hectares. I call for the immediate mobilization of the crisis reserve to help small producers. We also call for a total ban, without the possibility of circumvention, on all exports of at-risk plants from the infested area. The territories - be it Spain, Greece or France and islands such as Corsica, Sicily and Sardinia - must be protected. If they are not protected, it is over. Morocco has already banned imports of all plants from Italy into its territory. Finally, we must foresee the future today, i.e. allow the construction of double-closing greenhouses, so that the plants are raised indoors, without the possibility of insect attacks. These measures are not in the text. We have to go further. This is a European health emergency!

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, after careful reading of the new implementing decision, we note the belated decision to ban the import of coffee plants and to subject imports into the European Union of as many as 188 plants susceptible to Xylella fastidiosa under strict conditions.  Congratulations on the timing! In the meantime, however, half of Puglia will be deserted or poisoned. Yes, because, in addition to the eradication measures that have been reduced in theory, there is still a massive use of pesticides, which we denounced in an oral question circulated among Members, which took into account the appeals of the WHO and UNEP. EFSA itself has a clear position in its second report against the use of pesticides on a large scale.  I call on the Commission to reconsider its opinion and to consider Directive 128/2009/EC in this regard, which provides for the priority development of organic farming and the use of all alternative means to regularly registered chemical pesticides, in accordance with the precautionary principle of the right to health. It is a decision that has not been shared but lowered from above that does not take into account the effects on the environment and on the health of the population.  We cannot accept that our territory should be violated and we expect the European Commission to verify the real applicability of the measures and support field research and experimentation programmes and help farmers to implement good agricultural practices. Let us continue our fight and let us not stop. That is why I have invited colleagues from parliament from the countries most exposed to contagion, academic experts and academic organisations, to a round table to find together the common solutions to be proposed to the Commission. This is in order to deal with this emergency with full respect for European agriculture and the health of its citizens. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, Mrs D'Amato, you talked about the use of pesticides on a large scale. I just wanted to know what you meant by this concept?

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: Answer to a blue card question. – The implementing decision provided for treatments, they call them plant protection plants, they are in fact pesticides both plants to be eradicated before they are eradicated and on the plants to be exported. The Silletti plan, named after the Commissioner, already provided for the use of as many as seven active substances, two of which are considered harmful to health by the Italian Minister of Health himself. EFSA itself, the 5-star Movement does not say, advises against the use of pesticides on a large scale precisely because they have consequences for the food chain, for health and for the economy of our agriculture.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: Madam President, this dramatic crisis, which affects olive trees in Italy in particular, but which can also affect oaks and chestnut trees, is of course putting local cultures at risk. There are two different problems. First, finding the scientific solution to stop this epidemic, which is not easy. Second, make strong decisions and apply a form of protectionism to prohibit imports of plants that are not necessary.  The rule of your economic system, which is lethal in this case, is free trade. When France wanted to apply protection measures by banning plants from infested areas, it was accused of violating the rules of the free movement of goods.  This crisis therefore highlights the contradictions of European policy and, of course, proves the need for strict protection rules. It also brings water to the mill of criticisms against our industrial model, which tends to homogenize crops. A bacterium is being slaughtered in genetically homogeneous crops as a virus can do in industrial farms.  In any event, this case should prompt the Commission to consider the genetic diversification of crops, but also of livestock.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, As a technician, I believe that plant health measures are necessary, perhaps too drastic.  There is an area that is an infected area, there is an expansion zone in Puglia on which attention must be focused. Perhaps we need to review the measure of intervention a little, but I agree that the expansion zone must concentrate its activities, but there is one issue that needs to be highlighted, which is that of research. We have few clear elements yet and it is certainly not with Horizon 2020 that we will solve the problem.  Horizon 2020, as you know, has a procedure, it has selective calls, it has time, we need rapid, much shorter research responses and the Commission can act in this to give answers and certainties in certain directions that are necessary. We need to know in a short time what is the possibility that Xylella, this strain infected some ornamental plants or especially fruit plants, we talk about citrus fruits, we talk about vines, because only by having certain information can we obviously develop measures.  Then there is another aspect that comes from this story and from others with which the Commission is well aware. This is the aspect of border controls. We cannot continue to have borders from a phytosanitary point of view which are a sieve because we cannot continue like this, our farmers do not deserve it.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Madam President, among the preventive measures adopted this week against the introduction and spread of the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa, the European Commission is planning the felling of diseased trees and the establishment of strict surveillance within a 100 metre radius around each contaminated strain, as the Commissioner has pointed out. However, while European co-financing is possible for grubbing up, no compensation is provided to help affected farms and producers. In a study commissioned, Federazione coldiretti Puglia estimated the damage at 400 euros per plant. The calculation is simple: if a hectare of land can contain approximately a hundred plants, the damage per hectare can be estimated at 40,000 euros, not counting the years to multiply for post-eradication. It is therefore essential to put in place European aid to help the affected farms. Only effective management of this home will protect the entire territory of the European Union.

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: – Every farmer knows how terrible it is when your crops or livestock are beyond your control to get sick. Due to the outbreak of Xylella, it was decided the day before yesterday to close the door to more than 200 plant species. This is causing enormous financial damage. The Italian Government's decision not to enforce rigorous European legislation has been a poor choice in the face of the consequences. Robust and targeted controls are a better solution. In doing so, the current rules must be strictly observed. I call on the European Commission to clarify in writing as soon as possible the time limit and scope of the import ban. I would also like to know why the European Commission is considering defaulting on Italy. Finally, I am curious to see how the Commissioner for Better Regulation will ensure that joint agreements are also unambiguously complied with. Europe is trading. Incidents like this should not be an excuse to adapt the current open import system.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: – Madam President; Commissioner, I believe that this crisis, this dramatic situation which we are discussing here today as a result of the annoying Xylella in Italy, must serve us to draw lessons for the future. And I think the first thing is to analyze the root causes. I have to say that the transport and mass trade of products and goods around the world and climate change are a good breeding ground for the emergence and development of new diseases and the emergence of species that pose a serious and serious threat to our crops, biodiversity, the environment and our economy. The Xylella, which we have already said; the wasp, in the chestnut trees; Trioza, in citrus; Vespa velutina or Asian wasp, in bees; I think they are a good example of the challenges we are currently facing in the European Union and of which we have some knowledge. I want to say that mass logging is no solution, that concrete actions and a serious and comprehensive programme are needed.

name: Jordi Vicent SEBASTIA TALAVERA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the case of Xylella annoying bacteria is highlighting many of the incompetence of the European Union. We do not have effective control against the arrival of pests from other parts of the world in an increasingly globalized situation. In my country we suffered the plague of the red prick, which hopelessly destroys our palm trees, because infected palm trees of Egypt were imported uncontrolled.
