We shut down people fleeing wars who end up drowning at sea, but we do nothing to prevent the arrival of pests. The Xylella is destroying olive trees that had endured everything until now. If you arrive in other Mediterranean countries, the Valencian Country, Corsica, Catalonia, Andalusia, the consequences for olive oil, citrus, wine producers will be dramatic.  Nor are we reacting in a coordinated way: each country takes the measures it deems appropriate without taking into account that bacteria, insects do not understand borders. "What good is Europe for then?" the farmers ask me. In addition, the usual solutions are re-indicated: pesticides. More chemicals that expose the land and its diversity and that only facilitate the invasion of the next pest. When are we going to understand that mass-applied pesticides are no longer good for this and that their use has made us fall into a spiral of unsustainable dependence!? Commissioner, we urgently need the Plant Health Regulation to be unlocked; strong measures are taken to prohibit the total movement of plants in the affected area and the entry of all unsafe countries. And we need to address these problems from a common European and sustainable perspective.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: Madam President, Commissioner, after the sharka on the fishery, after the FCO on sheep or cattle herds, we are now faced with a new scourge, as a result of the facilitation of trade on our planet. And unfortunately, as in previous cases, it took a very long time for the Commission's services and the relevant agencies to take stock of the problem. The measures announced a few hours ago will obviously not be sufficient because they do not actually isolate the infected area.  Last week we saw coffee plants coming in Paris carrying the bacteria. What we need to implement, beyond the measures that have been agreed, is a real coordinated research programme at European level, in order to bring about a solution as soon as possible. If for the FCO, a few years ago, we had not had the rapid vaccination, the entire European herd would have been decimated.  So we need progress in the world of research, more consultation among researchers to find a solution. Europe must encourage this research. Of course, it must also help the producers who are concerned, today in Italy, but unfortunately perhaps tomorrow elsewhere in Europe, because we have been too late before isolating the perimeter of the disease.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by expressing my appreciation.  A new channel of dialogue is reopened, a sign of attention to the mobilization of the territory of the regional government which summarizes the concerns of the business system, associations and trade unions. The loss of a few million working days cannot but be at the top of our concerns. At a particular time of economic crisis, we believe that the attention of policy and institutions to two sectors – agriculture and the tourism industry – which must continue to be driving forces in the wake of a vision of growth that Europe wants to be sustainable from an environmental and social point of view, is not insignificant.  The measures announced find a new balance in a vision capable of protecting the entire heritage of olive trees of Puglia, thus guaranteeing the enterprise and the work. We would like to appreciate from you, Commissioner, a renewed commitment to research aimed at the prevention and treatment of the pathogen in question and that the priority objective of protecting human health does not disappear.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: – Madam President. They call it the Olive Grove. In Italy it has already affected 250 000 hectares and more than one million trees. So far it is only eradicated by destroying the affected plant, a measure that considers neither the age of some plants nor the costs of eradicating them.  In addition, it spreads easily because often the symptoms are not even seen. The European Union itself considers it a body that must be quarantined. It is essential to raise awareness among all the institutions of the Member States to take urgent action to ensure that this bacterium does not take the life of our fields. In Spain, for example, olive trees are present in around thirteen Autonomous Communities and is a fundamental source of wealth for farmers and peasants, that is, for thousands of families who, directly or indirectly, live off it. We have an obligation, as public leaders, to protect these people and their means of life.  Instead of closing borders to kill migrants, the European Union should do so to kill bacteria: these do come to end the work of our people.

name: Michèle RIVASI
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this problem is truly a historic threat, affecting a great deal of plant species. It is also an ecological (in view of the number of species concerned), economic (small farms, as well as larger ones, which grow vines, olive trees, etc., are concerned) and social. What to do about it? You are talking about slaughter. Take the example of the Drôme, where there was the sharka, mentioned earlier. Slaughter was done, but that did not prevent the disease from destroying all peaches and apricots because it exceeded the health areas established by the species affected. Much more draconian action is needed. The disease is known to come from Brazil and Central America. We also know that North America is affected, especially California and Florida. It is therefore necessary to introduce draconian controls with quarantine to control these products. In terms of research, it is absolutely necessary that we have to have the means. I am thinking, for example, of phage therapy, which could be used to fight the bacteria.

name: Lara COMI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, faced with a problem as serious as that of Xylella fastidiosa in Puglia, we are all called upon to have a great sense of responsibility.  What is at stake is public health, local economic interests and the very identity of the territory. The Committee of Technicians proposes a less rigid solution than we thought, but it still remains a drastic measure that would create incalculable damage, agricultural damage, food, historical, cultural, tourist, commercial damage, in a nutshell you would put Puglia, a beautiful region, "k.o.".  We are not technical, I am by no means a technician, and so we ask science and research to find alternative solutions to total eradication. We must act quickly and then, once the problem has been resolved, we will analyse who generated or encouraged this contagion: those who have made a mistake will certainly have to pay, they certainly do not have to pay the farmers, not the citizens, not the Apulian workers. No EU country independently can block imports of healthy Apulian products, only for fear of Xylella, and it is the European Commission that is responsible for blocking the movement of infected products.  I therefore call on the Commission to use all the resources necessary to compensate the owners of olive trees, but not only for the emerging damage and the loss of profit, but also for the community and for the environmental, cultural and tourist damage. We have to be quick, we don't have time anymore.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa, which is destroying the olive tree in southern Italy, can affect - and has been said to have this - more than 300 plant species, particularly the vines, as in California in the 1990s. You know that. The consequences of this health event can be catastrophic. However, since October 2013, when this bacterium was discovered in the Puglia region, the few measures taken by the Union have proved insufficient.  A year ago, in this Parliament, during the debate on the revision of the regulations on plant protection, I denounced the failures of the controls and proposed to make changes to this control strategy. I regret today that the Commission has neither heard nor listened to me and that it has never deigned to change the current control regime, which is proving ineffective.  There is an urgent need to act, first in the short term, by clearing the farmers of Puglia and adopting necessary measures, as proposed by the Standing Committee on 28 April, but also in the long term, by revising the controls strategy and implementing a concerted research programme at EU level.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: PPE). Madam President, Commissioner, in the 1960s, ignorance and inertia led to the destruction of the European vineyard by phylloxera disease. Today there is no effective method of plant protection of olives from Xylella which has affected the olive groves of Southern Italy.  I propose three interventions directly: border control, measures for the movement of plant and propagating material, compensation to producers. There are areas with olive trees, six hundred or even more years old, such as Corfu. We must therefore also look at the protection of the plant environment. We look forward to your initiatives, we are pleased that you are taking this action today and we expect positive results soon for olive producers in Southern Europe.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Standing Committee on Plant Health meeting in Brussels this week decided to adopt drastic measures for olive groves affected by Xylella fastidiosa.  In some areas of Puglia, not only sick olive trees, but also plants that are within a hundred meters of them, will have to be eradicated. I believe that this decision should be better assessed taking into account the olive, environmental and economic heritage of Puglia.  On the other hand, I welcome the adoption in Italy of the decree-law on access to the Solidarity Fund, while I expect the European Commission to check ad horas the real applicability of the measures which, if confirmed, must absolutely be accompanied by compensation for damage to farmers. The Commission is therefore also rapidly assessing Italy's requests for economic support for agricultural producers and reviewing European legislation which at the moment does not allow farmers to be compensated for the felling of the affected trees.  I regret the slow ness of the European Union's responses and call on the Commission to review the plant health regime for the plant trade in plants. Directive 2000/29/EC is totally ineffective and inadequate. Finally, a reply to Mr Bové, given that a strain of the bacterium has also been identified in France, what are we doing? Are we blocking all imports from France as well? The solution must be European.

name: Annie SCHREIJER-PIERIK
text: I share the concerns of my colleagues from France, Spain and Italy. Especially when it comes to the degradation of the ancient olive trees, but also when it comes to the degradation of other plant and tree species. Recently, the port of Rotterdam has been pointed at several times in the media as a transit point for the dangerous bacterium. It is forgotten that the Netherlands is the only Member State to have been extra alert to Xylella following the outbreak in Italy in 2013. What matters is that the current rules need to be better observed. To me, stricter rules in the form of a blockade of the internal market do not seem to me to be a wise move at all because the same market is of great importance to the agricultural and horticultural sector in Europe, including those not affected by Xylella. The financial consequences can be enormous. If we make the switch to a closed import system, the research costs of allowing certain plant and tree species into the European market can be as high as EUR 50 000 per species, and we certainly do not want that.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Madam President, today we are discussing this topic due to a really dangerous infection affecting the olive growing sector. Certainly the most dangerous imported into the European Union is Xylella fastidiosa. In the south of Italy, the consequences are dramatic. 11 million infected trees will be cut down.  Since the disease is transmitted by insects, olive groves of neighbouring Croatia and other Mediterranean countries are at risk. It has already been spotted on the stem of coffee in France, and we all hope that it is not the cause of the drying of olives in Istria. Olive milk disease already led to the growth of production in Croatia last year, because production amounted to only 10-15% of the average annual production. With the residual cocoons of olive milk and the spread of peacock eye diseases, the prognosis is just as bad for this year.  Therefore, I call on the Commission to approve, in addition to effective control measures on imported products, additional resources to at least partially mitigate the huge financial losses of olive growers and oil producers in the last year. Olive growing is much more than an agricultural branch, it is the basis of millennial crops. Let's protect him today so it lasts even longer.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Madam President, this is indeed a serious threat that is happening in the south of Italy. What worries me particularly is this measure we've heard from the commissioner, which is the felling of trees. So I understand that this is one of the measures, but at the same time a threat to the landscape, a threat to the landscape. I think we should focus on research, like you said, and resources from Horizon, or Horizon. In Croatia, in particular, 45,000 households are engaged in olive growing and they are also at risk due to some other diseases. However, there is a danger that this bacterium Xylella will also be transported to the long adriatic coast. Therefore, all prevention measures should really be taken.  But my question is to the Commission: How will you help small producers make up for these costs, which will happen by emasca? You mentioned rural development, however, what is the fund from which small producers in Italy will at the moment, and tomorrow perhaps elsewhere because there is a danger to both vines and citrus fruits, how will you help to recoup the costs?

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: S&D). Madam President, the emergence of Xylella bacteria in Italian olive trees must act as a distress signal for the relevant services in other countries. Xylella is transmitted by insects and not only destroys olive trees but also many other plants, such as vines and citrus fruits. We fully agree with the Commission's measures, although they have been taken too slowly, and we would like to add that vigilance is required from the authorities of the Member States and information to the rural world. In the United States where california vines were affected, there was a combined effort by producers, researchers and state actors that limited the spread. However, no overall treatment has yet been developed. European research on the species of insects carrying the bacterium and on how to protect plants from them should therefore be intensified. Also, because so far the only method of control is grubbing-up, there should be direct producer compensation so that the affected trees can be replaced. This will work positively to better work with them so that there is a direct report of outbreaks of infection before they become uncontrollable.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Commissioner, we are sounding the alarm, because Xylella has created enormous problems in Italy, as colleagues have pointed out very pointed out. Eleven million olive trees have already been cut and burned. You understand that this is an economic disaster for olive growers in Italy which may, in future, affect others.  In Greece olive production has been one of the main, traditional activities in the rural economy for centuries. Greek olive growers have already been affected by the memorandum's policy, they have already been affected by the fruitlessness that hit trees in 2013. We cannot think that the trees will be cut down, that there will be this total destruction. We are therefore calling for immediate measures to tackle the problem, a ban on imports of plants from third countries and provision for compensation, because we cannot accept the dismantling of the agricultural economy and olive growers in our country, Crete and other regions.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on 3 April, France imposed a de facto embargo on 102 Apulian agricultural products which it considers to be infected with Xylella, not on products from the infected area, but on products from throughout the region.  Our farmers are at a great time, but what is the Commission doing? It accepts the umpteenth limit on free movement impassively, and France has set a good example. Since that day Morocco and Algeria have done the same. Commissioner, until proven otherwise, France is part of the single market and Morocco has signed a free trade treaty with us, with which it literally fills us with cheap agricultural products. By the way, infected plants have entered France, only they were not Apulian but South American, yet I do not think that France has closed its borders with South America.  While Apulian farmers are waiting for real answers, the risk of other countries following France's example is very high and the Commission's insecurity, Commissioner, is simply unacceptable.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is an ecological and economic disaster.  What everyone has said a little bit is not to leave the farmers alone and try to make up for this shortcoming which is really becoming, as they said, a kind of Ebola and this must be done by Europe. But I also take my cue from this speech to say that just a few minutes ago (before we talked about Expo) there are the antagonists who have already arrived in Milan and have already written on the windows, they are messing around in the center of Milan. Those people there are the scum of society and they have to be arrested and first a Tsipras figure spoke saying that an MP was going near them. You too should be ashamed that maybe you secretly go to the McDonald's or drink Coca-Cola. This is the crap of Europe that we have elements in here that help criminals, criminals and then do demagoguery here, then secretly drink Coca-Cola and eat the McDonald's burger.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Madam President, in recent years European olive growers have been experiencing a turbulent period. From record harvests to droughts, floods and various other slears. The appearance of diseases caused by the Xylella fastidiosa bacteria in Italy and the possibility of spreading the disease to the olives of neighboring countries, causes fear. The European Commission says it is working with state and local authorities, but it is unclear what preventive and anti-disease measures have been taken to ensure that olive growers know how to handle the disease properly in time. I ask that the European Commission and the Council find a way to adequately indemnce olive producers. Only in this way will we be sure that everyone will take all necessary measures to prevent further spread of the disease. Fortunately, there is no occurrence of this disease in Croatia. Croatian olive groves, and some more than 1000 years old, are a historical and cultural heritage, a world heritage site. In the surroundings of clean sea and harsh bare stone, Croatian olive growers have been producing extra virgin olive oil for centuries. We aim to preserve such production, so I ask for strict phytosanitary measures to be applied and citizens to prevent the transmission of diseases by transferring plants between Member States.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, yesterday the decision taken by the EU Plant Health Committee to eradicate sick trees in the infected areas of all host plants within a radius of two kilometres, as a Pugliese, did not make me happy, but rather an extreme remedy for an absolute evil.  I call on the Commission to speed up its efforts in favour of Apulian farmers and to assume the financial burden of safeguarding at-risk farmers and the olive oil supply chain. In a region already on its knees by the economic crisis, it is not acceptable to proceed with the eradication of olive trees, resulting in the loss of almost 7 000 jobs without a rescue plan. Damage to the integrity of our natural heritage and to the dignity of those farmers who witness the felling of their cultivated trees with the same love with which they raise their children.  No, Commissioner, Puglia and the Apulians do not deserve to be abandoned! It is time for Europe to show that it is close to the problems of its citizens, and this Parliament has shown that it is united because colleagues from all the countries of the European Union have spoken.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I have listened with attention to honourable Members’ interventions, concerns, warnings and proposals on this delicate subject. They will be fully taken on board when elaborating further response measures. I share your views that we need measures, such as the ones presented by the Commission and endorsed by the Member States, which are based on scientific and technical bases. Their implementation should not be delayed. Furthermore, a new set of measures will be examined with a sense of urgency. Movements of plants out of the demarcated area in Italy and imports from third countries have to be subject to very strict conditions. At the same time, eradication measures have to be taken in the infected area in Italy to reduce the presence of the bacterium and prevent its spread in the Union. The Commission is determined to further intensify scientific research for Xylella treatment, involving the Horizon 2020 programme. Honourable Members, let me express my deepest understanding of how difficult it is for a farmer to remove a tree, especially when it has not yet been proven to be infected. It is our common responsibility to convince all actors of the benefits of such measures to prevent the spread of the disease in Italy and beyond. In conclusion, let me assure you that the Commission is ready to explore all possible tools available to support financially the implementation of the compensation measures provided in our legislation.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place in the next plenary session. I thank my fellow Members for their disciplined behaviour in the timeframe. And given that we don't have 12 hours and four minutes left, I'm ordering a recess until the vote. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Xylella fastidiosa poses a threat not only to olive cultivation in southern European countries. This bacterium can attack several hundred different species of plants, m.in. vines, fruit trees, grasses and cereals. It has already destroyed crops in North and South American countries on several occasions, and in October 2013 the Italian authorities informed them of its presence in the EU. So far, no effective drug has been found that would be able to help infected plants, and the removal of infected organisms does not stop the development of the disease. The potential damage that Xylella fastidiosa can do will have a very serious impact on our continent's economy and environment. Furthermore, according to the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), the costs that it will have to be tackled if the pathogen spreads will be extremely high. The European Commission must immediately take appropriate steps to curb the expansion of bacteria, focusing on strengthening controls on imported goods. Nevertheless, it is also important to compensate farmers who have lost their crops as a result of the epidemic and have incurred severe costs.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. European producers of olive oil from the Mediterranean arc are now facing the danger posed by the olive-killing bacterium, Xylella fastidiosa. The latter has already wreaked havoc in Italy in 2013 (Puglia) leading to the slaughter of tens of thousands of olive trees but also to that of the surrounding plants. Faced with Xylella fastidiosa there is currently no treatment and its rapid spread via other species worries the agricultural world. The Standing Committee on Plants, Animals, Food and Feed (PAFF) has indicated that it wants to strengthen prevention measures against the bacteria in order to prevent its spread. While the total ban on the importation of coffee trees from Honduras and Costa Rica (3 infected plants discovered last April in Rungis) is a step in the right direction, it is regrettable that the Commission did not wish to extend the bans to other plants (more than 200 species) from third countries where the presence of the bacterium is proven (Brazil, USA...). Corsica plans to ban the introduction of plants. This will be effective if the number of waivers does not explode. We see here the economic and ecological damage caused by globalisation and ultraliberalism encouraged by Brussels.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. We are facing a real phytosanitary emergency that now affects olive groves in southern Italy, but which could potentially expand and affect other crops and regions of Europe.  The scale is worrying, especially in terms of its economic, environmental and social consequences. Unfortunately, scientific research is lagging behind both in terms of the analysis of triggers and in terms of possible solutions or remedies to the emergency. The eradication plan ordered by the European Commission, as a preventive measure, has imposed the destruction of millions of olive trees, in the hope of blocking the spread of bacteria to other regions or crops. In support of this painful decision, we have EFSA's view that the destruction of trees is a valid choice once the disease has been detected as present in a particular, precisely circumscribed area. However, we cannot fail to share the strong concern of the producers and populations concerned.  We therefore call on the Commission to provide for adequate and immediate compensation for producers for economic losses and we call for more stringent phytosanitary control measures to be taken on imports into the European Union.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the vote. (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Madam President, I would just like to thank the co-signers and colleagues who signed the written declaration 2015/004 to combat violence against women and dedicate a year to this phenomenon. This is the first written declaration to receive a majority of signatures since the introduction of the new system. Colleagues, keep signing because the deadline is May 9.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: We are impressed, Mr Tarabella.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, just to give the sad news that Father Gruner missed last night in Canada, bringing to our Parliament the blessed statue of Our Lady of Fatima, founder of the World Apostolate of Fatima. A thought and a prayer in memory of this great man of prayer and peace.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: Chairman of the ENVI Committee. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her On behalf of the committee, we would like to request that the final vote on the legislative resolution be postponed and we try to reach an agreement with the Council in the trialogue. I would ask you to give your assent to suspend the vote.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: – Madam President, the oral amendment proposes to divide Amendment 5 into two paragraphs. The first would end according to the formula 'To proceed with the conclusion and entry into force of the Establishment and Association Agreement' and the second paragraph should begin – and here is the novelty – with the formula 'welcomes the long-awaited entry into force of the SAA set for 1 June 2015, which will allow Bosnia and Herzegovina to move forward in the EU integration process and open up the Reform Agenda for the benefit of the country.'  The rest of the amendment remains the same. I would like, on this occasion, to thank all my colleagues in the political groups for their cooperation.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: –  Doamnă președintă, vă mărturisesc că nu înțeleg de ce colegii s-au opus consemnării faptului că Acordul de Asociere va intra în vigoare. Mi se pare pur și simplu absurd - dar în fine! Amendamentul pe care îl propun acum, după paragraful 21, se referă la atacurile teroriste recente. Sper că, în această privință măcar, vom avea un consens.  Citez acest amendament:  ‘Strongly condemns the terrorist attack perpetrated on 27 April 2015 on a police station in the eastern Bosnian town of Zvornik, which claimed the life of one policeman and injured two others; expresses its solidarity with the victims and their families; condemns in the strongest terms the violent extremist ideology behind this attack; calls on the competent authorities, responsible security agencies and judicial institutions to cooperate in conducting a swift and thorough investigation and preventing future attacks; expresses hope that the institutions and citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina will come together in combating the threat of terrorism and extremist violence.’

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: – Madam President, our voting lists have 120 pages in these three days. If we pressed them on both sides, we'd save 45,000 sheets, or 5 to 6 meters of paper. Maybe someone can hear my words, maybe someone'll fix it next time.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: We are working on it.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Adina-Ioana VĂLEAN
text: The next item is the explanations of vote. We start with those that could not be taken yesterday.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, I voted in favour of this report on the EU Alcohol Strategy.  In Ireland, alcohol measures cost an estimated EUR 3.7 billion a year, working out at over EUR 3 000 per tax payer. Unsurprisingly, allowing alcohol companies to self-regulate has failed to tackle the serious public health and public disturbance costs alcohol has for our society. One of the world’s largest drink companies, Diageo, has recently stepped down from a so-called ‘responsible drinking’ campaign in Ireland, where its attempts to tamper with, and dampen, the public health message were clear. It is unfortunate that alcohol sponsorship in sporting events was not included by the Irish government in its alcohol bill earlier this year. Well-funded positive images of alcohol use from companies such as Diageo outweigh those of public health campaigns and have a powerful influence on young people. It is the role of Member States to counter this influence. Information and education campaigns can play a key role here, whilst the European Commission should help to share best practice. I welcome the reference in the report to a nutritional labelling regulation, because the Commission is dragging its feet. It was meant to come forward in December with a report on the possibility of including alcohol in nutritional labelling with a view to proposing legislation. If we are able to know the calorie content of a Mars bar, what, apart from industry concerns for their profit margins, is stopping us from knowing the same information for alcoholic beverages?

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this report on the EU alcohol strategy. It is vitally important that Member States take the necessary steps to tackle the causes and effect of alcohol consumption and addiction.  Unfortunately in Ireland there are many families affected, directly or indirectly, by alcohol addiction. As my colleague has said, education campaigns and the availability of information play a key role in addressing this problem. However, self-regulation has failed. Such campaigns are particularly important in informing young people of the implications of alcohol consumption for their health and well-being.  Indeed, we see a number of products, such as alcopops, that are marketed towards young people. From my work on the Tobacco Products Directive, I am very aware of the effects the labelling of tobacco products can have, so it is encouraging to see a reference to the nutritional labelling regulation in this strategy.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I am rationing myself at the moment as an MP elected in the Czech Republic, a country that we know by proglysing excellent quality beer and also by the high consumption of this alcohol. I voted in favour of this report, but I would like to explain that I am concerned about the name on this report, which is misleading. This report should not be called the 'Alcohol Report', but 'alcoholism'. This is a resolution that is aimed at combating alcohol overuse, against the risks of alcoholism, not alcohol itself, with particular emphasis precisely on the protection of pregnant women and adolescents. I think it would be easier for the European public to understand the name 'Report on Alcoholism'. However, I agree that this report proposes an increase in the age limit for alcohol consumption over 18 years of age, which is not self-evident everywhere in Europe. It is also important to reduce the availability of very cheap alcohol and responsible advertising. On the basis of recent tragic experiences in my own country with the methanol affair, I welcome the call on the Commission and the Member States to strengthen control in the fight against the production of virgin alcohol.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of EU-wide labelling on the calorie content of alcohol beverages and also supported the need for an EU-wide label warning pregnant women not to consume alcohol. I consider that this is a very important issue, especially when we look at the consequences of foetal alcohol syndrome. Indeed in Ireland, when we export alcoholic beverages to the US, they contain that label of a pregnant women with a line through her, but we do not have it at home. That makes absolutely no sense. I personally have an aversion to the nanny state, but I think that putting information on bottles containing alcoholic beverages is a sensible and reasonable idea. I also think it is reasonable to consider labelling which will alert consumers to the dangers of drink-driving. In Ireland we have had some success – our roads are somewhat safer – because of a sustained campaign and crackdown on drink-driving. Labelling is just one possibility but, given the often horrific consequences of drink-driving, I think we should consider all reasonable alternatives.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on a resolution calling on the Commission to launch a new alcohol strategy for the EU. A responsible alcohol policy is urgent, and the social dimension of the issue is important to me. At the same time, however, these issues belong at national level for obvious subsidiary reasons. Nevertheless, I chose to vote in favour of the resolution for two reasons. Firstly, the resolution addresses the need for alcohol products to also be subject to the labelling requirements for other foodstuffs. It seems unreasonable that alcohol today has a sour cream in that regard. Secondly, there are strong wordings on subsidiarity in the resolution. On the other hand, I would like to stress that I am critical of the wording on harmonising the age limits for alcohol purchases in the Union.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Alcohol Strategy approved during this April session will serve as a guideline for the European Commission's subsequent alcohol policy. Since the beginning of this parliamentary term, our delegation has been very sensitive and attentive to issues affecting European consumers. We believe that this strategy can help the consumer to have more information about alcoholic beverages through the labelling of the calories contained by them. Other important issues contained in the text are: the collection of data on alcohol consumption, the online sale of alcohol products and the advertising of alcoholic beverages to minors, the consumption of alcohol during pregnancy and binge drinking, that is, the intake by the very young of more alcoholic beverages in a short period of time. We believe that this strategy can help our country even more in controlling the intake of quality alcoholic beverages. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists voted in favour of a new EU alcohol strategy, as we believe that inaction is not justified given that, in the EU, 25% of all youth deaths (20-39 years old) are due to alcohol; that alcohol abuse is also recognized as the cause of more than sixty chronic diseases and that the social costs that can be attributed to alcohol are estimated at around EUR 155.8 billion.  We welcome the fact that the rest of the House has supported our amendment on the maintenance of measures for the promotion and information of the wine sector, in which we have included references to the CAP Regulations and actions for information and promotion of agricultural products approved in the previous parliamentary term.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety since I share your concern that Europe has the highest rates of alcohol consumption globally, which means that excessive or harmful alcohol consumption is the third leading cause of preventable diseases and a risk factor for more than sixty chronic diseases , including cancer and cardiovascular problems. The EU published a strategy in 2006 with the aim of cooperating with Member States and other actors to coordinate actions to reduce alcohol-related damage. However, few actions have been taken. This report calls on the new European Commission to work in this regard. Since numerous requests from my group on the importance of information and the correct labelling of alcoholic products, as well as for greater regulation of advertising and the commitment to prevention campaigns among young people, were included in the text, I have decided to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. Alcohol consumption patterns and trends vary considerably from country to country in Europe, particularly for health-risk consumption. To deal with alcohol-related damage, I support the European strategy which has already produced positive results. We need to renew it while improving its effectiveness. By enabling better information and proper education, this strategy should encourage moderate and responsible consumption and above all warn against excessive and dangerous consumption of alcohol.  The mentions of calories, ingredients and the nutritional value of products, such as a mandatory minimum price, cannot, in my opinion, be effective and sufficiently deterrent tools to combat these excesses, especially in the countries of the southern European Union, where alcohol consumption has been declining for several years, mainly due to moderate alcohol consumption. , relying mainly on quality products such as wine.  For these reasons, I supported the promotion of moderate and responsible wine consumption and voted against the labelling amendments.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This resolution calls on the European Parliament and the Committee on the Environment from the European Commission to formulate a European Strategy to deal with the negative consequences of alcohol abuse.  It is very important to have a European strategy that will continue the very good work of the previous one. However, the cultural habits of each people must also be taken into account and a distinction must be made between abuse and rational consumption.  For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution of the Committee on the Environment.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Excessive consumption of alcohol is the third most common cause of preventable deaths and illnesses in Europe. However, alcohol abuse can lead not only to numerous chronic diseases, but also to other problems such as social exclusion. It is therefore very important that the alcohol strategy, which expired in 2012, be replaced. The main tools for the prevention of alcohol abuse should be information campaigns, in particular aimed at young people and pregnant women, and the promotion of a healthy lifestyle. In addition, investments will be made in education in order to understand the behaviours of those affected and cultural differences in alcohol consumption and to be able to intervene more specifically. In order to curb alcohol abuse and promote responsible use of alcohol, I welcome the measures taken under the new alcohol strategy.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. The amendments voted are intended to take into account local realities, a key step in dealing with the issue of alcohol, in the sense that it must be dealt with in the sense of cultural peculiarities. In this, I voted for the promotion of the know-how of local craftsmen, for the fight against unfair competition, for an increased visibility of their interests.   Furthermore, the proposed amendments emphasize the need to take health logics into account as a matter of priority. It is not a question of denying the harms that may have been caused by the abuse of alcohol-related products, but of finding the right balance between denouncing them and promoting healthier lifestyles.   Finally, it should be remembered that this area of competence must be protected from the interference of supranational institutions in the local economic policy of States and remain under the strict and unique jurisdiction of states in order for them to conduct a national policy in the direction of their interests. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of transparency, my constituents have a right to know that I voted against this resolution.  The United Kingdom should be perfectly capable of drafting our own legislation on alcohol.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: in writing. ‒ The EU should not be involved in deciding the alcohol strategy of nation states.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union is one of the top alcohol consumers in the world, with an annual average of 10.7 litres per person (aged 15 or older). The misuse of alcohol is one of the major causes of preventable death and of diseases such as liver and heart disease and cancer. It has been estimated that the social cost of alcohol misuse is more than EUR 150 billion per year. At the moment the Commission is doing nothing to solve the alcohol misuse problem. Therefore, I support Ms Willmott’s resolution urging it to take action. The Commission had an Alcohol Strategy from 2006 to 2012: however, it was not renewed after its expiration in 2013. I believe that an immediate and effective strategy is needed for the upcoming years in order to raise awareness about important issues such as drink driving and drinking while pregnant. It is essential for the wellbeing of our society that the new strategy is adopted as soon as possible. I hope that this resolution will make the Commission take further steps with regard to this issue.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to call on the Commission to develop a new EU alcohol strategy (2016-2022) and to encourage labels for alcoholic beverages to indicate their energy value, as alcohol is very high-calorie, but many do not know. I agree that consumers have the right to a clear and fair labelling of alcoholic beverages in order to make the right decisions based on objective knowledge. The objectives of the new strategy are to help national governments reduce alcohol-related harm, support the collection of reliable data, promote prevention, health education and education, early diagnosis, improve treatment opportunities, provide continued support to addicts and their families, including psychological counselling programmes, and reduce the number of road accidents related to alcohol consumption, etc. in 2010. In Europe, the social costs associated directly or indirectly with regard to alcohol abuse amounted to EUR 155.8 billion. Euro. Alcohol abuse kills 3.3 million people every year. 5.9% of all deaths, harmful alcohol consumption is the third highest possible cause of preventable disease and causes of death in Europe, with alcohol linked to more than 60 chronic diseases, including cancer, heart and liver disease and obesity. In addition, alcohol abuse is linked to other social problems, including absenteeism, divorce and violence. In addition, Europe consumes the most alcohol worldwide.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. It is with dismay that I observe that we are once again seeking to follow the hygienicism of the United States, a country where alcohol consumption is generally prohibited for under-21s... and where at the same time the sad "binge drinking" fashion has developed. In addition to seeking to impose legislation on member states in an area outside the EU's jurisdiction, this "strategy" does not offer any consideration to guarantee the protection of traditional farms and production. However, it is the latter that should be defended in the face of counterfeiting.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. The EU's alcohol strategy aims to help governments coordinate their measures to reduce alcohol damage in the EU. Excessive alcohol consumption causes 3.3 million premature deaths worldwide each year and about 25% of deaths of young people between the age of 20 and 39 are beverage-related. This strategy will allow us to work together to reduce consumption among young people, alert risks and improve the prevention and treatment of alcoholism. We are also pleased that the text we have supported provides for an exception for the wine sector, which can continue to benefit from European agricultural product promotion programmes.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported the Final Resolution on the Strategy in Alcohol Materials, having supported the amendment calling for strengthening campaigns for the promotion of moderate wine consumption, in order to raise consumer awareness of responsible and intelligent consumption and to intensify the dissemination of information on wine characteristics , geographical indications, grape varieties, manufacturing processes and traditional mentions.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This proposal for a resolution on alcohol strategy follows a question with an oral response to the Commission.  Such a proposal can only be subject to criticism, since such a framework of recommendations will justify more concrete measures that will then have to apply to all States, despite their cultural differences, particularly in the area of food and alcohol consumption. While it is of course that the fight against alcohol abuse, against alcoholism trends and in favour of the protection of young people are laudable causes, it should not be forgotten that this text is akin to interference in private affairs. Moreover, the proposal does not address the fight against the trafficking of counterfeit alcohol, nor does it propose anything to guarantee the protection of traditional farms and productions. Given these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not intend to support this resolution expressly calling for nutrition labelling for all spirits. I believe that such a structured proposal favours standardised producers at the expense of our quality productions protected by geographical indications. I also believe that this text deliberately ignores the cultural value that moderate and responsible consumption of alcoholic beverages, such as wines, has throughout Europe but above all in Italy. As with all things, the problem is not in use, but in abuse.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists voted in favour of a new EU alcohol strategy, as we believe that inaction is not justified given that, in the EU, 25% of all youth deaths (20-39 years old) are due to alcohol; that alcohol abuse is also recognized as the cause of more than sixty chronic diseases and that the social costs that can be attributed to alcohol are estimated at around EUR 155.8 billion.  We welcome the fact that the rest of the House has supported our amendment on the maintenance of measures for the promotion and information of the wine sector, in which we have included references to the CAP Regulations and actions for information and promotion of agricultural products approved in the previous parliamentary term.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this resolution because it calls on the European Parliament to update the EU resolution on the EU Strategy against Alcohol for the period 2016-2022. Alcohol abuse is one of the most common causes of lifestyle-related diseases in EU countries, and dependence on alcohol leads to the risk of more than 60 chronic diseases. Kamet's binge drinking leads to 3.3 million deaths. early deaths in the EU, representing 5.9% of all deaths. In the 20-39 age group, a quarter of all deaths are alcohol-related. Parliament believes that the forthcoming EU alcohol strategy must aim to update the regulatory framework to help national governments reduce alcohol-related harm, support monitoring and the collection of reliable data, promote prevention, health education and education, early diagnosis, improve treatment options, provide continued support to addicts and their families, including psychological counselling programmes, and reduce the number of road accidents associated with alcohol consumption and better differentiate drinking habits , behavioural patterns and attitudes towards alcohol consumption.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes to this motion for a resolution because alcohol consumption in Europe is an issue that should be dealt with and a European alcohol strategy is probably the best way to do that. Nonetheless I strongly recommend that we also take into account the peculiarities of each Member State, since the relevance of alcohol abuse and alcohol-related problems vary greatly from one country to another.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament adopts with this resolution a clear and distinct position on the alcohol strategy in the Member States in order to respond to concerns related to the wrong, non-moderate and non-responsible use of alcoholic beverages. It cannot be denied that the harmful use of alcohol is still a cause of preventable death and a risk factor for many chronic diseases. However, an alcohol strategy in Europe cannot overlook the excellence of many alcoholic beverages that envy us all over the world and which make up a large part of European exports to third countries. I am thinking of the quantity of PDO and DOCG PGI wines and spirits which, only in my country, enrich the cultural and historical heritage of each region and whose very high quality and importance cannot be called into question, but must be protected and promoted. An alcohol strategy in Europe must therefore take into account the prevention of alcohol-related diseases, but it cannot underestimate the importance and value of the agri-food sector linked to the production of alcoholic beverages. We cannot run the risk of demonising alcohol consumption to the detriment of the cultural and socio-economic heritage linked to the wine production of many Member States.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The issue of alcohol consumption is being debated by specialists around the world, and there is a lot of controversy on the basis of this topic. Is moderate alcohol consumption healthy? If so, what does moderate mean? Also, alcohol consumption among minors is a serious problem and that raises many questions. Almost 4% of deaths worldwide were blamed by WHO specialists on excessive alcohol consumption. This number is worrying, surpassing the number of victims caused by HIV/AIDS and tuberculosis. Moreover, the figures show that, annually, alcohol abuse causes 3.3 million deaths, and the most alarming thing is that the age group is 20-39 years. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 'Alcohol Strategy', as the current EU strategy needs to be renewed, with alcohol abuse being the second leading cause of lifestyle illness adopted by citizens in some Member States. In this context, the Commission is invited to work closely with the Member States to develop a European action plan to reduce the harmful effects of alcohol consumption.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote was no. The resolution expressly calls for nutrition labelling for all alcoholic beverages. This markedly dirigiste and ethical approach is to be rejected at the root for several reasons, not least because it ignores the cultural value that the (moderate and responsible) consumption of alcoholic beverages such as wine has in some European countries (Italy on all). In addition, nutrition labelling presupposes that the alcoholic beverage is taken for feeding purposes, while today it is commonly understood as pleasure and proof of connection with the territory. This measure will benefit the large producers to the detriment of the small ones.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists voted in favour of a new EU alcohol strategy, as we believe that inaction is not justified given that, in the EU, 25% of all youth deaths (20-39 years old) are due to alcohol; that alcohol abuse is also recognized as the cause of more than sixty chronic diseases and that the social costs that can be attributed to alcohol are estimated at around EUR 155.8 billion.  We welcome the fact that the rest of the House has supported our amendment on the maintenance of measures for the promotion and information of the wine sector, in which we have included references to the CAP Regulations and actions for information and promotion of agricultural products approved in the previous parliamentary term.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution calling on the European Commission to develop a strategy for preventing the dangers of alcohol. Alcohol policies are mainly the responsibility of Member States, given the cultural and territorial differences in this area. However, a coordinated European strategy is needed to reduce the damage caused by excess alcohol. We need to increase prevention campaigns on the dangers of alcohol for drivers or pregnant women. Young people also need to be more aware of its dangerous effects. As such, I am in favour of the introduction of an age limit of 18 years for the consumption of alcohol throughout the European Union and the ban on the use of public money for the promotion of alcoholic beverages.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: in writing. I voted against the motion for a Resolution on the alcohol strategy for a number of reasons, but above all because I do not find that the concepts are sufficiently clear. What is the scope of the term 'alcohol'? What drinks does it include? What does "minimum price" mean? In my view, setting a minimum price would be detrimental to certain sectors as well as SMEs; we only have to think about the countries of southern Europe, large exporters of alcoholic beverages, which have done their best to innovate and strengthen their productive and commercial activity to adapt to the changes introduced in their sector. Moreover, it is not easy to talk about strategies when very different consumption habits coexist in the Union. Nor can it be said that, for example, there is a direct relationship between the price of alcohol and the level of consumption. In fact, in countries where alcohol is highly taxed, consumption is very high. Nor do I agree with the idea of restricting the use of public funds for the promotion of important sectors of our economy, such as agriculture, or moving forward with labelling standards without thinking about the adaptation needs of companies.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of a new EU alcohol strategy. In Europe, more than 7% of cases of early death occur from alcohol-related problems. 25% of young males between the ages of 15 and 29 lose their lives precisely because they drink too much.  The Commission must therefore start work as soon as possible on the new EU alcohol strategy (2016-2022) in order to add value to national policies. More can be done against drink-driving, effective data collection of alcohol consumption in all Member States must be carried out, action must be taken on the advertising of alcoholic beverages to minors, on the consumption of alcohol during pregnancy and on binge drinking, which is increasingly taking hold among adolescents. However, good mediation must also be found between the positions of countries such as Great Britain, where alcohol abuse is a serious health and public order problem, and countries such as Italy and Belgium, where there is a real culture of quality wine and beer consumption. The goal of the strategy is not to discourage moderate consumption, but to support the adoption of healthy lifestyles.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this important resolution as it aims to provide solutions to alcohol-related harm. This is the third highest cause of preventable premature death and disease in Europe and it is a serious problem both in Ireland and across Europe. Excessive drinking is an extremely serious public health issue, which takes a heavy human toll on individuals, families and the community at large. Sinn Féin’s alcohol strategy focuses on preventing the negative impacts of alcohol on the unborn and on young people, as well as in the workplace and in relation to road safety. Unfortunately, industry lobbying prevented the mandatory labelling of the calorie count in alcoholic drinks, but we want the Commission to revisit that issue. The Commission had a mandate to report on this requirement, which was due last December, and we are still waiting for it. Prevention and the stringent enforcement of legislation to prevent the sale of alcohol to minors are absolute priorities at a time when drinking habits and patterns are causing serious harm.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Alcohol consumption and the resulting harm are issues within the EU strategy to coordinate national governments' actions to reduce alcohol consumption and diseases. The EU Alcohol and Health Information System (EUSAH) monitors its trends and developments. However, what needs to be taken into account in implementing this strategy is the control by labelling the ingredients and nutritional values of alcoholic beverages, ensuring a more transparent and correct service to the consumer.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as a whole because I believe we must do all we can to tackle the problem of alcoholism and the phenomenon of excessive drinking, especially by young people. However, I voted against those amendments calling for significant changes to the labelling of different alcohols. I do not believe that adding the calorie count of a particular drink will greatly affect the drinking habits of people today or lead Europeans to adopt a healthier lifestyle. It is just one more distraction on already crowded labels.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution on the alcohol strategy because it misses the real issues in this area, while advocating an expansion of the EU's powers. Thus, despite their common sense, the amendments which tended to promote respect for the interests of companies or the fight against unfair competition in the field were rejected. At the same time, the resolution is positioning itself in favour of a European alcohol strategy by refusing to take into account the cultural differences between Member States; the patriotic members of the National Front had tried to remind the ENVI committee that French gastronomy - of which alcohol is a part - is part of UNESCO's intangible heritage; but the other Members, including the other French Members, refused to take this into consideration. Moreover, if the fight against alcoholism is a laudable objective, it must remain the competence of the Member States. Finally, no proposal is made in the resolution to strengthen border control to combat the trafficking of counterfeit alcohol.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ We had an alcohol strategy in place from 2006 until 2012, focused on preventing the negative impacts of alcohol on the unborn and our youth, as well as in the workplace and in relation to road safety. We want it back. Unfortunately, industry lobbying prevented the mandatory labelling of the calorie count in alcoholic drinks but we want the Commission to revisit the issue. The Commission had a mandate to report on this requirement, which was due last December, and we are still waiting for it. The right wing voted to restrict the scope of the demand to so-called ‘alcopops’, but thankfully a majority of colleagues defeated that. It is a matter of information, awareness and consumer choice, which even the European brewing industry has come to support. Prevention and the stringent enforcement of legislation to prevent the sale of alcohol to minors are absolute priorities at a time when very worrisome drinking habits and patterns are causing serious harm.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 As a co-sponsor I have followed this resolution very closely. I believe that the text is a good compromise, given the attention paid to producing SMEs and the cultural distinction between practices in Northern and Southern Europe. I am a little sceptical about certain aspects, such as labelling, because I believe that education is much more important, but I am pleased that I have managed to include in the text important references also for the promotion of alcohol products (especially wine) within the framework of the promotion of the territory and its culture.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Alcohol abuse is the second leading cause of lifestyle-related illness in some Member States, representing a risk factor in more than 60 chronic diseases. In addition, a quarter of road traffic accidents may be related to driving under the influence of alcohol. It is therefore essential that the European Union has a common strategy in this area to reduce the harm caused by alcohol and its dependence and to support moderate and responsible consumption. Although the competent authorities of each Member State are better prepared to develop individual policies adapted to their realities, as consumption patterns have distinct social, cultural, geographical and economic variations, I consider it essential to cooperate closely between member states and the European Commission in combating this transnational problem. It is necessary to organise education campaigns for the general public and the most vulnerable groups, such as pregnant women and minors, regulate the marketing of alcoholic beverages, label it in a demanding manner, allowing for easy perception for consumers, and to set quantifiable policy targets for monitoring progress. For these reasons, I support this Resolution.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: Writing. Alcohol production is an important part of European culture, safeguards millions of jobs in Europe and has great economic benefits. On the other hand, we must take into account the negative effects of excessive alcohol consumption and not ignore the consequences. On the positive side, we are addressing the problem of alcohol abuse at European level. In order to combat alcohol abuse effectively, we in Europe can learn from each other. However, I also agree with those who say that much of what we can and must do falls primarily within the competence of the Member States and that the principle of subsidiarity must be applied. As a member of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I also see a need for improvement in some places. I believe that we do not need a uniform minimum age across Europe. This regulation should be left to the Member States because there are different experiences and models in the handling of alcoholic beverages such as wine, beer and spirits in different countries. In my opinion, the resolution should also not set targets for minimum prices.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on a strategy on the consumption of alcoholic beverages, believing that a serious commitment on the part of the European Union to combat alcohol abuse, alongside the Member States and respecting the principle of subsidiarity, is very timely.  Alcohol consumption is the third leading cause of death in Europe, a risk factor for 60 chronic diseases, including cancer and obesity, or circulatory and liver-related problems. Moreover, considering that alcoholism can also have negative consequences on the family and work sphere of the affected subjects, it is also the cause of relational and social problems. I therefore support this resolution. I hope that the European Commission will soon develop a new strategy that includes the definition of specific objectives and the annual evaluation of the results achieved and that it will help the Member States to reduce the health, safety and socio-economic problems caused by alcohol abuse.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe that every effort must be made to help national governments reduce the harm caused by alcohol. In addition, we must make everyone aware of a reduction in the use of alcohol, especially by young people, by hindering intake, especially in large quantities, with the sole aim of losing control of themselves.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety since I share your concern that Europe has the highest rates of alcohol consumption globally, which means that excessive or harmful alcohol consumption is the third leading cause of preventable diseases and a risk factor for more than sixty chronic diseases , including cancer and cardiovascular problems. The EU published a strategy in 2006 with the aim of cooperating with Member States and other actors to coordinate actions to reduce alcohol-related damage. However, few actions have been taken. This report calls on the new European Commission to work in this regard. Since numerous requests from my group on the importance of information and the correct labelling of alcoholic products, as well as for greater regulation of advertising and the commitment to prevention campaigns among young people, were included in the text, I have decided to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Europe has the highest rate of alcohol consumption in the world. While no one would want to interfere in responsible drinking, Europe needs to act in order to control the health effects of irresponsible and uncontrolled drinking. I also believe that we need to find better ways to protect children who have to live in dire circumstances because of the irresponsible drinking habits of their parents or carers. I agree with the need to work on a new EU Alcohol Strategy (2016-2022) with a view to assisting and supporting Member States in implementing measurable and rigorous policy goals, while respecting the principle of subsidiarity and proportionality. Hence I voted in favour of this report.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. It is essential that issues relating to the effects of alcohol abuse on society be taken into account in national public policies and in European legislation. Therefore, the European Parliament's appeal through this resolution is justified. Nevertheless, it is essential not to confuse alcohol consumption with excessive alcohol consumption. The latter must be combated through effective and targeted prevention and treatment policies to vulnerable populations. However, alcohol consumption, when reasonable, cannot be considered a societal problem. On the contrary, it is a reflection of the cultural habits and gastronomic heritages that make the richness of our regions and Europe. I have therefore not been able to support all the amendments tabled in plenary, but I supported the report as a whole.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – The Alcohol Strategy vote was on the initiative of the European Parliament itself. Parliament wanted to remind the Commission and the Council that alcohol abuse can be as harmful as drug abuse. Although it is important to inform people about the consequences of alcohol abuse, I do not believe that overregulating in this matter works. I believe that the European citizen, when informed, can choose for himself or herself whether or not to drink alcohol. European citizens must have the freedom to make their own informed choices.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, it is crucial to combat the excessive consumption of alcohol responsible for many deaths. In this regard, the emphasis on prevention and education, especially among young people, is a very good thing.  I am pleased to see that the concepts of responsible consumption and culture have been preserved. Reasonable drinking is part of our heritage and we must protect it because our know-how and jobs are at stake.  I am also pleased that the importance of taking into account the consequences for SMEs and the artisanal production of labelling and information obligations on ingredients and nutritional content has been included in the text.  On the other hand I regret the introduction to include calories on bottles. Indicating calories will not solve the problem of alcohol abuse that is the subject of the resolution and raises many questions in terms of applicability.  Finally, I wonder about the proposal to introduce a minimum tariff per unit of alcohol. The implementation of this proposal raises many questions and could create unfair competition and operational problems within the internal market.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. 'Harmful alcohol consumption is still one of the leading causes of illness and premature death in the EU and is a risk factor for more than 60 chronic conditions. Drink-driving remains one of the leading causes of road fatalities. Harmful use of alcohol has also been linked to numerous social problems and causes a lot of human suffering. In addition, the cost to society is estimated at 155.8 billion euros (2010). The non-legislative resolution rightly calls attention to this issue. Prevention and the promotion of a healthy lifestyle remain necessary. At the same time, the text also explicitly emphasises that subsidiarity and proportionality must play a clear role here: the competent authorities in the Member States are indeed best placed to develop a tailor-made policy to prevent and combat the harmful use of alcohol. The EU can support the competent authorities where this provides added value, for example through research, the collection of reliable and comparable data and the exchange of best practices. From this point of view, the N-VA supported the resolution. Nevertheless, the N-VA considers the resolution to be too normative on several points.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. The EU's last alcohol strategy was in 2006. In 2013, the European Commission expressed its intention to put together a plan to reduce alcohol-related harm. The launch of this plan was to take place between May and September 2014. This resolution reminds the Commission of its commitments and calls on it to go further: in addition to the action plan in support of Member States' policies in the fight against alcohol-related harm, the resolution calls for a new comprehensive European strategy. The voted text details several points: labelling calories in alcoholic beverages (of which I am not a supporter), prevention labelling (dangers of drinking and driving; for pregnant women, etc.), reassessment of the use of aromatic substances, protection of minors from the harmful consequences of alcohol abuse, intensification of education on the harms of alcohol consumption, reduction of youth exposure to alcohol advertising , promoting policies for healthy lifestyles, introducing national policies to prevent the sale of very cheap alcohol, etc.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposed resolution on the alcohol strategy. On the one hand, the proposed amendments aim to take into account local realities, a crucial step in dealing with the issue of alcohol, in the sense that it must be dealt with in consideration of cultural peculiarities. In this, I voted for the promotion of the know-how of local craftsmen, for the fight against unfair competition, for an increased visibility of their interests.   On the other hand, the proposed amendments emphasize the need to take health logics into account as a matter of priority. It is not a question of denying the harms that may have been caused by the abuse of alcohol-related products, but of finding the right balance between denouncing them and promoting healthier lifestyles.   Finally, it should be remembered that this area of competence must be protected from the interference of supranational institutions in the local economic policy of States and remain under the strict and unique jurisdiction of states in order for them to conduct a national policy in the direction of their interests.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The alcohol strategy that was established in 2006 can definitely be said to reap success and positive development results for similar strategies in the Member States.  Since it expired in 2012, calls for its renewal have been numerous. The new strategy is expected to launch from 2016 to 2022.  I support the position that this strategy must remain as advisory as it has been so far, while encouraging Member States to develop national ones rather than requiring and forcing countries to take concrete measures.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. – Alcohol abuse claims more than 3 million victims worldwide every year, is also the cause of one in four road accidents and, in 2010 alone, cost Europe as much as EUR 155.8 billion in terms of direct and indirect social costs.  I am therefore voting in favour of this text, which clarifies the serious problem facing Europe with a strategy that is not afraid to go against the private interests of the alcohol industries. For example, as proposed in the text, it is first necessary to invest in advertising campaigns to raise awareness of the most influenced groups, who are now targets of messages calling for alcohol consumption. Reference should also be made to a rethink of the functioning of the European Forum on Alcohol and Health, so that it becomes a place representative of all stakeholders, from economic operators to NGOs, working together on effective and concrete actions to reduce the harm caused by alcohol abuse.  Finally, the text rightly urges the Commission to produce as soon as possible the report on the need to label the ingredients and nutritional values of alcoholic beverages, as provided for in Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The EU is the region of the world with the highest alcohol consumption – twice the world average, with 10.2 litres of pure alcohol per capita in 2010, according to a world health organisation report. The social costs of alcohol in the EU have been estimated at more than €155 billion. Harmful alcohol consumption remains the third leading cause of death and preventable diseases in Europe and a risk factor for more than 60 chronic diseases, including cancer, heart disease and liver disease. Alcohol abuse is also associated with obesity, a major public health problem and the fourth leading cause of preventable diseases in Europe. It is therefore important to realise what proposals the Commission has to put forward on this matter.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of a new EU alcohol strategy, as we believe that inaction is not justified given that, in the EU, 25% of all youth deaths (20-39 years old) are due to alcohol; that abusive alcohol consumption is also recognized as the cause of more than sixty chronic diseases and that significant social costs are derived from it.  I am grateful for the support given by the amendment proposed by the Spanish Socialist delegation on the maintenance of measures to promote and inform the wine sector, in which we have included references to the CAP Regulations and actions for information and promotion of agricultural products approved in the previous parliamentary term, and I would like to draw attention to the importance that institutional support has for the promotion of regional products such as the Asturian cider.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. Alcohol consumption remains one of the leading causes of death in Europe and is associated with a number of preventable diseases. In 2006, the European strategy to support Member States in minimising the harmful effects of alcohol was presented. This strategy has identified priorities that are largely unmet. During the duration of this strategy, the crisis and the policies of social devastation that were implemented in its name not only have brought about new situations of dependence and excessive consumption, but also dismantled in several Member States the necessary responsiveness of public health services at various levels. This resolution calls for concrete measures for the new strategy, including the preparation of a report to assess the need for the inclusion of alcoholic beverages in the labelling regulation providing for information on ingredients and their nutritional content, adding to the need for preventive labelling for pregnant women. Member States are also requested to strengthen their legislation in this area. Member States are also called upon to be responsible in this matter, calling attention to the need for policies and treatments to be implemented in national health systems to help and reduce alcohol problems. Measures that seem right to us and that we support.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ the last strategy to support Member States in reducing alcohol-related harm was only in place until 2012. Alcohol abuse is the second leading cause of lifestyle-related diseases in some Member States, and alcohol dependence is a risk factor for the development of more than 60 chronic diseases, including alcoholic liver disease, alcoholic pancreatitis and almost all digestive tract diseases, cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, obesity, foetal alcohol spectrum disorders and neuropsychiatric disorders such as alcohol dependence. The European Commission must take a more proactive approach to this issue and provide advice on reducing alcohol-related problems, as well as supporting the competent authorities in the Member States.
