The European Commission must actively towards a new European Union strategy on alcohol consumption for 2016-2022.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution expressly calling for nutrition labelling for all spirits. This markedly dirigiste and ethical approach is to be rejected at its root. It ignores the cultural value of the obviously moderate and responsible consumption of alcoholic beverages throughout Europe.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the Alcohol Strategy as a whole because some articles need very significant improvement.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ We all know that, in the European Union, alcohol consumption is a major public health concern, responsible for a great number of diseases and deaths. We are in need, notably, of more education and awareness campaigns to promote healthy lifestyles and discourage binge drinking, and of enforcement laws on the sale of alcohol in order to protect minors and also to prevent the sale of very cheap alcohol. I support a European action plan that supports Member States in implementing measurable, rigorous policy goals, while respecting the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality. We need better information about alcohol abuse. The Alcohol Strategy would result in significant improvements in public health and also in reduced healthcare and social spending for the Member States.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. U2012 Alcohol addiction poses a serious problem for hundreds of thousands of EU citizens, so it in turn is a serious public health problem. We must support measures aimed at educating and raising awareness of the risks associated with alcohol consumption, while supporting those affected to stop drinking alcohol. The social costs that can be attributed directly or indirectly to alcohol were estimated at EUR 155.8 billion in Europe in 2010. The European Commission must immediately begin work on the new EU alcohol strategy (2016-2022), while retaining the same objectives, in order to update the regulatory framework to help national governments address alcohol-related harm.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of a new EU alcohol strategy, because I believe that inaction is not justified given that, in the EU, 25% of youth deaths (20-39 years old) are due to alcohol; that alcohol abuse is also recognized as the cause of more than sixty chronic diseases and that the social costs that can be attributed to alcohol are estimated at around EUR 155.8 billion.  The Socialists have insisted on the necessary distinction between abuse and moderate consumption, since high quality products and tradition, such as wine, have even been recognized for their beneficial effects if consumed in moderation. That is why we welcome the fact that the rest of the House has supported our amendment on the maintenance of measures for the promotion and information of the wine sector, in which we have included references to the CAP Regulations and actions for information and promotion of agricultural products approved in the previous parliamentary term.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. We Spanish Socialists have voted in favour of a new EU alcohol strategy, as we believe that inaction is not justified given that in the EU, 25% of all youth deaths (20-39 years old) are due to alcohol; that alcohol abuse is also recognized as the cause of more than sixty chronic diseases and that the social costs that can be attributed to alcohol are estimated at around EUR 155.8 billion.  We welcome the fact that the rest of the House has supported our amendment on the maintenance of measures for the promotion and information of the wine sector, in which we have included references to the CAP Regulations and actions for information and promotion of agricultural products approved in the previous parliamentary term.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Thanks to the work of the EPP, we have prevented this strategy from being reduced to a sterile prohibition, proposing, on the contrary, an effective action plan that can establish a firm distinction between alcohol abuse, to be struck without ifs and buts, and moderate consumption, which is in no way a risk factor for health. In this way, we have at the same time protected the interest in the health of citizens and protected Italian wine excellence.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. Harmful alcohol consumption causes the deaths of 3.3 million people worldwide, 25% of whom are between the ages of 20 and 39, and is the second reason for the onset of major chronic diseases such as obesity, heart disease, liver disease.  In order to deal with such an alarming phenomenon, I welcome and support the proposal to launch a new European alcohol strategy 2016/2022 as soon as possible, capable of supporting the European WHO 2012-2020 Action Plan against the risks of alcohol abuse and of strengthening the Union's commitment to combating such a difficult battle, using all the instruments at our possession: awareness-raising and information, combating the worrying spread of binge drinking among young people, clarity on the relationship between excessive use of alcohol in pregnancy, support for responsible consumption to reduce health costs, the onset of indirect diseases, the reduction of road accidents and socio-behavioural discomforts related to addiction.  I also hope that the new European alcohol strategy will lead to a significant reduction in the number of children exposed to serious distress in families abusing them and that their well-being, such as that of all other children, will be adequately protected, as specified in the UN Declaration of the Rights of the Child, which was adopted and has become one of the priority values that the Union promotes.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the alcohol strategy. This is a very important issue, given the spread and abuse of alcohol consumption in Europe, especially among very young people and women. Alcohol is the second leading cause of life-related disease and is a risk factor for more than 60 chronic diseases such as liver disease, pancreatitis, diabetes, obesity and heart disease, among others. Alcohol also causes mental and behavioral disorders. It causes the deaths of 3.3 million people worldwide, with very high percentages among young people, and generates serious social costs on the shoulders of the Member States. Phenomena such as binge drinking by very young people, or massive alcohol abuse by pregnant women, must be stopped: too many children, in fact, live in families with alcoholism problems. I fully support the call for the Commission to develop the new EU alcohol strategy with objectives to support national efforts in prevention, data collection, education and early diagnosis. The Member States must do more in terms of informing and educating citizens about the posthumous risks of alcohol abuse by putting in place effective education policies.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: Writing. Some groups wanted to ban alcohol from the age of 16 and to raise taxes. I think that is wrong and I voted against it. In principle, I believe that we in Europe need to draw attention to the dangers of alcohol abuse. Alcohol at the wheel or consumption during pregnancy are major problems for our society. However, a meaningful enlightenment must not be allowed to pass into blind actionism. The EU must not give people the impression that they want to constantly regulate all areas of life. The calls for a general ban on alcohol under 18 and measures against cheap alcoholic beverages are inappropriate and do not solve the problem. Experience shows that tax increases fuel the black market and often have the opposite effects. In Germany, we were able to see this with the example of alcopops. Since the introduction of the special tax, young people have avoided alcopops, but they mix their drinks themselves again. Ultimately, this leads to higher alcohol consumption. The raising of the minimum age of consumption to 18 also goes too far. Studies show that enjoying a glass of beer or wine in the evening can be beneficial to your health. The decisive factor is the conscious handling. Alcohol consumption patterns in the EU vary so much that an equal approach to preventing alcohol abuse makes no sense.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Willmott report because I believe consumers have a right to know. Alcohol is the third-biggest cause of preventable death and disease in Europe and is a risk factor for over 60 chronic diseases, including cancer, heart disease, diabetes and liver disease, and is also linked to obesity. Europe has the highest rate of alcohol consumption in the world, yet the previous EU strategy on addressing alcohol-related harm ended in 2012 and has not been renewed. Clear and honest labelling, which is supported by many brewers in Europe, will now allow people to access the information they need so they are able to make an informed choice when they consume alcohol. Tackling alcohol-related harm should be a priority, and I hope the Commission will take this as a cue to finally come forward with a new strategy to make headway on this crucial issue.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: in writing. ‒ Health is a Member State competency and British Conservatives believe that the Commission’s new alcohol strategy should not compel Member States to take legislative action. Excess alcohol harms millions of individuals and families whilst having a significant cost to our health systems. The Conservatives are therefore keen to support a proactive alcohol strategy that respects the competences of Member States.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution calling for a new alcohol strategy.  Initially very hygienic and directive, the final proposal proved rather protective for French producers. It included amendments on three key points: the recognition and defence of appellations of origin, the fight against unfair competition and practices prohibited in French production, and finally the need to adapt regulations to SMEs and craftsmen. However, this adapted proposal was rejected by MEPs. The fight against alcohol abuse is still the responsibility of the Member States, provided that the commitments made by the Commission under the transatlantic treaty do not completely destroy our wine and brewing sectors.  This resolution will therefore not give rise to a legislative proposal from the Commission. However, I expect it to tackle products that are really dangerous to health, that citizens consume without even having the right to be informed: pesticides, GMOs, meats of animals slaughtered without being stunned. If the European Commission wants to defend our health, that is where it must start.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour because the proposal is mainly based on information campaigns; promoting healthy lifestyles; long-term harmful effects of alcohol; age limits on alcohol consumption, etc. We understand that there is a need for more information on labelling, as well as greater regulation in advertising related to alcohol and its derivatives. We do not, however, share the radical stance of the elimination of public aid without nuanced by specific cases to be taken into account, such as aid for agriculture.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I want to call for action to reduce alcohol-related harm, and for the clear, honest labelling of alcoholic drinks in order to allow people to make informed decisions.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. On Wednesday 29 April, I voted in favour of the European Union's new alcohol strategy to reduce the damage caused by its excessive and dangerous consumption. It has always seemed important to me that awareness-raising actions on the dangers of excessive alcohol consumption, in particular to make adolescents responsible, but also pregnant women, should be developed within the countries of the Union. I sincerely believe that appropriate and targeted pedagogy can lead to concrete results. However, we must differentiate between the consumption of alcohol as such and the abuse of alcohol, which must be denounced as a priority. That is one of the reasons why I did not want to impose a caloric labelling on the wine growers that would have increased the burden and created additional bureaucracy. It is about protecting our culture and heritage. The challenge lies in the balance between responsibility, pleasure and public health.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists voted in favour of a new EU alcohol strategy, as we believe that inaction is not justified given that, in the EU, 25% of all youth deaths (20-39 years old) are due to alcohol; that alcohol abuse is also recognized as the cause of more than sixty chronic diseases and that the social costs that can be attributed to alcohol are estimated at around EUR 155.8 billion.  We welcome the fact that the rest of the House has supported our amendment on the maintenance of measures for the promotion and information of the wine sector, in which we have included references to the CAP Regulations and actions for information and promotion of agricultural products approved in the previous parliamentary term.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. Today, a vote on the European Commission's alcohol strategy was on the agenda. I sat back and said my "healthy (?) common sense" and asked me: what does Brussels actually have to do with all this? Why do we have to regulate the diverse drinking culture – I have to admit, in this context, "culture" is a bit difficult for me to see here – in Europe and to unify laws? In Normandy, my family's second home, you like to hiss a cider and tip a Calvados behind the tie. Otherwise, the French enjoy their wine, the Belgians rather their beer. The Poles love their vodka, the Italians love the martini, Calvinists rather nothing of everything. Everyone knows that alcohol can affect health; that young people must be particularly protected from this. But for God's sake, let this be a matter for each country and its parliament! If we carry on like this, we will soon all be Swedes in terms of alcohol. But I do not want that, at least not as far as the paternalistic interference of the state in people's drinking habits and the horrendous taxes on alcohol are concerned. No wonder many of the liquor corpses you see sleeping out at night on the Reeperbahn have a Swedish or Finnish passport. I voted against.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the alcohol strategy. It is a big challenge to develop a single, coherent strategy for alcohol consumption, as this problem has many aspects. On the one hand, excessive alcohol consumption poses a health risk and can lead to many social problems. On the other hand, I share the arguments put forward during the debate by colleagues who point to the positive cultural dimension of moderate alcohol consumption.  However, one issue is clear: excessive alcohol consumption is particularly harmful to children and adolescents. Unfortunately, statistics in many countries show that alcohol consumption among young people is increasing and the age of alcohol initiation is devalued. I believe that education is the key to this problem, and I am pleased that this has been highlighted in the motion for a resolution. However, I believe that not only young people, but society as a whole, should be educated in this respect. Still, too often, adults allow adolescents to consume alcohol. In many countries, it is recklessly sold to minors in shops and bars, which is done with adult indifference.  I would like the Commission to take this issue into account in the draft alcohol strategy and to come up with guidance on how to combat it.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. Alcohol consumption can be a danger to yourself and others if you do not know the limits. For this reason, moderate consumption education is needed to combat the direct (disease) and indirect (accident) negative consequences associated with alcohol abuse. Europe needs an alcohol strategy to prevent the excesses and excesses found in all countries. It's a necessity. However, we must not hide the notion of pleasure related to tasting and salute the know-how of producers, craftsmen and companies, who through practices inherited from generations to generations, maintain a rich cultural heritage and contribute to the influence of France and Europe in the world. The European Parliament's resolution manages to respect this balance between prevention, which is essential and the recognition of an asset for our continent, which I welcome.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour because the proposal is mainly based on information campaigns; promoting healthy lifestyles; long-term harmful effects of alcohol; age limits on alcohol consumption, etc. We understand that there is a need for more information on labelling, as well as greater regulation in advertising related to alcohol and its derivatives. We do not, however, share the radical stance of the elimination of public aid without nuanced by specific cases to be taken into account, such as aid for agriculture.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of finally approving a campaign for the promotion of wine.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a motion for a resolution on alcohol strategy because I want to support sensibility towards excessive and harmful alcohol consumption. At the same time, I would like to warn that the importance of wine and other beverage culture in the European tradition must not be diminished. A one-sided, exclusively negative view of the consumption of wine and other well-known excellent European alcoholic beverages is not welcome.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposed resolution on the alcohol strategy. On the one hand, the proposed amendments aim to take into account local realities, a crucial step in dealing with the issue of alcohol, in the sense that it must be dealt with in consideration of cultural peculiarities. In this, I voted for the promotion of the know-how of local craftsmen, for the fight against unfair competition, for an increased visibility of their interests.   On the other hand, the proposed amendments emphasize the need to take health logics into account as a matter of priority. It is not a question of denying the harms that may have been caused by the abuse of alcohol-related products, but of finding the right balance between denouncing them and promoting healthier lifestyles.   Finally, it should be remembered that this area of competence must be protected from the interference of supranational institutions in the local economic policy of States and remain under the strict and unique jurisdiction of states in order for them to conduct a national policy in the direction of their interests.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the alcohol strategy, which aims to tell the committee what works in the existing strategy and what needs to be improved. The fight against alcoholism remains a great struggle that the European Union must fight. This resolution has been adopted, which I welcome.

name: Kaja KALLAS
text: in writing. ‒ It is high time we paid more attention to the general alcohol policy in Europe. It is particularly important to step up efforts to reduce the consumption of alcohol by young people, for example by monitoring the effects of alcohol advertising on young people. We should also take the necessary measures in order to reduce road accidents related to drink driving.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. In principle, I am in favour of promoting awareness-raising and information campaigns on the prevention of addiction, be it alcohol, tobacco or drugs. However, prevention of addiction is not within the competence of the EU and should continue to be left to the Member States due to regional demographic, cultural and social differences, in order to increase the efficiency of the measures to be applied.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution.  Parliament is proposing to the Commission to come forward with an alcohol strategy to answer the dramatic and worsening socio-economic developments that alcohol is causing. Europe has about 12 million alcohol addicts, a quarter of road deaths are linked to alcohol, domestic violence is often linked to alcohol. Europe’s economy loses EUR 155.8 million euros a year due to alcohol-related problems.  The resolution unites all political groups, a phenomenon not often seen in this house.  As a result, Parliament will send a strong message to the Commission and Member States to take this matter seriously.  One of the arguing points remains labelling and the fear, especially in the Southern European states, that labelling and other requirements could harm the image of traditional wine culture. In my view indicating the nutrition value and consistency on the bottle would make sense.  A comprehensive alcohol strategy would contribute to saving  lives and  reducing costs. But most importantly it will provide better protection for children from alcohol-related harm.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ Alcohol is the leading cause of ill health and premature death for the core of the EU´s working-age population (25-59). The social cost attributable to alcohol is an estimated EUR 156 billion a year, as it is linked to public health issues such as obesity and to other social problems including family breakdown and violence. Reducing alcohol-induced harm is therefore an active investment in our economies as well as a means by which we can achieve a better quality of life for all European citizens. With the recent publication of the Public Health (Alcohol) Bill, Ireland is now leading the way in addressing this issue and Europe needs to follow suit. I believe that this resolution strikes the right balance between the public health promotion and the recognition of national cultural differences in relation to alcohol consumption. I have therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution, as it calls for the Commission to produce a new EU Alcohol Strategy and to take greater steps to ensure that people are fully aware of the dangers of drink-driving and drinking when pregnant. Europe is still the heaviest drinking region in the world, with alcohol the third biggest cause of preventable death and disease, and alcohol-related harm costing the EU economy EUR 155.8 billion a year. Parliament has made it clear that we want the Commission to make tackling alcohol-related harm a priority. We have sent a strong message to the Commission and I hope they will listen and finally come forward with a new strategy to set out how this will be done.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. \u2012 On 29 April 2015, I voted in favour of the report on a new (anti-)alcohol strategy of the EU. The World Health Organization warns that alcoholism causes 3.3 million premature deaths worldwide. These deaths are most ly related to road accidents, violence and liver disease. The situation is particularly disingeful in the Czech Republic, which is one of the absolute world leaders in alcohol consumption at all ages. Excessive consumption of alcohol then causes not only health problems, but above all social problems, for this reason this phenomenon must be seriously combated. Alcohol is more dangerous in some aspects than smoking. Smokers usually do not attack their surroundings under the influence of nicotine, and smoking does not destroy entire families. Excessive alcohol consumption is logically associated with obesity. The European Parliament's report in this report therefore rightly recommends that Member States force producers and importers of spirit drinks to give information on the caloric value of the drink sold and a warning that it is not suitable for drivers and pregnant women. We now have nutritional values on virtually every product. When we have this information on any bar we buy in the store, there is no reason for it to continue to be lacking in alcohol.

name: Elisabeth KÖSTINGER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on a new alcohol strategy.  Coordinated solutions to the fight against addiction problems across the EU are desirable. It should be noted, however, that there must be a clear distinction between the consumption of alcohol and its abuse. Our millennia-old European culture of wine and beer production must, in any case, be preserved. We must also avoid a labelling jungle: labelling is not a panacea! Information campaigns and active information work often bring more.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution calling on the European Commission to present a new alcohol strategy by the end of 2016. Foreword, the necessary distinction between the responsible use and consumption of alcohol and the harmful and therefore dangerous use of alcohol, our demands have focused on combating the harm caused by alcohol abuse.  We therefore call on the Commission to assess what the effects of new labels would be by indicating information on the risks of drink-driving during pregnancy or on minors and what the consequences would be on consumers' habits in the event of any indication on the label of the ingredients and nutritional aspects of the alcoholic beverage.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution, which calls for the adoption of a new and more effective EU alcohol strategy, with a greater focus on prevention, especially among young people. I am pleased to recognise that the proposals put forward in the resolution were supported by all the political groups in Parliament, i.e. ensuring the good health of Europeans and ensuring the sustainability of our society is a common challenge for all of us. In order to raise awareness of people and prevent alcohol-related harm, I fully support the introduction of a requirement to provide ingredients and nutritional information for beverages. It is also important to establish a common labelling system so that the necessary information is unambiguous to everyone across Europe.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the European Union's alcohol strategy.  The aim of this strategy is to be able to reduce alcohol abuse, a scourge of public health that unfortunately affects younger and younger populations. Alcohol is also part of the gastronomic and cultural heritage of the Member States and this essential aspect has been preserved in the text.  In adopting this resolution, we called for the EU's alcohol strategy to focus on underage drinking and eu-wide labelling to discourage drinking and driving during pregnancy.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety since I share your concern that Europe has the highest rates of alcohol consumption globally, which means that excessive or harmful alcohol consumption is the third leading cause of preventable diseases and a risk factor for more than sixty chronic diseases , including cancer and cardiovascular problems. The EU published a strategy in 2006 with the aim of cooperating with Member States and other actors to coordinate actions to reduce alcohol-related damage. However, few actions have been taken. This report calls on the new European Commission to work in this regard. Since numerous requests from my group on the importance of information and the correct labelling of alcoholic products, as well as for greater regulation of advertising and the commitment to prevention campaigns among young people, were included in the text, I have decided to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 At a time of enormous debt for EU states, rising unemployment and discontent in Europe, I do not consider efforts to address the EU-wide alcohol strategy to be sensible. Firstly, drinking alcohol is a matter and responsibility of citizens, and the EU should not seek to put it in the role of caring 'parent'. Secondly, alcohol consumption cannot be addressed by any regulation, recommendation or prohibition. The consequences of prohibition in the US have caused a very bad situation, and the experience of the United States shows that trying to limit people's alcohol is going nowhere.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: in writing. \u2012 In most Member States of the European Union, alcohol consumption poses a serious public health problem that causes large-scale socio-economic damage. Alcohol abuse is the cause of the premature death of about 3.3 million people a year worldwide. In addition, in 2010 in Europe alone, the direct and indirect costs of alcohol abuse reached EUR 155.8 billion.   Today's resolution with my colleagues call on the European Commission to create a new alcohol strategy for the period 2016-2022. It must include: the collection of reliable data for the purpose of monitoring, improving prevention and treatment and reducing incidents caused by driving under the influence of alcohol.  The resolution also asks the Commission to submit a proposal for the mandatory disclosure of ingredients and calories on the label of alcoholic beverages, as well as labels containing warnings to pregnant women and drink driving.  Parliament also proposes to increase measures with regard to the protection of young people, for example - increased dissemination of information campaigns on the danger of alcohol abuse in minors and strict compliance with the laws on the age limit for alcohol consumption.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ Alcohol is the most common drug in several Member States of the Union, which, in addition to the major health and social impacts, also poses an economic and financial problem. The European Union is at the forefront of alcohol consumption. This situation is alarming and requires the Union, in cooperation with the Member States, to prepare a proposal for a strategy that leads to conscious and responsible alcohol consumption. It is important to focus in this area already on educate adolescents and to introduce sufficient awareness of the effect of substances contained in alcohol on the human body.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the motion for a resolution on the alcohol strategy because I consider it complete and well documented.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU's alcohol strategy is intended to help national governments deal with alcohol-related harm. Alcohol abuse is the second leading cause of lifestyle-related illness. Every year, this abuse causes death for about 3.3 million people worldwide, 25% of whom are in the 20-39 age group. Alcohol addiction is also a risk factor for more than 60 chronic diseases, heart disease, liver disease and cancer, and frequent consumption of significant amounts can be addictive. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Through this resolution, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to promote a proposal aimed at introducing labelling of caloric content for alcoholic beverages by 2016.  Together with my colleagues, we are calling, at the same time, for a new European alcohol strategy, focusing on the problem of alcohol consumption by children and proposing to include information on product labels on the risks of drink-driving and the consumption of alcoholic beverages during pregnancy.  By agreeing with the content and purpose of this document, I have decided to support it with a vote in favour.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I rejected the report on the strategy against alcohol abuse because this issue does not fall within the competence of the European Union and is therefore unnecessary or contrary to the Treaty.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this strategy as more needs to be done to tackle the negative effects of alcohol abuse, particularly by minors.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Excessive alcohol consumption poses risks to public health. The text considers alcohol as the source of all the ills that plague Europe: cancer, obesity, neuro-psychiatric disorders .... Yet I observe that the number of cancer has been exploding since the 1960s even as alcohol consumption continues to decline. It is therefore good that alcohol cannot be the only cause. The mass poisoning inflicted on our food supply by the food industry with its procession of pesticides and fertilizers has its share. So is the addictive use of sugars and salts in the obesity epidemic. The designation of alcohol as a cause of epidemics and ills due to the methods of the productive economy is a peak of hypocrisy. A European alcohol strategy is needed but not in these terms. I abstain.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ Having followed the development of the EU Alcohol Strategy for some time, I voted in favour of this resolution encouraging the adoption of this strategy. I chose to support this resolution because of its call for Member States to introduce specific policies and treatments that reduce alcohol addiction in individuals. It is also crucial that education and awareness campaigns regarding the effects of alcohol consumption are carried out amongst the public, particularly minors.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on an alcohol strategy. Tackling alcohol-related harm with robust policy goals would result in significant improvements in public health and reduced costs in health care and social spending. Productivity would also increase, as workplace absenteeism would decline.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of an agreed motion by the political forces represented in the EP, including the S&D group.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. An alcohol strategy should focus on alcohol abuse and misuse. We must not forget that alcohol abuse is the second leading cause of lifestyle-related illness in some Member States and that alcohol dependence is a risk factor for chronic diseases.  I voted in favour of the need for more campaigns among the most vulnerable public, namely young people and pregnant women. I believe that a thorough analysis by the European Commission is needed on the possible integration of the nutritional content of beverages. We must, of course, provide clear and truthful information to the consumer, but in view of its applicability. Finally, I would like to point out that the promotion and public support for wine regions should continue, because of the importance they have for the so-called Wine Tourism.  We must support awareness-raising and information campaigns for the population, referring to the harmful effects of abusive consumption.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The proposed resolution on the alcohol strategy is not without criticism. It follows a question with an oral response to the Commission. This proposal, if implemented, would clarify the alcohol-related measures that would be imposed on all Member States, despite the cultural and food differences between the different countries of the European Union.  In addition to interfering in the affairs of Member States, the text also interferes in matters within the private sphere. The justifications put forward, such as the fight against alcohol abuse, alcoholism trends and the protection of young people, which are laudable causes, are not sufficient in nature to violate privacy.  Nothing is said about the fight against alcohol trafficking and counterfeiting, nor on how to guarantee the protection of traditional farms and productions. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs call for action to reduce alcohol-related harm and for clear, honest labelling of alcoholic drinks to allow people to make informed decisions.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the European Union's alcohol strategy. I have matched my vote with amendments clearly distinguishing between responsible and cultural alcohol consumption, consistent with a healthy lifestyle, and alcoholism, which is responsible for too many deaths, both by the diseases it causes and by the acts of violence it engenders.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 With this resolution, we call on the Commission to examine existing European legislation and insist on the need to ensure clear and effective information on the effects of alcohol consumption and health risks.  In some Member States, alcohol abuse is the second leading cause of lifestyle-related illness and is a risk factor for more than 60 chronic diseases. We believe that, in order to prevent excessive alcohol consumption by young people, education, information and prevention campaigns are fundamental tools. It is therefore appropriate for the Commission to start defining a new strategy, while at the same time promoting appropriate awareness-raising campaigns on moderate and responsible consumption of alcoholic beverages.  We call on the Commission to consider adopting EU labelling to warn consumers about the dangers of alcohol abuse; we call on you, together with the Member States, to develop appropriate strategies to step up controls to tackle the problem of the counterfeiting of alcoholic beverages and the illegal and illegal sale of alcohol, with particularly negative effects for the most disadvantaged social groups and young people, and to protect geographical indications within the EU and worldwide through international trade agreements.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution which will direct the European Commission's work on this issue for the next seven years. The GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats has obtained the rewriting of Article 23, which aimed at the introduction of an equal 'minimum price' for all EU States, that is to say, an excise duty as for cigarettes which, in addition to penalising our producers with a greater tax burden, would have the effect of assimilating wine to tobacco, with the possibility of having repercussions in terms of labelling in the future. With the final vote in plenary we have obtained the amendment of two other important points. Firstly, the ban on the introduction of a minimum age for the purchase of alcoholic beverages throughout Europe, which was aimed at 21 years. Each State, therefore, will continue to decide for itself (in Italy, for example, it is 18 years). Secondly, we have removed from the text of the resolution the ban on the use of public resources to promote alcoholic beverages, including wine. If this concept had passed, we would no longer have been able to use European funds for the promotion of agricultural products, which have been and remain indispensable to make known all over the world the excellence of "made in Italy".

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the European Commission has indicated the effectiveness of the strategy, further improvements are being made to the EU's alcohol strategy. We'd be chasing false illusions if we tried to banish alcohol from our lives like a villain. Drinking alcohol has been part of European culture for centuries. However, its consumption requires attention and self-control. Alcohol consumption has a culture, history and tradition, but the health, public safety and social risks are not low. We must balance all this if we are to achieve a sustainable, real-world European alcohol strategy. This balance could, in my opinion, be achieved by encouraging society to drink quality alcohol. A number of economic incentives could be included, either by introducing mandatory criteria or by imposing special taxes. We need to plant a principle among drinkers that prioritises quality rather than quantity.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 Alcohol abuse is the second leading cause of illness, linked to the lifestyle of the population in some Member States, and chronic alcohol consumption is a risk factor for more than 60 chronic diseases. I voted for this resolution because, through its text, it underlines the need to start the Work of the Commission on the EU Alcohol Strategy (2016–2020). The resolution also calls on the Member States to implement, within their health systems, policies and treatments aimed at reducing alcohol dependence.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I stand firmly behind the call for a New European Union Alcohol Strategy 2016-2022, because the lack of vision and action plan will only reinforce the already worrying trends in our society.  Despite efforts in recent years, the statistics remain startling. The age at which not only minors, but also already minors systematically abuse spirits, continues to decline. The European Union must address and propose pan-European measures to combat this trend. Alcohol tourism is not a phenomenon due to traditions in the destination country. This is a common problem and a solution must be sought at European Union level.  The European Schools need adequate education programmes that not only present the consequences of this critical information, but also stimulate a healthy lifestyle. Healthy lifestyle classes and more physical activities will help, both in the fight against alcohol consumption by adolescents and in the other serious problem of young Europeans – obesity. I firmly believe that the subject of information campaigns should not, however, be only adolescents. In a Europe where the proportion of ageing populations is growing, public health care is starting in the fetal stages, so I strongly support the proposal for more information campaigns among pregnant women as well. The harm that alcohol consumption causes on the fetus has lasting and severe consequences on the individual, and on public health in general.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have decided to abstain from voting on the proposal for an alcohol strategy because I do not support all the ideas and proposals expressed in it. The socio-economic impact of such a strategy is very large and I think it is imperative to evaluate the various possible strategies by looking at how they will have the expected results in relation to how they will affect Member States' economies and the labour market.  With regard to the ideas expressed in this report, some of them have raised questions for me, and for others I have doubts about the final results, which are the reasons why I have decided to abstain from voting.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing. \u2012 The negative effects of excessive alcohol consumption deserve a strategic approach at EU level and follow-up legislative action. I welcome the fact that attention has been focused on groups of people in whom alcohol consumption can have fatal consequences, such as drivers, young people and pregnant women. In the near future, an obligation should be introduced for alcoholic beverage manufacturers to indicate on labels warnings to drivers, young people and pregnant women against alcohol consumption. At the same time, an obligation should be introduced to indicate on labels the calorie content of alcoholic beverages, which is now applicable to all packaged foods. I see no reason why it should not apply to alcoholic beverages, but technical details will need to be fine-tuned, but, as with similar regulations, the revenues and costs of this policy and the search for ways to least put a minimum of weight on producers, especially small firms, should be carefully considered.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: Writing. \u2012 In my view, since alcoholism causes serious health and social problems in several Member States, including Hungary, and data on young people's drinking habits are particularly worrying, it is necessary to establish a European strategy, in particular in support of prevention and informed decision-making.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: Writing. Food or beverages such as alcohol or cigarettes have long been subject to strict regulations. More strategies against alcohol abuse are now planned. Unfortunately, I do not have specific proposals in the draft on how to actually protect minors from alcohol. New labelling will not prevent consumers from consuming alcohol. In my view, this regulation must be rejected. I expect constructive proposals that will actually protect the consumer.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I supported by my vote this resolution, of which I was co-reporter, which calls on the European Commission to renew its European alcohol strategy and has many positive points. , I hoped that this resolution would be seen through the prism of public health, and that it would allow member States to bring more coherence to the action of the Member States in their measures to combat alcoholism. These include the problems of alcohol use among young people, the dangers of alcohol during pregnancy, and the proper labelling of drinks with clear information on their content.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because I consider it important to prevent alcohol use among minors. It should be borne in mind that alcohol is not available to young people, and information must also be carried out on the dangers of drinking alcohol. The resolution calls for the adopt of a new EU alcohol strategy that will focus on stepping up efforts to reduce young people's alcohol consumption and reduce alcohol consumption during alcohol and pregnancy.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. The EU's alcohol strategy aims to help governments coordinate their measures to reduce alcohol damage in the EU. Excessive alcohol consumption causes 3.3 million premature deaths worldwide each year and about 25% of deaths of young people between the age of 20 and 39 are beverage-related. This strategy will allow us to work together to reduce consumption among young people, alert risks and improve the prevention and treatment of alcoholism. We are also pleased that the text we have supported provides for an exception for the wine sector, which can continue to benefit from European agricultural product promotion programmes.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the alcohol strategy because I believe that it is essential to develop a coordinated policy at European level in this area.  Europe is one of the leading producers of excellence in the sector and responsible alcohol consumption is not incompatible with a healthy lifestyle. However, due to the lack of an adequate information campaign on the health risks arising from excessive alcohol consumption and the inadequacy of preventive and control measures, more than 3 million people die each year from alcohol abuse. About one in four road accidents is due to drink-driving and young people are the most affected.  It is important for the Commission to define a new European strategy that can support and strengthen the WHO Action Plan on this issue for the period 2012-2020. National governments must be supported in this fight and greater cooperation is needed at European level. Alcohol addiction is a serious problem and Member States must be able to ensure adequate access to care and active support for those affected and their families.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on an alcohol strategy, which calls on the Commission to immediately begin work on a new EU alcohol strategy to assist Member States in dealing with alcohol abuse. The Commission has to evaluate whether the requirement to provide consumers with information on ingredients and nutritional content should apply to alcoholic beverages. The related report was due by the end of 2014, but we are still waiting for it. I agree with the importance of providing clear information to consumers on the ingredients and the content of the products they buy. Whether the discussion is about meat or about alcohol, it does not change the basic fact that consumers have the right to be informed, and MEPs have the duty to fight for their right to be heard. However, I am conscious of the need to select what information to include in a label, so that consumers are not confused by the amount of data and producers do not have to pay excessive costs. My votes on the amendments reflect these complexities in the aim of finding a balance between the needs of the consumers and the needs of the producers.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. If Amendments 1, 4 and 8 had been adopted (respect for business interests, geographical indications and the fight against unfair competition), I could have considered accepting this text. As not all of them have been adopted, I cannot vote in favour of the final text and therefore I am voting against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. Europe leads the way in the amount of alcohol consumed. Alcohol is perceived as a dietary supplement, a mood lifter, most often without widespread awareness of the consequences of excessive consumption. And this is the third largest cause of death. Excessive consumption leads to domestic and social violence, while the costs of treating alcoholism and the diseases it causes are extremely high. Of particular concern is the data on the amounts of alcohol consumed by underage pupils. Although the law prohibits under-18s, as many as 85% of students in Croatia admit to drinking alcohol. In doing so, they consume the cheapest alcohol the most because its price is the most common limiting factor, not the legal provisions. For all these sad reasons, I join calls on the Commission to adopt a comprehensive alcohol strategy as soon as possible. Thus, a different approach to alcohol consumption, clear labelling of ingredients of alcoholic beverages and calorie values, and cooperation of all stakeholders in informing citizens, especially the youngest generations. Unlike many others, the problem of alcoholism can be successfully prevented!

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support the alcohol strategy because abuse of this kind is a risky factor of today which, given the manifold harmful effects of alcohol, leads to addiction, pernicious health conditions, deaths, accidents and violence. Taking into account the high concentration of minors who are increasingly available to enjoy intoxicating beverages and are not sufficiently informed about their harmfulness, I believe that this strategy will help limit their excessive consumption.   Since the craft production of alcoholic beverages is the backbone of tourism in local communities, and thus exposed to attendance of various social profiles, from pregnant women, minors to people prone to risky diseases, it is important to emphasize the need to label alcoholic products that will provide a review of various negatives. In general, very little is known about products used for the production of alcoholic beverages, especially high alcoholic premixes, and given the nature of the risk, comprehensive information regarding the energy values of ingredients is necessary.  Efforts to educate the general public on the harmful consequences and consumption of alcohol should be increased, while also bearing in mind the impact on the health of moderate consumption with a balanced lifestyle. Given the cultural aspect of the diversity of EU countries, it is necessary to promote moderation and responsibility in the enjoyment of alcoholic beverages, but also a legal proposal to establish rules for the list of ingredients and a mandatory food declaration for these products.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the resolution on alcohol, that there are initiatives by the Commission and the Member States to show European citizens the health effects of harmful alcohol consumption and that moderate and responsible consumption of alcoholic beverages is promoted. I hope that the Commission will work assiduously on the new EU alcohol strategy and that the same objectives will be respected, but by updating the regulatory framework in conjunction with national governments, addressing issues relating to the harm caused by excessive consumption and involving the highest number of stakeholders in the information action. Member States must be strict in their application of the law and that existing legislation must be respected, in particular on age limits for alcohol consumption, and in assessing the need for additional binding legal requirements to ensure effective protection of children.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. On Wednesday 29 April, Parliament adopted a resolution on the European alcohol strategy. I voted in favour of this resolution, which takes stock of the current Strategy and points out the necessary improvements. If I fight against the sometimes irreparable damage caused by alcohol in our populations, it is in terms of prevention that I believe we will be able to gain ground, especially among young people. This resolution sometimes goes too far. It advocates ways that will harm the competitiveness of our SMEs and the wine world. In particular, I have taken a stand against the imposition of a minimum price on alcohol, even though a majority of Members were in support. However, if this resolution is criticised, it is not binding, which still leaves some room for manoeuvre for our winemakers and our companies in the sector.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. Alcohol abuse is the second leading cause of lifestyle-related illness in some Member States and alcohol dependence is a risk factor for more than 60 chronic diseases, such as alcoholism. This resolution considers that the EU's alcohol strategy has been successful in supporting Member States' measures to reduce the harm caused by alcohol abuse, in particular by exchanging best practices in areas such as the protection of young people. It also calls on the Commission to start working immediately on the new EU Alcohol Strategy, based on the objectives of reducing health and safety problems and socio-economic problems caused by alcohol. These objectives can then be achieved, according to the resolution, through measures relating to the degree, patterns and contexts of alcohol consumption, as well as the social determinants associated with it, for example through education and the launch of information campaigns. I voted, therefore, in favor.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Even if Member States have the main levers to act on the fight against alcoholism (prevention and awareness campaigns), the European Union has a say and needed to renew its alcohol strategy, which expired in 2012.  In short, this is the message delivered by MEPs with the adoption this lunchtime of the resolution calling for strong European action in this area. The first step is to label the ingredients and calorie content of alcoholic beverages. The recent voluntary initiative by brewers to carry out such labelling, in the interests of transparency towards consumers, is welcome and should inspire other alcohol products. The Commission's statements in Monday's debate also go in the right direction: a report on the feasibility of labelling, as required by the 2011 Consumer Information Regulation. Another important message from the European Parliament is the adoption of a European Union-wide label warning consumers of the dangers of drinking heavily alcoholic beverages during pregnancy and driving. Two visible and readable symbols that can save lives.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 I support a policy that aims to reduce alcohol consumption and all the social and health harms it entails. However, I have some reservations when it is said that "public funds should under no circumstances be used to promote alcohol consumption", since, especially with regard to the economies of Southern Europe, this may be a principle invoked to prevent support for campaigns for the promotion and internationalisation of products such as Port Wine or Madeira Wine, this may be a principle invoked to prevent support for campaigns for the promotion and internationalisation of products such as Port Wine or Madeira Wine , to highlight only a few.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists voted in favour of a new EU alcohol strategy, as we believe that inaction is not justified given that, in the EU, 25% of all youth deaths (20-39 years old) are due to alcohol; that alcohol abuse is also recognized as the cause of more than sixty chronic diseases and that the social costs that can be attributed to alcohol are estimated at around EUR 155.8 billion.  We welcome the fact that the rest of the House has supported our amendment on the maintenance of measures for the promotion and information of the wine sector, in which we have included references to the CAP Regulations and actions for information and promotion of agricultural products approved in the previous parliamentary term.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. The European Parliament today voted in favour of labelling calories on all bottles of alcohol, including wine, to better combat alcoholism and obesity.  The text calls on the Commission to act as soon as possible, and by the end of 2016 at the latest, to impose this labelling, whose alcohol was exempted in 2011, when the measure was decided for all foodstuffs and non-alcoholic beverages. The text also calls on the EU executive to consider labelling on bottles of prevention messages for pregnant women and drivers.  While it does not explicitly propose setting a floor price for alcoholic beverages, it calls for the launch of a reflection involving Member States to prevent the sale of low-cost alcohol.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the European Commission's efforts to reduce alcohol consumption in Europe. Addiction and health are problems at European level which, unfortunately, are not able to be dealt with effectively by the state and the community. According to official statistics, 12 million people in the EU are addicted to alcohol. 1 out of 4 road accidents in the EU are caused by the fault of drunk drivers. In 2010, almost 31 000 Europeans died on the roads, and 25% of these deaths were influenced by alcohol. The social harm caused by alcohol consumption amounts to EUR 155.8 billion per year, the main cause of poor health and premature death in the working-age population (25-59 years). When discussing the Alcohol Strategy in the European Parliament and analysing the proposals, I understand also the efforts of representatives of individual southern states to legitimise the concepts of responsible consumption. However, what may be normal in Spain or Italy with a moderate consumption culture is completely unsuitable for Lithuania and many countries in Northern and Eastern Europe. In Lithuania, almost a quarter of 15-year-olds consume alcohol weekly. The scale of alcoholism is equivalent to Russia and Belarus.  I believe that the European Union cannot compromise on this issue and that the good policies must be completely unfavourable to alcohol consumption and focus on the annual reduction in alcohol sales. Therefore, no consumption, even moderate, can be encouraged. Therefore, recital P, paragraph 5 and, in particular, paragraph 16 of the draft had to be reseded.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The 4 orders of reasons described briefly in The Oral Question to the Commission: 1) Harmful alcohol consumption remains the third leading cause of death and preventable diseases in Europe; 2) Alcohol abuse is also associated with obesity (the fourth leading cause of preventable diseases in Europe); 3) Alcohol abuse and dependence are also associated with other social problems, such as high levels of absenteeism at work, breakdown of the family nucleus and violence; 4) Europe has the highest rate of alcohol consumption in the world. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution endorsed by the 7 Parliamentary Groups, which calls on the Commission and the Member States to define a (new) Strategy on responsible alcohol consumption, proposing very concrete measures with regard to labelling, the promotion of education and/or preventive actions, legislation on marketing or consumption by pregnant women.  With this Resolution, we also affirm that the new EU Strategy should not set new targets, but should support those already agreed under the WHO European Action Plan to reduce harmful alcohol consumption in the period 2012-2020.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which focuses on alcohol prevention and education, including the need for responsible drinking.  The text also stresses the importance, in view of the Commission's future proposal, of taking into account the consequences for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and the artisanal production of labelling and information obligations on ingredients and nutritional content.  In the end, it is crucial to continue the fight against alcohol abuse, which is responsible for many deaths and whose direct and indirect social cost is estimated at EUR 155.8 billion in Europe for the year 2010.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With this resolution we have asked the European Commission to approve an alcohol strategy, taking initiatives to encourage the coordination of stakeholders. Because while it is true that excessive alcohol consumption is the third leading cause of death and preventable diseases in Europe, it is also true that a distinction must be made between alcohol use and abuse, just as we must not forget that it is right to diversify the treatment of this subject. Each country has its own culture and specific characteristics, and that is why we cannot call for a repressive policy that is the same for everyone, because it would go against the specific characteristics of individual countries, as well as being able to create economic damage for those states where alcohol production is one of the most economically productive items.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because the resolution, in its nodal part, expressly calls for nutrition labelling for all spirits. This markedly dirigiste and ethical approach is to be rejected at the root for a number of reasons, not least because it ignores the cultural value that the consumption – moderate and responsible, of course – of alcoholic beverages has throughout Europe. In addition, nutrition labelling presupposes that the alcoholic beverage is taken for feeding purposes. Fortunately, the days when wine or beer were drunk as a real food and energy supplement of poor diets are now behind us. Today the alcoholic beverage is commonly understood as a pleasure, as demonstrated by the production and consumption of wine, which have fallen in quantities in favor of quality.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour because the proposal is mainly based on information campaigns; promoting healthy lifestyles; long-term harmful effects of alcohol; age limits on alcohol consumption, etc. We understand that there is a need for more information on labelling, as well as greater regulation in advertising related to alcohol and its derivatives. We do not, however, share the radical stance of the elimination of public aid without nuanced by specific cases to be taken into account, such as aid for agriculture.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ Alcohol production is an ancient European industry, and alcohol consumption is a part of European culture. But excessive use and abuse cause many public health problems and lead to huge costs for health and social care systems. Alcohol is strongly linked to some cancers, heart disease, diabetes and liver disease. And the effects on individuals, families and society of people struggling with addiction can be devastating and costly. We need to have a common ambition to reduce alcohol-related harm, and a new alcohol strategy could work towards this goal. I am especially supportive of better labelling to warn about the dangers of drinking when pregnant. Clear, objective information about alcohol should form part of a wider strategy to promote healthy lifestyles and preventive medicine in general.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety since I share your concern that Europe has the highest rates of alcohol consumption globally, which means that excessive or harmful alcohol consumption is the third leading cause of preventable diseases and a risk factor for more than sixty chronic diseases , including cancer and cardiovascular problems. The EU published a strategy in 2006 with the aim of cooperating with Member States and other actors to coordinate actions to reduce alcohol-related damage. However, few actions have been taken. This report calls on the new European Commission to work in this regard. Since numerous requests from my group on the importance of information and the correct labelling of alcoholic products, as well as for greater regulation of advertising and the commitment to prevention campaigns among young people, were included in the text, I have decided to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution to call on the Commission to start work immediately on the European Alcohol Strategy (2016-2022) in order to help national governments reduce the harm caused by alcohol abuse. I would like to remind you that in Europe, excessive alcohol consumption is the direct and indirect cause of 3.3 million premature deaths in road accidents, acts of violence or liver disease every year. We are talking about a serious public health problem with a social cost of around EUR 155.8 billion. In addition, it is estimated that between 2% and 4% of children born in Europe suffer from different mental disabilities such as learning disabilities, mental retardation, behavioural and psychiatric disorders due to prenatal exposure to alcohol taken during pregnancy. I believe that the priorities of this new strategy must be to raise awareness and inform consumers, especially younger consumers, about the health risks, working and driving skills associated with excessive alcohol consumption. I am confident that this type of intervention can improve general awareness by bringing positive benefits to public health.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Europe is the heaviest-drinking region in the world. The social costs of alcohol-related harm are estimated at EUR 155.8 billion a year, and alcohol is third biggest cause of preventable death and disease in Europe. Alcohol is currently exempt from EU requirements to provide nutritional and ingredient information under the Food Information Regulation. We support this resolution calling for the Commission to come forward with a new alcohol strategy and to publish the delayed report.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting the resolution on alcohol strategy. I believe that it is important to combat excessive alcohol consumption. In particular, adolescents should not get to consume alcohol. They need to be edued in this regard. Alcoholism has a destructive effect on the development of man, family and thus on society as a whole.  I appreciate that alcoholic beverages will bear a symbol informing that alcohol is not suitable for pregnant women.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – I supported the motion for a resolution on a strategy on alcohol consumption. Statistics show that alcohol abuse is the second leading cause of lifestyle-related diseases in some Member States, and alcohol dependence is a risk factor for the development of more than 60 chronic diseases, including alcoholic liver diseases, almost all digestive tract diseases, cancer, diabetes, obesity, heart disease and many neuropsychiatric disorders. Every year, 6% of people die from alcohol abuse, including up to 25% between the ages of 20 and 39. Alcohol abuse among young people is becoming common practice. Alcohol problems are related to many factors such as socioeconomic level, cultural background, influence of parents, peers, family, school, education and education... Therefore, the call to the Commission for the preparation of a new strategy on alcohol consumption must be drawn up in cooperation with individual Member States, aimed at preventing, educating and educating young people about the extremely harmful impact of alcohol on young people's organisms, on the social and health consequences for the individual, families and society.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the resolution on the alcohol strategy, as it is important for the European Commission to update the regulatory framework to support national governments in developing strategies to deal with the harmful consequences of alcohol consumption. In addition, support for monitoring and collecting reliable data, promoting preventive and health education and supporting people facing alcohol-related problems is also important. As a member of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I believe that consumers should be informed about the ingredients and nutritional values in alcoholic beverages, just as they are informed of this data for other foodstuffs. In addition to such labelling, Member States should endeavour to raise awareness among the general public. Minors and pregnant women are particularly vulnerable here, as the harmful effects of alcohol consumption on these two groups are all the greater. Member States should also make efforts to reduce the number of drink-driving-related traffic accidents. It should be pointed out here that at EU level, as many as 25% of all alcohol-related deaths of young men aged 15 to 29, the same is true for every 10th female death in this age group.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. 'Better regulation of alcohol consumption can greatly benefit public health in Europe. That is why I approved these recommendations. This is not a political action against alcohol consumption, but an attempt to better inform citizens that abuse is the cause of dozens of chronic conditions, including liver disease, cancer, diabetes and obesity. Although the EU has long required almost all food and drink to clearly indicate on the packaging how much sugar, fat and protein are contained, this is strangely not yet the case for alcoholic beverages. The fact that the labelling of alcoholic beverages does not mention the nutritional value and therefore the number of calories is the result of strong lobbying by the industry. Now the parliamentary Committee on Public Health wants action. It is important that people know that pins have a decent nutritional value. The European Commission should have come forward with concrete proposals in December 2014 to indicate the calorie value on labels. At the moment, there are still no such people. That's sobering. The EP wants the Commission to submit these proposals without delay. In the resolution, we call for the European Commission to develop a new European strategy on alcohol for the period 2016-2022, in close cooperation with the Member States and all stakeholders.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 Health protection should be the foundation of any society. However, in the fight against alcoholism, I place particular emphasis on prevention, raising awareness of the consequences and risks associated with alcohol abuse, as well as on greater coverage of this topic in the education of children, young people and adults.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ In some Member States, alcohol abuse is the second most common cause of lifestyle-related diseases and alcohol addiction is a risk factor in more than 60 chronic diseases, such as alcoholic liver disease, chronic alcoholic pancreatitis and almost all other gastrointestinal diseases, cancer, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, obesity, fetal alcohol spectrum disorders and neuropsychiatric disorders such as alcohol addiction.  It is therefore important that Member States step up efforts to inform citizens about the cultural values of responsible alcohol consumption, the positive impact on the health of moderate alcohol consumption and the coherence of such consumption with a healthy and balanced lifestyle. It is also important to take into account the importance of this industry in Europe, and therefore I support the continuation of dialogue with all social factors around the alcohol strategy.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution on mandatory calorie labelling for alcohol products in the EU. Clear and honest alcohol labelling will allow citizens to make informed decisions about their consumption, and will be crucial in reducing alcohol-related harm across the Member States.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. – Harmful alcohol use remains the biggest cause of death and disease in Europe, but also in Croatia, while alcoholism and addiction are associated with domestic violence or absences from the workplace. Unfortunately, abuse of alcohol products has grown. Today, 10 litres of alcohol per EU resident are consumed, which is worrying.  It is necessary to do everything to indicate the harmfulness of consuming alcohol products, and one of the good starts is certainly the introduction of a label with ingredients on harmfulness. I support the proposal for a resolution of the alcohol strategy, but noting that we must be careful when distinguishing between alcoholic products, primarily thinking of winemakers, we must not jeopardise the competitiveness of European wines given the increasing presence of wines from other continents.  That is why I am committed to maintaining as much autonomy as I can of individual decision-making by member states, given the cultural, civilizational and traditional diversity of the 28 Member States of the Union.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: Writing. I supported the motion for a resolution of the alcohol strategy. As an alternate member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I would like to highlight the devastating consequences of alcohol in transport. Drink-driving is the reason for every fourth accident on Europe's roads, which ends in fatalities. 10,000 unnecessary deaths a year. Add to that the badly injured. European Commission statistics show that we have on average four who survive for each dead, but with permanent and severe brain damage or spinal injuries. Today we are talking about measures that could reduce alcohol consumption. When we talk about costs, we must therefore also talk about the pain, suffering and costs arising from alcohol.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. \u2012 In today's vote on the motion for a resolution on the EU alcohol strategy, I supported the PPE amendments, as I believe that, for example, considering the possibility of EU information campaigns that are properly targeted and overall designed to be truly effective is a better solution than mandatory labelling of alcoholic beverages with text highlighting the possible consequences of excessive consumption. As part of the steps taken in this area, care must be taken to respect the principle of subsidiarity, as practices in the handling of alcoholic beverages (within the limits of the law) vary from one part of the European Union to another.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Some articles need to be improved.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the alcohol strategy, as I agree that we must also take action against excessive alcohol consumption at EU level. As we know, a significant proportion of preventable deaths and diseases in Europe are attributable to this and the previous EU strategy to alleviate alcohol-related harm expired in 2012. The Socialists and Democrats' group was also actively involved in the drafting and its proposals were successfully incorporated. In my view, the resolution is not intended to make the sector impossible, as this would also mean job losses, for example, for local products. Moreover, with this aspect in mind, the resolution also takes into account local cultural traditions. In addition, the draft takes significant steps to protect consumers, for example by introducing the labelling procedure proposed in the resolution to provide consumers with more information. The strategy is also of the utmost importance because it will allow Member States to edit the monitoring and data collection practices of their work on alcohol consumption, to encourage prevention, health promotion, early diagnosis and better access to treatment. I believe that the elements of the strategy are not a burden for manufacturers, but that we can take important steps to achieve responsible alcohol consumption.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the alcohol strategy. In particular, I supported those amendments which support the increased efforts to promote and disseminate responsible and moderate alcohol consumption: yes to campaigns and labels that inform citizens of the harm caused by alcohol abuse and the risks to pregnant women and that promote moderate consumption of wine and spirits in order to educate citizens , especially the younger ones, to a responsible culture of wine. I voted in favour of Amendment No 8, which emphasises the lack of legislation containing labelling requirements for the ingredients used, for the nutritional qualities and for substances used in the production process of wine products, such as chaptalization, i.e. the addition of sugar or other sucrose to must in order to increase the alcohol content and achieve the minimum level necessary for marketing. This process seriously damages the Italian agricultural sector, creating a situation of unfair competition, since our winegrowers cannot use chaptalization. Furthermore, it also harms citizens because they cannot distinguish a wine made solely from grape must from that which has been further manipulated.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The European Parliament has just voted in favour of a resolution that introduces the labelling of alcoholic products and calls for legislation to be put in place. You should know that Europeans are the largest consumers of alcohol in the world. And yet, no one knows the number of calories, the composition or the energy value of what he drinks.  Europe is slow to regulate. The legislative position was already expected in 2014, but still no news: this is not acceptable! Alcoholic beverages must be subject to the same regulatory labelling regime as other foodstuffs. In 2011, alcoholic beverages were removed from the food labelling legislation, at the bet of the industry lobby.  The European Parliament's majority vote today sent an excellent signal.
