It is time to put an end to this particular regime. We want to play the transparency card. The consumer has a right to know!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution asking the Commission to present a new alcohol strategy based on a strong impact assessment for the period 2016-2022. The 2006 EU strategy expired in 2012 and has not yet been replaced. In this context, it is essential to pursue our efforts against abusive alcohol consumption, especially among young people, and also to prevent drink-driving and drinking during pregnancy. It should be noted that the text makes a distinction between moderate and excessive alcohol consumption.

name: Yana TOOM
text: Writing. \u2012 Nearly 60 chronic diseases are associated with excessive alcohol consumption. Drinking not only harms health, but also breaks the family, encourages violence, etc. In the case of Estonia, it should be noted that the restrictions on alcohol advertising that have been in place so far did not reduce consumption, but the new strategy gives us the opportunity to combat excessive drinking more effectively.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour because the proposal is mainly based on information campaigns; promoting healthy lifestyles; long-term harmful effects of alcohol; age limits on alcohol consumption, etc. We understand that there is a need for more information on labelling, as well as greater regulation in advertising related to alcohol and its derivatives. We do not, however, share the radical stance of the elimination of public aid without nuanced by specific cases to be taken into account, such as aid for agriculture.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this alcohol strategy. As a liberal I am in favour of better regulation and not over-regulation. I also want to stress that I am in favour of and support the wine and spirits industry. In my constituency back home there is a vibrant and very well-performing wine production, for example. I am also in favour of and welcome better transparency and better information for consumers. Like with other products, displaying nutritional information on the bottle is a good thing, to make sure consumers can make informed choices. Providing a list of ingredients and nutritional information can facilitate comparison and choice between alcoholic drinks. The wine and spirits industry already does a lot to advocate responsible drinking and correct behaviour. Moreover, let me stress that it is already forbidden to advertise near schools or to target children. Let me conclude by stressing that, as with other products, education and information is key. Prohibition only creates a black market and does not solve binge-drinking problems, for example; on the contrary, it aggravates it.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution also seeks to recommend a framework to combat alcohol abuse, alcoholism trends and the protection of young people. But this is not within the competence of the Union and could amount to an intrusion into private affairs. There are no real solid proposals to encourage border control to contain the trafficking of counterfeit alcohol or proposals for guarantees to protect traditional farms and production. I'm voting AGAINST.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the strategy to combat the harmful effects of alcohol in the EU, as alcohol abuse causes millions of deaths annually, particularly affecting young people. The social and medical implications of excessive alcohol consumption oblige Member States to make measures to combat alcohol dependence more effective and to better inform vulnerable groups about the risks. This is particularly about minors, and I appreciate the requests made in the resolution for prevention and advice campaigns, namely to limit advertising to alcohol and to restrict the sale of alcoholic beverages to minors.   I stress that the origin of a quarter of road accidents is alcohol consumption, which kills more than 5,200 people annually. Despite efforts, driving under the influence of alcohol continues to be second among the factors causing road deaths in the EU. It is an additional argument for coordinated, cross-border action against major risks arising from insufficient prevention.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We voted in favour because the proposal is mainly based on information campaigns; promoting healthy lifestyles; long-term harmful effects of alcohol; age limits on alcohol consumption, etc. We understand that there is a need for more information on labelling, as well as greater regulation in advertising related to alcohol and its derivatives. We do not, however, share the radical stance of the elimination of public aid without nuanced by specific cases to be taken into account, such as aid for agriculture.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution to ensure that the EU is effectively fighting alcoholism, with a social, economic and health approach.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: Writing. – Alcohol abuse in some Countries of the European Union is a serious cause of health and social problems. As a result, both national health and social costs are increasing. Statistics show that around five to nine million children in the EU live in families negatively affected by alcohol consumption, while one in four road accidents can be linked to driving under the influence. I believe that a common EU-level strategy could help national governments reduce alcohol-related harm, compile statistics and educate citizens. At the same time, the rules should take into account the different situations of the Member States, allowing them to choose the most appropriate ways of directing public attention to the harmfulness of alcohol. Information campaigns for young people, labels with warnings about the dangers of driving under the influence, or inscriptions about the dangers of alcohol during pregnancy are just a few examples of how this could be done. Consideration should also be made that the new rules do not have a negative impact on small and medium-sized enterprises. It is positive that in Latvia already some alcohol companies already choose to put warning inscriptions on their products for pregnant women or drivers about the negative impact of the drink. A single EU strategy would be an important step in reducing the number of alcohol-related illnesses and accidents, which is why I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists voted in favour of a new EU alcohol strategy, as we believe that inaction is not justified given that, in the EU, 25% of all youth deaths (20-39 years old) are due to alcohol; that alcohol abuse is also recognized as the cause of more than sixty chronic diseases and that the social costs that can be attributed to alcohol are estimated at around EUR 155.8 billion.  We welcome the fact that the rest of the House has supported our amendment on the maintenance of measures for the promotion and information of the wine sector, in which we have included references to the CAP Regulations and actions for information and promotion of agricultural products approved in the previous parliamentary term.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution from the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety since I share your concern that Europe has the highest rates of alcohol consumption globally, which means that excessive or harmful alcohol consumption is the third leading cause of preventable diseases and a risk factor for more than sixty chronic diseases , including cancer and cardiovascular problems. The EU published a strategy in 2006 with the aim of cooperating with Member States and other actors to coordinate actions to reduce alcohol-related damage. However, few actions have been taken. This report calls on the new European Commission to work in this regard. Since numerous requests from my group on the importance of information and the correct labelling of alcoholic products, as well as for greater regulation of advertising and the commitment to prevention campaigns among young people, were included in the text, I have decided to vote in favour of this Resolution.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The World Health Organization is concerned about the increase in alcohol consumption worldwide and the number of deaths it causes.  3.3 million people died from harmful alcohol use in 2012. 5.9% of the world's deaths are reported to be alcohol-related and more than 200 diseases are linked to alcohol consumption.  This Parliament's resolution calls on Member States to: - to launch information campaigns on the risks associated with the harmful use of alcohol - to strengthen information and labelling and to regulate advertising, particularly to young people. I have therefore voted in favour of this resolution, even though it is essentially a question of following the progress of the Member States in this area. I even want to say; it is time because I have always been dismayed at the difference in treatment between tobacco control and the fight against alcoholism, the considerable social damage of the latter, especially in terms of accidents and violence, seeming to escape most policy makers completely.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. Alcohol consumption remains the third leading cause of death in Europe in a number of preventable diseases. It is also a risk factor for more than 60 other chronic diseases. In addition, problems related to excessive alcohol consumption are linked to various social problems. Europe has the highest rate of alcohol consumption in the world. The purpose of both the oral question and this resolution is to obtain more information in this regard. It also asks for clarification as to why a new separate report has not yet been published on the application of the requirements for the provision of information on the ingredients of alcoholic beverages and nutritional information on those beverages which should have been submitted in December 2014.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I rejected the report on the strategy against alcohol abuse because this issue does not fall within the competence of the European Union and is therefore unnecessary or contrary to the Treaty.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. Parliament has adopted a new EU alcohol strategy. Of course, this is not about limits on the consumption of alcohol by their officials, but rather at the citizens' gait. I therefore did not vote in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the alcohol strategy (2015/2543(RSP). Alcohol is a stimulant which is widely used in the Member States. The EU is not concerned about how Member States position themselves here. The principle of subsidiarity is therefore being violated. It seems just too funny when the resolution points out that the consumption of alcohol creates 'health inequalities'. It is true that alcohol and its enjoyment cause individual risks. Everyone should judge this on their own responsibility. In any case, the person consuming the food does not belong between the gears in the gearbox of the Brussels bureaucrat mills.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the Alcohol Strategy, which calls for a new EU alcohol strategy focusing on combating underage drinking and including wide labelling at European level to discourage driving under the influence of alcohol. EU Member States need to step up efforts to protect young people, while the European Commission must effectively tackle the cross-border sale of alcohol over the internet.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Alcohol Strategy resolution today. The resolution urges the Commission to present a new strategy to combat the harmful effects of excessive alcohol consumption. I think it is very appropriate to draw up an organic strategy, geared to the prevention of alcohol abuse and aimed primarily at the new generations.  I find the approved text particularly timely and balanced in condemning the excesses and abuse of alcohol without criminalizing its moderate and responsible consumption.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Although the number of babies born with foetal alcohol syndrome is increasing every year, the topic is not yet paid as much attention as it should. Many experts have warned for years that drinking alcohol during pregnancy can have devastating effects on the fetus. Even ingesting a small amount can seriously harm a child's development and manifest themselves in the form of physical and mental disabilities. However, unlike other disabilities, we can prevent foetal alcohol syndrome. I am glad that the resolution on the alcohol strategy that we have approved also touches on this subject and calls on the Member States and the Commission, as well as all stakeholders, to examine and strengthen awareness-raising campaigns aimed at the harmfulness of alcohol consumption, especially for pregnant women, and the impact of alcohol on the unborn child. One effective campaign is certainly the labelling of alcoholic beverages with a pictogram highlighting these risks. I am convinced that good education will save many children from permanent and serious health damage.

name: Damiano ZOFFOLI
text: in writing. \u2012 I am particularly pleased with the adoption of the resolution on the European Union's alcohol strategy, which urges the European Commission to come to a new strategy for 2016 - 2020 as soon as possible. Alcohol is, in fact, one of the main causes of many chronic diseases and combating their abuse must be a priority for the European institutions. However, I would like to stress the need to distinguish between the use and abuse of alcohol, because we cannot deny the fact that its responsible consumption, and in particular the consumption of certain types of alcohol such as wine, is compatible with a healthy lifestyle. It is essential to strike a balance between two opposing requirements: on the one hand, the need to protect health and public order and, on the other, that of not penalising conscious and moderate consumption, also in the light of the objective and different habits of consumers in the countries of the European Union. It is also our duty to promote and protect our excellent producers, including with public money, especially as regards the wine sector, because they are an important sector of our economy.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Alcohol Strategy because, recognising the importance of differences in consumption patterns between Member States and the cultural aspects of responsible alcohol consumption, its focus is on its concern about limiting the intake of alcoholic beverages by minors and individuals suffering from serious disorders, chronic diseases or related dependencies.  In order to reduce the harm caused by alcohol, in order to ensure the lasting impact of the results achieved to date and to continue to support national governments in combating long-term alcohol harm, the European Commission is urged to start work immediately on a new Alcohol Strategy for the period 2016-2022 , which clearly has my agreement. Finally, because it calls on the Commission and the Member States to carry out awareness-raising campaigns and to invest in education as a means of preventing the effects on health and society of harmful alcohol consumption, while promoting responsible and moderate consumption of alcoholic beverages.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. This resolution calls for concrete measures for the new strategy, including the preparation of a report to assess the need for the inclusion of alcoholic beverages in the labelling regulation providing for information on ingredients and their nutritional content, adding to the need for preventive labelling for pregnant women. Member States are also requested to strengthen their legislation in this area. Member States are also called upon to be responsible in this matter, calling attention to the need for policies and treatments to be implemented in national health systems to help and reduce alcohol problems. Measures that seem right to us and that we support.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution on the alcohol strategy because I share the balanced position that this House has wanted to maintain on this issue. On the one hand, I agree that more information must be made available to consumers about the content and qualities of alcoholic beverages, so that they can make informed choices. On the other hand, however, we must ensure that responsible consumer education and the fight against abuse are carried out seriously but at the same time with a rational balance. Wine represents an excellence among the quality productions of our continent and its moderate use is part of the cultural tradition of our society. A sector, therefore, that must be protected and valued.

name: Jude KIRTON-DARLING
text: – Madam President, two years ago the collapse of the Rana Plaza garment factory tragically revealed the real price of unbridled globalisation in showing consumers across Europe that cheap clothes too often come with cheap labour rights and little safety at work. The companies named in this resolution should cough up the compensation they owe.  This week workers around the world marked International Workers’ Memorial Day, when we remember those killed or injured at work or victims of occupational diseases, and we commit to make working conditions better throughout the world. In Bangladesh much needs to be done. The latest International Labour Organisation (ILO) report demonstrates that basic legal changes are needed and workers are still subject to violence and intimidation for trade union activities. This is why I supported and co-signed the resolution.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: – Madam President, progress in investigating the Rana Plaza building collapse, ensuring satisfactory levels of health and safety in the workplace, and the Bangladesh Government’s reluctance to pave the way for trade union formation to represent workers’ rights, remains very disappointing. More importantly, democracy is declining fast in Bangladesh. Elections at both national and local level are held without the opportunity for the people to fully participate in a free and fair process. The European Union cannot expect to achieve fundamental rights for workers in an environment where political governance has completely broken down and human rights are curbed on a widespread basis. It is most important that we address the issue of a free and fair, inclusive national election. The lack of free elections is the root cause of the political turmoil in Bangladesh. Without sound political governance in Bangladesh, securing workers’ rights and safer workplaces will be difficult.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I supported the Resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building, firstly, to remind the more than 1,200 fatalities, the vast majority of women, of accidents in Bangladesh's textile industry – workshops that supplied companies such as Adler Modemarkte, Ascena Retail, Carrefour, Grabalok, J.C. Penney, Manifattura Corona, NKD, PWT or YesZee; to require companies linked to Rana Plaza and the Tazreen factory, burned down shortly before, to promptly provide the aid they owe to victims, many of them unable to return to work and who need medical care; to recall the importance of the Bangladeshi Government undercomed legislative reforms to ensure effective labour protection and the right to freedom of association of workers in its country, in compliance with ILO Conventions; and because it urges the EC and EU governments to consider establishing a system that forces companies to repair and compensate victims because, under the current framework, they respond either because of their goodwill or for fear that pressure groups will point them out and highlight their irresponsible behaviour.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. As the Resolution recalls, more than 1,100 people were killed on 24 April 2013 and more than 2,500 injured in the rana Plaza collapse, a building that housed several garment companies.  The text sets out clearly the seriousness of these facts and the situation of labour rights in the garment industry in developing and less developed countries. For the specific case of Bangladesh, the limitations on the right to strike and trade union membership, especially in export free zones, are affected; lack of labour inspections or inadequacy of the minimum wage to meet the basic needs of the population. It also affects the hypocrisy of multinationals such as Adler Modemarkte, Ascena Retail, Carrefour, Grabalok, J.C. Penney, Manifattura Corona, NKD, PWT or YesZee, which have not yet contributed anything to the voluntary compensation fund to victims and family members despite their link to the accident. By clearly sharing these contents, I voted in favour of this Resolution.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. Sad anniversary of the collapse of Rana Plaza: 1138 workers killed, several thousand injured, and in the rubble, labels of major European brands... These Bangladeshis were overexploited and working in undignified security conditions to provide cheap clothing to the rest of the world.  Today, justice has still not been done. Millions of dollars are missing from the compensation fund for victims and their families. And much remains to be done to ensure decent working conditions.  Europe must build on existing national initiatives. The French National Assembly has thus adopted a pioneering bill that obliges transnational corporations to have a vigilance plan with their subsidiaries and subcontractors to prevent human rights and environmental abuses, fight corruption and repair the damage suffered by victims. In other countries, the same thinking is at work. This is the beginning of a movement that the European Union has the capacity and duty to amplify.  Parliament's message is clear. We call for concrete and binding measures to make companies accountable by legislating to establish a duty of vigilance and an obligation to trace and transparent the supply chain.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. Following the collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Bangladesh, killing 1,100 people and injuring 2,500, the proposal aims to update the sustainability pact launched by the Bangladeshi government, the ILO and the Commission on 8 July 2013.  The pact aims to improve the health, safety of factories and working conditions of workers in the ready-to-wear sector. The proposal denounces the exploitation of low-cost labour by large textile sector organizations. And while the European initiative for responsible supply chain management in the ready-to-wear sector is likely to undermine national initiatives, efforts to improve the defence of workers' freedoms seem to me to be paramount. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I felt it consistent with my principles to abstain: the motion has much to commend it, but it appears to have wider ramifications which would not be in accord with the principles expected of a UKIP MEP.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to commemorate the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building and to assess progress in implementing the sustainability agreement. Two years ago, rana plaza collapsed in Bangladesh. 1.1 000 people died in this disaster. People. As the world's second largest exporter of clothing, more than half of its production is exported to the EU. However, the people who produce it work in dangerous conditions. A number of changes have been made to the EU and the International Labour Organisation in support of the EU. It was agreed to improve the maintenance of factory operations and to improve fire and electrical safety rules. In addition, the minimum wage has increased and the role of trade unions has been strengthened. The Bangladesh Sustainability Agreement is an agreement between the EU and the Government of Bangladesh, which is also supported by the ILO. This agreement has partly led to changes in Bangladesh's labour law. Public pressure and potential reputational damage have led to international brands that have been involved with Rana Plaza becoming more involved in the resolution of this issue.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Doesn't the EU have its share of responsibility for the Rana Plaza tragedy? Has it not encouraged the exploitation of low-cost labour in third countries when its refusal of protectionism has ruined our own textile industry?

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Following the collapse of the Rana Plaza building on 24 April 2013 in Bangladesh, 1,100 textile workers lost their lives. This is the worst industrial disaster in the country. The European Parliament welcomes the memory of the victims on the 52nd anniversary of the disaster. Parliament also denounces the fact that a third of the companies linked to the factory did not pay money to the Donor Fund to compensate the victims and their families. Finally, Parliament welcomes the EU's sustainability pact, which aims to improve working conditions and the rights of Bengali workers.

name: Ivo BELET
text: Written. 'Dignified work must enable workers to earn their living and their families. The fact that more than 1 100 textile workers died in the Bangladeshi factories supplying finished garments to multinational chains as a result of the abuses in the textile sector is inhumane and unacceptable. In the meantime, a number of important steps have been taken to address the dire working conditions. Under the Sustainability Pact, the EU, the International Labour Organisation and the Bangladeshi Government have increased the number of inspections of buildings and raised minimum wages. This resolution calls for further progress and the sustainable protection of workers' rights in the international textile production chain. Companies must assume their responsibility and contribute to the compensation fund for the victims. But it is also a matter of considering responsible international supply chains and establishing a structural mechanism for the reimbursement of accidents at work in Bangladesh. In addition, we ask the Government of Bangladesh to better protect and enshrine freedom of association throughout the territory in accordance with international standards. Freedom of trade is crucial to prevent tragedies and to make sustainable work on living wages and decent work in the textile production chain.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The European Parliament commemorates the collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Bangladesh on 24 April 2013. The death toll caused at least 1,127 deaths and 2,500 injuries. This tragedy has become the symbol of this crazy globalization and this race for profit at all costs. It showed the conditions under which our low-cost imported garments are made and the deplorable working conditions in the textile industry.  While we are obviously deploring the collapse of this building and the number of victims, it is time for the Union to stop hiding its face with good feelings and angelic resolutions, even though it is co-responsible for this type of situation by promoting globalised free trade and the refusal of intelligent protectionism to put pressure on countries that do not respect social norms. environmental and fiscal issues.  Nevertheless, in the light of this tragedy, I voted in favour of this text and the sustainability pact.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: in writing. I supported this Resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Bangladesh. I supported the amendment detailing the names of companies which have not yet assumed their responsibility for the victims and, for this purpose, the adoption of the amendment which refers to the inclusion of a mandatory and enforceable clause on corporate social responsibility in bilateral trade and investment agreements signed by the Union has also been very important.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with what is said in the resolution we are voting on. The Rana Plaza tragedy is an emblem of a situation that is becoming increasingly untenable. The rules in force in these countries not only fuel the ignoble exploitation of these workers, but also create social dumping that is now unsustainable to our own. Europe is being complicit in this whole situation with international rules and agreements that are increasingly forcing European companies to relocate to Asia to the detriment of our market and our citizens' jobs.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I supported the Resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building, firstly, to remind the more than 1,200 fatalities, the vast majority of women, of accidents in Bangladesh's textile industry – workshops that supplied companies such as Adler Modemarkte, Ascena Retail, Carrefour, Grabalok, J.C. Penney, Manifattura Corona, NKD, PWT or YesZee; to require companies linked to Rana Plaza and the Tazreen factory, burned down shortly before, to promptly provide the aid they owe to victims, many of them unable to return to work and who need medical care; to recall the importance of the Bangladeshi Government undercomed legislative reforms to ensure effective labour protection and the right to freedom of association of workers in its country, in compliance with ILO Conventions; and because it urges the EC and EU governments to consider establishing a system that forces companies to repair and compensate victims because, under the current framework, they respond either because of their goodwill or for fear that pressure groups will point them out and highlight their irresponsible behaviour.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it marks the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building and progress in the implementation of the Bangladesh Sustainability Agreement. On 24 April 2013, an eight-storey Rana Plaza building with several garment factories collapsed in the Savar area near Dhaka, killing more than 1,100 people and injuring more than 2,500. The collapse of this rana plaza building is the worst industrial disaster ever in Bangladesh and the tragedy that has been claimed by the greatest casualty in modern history due to a structural shortage. On 24 November 2012, a fire at the Tazreen plant in the Asulia district of dhaka city killed at least 112 people. Parliament has welcomed the steps taken to establish a permanent national insurance scheme against disasters at work and, in this regard, calls on the Government of Bangladesh to fulfil its commitment to the implementation of the National Tripartite Action Plan. However, it remains concerned about the alleged corruption in Bangladesh between health and safety inspectors and clothing factory owners and calls for more efforts to combat this practice.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ The tragic suffering of textile factory workers in Bangladesh alerts us to the working conditions there. It is necessary to use all instruments in negotiations with these countries to make workers more safe.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. I voted for the Declaration on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building. Indeed, the disastrous consequences of a deadly globalization, in particular the shameful exploitation of a low-cost labour force, must be denounced. This building on the outskirts of Dhaka, the capital of Bangladesh, housed several garment shops working for various international clothing brands. As a full member of the Delegation for Relations with South Asia, I am particularly sensitive to this issue. Last March, the Vice-President of the Subcommittee on Human Rights presented us with the report of a recent study trip to Bangladesh.  The responsibility of European industrialists in the sector, in Bangladesh, was highlighted, in particular.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because the collapse of the Rana Plaza building was a tragedy and it shows us that much has to be done in order to ensure that workers all over the world are able to work in a safe environment without risking their lives every day on the job. It is our duty to help countries like Bangladesh to achieve a higher level of protection of workers’ rights in order to make sure that tragedies like this one do not happen ever again.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote was positive. Cases such as the Rana Plaza are the emblem of an untenable situation. The rules currently in force in these countries mean that social dumping against our workers is very high. The EU is also complicit, with its rules and the international agreements it contracts, and is encouraging more and more European companies to relocate cheaply to Asia where social and labour protection conditions are null and void.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I supported the Resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building, firstly, to remind the more than 1,200 fatalities, the vast majority of women, of accidents in Bangladesh's textile industry – workshops that supplied companies such as Adler Modemarkte, Ascena Retail, Carrefour, Grabalok, J.C. Penney, Manifattura Corona, NKD, PWT or YesZee; to require companies linked to Rana Plaza and the Tazreen factory, burned down shortly before, to promptly provide the aid they owe to victims, many of them unable to return to work and who need medical care; to recall the importance of the Bangladeshi Government undercomed legislative reforms to ensure effective labour protection and the right to freedom of association of workers in its country, in compliance with ILO Conventions; and because it urges the EC and EU governments to consider establishing a system that forces companies to repair and compensate victims because, under the current framework, they respond either because of their goodwill or for fear that pressure groups will point them out and highlight their irresponsible behaviour.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Bangladesh is one of the world's largest textile exporters. In response to global competition in the ready-to-wear sector, major exporting countries tend to reduce the quality of work of their employees both in terms of safety, health and wages. The Rana Plaza fire is proof of this assertion. Security and incendiary standards were not met, which inevitably led to this tragedy. Now, two years later, the situation in Bangladesh has changed considerably. Some measures have been put in place through the Sustainability Pact to improve working conditions for employees in textile companies. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution for the "Second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building and the situation of the sustainability pact" so that tragedies such as the emblematic Rana Plaza that cost the lives of 1 138 people will no longer happen. Two years have passed and these companies have not yet been able to provide adequate funding to compensate the victims of the families of the deceased workers.  The Rana Plaza tragedy was the terminus of a global production system that is no longer able to protect people's fundamental rights, reduced to mere commodities traded for a few pennies in the international labour market.  We must work to export European standards with regard to the rights of those who work all over the world. While the number of deaths at work in the world is still falling in Europe, the figures for white deaths are still very high, there are about 2 million people a year of these 12 000 children.  Europe must also be able to provide its citizens with the necessary tools to make responsible choices according to criteria of justice, equity and social solidarity, security and economy.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This month marked the second anniversary of the Rana Plaza building collapse in Bangladesh, in which more than 1 100 workers died in one of the most fatal industrial accidents of our time. As a result of the Rana Plaza disaster, a number of initiatives were taken on an international level to improve the situation in the ready-made garment sector. This sector employs 4 million people, mostly female workers in Bangladesh. One of these initiatives was the Sustainability Compact, which was signed in July 2013. The Rana Plaza building collapse was followed by a public outcry which exposed a number of violations of labour law. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am pleased that the resolution has included amendments tabled by our group, in particular the one on putting pressure on clothing companies to contribute more fully to the economic fund for the families of the victims. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which commemorates the collapse of the Rana Plaza building and provides an update on the progress of the sustainability pact. It was indeed important to pay tribute to the 1,100 dead and 2500 injured in this tragedy of 24 April 2013, when the eight-storey Rana Plaza building, located in the town of Savar on the outskirts of Dhaka and which housed several garment shops, collapsed.  A veritable industrial and human disaster for Bangladesh, this dramatic event also highlights the need to take action on the textile industry: adopting a mandatory clause on corporate social responsibility in all EU agreements, combating the exploitation of low-cost labour, which remains in a situation of great social and economic insecurity, as much as the EU should make, as much effort as the EU should make. , she always so quick to give moral lessons to everyone.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. ‒ Today we mark the second anniversary of the tragedy in Bangladesh where the collapse of the Rana Plaza building killed 1 134 people and injured hundreds of others. Families of the victims are still fighting for compensation and, although a number of major brands have donated to the Rana Plaza Donors Trust Fund to award compensation, there is still a huge shortfall. Despite the efforts of the International Labour Organisation and of EU and US agencies, the rights and safety of garment factory workers in Bangladesh are still not being safeguarded. Many companies are still refusing to pay their workers a fair living wage, and the issuing of building permits is still not being properly monitored. Unless there is real pressure from across the globe, we will continue to see cheap and fast fashion at the cost of human lives.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because it aims to improve working conditions, health and safety in Bangladesh's clothing factories.  The need for greater protection for workers became necessary following the tragedy of the collapse on April 24, 2013 of the "Rana Plaza" in Dhaka, where an 8-storey commercial building, which squatterly housed 5 clothing factories, collapsed, killing 1,129 workers, mostly women and some under the age of 10. I welcome the commitment of the Government of Bangladesh to reconstitute the Department for Inspections in Factories and Factories, as well as the significant strengthening of its inspection services in January 2014 and the adoption of a national health and safety policy.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The tragic event in Rana Plaza, whose second anniversary is celebrated, is just one of several accidents in the least developed countries, where workers work in total absence of safety standards. Although the Government of Bangladesh is not yet in line with international safety standards, some significant progress has been made thanks to the EU Sustainability Pact, which aims to ensure respect for workers' rights and to promote responsible behaviour by companies in the packaging industry in Bangladesh.   Therefore, considering it necessary to continue implementing the commitments agreed with the Bangladeshi authorities, I have decided to vote in favour of this motion for a resolution.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 On April 24, 2013, more than 1,100 people died and thousands were injured in the collapse of the Rana Plaza building, located in Savar, Bangladesh.  The collapsed building of the Rana Plaza factory had been illegally built and did not comply with safety regulations. Since the disaster, 29 factories have been permanently closed, following major safety concerns, while 17 factories have been partially closed. However, a significant number of factories have yet to raise their standards to a sufficient level. I am voting in favour of this joint motion for a resolution because I believe that we need not only local action in Bangladesh, but also new legislation at EU level establishing a legal obligation of due corporate diligence in the field of human rights for EU companies that outsource production to third countries, including binding measures to ensure traceability and transparency through legislation that obliges companies wishing to operate in the market. european Union to implement due diligence and to provide information about the entire supply chain of its products, in line with the UN guiding principles on business and human rights.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. As the Resolution recalls, more than 1,100 people were killed on 24 April 2013 and more than 2,500 injured in the rana Plaza collapse, a building that housed several garment companies.  The text sets out clearly the seriousness of these facts and the situation of labour rights in the garment industry in developing and less developed countries. For the specific case of Bangladesh, the limitations on the right to strike and trade union membership, especially in export free zones, are affected; lack of labour inspections or inadequacy of the minimum wage to meet the basic needs of the population. It also affects the hypocrisy of multinationals such as Adler Modemarkte, Ascena Retail, Carrefour, Grabalok, J.C. Penney, Manifattura Corona, NKD, PWT or YesZee, which have not yet contributed anything to the voluntary compensation fund to victims and family members despite their link to the accident. By clearly sharing these contents, I voted in favour of this Resolution.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 In Bangladesh, there are about 4,000 textile factories, where more than 3 million people work, with Bangladesh being the world's second largest clothing producer after China. Rising labour prices in other parts of the world led to the transfer of low-skilled labour to India, Pakistan, Cambodia, Vietnam and, in particular, Bangladesh. Conditions in textile factories are often poor, with very little attention being paid to workers' rights, such as those recognised by the main ILO conventions, and safety rules are not respected at all or only to a small extent. It is necessary for the European executive to continue to actively promote the obligation of responsible commercial behaviour among EU companies operating abroad, with a particular focus on ensuring strict compliance with international standards and norms in the fields of human rights, labour and the environment. Workers and trade unions play an important role in the continued development of workers- and workers' safety committees in all factories, as well as the importance of trade unions' access to factories in order to train workers on how to protect their rights and safety, including the right to refuse safe work.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which remembers the victims of the Rana Plaza tragedy in Bangladesh on the occasion of the second anniversary of the tragic events. The resolution calls for more commitment to real change by the Government of Bangladesh, including by making the necessary changes to the Bangladesh Labour Act. In Bangladesh there are still numerous obstacles to the exercise of freedom of association and collective bargaining, trade-union limitations and the lack of effective labour inspection for the enforcement of labour standards.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 On April 24, 2013 in Dhaka, Bangladesh, rana plaza collapsed, a building that housed clothing companies where mostly women worked. A great many people have died and been injured, first and foremost victims of non-compliance with basic standards in the areas of health and safety at work and workers' rights. The resolution, which I voted for whole much and of which I am a co-signatory, is intended first and foremost to remember the more than a thousand victims of that tragedy. It also brings attention to the issue of working conditions in developing countries, which often blatantly violate the most basic international rules and conventions on labour rights and trade union freedom and create unfair competition with European producers.  Bangladesh, like so many other developing countries, still has a great deal of progress to make to ensure that workers' health and safety conditions at work are substantially improved and that companies, including foreign companies, behave responsibly.  The EU will also have to play its part, including the ratification of the ILO's core standards, health and safety inspections and freedom of association as a condition for granting trade preferences.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: Written. 'This resolution mandates the European Commission to intervene in depth in Bangladesh's internal affairs. As much as the situation in Bangladesh is to be regretted, it is up to Bangladesh itself to shape its social and economic system. That is not what the EU is about. In addition, it is up to the Member States themselves to decide which imports they allow on the market and what requirements they place on origin and production methods. The PVV therefore votes against.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. Two years ago, the Rana Plaza factory collapsed in Bangladesh, killing many textile workers (1,100 people lost their lives there). Since this tragedy, thanks to the Bangladesh Sustainability Pact and the active support of the EU and the ILO, a few changes have taken place: agreements to improve factory inspections and electrical safety standards and in the event of a fire, an increase in the minimum wage, the adoption of a law on the training of trade unions, etc. This pact aims to ensure that there is long-term follow-up because much remains to be done: combating anti-union discrimination and corruption of health and safety inspectors, urging Bangladesh to act first on all its commitments, etc. The fund created to collect corporate donations to compensate victims and families is still missing $3 million (out of 30). It is important to ensure that all compensation due will be distributed. I have supported this text without reservation.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. Following the collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Bangladesh, killing 1,100 people and injuring 2,500, the proposal aims to update the sustainability pact launched by the Bangladeshi government, the ILO and the Commission on 8 July 2013.  The pact aims to improve the health, safety of factories and working conditions of workers in the ready-to-wear sector. The proposal denounces the exploitation of low-cost labour by large textile sector organizations. And while the European initiative for responsible supply chain management in the ready-to-wear sector is likely to undermine national initiatives, efforts to improve the defence of workers' freedoms seem to me to be paramount. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I approve this step for a joint resolution, as it is very important for us to support the proper implementation of the Bangladesh Sustainability Pact. The obvious violation of human rights needs to be corrected and I welcome relief efforts by ensuring a control process providing the right guidance.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The fall of Rana Plaza, an eight-storey building in Savar, on the outskirts of Ddaca, where several garment factories operated, killed more than 1,100 people and injured more than 2,500, turning into the most serious industrial disaster in Bangladesh. Factory fires, building collapses and other incidents related to workplace health and safety issues are not limited only to Bangladesh's confectionery sector, but are very worrying issues in other developing countries and less developed countries. In addition to the need to comply with international standards with regard to the safety and conditions of workers, it is important that the $3 million available for compensation is distributed without further delay.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 1,129 people died and about 2,515 injured were pulled alive from the rubble in the Rana Plaza collapse in Bangladesh. Five thousand people worked in the palace, mostly women, who produced clothing for many well-known Western brands.  It is well known that the conditions under which workers were forced to work were scandalous to say the least, both in terms of safety and in economic terms. This exploitation of workers had only one purpose: to satisfy the blind interest in the profit – whatever the cost – of Western companies that often own famous brands. Despite the commitment made by companies worldwide, two years after the tragedy, most of the victims have not yet been compensated and the safety standards situation in Bangladesh's textile factories remains very critical. The survivors, many of whom have remained inseadable, are probably the ones who pay the highest price today.  For these reasons, we have a duty not to forget and denounce what happened at rana plaza, but also to demand that entrepreneurs who sell their products on the European market at least comply with the most basic rules on corporate social responsibility.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The tragedy in Bangladesh has revived a long-known problem: inhumane working conditions and extreme exploitation in the production chain of multinationals supplying the European market. A few thousand more lives have been claimed on the altar of global capitalism. The country is the second largest textile producer in the world. Almost 90% of production is destined for Europe, the USA and Canada. The Ddase region has been reconfigured by the proliferation of manufacturing units operating in unhealthy spaces, under subcontracting, practicing miserable salaries of 30 euros/month and denying the most elementary labor rights. There are about 100,000 factories, in the capital area alone. Two years on the rana plaza tragedy continue to take action in the face of companies profiting from the persistence of this situation. Mechanisms to cope with imports of products of this origin are still delayed. The EU is not interested in really changing the situation and this resolution, in essence, demonstrates this.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ on the second anniversary of the Tragedy at Rana Plaza, one of the worst industrial disasters, we are obliged to reiterate that if there were better occupational safety and health systems, loss of human life could have been prevented. It is also worth pointing out that many companies, which were likely to have ties to the Rana Plaza factory complex, had underperformed their contributions to the trust fund and several firms refused to even disclose the amount they contributed. I therefore welcome the initiative led by the European Union to implement the Pact on issues of safety and health at work, working conditions, respect for labour rights and the promotion of responsible business behaviour in Bangladesh.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution denouncing labour problems in countries such as Bangladesh. There is no doubt, however, that I am also denounced by the EU, which I believe is complicit, with its rules and with the international agreements that it contracts and which increasingly encourage European companies to relocate cheaply to Asia.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I consider it essential to recognise the responsibility of textile companies for the dignity of work. In this regard, this resolution expressly stresses the need for actions aimed at increasing wages, intensifying inspection activity and, in general, ensuring greater transparency and traceability of products. The European institutions are also asked to recall what is contained in the ILO conventions, particularly with regard to issues relating to the health and safety of workers, when concluding trade agreements with third countries, in order to extend the requirements that guarantee every citizen the right to decent work.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 My vote is in favour of the report on the anniversary of the Bangladesh factory fires and the progress of the Bangladesh Sustainability Pact because measures to improve conditions are generally proposed.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The collapse of the Rana Plaza building was one of the deadliest tragedies in the history of the garment industry and one that served as an important wake-up call about the need for urgent reforms. Following this tragedy the textile industry has been changed forever, and finally common goals have been established in relation to safety standards, workers’ safety and workers’ rights. I believe that the Bangladesh Sustainability Compact is a fundamental step towards improved labour rights, working conditions and factory safety. It has the potential to avert another factory collapse through a more responsible management of the garment industry supply chain in Bangladesh. We should encourage further efforts by the Government of Bangladesh to complete the relevant labour-law reform, to recruit and train labour inspectors and to create the conditions for meaningful freedom of association in the country. In commemoration of the anniversary of the tragedy it is important that we remember the victims and extend our deepest condolences to their families, with the hope that the Sustainability Compact will prevent any repeat of these dreadful events.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. U2012 The 2013 collapse of the Rana Plaza building that housed several garment companies caused more than 1,100 fatalities and some 2,500 injured. Positive steps have been taken to improve the situation of workers in Bangladesh, such as the EU-led initiative to launch the Covenant, to ensure a fresh start in occupational health and safety, working conditions, respect for labour rights and the promotion of responsible business behaviour in the Bangladeshi garment industry. Similarly, the Bangladeshi authorities have made good progress, but there is still a long way to go in this field. From the EU we must be vigilant in fulfilling obligations to Bangladeshi workers.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I supported the Resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building, firstly, to remind the more than 1,200 fatalities, the vast majority of women, of accidents in Bangladesh's textile industry – workshops that supplied companies such as Adler Modemarkte, Ascena Retail, Carrefour, Grabalok, J.C. Penney, Manifattura Corona, NKD, PWT or YesZee; to require companies linked to Rana Plaza and the Tazreen factory, burned down shortly before, to promptly provide the aid they owe to victims, many of them unable to return to work and who need medical care; to recall the importance of the Bangladeshi Government undercomed legislative reforms to ensure effective labour protection and the right to freedom of association of workers in its country, in compliance with ILO Conventions; and because it urges the EC and EU governments to consider establishing a system that forces companies to repair and compensate victims because, under the current framework, they respond either because of their goodwill or for fear that pressure groups will point them out and highlight their irresponsible behaviour.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I supported the Resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building, firstly, to remind the more than 1,200 fatalities, the vast majority of women, of accidents in Bangladesh's textile industry – workshops that supplied companies such as Adler Modemarkte, Ascena Retail, Carrefour, Grabalok, J.C. Penney, Manifattura Corona, NKD, PWT or YesZee; to require companies linked to Rana Plaza and the Tazreen factory, burned down shortly before, to promptly provide the aid they owe to victims, many of them unable to return to work and who need medical care; to recall the importance of the Bangladeshi Government undercomed legislative reforms to ensure effective labour protection and the right to freedom of association of workers in its country, in compliance with ILO Conventions; and because it urges the EC and EU governments to consider establishing a system that forces companies to repair and compensate victims because, under the current framework, they respond either because of their goodwill or for fear that pressure groups will point them out and highlight their irresponsible behaviour.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With this resolution, to which I am a signatory, we wanted to express our closeness to all the families of the victims of the Rana Plaza disaster and the Tazreen fire. These tragedies could easily have been avoided if only basic rules on safety at work had been complied with. We welcomed the EU's action, which promoted and was part of a pact with the UNITED States and the ILO to urge Bangladesh to ensure the safety of workers, including in cooperation with the industrial sector. We will monitor the action of the Government of Bangladesh. A first step has been taken, but it is necessary to ensure that all the actors involved fulfil their commitments.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I believe that we must ensure that new European legislation is put in place which is incapable of disregarding, in company matters, the profound respect and protection of the human rights of the staff employed. The dignity of the individual and the right to well-being are fundamental values of the Union and we cannot accept that they can be put at risk either in the Member States or in third countries where the large multinationals operate and trade. That is why I strongly support and support the motion for a resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building. Two years after the tragic accident, I can only welcome the great work that continues to be done by the ILO, together with the Government of Bangladesh, on new policies to protect the safety and guarantee of workers' human rights, but at the same time I deplore the delays in full compensation to the families of the victims and the episodes of corruption that unfortunately still contribute to the slowing down of fair compensation procedures and good business and administrative practices. I hope that Bangladesh and its workers will increasingly move towards a sustainable economy and production that respect human dignity, as clearly highlighted in the guidelines of the Global Compact and those of the United Nations Johannesburg Declaration.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Notwithstanding the fact that some improvements have been made since the Rana Plaza disaster two years ago, we still have a long way to go in securing decent working conditions for the four million workers of the textile industry in Bangladesh. That is why I supported this resolution, and more particularly the call on the Bangladeshi government to fully reform the Labour Act and ensure safe buildings and robust health and safety legislation, which can support vital jobs in the garments industry. Furthermore, the government needs to ensure that workers can make use of their right to form trade unions. It is unacceptable that members of trade unions continue to suffer discrimination and dismissal to this very day. It is also high time international brands start taking responsibility and pay the outstanding 8.5 million USD in compensation they still owe to the survivors and the relatives of the victims. Last but not least, Rana Plaza made clear that access to information in the garment sector remains the most important obstacle to tackling human rights violations in the global supply chain. That is why it is crucial that a legal obligation of due diligence is imposed on EU companies outsourcing production to third countries.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. Commemorating the terrible slaughter of workers at the textile complex in Bangladesh is a moral duty. We must always remember and highlight the serious negligence and complicated working environment that caused such a tragedy, with the knowledge, unfortunately, that the conditions of that time have not changed. As long as Bangladesh does not really raise safety standards and has effective labour legislation that includes real inspections and freedom of association, workers will always be exposed to very serious dangers. We must also remember the unresolved aspects of this matter. We cannot forget the families of the victims, who have not yet received any compensation for the losses they have suffered. It is a disgrace when we consider that that factory produced for large clothing brands that certainly do not lack resources to compensate the victims.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution in support of human rights in Bangladesh, recalling the sad event at Rana Plaza.  Two years ago, more than 3,000 textile workers in Bangladesh fell victim to financial cynicism and the race for globalization.  Through relocations, international institutions such as the WTO, the European Commission and the European Parliament are helping to transform entire countries into subcontracting centres, under conditions that Émile Zola himself would have recognised as slavery.  "Decarbonization of the economy", "free trade agreements", all words that cover only one objective: ever more profits for some transnationals.  The Union's decisions lead to unemployment and misery here, but also there. The European Union is as responsible as the contractors, with little regard for working conditions provided that the price is always falling.  Let us truly pay tribute to these bereaved workers and families by regaining our autonomy of production. This would finally allow developing countries to focus on the needs of their people rather than being enslaved. Respect for human rights there begins with us.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building and the progress of the Sustainability Pact, as we consider the recognition of the responsibility of companies in the textile sector and their subcontractors to address issues of labour dignity of paramount importance. In addition, the Resolution makes an explicit mention of the importance of raising minimum wages and sponsoring labour inspections and their transparency for the dignity of workers. The Resolution also calls on the authorities of the European Union to take into account the conventions of the International Labour Organization and the international standards of health and safety of workers when signing trade and economic partnership agreements with third countries, in order to promote decent work.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because it expresses its support for those who have died and their loved ones, marking the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building. The collapse of the Rana Plaza, which has housed several garment factories and killed more than 1,100 people and injured more than 2,500, was the worst industrial disaster ever in Bangladesh and the tragedy that has claimed the most casualties in modern history. Parliament has welcomed the steps taken to establish a permanent national insurance scheme against disasters at work and, in this regard, calls on the Government of Bangladesh to fulfil its commitment to the implementation of the National Tripartite Action Plan. It also calls for a solution to persistent corruption among health and safety inspectors and clothing factory owners.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. I supported the Resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building, firstly, to remind the more than 1,200 fatalities, the vast majority of women, of accidents in Bangladesh's textile industry – workshops that supplied companies such as Adler Modemarkte, Ascena Retail, Carrefour, Grabalok, J.C. Penney, Manifattura Corona, NKD, PWT or YesZee; to require companies linked to Rana Plaza and the Tazreen factory, burned down shortly before, to promptly provide the aid they owe to victims, many of them unable to return to work and who need medical care; to recall the importance of the Bangladeshi Government undercomed legislative reforms to ensure effective labour protection and the right to freedom of association of workers in its country, in compliance with ILO Conventions; and because it urges the EC and EU governments to consider establishing a system that forces companies to repair and compensate victims because, under the current framework, they respond either because of their goodwill or for fear that pressure groups will point them out and highlight their irresponsible behaviour.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution on the Rana Plaza building collapse. I was happy to support Amendment 1, naming and shaming companies which did not pay their fair share of the contributions and those companies which have refused to declare their donation. I voted against Amendment 2 but I am changing my vote to ‘in favour’, as I had intended to vote in favour of a mandatory and enforceable corporate social responsibility (CSR) clause in all bilateral trade and investment agreements signed by the EU, but unfortunately I pressed the wrong button.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution as I believe that more must be done to improve working conditions in Bangladesh. The European Parliament has an important role to play in putting pressure on the Bangladeshi government to act on its commitments to improve working conditions, particularly for factory workers.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a joint motion for a resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building and the progress of the Bangladesh Sustainability Pact, as it reaffirms the interest of the European Union and member states as well as other entities in the assistance bangladesh needs and expects from us. The tragic events two years ago with the fire and collapse of the Rana Plaza building, which caused the deaths of a large number of people, have not yet been healed. Responsibility for this event is also on the European side and therefore we should participate in the repair of all the consequences of this tragedy. For these reasons, I believe that this report shows well the situation and needs and I want to support it as an expression of European solidarity and responsibility.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. Following the collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Bangladesh, killing 1,100 people and injuring 2,500, the proposal aims to update the sustainability pact launched by the Bangladeshi government, the ILO and the Commission on 8 July 2013.  The pact aims to improve the health, safety of factories and working conditions of workers in the ready-to-wear sector. The proposal denounces the exploitation of low-cost labour by large textile sector organizations. And while the European initiative for responsible supply chain management in the ready-to-wear sector is likely to undermine national initiatives, efforts to improve the defence of workers' freedoms seem to me to be paramount. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution commemorating the second anniversary of the collapse of textile factories in Bangladesh following fires. The deplorable working conditions in these factories had sparked international outrage, leading the country to improve its legislation and for companies using these factories to pay compensation to families affected by the fires. The resolution stresses, however, the importance of the road ahead to end the precarious social situation of Bangladeshi workers. The resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. The report makes good demands on reporting on compliance with the Code of Conduct of companies that produce in Bangladesh and have their sales market in Europe. Compliance with such standards is important for the creation of wealth in these countries and does not conflict with the low production costs, which are the main incentive for outsourcing production. That is why I am voting in favour of the proposal that has been tabled.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I wholeheartedly support this motion for a resolution. Two years after 1 129 workers lost their lives in the Rana Plaza building collapse, as well as numerous other deaths in the region from factory fires and collapses, we mark the anniversary in order to show respect for the victims. I welcome the continued monitoring of the situation. It is of vital importance that the conditions of the Sustainability Compact continue to be implemented in order to improve the working conditions for the four million workers in 4 000 textile factories in Bangladesh, particularly in areas such as occupational safety and respect of labour rights. We acknowledge the efforts already made by the Government of Bangladesh and the further improvements that must be undertaken.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ The day before Rana Plaza collapsed, workers did not have a collective voice to enable them to refuse to enter an unsafe workplace, and they were confronted by factory management with the choice of losing their jobs. This was not just a Bangladeshi tragedy but an international one, with 29 international brands sourcing garments from the factories housed in the faulty building. It is a disgrace that those injured and the families of the victims still await rightful compensation while brands continue to generate large profits. Payments must be made. Sadly, it took a manmade disaster to begin long overdue efforts to ensure better working conditions in the sector. Thorough reform of the Bangladesh Labour Act is therefore needed. We have a moral obligation to ensure a more comprehensive and effective multilateral approach to make basic labour standards and minimum working conditions a priority. The EU needs to use its influence for this change. We owe this to the more than 1 100 workers who lost their lives on 24 April 2013 and to future generations. I echo my colleagues in hoping that the Commission will push for the compensation to be paid, for the prevention of future tragedies and for the strengthening of trade unions.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. We still have in our memories the memory of those terrible images of 24 April 2013 in Bangladesh, in which over a thousand people lost their lives. My thoughts today more than ever go to those victims. The Pact signed in Geneva is a response to the Rana Plaza tragedy, but I agree with the Commission on the need to support improvements in the implementation and development of the Sustainability Compact, a targeted programme for the world of work in Bangladesh promoted and sponsored by the EU, the US and the ILO.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The resolution of the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building focuses on the progress of the sustainability pact that followed. Despite this disaster, which tragically demonstrated the terrible working conditions in the textile industry in developing countries, the commitments made by companies often remain in the promise stages, whether on safety at work, remuneration, the right to collective action and the end of corruption. I have therefore supported this text, which reminds the companies that are prime contractors of their commitments to improve labour rights and security measures for their productions and those of their subcontractors, which calls for the introduction of a minimum wage for living in Bangladesh, as well as an end to the corruption schemes of local authorities.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution because it pays tribute to the 1,200 textile workers who were victims of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building two years ago in Bangladesh's capital. That said, the European Union is partly responsible for this tragedy, because it encourages the ultraliberalism and social dumping that cause it.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. Our group has requested a statement from the Commission, followed by a Parliamentary Resolution, on the occasion of the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Bangladesh, the fire in the also Bangladeshi resort of Tazreen and other consecutive tragedies that ended up in Southeast Asia with the lives of more than 1,200 workers in the textile industry — the vast majority women — that they produced for European and other western companies. Among the most popular examples are Spanish companies such as Inditex, Mango and El Corte Inglés, and others operating in Spain such as H&D, Benetton and Primark. The catastrophes highlighted the terrible working, health and safety conditions in which the people who produce the clothes of many of our major brands work, as well as the lack of transparency in the supply chain. It took some of the companies weeks to find out if they had subcontractors with the workshops affected by these tragedies, and the compensation paid to victims or their families came very late. In fact, today, responsible companies still owe about nine million U.S. dollars to the compensation fund created to assist those affected.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. As the Resolution recalls, more than 1,100 people were killed on 24 April 2013 and more than 2,500 injured in the rana Plaza collapse, a building that housed several garment companies.  The text sets out clearly the seriousness of these facts and the situation of labour rights in the garment industry in developing and less developed countries. For the specific case of Bangladesh, the limitations on the right to strike and trade union membership, especially in export free zones, are affected; lack of labour inspections or inadequacy of the minimum wage to meet the basic needs of the population. It also affects the hypocrisy of multinationals such as Adler Modemarkte, Ascena Retail, Carrefour, Grabalok, J.C. Penney, Manifattura Corona, NKD, PWT or YesZee, which have not yet contributed anything to the voluntary compensation fund to victims and family members despite their link to the accident. By clearly sharing these contents, I voted in favour of this Resolution.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very sorry for the victims of the tragedy that took place in a Bangladeshi factory. However, I do not believe that the EU should try to oversee factories variously around the world and "advise" sovereign states on what laws or regulations to adopt. I am particularly concerned about populist calls to raise the minimum wage, which may make a large proportion of people in the Third World unemployable and their poverty will thus increase.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The biggest disaster in the textile industry is the collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Bangladesh two years ago, which killed 1,134 people and injured hundreds. Only when accidents like this happen does a loud discussion begin about the problems of labour exploitation and working conditions.  It is regrettable that the survivors and families of those killed in the Rana Plaza building collapse have not yet been fully compensated. The partial culprit is the Italian textile company Benetton, which has only now agreed to pay $1.1 million into a compensation fund, as one of a series of companies with production in Rana Plaza.   This disaster should be a warning to all and an incentive to respect workers' rights and ensure safe workplace conditions. The warning applies in particular to large companies that have their production facilities in developing countries where labour is cheaper.    The purpose of the resolution, which I supported, is to pay tribute to the victims of this tragedy and remind everyone that timely care of working conditions could have prevented the disaster. The resolution supports all efforts and initiatives aimed at improving OSH, working conditions, respecting workers' rights and promoting responsible business behaviour in the industry.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ Bangladesh is the second largest producer of textile clothing, with textile industry exports representing 85%, with 60% of exports going to European Union countries. Production in the textile industry provides a livelihood for 40 million Bangladeshi populations, 25% of the total population. Interest in goods and reckless pursuit of profits have led to the construction of illegal buildings, without taking into account safety regulations and standards. This was also the cause of the tragic death of 1,100 employees and the injuries of another 2,500 people in the collapse of the Rana Plaza building, which was home to mostly clothing companies. Despite this tragedy, to date, not all the compensation associated with the tragedy has been paid, which has ethical implications in addition to undesirable economic consequences. It is therefore necessary to adopt and implement measures that allow cooperation and trade only with partners demonstrably respecting the legal security requirements and standards for carrying out the work, while respecting human rights.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building and developments with regard to the Bangladesh Sustainability Pact for the reasons I analysed in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament of 27 April 2015.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this motion of resolution because it denounces the globalist organisation of the textile sector and its serious negative consequences. The fight against the exploitation of low-cost labour, as it exists in some countries, is a necessity.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
