text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 'second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building and the situation of the Stability Pact'. It was the worst industrial disaster in Bangladesh and the deadliest accidental structural failure in modern history, killing more than 1,100 people.  Two years after the collapse of the building in Bangladesh, the survivors are still in a dramatic condition. More than 60% need constant medical care, one in five has even worsened. And fashion houses are slow to compensate. The employment figures are also dramatic: more than 55% of the textile workers who were employed in the Rana Plaza are currently out of work and, despite the forms of economic compensation received, continue to have serious economic difficulties.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 In April 2013 rana plaza, an eight-story building home to various clothing factories located in Savar, Bangladesh, collapsed. The accident killed more than 1,100 people. It was the worst industrial disaster in Bangladesh and the deadliest accidental structural failure in modern history. The collapsed building in the Rana Plaza complex had been built illegally and without the safety criteria being met. I have decided to support this resolution because I believe it is important for the international community to take a strong stance of condemnation of anyone who does not respect workers' rights, first and for all the right to safety.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The report on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building and the state of play of the Sustainability Pact, in my view, make useful demands on the code of conduct of companies that not only produce there but also have their market in Europe. Moreover, compliance with such standards for wealth creation in these countries is very important in order to keep potential economic refugees there, and is not at odds with low production costs. That is why I voted in favour of this motion.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution to mark the second anniversary of the Rana Plaza garment factory collapse, as more needs to be done to tackle corruption in the health and safety inspectorates and to improve working conditions.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: in writing. ‒ Progress on investigating the Rana Plaza building collapse and on ensuring satisfactory levels of health and safety at work remains disappointing, as does the Bangladesh Government’s reluctance to pave the way for trade union formation. Democracy is declining fast in Bangladesh: elections at all levels are held without full participation in a free and fair process. The EU cannot expect to achieve fundamental workers’ rights in an environment where political governance has broken down, widespread human rights violations prevail, and media freedom and democratic rights are curbed. There is a serious democratic deficit in Bangladesh. For example, in the city elections in Dhaka and Chittagong, on 28 April 2015, media reports alleged that Awami League activists attacked Opposition leader Khaleda Zia’s vehicle, and serious allegations have been made that these elections were rigged in favour of Government-supported candidates. Attacks on the Swedish Ambassador to Dhaka as he was observing the elections are also a matter of concern. Therefore, it is now important to address the issue of a free, fair and inclusive national election. The lack of free elections is the root cause of the political turmoil in Bangladesh. Without sound political governance in Bangladesh, securing workers’ rights and safer workplaces will be difficult.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The resolution proposes a state of affairs two years after the collapse of the Rana Plaza in Bangladesh, which resulted in 1,100 deaths and 2500 injuries at its ready-to-wear factories. She is particularly critical of the government's onst efforts on working conditions and related rights of workers. It also denounces the lack of participation of large companies in the support fund set up for the victims of the Rana Plaza. It calls for such funds to be mandatory in the future to ensure the substantial participation of companies such as Benetton and Mango. The text also denounces collusion and corruption between multinationals and local elected officials. But this resolution does not criticise the Union's national policy and its generalised preference system. Indeed, without solidarity protectionism, European SMEs cannot cope with European companies that pay its workers in Bangladesh 60 euros a month and then export their products to Europe at preferential rates.  Nevertheless, I vote for this report which is unusually critical for the European Parliament, recognising at least the responsibility for these own European policies and companies.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ This joint resolution recalls the victims of this tragedy in Bangladesh, and I offer my sincere condolences to the families of the victims of the Rana Plaza tragedy. The resolution also notes the positive steps that have been made in the field of occupational health and safety over the past two years. The EU-led initiative to launch the Sustainability Compact has had a positive impact and the Bangladeshi authorities are reportedly making good progress in improving health and safety in factories and working conditions in the Ready-Made Garment (RMG) industry.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: Written. – Two years ago, the Rana Plaza plant in Bangladesh collapsed. This tragedy, which claimed the lives of more than 1,100 workers, illustrated the human cost of producing cheap clothing in unsafe conditions. The international public outcry following this tragedy led to a change in mentality among all the actors involved. In order to give textile production in Bangladesh a better future, the EU 'Sustainability Pact Bangladesh' initiative was launched with the support of the ILO. This agreement ensured that there are better labour inspections today, that working conditions have improved, that the minimum wage has increased and that workers can unite. The Sustainability Pact aims to ensure that the situation is monitored in the longer term. In order to achieve the objectives, the Efforts and commitment of the Bangladeshi Government to capacity building for a safe and healthy working environment, better remuneration and the right to unionise workers must be stepped up. With 4 million workers, the textile industry is an important economic sector in Bangladesh. Safe working conditions, a correct price, a decent wage and guaranteeing the freedom of union of workers are essential factors in achieving sustainable economic growth in Bangladesh.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on second anniversary of the Rana Plaza building that collapsed on 24 April 2013 outside Dhaka, causing the death of over 1 100 people and leaving some 2 500 people injured.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The European Parliament commemorates the collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Bangladesh on 24 April 2013. The death toll caused at least 1,127 people.  It was a 9-storey textile workshop, designed to accommodate only 5. It supplied the major global brands. This tragedy has become a symbol of this globalization, which some people describe as happy. It showed the conditions under which our low-cost imported garments were made. He also showed how the textile industry is trying to evade its responsibilities by curbing any improvement in social norms in Bangladesh.  The European Parliament here deplores the consequences of globalised free trade, an absolute dogma that the European Union continues to cherish. It is high time to propose, in addition to this "sustainability pact in Bangladesh", reasonable protectionism to put pressure on countries that do not meet certain standards and play on social dumping. I have decided to vote in favour of this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution, which pays tribute to the victims of the Rana Plaza collapse and the Tazreen factory fire in 2013 and 2012 on the outskirts of Dhaka, Bangladesh. This text recalls that neither the owners nor the managers of these factories were brought to justice, even though these textile production sites had been built illegally and did not meet any safety standards. More than a thousand people were killed and 2,500 injured in the tragedies.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this resolution so that the European Commission and companies monitor the implementation of the sustainability agreement in Bangladesh and continue to work to improve the situation of workers in that country. Over the past two decades, economic growth has helped reduce poverty in Bangladesh by almost a third. Even today, however, 31% of the population lives below the poverty line. The ready-to-wear clothing sector is one of the main players in economic growth and is the sector that exports the most, thanks to duty-free access to the European market, through the All But Arms trade preferences system, EBA.  The Sustainability Agreement in Bangladesh, which brings together the EU, Bangladesh, the US and the ILO, includes short- and long-term commitments under three pillars: respect for workers' rights; structural integrity of buildings and safety and well-being in the workplace; responsible conduct of companies. Bangladesh has made a lot of progress since the agreement was launched, but nevertheless the workers still perceive the improvements in their condition to a minimum. Much remains to be done to consolidate the progress made and to ensure that real change is maintained in the long term.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution to commemorate the second anniversary of the collapse of rana plaza in Savar, the metropolitan area district of the capital Dhaka, where an 8-storey commercial building housing a bank, shops and, abusively, 5 clothing factories, collapsed, killing 1 129 workers, mostly women including some under the age of majority. The resolution also calls for the progress of the Sustainability Pact, a joint initiative to improve working conditions, health and safety in Bangladesh's clothing factories, launched by the EU Commission on 8 July 2013. Signed in Geneva by the Commission, the Government of Bangladesh, the International Labour Organization (ILO), representatives of Bangladeshi textile producers and major European clothing importers, the pact is a response to the tragedy of the Rana Plaza collapse.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament launched, together with the Government of Bangladesh, with the Government of Bangladesh, the "Sustainability Pact for the Continuous Improvement of Workers' Rights and Safety in Bangladesh's Clothing and Knitting Industries' (Sustainability Pact), whereby Bangladesh committed to adopt measures to improve labour standards and working conditions in the garment sector on its territory. I signed and voted on this resolution because, through its text, it comes to hasten the implementation of the measures provided for in this pact.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I would like to express my condolences to the relatives of the more than 1,200 workers killed in textile factories in Bangladesh over the past two years.  At the same time, however, through my support for the joint resolution, I strongly disapprove of the policies that lead a number of global brands and chains in the textile sector, which have been ignoring the working conditions in which their products are made for years.  The European Commission should, instead of discussing mechanisms such as the now-notorious ISDS system, place binding CSR clauses before its partners in the international agreements it negotiates.  This requirement must also apply to all European companies. I consider it unacceptable that European chains with annual profits of more than 1 billion euro have decided to contribute a minimum amount to the donor fund for bangladeshi victims and victims. Europe must stop maintaining this policy of following only economic interests by exporting production to countries with minimal production costs. This attitude leads to the closure of textile capacities in EU Member States and increases unemployment in them. It also condemns these third countries to uncool poverty and makes the European consumer an unwitting accomplice to this modern enslavement. It's time for this to stop.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the bill. The situation of workers in factories in Bangladesh has improved but needs to be monitored consistently. There is a need for continuous inspections in factories, but inspectors must be trained and the number of inspectors increased. Europe has a moral obligation to help Bangladesh in this area, given that a number of large producers are ordering their produce precisely from factories in Bangladesh because of the cheap labour there. Bangladesh's sustainability agreement and its progress are therefore welcome, and it is also necessary to ensure that more producers join it.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the Commission's light initiative on responsible supply chain management in the clothing sector is welcomed, the EU is considered to have the capacity and duty to be a global leader in responsibility along the supply chain. Given that access to information in the clothing sector is often considered to be the main obstacle to the fight against human rights violations in the global supply chain and that provision should be made for a compulsory notification system providing useful information to link all actors involved in the value chain of an individual product, from the place of production to retailers. Given the important role that workers and trade unions can play, such as the continued development of worker-led safety committees in all plants, and the importance of access to plant by trade unions, in order to train workers on how they can protect their rights and safety, including the right to refuse dangerous work. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The resolution calls for improvements in traceability in the textile sector so that tragedies comparable to the collapse of the Rana Plaza building do not happen again. It is necessary to be able to control the conditions of textiles manufacturing because this industry, in order to bring down costs, often exploits the working poor in countries with low social protections. So I voted in favor of this proposal.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I regret all the victims who lost their lives in the Rana Plaza factory fire as a sad reminder of the extremely poor human and labour rights situation in Bangladesh and other developing countries. I regret the fact that this tragedy has not led to a noticeable improvement in the situation either, and I share my concern over reports that newly formed trade unions have suffered discrimination, dismissals and awe.  Widespread discrimination against trade unions continues to prevail in Bangladesh, highlighted by extensive documented acts of retaliation against union workers as well as acts of physical violence against union leaders and activists, including the killing of union leader Aminula Islam. I call on the Government of Bangladesh to arrest and prosecute perpetrators of criminal attacks against union members in order to end impunity for such crimes and to send a message that violence against union members will not be tolerated.  I also welcome the launch of the EU Flagship Initiative under the European Year of Development 2015 on responsible management within the supply chain in the garment sector, which is a direct result of citizens' concerns about tragic events.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Marking the second anniversary of the Rana Plaza factory accident where cheap products were produced for a number of international companies, and where 1,100 workers died, the issue of inhumane working conditions in Bangladesh has again opened up. Worryingly, most of the companies involved in the Rana Plaza case have denied their links. Minimum payments to a fund set up to raise funds to help victims' families have moved even further away from tackling poor working conditions in Bangladesh. It is therefore of utmost importance to take action to control working conditions as urgently as possible to prevent similar accidents.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I very much hope that such a serious event will never happen again as the collapse of the Rana Plaza building where, due to the collapse of the structure, more than 1,100 people who worked in the different clothing factories installed in the building died.  Decisive action must be taken to ensure that priority is given in the developing countries to worker protection, the health and safety of factories and working conditions in general. I welcome the efforts made by the Government of Bangladesh since the tragic event to improve both working conditions and the minimum wage. It is a good thing that the Stability Pact has been launched, which has made an incisive contribution to the application of all the commitments and agreements envisaged. I am convinced that the second revision of the Stability Pact will achieve significant results on the structural integrity of buildings, safety at work and responsible business conduct.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Parliament adopted a resolution on Wednesday (April 29th) to commemorate the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Bangladesh and to rule on the progress of the sustainability pact. I voted in favour of this text, which welcomes the progress made by Bangladesh and international organisations. However, the resolution also stresses progress to improve the safety and health conditions of the sectors concerned, and recommends certain measures.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. On April 24, 2013, Rana Plaza, an eight-story building located in Savar, on the outskirts of Ddaca, where several garment factories operated, collapsed, causing the deaths of more than 1,100 people and leaving more than 2,500 injured. As a result of these tragic events and with public protests and calls for the European Parliament to take action, the EU, in collaboration with the Government of Bangladesh and the World Labour Organisation, launched on 8 July 2013 the 'Pact for the continuous improvement of labour rights and manufacturing security in the confectionery and knitting industry in Bangladesh' (the Sustainability Pact) , under which Bangladesh has undertaken to take measures to improve labour standards and working conditions in the country's confectionery industry. This resolution recalls the victims on the second anniversary of the tragedy and takes note of the conclusions of the pact's first evaluation in October 2014. It notes good progress by the Bangladeshi authorities and recognises the Contribution of the Pact to improving plant health and safety and working conditions in the confectionery industry. I voted in favour.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Writing. This catastrophic collapse of the factory building in Bangladesh with more than 1 100 deaths has now taken place for two years. It is just one of many, terrible examples that show the consistent disregard for the fundamental right to safety and health. This is about social responsibility, but above all about legal responsibility. We are talking about companies that seem to be able to evade this responsibility. The compensation payments of the responsible groups, some of which have not been paid to minimally, cannot be regarded as compensation for the tragedies.  After all, an estimated 3,000 people affected by the Rana Plaza disaster are still waiting – two years later – for 30% of the share they are entitled to! This is unacceptable. We in the European Union, which is one of the largest outlets for Asian products, also have a social responsibility towards the workers concerned: European companies should not be allowed to hide behind a subcontractor chain and thus benefit even more from the obvious abuses!  We must also carry the values that we have enshrined ourselves through our Charter of Fundamental Rights to the outside world, rather than totolerate these prevailing practices. Far too little has happened so far, the more there is to be done. And now, and not after the fifth or tenth anniversary. I therefore, of course, voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. The European Parliament paid tribute on 15 April to the victims of the collapse of a textile factory in Dhaka, Bangladesh. With his vote this afternoon, he wants to encourage the changes planned in the 2013 Sustainability Pact Agreement. Bangladesh already appears to be making progress in terms of social responsibility for workers in the textile sector, which employs nearly 4 million people. As for the commitments made by certain garment brands linked to this plant to ensure transparency throughout the manufacturing process, from raw materials to the finished product, one in three manufacturers has not donated a single penny to the Donor Fund. Some have even refused to publish the amount of their donation. The text voted this lunchtime by the EP clearly puts the big brands, and others before their responsibilities, will now be denounced those who clearly fail in their responsibilities. The involvement of brands must intensify to put an end to these medieval practices. Exposure to chemicals and non-compliance with safety rules turn these sweatshops into giant cemeteries. Renovating buildings, strengthening safety rules and improving working conditions is THE priority. #MRK

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. Although two years have passed, the tragedy in the Rana Plaza building is still very much present in our memories, were it not for one of the most devastating industrial disasters ever. The implementation of an effective workplace security system is imperative and situations such as this could have been avoided. It is important that the Government of Bangladesh has an active stance in implementing measures relating to safety at work. It is important to focus on training for safety at work and it is even more important to ensure that the guidelines are implemented in the work context.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I supported the Resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building, firstly, to remind the more than 1,200 fatalities, the vast majority of women, of accidents in Bangladesh's textile industry – workshops that supplied companies such as Adler Modemarkte, Ascena Retail, Carrefour, Grabalok, J.C. Penney, Manifattura Corona, NKD, PWT or YesZee; to require companies linked to Rana Plaza and the Tazreen factory, burned down shortly before, to promptly provide the aid they owe to victims, many of them unable to return to work and who need medical care; to recall the importance of the Bangladeshi Government undercomed legislative reforms to ensure effective labour protection and the right to freedom of association of workers in its country, in compliance with ILO Conventions; and because it urges the EC and EU governments to consider establishing a system that forces companies to repair and compensate victims because, under the current framework, they respond either because of their goodwill or for fear that pressure groups will point them out and highlight their irresponsible behaviour.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. April 24 marked the sad anniversary of the 2013 tragedy at the Rana Plaza garment factory in Dhaka, Bangladesh. The dramatic collapse of the building claimed the lives of 1,134 people, mostly workers in the textile industry. Bangladesh is the world's second largest clothing exporter. 60% of these exports go to the European Union. In these circumstances, the Union had to react and take responsibility by adopting measures to improve the working conditions, safety and health of Bangladeshi workers.  The European Parliament today voted on a resolution that I co-signed on the state of the clothing industry in the country. It calls on the Government of Bangladesh, major international brands, the ILO and other stakeholders to continue efforts to improve working conditions and worker safety in Bangladesh. As European consumers, we have a responsibility. Let us be aware that the clothes we can buy cheaply often have a human cost. The safety of textile workers in Bangladesh and elsewhere in the world must be ensured, and it is priceless.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. As head of the EPP for this debate, I welcome the fact that the 7 Political Groups of this Parliament have managed to draft the same Resolution on these tragic events, adopted by 97% of the votes in 2012, demonstrating our commitment and unity in defending and promoting decent, fair and properly framed legislative working conditions on a global scale. Two years after this terrible tragedy, we remind you that there is still unpaid compensation for victims and their families and that, despite much that has already been done to improve the working and safety conditions of manufacturing buildings in this country, much is still to be done. I therefore stress the absolute need for future monitoring of the implementation of the ongoing measures (the Sustainability Pact, the 'Agreement', the 'Alliance' and the 'Best Work' programme) by the International Community (notably the ILO, EU, US, business and trade union community) and support to the Government of Bangladesh so that these measures (and others announced, such as the amendment of Labour Legislation) are effectively implemented 'on the ground' , densified (e.g. increase in the number of inspections, improvement of labour rights in export free zones \u2012 ZFE) and in-depth (e.g. by hiring more Labour Inspectors).

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. Two years after the rana Plaza collapse in Bangladesh, which killed 1,100 people and injured more than 2,500, this text takes stock of the current situation.  On 8 July 2013, in cooperation with the Bangladeshi government, the United States and the ILO, the European Union launched the Sustainability Pact, for which Bangladesh is committed to taking steps to improve standards and working conditions in the ready-to-wear sector.  Progress has been made with the adoption of a new law strengthening labour law and freedom of association or the recruitment and training of labour inspectors. At the same time, two private initiatives, the Accord and the Alliance, evaluated more than 2,000 ready-to-wear plants and contributed to the closure of more than 30 plants deemed too dangerous.   Nevertheless, we are still far from the objectives set by the Sustainability Pact and it is essential that Bangladesh continues its work to reform labour law and that the European Union and businesses maintain their commitment; it is in this sense that I supported this resolution.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution as I welcome the EU-led initiative to make voluntary donations to the trust fund to compensate the families of the victims by all parties involved effective. I also welcome the initiative to launch the sustainability pact, with the aim of ensuring a fresh start on health and safety at work, working conditions and respect for workers' rights, as well as promoting responsible behaviour on the part of companies in the packaging industry in Bangladesh.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I chosen to vote in favour because this resolution was drafted on the occasion of the second anniversary of the Rana Plaza tragedy, a building that housed several companies in Bangladesh and in whose collapse 1 100 workers died. Cases such as the collapse of the Rana Plaza are emblematic examples of an untenable situation. The EU is also complicit, with its rules and international agreements that it contracts and which increasingly encourage European companies to relocate cheaply to Asia.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building and the progress of the Sustainability Pact, as we consider the recognition of the responsibility of companies in the textile sector and their subcontractors to address issues of labour dignity of paramount importance. In addition, the Resolution makes an explicit mention of the importance of raising minimum wages and sponsoring labour inspections and their transparency for the dignity of workers. The Resolution also calls on the authorities of the European Union to take into account the conventions of the International Labour Organization and the international standards of health and safety of workers when signing trade and economic partnership agreements with third countries, in order to promote decent work.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. As the Resolution recalls, more than 1,100 people were killed on 24 April 2013 and more than 2,500 injured in the rana Plaza collapse, a building that housed several garment companies.  The text sets out clearly the seriousness of these facts and the situation of labour rights in the garment industry in developing and less developed countries. For the specific case of Bangladesh, the limitations on the right to strike and trade union membership, especially in export free zones, are affected; lack of labour inspections or inadequacy of the minimum wage to meet the basic needs of the population. It also affects the hypocrisy of multinationals such as Adler Modemarkte, Ascena Retail, Carrefour, Grabalok, J.C. Penney, Manifattura Corona, NKD, PWT or YesZee, which have not yet contributed anything to the voluntary compensation fund to victims and family members despite their link to the accident. By clearly sharing these contents, I voted in favour of this Resolution.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ We voted in support of the joint motion for a resolution on the second anniversary of the Rana Plaza building collapse and progress of the Bangladesh Sustainability Compact. We remember the victims on the occasion of the 2nd anniversary of the Rana Plaza tragedy, one of the most devastating industrial disasters ever. MEPs have expressed their condolences once again to the bereaved families and to those injured or disabled. These losses could be avoided with better safety-at-work systems.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. On the second anniversary of the tragedy that occurred in Rana Plaza, Bangladesh, we mark the deaths of more than 1,100 people and 2,500 injured. This accident is considered to be one of the largest that has occurred in the garment factories. In 2013, a fund was set up to help the families of the victims and the injured financially cover the medical costs and other claims related to the accident. The estimated amount to cover those costs is $30 million, but by February 2015 they had managed to collect only $21 million. However, this shortfall is mainly at risk of the treatment of persons in need of long-term medical assistance. It is certainly unacceptable that there is a shortfall in funds in this fund. I cannot pass by the fact that many internationally known and reputed brands directly linked to Rana Plaza have still not contributed any financial assistance. Brands must ensure that workers are paid fairly for their work and not simply look at their own profits. I believe that the exploitation of workers in any industry is not appropriate and that every person deserves fair pay for their work. In addition, workers should be able to work in a safe and appropriate environment. On the basis of the above reasons, I supported the resolution and voted in favour of its adoption by the European Parliament.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒On April 24, 2013, an eight-storey Rana Plaza building containing several garment factories collapsed in Savar outside Dhaka, causing the deaths of more than 1,100 people and injuring approximately 2,500. The collapse of the Rana Plaza building is the biggest industrial disaster in Bangladesh's history and an accident that has resulted in the collapse of the structure with the highest death toll in recent history.  This way I would like to extend my condolences to all the injured and disabled and the families of the victims. I also call on the Bangladeshi authorities to continue in line with the initial positive trend of reforms in order to meet the targets of adequate presentation of 4 million workers in the garment sector. I believe that these losses could have been avoided through better safety systems at work, and therefore I support the report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the second anniversary of the Rana Plaza building collapse. I strongly support the EU in its efforts to promote human rights and labour standards.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. – I support the drafting of a resolution related to the demolition of the Rana Plaza building and the planning of sustainable development. The tragedy that caused the deaths of more than 1,100 people must not be ignored. The demolition of the Rana Plaza building is one of the worst industrial disasters in Bangladesh's modern history.  Bangladesh's most important industry, the RMG, is responsible for employing a large population and thereby contributing to reducing poverty, and has also contributed to reducing gender inequality in society. The EBA initiative in the economic area also played a major role in Bangladesh, as it has contributed to improving material conditions for many people, especially women.  Also, the proposed resolution would encourage and call on the Government of Bangladesh to step up inspections of factories and to take appropriate corrective action. The proposed resolution should enhance cooperation and information sharing and systematically report on factory inspections and consequently increase safety at work.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Positive, due to the imposition of measures that create better conditions.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Rana Plaza, the palace comprising textile factories that collapsed in Bangladesh in 2013 causing more than 1,100 deaths, represents the true face of globalization: the pursuit of the lowest cost and the highest profit through the relocation of production activities to places where workers are underpaid and have no rights. In the case of Rana Plaza, the desire to lower costs even led to ignoring the signs of collapse of the building that then collapsed on itself and thousands of human lives. The true face of globalisation is often hidden from the eyes of the Western consumer. I therefore voted in favour of the amendments to clarify in the text of the resolution the names of trade marks linked to products manufactured in Rana Plaza and to include a binding clause on corporate social responsibility in the treaties signed by the EU on trade and investment with third countries. I also supported a specific text on the EFDD's Rana Plaza, which calls on the EU to set up a pilot project in Bangladesh to produce clothes with full respect for human rights and to mark these clothes with a special label, so that European consumers can make informed choices.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Clothes, not workers' rights or human rights, can be sold. Two years after the tragedy, some brands are making efforts, often too timid. Others do nothing, such as Europe must impose sanctions on those who treat workers like cattle.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the second anniversary of the Rana Plaza textile factory collapse. While I welcome the progress made towards improving labour standards and conditions, as well as workplace safety in the country, much still need to be done. The Bangladeshi Government has to pursue and speed up its reforms in the short, medium and long term, and the companies involved must behave more responsibly.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building and the progress of the Sustainability Pact, as we consider the recognition of the responsibility of companies in the textile sector and their subcontractors to address issues of labour dignity of paramount importance. In addition, the Resolution makes an explicit mention of the importance of raising minimum wages and sponsoring labour inspections and their transparency for the dignity of workers. The Resolution also calls on the authorities of the European Union to take into account the conventions of the International Labour Organization and the international standards of health and safety of workers when signing trade and economic partnership agreements with third countries, in order to promote decent work.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ It is already two years since the collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Savar, Bangladesh, in which 1 134 people died and 2 500 were injured, many of whom were temporarily or permanently disabled. Although working conditions and wages remain low, currently 200 fashion brands and retailers have signed the legally-binding agreement on security and fire protection of buildings. We welcome this first major milestone while issuing an urgent appeal to those who have not yet signed the appeal, especially those based in the EU. Gradually there will be better working conditions worldwide.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The adopted decision details the progress made so far on the second anniversary of the rana plaza collapse and the progress made under the Bangladesh Sustainability Pact. It is important that tragedies such as this can be avoided in the future. I voted in favour of this decision.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building and the progress of the Sustainability Pact, as we consider the recognition of the responsibility of companies in the textile sector and their subcontractors to address issues of labour dignity of paramount importance. In addition, the Resolution makes an explicit mention of the importance of raising minimum wages and sponsoring labour inspections and their transparency for the dignity of workers. The Resolution also calls on the authorities of the European Union to take into account the conventions of the International Labour Organization and the international standards of health and safety of workers when signing trade and economic partnership agreements with third countries, in order to promote decent work.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. I supported the Resolution on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building, firstly, to remind the more than 1,200 fatalities, the vast majority of women, of accidents in Bangladesh's textile industry – workshops that supplied companies such as Adler Modemarkte, Ascena Retail, Carrefour, Grabalok, J.C. Penney, Manifattura Corona, NKD, PWT or YesZee; to require companies linked to Rana Plaza and the Tazreen factory, burned down shortly before, to promptly provide the aid they owe to victims, many of them unable to return to work and who need medical care; to recall the importance of the Bangladeshi Government undercomed legislative reforms to ensure effective labour protection and the right to freedom of association of workers in its country, in compliance with ILO Conventions; and because it urges the EC and EU governments to consider establishing a system that forces companies to repair and compensate victims because, under the current framework, they respond either because of their goodwill or for fear that pressure groups will point them out and highlight their irresponsible behaviour.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. As the Resolution recalls, more than 1,100 people were killed on 24 April 2013 and more than 2,500 injured in the rana Plaza collapse, a building that housed several garment companies.  The text sets out clearly the seriousness of these facts and the situation of labour rights in the garment industry in developing and less developed countries. For the specific case of Bangladesh, the limitations on the right to strike and trade union membership, especially in export free zones, are affected; lack of labour inspections or inadequacy of the minimum wage to meet the basic needs of the population. It also affects the hypocrisy of multinationals such as Adler Modemarkte, Ascena Retail, Carrefour, Grabalok, J.C. Penney, Manifattura Corona, NKD, PWT or YesZee, which have not yet contributed anything to the voluntary compensation fund to victims and family members despite their link to the accident. By clearly sharing these contents, I voted in favour of this Resolution.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because access to information in the garment sector is often the most important obstacle to tackling human rights violations in the global supply chain. Also, a mandatory information system is needed that provides information linking all the actors in the value chain of a single product, from the place of production to the retailers.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The second anniversary of the rana Plaza collapse in Bangladesh, which killed 1,100 people and injured 2,500, was an opportunity for the European Parliament to monitor the situation of the textile industry in Bangladesh.  Bangladesh is the world's largest clothing exporter after China but also one of the lowest-wage countries.   I voted in favour of this resolution, which highlights labour law through key ILO conventions.  Moreover, despite all the efforts of the European right, the European Parliament has adopted the amendments tabled by my group expressly naming European companies, such as Mango, Matalan or Inditex, which, denying their responsibilities, have refused to subsidize the compensation funds for victims while $3 million is still missing. Finally, even without legislative scope, the resolution takes a step towards corporate accountability by calling for the creation of mandatory corporate social responsibility clauses in the bilateral trade and investment agreements contracted by the European Union.  A fight far from won when we know that member states voted against the UN resolution on the same subject last year.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. On April 24, 2013, 1,134 people died and hundreds of people were injured in the collapse of the Rana Plaza building in Savar, Bangladesh. Later, 112 people lost their lives in the fire at the Tazreen factory in The Ashulia district of Ddashea, Bangladesh, and on November 24, 2012, 289 more people lost their lives in a fire in Karachi, Pakistan, in September 2012. These are glaring examples of a more extensive list. This is a poignant show of what is capable of the wildest capitalism. Bangladesh's confectionery industry has developed in the space of just a few decades and has become the second largest in the world, thanks to the large multinational chains that have seen there a way to increase the exploitation of the workforce and increase its profits. It is no accident that Bangladesh enjoys access to the EU market with exemption from EU duties and quotas for all its products included in the 'Everything but arms' initiative, which covers 55% of Bangladesh's exports, largely textiles/clothing.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. The report on the second anniversary of the collapse of the Rana Plaza building and the state of play of the Sustainability Pact, in my view, make useful demands on the code of conduct of companies that not only produce there but also have their market in Europe. Moreover, compliance with such standards for wealth creation in these countries is very important in order to keep potential economic refugees there, and is not at odds with low production costs. That is why I voted in favour of this motion.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: in writing. – I voted on the resolution tabled on the basis of the Commission's statement on the commemoration of the victims of the fire in the clothing factory in Rana Plaza and Tazreen in Bangldesh and on the progress made under the sustainability pact concluded with this Asian state. This resolution is a manifestation of MEPs' concern about the conditions in which thousands of people in Bangladesh work in the country's garment factories. Through this document, MEPs are calling on representatives of international textile brands to contribute to the open fund to compensate the families of people who have died in factory fires. The adopted resolution also welcomes the EU's initiative to bring the Bangaldesh government, representatives of the EU, the US and the International Labour Organisation to the same table, with a view to finding solutions to improve the conditions and safety of work in factories in that country.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 More than 1100 dead and 2500 injured. Such was the result of the tragic collapse of a textile factory in Bangladesh in 2013. The resolution that we adopted and voted for not only naming things that have been improved, but also highlights emphatically the problems that persist in the Bangladeshi textile industry. On the one hand, labour law has been amended and the number of labour inspectors has increased. However, there is still a lack of implementing rules for certain laws and the number of inspectors is insufficient. The situation is not good, nor is it as regards the establishment of trade unions, the registration of new trade unions is often rejected and trade unionists persecuted. I find it unacceptable that, even two years after the tragedy, there is still a lack of $3 million in compensation for families left without breadwinnes or compensation for workers who have suffered serious injuries. In the resolution, we call on specific fashion brands that have not yet made or have not made sufficient contributions to do so as soon as possible. In the future, it will be crucial that clothing companies themselves trade transparently. To require their subcontractors to provide employees not only with decent working conditions, but also with a reasonable wage. I see positively that the pressure for change can now be exerted not only by politicians, but also by consumers themselves by participating in various campaigns.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. The European Parliament today spoke on the tragedy that occurred two years ago in Bangladesh, where more than 1,100 people, mainly women, lost their lives. With regard to this tragic event, the EP is continuing the way of laundering the role of multinationals in the unscrupulous use of cheap labour to which they use in countries such as Bangladesh, where hundreds of thousands of human beings are exploited in inhumanworking conditions. So slight, corporate responsibility is neglected in an atrocious cynicism, pushing responsibility for the Government of that country, inevitably conditioned by the economic and social impositions that are the support of the great monopolies. In addition to this pitiful hypocrisy, it takes the opportunity to pursue its strategy of interference with the free design of peoples, making considerations and making indications as to the meaning that the construction of the labour and trade union framework should take on in that country, as well as strengthening the role of the High Representative as part of a foreign policy that we do not recognise to the EU. For these reasons, we abstained.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. - I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the second anniversary of the rana plaza collapse and progress on the Bangladesh Sustainable Agreement, because it represents the collapse of this building in the Dhaka suburbs, where several garment factories were one of the deadliest industrial accidents in modern history. On April 24, 2013, more than 1,100 people died and about 2,500 were injured, all of which could have been prevented by better safety systems at work. There are serious shortcomings in transparency and traceability in the global supply chain and not all companies in the garment sector respect labour standards in their supply chain, as they should in accordance with internationally recognised CSR principles. I am pleased that in July 2013 the EU established an agreement to continuously improve safety in the garment industry's factories in Bangladesh, in which Bangladesh committed itself to taking steps to improve labour standards and working conditions in the garment industry.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Madam President, yesterday we heard unacceptable words in the debate in this House, starting with those of Mr Juncker, who spoke of the mistake of the end of Mare Nostrum, as if there were no specific responsibility for having determined the end of Mare Nostrum and the choice of Frontex and Triton as strategies. Now, yesterday in front of this Parliament, we unroasted a very long banner reminding us of the names of the victims of the massacres in the Mediterranean. We believe that we need a radical change of course, a radical change of which, unfortunately, the Council's conclusions do not tell us, nor the resolution voted on yesterday, the positive elements of which led us to abstain, but at the same time we denounce its total inadequacy. We need a humanitarian corridor, we need a radical change in visa policy, we cannot take political responsibility for consequences of further deaths in the Mediterranean.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, my political faction is against quotas for the redistribution of refugees, as is my political party, even the government in my country, to which I am currently in opposition. It is therefore surprising to me that members of the European Parliament who come from government parties voted in favour of quotas, but I am truly convinced that quotas will not solve anything, that they will only make the situation worse. We must make it clear that Europe is unable to absorb tens of thousands or hundreds of thousands more refugees, we must be able to protect our southern border, that is, the EU's sea border, invest resources in it, use methods such as towing intercepted illegal smugglers at sea back to their home ports. And we must also invest money in stabilising the situation in the countries where refugees come from, rather than using artificial arbitrary quotas to redistribute refugees.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I voted against most of my faction on this point, which is why I want to explain why I voted in this way. I abstained from this proposal, precisely because of the quotas mentioned. I do not think that the solution to the refugee situation, which is a really burning problem, should be that the Commission unilaterally imposes refugee quotas on all Member States and these countries have to respect this, even in a situation where the country's options are not fully considered and where security, economic and social problems can arise in that country. I am in solidarity, but solidarity as such is always built on volunteering and agreement. It is therefore necessary for individual Member States to agree with the Commission on how they will help, how they will contribute to solving the problems of refugees. So my aim is not to be non-solidarity, but to find volunteering, not a unilateral decision from Brussels.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Madam President, I also want to explain why I voted in favour of the final resolution on the tragedies in the Mediterranean and European migration and asylum policy. I consider this resolution to be comprehensive, it concerns precisely all measures that can help to address this very burning issue, precisely in the context of the solidarity of all European countries. I voted against mandatory quotas, but also in the knowledge that an effective effective policy must also be addressed in the context of the Member States, that no mandatory quotas will be agreed without the support and decision of the national governments of the Member States. So the point is that the approach is comprehensive, so that it is addressed where problems arise, i.e. in the countries of the Middle East, where politics actually leads to these tragedies. These are only secondary measures and we must cooperate within the EU, which is why I supported the comprehensive resolution, which also includes a proposal for quotas, which, however, will not be agreed without the consent of the Member States.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – I voted in favour of this resolution, on EU migration and asylum policies. Of course, in my view, this is an attempt to put a small patch on a huge wound. European migration policy reflects the ideological problems of the European Union, in my view. We must choose either to recognise that the main ideology of European countries is local egoism, or yet the EU has proclaimed fundamental values. In the first case, we lose the moral right to teach and condemn other countries that they are acting in their own selfish interests. Secondly, we need to act in principle, despite the fact that many Europeans may not like it. People want to live better, so they come to Europe. It is natural, and there is no wall that could stop them. We must help them to organise and improve their lives in their own countries or to help integrate into European society if they want to come to Europe. Both ways require solidarity from us. If we do not want to do that, then we must honestly recognise that the core core value that unites us is selfishness.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for No one should die in the Mediterranean and at the same time there is no "quick fix".  I support the resolution on migration, because it is a step forward for several Member States to take more responsibility. It is not enough for the message from Parliament to be clear. It is not enough to have all the institutions that we have and the rules that we have in common if the Member States do not implement and apply them in full.  Member States must provide resources to Frontex, to the Asylum Office, to the joint efforts to seek and save lives in the Mediterranean. Member States must also agree on a binding distribution system for the accept of several refugees.  For those who have the right to international protection, we have a common asylum package. It must be applied. However, several legal routes are not fighting illegal routes in unless we also take action against smugglers and traffickers who exploit the migrants.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: – Madam President, thank you for the opportunity to explain your vote yesterday. Yesterday I voted against points 8 and 10, that is, against mandatory quotas. As the resolution was written, I think it was very unfortunate. And there is no way that such a resolution can be adopted. However, as a show of solidarity with the people who are dying in the Mediterranean, I supported the whole resolution as a whole, because it is important to signal to our states on the southern border that we see the solidarity with them and that the problem of refugees is not a problem for several states in the south, but it is a problem for Europe as a whole. That is why I voted in favour of the resolution, which is why I support solidarity between

name: Miriam DALLI
text: – Fil-fatt jien ivvutajt favur għaliex irrid li llum qabel għada nitkellmu dwar nies u mhux dwar numri. Għalija dak it-tifel ta' sentejn liebes pulit biex jitla' fuq il-vjaġġ lejn tama ġdida in minflok il-ġisem blah ħajja tiegħu spièèa mkaxkar għal ġisem <3> <3> fuq il-bone Libjana set' faèilment kien jismu Omar għaliex jien nippreferi nagħtih isem milli nagħtih numru in nitta li dawn in-nies ma jibqgħux numri.  F'Malta ilna niffaèèjaw din il-problema għal snin twal u fl-aħħar donnhom il-pajjiżi tal-Unjoni Ewropea qegħdin iqumu imma ftit äittadini qegħdin if din id-darba l-affarijiet jistgħu verament ikunui different. Ir-riżoluzzjoni waħedha mhijiex biżżejjed. Għandna bżonn soluzzjoni fit-tul. Irridu nindirizzaw l-għeruq tal-problema fil-pajjiżi Afrikani in s-summit bejn l-Unjoni Ewropea in l-Unjoni Afrikana you jsir f'Malta jista' jkun l-ewwel pass wara ħafna snin għalkemm fadal għalkemm fadal għalkemm Ħafna aktar xi jsir biex naslu għal soluzzjoni dejjiema u fuq kollox irridu nindirizzaw is-sitwazzjoni fil-Libja llum qabel għada bl-immigrazzjoni tkun fuq nett tal-aġenda.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists congratulate the resolution adopted by Parliament on the humanitarian drama of immigration in the Mediterranean. It has been the horror of the tragedy suffered that has led political groups to adopt a resolution that advances in European positions that had never been given: - the recognition that the abandonment of the Mare Nostrum mission and its replacement by joint operation Triton, with a smaller budget, was a grave mistake;  - the commitment reached by Member States to promote joint operations and increase naval resources with the aim of preventing further deaths at sea; - the consideration of the migration issue in North Africa as an international humanitarian crisis calling for a comprehensive policy, from the pacification and stability of these countries to the fight against mafias, from development cooperation to a common asylum policy that includes the extension of EASO's mandate; - effective implementation of Member States' solidarity to welcome asylum seekers and refugees and integrate them into our countries as a moral, legal and vital duty to our democratic beliefs.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. We understand that the tragedies and deaths in the Mediterranean are a consequence of the 'Fortress Europe' that has been championed by the European institutions. That is why we voted against this resolution, which seems to us to be an attempt by majority groups to wash away their image. Apart from not recognising direct responsibility for European policies, the text speaks to the need to strengthen cooperation with third countries to combat immigration (which seems like a veiled reference to the establishment of detention centres in the countries of the southern bank of the Mediterranean) and calls on States to step up their contributions to Frontex , an agency that does not have the ransom between its missions, but fights against the entry of people, even though many of these may be asylum recipients. Instead of strengthening these mechanisms, our commitment would be to guarantee humanitarian corridors and visas in countries of origin for those fleeing violence, and to bet on an international policy not based on the bellicoseness or destabilization of third countries, as well as passing regulations that prevent the expoliation of the natural resources of the South.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, as I agree with Parliament's proposals for greater solidarity between Member States, for increasing funding for the Poseidon and Triton programmes, for the development of European Union actions in the countries of origin and for a fairer distribution of asylum seekers, which also requires the amendment of the Dublin III Regulation.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report, as a whole, falls under the yoke of nonsense and absurdity. We all know that today, mass immigration is not beneficial to the men who try it, nor to those who welcome it. However, through this report, the Council persists and signs by strengthening already existing and out-of-phase mechanisms, when it is a question of changing paradigms.  The Council is based on two erroneous assertions: that of the attractiveness of the illegality of immigration and that of the voluntary return of migrants who have arrived in the Union. Who will the Council make believe that the men and women who have transited in undignified conditions in order to reach EU territory will voluntarily decide to leave?  Moreover, this report is constantly blaming member states, which would be subject to binding solidarity and would be given distribution rates for asylum seekers. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I oppose a Common Asylum Policy for the European Union, and therefore voted against this resolution.  In particular I voted against binding EU quotas on migration.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. The Mediterranean, the sea of antiquity, has become an immense liquid cemetery. The sea of civilization is now the sea of death. Practically every day there human beings who seek to reach Europe die. Just over a week ago the tragedy of the deaths of 700 people once again shook our daily lives. After a joint meeting of The Ministers of The Interior and Foreign Affairs, the Commissioner for Migration, Home Affairs and Citizenship presented a ten-point plan to address this tremendous humanitarian crisis. The plan points to the strengthening of joint actions by Member States, improving the conditions for the reception and treatment of displaced persons and cooperation with third countries considered essential for the control of these migration flows. It is imperative that we increase our water patrol capacity to try to stop disasters and destroy human trafficking networks. It is important that we provide decent conditions to those who reach our lands. But it is crucial that we strive to contribute to solving the problems facing the Middle East and Africa. Those who so desperately seek to reach Europe just want to leave fear behind. Europe is responsible for combating it.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to review the extraordinary European Council (23 April 2015) and to discuss the recent disasters in the Mediterranean and the EU's migration and asylum policy. More than 1,600 migrants have already died in the Mediterranean since the beginning of this year, according to the UN Refugee Agency. I agree that the EU must take concrete action to save the lives of migrants and to allocate sufficient funds to search and rescue services.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. I have obviously voted against this report, which further encourages illegal immigration with the dramatic consequences we are experiencing. The road to hell is paved with good intentions. There is an urgent need for a policy of firmness and deterrence: illegal immigrants must know and understand that they have nothing to gain from risking their lives, because our countries have nothing to offer them. By no longer admitting any illegal immigrants arriving on its soil, Australia achieved with Operation Sovereign Borders the figure of zero deaths at sea (trying to reach its shores) in 2014, up from several hundred in previous years.  In the same year, attracted by the promise of a fantastical European eldorado but also of a rescue at sea in case of difficulties, 3,000 illegal immigrants tragically perished in the Mediterranean.  I therefore invite all French and European leaders to divest themselves of their ideological blinders and to ask themselves the question in conscience: what is the most responsible and above all the most humane policy? Australia's policy of firmness, or the european Union's policy of opening up and those hundreds of deaths in a matter of days?

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The European Union must react effectively and in solidarity to avoid repeated human tragedies in the Mediterranean.  The necessary means must be deployed to save lives, to tackle criminal networks of human traffickers and to provide concrete solutions for the stability and development of countries of origin or transit. It is also high time to pursue a genuine immigration policy at European level based on solidarity between states and a comprehensive approach.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The recent human tragedies are unfortunately the consequences of the Union's migration policy. Bringing migrants' boats to shores encourages illegal immigration. There have been increased barriers to the deportation of illegal immigrants, who are returned in only 1% of cases. The European Union, by its laxity and by the increase in obstacles to the expulsion of illegal immigrants, is complicit in the smugglers. Instead, national borders should be restored, migrants' ships return to their starting point and the aspiring immigration pumps, such as social assistance, should be put to an end.  For all these reasons, I voted against this report, which will not solve the situation in any way and just allows our leaders to give themselves good conscience.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not intend to support this resolution with my vote. I believe that it does not express itself sufficiently firmly in condemning the lack of results achieved at the recent European Council summit, and I in no way agree with the call for new missions in the style of 'Mare nostrum', which has shown that it has an aggravating effect of the migration crisis rather than a content or decisive effect.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: Written. I abstained from voting in the final vote. Although the resolution contained clear improvements over the Council's and the Commission's views on asylum policy and death in the Mediterranean, I cannot support it. It does not distance itself from the so-called outsourcing of eu asylum policy. In addition, the resolution focuses on Frontex, the EU's border guard service, rather than a civilian rescue operation. It also has too much focus on the role of refugee smugglers instead of the responsibility of the EU and the Member States for what is happening. I am in favour of the adoption of our amendment to the removal of the so-called 'SWIFT Return', as well as an amendment by the Green Group which requires the focus to be on a robust and permanent humanitarian rescue operation. However, I cannot support a statement containing so many bad pieces. The Left Party continues to demand a Mare Nostrum 2 and the introduction of asylum visas, but the fact that a coalition of willing Member States is going ahead and pushing for life-saving and a humane refugee policy will not be able to solve this.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists congratulate the resolution adopted by Parliament on the humanitarian drama of immigration in the Mediterranean. It has been the horror of the tragedy suffered that has led political groups to adopt a resolution that advances in European positions that had never been given: - the recognition that the abandonment of the Mare Nostrum mission and its replacement by joint operation Triton, with a smaller budget, was a grave mistake;  - the commitment reached by Member States to promote joint operations and increase naval resources with the aim of preventing further deaths at sea; - the consideration of the migration issue in North Africa as an international humanitarian crisis calling for a comprehensive policy, from the pacification and stability of these countries to the fight against mafias, from development cooperation to a common asylum policy that includes the extension of EASO's mandate; - effective implementation of Member States' solidarity to welcome asylum seekers and refugees and integrate them into our countries as a moral, legal and vital duty to our democratic beliefs.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because we cannot allow such tragedies to happen in the future, which have claimed many lives. More than a thousand migrants have died in the last two weeks and it is possible that more than 30 000 people have died in the Mediterranean, according to the International Organisation for Migration. This demonstrates once again the need to do everything possible to save the lives of people in danger, and that Member States must comply with international maritime rescue obligations. Migration is a global and complex phenomenon and requires a long-term approach that tackles its root causes, such as poverty, inequality, injustice and armed conflict. The European Parliament calls on the European Union, its Member States and the international community to help find sustainable political solutions in conflict-affected countries and to strengthen political dialogue to cover all aspects of human rights, to increase the resilience of local communities and to promote the social and democratic development of countries of origin and their populations.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Saving people's lives in an emergency is our moral duty. At the same time, we have a responsibility in the Union to prevent or prevent more and more people from being on the frontier of life and death. It is therefore necessary to take decisive action against smuggling networks, to do everything possible to stop thousands of people going on such a risky journey. The number of illegal immigrants in Hungary has increased 20 times this year, we are the fifth most touched Member State. People are concerned about immigration policy to distinguish between genuine refugees and illegal immigrants. There is a pressing need for a solidarity mechanism to address the problem in the Union, but a system of centrally imposed mandatory quotas that do not follow local problems and do not take into account local characteristics is not the solution to the increasingly serious situation. For this reason, I abstained from voting on the decision.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly support Parliament's unified resolution on the humanitarian crisis linked to migration in the Mediterranean. Parliament is sending a clear message to the Commission, which is currently working on its immigration agenda. There are two main points of the resolution: the call for quotas to be set for the distribution of asylum seekers among the Member States – an urgent issue in view of the fact that today only 5 out of 28 countries are facing around 80% of asylum applications; the hope that the means and scope of operation Triton will be expanded. The latest dramatic events call on the EU to establish a binding solidarity mechanism in the management of policies on immigration and the reception of refugees. We also need to act on the causes of the mass migration that we have seen in recent years. That is why in the resolution we call for the policies of the EU and the Member States to finally be coordinated and set forward with foresight in terms of foreign policy and cooperation with African and Middle Eastern countries.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the fact that Member States immediately gathered for an emergency summit to find common solutions in response to the crisis situation in the Mediterranean. Nevertheless, I find it regretting that the measures taken are still largely insufficient to stop the loss of life. I call on all Member States of the participants to transpose quickly and fully and effectively implement the Common European Asylum System, which will guarantee common European standards under existing legislation. In conclusion, close cooperation and partnership with third countries of origin and transit is needed to find a comprehensive approach to migration and asylum policy in the EU.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: In writing. We can only regret the lack of awareness of the European Council on 23 April, which is urgently dedicated to the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and immigration and asylum policies.  The results of this one are disappointing and give no answer to the real causes of the problem generated by mass immigration and Islamist terrorism.  These tragedies stem, in part, from the geopolitical chaos in the Near and Middle East, engendered by the warlike folly of some. It is a principle to bring every illegal immigrant back to their port of departure and to restore Europe's internal borders. Let us stop covering our faces and act effectively against this problem of immigration, which has been addressed in a hypocritical way.  So I voted against it.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to endorse this resolution because it is important that the European institutions act to stop the tragedy that is taking place in the Mediterranean sea a few miles off our coasts. The Union and the Member States should show more resolve in addressing this issue and should also show more solidarity, both among themselves and towards those people who are risking their lives hoping to find a better life on our continent. We must act and we must do it now.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 Migration flows do not stop. The unstoppable will to survive does not subside, even when it costs effort, tears, goodbyes and abandonments at sea. Because those who migrate never do so without a need, especially when migration is ruthless and costs a very high price, a price as high as life, the same for which an escape route is sought.  We Italians know this well, we too have been a people of migrants in an era not so far away towards almost never cordial and welcoming beaches. However, today such phenomena no longer allow for myopic and selfish management, today we can no longer pretend not to know, ignore our share of responsibility, because for every man who dies at sea, many others are suffocated in the holds. We can't just sit back and watch. The resolution adopted today by a large majority in the European Parliament calls for clear commitments to be made, which must affect the fair distribution of asylum seekers and legal forms of immigration. The EU must change the way we think about migration policy, because as long as the only possible choice is to escape poverty, dictatorships and violence, these tragedies will not end.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the beginning of the year, more than 1,500 people have lost their lives trying to reach Europe. The latest tragedy estimates that no fewer than 900 people would have lost their lives after a fishing vessel carrying a considerable number of migrants sank off the coast of Libya.  In this context, the EU and the Member States should do everything possible to prevent further loss of life at sea. I would like to stress that it is necessary to provide the necessary resources for the effective fulfilment of search and rescue obligations and, therefore, to ensure their funding properly and under the coordination of Frontex. I voted in favour of this report because it calls for closer coordination of the policies of the EU states and the Member States in combating the root causes of migration, guaranteeing the protection of migrants' rights and ensuring safe and legal access to the European asylum system. At the same time, the European Commission should inform the populations of third countries, in particular in the MENA region, of the risks and dangers posed by illegal migration networks.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 My vote was no. The resolution does not strongly condemn the poor results of the European Council on this issue. It calls for more Europe and more missions such as Mare Nostrum, which are useless and which have been shown to attract more and more immigrants, causing more and more deaths.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists congratulate the resolution adopted by Parliament on the humanitarian drama of immigration in the Mediterranean. It has been the horror of the tragedy suffered that has led political groups to adopt a resolution that advances in European positions that had never been given: - the recognition that the abandonment of the Mare Nostrum mission and its replacement by joint operation Triton, with a smaller budget, was a grave mistake;  - the commitment reached by Member States to promote joint operations and increase naval resources with the aim of preventing further deaths at sea; - the consideration of the migration issue in North Africa as an international humanitarian crisis calling for a comprehensive policy, from the pacification and stability of these countries to the fight against mafias, from development cooperation to a common asylum policy that includes the extension of EASO's mandate; - effective implementation of Member States' solidarity to welcome asylum seekers and refugees and integrate them into our countries as a moral, legal and vital duty to our democratic beliefs.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. In the wake of the recent migrant shipwrecks in the Mediterranean, the European Parliament has passed a resolution on European migration and asylum policies. This real tragedy has led to the death of more than 800 people, the European Union must act quickly and effectively. We cannot accept such tragedies taking place off our coasts. Traffickers and smugglers are criminals whom we must fight and condemn. That is the message that the European Parliament needs to get across. I welcome, of course, the European Council's decision to increase the budget of the external border protection agency Frontex. But that is not enough. We need to coordinate national immigration policies and increase Frontex's resources further. In this way we can both strengthen control of the European Union's external borders and prevent shipwrecks at sea.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the extraordinary European Council report (23 April 2015) on recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and EU policies on migration and asylum. I believe that the European Union should make every effort and as a matter of priority to prevent further loss of life at sea. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution, which highlighted Parliament's position on the European Council of 23 April. surely a missed opportunity. In this respect, I believe that greater efforts are needed on the part of the Member States.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution. It is absolutely imperative to show solidarity with those who require it most. Despite public outrage over the horrendous loss of lives and the plight of thousands of migrants fleeing poverty and conflict in their homelands, the uncomfortable reality is that many EU citizens are opposed to further immigration into Europe – as is evidenced by the rise of various right-wing anti-immigration parties. Furthermore, the European Council’s recent 10-point plan included measures to tighten up, rather than open up, borders, and included too the introduction of fingerprinting of migrants, and return programmes for irregular migrants. These measures only serve to foster a sense of distrust and suspicion and do not provide any meaningful steps towards the eradication of poverty, or any hope for those who require it so desperately.
