It should be remembered that the European Union was meant to be as much about solidarity as about economic growth. As we all know, all politics is local, but solidarity has no borders.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 There have always been some voices, including those of the 5 Star Movement, desperately asking to move from words to deeds to stop an unprecedented humanitarian catastrophe. I voted in favour precisely because Europe cannot afford to remain silent.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. – While I agree with many of the solutions proposed in the resolution, I am of the opinion that our primary focus must be on the prevention of these humanitarian disasters at their source. This means, within the countries bordering Europe, we must do more to support the fight against organised crime and smugglers. We also need a stronger Frontex mission better prepared to help individuals in need. We have to attack this at the root and I think that, working together, we can. However, I do not believe that a European asylum system with national quotas is the best solution to the current problems. It will do nothing either to address the humanitarian situation or to address our citizens’ concerns over migration flows.  Migrants will not stay forever in the country to which they would be assigned unless it was their original goal. They will stay just the minimum time required to gain papers allowing free movement, and will then move on, be it to Germany, the UK or Sweden. We will be creating a huge European system that does not address any long-term strategy or help to save lives. Let us keep looking, and I am sure we will find an answer.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which shows once again that for the modern West, politics is tantamount to exploiting the emotion aroused by dramatic events to make the peoples of Europe accept the unacceptable. This report indecently uses the deaths of thousands of migrants in the Mediterranean in recent months to advocate ignominious measures and evade real solutions. Following the Council, parliamentarians are therefore in favour of the adoption of binding quotas for the distribution of asylum seekers - which means forcibly bringing immigrants into our territory - or even advocating a European immigration policy, even though the EU, through the failures of Frontex and Triton, has proved incapable of protecting our external borders. Finally, by genuine ideological blindness, the report is in favour of an increase in legal immigration, a measure that would be the only one capable of stemming illegal immigration. In short, a completely dogmatic and unrealistic report which, if it really inspires the EU's positioning on immigration for years to come, leads Member States to disaster.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 A couple of weeks ago we witnessed, once again helplessly, the loss of life, too many lives of migrants who hoped and believed they could find a better life in Europe. A broken dream, but we can revive it if we can move from words to deeds. Financial aid, although necessary, is not sufficient to deal with a phenomenon which seems endless. Humanitarian corridors must be set up as a matter of urgency and asylum application procedures must be initiated as soon as possible and as quickly as possible. As co-legislators together with the Council, it is time to study all the measures that could create a legislative framework capable of dealing with the difficult situation, given the continuity of migratory flows. But we need to act quickly. The joint resolution voted on today identifies the areas for action, and for these reasons I voted in favour. This is the first step in the right direction.  I expect the Commission to be able to translate Parliament's demands into ambitious, concrete and immediate action soon.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Italy alone is holding up the shock of the flow of migrants arriving from Libya, but after yet another major massacre at sea I once again urge the EU and the other Member States to make every effort to implement greater cooperation and thus prevent further loss of life at sea. On 23 April 2015, I attended the EPP bureau meeting in Milan, where it was hoped that EU operations Triton and Poseidon would be rapidly strengthened, at least by tripling their financial resources, so as to increase the chances of dismantling the traffickers' networks. I voted in favour of this resolution because its objective is to detect and destroy vessels before they are used by traffickers, and also to bring human traffickers to justice. Finally, I believe that the negotiations with Libya, under the leadership of the United Nations, must be strengthened in order to restore the democratic government authority of the country, because the creation of regional stability in the conflict zones is essential to prevent further displacement of people.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Unfortunately, we are once again faced with a resolution following a tragedy in the Mediterranean. Again, this resolution highlights the failure of The Member States to respond to the humanitarian emergency facing Europe. Saving lives is a priority and for that we need more solidarity. We need Frontex to have sufficient means to carry out effective search and rescue operations, thus applying Regulation No 656/2014.  On the other hand, the resolution also looks at the fundamental problem. And then the European Council failed again. To do this, as the resolution rightly points out, we must better regulate legal immigration and combat illegal immigration; contribute to peace in war-based territories, with a focus on Syria; put an end to the power vacuum in Libya; defeat the self-styled Islamic State; effectively combat human traffickers; invest more in cooperation and development. Now is, without a doubt, time to act!

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I have chosen to vote in favour of this resolution because I believe that the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean have shown the urgency with which Europe is called upon to address the root causes of one of the most serious humanitarian emergencies of our century.  It seems all the more necessary for the Member States to coordinate their policies on the basis of the principle of fair sharing of responsibilities and for every effort to be made to promote dialogue with third countries of transit and origin, in order to combat trafficking in human beings. I also believe it is essential to rethink asylum and immigration policy so as to guarantee legal access to the EU asylum system, while respecting the principle of non-refoulement, and at the same time encouraging voluntary return by guaranteeing the protection of migrants' rights.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the most recent tragedies in the Mediterranean Sea, European migration and asylum policies. I firmly believe in the need for a European search and rescue operation and I am critical of the Council's position to reinforce Triton, a border patrol operation at the expense of search and rescue operations at sea. We also need binding quotas for the distribution of asylum seekers between Member States. But more than anything else, we need to take concrete action with effective, shared and coordinated measures at European level and not wait for yet another tragedy to make another resolution.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. We understand that the tragedies and deaths in the Mediterranean are a consequence of the 'Fortress Europe' that has been championed by the European institutions. That is why we voted against this resolution, which seems to us to be an attempt by majority groups to wash away their image. Apart from not recognising direct responsibility for European policies, the text speaks to the need to strengthen cooperation with third countries to combat immigration (which seems like a veiled reference to the establishment of detention centres in the countries of the southern bank of the Mediterranean) and calls on States to step up their contributions to Frontex , an agency that does not have the ransom between its missions, but fights against the entry of people, even though many of these may be asylum recipients. Instead of strengthening these mechanisms, our commitment would be to guarantee humanitarian corridors and visas in countries of origin for those fleeing violence, and to bet on an international policy not based on the bellicoseness or destabilization of third countries, as well as passing regulations that prevent the expoliation of the natural resources of the South.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 This year alone, 36,000 people have tried to cross the Mediterranean in search of refuge in Europe, and more than 1,700 of them have lost their lives. Migration is a global and complex phenomenon that requires a long-term approach that deals with its root causes, such as poverty, inequalities, injustice and armed conflict. The EU, its Member States and the international community must find political and sustainable solutions for the countries in conflict and strengthen political dialogue to help local communities and stimulate the social and democratic development of their countries of origin and peoples. Asylum is a fundamental human right guaranteed by international law and obligations and is binding on all Member States. It is therefore very important to transpose the common European asylum system quickly and fully and effectively by all participating Member States in order to ensure common European standards in accordance with the legislation in force. I welcome the meeting of European leaders at which it was decided to increase the funds allocated to patrols on the Mediterranean. Thus, the budget of the EU patrol mission "Triton" will have the sum of 120 million euros. I also support plans for possible military action against illegal immigrant smuggling networks.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: Writing. \u2012 Saving people's lives in an emergency is our moral duty. At the same time, we have a responsibility in the EU to prevent and prevent more and more people from being on the frontier of life and death. It is therefore necessary to take decisive and effective action against smuggling networks, to do everything possible to stop thousands of people going on such a risky journey.  The Member States of Central Europe have recently seen an increase in the number of illegal immigrants. It is no longer valid that only a few Member States are affected by the movements of illegal immigrants. People are increasingly concerned about immigration policy to distinguish between genuine refugees and illegal immigrants.  There is a pressing need for a solidarity mechanism to address the problem in the Union, but a system of centrally imposed mandatory quotas that do not follow local problems and do not take into account local characteristics is not the solution to the increasingly serious situation. For this reason, I abstained from voting on the decision.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that while in the European Council conclusions it is positive to see more Member States dedicating more resources to saving lives, while it is positive to see a push towards granting more attention to Libya and while I welcome the Malta EU-African Union Summit, I still believe that much more could have been done when it comes to responsibility sharing.  The conclusions still lack the proper political will and commitment by all governments of the different Member States to really have fair responsibility sharing. Voluntary relocation programmes never gave the desired result and I still cannot understand how the European Council is expecting that ‘emergency relocation between all Member States on a voluntary basis’ will give results this time round. The European Parliament Joint Motion for a Resolution, even though very watered down from the S&D resolution to which I am a signatory, is already a better position than the European Council’s position.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that migration is a global and complex phenomenon that calls for a long-term strategy that addresss its root causes, such as poverty, inequalities, injustice and armed conflict, I believe that Member States and the international community must contribute to finding sustainable political solutions in the countries in conflict and strengthen political dialogue, which encompasses all elements of human rights to support inclusive and democratic institutions , to strengthen the resilience of local communities and to promote social and democratic development in their countries of origin and among their populations.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's joint resolution on the tragic events in the Mediterranean last week.  This umpteenth tragedy is the sad confirmation that the individual Member States of the Union cannot cope with the growing migratory pressure in the Mediterranean: it is the European Union as a whole that has to take on this serious situation, preventing further tragedies. The decisions of the extraordinary European Council of 23 April finally represent a significant first step towards a real awareness of the whole of Europe. Of course, much remains to be done. The European Parliament must, as on this occasion, continue to exert strong pressure on the Council of the EU to take concrete action to create a genuine common European immigration policy that will make it possible, firstly, to deal adequately with emergency situations, by strengthening rescue and search operations with effective coordination between the Member States and fair burden-sharing; At the same time, it will be necessary to combat the deeper and structural causes of immigration, also thanks to an effective policy of international cooperation on the part of the EU.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution expresses the European Parliament's emotion at the tragic loss of life in the Mediterranean in recent months. The time for emotion and recollection must then give way to reflection and action, the European Parliament therefore calls on the European Union and its Member States to strengthen existing cooperation in the management of migration flows and the fight against trafficking and smuggling networks. Considering that, in addition to an increase in the budget for this policy announced by the European Council, it is necessary to think about genuine European coordination based on solidarity mechanisms between the Southern States under heavy migratory pressures and those less concerned, through the FRONTEX agency for example. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on "tragedies in the Mediterranean and asylum and immigration policies. What is currently unfolding in the Mediterranean is a tragedy and it is our responsibility to act. To do this we must access our actions on: - the fight against smugglers and traffickers;  - strengthening dialogue with source and transit countries;  - conditioning development aid to genuine commitments to restore the rule of law, fight corruption and good governance. And I welcome the fact that these aspects are in the resolution. On the other hand, I voted against the proposal for a mandatory distribution of asylum applications. Indeed, France, whose services are already overloaded with applications, has no interest in having a system imposed on it that will leave no room for discretion on the number of asylum seekers it wishes to take in. This placing the Member States under the tutelage of the Member States will only mean that the processing times are already too long will be extended.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP delegation, I share the common view that saving people's lives in an emergency is our moral duty. At the same time, we have a responsibility in the Union to prevent or prevent more and more people from being on the frontier of life and death. It is therefore necessary to take decisive action against smuggling networks, to do everything possible to stop thousands of people going on such a risky journey. The number of illegal immigrants in Hungary has increased 20 times this year, we are the fifth most touched Member State. People are concerned about immigration policy to distinguish between genuine refugees and illegal immigrants. There is a pressing need for a solidarity mechanism to address the problem in the Union, but a system of centrally imposed mandatory quotas that do not follow local problems and do not take into account local characteristics is not the solution to the increasingly serious situation. For this reason, I abstained from voting on the decision.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. \u2012 Saving people's lives in an emergency is our moral duty. At the same time, we have a responsibility in the Union to prevent or prevent more and more people from being on the frontier of life and death. It is therefore necessary to take decisive action against smuggling networks, to do everything possible to stop thousands of people going on such a risky journey.  The number of illegal immigrants in Hungary has increased 20 times this year, we are the fifth most touched Member State. People are concerned about immigration policy to distinguish between genuine refugees and illegal immigrants.  There is a pressing need for a solidarity mechanism to address the problem in the Union, but a system of centrally imposed mandatory quotas that do not follow local problems and do not take into account local characteristics is not the solution to the increasingly serious situation. For this reason, I abstained from voting on the decision.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The smugglers warn the Italian navy to retrieve the boats. And Parliament is about to triple the means of passage for smugglers: the European Union is therefore becoming complicit. To put an end to these tragedies and illegal immigration, it is important, first, to allow states to restore their borders and to implement a proactive policy, aimed at drying up the aspiring pumps and bringing the ships back to their port of origin. This effective and humanistic policy must be adopted. President Juncker announces that he wants to open the doors to prevent people from entering through the windows without any European people being consulted on this issue. This lack of democracy once again demonstrates the distance between European technocrats and peoples.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Once again, I express great concern about the half-hearted way in which the problem is being acted on and viewed in the Mediterranean. We all see that the situation is escalating and there is not a single signal or symptom that things will calm down. In Africa and the Middle East, we have conflicts that will unleash new and new waves of illegal immigrants. The more illegal immigrants, the more boats there will be and the more accidents. It concerns me that the question of what to do is answered by measures that would have been appropriate before 10-15 years ago. Now they are simply an unworkable or partial solution to a general issue. I therefore again insist on a total revision of Community legislation on the issue of migration and asylum. I also urge the countries that are on the front line – Bulgaria, Greece, Italy and Spain to help immediately – financially, with teams from Frontex and with equipment. I call, instead of endlessly pre-ordering measures that do not work, that support be provided within weeks to a month. It's solidarity, not procrastinating forever.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the joint resolution, although it contains correct findings, because it moves to avoid the real problem. No policies are sought to tackle illegal immigration, no solutions are proposed to the problem of trafficking ring action and finally only wishful meals are proposed for a change in the situation of the countries of origin of migrants, when, especially in Libya, the problem began with EU intervention.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 Saving people's lives in an emergency is our moral duty. At the same time, we have a responsibility in the Union to prevent or prevent more and more people from being on the frontier of life and death. It is therefore necessary to take decisive action against smuggling networks, to do everything possible to stop thousands of people going on such a risky journey.  The number of illegal immigrants in Hungary has increased 20 times this year, we are the fifth most touched Member State. People are concerned about immigration policy to distinguish between genuine refugees and illegal immigrants.  There is a pressing need for a solidarity mechanism to address the problem in the Union, but a system of centrally imposed mandatory quotas that do not follow local problems and do not take into account local characteristics is not the solution to the increasingly serious situation. For this reason, I abstained from voting on the decision.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. \u2012 On April 18, 2015, yet another tragedy unfolded in the waters of the Mediterranean Sea: more than 700 migrants lost their lives in the hope of reaching italian shores. Yet another because more than 1,500 people have died in that stretch of sea since the beginning of this year alone. The text notes several critical issues of European policies on managing the flow of migrants. In particular, while for Mare Nostrum, an operation that saved 150,810 migrants in a year, EUR 9 million was allocated to Triton, the new operation launched in November 2014, only EUR 2.9 million was allocated. There is also a fair reference to the battle that Europe as a whole must wage against those who profit from the despair of migrants but, more importantly, to the effort that the Union should make to try to establish or restore a situation of peace in the countries of origin.  It is also crucial to call on Europe to take a holistic approach to the situation and to be able to increase support for its Member States, which are most affected by the consequences of migratory flows, for example through a serious plan for the distribution of asylum seekers. For these reasons, I am voting in favour.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. This resolution regrets the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and reminds us that the EU and the Member States have responsibilities and need to take action to prevent future deaths at sea. Thus, financial and human resources should be allocated for mandatory capture and rescue operations, under the coordination of FRONTEX. The EP must therefore take a strong stand and it is in this sense that I voted in favour of this common resolution as a step towards a less tragic future for immigrants seeking a better life.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. More than 1,600 refugees and migrants have died in the Mediterranean since the beginning of the year, according to data from the UN High Commissioner for Refugees. The European Parliament has urged the EU to take its share of responsibility and solidarity with the Member States hosting the largest number of refugees and asylum seekers, both in absolute and proportionate terms. Search and rescue obligations must be 'effectively fulfilled' and 'properly financed' in the medium and long term. Safe and legal routes for asylum seekers to enter the EU, cooperation with third countries of transit and origin, the return of irregular immigrants and the fight against traffickers and traffickers are other aspects that cannot be over-neglected.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. The horror of the tragedy suffered has moved political groups to adopt a resolution that advances in European positions. I would like to highlight the following: - the recognition that the abandonment of the Mare Nostrum mission and its replacement by joint operation Triton, with a smaller budget, was a serious mistake;  - the commitment reached by Member States to promote joint operations and increase naval resources with the aim of preventing further deaths at sea; - the consideration of the migration phenomenon in North Africa as an international humanitarian crisis calling for a comprehensive policy, from the pacification and stability of these countries to the fight against mafias, from development cooperation to a common asylum policy that includes the extension of EASO's mandate; - effective implementation of Member States' solidarity to welcome asylum seekers and refugees and integrate them into our countries as a moral, legal and vital duty to our democratic beliefs.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I do not consider it particularly ambitious and critical of the insufficient and inadequate conclusions of the extraordinary European Council on immigration, I voted in favour of the resolution. I believe that the priority at the moment is to save lives and avoid further tragedies. It is essential to support common-sense measures. Firstly, a search and rescue operation must be set up with sufficient financial, technical and human resources at European level. If the EU does not expand Triton's mandate and scope, everything will remain unchanged.  We need a holistic approach to the phenomenon that does not neglect its true causes, the security of migrants and refugees as well as that of European citizens, the protection of fundamental rights, the need to have legal and legal channels of immigration. On the basis of the principle of shared solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities among all Member States, mechanisms for allocating quotas of those arriving in Europe must be identified. No less important are the fight against the criminal networks of human traffickers, international cooperation in development and political stability, and monitoring the proper use of funds for the reception system.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 While thousands of lives are lost in the Mediterranean, in the mass exodus of countries from Africa and the Middle East, fleeing war, hunger and extreme poverty, the European Council, concerned above all with the media repercussions, rather than finding effective solutions, deepens the communitisation of its immigration policy and the European Neighbourhood Policy – a guideline now ratified by the majority of Parliament , with this resolution.  This resolution points the way to strengthening policies of aggression, interference and support for the destabilization of the countries of those regions, promoting war and extremist movements, which increase migratory pressure. We condemn the eu's repressive and criminalised treatment of refugees by denying adequate integration policies, as well as strengthening the vision of a "Fortress" Europe, closed to migration flows, helping to maintain human trafficking networks. This is the view of this resolution and, for that reason, we voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing ‒ Almost every month in the last quarter of the last quarter, the European Parliament's parliamentary session begins with a minute's silence for the victims who lost their lives in the Mediterranean while trying to reach the shores of the European Union. Many of these refugees are fleeing hunger, violence, wars or a generally bad social situation. It is our duty to seek solutions to prevent, in particular, the mass exolotion of refugees from their countries of origin. Some citizens of the Member States of the European Union are beginning to express their resentment towards these mass influxes of refugees. However, it must be realised that they expect solutions from politicians, not populist criticisms towards the refugees themselves.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution does not strongly condemn the poor results achieved during the extraordinary European Council. He insists on missions such as Mare Nostrum, which have proved to attract even more migrants.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: Writing. – The joint resolution contains some correct findings but is essentially based on the logic of avoiding the real problem. No policies are sought to tackle illegal immigration and no solutions are proposed to the problem of trafficking ring action. There are only wishes for a change in the situation of the countries of origin of migrants, especially in Libya the problem started with the EU intervention. For the above reasons, my vote is against.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ It is clear that if we do not act now we will bear the responsibility before future generations for these tragedies. We can no longer afford not to tackle this issue seriously: we must implement an effective strategy to save the lives of these people. Right now, only those who have money and are strong enough to escape from wars and poverty have a chance to reach the shores of Europe, safely but illegally. The weak, the poor and the families with children are left behind in harm’s way. And this is primarily due to our hypocritical barriers that prevent asylum seekers and refugees from saving their lives in a better world. We must take urgent action now to confront these crises and conflicts.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 Saving people's lives in an emergency is our moral duty. At the same time, we have a responsibility in the Union to prevent or prevent more and more people from being on the frontier of life and death. It is therefore necessary to take decisive action against smuggling networks, to do everything possible to stop thousands of people going on such a risky journey. The number of illegal immigrants in Hungary has increased 20 times this year, we are the fifth most touched Member State. People are concerned about immigration policy to distinguish between genuine refugees and illegal immigrants. There is a pressing need for a solidarity mechanism to address the problem in the Union, but a system of centrally imposed mandatory quotas that do not follow local problems and do not take into account local characteristics is not the solution to the increasingly serious situation. For this reason, I abstained from voting on the decision.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 Saving people's lives in an emergency is our moral duty. At the same time, we have a responsibility in the Union to prevent or prevent more and more people from being on the frontier of life and death. It is therefore necessary to take decisive action against smuggling networks, to do everything possible to stop thousands of people going on such a risky journey.  The number of illegal immigrants in Hungary has increased 20 times this year, we are the fifth most touched Member State. People are concerned about immigration policy to distinguish between genuine refugees and illegal immigrants.  There is a pressing need for a solidarity mechanism to address the problem in the Union, but a system of centrally imposed mandatory quotas that do not follow local problems and do not take into account local characteristics is not the solution to the increasingly serious situation. For this reason, I abstained from voting on the decision.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. U2012 The terrible loss of human life in the Mediterranean of migrants trying to reach Europe has touched us all deeply. According to the International Organization for Migration, more than 1,500 people have lost their lives in the Mediterranean Sea since the beginning of this year. Smugglers and human traffickers exploit irregular migration by showing total contempt for human life. The EU and Member States must put the necessary resources to ensure that their search and rescue obligations are met. Similarly, Member States must show their solidarity towards those States most exposed to the phenomenon of irregular immigration, as it is a serious problem affecting the whole Union equally.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution on the humanitarian drama of immigration in the Mediterranean because, in the face of the horror of the tragedy suffered, we advanced European positions that had never been given before: - the recognition that the abandonment of the Mare Nostrum mission and its replacement by the Joint Triton operation, with a smaller budget, was a serious mistake;  - the commitment reached by Member States to promote joint operations and increase naval resources with the aim of preventing further deaths at sea; - the consideration of the migration issue in North Africa as an international humanitarian crisis calling for a comprehensive policy, from the pacification and stability of these countries to the fight against mafias, from development cooperation to a common asylum policy that includes the extension of EASO's mandate; - effective implementation of Member States' solidarity to welcome asylum seekers and refugees and integrate them into our countries as a moral, legal and vital duty to our democratic beliefs.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists congratulate the resolution adopted by Parliament on the humanitarian drama of immigration in the Mediterranean. It has been the horror of the tragedy suffered that has led political groups to adopt a resolution that advances in European positions that had never been given: - the recognition that the abandonment of the Mare Nostrum mission and its replacement by joint operation Triton, with a smaller budget, was a grave mistake;  - the commitment reached by Member States to promote joint operations and increase naval resources with the aim of preventing further deaths at sea; - the consideration of the migration issue in North Africa as an international humanitarian crisis calling for a comprehensive policy, from the pacification and stability of these countries to the fight against mafias, from development cooperation to a common asylum policy that includes the extension of EASO's mandate; - effective implementation of Member States' solidarity to welcome asylum seekers and refugees and integrate them into our countries as a moral, legal and vital duty to our democratic beliefs.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution adopted today by the European Parliament is a significant step forward compared to the past. The strategy indicated is finally to establish compulsory quotas between states and to implement the EU directive on the temporary protection of refugees. Reforming and strengthening Triton is not enough, you can no longer hide and leave all the weight on the shoulders of one or two countries. That is why I have wholely voted 'yes' to today's resolution and we will continue as the PPE Group, and also personally, to do everything possible to ensure that there is finally a radical change of pace with regard to the failed immigration policies of the past.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. The Union must respond to the seriousness of the current migration emergency. The latest dramatic journeys of hope of desperate men, women and children fleeing war, hunger and poverty in Libya to seek salvation in Europe have already resulted in 1 600 deaths since the beginning of 2015.  I therefore support and warmly welcome the results and commitments made by the EU at the extraordinary summit promoted by the Italian Government to accelerate plans and strategies in support of urgency, and I hope that this will be only a first step towards new concrete common commitments. We need a European strategy which will lead to an overall assumption of responsibility, not only for an economic investment plan, but also for wider action inspired by the founding values of the Union, which give priority to the right to the well-being and health of the individual.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and on EU policies on migration and asylum. The continuing terrible tragedies in the Mediterranean Sea, which lead to the deaths of vulnerable people, women and children fleeing their lands in order to build their life plan, generate pain and grief and oblige Europe to act with solidarity and vigour. I welcome the rapid convening of last week's European summits and the decision to triple the resources for the Triton mission, involving EASO in the examination of asylum applications. But more can and must be done. It is essential to expand Triton's range of action to turn it into a real search and rescue mission at sea. The EU must base its response on solidarity and a fair distribution of responsibility. Less indifference, more humanity! We call for a substantial revision of the Dublin Treaty to allocate asylum seekers among all states, to establish binding quotas for the distribution of asylum seekers among all Member States and to create humanitarian channels for legal migration. All this with the great theme of stabilising Africa and a stronger foreign policy towards African countries in the background.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because it draws attention to the tragedy of people trying to cross the Mediterranean, fleeing war or persecution in Syria, Iraq, Eritrea, Somalia and Libya. More than 1,500 people have already died in the Mediterranean since January this year. Our resolution calls on the Commission to develop a European agenda on migration that takes into account all aspects of migration and to propose urgent action to prevent further deaths at sea, and calls for closer coordination between EU and Member State policies on eliminating the root causes of migration. At the same time, close cooperation should be established with Europol, Frontex, EASO and Eurojust in order to combat human traffickers and criminal networks of smugglers linked to drug trafficking, arms and terrorism. Action should be taken to detect and track their funding and to identify methods of action to prevent them from making a profit at the expense of migrants' lives. Close cooperation and compliance by third countries with regard to saving lives at sea, as well as ensuring the protection of refugees and respect for fundamental rights, must be ensured.  Member States should make use of all possibilities for issuing humanitarian visas in their diplomatic missions. A solidarity mechanism must work in the event of a mass or sudden influx of migrants. The Common European Asylum System must be implemented quickly and effectively by all participating Member States, ensuring common European standards.

name: Neena GILL
text: in writing. ‒ Twenty-two thousand lives have been lost in the Mediterranean since 2000. Lives that could have been saved if Europe’s leaders did not choose to bury their heads in the ground rather than provide an adequate response. The UK Government played a leading role in scaling back search-and-rescue operations at EU level, arguing that saving migrants would serve as a pull-factor for migration. I say saving lives is not an issue of encouraging or discouraging migration.  It is a moral duty. Boat arrivals, moreover, are a result of the complex humanitarian crisis in our neighbourhood.  That is why a comprehensive response is required. Measures put forward by the Council last week are not enough. Tackling human trafficking is important, but we cannot ignore the first priority, saving those at sea, nor the need to tackle deeper root causes.   We need a major expansion of the search-and-rescue operations and a clear commitment from the UK and other governments to resettle a meaningful number of refugees. Third, we need to connect the dots between our actions in the fields of foreign and security policy, trade and development to tackle the root causes forcing people to flee their homes in search for a better life.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. U2012 Recent deaths of migrants drowned in the Mediterranean must serve as an aldabonazo for the development of a genuine European migration policy. There are different dimensions in which we must act, it is imperative to note that a fundamental pillar of this policy must be the establishment of a European search and rescue fund covering the performance of these functions by the Member States, both when acting individually and when they do so under Frontex's coordination. We cannot leave Italy alone in the task of avoiding the hundreds of deaths that have occurred in recent weeks. Europe must also pursue mafias that exploit vulnerable immigrants, strengthen cooperation with countries of origin and transit, work for the stabilisation of Libya, promote voluntary return policies, implement the Common European Asylum System, and address, through its common foreign and security policy and its policy of development cooperation , the root causes of migration.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: In writing. I voted against the proposal for a joint resolution on the European Union's migration and asylum policies.  I deplore the shameless exploitation of recent tragedies to facilitate, once again, the trafficking of human beings. Instead of taking illegal immigrants back to their countries of origin or to a safe third country, The Europeanists propose to facilitate asylum applications.  On the contrary, we must draw inspiration from Australia, where illegal immigrants are systematically sent to three countries that have signed an agreement with Australia: Nauru, Papua New Guinea and Cambodia.  As a result of this policy, Australia has significantly reduced the number of illegal immigrants and there has not been a single migrant who has died at sea for 18 months.  Finally, illegal immigrants arriving by sea account for about 4% of entries into Europe: the majority of illegal entries, which take place by land or air, are therefore deliberately hidden.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. After the tragedy in the Mediterranean last week, the European Union has reacted. The proposal for a Joint Resolution negotiated between the EPP, S&D, ALDE and Verts/ALE has several problems. It calls for strengthening Frontex's activity and funding (including rescue and search operations), focuses on the issue of human trafficking, calls for strengthening cooperation with Libya's neighbouring countries to combat criminal networks, and is unable to make a single criticism of the European Union's structural policy. It does not even criticize triton's limited mandate, which does not operate more than thirty nautical miles off the Italian coast, preventing the provision of assistance to shipwrecks near Libya. It speaks of asylum protection as a voluntary matter. Asylum protection cannot be a voluntary issue. It is an obligation that the EU has assumed through a wide variety of international treaties. When the question of asylum is a voluntary thing, we already know that many countries will not assume it, as is the case in Spain (130 resettlements for the whole year). We abstained.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the European Union must not only respond to the recent increase in the pattern of tragedies, deaths of people in the Mediterranean, but also to address fundamentally the compliance of member states' international maritime rescue obligations and migration policies, support policies for developing countries. I support the motion in the resolution calling on the European Union, its Member States and the international community to help find sustainable political solutions in conflict-affected countries and to strengthen political dialogue to cover all aspects of human rights, to increase the resilience of local communities and to promote the social and democratic development of countries of origin and their populations.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists congratulate the resolution adopted by Parliament on the humanitarian drama of immigration in the Mediterranean. It has been the horror of the tragedy suffered that has led political groups to adopt a resolution that advances in European positions that had never been given: - the recognition that the abandonment of the Mare Nostrum mission and its replacement by joint operation Triton, with a smaller budget, was a grave mistake;  - the commitment reached by Member States to promote joint operations and increase naval resources with the aim of preventing further deaths at sea; - the consideration of the migration issue in North Africa as an international humanitarian crisis calling for a comprehensive policy, from the pacification and stability of these countries to the fight against mafias, from development cooperation to a common asylum policy that includes the extension of EASO's mandate; - effective implementation of Member States' solidarity to welcome asylum seekers and refugees and integrate them into our countries as a moral, legal and vital duty to our democratic beliefs.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. \u2012 Saving people's lives in an emergency is our moral duty. At the same time, we have a responsibility in the Union to prevent or prevent more and more people from being on the frontier of life and death. It is therefore necessary to take decisive action against smuggling networks, to do everything possible to stop thousands of people going on such a risky journey.  The number of illegal immigrants in Hungary has increased 20 times this year, we are the fifth most touched Member State. People are concerned about immigration policy to distinguish between genuine refugees and illegal immigrants.  There is a pressing need for a solidarity mechanism to address the problem in the Union, but a system of centrally imposed mandatory quotas that do not follow local problems and do not take into account local characteristics is not the solution to the increasingly serious situation. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I abstained from voting on the decision.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and on EU migration and asylum policies. This has been and continues to be a crucial issue for the EU. Vast numbers of irregular migrants, many of whom are fleeing conflict or persecution, are attempting to come to Europe. Unfortunately it has taken the harrowing deaths of hundreds of people for Member States and the EU to sit up and pay attention. That more than 1 500 people have died in the Mediterranean since the beginning of this year alone is shocking. Europe must show solidarity and share responsibility. Operation Triton is underfunded, and the EU and Member States must ensure its effectiveness into the future by providing necessary resources. Therefore the European Council’s commitment to reinforcing the EU Triton operation by increasing funding and assets is very welcome.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. After the tragedy in the Mediterranean last week, the European Union has reacted. The proposal for a Joint Resolution negotiated between the EPP, S&D, ALDE and Verts/ALE has several problems. It calls for strengthening Frontex's activity and funding (including rescue and search operations), focuses on the issue of human trafficking, calls for strengthening cooperation with Libya's neighbouring countries to combat criminal networks, and is unable to make a single criticism of the European Union's structural policy. It does not even criticize triton's limited mandate, which does not operate more than thirty nautical miles off the Italian coast, preventing the provision of assistance to shipwrecks near Libya. It speaks of asylum protection as a voluntary matter. Asylum protection cannot be a voluntary issue. It is an obligation that the EU has assumed through a wide variety of international treaties. When the question of asylum is a voluntary thing, we already know that many countries will not assume it, as is the case in Spain (130 resettlements for the whole year). We abstained.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this document on the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the migration and asylum policies of the European Union.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The tragic events in the Mediterranean are primarily the result of the irresponsible geopolitics of the great powers that have destabilised some countries in north Africa. However, trying to resolve this situation – by taking millions of refugees to European countries – is probably the worst possible solution. In the first place, this will not solve the complicated situation in the countries of north Africa, nor is it a guarantee of a peaceful and stable life for refugees and will significantly worsen the economic situation of the countries hosting the refugees. Solutions to the tragic situation of refugees should be sought on their home soil.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a joint motion for a resolution on the recent Mediterranean Sea tragedies and migration and asylum policy in the EU regardless of what I have specific objections to. I am not satisfied with the results of the European Council session because I think more radical action should have been taken. In my view, strong and efficient surveillance of all vessels should be set up in the Mediterranean, as this is technically absolutely possible. It is necessary to carry out a broad international action by all entities involved in conflicts in north Africa and the Middle East and to involve the UN in the resolution of this tragic situation. More solidarity is also needed between member states to distribute the burden of the afflicted refugees more evenly.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I voted against the report of the extraordinary council meeting dated 23 April 2015.  This report falls under the yoke of nonsense and absurdity. We all know that today, mass immigration is not beneficial to the men who try it, nor to those who welcome it. However, through this report, the Council persists and signs by strengthening already existing and out-of-phase mechanisms, when it is a question of changing paradigms.  The Council is based on two erroneous assertions: that of the attractiveness of the illegality of immigration and that of the voluntary return of migrants who have arrived in the Union. Who will the Council make believe that the men and women who have transited in undignified conditions in order to reach EU territory will voluntarily decide to leave?  Moreover, this report is constantly blaming member states, which would be subject to binding solidarity and would be given distribution rates for asylum seekers.   I voted against this text which denigrates reality, offers no solution to migrants or the citizens of the European Union and deprives States of one of their most fundamental competences while jeopardising the social and national cohesion of the peoples of Europe.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I support a complex approach to migration, including the enhanced use of the CFSP and the UN to help improve the situation in Africa and the Middle East. I also support measures addressing the unbearable humanitarian situation. However, I do not believe European solidarity can be achieved through the implementation of a binding quota system. In some Member States, due to historical and other reasons, a quota system may backfire and may have the potential to disrupt Schengen, the free movement of people and perhaps even the EU as a whole.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution in response to the migrant tragedies in the Mediterranean and the proposals made by the European Council that followed. This resolution underlines the Responsiveness of the Council and supports the tripling of the resources allocated by Member States to Operation Triton, while calling for enhanced cooperation between countries for the management of asylum applications. The resolution also calls on Member States to work more closely with Frontex and to tackle more rigorously against human trafficking and smugglers who exploit the most vulnerable. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support this resolution which calls for greater efforts by the EU and all Member States in several different areas: increased resources for search and rescue operations; increased solidarity and responsibility in terms of more protection for the refugees and standardisation of legal, financial and reception conditions; implementation of strong criminal sanctions against human traffickers; closer coordination of EU and Member States in tackling migration and its root causes. These can all be improved even beyond these aims, and I hope that the EU and its Member States will work together to tackle this grave issue.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. \u2012 Since I am very sympathetic to refugees heading for European shores, I am not entirely comfortable with the optics that many resort to, not to see refugees primarily as a threat to our security. It is hard to imagine a situation from today's Europe where uncertain fate at sea seems like a better alternative than staying in your homeland. The fact that they can risk not only their lives, but the lives of their entire families and put themselves at risk to enterprizing smugglers, is indicative of the profound suffering they face in their region. These refugees come from destabilised countries and we must realise that we bear our share of responsibility for their situation, see the war in Libya. I therefore prefer to see this issue humanely and in context. On the other hand, this does not mean that I agree that the Commission should introduce binding quotas for the distribution of asylum seekers among all Member States. In this I agree with the position of the Czech Government, which believes that this should remain the sovereign right of each country. The Czech State knows where its limits are and what it can do to calm the situation and should not be forced into anything. However, the joint motion for a resolution otherwise contained points with which I identify, which is why I have decided to abstain.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. \u2012 Saving people's lives in an emergency is our moral duty. At the same time, we have a responsibility in the Union to prevent or prevent more and more people from being on the frontier of life and death. It is therefore necessary to take decisive action against smuggling networks, to do everything possible to stop thousands of people going on such a risky journey.  The number of illegal immigrants in Hungary has increased 20 times this year, we are the fifth most touched Member State. People are concerned about immigration policy to distinguish between genuine refugees and illegal immigrants.  There is a pressing need for a solidarity mechanism to address the problem in the Union, but a system of centrally imposed mandatory quotas that do not follow local problems and do not take into account local characteristics is not the solution to the increasingly serious situation. For this reason, I abstained from voting on the decision.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The European Council's report on the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and migration and asylum policy in the EU has sparked a heated debate. The deaths of refugees, the dramas and wrongs taking place in their countries are shocking and unacceptable. We cannot be indifferent to these wrongs. However, it is clear that Europe, an island of peace and prosperity against a backdrop of war-torn worlds, has limited financial and territorial resources. Our solidarity with the people of other parts of the world must be matched to our capabilities. Let us develop our migration and asylum policies, education systems and the organisation of social life towards multiculturalism and multi-religion, but with caution, without losing our own identity and religion. Instead of moving the world to Europe, Europe is crucial to move Europe, in terms of institutions, organisations and ideas, to other continents, to provide aid in situ, to reduce illegal human smuggling. That is why I voted against mandatory migration quotas for Member States because they are economically diverse, often not yet adapted to multiculturalism, have different geopolitical situations. Poland, for example, is already accepting many migrants from Ukraine and other eastern countries, and we expect more. That is why we need a non-fragmented European policy that also takes into account these directions of migration, as well as the different status of migrants in view of the political and economic situation in their countries of origin.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. As you know, I come from Sicily, and that is why I can watch the landings on our coasts every morning and look at the faces of immigrants arriving in the ports of my Sicily. But that is only the end of a much more adventurous journey, as a result of which the tragedies to which we are unfortunately accustomed take place, the last of which has caused the death of 900 migrants. The European Union cannot stand still. For these reasons, I welcomed the decision to hold an extraordinary European Council on this subject, and the decisions it has taken, as well as the resolution adopted by this House today. There is no doubt that this phenomenon affects all Member States without distinction, and not just Italy or Malta, and all states must therefore take responsibility for this, through resources and means and through a compulsory division of the quotas of asylum seekers. More and more can and must be done because this is the united and united Europe that we have hoped for and want.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the EU's migration and asylum policies.  We would therefore like to reiterate that, while strengthening the fight against human traffickers and smuggling networks is a necessity, the EU and its member states also have a duty to ensure a humanitarian mission in the Mediterranean by strengthening search, rescue and migrant assistance operations. Through this resolution, we also call for the establishment of a common asylum policy for the 28 member states through the establishment of a binding solidarity mechanism and the strengthening of the EU's political and diplomatic action to source and transit countries to dry up the flood of misfortune and human despair that throws thousands of people , women and children, on roads and in precarious ships, risking their lives.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution, unfortunately adopted by an overwhelming majority, because it aims to increase the means to rescue migrant boats. It thus constitutes a new aspiring pump of immigration. I believe that a policy that respects the interests of the peoples of Europe would rather consist of drying up the sources of immigration, helping Libya to prevent these boats from leaving and, on the other hand, turning migrants back to their point of departure, as Australia successfully does.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against it. Of course, we cannot be insensitive to the situation of migrants who are currently trying to reach European shores. That being said, even if the subject is difficult to resolve, the measures defended by Parliament are inadequate, and President Schultz's recent statement is proof of this. The priority of border control is not accepted, Parliament provides for an increase in funds for rescue actions but nothing for the control of migration. There is no firm will to fight the smugglers. No reference to any policy of aid to countries of origin or willingness to take action against those who promote such migration. The European Union acts as if it wants to increase legal immigration to avoid illegality, which also poses problems of reception, integration etc. Parliament is not aware of the future consequences of its policy. Although host countries are considered to be rich countries, they face difficult economic situations (unemployment etc) that do not presage good integration of migrants. In addition, the European Union imposes its policy on member states.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This is a resolution debate with representatives of the Council and the Commission to pay tribute to the victims of the tragedies and to analyse the outcome of the European Council meeting on 23 April.  On 19 April, a ship was shipwrecked off the coast of Libya, shocking all European public opinion. This is the greatest tragedy experienced in the Mediterranean so far, as between 700 and 900 people travelled there, of whom only 28 have been rescued, but unfortunately this is not an isolated event. Days later, two other barges with about 450 people were found adrift in the Mediterranean. According to UNHCR, more than 1,600 people have died trying to make this journey so far this year.  To address this situation, the European Council met in an extraordinary manner on 23 April.  They have made a commitment that combines solidarity measures with others to support the control work of countries on the migration route of these migrants to the Mediterranean.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. We understand that the tragedies and deaths in the Mediterranean are a consequence of the 'Fortress Europe' that has been championed by the European institutions. That is why we voted against this resolution, which seems to us to be an attempt by majority groups to wash away their image. Apart from not recognising direct responsibility for European policies, the text speaks to the need to strengthen cooperation with third countries to combat immigration (which seems like a veiled reference to the establishment of detention centres in the countries of the southern bank of the Mediterranean) and calls on States to step up their contributions to Frontex , an agency that does not have the ransom between its missions, but fights against the entry of people, even though many of these may be asylum recipients. Instead of strengthening these mechanisms, our commitment would be to guarantee humanitarian corridors and visas in countries of origin for those fleeing violence, and to bet on an international policy not based on the bellicoseness or destabilization of third countries, as well as passing regulations that prevent the expoliation of the natural resources of the South.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution urging the European Union and the Member States to do everything possible to prevent further deaths at sea; I call on the EU and the Member States to provide the necessary resources to ensure that search and rescue obligations are actually met and, to do so, to receive the necessary funding and staff in the short, medium and long term, under Frontex's coordination. In addition, EU border and security policy should be strengthened immediately and frontex and the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) improved. The Resolution also calls on Member States to work closely with Europol, Frontex, EASO and Eurojust to combat human traffickers and criminal networks for the clandestine passage of borders, and to detect and track their funding.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the tragic events in the Mediterranean and the Union's asylum and migration policy. The lack of a common approach to migration policy undermines our ability to combat such tragedies. Unfortunately, despite many attempts, we have still not been able to develop a common approach on migration. At present, none of us has any doubt that such a policy based on solidarity and respect for human rights is a necessity.  Cooperation with countries of origin and transit of migrants is crucial in combating irregular migration. Cooperation on humanitarian, financial and political assistance, which should focus both on improving the living conditions of the local population and on combating networks of smugglers and traffickers. Further steps must focus on the proper implementation of existing legal measures, including m.in. on the effective implementation of the Sanctions Directive against employers employing irregular migrants.  We must also address legal migration in the discussions on the Union's approach to migration. As europe's population ages, migration can be an opportunity for us to fill labour shortages in certain sectors of the economy. That is why we need a clear European system that will help bring different categories of workers to Europe and reduce irregular migration.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am fundamentally opposed to any artificial immigration and redistribution of people against the will of the citizens and themselves. It is not the solution to "invite" millions of people to Europe who would like to emigrate here. In the current system of an over-welfare state, europe cannot cope with so many immigrants. Trade with third countries needs to be freed up so that their citizens also have the opportunity to get rich and do not suffer because of the barriers, tariffs and unfair subsidies we have set.

name: Vicky MAEIJER
text: Written. – This motion for a resolution will only lead to more illegal immigrants making the crossing on the Mediterranean. By strengthening sea searches and thereby increasing the sucking effect, the authors of this resolution will achieve exactly the opposite of what they envision, namely more deaths at sea. The PVV believes that this flow of illegal immigration must stop. The EU must therefore stop facilitating people smuggling and encouraging illegal immigration and instead make it clear that the Mediterranean shuttle service has ended. The focus should be on sending illegal immigrants back to their country of origin or departure, and on reception in the region. This will automatically put an end to the flow of illegal immigrants and the tragic incidents at sea. Australia has already proven that this approach works.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ This year alone, 1,800 refugees have died in the Mediterranean, and more than 20,000 people have died in the last 20 years in an attempt to reach Europe. The death and death toll is frightening, and the ways in which they die are inhumane.  Although union leaders decided at an extraordinary Summit to increase the budget for the "Triton" surveillance and rescue operation at sea and now have nine million euros at their disposal, our concern should also be how to help those who reach the mainland. The main message of the resolution is to warn about the worrying state of fundamental human rights and democracy in the countries of Africa and Asia and the insufficient fight against human trafficking The causes of the problem should be addressed in these countries. We need better coordination, agreement to send a unified message and fair sharing of responsibilities between Member States in efforts to help refugees.  I supported a resolution intended to encourage a strong response to the tragic events in the Mediterranean and the situation with immigrants. In this context, the Republic of Croatia plans to send a military ship to Italy in May to help control the coast and rescue refugees in the Mediterranean. Even though we're a country with a coastline, we don't have a problem with refugees, so I'm glad we can help in this way.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing ‒ The latest tragic events in the Mediterranean region justify a review of the European Union's migration and asylum policy. The mass influx of migrants has to be borne mainly by Italy, whose shores have attracted 170,000 migrants in the past year alone. Coping with such an influx of asylum seekers represents an onslaught on the security and rescue services, administration and other considerable costs associated with providing assistance to these persons. It is necessary for the Commission to develop a strategy on migration and asylum policy that responds to events in the Mediterranean, while encouraging all local and international institutions to implement political, economic and anti-corruption measures that stop unwanted population migration.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained because the resolution under consideration is not sufficient. It should be noted that the European Union must immediately apply the famous principle of European solidarity. This means that the burdens of refugee and migration flows must be shared between the countries of the European Union, depending on the extent, population, GDP and the unemployment rate must also be taken into account.

name: Fulvio MARTUSCIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation in the Mediterranean is dramatic. More than 1,500 people have lost their lives in the Mediterranean Sea since the beginning of the year. It is not acceptable for hundreds of people to die trying to cross the sea and reach Europe. It is essential to make every effort to avoid further loss of life at sea and to provide the necessary resources to ensure that search and rescue obligations are respected and therefore adequately funded. We need a global approach from the European Union that strengthens the coherence of internal and external policies, with particular reference to the common foreign and security policy, development policy and migration and asylum policy.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The time has come for the European Union to take note of the fact that there is no short-term solution to migration. Only systematic action, based on the fight against traffickers in human beings, on a fair distribution of asylum applications among the Member States, on a conscious return policy and on a more rational management of funding for international cooperation, could stem what we can no longer call an emergency. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that it offers a holistic perspective on the migration problem. In particular, I welcomed the reference made in the document to the need for some Member States to step up their contribution to the definition of a lasting strategy, based on a solid distribution of responsibility between countries.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. I have chosen not to report on the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the EU's migration and asylum policy, as I do not consider the whole report as a whole to be useful. Among other things, I cannot support the call for a binding quota, which is set by the Commission, for the distribution of asylum seekers among the Member States, but also the pointless financing of resettlement programmes and the uncontrolled mass reception of refugees.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. 1,500 people have already died in the Mediterranean since the beginning of the year, 700 of them remain "missing". It is high time that each state took responsibility. The resolution contains good elements on asylum policy and refugees but tries to use emotion in the face of the recent tragedy to force through the idea of strengthening Frontex. An EU agency that violates the most basic fundamental rights of migrants and whose mandate is not to save migrants but to turn them away and to turn them back. It makes Frontex's "Triton" operation the equivalent of the Italian operation "Mare Nostrum" entirely devoted to rescue with a budget three times that of the European one.  Finally, this resolution does not question the root causes of migration: the European Union's trade and agricultural policy in African countries is ruining local economies; foreign policy, particularly in Libya. Not to mention the issue of climate migrants. These are all reasons that force these people to forcibly leave their homes.  I abstain so as not to give the impression that I am opposed to something being done, even if what is being proposed is completely inadequate.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ Having played a role in shaping this joint resolution I was proud to support it and I am very pleased with the level of cross-party support it received. It is significant that specific reference was made to the binding mechanism for solidarity and also the establishment of a quota system to share the distribution of asylum seekers.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. In the face of human tragedies, the urgency is first and foremost humanitarian. Human life is priceless and European mobilization must be general. The blatant lack of responsiveness, solidarity and responsibility of certain Member States is a flaw in our European system. The Union must now become a leading player and focus its efforts on joint actions mainly carried out by Frontex.  It should be remembered, however, that the cause of this tragedy is first and foremost the poor governance in the countries of origin. We must hold the governments of origin and transit accountable by strengthening our cooperation so that it can better control their territory and ensure economic development with an equitable distribution of wealth. We must also break the channels of smugglers, real criminals exploiting human despair as a commercial good. To do this, it is important that large-scale European operations are set up quickly.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. \u2012 Refugees from Africa or the Middle East need concrete help, not expression of compassion and watching. From a humanitarian point of view, we clearly have a duty to urgently help those who are fighting for their lives in mediterranean waters. At the same time, however, we must not forget the complex and long-term solutions that much more effective development aid brings. More effective development aid to the countries from which migrants come means solving the problem from the root. Thanks to it, people can stay and work in their homeland, without disturbing family and social ties, and without exposure to often very precarying conditions in the beneficiary countries, whose language or culture they do not know.  When it comes to accepting refugees into the EU, it is neither rational nor economically and socially bearable to take in refugees from all over the world. We cannot be held responsible for the personal decision of individuals leaving their own country with knowledge of risk. I recall that public officials have a primary duty to their own citizens, who must be protected from negative consequences in the area of safety, health or even life.  Finally, I strongly support and expect urgent humanitarian aid and concrete follow-up.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the latest tragedies in the Mediterranean and EU migration and asylum policies because this is a big step forward in the EU’s approach to the migration problem. The policies which have been voted upon favour the asylum seekers as well as receiving countries. This resolution also indicated that EU is recognising that this is a European problem which requires a European solution.

name: Angelika MLINAR
text: Writing. With the adoption of the motion for a resolution on the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean, the European Parliament has today taken a position and calls on the Council and the Member States to take action on this matter at long last. Europe's credibility is at stake, because without solidarity, Europe is not Europe. We need a holistic approach to European asylum and migration policy with concrete, workable measures. An important step in this realignment is the strengthening and expansion of the competences of the two main actors EASO and Frontex. We also need to step up the fight against people smuggling, in particular through closer cooperation with the third countries concerned. The 'Mare' team, coordinated by Europol, makes an important contribution to the fight against organised crime, but that alone is not enough. Here too, as in so many other areas of asylum and migration policy, we need the increased commitment of the Member States. Because if we do not take joint responsibility and find a European solution soon, the tragedies of the past few weeks will certainly not be the last.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 In the absence of a common EU immigration policy, the Mediterranean has become the largest mass grave in the world in recent months. Europe must accept the fact that refugees crossing the Mediterranean will continue to travel even if we send warships to the coast of Libya and risk their lives even if Europe reduces the number of ships deployed to rescue them. As one recent survivor put it, "I'd go even if they were running electricity all over the sea." Where there's war, anarchy, extreme poverty, people are fleeing because the instinct to survive is stronger than anything. The EU can continue to watch the Mediterranean become a single feropheric graveyard, or behave like a Nobel Peace Prize-winning and sober superpower: it restores its rescue capacities and gives refugees the opportunity to legally submit their claims. This is what the Hungarian Prime Minister turns his back on when he makes statements that are so morally unacceptable that Europe does not need immigrants. The Hungarian Prime Minister is offended by the memory of the thousands who drowned at sea when, in response to the humanitarian catastrophe, he launches a national consultation on the detention, immediate deportation and work of migrants in order to reimburse the costs of their stay. We must fight not against illegal immigrants, but against the root causes of illegal immigration. It would be good if the Hungarian Prime Minister could see this and not stop his declining popularity by demonising immigrants.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. The numbers are alarming. In the first months of this year alone, 35,000 people made it to the old continent by sea, but more than 2,000 lost their lives. Since 2000 we have been talking about 22,000 people, according to the World Migration Organization. A real humanitarian catastrophe. Last week 6,700 people tried their luck. And we could go on.  In the short term, we must respond to this humanitarian emergency by supporting Member States for operations such as Mare Nostrum and Operation Triton. In the long run, we have to support better regulation in terms of legal immigration. We must fight illegality and punish human traffickers. We must contribute to peace in war-based territories, with a focus on Syria and Libya. The Union with the International Community must defeat the self-styled Islamic State. We should invest more in cooperation and development. Europe must support the good initiatives of the Member States. We cannot leave to your fate countries like Italy, Malta and Greece – we have to be supportive.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The recent tragedies in the Mediterranean linked to mass immigration from Africa have given rise to a vast number of hypocrisy on the part of the European Union. On the one hand, we deplore the tragedies that have occurred and, on the other hand, we promote every possible and conceivable air calls.
