The result of this will be to keep the flow of migrants at a sustained level and thus to cause potential accidents.  Moreover, no consequences have been drawn from the war in Libya, which is at the root of the increase in tragedies. Instead of putting in place a courageous policy as Australia has done, by bringing back to the territories of origin any illegal boat, the "figures" of the Union, such as Jean-Claude Juncker and Martin Schultz call for ever more immigration and ever less generosity for the citizens of European countries.  As this resolution is largely pro-immigration and counterproductive, since it helps to increase the resources used by the Union in the fight against immigration, while amplifying the existing air calls, I have decided to vote against it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean. More than 1,500 people seeking to reach Europe illegally have lost their lives at sea since the beginning of the year. Italy is struggling to cope with this unprecedented wave of migration. The text welcomes the tripling of the resources allocated to the Triton rescue operation. It also calls on the Union to strengthen the fight against smugglers and human traffickers who are the first ones responsible for shipwrecks. I voted on amendments opposing a quota allocation of asylum seekers among Member States because the asylum systems of European countries are saturated. In France, the cost of asylum continues to rise to 2 billion euros per year. In addition, only 1% of rejected applicants are effective for only 1% of rejected applicants. 99% of them therefore maintain themselves illegally and precariously in France or in another Schengen country. It is therefore better to focus on setting up safe reception camps for refugees under the aegis of the United Nations near their countries of origin than to let them risk their lives by a perilous crossing of the Mediterranean at the mercy of smugglers.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 In the last two weeks, more than a thousand migrants have died in Mediterranean waters.  While we welcome the fact that the Member States immediately convened an extraordinary summit, we regret that the measures taken are still largely inadequate. We recall the principles of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities, as laid down in Article 80 TFEC, and we call for new initiatives to be taken in a holistic approach that takes into account all dimensions of the phenomenon, including respect for the rights of migrants and the right of asylum.  We call on all Member States, even those not directly concerned, to respect the principle of non-refoulement, in accordance with international law. We call on the EU to restore the conditions of Mare Nostrum on a European scale, with a search and rescue mandate, with a range of operations beyond 170 miles and the dual purpose of helping migrants and fighting smugglers systematically. We call for an immediate revision of the Dublin III regulation to establish a fair distribution of migrants between all Member States, as well as for the rapid transposition and effective implementation of the Common European Asylum System by all participating States, thereby ensuring common European standards of existing legislation.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Finally, President Juncker admitted that Italy had been left alone and that Operation Mare Nostrum, which saw the contribution of Italy alone, should become a European instrument with funding from all Member States. But the most important point, moreover, is to amend Dublin Three, so that there is a real European redistribution of migrants arriving on Italian shores. For these reasons, I have decided to strongly support this resolution.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I signed and voted on this resolution because, through its text, it reiterates the importance of the concrete involvement of the European Union and the Member States in resolving the most recent tragedies that have taken place in the Mediterranean. The resolution also underlines the equitable sharing of responsibility between Member States, showing solidarity with the countries that are forced to receive the highest number of refugees and asylum seekers.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing. \u2012 The solution to the status quo must be comprehensive, not limited to the Mediterranean region. EU countries must show solidarity with each other. The European Union must actively operate outside its territory in vulnerable countries and in the surrounding countries from where immigrants travel. Moreover, a distinction must be made between refugees fleeing persecution and trying to save their lives and illegal migrants. Union countries must be complicity in resolving the situation, whether financially or by accepting refugees on a voluntary basis. The creation of a cooperative, more voluntary system and the search for the most appropriate form of national involvement can be negotiated at national and EU level.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the bill. The European Union must make a strong diplomatic contribution to the achievement of agreements to alleviate the pressure on refugees in order to reduce the wars and conflicts in europe's immediate neighbourhood, as well as in Europe itself, or Ukraine itself. The contribution must be made to ending the Syrian civil war and the push out of ISIL from the region. As a matter of urgency, agreements must be reached on the establishment of properly equipped refugee camps in a secure area near conflict zones. In addition, a solution to the situation in Libya must be strengthened and FRONTEX strengthened.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that more than a thousand migrants have lost their lives in the last two weeks and that more than 30 000 potential victims in the Mediterranean have died this year, according to estimates by the International Organisation for Migration (IOM), which once again demonstrates the need to do everything possible to save the lives of those in danger and to ensure that Member States comply with their international obligations in the field of rescue at sea. Considering that I express deep sorrow and sorrow at the tragic loss of life in the Mediterranean. Given my membership of a Mediterranean country and my role as a representative of a constituency directly involved in this issue, I can only express my deepest and most sincere concern at the events of recent times. While I welcome the work done by the rapporteurs and the general approach taken to dealing with this issue, I can only express my negative opinion on the way in which some more specific issues are analysed and addressed. For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The only solution to avoid the tragedy of shipwrecks in the Mediterranean is known: it is the strict policy applied by Australia. We can always lament how this country treats migrants, but the European Union does not treat them so much better and causes the death of many more through its incoherent, ineffective and lax policies. The proposed text cannot in any way provide a real solution to the major problem before us and I therefore vote against it, regretting that, by its blindness, the European Union is causing the death of so many unfortunate people.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Wars, political persecution, hunger and the lack of a future are forcing thousands of human beings to leave their homes, their land. They are people who seek protection in our countries and who are treated as hostile enemies to be combated. I voted in favour of this resolution because we can no longer tolerate policies of isolation, policies in which there is a lack of solidarity and in which the responsibility of the Member States is not shared. The European Union must guarantee protection for the persecuted and recognise their right of asylum, which is common throughout Europe and which restores dignity to people who see flight through the waters of the Mediterranean as their only hope of survival. Helping them must be our primary task, a common necessity over and above political differences, as Europe but above all as a Union. It is therefore necessary for all 28 Member States to take responsibility for asylum seekers, while at the moment only 5 deal with 80% of applications. The policy to deal with this emergency must be united and European.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. First of all, I would like to highlight my regret over the new great tragedy – the sinking of the ship on April 19th, 50 nautical miles off the Libyan coast, with hundreds of people looking for a better future in Europe.  It is a significant problem that is not new, but is becoming more serious both in intensity and scale. For example, the UNHCR and the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) estimate that 2014 was the year of the 20th century. 219,000 migrants crossed the Mediterranean, almost four times more than the previous year and as many as ten times more than in 2012.  Therefore, I welcome the agreed measures at the extraordinary session of the European Council. Significantly increasing funding and strengthening triton personnel and technical capacity and stepping up efforts to seize and destroy smuggler vessels should contribute to reducing the volume of irregular migratory flows.  Despite some changes, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and the European Agency for The Management of Operational Cooperation at external borders (Frontex) must also be further financially and operationally strengthened.  Although migratory pressures are most affected countries in southern Europe, the problem of migration is crucial for the entire European Union. This requires both a unified approach based on solidarity and accountability between Member States. Only a common comprehensive migration and asylum policy strategy can establish a quality basis for adequately addressing migratory pressure.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 As a European citizen and as a Sicilian, I am extremely saddened and concerned by recent events in the Mediterranean and the tragic crossings organised by unscrupulous human traffickers that have caused the deaths of thousands of migrants. Europe has behaved in a "pilatesca" way, leaving Italy alone to face a European emergency. But the latest tragedy in the Strait of Sicily has probably awakened consciences. I was very pleased to welcome the extraordinary Council recently convened in Brussels, the tripling of appropriations for Operations Triton and Poseidon and the other initiatives taken. More needs to be done: first of all, to amend Dublin III, in so large part, in which only the port state is given the task of analysing asylum applications, by identifying a mechanism for non-optional 'compulsory quotas' of asylum seekers to be allocated to all Member States and by speeding up return procedures for migrants who do not qualify for it.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Following the recent tragic events off the coast of Libya that resulted in the deaths of 800 migrants and the disappearance of so many, the European Parliament expressed its sadness and regret at the inadequate responses to combat illegal immigration and preserve the lives of these people. I voted in favour of this text and I support the need for a more organised, coordinated and supportive European response. We have to work with the countries of origin as well as transit because the majority of these migrants will not get asylum because they are economic migrants.

name: Emil RADEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on migration because it outlines the main policies of the European Union and the necessary steps that need to be taken as quickly as possible to overcome the migrant and refugee crisis at European borders. In the past few years, Europe, and in particular the Union's external borders such as Bulgaria, Italy, Greece and Malta, have been under unprecedented migratory pressure and a refugee wave. The existing Dublin rules have now proved inadequate to the situation – only a few Member States are obliged to deal with the influx of people, while most are protected from shared responsibility. However, a genuine European response to the migration crisis must be based on solidarity and mutual assistance between Member States. I therefore welcome the inclusion in the EP resolution and last week's Council conclusions of an emergency mechanism for the redistribution of refugees and asylum seekers within the Union. A specific step would be the introduction of a mandatory quota in each country, as the EP insists. This is the first but also the most difficult step towards overhauling the Dublin system. I believe that the positive experience of these measures will not only help countries like Bulgaria, but will also improve the lives of asylum seekers.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. The purpose of this resolution is to respond to recent events in the Mediterranean, with the disappearance of 700 migrants following the sinking of the fishing vessel on which they were travelling, and the European Council Conclusions of 23 April 2015 that followed. Overall, the EU faces the challenge of increasing the proportion of people trying to cross the Mediterranean, exploited by traffickers and human traffickers, to escape the conflict or persecution in Syria, Iraq, Eritrea, Somalia and Libya. The resolution therefore reiterates the need for the EU and Member States to make every possible effort to prevent more lives from being lost at sea by making the necessary resources available to ensure that search and rescue obligations are effectively met. It also calls on the EU to base its response on solidarity and fair division of responsibility by adopting a comprehensive European approach. So, and finally, i agree with the call for closer coordination of EU and Member State policies in the fight against the root causes of migration, I voted in favour.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. Since the tragedy in Lampedusa, the European Parliament has repeatedly reminded us that without a strong European response, this situation will happen again. Yet since the beginning of the year, more than 1,500 migrants and asylum seekers have died in the Mediterranean. In response, MEPs point out that it is necessary for all Member States to participate in the financing of migrant rescue operations at sea. Member States also have a responsibility to take in more refugees and migrants by establishing safe and legal access routes to the European Union. With this text, Parliament defends the implementation of a comprehensive and coherent migration policy, through a European humanitarian visa system and a mandatory resettlement programme. However, I do not agree with imposing a quota for the distribution of refugees. We must not set numerical limits, because the number of refugees is constantly changing, as well as their background, and it cannot be quantified numerically, but has much more ambition.  Finally, this resolution reaffirms the need to strengthen dialogue between the Union and third countries, in particular Libya, with an emphasis on human rights and democracy.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. On 19 April, fleeing conflict and persecution, 800 migrants lost their lives in the sinking of their makeshift boat, which led them to a better world. In the face of this terrible humanitarian tragedy, the European Parliament this afternoon reaffirmed its determination to fight ferociously the smugglers and traffickers, real criminals who exploit human despair as a commercial good.   Unfortunately, this tragic event is only the most important of a growing phenomenon. Since 1 January this year, 24,000 people have reached the Italian coast at risk of their lives, thousands have been rescued at sea and the less fortunate, more than 1,500, have never arrived safely and drowned in the Mediterranean. The emergency today is humanitarian, and the response must be swift and effective.  Of course, the budget for Operation Triton (border surveillance) will be tripled from 2.9 million euros to 9 million euros per month, but to stem this real scourge, Europe will have to propose more concrete actions, such as making Frontex a genuine border protection agency, developing a humanitarian visa system that would not force migrants to rely on criminal networks. , or to put in place a genuine Community asylum policy.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. According to the International Organization for Migration (IOM), more than 1,500 people have died in the Mediterranean Sea since the beginning of this year. An estimated 23,918 migrants have reached the Italian coast since 1 January 2015 and that, according to greek authorities, 10,445 migrants were rescued by the Greek coast guard in the Aegean Sea during the first quarter of 2015. The increase in people trying to cross the Mediterranean to escape conflict or persecution in Syria, Iraq, Eritrea, Somalia and Libya is worrying and is not an exclusive concern of this or that Member State. It should be a concern of the European Union and all its Member States. It's about lives. It is imperative to strengthen and cooperate to prevent more lives from being lost at sea. It is important that the European Union, in coordinated action with the other Member States, make efforts to put an end to this situation.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists congratulate the resolution adopted by Parliament on the humanitarian drama of immigration in the Mediterranean. It has been the horror of the tragedy suffered that has led political groups to adopt a resolution that advances in European positions that had never been given: - the recognition that the abandonment of the Mare Nostrum mission and its replacement by joint operation Triton, with a smaller budget, was a grave mistake;  - the commitment reached by Member States to promote joint operations and increase naval resources with the aim of preventing further deaths at sea; - the consideration of the migration issue in North Africa as an international humanitarian crisis calling for a comprehensive policy, from the pacification and stability of these countries to the fight against mafias, from development cooperation to a common asylum policy that includes the extension of EASO's mandate; - effective implementation of Member States' solidarity to welcome asylum seekers and refugees and integrate them into our countries as a moral, legal and vital duty to our democratic beliefs.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. Less than a week after the EU summit on the Mediterranean migration crisis following the tragedies at sea, the European Parliament adopted a resolution calling for the mandate of Operation Triton, led by the Frontex agency, to be clarified in order to increase its area of operation and to be expanded for search and rescue operations at EU level. The text of the resolution also stresses that Operation Triton will have to resemble a permanent and robust European humanitarian rescue operation that would operate on the high seas and to which all Member States would contribute financially. Member countries should continue to show solidarity and commitment by increasing their contribution to the budgets and operations of Frontex and the European Asylum Support Office. On this point, I also welcome Jean-Claude Juncker's decision to release EUR 120 million for 2015 to allow Triton's endowment to triple and I share his disappointment at the Council's refusal to tackle the problem of illegal immigration. Finally, the resolution calls for more efforts by the 28 on issuing humanitarian visas and strengthening the fight against smugglers and traffickers and criminal sanctions.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. Since the beginning of this year, more than 1,500 people have tragically lost their lives in the Mediterranean Sea, according to data from the International Organization for Migration. In the last 15 years there have been 22,000 deaths, figures that by the end of the year could exceed 30,000. But more than talking about numbers, we talk about people and each of these numbers is a human life that has been lost incomprehensibly, unjustly! The European Union cannot allow the Mediterranean Sea to become an immense, dark graveyard. Urgent action is therefore needed by the EU and our Member States to enable, on the one hand, to provide due humanitarian aid and to provide more substantive financial support for search and rescue operations and, on the other hand, to make all necessary efforts to combat the terrible scourges of trafficking in human beings and criminal networks of 'dowels'. For this reason, I agree with the extension of the mandate of operation Triton beyond 30 nautical miles off the Italian coast and with a European humanitarian rescue operation that is capable of operating on the high seas, obviously with the contribution of all Member States, in logistical and human resources.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 After yet another tragedy in the Mediterranean and the extraordinary European Council devoted to this sensitive issue, the European Parliament had an obligation to intervene and express its thoughts and concerns. The vote in favour of the joint resolution served above all to draw the attention of individual Member States to an issue that everyone agrees on finding a solution to, but there is much disagreement as to how to implement a common policy that avoids the continuous landing of poor people fleeing their territory where essential rights are not guaranteed. The most important request we have made to the Commission is certainly to set a binding quota for the distribution of asylum seekers among all Member States.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against it because the resolution does not strongly condemn the poor results achieved at last Thursday's European Council. It calls for more Europe and missions such as Mare Nostrum that have been shown to attract even more migrants.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. After the tragedy in the Mediterranean last week, the European Union has reacted. The proposal for a Joint Resolution negotiated between the EPP, S&D, ALDE and Verts/ALE has several problems. It calls for strengthening Frontex's activity and funding (including rescue and search operations), focuses on the issue of human trafficking, calls for strengthening cooperation with Libya's neighbouring countries to combat criminal networks, and is unable to make a single criticism of the European Union's structural policy. It does not even criticize triton's limited mandate, which does not operate more than thirty nautical miles off the Italian coast, preventing the provision of assistance to shipwrecks near Libya. It speaks of asylum protection as a voluntary matter. Asylum protection cannot be a voluntary issue. It is an obligation that the EU has assumed through a wide variety of international treaties. When the question of asylum is a voluntary thing, we already know that many countries will not assume it, as is the case in Spain (130 resettlements for the whole year). We abstained.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. We understand that the tragedies and deaths in the Mediterranean are a consequence of the 'Fortress Europe' that has been championed by the European institutions. That is why we voted against this resolution, which seems to us to be an attempt by majority groups to wash away their image. Apart from not recognising direct responsibility for European policies, the text speaks to the need to strengthen cooperation with third countries to combat immigration (which seems like a veiled reference to the establishment of detention centres in the countries of the southern bank of the Mediterranean) and calls on States to step up their contributions to Frontex , an agency that does not have the ransom between its missions, but fights against the entry of people, even though many of these may be asylum recipients. Instead of strengthening these mechanisms, our commitment would be to guarantee humanitarian corridors and visas in countries of origin for those fleeing violence, and to bet on an international policy not based on the bellicoseness or destabilization of third countries, as well as passing regulations that prevent the expoliation of the natural resources of the South.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ MEPs have expressed their deep regret and sorrow at the recurring tragic loss of lives in the Mediterranean. The European Union and the Member States should build on existing cooperation and do everything possible to prevent further loss of life at sea. The EU and the Member States should provide the necessary resources to ensure that search and rescue obligations are effectively fulfilled and therefore properly funded.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – What is happening as a result of the conflict in Syria, Libya and other African states, the fact that hundreds of people are buried in the Mediterranean almost daily, has forced the representatives of the European Council to take urgent action to prevent similar situations. Budget increase is not a panacea and further solutions will need to be sought, in particular, to prevent smuggling organised gangs from making millions from people's misfortune. I consider the adoption of the resolution to be urgent and it is high time to make every effort to save the lives of people in danger and to prevent further loss of life at sea. In addition to the challenges that Frontex will face, I expect measures to be taken to ensure a common European asylum system, and I also expect a review of the overall strategy for cooperation with third countries in order to address the root causes of migration. The situation in the Mediterranean leaves no one indifferent, so I am glad that among the Commission's priorities for 2015 is also the solution to the migrant issue, even though yesterday was too late.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. In 2012, 276,113 migrants entered the EU illegally in 2012, an increase of 138% compared to the same period in 2013. This figure takes into account illegal entry into the EU territory by land, air and sea routes. Most of the migrants, however, have turned to criminal networks of smugglers for transport. Illegal migrant smuggling is a rapidly escalating crime. Combating migrant smuggling has been one of the EU's key objectives for more than a decade and I believe that it must remain at the top of the priorities in the future. The illegal smuggling of migrants through Mediterranean waters has particularly increased in recent years, which is also evident in the increasing number of tragic accidents that end in the loss of innocent lives. In 2014, more than 220,000 migrants reached the EU via maritime routes, an increase of 310% compared to the same period in 2013. The atrocities to which migrants are exposed on boats often put their lives at risk. The EU must not stand idly by and watch innocent people lose their lives. We cannot allow the burden of migrants to fall on the shoulders of only certain Member States. The public should be reminded of the existing pressing issues, which is why I also supported the European Parliament resolution on the Mediterranean emigrant problem, which needs an immediate solution.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean, the Union's immigration and asylum policies because I believe that we must raise our voices urgently. Solidarity is called for in practice. I do not just mean search and rescue, where I am covered by President Juncker's commitments and Commissioner Avramopoulos' excellent work. Only a few Member States face 80% of the pressures of migration flows. "Where are the other partners?" asks citizens in Greece, Malta, Italy. But in other countries, far from the Mediterranean, the question is the same. Already in Poland we have thousands of refugees from Ukraine. It is now imperative that the Dublin Regulation be changed immediately in practice. Burdens should be shared equally in the Member States. It is necessary to establish a binding quota between Member States for the distribution of asylum seekers. Let us start by allowing the suspension of transfers of asylum seekers to Member States facing significant pressures Let us establish a mechanism for the internal relocation of migrants within the EU. I think it's time to get away from words and move from communication to practice. Legislate for real solidarity For real sharing of responsibilities.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to prevent similar tragedies, it is important that the European Union does not only address the consequences of similar tragedies, but also deal with their causes. It is essential to better address development aid and to try to raise living standards in the countries where most refugees and asylum seekers come to the EU. Only in this way will we be able to solve the problems of EU migration and asylum policy systemically.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: in writing. ‒ The latest tragedy in the Mediterranean calls for a renewed focus on the EU’s external and development policies and on building inclusive and effective institutions in countries that are today in complete chaos or ruled by corrupt elites which bring such misery to their citizens that many of them prefer to risk their lives on a boat rather than stay in their oppressed homelands. These desperate people are ready to give their life savings to smugglers and traffickers in order to reach the shores of Europe because they are certain that there is no future for them in their countries, which are torn apart by corruption and violence. I strongly support this resolution, which emphasises that the root causes of violence and underdevelopment need to be addressed in the countries of origin in order to stem the flow of refugees and economic migrants. The resolution also points out that the main priorities of development cooperation with countries of origin should be: significantly enhancing governance structures by building effective and inclusive public institutions; ensuring capacity-building in third-country asylum systems; establishing the rule of law, and fighting endemic corruption at all levels; as well as promoting human rights and further democracy.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution concerning the European Council report on EU migration and asylum policies. It is vital that the EU acts to tackle the appalling tragedies which are ongoing in the Mediterranean.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I supported this proposal governing the area of migration and asylum for refugees from African countries and other parts of the world affected by war. We were particularly shaken by the recent tragedy in the Mediterranean when more than 700 people died trying to reach the European mainland and in seeking a better life, among them many women and children.  I believe that the motto of this debate "Je suis un migrant/I am a refugee" in the City Hall of European Democracy in Strasbourg applies to all of us, given that the immigrant wave in the Mediterranean is a topic that goes beyond party interests, because the tragedies that happen on a daily basis cannot leave anyone indifferent, and we know well that the causes of migration are different from those of an economic nature to trafficking in human beings, but they are mainly due to ethnic conflicts and the emergence of the so-called "Islamic State".  I must stress the need to introduce humanitarian visas and Member States should distribute the 'burden' of refugees evenly in line with the principle of solidarity by adopting quotas based on the population criterion and the economic situation in the Member States.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported today's voted resolution on the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and on the EU's immigration and asylum policy as a whole, even though this resolution calls for the introduction of binding quotas for the distribution of asylum seekers among the member states. I do not support the introduction of binding quotas, I voted against this requirement, but I believe that member parties need to be persuaded to agree on agreements on the distribution of a certain number of refugees in order to help the states that are dealing with this problem on the front line. If not all Member States are involved in solving this problem, the situation with refugees may get out of control and similar problems as Italy will be addressed on their territory by other Member States. I supported the resolution as a whole, inter alia, because it strongly condemns the practices of traffickers and calls for active, uncompromromous action against them.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately the joint resolution moves to the logic of administrative measures and most responsibilities (under the cloak of rescue) in FRONTEX. It also does not mention the main reasons why migrants are forced to seek their fate elsewhere, i.e. the imposed economic policies and interventions and instability in their countries. What is needed now is immediate measures to address the current situation, measures based on international law, solidarity, human rights and human dignity. We urgently need a different approach to migration to stop refugees being treated as criminals. That is why we voted against the joint resolution.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report, although it contains correct findings, unfortunately moves to avoid the real problem. Policies to tackle illegal immigration are not being sought, no solutions are being proposed to the problem of trafficking ring action and there is nothing but wishful talk of a change in the situation of the countries of origin of migrants when, especially in Libya, the problem began with EU intervention.

name: József SZÁJER
text: Writing. \u2012 When the position of the Hungarian Fidesz-KDNP delegation differs from that of the People's Party, in order not to be contradicted because of my obligation as Vice-President, in cases where the parliamentary group votes differently from the Hungarian members in the roll call vote, I do not directly participate in the vote. In other words, I will not press the voting button, but I will put my hand on the voting position previously decided jointly by the PP group.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The issue of immigration should be dealt with not only in the context of the current consequences, but also in the future effects to be expected not only in Europe, but also in the areas from which the population emigrates. And that's the consequences that will occur in a few decades. There is no doubt that the admission of hundreds of thousands of people from other cultural, religious and linguistic backgrounds to european countries every year will have a huge impact on socio-economic relations in Europe. Worse still, a significant exodus of active people from the affected areas can lead to long-term development problems and major changes in the social structure of these countries. This can be used by extreme environments, terrorists and dictatorial governments to pursue uncompromising policies, not only for their own communities and peoples, but also for third countries, including European ones.  The Union should therefore not only pursue a humanitarian policy towards refugees, but above all be active also in the centres of exile themselves. It is therefore necessary to combat not only the effects of immigration, but also its causes. For these reasons, I abstained from voting on a resolution which made no reference to the Union's strategy to address the causes of the mass influx of people from African and Middle Eastern countries to Europe.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is a land of hope for millions of people around the world. The European Parliament must take a greater role in defining the European Strategy on Migration. In this respect, I believe that we must impose a more active approach in the European legislature, which will lead to real changes both in the causes of the phenomenon of illegal migration and in the effects that shock the international community. Solidarity can stop the tragic events that have unfortunately been repeated for too long in the Mediterranean. The protection of refugees, as well as the inclusion of the northern African states in EU government aid and assistance plans, must now become a priority, until we again end up witnessing, once again, helpless, other maritime tragedies that lead to enormous loss of life.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Europe is fighting for a banking union and an economic union. It is also time for her to think of a humanitarian union. It is essential that the European Union responds to the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean on the basis of the principle of solidarity and equitable sharing of responsibilities, in accordance with Article 80 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, as well as on a comprehensive European approach.  It is also important that it increases the equitable sharing of responsibilities and solidarity with the Member States that receive the largest number of refugees and asylum seekers, both in absolute and relative terms.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Migration is a significant challenge for Europe, which can efficiently be met only over time, with well-focused effort, imagination and solidarity. Nobody can disagree that we need measures to address the unbearable humanitarian situation in the Mediterranean Sea. Notwithstanding this, there is an absolute necessity for further complex measures against illegal immigration. This is also the expectation of European citizens. For these reasons I voted against this resolution, which is too narrow, lacks complex measures and goes beyond the Council conclusions In particular, I am strongly opposed to a quota system for asylum seekers. While quotas are unacceptable, I am advocating better and closer harmonisation and coordination of the different national systems. It is through greater coordination between Member States, supported by the Union, that our asylum system in the EU will improve, and through combating illegal trafficking that we will achieve better results. We will achieve no improvement through administrative measures which are easy to overcome.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution which includes a number of important statements and recommendations. I also believe that the current asylum system in the EU is inadequate and the Union needs a distribution of asylum seekers among all 28 Member States. This distribution should be based on the principle of solidarity. No references to specific historical experience or to the number of residing immigrants can be used as an excuse for a preferential treatment at the EU level.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. After the tragedy in the Mediterranean last week, the European Union has reacted. The proposal for a Joint Resolution negotiated between the EPP, S&D, ALDE and Verts/ALE has several problems. It calls for strengthening Frontex's activity and funding (including rescue and search operations), focuses on the issue of human trafficking, calls for strengthening cooperation with Libya's neighbouring countries to combat criminal networks, and is unable to make a single criticism of the European Union's structural policy. It does not even criticize triton's limited mandate, which does not operate more than thirty nautical miles off the Italian coast, preventing the provision of assistance to shipwrecks near Libya. It speaks of asylum protection as a voluntary matter. Asylum protection cannot be a voluntary issue. It is an obligation that the EU has assumed through a wide variety of international treaties. When the question of asylum is a voluntary thing, we already know that many countries will not assume it, as is the case in Spain (130 resettlements for the whole year). We abstained.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: Writing. \u2012 I am unequivocally opposed to the introduction of mandatory quotas for the redistribution of refugees. This is not the solution to the problem, the EU must focus primarily on combating illegal people smuggling and aid directly in the regions where the biggest wave of migration is flowing.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ We cannot continue pretending that nothing is happening when there are people who die in the Mediterranean due to wars, conflicts and abuse mafias who traffic people desperate to flee their country in search of a better life. We, the European institutions and Member States, need to find a permanent solution and improve cooperation with the countries of origin. We must also deal in a very clear and firm way against the mafias and prevent more deaths in the Mediterranean Sea.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This report is to be rejected because it encourages immigration in several ways and does not propose any solution deterring smugglers and therefore potential candidates for immigration. The events of the last few days are in the measure of the human drama that this immigration represents. But the solution is not in the organization of these artisanal gateways between the African and European continents but in deterrence. The report calls for this immigration to be 'facilitated', for the EU to set up migrant quotas by country, for asylum applications (of all types) to be quickly reviewed and for the granting of residence permits to be facilitated, regrets the lack of solidarity, even removes the reference to the fight against smugglers. The report even states that immigration would not be illegal if it were legalized. Incredible.  I vote absolutely and resolutely AGAINST.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. After the tragedy in the Mediterranean last week, the European Union has reacted. The proposal for a Joint Resolution negotiated between the EPP, S&D, ALDE and Verts/ALE has several problems. It calls for strengthening Frontex's activity and funding (including rescue and search operations), focuses on the issue of human trafficking, calls for strengthening cooperation with Libya's neighbouring countries to combat criminal networks, and is unable to make a single criticism of the European Union's structural policy. It does not even criticize triton's limited mandate, which does not operate more than thirty nautical miles off the Italian coast, preventing the provision of assistance to shipwrecks near Libya. It speaks of asylum protection as a voluntary matter. Asylum protection cannot be a voluntary issue. It is an obligation that the EU has assumed through a wide variety of international treaties. When the question of asylum is a voluntary thing, we already know that many countries will not assume it, as is the case in Spain (130 resettlements for the whole year). We abstained.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. In 2012 The Spanish Socialists congratulate the resolution adopted by Parliament on the humanitarian drama of immigration in the Mediterranean. It has been the horror of the tragedy suffered that has led political groups to adopt a resolution that advances in European positions that had never been given: - the recognition that the abandonment of the Mare Nostrum mission and its replacement by joint operation Triton, with a smaller budget, was a grave mistake;  - the commitment reached by Member States to promote joint operations and increase naval resources with the aim of preventing further deaths at sea; - the consideration of the migration issue in North Africa as an international humanitarian crisis calling for a comprehensive policy, from the pacification and stability of these countries to the fight against mafias, from development cooperation to a common asylum policy that includes the extension of EASO's mandate; - effective implementation of Member States' solidarity to welcome asylum seekers and refugees and integrate them into our countries as a moral, legal and vital duty to our democratic beliefs.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. Although the joint motion for a resolution did not strongly criticise the conclusions on immigration of the extraordinary European Council, I voted in favour because it outlines a direction that I can support towards the necessary actions to be taken at this delicate stage.  I would like to express my disappointment at the response given to the ongoing humanitarian crisis in the Mediterranean by the European Commission and the Member States, which have not envisaged adequate action to prevent deaths at sea. The lack of legal access routes to the EU has also helped to support the criminal networks of human traffickers: it is not enough to establish the strictest possible criminal sanctions, but we need a comprehensive EU approach to migration that also looks at the roots of its causes.  The Member States must be the protagonists of actions based on the principle of shared solidarity, as well as a fair distribution of their responsibilities in the management of flows, by setting a binding quota for the distribution of asylum seekers among all the States of the Union. I therefore hope that every effort will be made to prevent further loss of life at sea and that tragic events such as those that have taken place recently will no longer take place.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. We understand that the tragedies and deaths in the Mediterranean are a consequence of the 'Fortress Europe' that has been championed by the European institutions. That is why we voted against this resolution, which seems to us to be an attempt by majority groups to wash away their image. Apart from not recognising direct responsibility for European policies, the text speaks to the need to strengthen cooperation with third countries to combat immigration (which seems like a veiled reference to the establishment of detention centres in the countries of the southern bank of the Mediterranean) and calls on States to step up their contributions to Frontex , an agency that does not have the ransom between its missions, but fights against the entry of people, even though many of these may be asylum recipients. Instead of strengthening these mechanisms, our commitment would be to guarantee humanitarian corridors and visas in countries of origin for those fleeing violence, and to bet on an international policy not based on the bellicoseness or destabilization of third countries, as well as passing regulations that prevent the expoliation of the natural resources of the South.

name: Johannes Cornelis van BAALEN
text: Written. – The VVD fully recognises the humanitarian drama unfolding in the Mediterranean. All drowning people must be saved. However, the VVD is not convinced that the measures proposed in the resolution can limit or prevent such tragedies in the future. For example, there is no focus on the reception of refugees in the region and no measures are proposed to prevent the departure of refugees from the Libyan coast to the EU. The VVD considers the granting of humanitarian visas at EU embassies to be incorrect given the sucking effect, and opposes the imposition of refugee quotas on Member States from Brussels.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Written. The drowning deaths of so many refugees and migrants in recent weeks and months have been appalling. Europe cannot let this happen. I am in favour of a substantial financial, operational and territorial expansion of Triton, with contributions from all member states and the European Commission. I am also in favour of greater cooperation between Member States and EU agencies and a partial extension of the responsibilities of these agencies. At the same time, the situation in the source countries needs to be improved and the reception in the region improved, for example with winter and summer fixed tents. Member States can also resettle more refugees now residing in UN camps in the region. Crucially, it is also to tackle the criminal people smugglers, including through legal proceedings, financial and other sanctions, and to confiscate and destroy their resources. As regards the granting of humanitarian visas, Member States themselves should be able to weigh up when they do or do not do so. With regard to the necessary partial redistribution of asylum seekers among the Member States, the Council should take the lead, not the Commission.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it calls for the rapid and full transposition and effective implementation of the Common European Asylum System by all participating Member States, thereby ensuring common European standards under existing legislation.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. On 19 April this year, some 800 people lost their lives fleeing persecution and conflict in their homeland. They died in the Mediterranean in search of a more dignified existence they hoped to find in Europe. That hope is being exploited by people smugglers who are pursuing criminal practices to make money on the backs of these people's misery. 24 000 such refugees have already arrived on Italian beaches this year. The European Parliament has loudly agreed to declare war on these people smugglers. We agree to a tripling of Triton's resources, but that is not - I fear - enough to deal with this flow of refugees. We must focus on the causes of this migration rather than just on the migration itself.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The tragedies continue in the Mediterranean and it took 700 deaths in a single shipwreck to finally provoke an extraordinary meeting of the Council.  Unfortunately, he had only an extraordinary name and NGOs denounced a Council of Shame. In the face of so much cynicism, the GUE/NGL asked the highest representatives of these two institutions, Mr Donald Tusk and Mr Jean Claude Juncker, to come and explain themselves to the European Parliament.  The resolution adopted is a good move, although it is still insufficient.  Yes, there is an urgent need to set up a European rescue operation at sea, to activate the Temporary Protection Directive, to implement resettlement programmes for refugees.  The resolution also calls for every way possible to identify the dead and missing. An amendment by the GUE NGL was adopted removing all Parliament's support for the faster return mechanisms proposed by the Council. However, Parliament has lacked ambition to propose real solutions such as the establishment of legal channels. So I abstained.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. In the last two weeks, more than a thousand migrants have died, meaning more than 30,000 potential deaths in the Mediterranean Sea over the course of this year, according to estimates by the International Organisation for Migration, which underlines once again the need to do everything possible to save lives in danger and the need for Member States to respect their international maritime rescue obligations. In this completely hypocritical speech of the European Union, the blatant responsibilities of EU states in the disaggregation of vast regions of North Africa are unabashedly omitted, with large-scale armed interventions such as Iraq, Libya and Syria just to name the latest examples. Moreover, the capitalist powers, through their multinational companies, continue to foment corruption, thus maintaining their privileges and the immense summing up of the riches of these countries, whose development has been delayed for too long, and feeding an increasing flow of emigration.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Writing. I have chosen not to report on the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the EU's migration and asylum policy, as I do not consider the whole report as a whole to be useful. Among other things, I cannot support the call for a binding quota, which is set by the Commission, for the distribution of asylum seekers among the Member States, but also the pointless financing of resettlement programmes and the uncontrolled mass reception of refugees.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the recent tragedies in the Mediterranean and the EU's policies on migration and asylum. The EU should do everything possible to prevent the loss of other lives at sea. It is not possible for some Member States, such as Greece, to face this enormous humanitarian problem on their own. It is regrettable that the European Council of 23 April did not undertake to create a pan-European binding solidarity mechanism. The European Commission should establish as soon as possible a "binding quota" for the distribution of asylum seekers among all EU countries, on the basis of objective criteria. The problem is European and a European solution is urgently needed.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Since 2000 at least 22 400 people have lost their lives in the Mediterranean in an attempt to reach Europe, turning the Mediterranean into the world's deadliest sea for migrants. Operation Mare Nostrum and the joint Operation Triton have proved to be unsuccessful, which shows that everything possible must be done to save the lives of those in danger and that it is also necessary for The Member States to respect their international obligations in the field of sea rescue.  A coordinated approach is more necessary than ever in order to find a European solution based not only on solidarity, but also on the fair distribution of responsibility and on a global approach that also has a positive impact on internal security. I do not think that the extraordinary European Council of 23 April has produced satisfactory results, and I fear that once again countries will be left alone to deal with migratory flows that they are unable to manage.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 While thousands of lives are lost in the Mediterranean, in the mass exodus of countries from Africa and the Middle East, fleeing war, hunger and extreme poverty, the European Council, in an act of media folklore, beyond finding effective solutions, deepens the communitisation of its immigration policy and the European neighbourhood policy, now ratified in the EP by its right-wing majority.  Today, the majority of the EP has strengthened these policies of aggression, interference and support and funding for the destabilisation of the countries of those regions, promoting war and extremist movements, resulting in these migration flows. We condemn the eu's repressive and criminalised treatment of refugees by denying adequate integration policies and strengthening the vision of a 'Fortress' Europe, closed to migration flows, helping to keep human trafficking networks operating in the region. We condemn the Measures of the European Council which, by not solving the problem, perpetuate interference and aggression in African and Middle Eastern countries and strengthen the European militarisation process, with guidelines expressed to the High Representative to move immediately towards intervention in the framework of European security and defence policy. We voted against it.

name: Milan ZVER
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the recent tragic events in the Mediterranean and the EU's migration and asylum policy, because this resolution can contribute to preventing many further deaths in the Mediterranean. In one tragic event, around 700 migrants died recently and about 400 in the other. The Union must respond to these events as a whole, and all Member States must show solidarity with those most burdened with migration, such as Italy, where some 24 000 migrants have arrived in recent months, and Greece, where around 10 000 migrants have arrived in that time. We need to strengthen Frontex, EASO, Europol and Eurojust and increase their effectiveness, and above all, the fight against traffickers must become much more effective.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, in view of the present proposal, on which I voted in favour, I would like to justify my vote. My vote was motivated by support for the access of the Countries of the Western Balkans to the EU market. These are, in fact, unlimited duty-free approaches that are one-sided and autonomous. This was mainly about prolonging this situation until 2020, but at the same time, and I think it is essential that the EU can reduce this declaration of support in the event of systematic and serious violations of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. I consider this to be very important, because it is an opportunity to deny these advantages, which have been established in favour of these countries, if they violate EU values, which I consider to be truly not sacred, but certainly worthy of protection.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted against the amendments to the suspension of the exceptional trade measures applied to Bosnia and Herzegovina on the view that Bosnia deserves special treatment in trade terms following the EU's enlargement to Croatia, which has significantly damaged the Bosnian economy. In addition, the amendments adopted delve into the line of EU policy towards candidate countries and potential candidates, reproducing a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet made the adjustment to the Interim Agreement, which became necessary after Croatia's accession to the EU on 1 June 2013. For this reason, the EU wants to suspend the automatic renewal of autonomous trade agreements with Bosnia and Herzegovina. If the adjustment is made, the EU will reintroduce the preferential tariff quotas for Bosnia and Herzegovina. I welcome this measure and hope for an early agreement, which is accepted by both sides.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to call on Bosnia and Herzegovina to adapt the Interim Agreement to preferential trade with Croatia after the latter joined the European Union on 1 July 2013, and also to call on the parties to the agreement to take into account mutual interests in order to reach an agreement acceptable to EU Member States and members of the Central European Free Trade Agreement. I agree that the EU should confirm its firm commitment to further integration into the EU of countries covered by this Regulation by granting unilateral trade preferences. Trade preferences are the most effective means of ensuring the stability of the region and an incentive to implement political, social and economic reforms as soon as possible.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. The EU introduced exceptional trade measures for Balkan countries in 2009 through Regulation 1215/2009. This regulation applies until 31/12/2015. Since then, association agreements have been signed with all countries except Bosnia and Herzegovina and "Kosovo", whose self-proclaimed independence is not recognised by five EU member states. Following Croatia's accession to the EU, there is a problem with the calculation of quotas set out in Regulation 1215/2009, a problem related to the ill will of Bosnia and Herzegovina. This text calls on Bosnia and Herzegovina to play the game and respect its commitments.  Otherwise, Bosnia and Herzegovina's preferential trade measures will be suspended from 1 January 2016. It should come as no surprise, then, that I voted in favour of this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal aims to put an end to an exceptional trade regime that was put in place in favour of Bosnia and Herzegovina when Croatia was not yet a member of the Union. However, since Croatia's accession, Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet agreed to adapt the trade regime granted to it under the interim trade and trade agreement with the EU. If no agreement is reached on this issue by the end of the year, preferences for Bosnia and Herzegovina could be suspended from 1 January 2016.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The European Union and Bosnia and Herzegovina have been invited to reach an agreement on the adaptation of the interim agreement with the EU, following Croatia's accession, in order to avoid the suspension of preferences for Bosnia and Herzegovina on 1 January 2016. The report considered it necessary to recall the steady progress made by the countries and territories concerned in the Western Balkans towards eu membership, as well as the Union's unequivocal commitment to the European perspective of Bosnia and Herzegovina, as recalled in the conclusions of the General Affairs Council of 15 December 2014. Since Croatia's accession to the Union, there has been a problem in calculating the quotas set out in Regulation 1215/2009, a problem linked to the ill will of Bosnia and Herzegovina. This text calls on Bosnia and Herzegovina to play the game and respect its commitments. Otherwise, preferential trade measures in favour of that country will be suspended from 1 January 2016. I voted against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I remain critical of the Stabilisation and Association Agreements negotiated by the Commission with Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is why I voted against this measure.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report amending Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009 on exceptional trade measures for Balkan countries. The implementation period of the Regulation is extended until 2020 to extend exceptional trade measures to that date, thus giving the countries of the Western Balkans and the EU sufficient time to adapt the preferences granted under the Regulation to those provided for under the different ratified Stabilisation and Association Agreements. In addition, it is planned to suspend the preferences granted to Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1 January 2016 if Bosnia and Herzegovina fails to reach an agreement with the EU on the adaptation of trade concessions under the interim agreement to take account of Croatia's accession to the EU. Finally, it is worth noting the introduction of a clause in the Regulation in order to be able to temporarily suspend the granting of exceptional trade measures in the event of a serious and systematic violation of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. On a socialist proposal, a serious and systematic violation of labour rights was also included as a cause of suspension of preferences.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. - I supported the proposed report. Economic cooperation with countries that are in the process of pre-accession negotiations for entry into the EU or are still preparing for them is of paramount importance to these countries. Bosnia and Herzegovina is in an unenviable economic situation, making the willingness to cooperate economically and create an attractive business environment all the more important. The EU is very much in favour of opening up markets with BiH, as it wants to help the country and steer it on a more optimistic path. BiH needs this, especially after last year's catastrophic floods that destroyed much of the basic infrastructure. I support this path, as many unemployed young people in BiH need to be given a brighter future. Unlike the one that's showing up today. Opening up markets, mutual cooperation and contact with the European cultural space will help most to reform the country and the citizens themselves and help in their perspective.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I would like to take this opportunity to point out that Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet adapted its acts arising from CEFTA to the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the EU. According to the data at my disposal, Croatia has lost over 220m euros since joining the Union. I support the measures in this report, as I believe that the Commission must protect the interests of its Member State, which suffers direct damage as a result of BiH's failure to meet its international obligations.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. I do not agree with the objective of allowing Bosnia into the EU and, above all, I am critical of the many negative aspects that any accession of that country will entail: immigration, trafficking in human beings, religious fundamentalism are just some of the implications that the resolution does not properly cover.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the report, I particularly welcome the amendments to delegated acts relating to trade measures involving the inclusion of a clause in favour of the protection of human rights. I also agree with the suspension of trade agreements with Bosnia and Herzegovina in the absence of its alignment with the method used by the EU to adapt the interim agreement linking it to the EU.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which provides for the suspension of the exceptional trade measures for which Bosnia and Herzegovina is benefiting. Of course, I am personally associated with the difficulties currently facing the peoples of Bosnia - I am thinking particularly of the Serbs - after the tragic floods which have the macabre toll of 90,000 displaced persons, 75,000 affected households and 25 victims. Unfortunately, this tragic human toll cannot and must not overshadow the behaviour of the Government of Bosnia and Herzegovina following Croatia's accession to the EU: if Bosnia wants to play the European game, it must accept the rules and respect its commitments. However, since Croatia's accession, the ill will of the authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina has led to a problem of calculating quotas, which were set by Regulation 1215/2009, which introduced exceptional trade measures. For this reason, parliamentarians are calling for its commitments to be respected, or preferential trade measures will be suspended on 1 January 2016.

name: Salvatore CICU
text: in writing. \u2012 The liberalisation of trade between the EU and the countries of the Western Balkans is ensured through a series of Stabilisation and Association Agreements (SAP) and an Interim Agreement (AI) in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Bosnia and Herzegovina, like the Balkan region as a whole, benefits from autonomous trade measures (ATMs). However, following Croatia's accession to the European Union on 1 July 2013, Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet agreed to adapt the Interim Agreement in order to take account of traditional preferential trade between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina under the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA), which linked the two countries before 1 July 2013. After three rounds of negotiations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, no agreement could be reached. In the light of this stalemate, the Commission proposes that the extension of the autonomous trade measures for Bosnia and Herzegovina should not be automatic but conditional on acceptance of the method used by the Union for the adaptation of the Interim Agreement. Once Bosnia and Herzegovina and the EU have provisionally agreed, signed and implemented an agreement on the adjustment of trade concessions, preferences for Bosnia and Herzegovina will be re-established. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the proposed amendments to the text amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009 on exceptional trade measures applicable to countries and territories participating in or linked to the Stabilisation and Association Process of the European Union and suspending its application with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina. I disagree with the amendments introduced on a GUE proposal which amend the text as it came out in the Commission. I agree with the decision to postpone the adoption of the text and to entrust it to a rapporteur in order to discuss its content again with the Council and the Commission. I trust in the work that the rapporteur responsible will be able to complete and in the success of the negotiations in the trialogue.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I believe it is important to encourage the introduction of trade measures that can facilitate trade between the EU and the Balkan countries, in fact, this allows unrestricted access to the EU market free of duties for most products. I welcome the tariff liberalisations provided for in the free trade agreements, as well as the Commission's proposal to extend the autonomous trade measures for Bosnia and Herzegovina subject to the country's acceptance of the method used by the EU for the adaptation of the Interim Agreement.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted against the amendments to the suspension of the exceptional trade measures applied to Bosnia and Herzegovina on the view that Bosnia deserves special treatment in trade terms following the EU's enlargement to Croatia, which has significantly damaged the Bosnian economy. In addition, the amendments adopted delve into the line of EU policy towards candidate countries and potential candidates, reproducing a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ For my group it was imperative that the vote would be postponed on the legislative resolution so that the discussions would enter into trilogues during the first reading. I am also in favour of granting trade preferences to Western Balkan countries to support their socio-economic development and underpin their European trajectory.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on exceptional trade measures applicable to countries and territories participating in or linked to the Stabilisation and Association Process of the European Union and suspending its application with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina. It is a proposal that I consider to be politically very important because of the European Union's commitment to a genuine recovery of the economies of all the countries of the Western Balkans, to which the unilateral regime of trade preferences is extended until 2020, and towards a more general political stability in the region.  Furthermore, the proposal for a regulation introduces the parameter of respect for human rights as a fundamental requirement for the granting of trade preferences. In this respect, I consider the decision to use the instrument of delegated acts to be very appropriate for the possible suspension of preferences, so that greater democratic control can be made possible on such sensitive political issues. With regard to the suspension of exceptional trade measures for Bosnia and Herzegovina, given the European Union's repeated and unequivocal support for Bosnia and Herzegovina, I hope that an appropriate solution will be found for the adaptation of the interim agreement to Croatia's accession to the European Union, avoiding possible damage to European commercial interests.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this report as it contains several crucial points and decisions of the European Parliament. First of all, the adoption of the report introduces the so-called "no-fly zone". a "human rights clause" in the Regulation on autonomous trade measures, which gives western Balkan countries preferential, unlimited and duty-free access to the EU market. The new clause allows for the suspension of preferences in the event of a serious and systematic violation of the fundamental principles of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. Secondly, the report proposes to suspend exceptional trade measures with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina because, since Croatia has been adopted in the EU, the country has not brought its legislation into line with European law, leading to an imbalance in trade and furthering the EU. Thirdly, the report proposes to replace implementing acts by giving the European Parliament greater competence. This means that in the event of violations of the human rights clause, the European Parliament will have the power to suspend the trade preferences of the country concerned.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because Bosnia and Herzegovina does not meet basic conditions of a rule of law and therefore cannot be mentioned for its accession. There is no serious effort to develop good neighbourly relations, nor is there respect for the fundamental principles of democracy. It is not a member of the Central European Free Trade Agreement and does not respect traditional EU trade.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The fundamental objective of the proposed amendments is to confirm the EU's real and deep commitment to the future of European integration in the countries and territories covered by this Regulation by granting unilateral trade preferences. From this perspective, such concessions, or their possible suspension, should be accepted as an impetus to accelerate the transition from the political and socio-economic reforms highlighted in the 'Pact for Growth', which are indispensable for the western Balkan countries' compliance with the Copenhagen criteria and the acquis communautaire.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The Stabilisation and Association Agreements with the western Balkan countries are generally preceded by asymmetric trade liberalisation. Asymmetric trade liberalisation is provided by Council Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009, which adopts exceptional trade measures in favour of countries and territories participating in or linked to the stabilisation and association process. This Regulation applies until 31 December 2015. The amendments to this Regulation relate to the following objectives: - extension of the period of application of the Regulation until 31 December 2020, - introduction of the human rights clause , - possible suspension of autonomous trade measures to Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1 January 2016 because it has not agreed to adapt the trade concessions granted under the Interim Agreement in order to take account of traditional preferential trade between Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina under the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA). Furthermore, given that the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Kosovo was initialled in July 2014, this Regulation will also cover Kosovo.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The intention of extending the current preferences until the end of 2020 in the area of trade between the European Union and the Countries of the Western Balkans is intended to give the beneficiary countries more time to reconcile preferences, both under the basic regulation and under the regimes of the Stabilisation and Association Agreements. At the same time, the proposal in question also introduces a human rights clause, which makes it possible to suspend preferences in the event of serious and systemic violations of fundamental human rights principles by a beneficiary country.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the agreement covered by the Stabilisation and Association Agreements negotiated by the European Commission.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because Bosnia and Herzegovina does not meet basic conditions of a rule of law and is therefore far from joining. No serious effort is being made to develop good neighbourly relations and the fundamental principles of democracy are not respected. It is not a member of the Central European Free Trade Agreement and does not respect the traditional terms of trade within the EU.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the fact that, through this report, the S&D Group has taken the lead on granting trade preferences to Western Balkan countries to support their socioeconomic development and underpin their European trajectory. While it is true that the trade between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina covered tariff lines not previously included in the Interim Agreement, the inclusion in the adapted agreement would come with quotas set at the limit of the amount of traditional trade with Croatia. Another reason why I voted in favour is that the proposal includes human rights as a conditionality in the autonomous trade measures, something which has been a key demand from the S&D Group in the past. In the human rights clause we succeeded in defending a reference to core labour rights.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. Trade between the EU and the countries of the Western Balkans is liberalized through a series of Stabilisation and Association Agreements and an interim agreement in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Following Croatia's accession to the EU, Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet agreed to adapt the interim agreement to take account of its traditional preferential trade with Croatia under the Central European Free Trade Agreement, which linked the two countries since before 1 July 2013. After three rounds of negotiations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, it has not been possible to reach an agreement. Given that the negotiations have reached this deadlock and the damage to the EU's commercial interests, the Commission proposes that the extension of autonomous trade measures for Bosnia and Herzegovina should not be automatic, but depends on the EU's acceptance of the EU methodology for the adaptation of the interim agreement.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it, since it provides for the suspension of trade preferences (applicable in eight months) for access to the European market for products coming from Bosnia. These are very sensitive agricultural products for Bosnia. Bosnia's economy is on the ground. Bosnia chronically suffers from a large trade deficit and is under the IMF's agenda. Unemployment, and in particular youth unemployment, reaches outrageous rates. Exactly a year ago, Bosnia experienced its most violent social discontent since the war of the 1990s, and this is due to the economic situation. Most of these problems — for which the EU is also responsible — are due to the post-war constitutional configuration. Other Balkan countries have accepted the 'technical adaptation' of their Stabilisation and Association Agreement, but we must not forget that Bosnia is not like any other Balkan country and that its prospect of accession is also long-term, unlike other Balkan countries. We believe that three rounds of negotiations are not enough. We believe that, in this case, a more flexible solution can be found that is not based on traditional trade.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution. However, I am embarrassed to note that Bosnia and Herzegovina is showing such a slow process of progress.
