Internal peripherys, unfortunately, also do not contribute to the necessary strategies necessary to implement and absorb the preparation financial instruments. Political instability hampers the ability of the country and its citizens to make the long-term commitments necessary to make use of the EU's socio-economic instruments. In addition, the country must ensure the fundamental principles of human rights, democracy and the rule of law.

name: Anja HAZEKAMP
text: Written. \u2012 The European Union has in the past granted Bosnia and Herzegovina trade advantages in order to be able to export cheaply to the EU. The European Commission is now proposing to allow these trade benefits to be suspended if Bosnia and Herzegovina is guilty of violations of the fundamental principles of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. It is a good thing that Europe is favouring these human rights on commercial interests. At the same time, the proposal calls for Bosnia and Herzegovina to join the EU. Enlargement of the European Union is unwise, as long as it does not function democratically. The Party for Animals is opposed to the accession of new Member States in the current circumstances and cannot therefore accept the Commission's proposal. In order not to block the observing of human rights, the vote was abstained.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it, since it provides for the suspension of trade preferences (applicable in eight months) for access to the European market for products coming from Bosnia. These are very sensitive agricultural products for Bosnia. Bosnia's economy is on the ground. Bosnia chronically suffers from a large trade deficit and is under the IMF's agenda. Unemployment, and in particular youth unemployment, reaches outrageous rates. Exactly a year ago, Bosnia experienced its most violent social discontent since the war of the 1990s, and this is due to the economic situation. Most of these problems — for which the EU is also responsible — are due to the post-war constitutional configuration. Other Balkan countries have accepted the 'technical adaptation' of their Stabilisation and Association Agreement, but we must not forget that Bosnia is not like any other Balkan country and that its prospect of accession is also long-term, unlike other Balkan countries. We believe that three rounds of negotiations are not enough. We believe that, in this case, a more flexible solution can be found that is not based on traditional trade.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of deferring the vote so that an agreement can be reached in the tripartite dialogue.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Suspension of Extraordinary Trade Measures regarding Bosnia and Herzegovina regardless of what is more about the technical issue for some than intrinsically, it is nevertheless important for the Republic of Croatia and our neighbour Bosnia and Herzegovina and I want to explain my vote for. It is essential that the European Commission conducts a coherent policy towards the Countries of the Western Balkans, including in the case of trade measures. After the accession of the Republic of Croatia to the European Union, its membership in CEFTA ceased and it stands to reason that this new situation should also be legally sanctioned when it comes to other countries.  We expect that Bosnia and Herzegovina will recognize its interest and that the preference system will continue until 2020, not terminated as early as 01. 01. 2015.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. The report presented to the European Parliament proposes to suspend the exceptional trade measures granted to Bosnia and Herzegovina in the event of a breach of commitments.  Croatia's accession to the European Union has led to a change in the calculation of quotas, changes which Bosnia and Herzegovina has not clearly complied with. It appears that cooperation between administration is a pillar of good understanding and respect for the association agreements concluded between the Union and Bosnia and Herzegovina. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the amendments tabled in plenary, which reaffirmed these requirements.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. – I support this report which urges Bosnia and Herzegovina to adapt the Interim Agreement to preferential trade with Croatia. The prolongation of Autonomous Trade Measures (ATMs) should not be automatic but should be dependent on acceptance of the EU methodology. At the moment, all Western Balkan countries – the members of the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA) – with the exception of Bosnia and Herzegovina have concluded negotiations to amend their agreements with the EU to apply the new rules. I hope, therefore, that more work will be done so that Bosnia and Herzegovina and the EU can conclude and sign an agreement with which trade preference will be re-established.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ We welcome these proposed reforms to the  HYPERLINK "http://ec.europa.eu/enlargement/policy/glossary/terms/saa_en.htm" Stabilisation and Association Agreements and the Interim Agreement in the Western Balkans region. The extension of Autonomous Trade Measures (ATMs) will continue to offer economic and political support to the Western Balkan countries, while including a key human rights clause, of which labour rights conditionality forms part, attached to the trade measures. The S&D Group has been at the forefront in demanding this. We also support proposals to allow Parliament a greater role in scrutiny of the Western Balkan countries’ compliance with the human rights clause, and in ATM suspension if necessary. It is hoped that Bosnia and Herzegovina will be able to acknowledge the accession of Croatia to the EU, so as to avoid ATM suspension, and we urge the Commission to maintain dialogue on this issue. In the long term, however, we cannot support any third country discriminating against EU Member States, and the ability to use the suspension clause is necessary.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Vote for. In 2009, the European Union introduced exceptional trade measures for Balkan countries through Regulation 1215/2009, which apply until 31/12/2015. But Bosnia and Herzegovina is showing ill will in relation to the rules to be applied in accordance with these regulations. This is not tolerable as it is a preferential agreement. This text therefore calls on Bosnia and Herzegovina to respect its commitments. Otherwise, exceptional trade measures, however to the advantage of Bosnia and Herzegovina, will be suspended from 1 January 2016. I support this proposal. Vote FOR/ compliance with Bosnia's commitments under a preferential agreement with the EU.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. In 2003, Bosnia and Herzegovina was granted the status of a potential candidate country for EU membership, and in 2008 Bosnia and Herzegovina signed a Stabilisation and Association Agreement committing to meet EU conditions for accession. Since then, an interim agreement on trade and trade-related matters has been applied to Bosnia and Herzegovina pending the completion of the ratification process of the Stabilization and Association Agreement. The INTA Commission report highlights the progress made by the countries of the Western Balkans towards further integration into the EU and urges the EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina to try to reach agreement on the adaptation of the interim agreement with the EU in order to avoid the suspension of preferences. In addition, it was possible to approve in the INTA Commission that the Commission's decision to suspend preferences, in the event of non-compliance with the conditions laid down in the Regulation, must be carried out by delegated act and not by implementing act.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 The report on the suspension of the implementation of the exceptional trade measures with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina is complete and documented and should therefore be accepted.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted for this report. In 2009 the EU introduced exceptional trade measures for Balkan countries, with these measures in force until 31 December 2015. Since then, association agreements have been signed with all these Balkan countries apart from Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo. With Croatia's accession there is now a problem of calculating quotas, because of the ill will of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The report calls on Bosnia and Herzegovina to meet its commitments, otherwise preferential trade measures will be suspended as early as 2016. Bosnia and Herzegovina must live up to its commitments and I therefore support this report.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. 2012 This proposal concerns a number of procedures relating to the application of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and Bosnia and Herzegovina, of the other part, and of the Interim Agreement on Trade and Trade Affairs between the European Community, of the one part, and Bosnia and Herzegovina, of the other part. Since the purpose of the Duda report is to officially codify existing legislative texts, I have decided to support it with a positive vote.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The Council's position has been noted. I could not support the amendments.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Codification consists of grouping normative texts of various natures into collections concerning a field. It aims at simplification, clarity and transparency. The purpose of this proposal is to codify certain procedures for the implementation of the trade agreement and the association agreement with Bosnia and Herzegovina. It should be remembered that association agreements aim to impose free trade with the countries concerned. These undemocratic technocratic procedures prevent Europe from practising solidarity protectionism, which is the ecological and social emergency of our time. Also even if it is only a technical report I vote against.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, as the preferential trade regime currently in place between the European Union and the Western Balkans has resulted in an increase in exports from the Western Balkans to the EU. A further five-year extension of the Autonomous Trade Measures confirms the EU’s commitment to the future European integration of the Western Balkans. It is crucial that we view the suspension of this agreement with Bosnia and Herzegovina as an incentive to resolve the ongoing disagreement with the EU.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to amend Council Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009 introducing exceptional trade measures for countries and territories participating in or related to the Stabilisation and Association Process of the European Union. Under the proposal: the current benefits would be extended until the end of 2020 in order to give the beneficiary countries time to coordinate the benefits under the basic Regulation and the stabilisation and association agreements and the advantages granted under the interim agreements; a human rights clause would be added to the Regulation which would allow for the suspension of benefits if any of the beneficiary countries seriously and systematically violates the principles of human rights, democracy and the rule of law;  the application of the Regulation to Bosnia and Herzegovina would be suspended from 1 January 2016 as Bosnia and Herzegovina has so yet not consented to adapting the Interim Agreement on the liberalisation of trade between it and the EU in the light of Croatia's accession to the EU.  I agree with all three amendments.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. Following Croatia's accession to the Union, Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Eu had to reach an agreement on the adaptation of the INTERIM AGREEMENT of the Union, to avoid the suspension of preferences for Bosnia and Herzegovina on 1 January 2016.  Croatia's accession has in fact led to technical problems due to the calculation of quotas set out in a regulation (No. 1215/2009), but also to the ill will of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The report therefore calls on the latter to honour its commitments. Otherwise, trade preference measures could fall as early as January 1, 2016.  I abstained.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which provides for the suspension of exceptional trade measures for the benefit of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The text calls for respect for democratic principles, the rule of law and fundamental freedoms, especially those of minorities. Without this, the process of accession to the European Union of this candidate country will not progress.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this proposal for a regulation, as we intend to confirm the European Union's effective and firm commitment to the future European integration of countries and territories participating in or linked to the stabilisation and association process, by granting exceptional trade measures, such as unilateral trade preferences. In this way, we are confident that we can help to ensure stability in the region.  These concessions, together with the provision for their possible and possible suspension, will provide the right impetus to speed up the path of political and socio-economic reforms that the countries of the Western Balkans need in order to comply with the Copenhagen criteria and the Union acquis. For the same reason, we have decided to urge Bosnia and Herzegovina to adapt the Interim Agreement to preferential trade with Croatia, following croatia's accession to the European Union on 1 July 2013, and at the same time we call on the parties to take account of each other's interests so as to reach an agreement acceptable both to the EU Member States and to the countries signatory to the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA).

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission proposes to amend Council Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009 on exceptional trade measures applicable to countries and territories participating in, or linked to, the Stabilisation and Association Process implemented by the European Union, extending the benefits for the countries of the Western Balkan region until the year 2020.  All the countries of the Western Balkans which are members of the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA), with the exception of Bosnia and Herzegovina, have concluded negotiations to amend these agreements with the Union. After three rounds of negotiations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, no agreement could be reached.  That is why the Commission proposes to suspend benefits for this country from January 2016 until an agreement has been reached. In the light of the above and for the above reasons, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union was the most important partner for the Balkan region in 2013, both in terms of exports and imports. I voted for this resolution because, through its text, it comes to stress the need to respect the principles of democracy, the rule of law and human rights in these countries, as they wish to make progress in the process of accession to the European Union. The resolution also confirms the EU's commitment to the future European integration of the countries and territories covered by this Regulation by granting unilateral trade preferences.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The European Union is using the threat of this suspension of trade agreements with Bosnia to encourage Bosnia to submit. Moreover, the abolition of these agreements is part of the EU's desire for enlargement, which seeks to eventually integrate Bosnia and Herzegovina. So I voted against it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ In the last budget period, BiH received EUR 660 million in financial assistance from the EU, while in the first 6 months of membership Croatia lost EUR 220 million due to BiH's refusal to adjust its SSP.  As a former member of CEFTA, Croatia was to adapt its SSP in 2004 after Slovenia and Hungary joined the EU. It is a standard practice of adapting trade agreements based on the principle of preserving traditional trade and all other CEFTA members have already adapted their SSP to Croatian accession to the EU. With the signing of a written statement in February, biH political leaders pledged to "increase the efficiency of the institutions so that they can adopt the EU acquis communautaire and other obligations arising from the EU accession process".  I am glad that all the institutions of the European Union share the same opinion on this problem, and I really hope that there will be an adjustment of the SPP of Bosnia and Herzegovina before the end of the year, which will automatically make the suspension flawless.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I am convinced that the suspension is a fair measure as Bosnia and Herzegovina, following Croatia's entry into the EU, has not yet agreed to adapt the Interim Agreement for traditional preferential trade under the CEFTA Free Trade Agreement. Of course, on the day when the EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina have agreed and signed an agreement on the adjustment of trade concessions, preferences will be able to resume.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Given that Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet agreed to adapt the agreement governing its trade relations with the UNION following Croatia's accession to the EU on 1 July 2013, the Commission has proposed to temporarily suspend exceptional trade measures against Bosnia and Herzegovina. Once an agreement has been reached with that country, the sanctions will be lifted.  The European Parliament has adopted this proposal. I voted in favour of this text. It is important that Bosnia and Herzegovina submits and accepts the evolution of the Union in order to ensure the continuation of sustainable trade and diplomatic relations with the Union.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. Trade between the EU and the western Balkan countries is liberalised through a series of Stabilisation and Association Agreements (SAAs) and an Interim Agreement (PA) in the case of Bosnia and Herzegovina. Kosovo and the entire region also benefit from Autonomous Trade Measures (AM). These unilateral preferences allow unlimited access to the Union duty-free for most products. This resolution suggests the introduction of three main amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009 on these preferences. On the one hand, it introduces the extension of current preferences until the end of 2020, and the regime has contributed to increased trade. On the other hand, it includes the human rights clause in the MCA Regulation, allowing the suspension of preferences in the event of serious and systematic violations of these principles by any of the beneficiary countries. The proposal ultimately provides for the possible suspension of MCA for Bosnia and Herzegovina (BH) from 1 January 2016, as it has not yet agreed to adapt the Interim Agreement to take account of traditional preferential trade between Croatia and BH following Croatia's accession to the EU on 1 July 2013. I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. MEPs voted this lunchtime in favour of a report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending the Regulation (EC) No. 1215/2009 introducing measures trade for participating countries and territories linked to the European Union's stabilisation and association process and suspending its application with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this draft report which urges Bosnia and Herzegovina to adopt the interim preferential trade agreement with Croatia and at the same time calls on both sides to take into account mutual interests in order to reach a satisfactory agreement for both the Member States of the Union and the members of the ALECE.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for the suspension of exceptional external trade instruments for the countries involved in the stabilisation and association process, including Bosnia and Herzegovina. The document is a very important topic and is being discussed at a particularly relevant time, at a time when Bosnia and Herzegovina is still working to ensure both internal stability and its European orientation.  At the same time, I would like to stress that the decision is made for fundamentally technical reasons. Politically, trade is one of the essential tools by which the EU can spread its soft power. It is therefore extremely important to look for mechanisms to keep the states that are important to us in the EU's orbit. In cases where partner countries are not sufficiently successful in fulfilling their partnership commitments, the EU should focus more on technical assistance measures rather than on sanctions that will exacerbate the situation.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. European policy towards the countries of the Western Balkans is defined in the framework of the Stabilisation and Association Process, launched in May 1999. This proposal seeks to amend Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009 adopting exceptional trade measures in favour of countries and territories participating in or linked to the stabilisation and association process. The amendments considered include the extension of preferences for another 5 years, the suspension of trade preferences for Bosnia and Herzegovina from 01/01/2016 and the introduction of the so-called 'Human Rights Clause'. All the western Balkan countries that are members of CEFTA have concluded negotiations to amend their agreements with the European Union. Bosnia and Herzegovina, which recently agreed to sign and provisionally implement an agreement on the adaptation of trade concessions, was missing, and trade preferences for that country were therefore restored. I support this proposal, which calls on Bosnia and Herzegovina to adapt the Interim Preferential Trade Agreement with Croatia and also calls on the parties to take account of their mutual interests in order to reach a satisfactory agreement for both EU Member States and CEFTA members.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the extension of certain tariff benefits with balkan countries, the Commission has decided to make the consequent changes to the agreements with individual countries. The failure to reach an agreement with Bosnia and Herzegovina has led the Commission to request the suspension of these benefits. That is why I approved the document voted on here today, because I believe that this decision is correct and, above all, because I agree with the European Union's call in the report for greater respect for the principles of democracy and the fight against corruption that that country must respect.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it, since it provides for the suspension of trade preferences (applicable in eight months) for access to the European market for products coming from Bosnia. These are very sensitive agricultural products for Bosnia. Bosnia's economy is on the ground. Bosnia chronically suffers from a large trade deficit and is under the IMF's agenda. Unemployment, and in particular youth unemployment, reaches outrageous rates. Exactly a year ago, Bosnia experienced its most violent social discontent since the war of the 1990s, and this is due to the economic situation. Most of these problems — for which the EU is also responsible — are due to the post-war constitutional configuration. Other Balkan countries have accepted the 'technical adaptation' of their Stabilisation and Association Agreement, but we must not forget that Bosnia is not like any other Balkan country and that its prospect of accession is also long-term, unlike other Balkan countries. We believe that three rounds of negotiations are not enough. We believe that, in this case, a more flexible solution can be found that is not based on traditional trade.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted against the amendments to the suspension of the exceptional trade measures applied to Bosnia and Herzegovina on the view that Bosnia deserves special treatment in trade terms following the EU's enlargement to Croatia, which has significantly damaged the Bosnian economy. In addition, the amendments adopted delve into the line of EU policy towards candidate countries and potential candidates, reproducing a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ We welcome these proposed reforms to the  HYPERLINK "http://ec.europa.eu/enlargement/policy/glossary/terms/saa_en.htm" Stabilisation and Association Agreements and the Interim Agreement in the Western Balkans region. The extension of Autonomous Trade Measures (ATMs) will continue to offer economic and political support to the Western Balkan countries, while including a key human rights clause, of which labour rights conditionality forms part, attached to the trade measures. The S&D Group has been at the forefront in demanding this. We also support proposals to allow Parliament a greater role in scrutiny of the Western Balkan countries’ compliance with the human rights clause, and in ATM suspension if necessary.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒The problem with Bosnia and Herzegovina lies in the fact that it is still the only remaining country in Southeast Europe that has not signed a treaty change after Croatia's accession to the European Union. For this reason, Croatia does not yet have the same trade relations with BiH as other EU Member States. I therefore supported the suspension of extraordinary trade measures with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina.  Bosnia and Herzegovina needs to show strong initiative in achieving common regional interests by accepting changes in the Stabilisation and Association Agreement as well as the Interim Agreement. I emphasise concerns about Bosnia and Herzegovina's political disunity to joining the European Union. I think it is crucial to steer BiH towards implementing reforms to bring the EU closer to eu standards, thus ensuring a better future for its own citizens and co-operation for all countries in the region.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. As a representative of the Green Party, I did not support the autonomous preferential agreement requested by bosnia and herzegovina by the European Commission, arguing that it was merely a technical change. By requiring Bosnia and Herzegovina to sign the agreement or to abolish it completely from 1St 1st 2016, the Commission placed them in a corner. Such an act would only put their already weak economy at risk. Bosnia and Herzegovina pointed out that their requirement not to accept an autonomous preferential agreement is based mainly on the fact that, under the existing trade agreement with Croatia, they have a special agreement for 15 types of agricultural products, which represent a significant proportion of their exports. Therefore, any change in export conditions for these sensitive products threatens their already weak economy. Moreover, such an act is not in line with mogherini's approach, which advocates economic growth and job creation in the country. The country and its people need to be listened to and understood. After all, the very high unemployment rate, the poor economic situation, the excessive level of corruption and many other problems they face clearly indicate that Bosnia and Herzegovina and its citizens do not need further blows, but a hand of help and understanding.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important that Bosnia and Herzegovina and the EU reach an agreement on the modification of the Interim Agreement with the EU following the accession of Croatia in order to avoid the suspension of preferences for Bosnia and Herzegovina on 1 January 2016. It is the European process of integration that has proved to be the most effective instrument for the stability of the region. Therefore, a mutual agreement between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the EU can support political and socio-economic reforms in the Western Balkans.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ As shadow rapporteur by the EPP Group, I fully support the extension of autonomous trade preferences for the Countries of the Western Balkans, which are a useful tool for economic assistance, but certainly an important tool in the integration of countries on their path towards full membership of the European family. Further opening up the Community market to imports from western Balkan countries greatly contributes to the political and economic stabilisation of the region.  However, as Bosnia and Herzegovina has not accepted the adjustment of trade preferences granted under the Interim Agreement in order to take into account traditional trade between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina under the Central European Free Trade Agreement, in the event that until this regulation is adopted, the European Union and Bosnia and Herzegovina do not sign and apply the agreement on the adjustment of trade preferences under the Stabilisation and Association Agreement and the Interim Agreement , the privileges granted to Bosnia and Herzegovina should be suspended from 1 January 2016.  Once Bosnia and Herzegovina and the Commission have signed and started applying the agreement on the adjustment of trade preferences under the Interim Agreement, those preferences should be reintroduced. I therefore urge that the Bosnian and Herzegovinian authorities and the Commission redouble their efforts to find a solution in accordance with the Interim Agreement by 1 January 2016, and I sincerely hope that the measures will not be implemented.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ In order to allow time to deliberate further and to table the best possible report, I voted in favour of postponing the vote on the suspension of exceptional trade measures with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina. I welcome these proposed reforms to the  HYPERLINK "http://ec.europa.eu/enlargement/policy/glossary/terms/saa_en.htm" Stabilisation and Association Agreements and the Interim Agreement in the Western Balkans region. The extension of Autonomous Trade Measures (ATMs) will continue to offer economic and political support to the Western Balkan countries, while including a key human rights clause, of which labour rights conditionality forms part, attached to the trade measures. I also support proposals to allow Parliament a greater role in scrutiny of the Western Balkan countries’ compliance with the human rights clause, and in ATM suspension if necessary. In the long term, however, I cannot support any third country discriminating against EU Member States, and the ability to use the suspension clause is necessary.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the proposal. While I agree with the extension of the current trade preferences vis-à-vis Bosnia and Herzegovina, which allow Bosnia and Herzegovina to export more freely to the European Union, I do not agree with the possible suspension of autonomous trade measures unless Bosnia and Herzegovina liberalises access to its market as requested by the European Union. Bosnia and Herzegovina's lack of liberalisation is regrettable, as it is also detrimental to EU exporters and also to customers in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Nevertheless, the possible lifting of exceptional trade measures by the EU would nevertheless damage not only bosnia and Herzegovina's exporters, but also harm the EU populations themselves.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Bosnia and Herzegovina does not meet basic conditions of a rule of law and is therefore far from joining. No serious effort is being made to develop good neighbourly relations and the fundamental principles of democracy are not respected. It is not a member of the Central European Free Trade Agreement and does not respect the traditional terms of trade within the EU.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support the report on the imposition of extraordinary trade measures for countries and territories participating in or linked to the Stabilisation and Association Process of the EU and the suspension of its application with regard to Bosnia and Herzegovina. The trade preferences that Bosnia and Herzegovina enjoys with Croatia are a matter of tradition and very close relations.  Therefore, as long as such measures are warnings and guidelines in the further progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina, support will not be absent. A healthy relationship between a transitional state and a union of countries where many have gone down a similar integration path can only benefit if advice is to be taken into account and efforts required. As an MP from Croatia who has encountered challenges in the past 20 years on human rights violations, I call on the authorities at all levels to sit at the table and find consensus in order to pave the way for reforms, and ultimately to boost economic growth and ensure equal rights for all ethnic groups and individuals.  Since Bosnia and Herzegovina has not yet implemented the adjustment of trade preferences under the Interim Agreement, I believe that the provisions of this report should be taken into account as an indication that compromise can indeed be found if there is a strong political will, and continue to promote tolerance and coexistence in Bosnian-Herzegovinian society.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against it, since it provides for the suspension of trade preferences (applicable in eight months) for access to the European market for products coming from Bosnia. These are very sensitive agricultural products for Bosnia. Bosnia's economy is on the ground. Bosnia chronically suffers from a large trade deficit and is under the IMF's agenda. Unemployment, and in particular youth unemployment, reaches outrageous rates. Exactly a year ago, Bosnia experienced its most violent social discontent since the war of the 1990s, and this is due to the economic situation. Most of these problems — for which the EU is also responsible — are due to the post-war constitutional configuration. Other Balkan countries have accepted the 'technical adaptation' of their Stabilisation and Association Agreement, but we must not forget that Bosnia is not like any other Balkan country and that its prospect of accession is also long-term, unlike other Balkan countries. We believe that three rounds of negotiations are not enough. We believe that, in this case, a more flexible solution can be found that is not based on traditional trade.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The EU introduced exceptional trade measures for Balkan countries in 2009. Since then, association agreements have been signed with all countries except Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo. Following Croatia's accession to the EU, there is a problem of quota calculation due to the ill will of Bosnia and Herzegovina. This text calls on Bosnia and Herzegovina to play the game and respect its commitments. Otherwise, Bosnia and Herzegovina's preferential trade measures will be suspended from 1 January 2016. I vote FOR compliance with Bosnia's commitments under a preferential agreement with the EU.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 The opinion of the Committee on Foreign Affairs is fully part of the report. In order to develop the region, it is important that autonomous trade measures for the western Balkan countries and territories participating in the stabilisation and association process are extended for a further five years, i.e. until 31 December 2020. This preferential trading system has contributed to an increase in EU imports of Western Balkan products. In addition to trade aspects, it is essential that the Copenhagen criteria are met (including basic labour and environmental standards, promoting and protecting human rights and the principles of sustainable development). I voted in favour of this report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote on the report on the evolution of Bosnia and Herzegovina 2014, as we believe that its approach does not correspond to the perspective we have with regard to the Balkan countries. One of the reasons has to do with the insistence of the different parliamentary groups (contrary to our position) to increase the pressure on these countries to carry out structural reforms in the economic, social and political spheres. We reject these reforms as a precondition for their future access to the European Union. However, despite this, the report includes a commitment that goes in line with intensifying regional cooperation, mainly in the face of disasters and natural disasters affecting Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted against the amendments to the suspension of the exceptional trade measures applied to Bosnia and Herzegovina on the view that Bosnia deserves special treatment in trade terms following the EU's enlargement to Croatia, which has significantly damaged the Bosnian economy. In addition, the amendments adopted delve into the line of EU policy towards candidate countries and potential candidates, reproducing a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: Written. 'The European Parliament has approved this report on exceptional trade measures for the countries and territories participating in or associated with the EU stabilisation and association process and suspending its application as regards Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The amendments to this Regulation relate to the following objectives: extension of the period of application of the Regulation until 31 December 2020; introduction of the human rights clause; possible suspension of autonomous trade measures to Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1 January 2016 because it did not agree to adapt the trade concessions granted under the Interim Agreement to take account of traditional preferential trade between Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina under the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA). Furthermore, given that the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Kosovo was initialled in July 2014, this Regulation will also cover Kosovo.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. The Stabilisation and Association Agreements with the western Balkan countries are generally preceded by asymmetric trade liberalisation. Asymmetric trade liberalisation is provided by Council Regulation (EC) No 1215/2009, which adopts exceptional trade measures in favour of countries and territories participating in or linked to the stabilisation and association process. This Regulation applies until 31 December 2015. The amendments to this Regulation relate to the following objectives: - extension of the period of application of the Regulation until 31 December 2020, - introduction of the human rights clause , - possible suspension of autonomous trade measures to Bosnia and Herzegovina from 1 January 2016 because it has not agreed to adapt the trade concessions granted under the Interim Agreement in order to take account of traditional preferential trade between Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina under the Central European Free Trade Agreement (CEFTA). Furthermore, given that the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Kosovo was initialled in July 2014, this Regulation will also cover Kosovo. We voted against it.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I would certainly like to condemn the tragedy that has taken place in Kenya, which was motivated by apparently unequivocal confessional violence, i.e. to separate students according to faith and to unleash violence, thus weakening as much as possible those who professed other religious behaviours. In this sense, I would like to call once again, above all, on the moral authorities of religious orientations, be it Christianity, Islam, or, of course, other religious directions, which should, by joint decisive action, condemn these manifestations of barbarism and violence and should, in my opinion, show young people who are radicalised that this is not the value of their religion. And I think that this collective activity of the moral authorities of these religious directions is apperably lacking these days.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: –  Madam President, I support this resolution and I voted in favour. It clearly and openly stands for those who are without doubt being repressed, persecuted, hunted and killed on an everyday basis. What really bothers me is the attitude of some Members of this House. They turn a blind eye to the fact that we are speaking about Christians who are dying all around the world just because of their faith. No political preference should hinder us from fighting for justice for those who need it right now. Just let me say that I am proud to be a Christian. Just like the students in Kenya, I can speak with no fear, which I am very grateful for. However, the students had to pay with their lives. Do not make them random victims of violence. Call them martyrs, because they died for what they believed.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I have subscribed to the explanation of vote on the grounds that I want to say that I primarily supported the version of the resolution tabled by my PPE faction, because I believe that the unapproved version of the PPE more expressed the problem associated with the massacre in Kenya, and that is the problem of dismantling huge Christian communities in the Middle East and parts of Africa. Their huge persecution and, unfortunately, the slaughter. I think it must be said that what was behind the huge massacre of students in Kenya was not an isolated tragic event, but that it is linked to a global problem where Muslim extremists persecute and murder Christians in this way. Last year it was 150,000 victims.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, when Al-Shabaab militants raided Garissa University, Christians were singled out to be executed. The Al-Qaeda affiliated group has portrayed itself over the past years as fighting a holy war against Christians, even though its actions in Somalia have killed mostly Muslims. Al-Shabaab, in an extremely gruesome way, is trying to compete with ISIS in killing civilians and especially Christians. The dynamics of both groups display many similarities, whereby ethnic and religious differences are exploited to further create instability in the region and seize control over resources. What if Al-Shabaab and ISIS decide to collaborate? It is often stated that these terrorist groups are ‘just a bunch of disorganised bandits’, but how many more atrocities and casualties are to be expected before there is a meaningful, targeted action that will end in misery for many? Ms Mogherini stated that the EU’s solidarity with Kenya and Iraq is assured, but this needs to translate into concrete measures that have tangible effects when it comes to security.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, ní minic a bhíonn bualadh bos sa Pharlaimint seo tar éis na vótaí, ach inniu nuair a vótáil 578 bhFeisire as 643 i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo chualamar bualadh bos mór.  Taispeánann sé sin chomh dáiríre agus atá Feisirí faoin ábhar seo agus chomh sásta atáimid chun an foréigean agus an marú atá ag tarlú do Chríostaithe timpeall an domhain a cháineadh. Bhí an seans sin againn inniu. Tá sé ag dul i méad le blianta beaga anuas, go háirithe sna Afraic agus sa Mheán-Oirthear agus cáinim go mór cad a rinne al-Shabab ar mhic léinn sa Chéinia. Dá bhrí sin, caithfimid gach rud a dhéanamh chun Críostaithe a chosaint, ach go háirithe, ach freisin an ceart daonna atá ag gach duine an reiligiún is mian leo a leanúint.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. In the strongest terms, the Resolution condemns the deliberate terrorist attack by Al Shabab on 2 April 2015 in Garissa, in which 147 university students were killed and another 79 injured. We condemn all human rights violations, particularly when people are killed on the basis of their religion, beliefs and ethnicity. Freedom of religion is a fundamental right and we strongly condemn any violence or discrimination on the grounds of religion. I voted in favour of the resolution adopted because violence in Nigeria and Kenya reveals that terrorism is a threat that requires a comprehensive solution. We Socialists believe that the EU should promote religious freedom and interreligious tolerance, and support Kenya and Nigeria to address the root causes of radicalisation. Bombs, suicide bombings, sexual slavery and other forms of violence, as well as abductions by terrorist sects in Africa constitute crimes against humanity.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I share the unequivocal condemnation for this Resolution of the massacre committed on 2 April by the terrorist group Al Shabab in the attack on the university campus of the Kenyan city of Garissa, near the border with Somalia, a massacre in which 148 people, mainly students, were killed.  However, I voted against this text because it does not address the fundamental problem in the area and does not take into account fundamental factors, such as the US military intervention in Somalia in 1992 with disastrous implications still being paid for by the peoples of the region, the responsibility of the former colonial powers in promoting conflict and in plundering the natural resources of the Horn of Africa , land grabbing, high poverty rates, hundreds of thousands of refugees, infant mortality, hunger or malnutrition...   In the majors, it victimizes Christianity, diverting the focus from the source of the problem, and maintains the logic of the "global fight against terrorism" with a military approach that fosters EU military cooperation with the governments of the countries in the area.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the persecution of Christians around the world. There is no doubt that some Christian communities suffer persecution in different parts of the world – and this must be recognised and condemned. However, persecution of all and any religious minorities anywhere in the world must be condemned as unacceptable. Unfortunately many of the amendments submitted concerned the persecution of Christian minorities only. While I supported amendments that were factually accurate, it would have been preferable had the amendments concerned the persecution of all religious minorities, all around the world, rather than just Christians, particularly those in the Middle East. Because of the large number of authoritarian regimes in the Middle East and the ongoing conflicts, the rights of many religious minorities, not only Christians, are poorly protected. Indeed, many different religious, ethnic, cultural and linguistic minorities, as well as the LGBT community and refugees, are all extremely vulnerable to violence and oppression. Sinn Féin fully supports the right of all people to freedom of religion and belief, and takes the view that all minorities and vulnerable people need to be strongly protected in law.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. On April 2, 2015, 148 students of Christian faith were murdered by the Somali terrorist group Al-Shabab in a massacre at a Kenyan university. Kenya's active participation in the African Union mission in Somalia has caused widespread outrage over the past two years in Kenya. However, other regions are also experiencing a massive increase in sectarian violence, for example in Syria and Iraq (IS/Da'isch). I strongly condemn the religious violence and welcome Parliament's motion for a resolution on the 'persecution of Christians in the world, in connection with the murder of students in Kenya by the Islamist terrorist group Al-Shabab'.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution condemns the persecution of Christians. As attacks on Christians have reportedly increased in recent months, there is an urgent need for measures to be put in place as quickly as possible to deal with persecution and avoid new ones. The proposal aims to strengthen dialogue with Christians and urges Muslim leaders to condemn terrorist attacks against Christians. It advocates cooperation with African states in the fight against terrorism. To do so, it is implementing the creation of a delegation of mediators and experts specializing in the issue of intercultural and interreligious dialogue in order to stimulate negotiations and mediation of conflicts by United Nations envoys. Above all, it stresses that international jihadist terrorism is financed by money laundering, drug trafficking and corruption and calls on the Commission and Member States to strengthen their cooperation with third countries and to adopt stricter legislation on freezing suspicious assets. Even if the solutions implemented are not yet sufficient, this proposal is an urgent first step for Christians.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I utterly deplore these killings.  The wording was a concern in some areas but, given that most of the amendments had passed, I felt sufficiently comfortable to vote in favour of the overall text.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to condemn the persecution of Christians in the world, in the light of the massacre of students in Kenya by the terrorist group al-Shabab. The EP condemns the al-Shabab terrorist attack, which killed 147 students and injured 79 on 2 April. I support the calls for Mr Mogherini and the Council to address security and terrorist threats in this regional crisis in cooperation with the African Union and to assist it in the fight against al-Shabab. It is important that the Kenyan authorities guarantee the freedom of all faiths.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. While I remain vigilant about abuses of interference by the EU, I voted in favour of this text, which recognises and denounces the persecution of Christians.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. On 2 April 2015, Al-Shabaab militiamen entered the campus of Garissa University in Kenya and killed 148 students, mostly targeting non-Muslim students. The European Parliament wishes to show its solidarity with the victims and their families. Parliament also calls on the Kenyan authorities to avoid any polarization by pitting Muslims against Christians. Finally, Parliament calls on the Union to adopt a comprehensive and coordinated response to combat radicalisation and terrorist financing. The problem of terrorism must be tackled at its root if this global threat is to be eradicated.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The resolution on the persecution of Christians around the world, including the killing of students in Kenya by the terrorist group Al-Shabaab, recalls a number of fundamental principles to which I am deeply attached. First, it condemns the massacre committed by Al-Shabaab on 2 April 2015 in Garissa, which resulted in 147 innocent young students being murdered and 79 wounded. These terrorist attacks, committed, moreover, in educational institutions, must be condemned with the utmost firmness by anyone committed to respect for human life. Secondly, it reminds us that Christians are the most persecuted religious minority in the world, in many parts of the world. Religious freedom must be guaranteed all over the world and no one can be worried because of their beliefs. For all these reasons, I can only vote in favour of this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The massacre of these students murdered simply because they are Christians is unfortunately just another episode in an escalation of violence that Europe continues to ignore. One hundred million Christians are persecuted in the world, one hundred thousand Christians who are killed, beheaded and crucified every year, one every five minutes, with the complicit silence of the institutions, including those of Europe. Behind this insane genocide there are no economic interests but religious intolerance, radical Islam preaching hatred. For these fanatics, for these monsters, Christians, we Christians, have no right to exist, to live, but we must be erased. That is the truth. I will continue to fight for this Europe to stop looking the other way and to act and react to this extermination.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. In the strongest terms, the Resolution condemns the deliberate terrorist attack by Al Shabab on 2 April 2015 in Garissa, in which 147 university students were killed and another 79 injured. We condemn all human rights violations, particularly when people are killed on the basis of their religion, beliefs and ethnicity. Freedom of religion is a fundamental right and we strongly condemn any violence or discrimination on the grounds of religion. I voted in favour of the resolution adopted because violence in Nigeria and Kenya reveals that terrorism is a threat that requires a comprehensive solution. We Socialists believe that the EU should promote religious freedom and interreligious tolerance, and support Kenya and Nigeria to address the root causes of radicalisation. Bombs, suicide bombings, sexual slavery and other forms of violence, as well as abductions by terrorist sects in Africa constitute crimes against humanity.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. I sincerely regret the loss of life at the University of Garissa and hereby extend my sincere condolences to the families of the victims of this brutal attack. The European Parliament stands fully with the Kenyan people in its determination to fight all forms of terrorism in its country and to defend its own human rights, in particular the right to education. The extremists attacked the students because they know their greatest enemy is knowledge. I call on the Kenyan government, opposition leaders and religious leaders to respond to the historical injustices of marginalisation, regional division within the country and institutional discrimination, and to ensure that counterterrorism operations target only perpetrators, not wider ethnic and religious communities.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the persecution of Christians around the world. There is no doubt that some Christian communities suffer persecution in different parts of the world – and this must be recognised and condemned. However, persecution of all and any religious minorities anywhere in the world must be condemned as unacceptable. Unfortunately many of the amendments submitted concerned the persecution of Christian minorities only. While I supported amendments that were factually accurate, it would have been preferable had the amendments concerned the persecution of all religious minorities, all around the world, rather than just Christians, particularly those in the Middle East. Because of the large number of authoritarian regimes in the Middle East and the ongoing conflicts, the rights of many religious minorities, not only Christians, are poorly protected. Indeed, many different religious, ethnic, cultural and linguistic minorities, as well as the LGBT community and refugees, are all extremely vulnerable to violence and oppression. Sinn Féin fully supports the right of all people to freedom of religion and belief, and takes the view that all minorities and vulnerable people need to be strongly protected in law.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution because the killing of 147 students in Garissa, Kenya, last month and, in general, what is happening to Christian minorities all over the world are real tragedies. It is our duty to act in order to prevent such tragic events happening again.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 Globalization of persecution against Christians is a phenomenon of constantly worsening and geographical expansion. The main threat facing the Christian population is Islamic extremism. Countries experiencing a phenomenon of deep Islamic radicalisation and where Christians are subjected to violence include Kenya, Nigeria, Iraq, Syria, the Central African Republic, Sudan and Pakistan. In this context, we are talking about the attack in Kenya, where 147 students were the victims of an attack by the terrorist group Al-Shabaab. This attack reveals people's vulnerability to groups formed to unjustifiably induce global terror. Such attacks, of particular gravity and without any justification, further strengthen our commitment to fight international terrorism and extremism. Events in Kenya are a wake-up call for world peace and anti-terrorist organisations.  Given that in 2014 some 4,344 Christians were killed because of their religion, twice as much as in 2013 (2,123 victims), I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution to ensure that the Christian world is secured with security and integrity.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained. The condemnation of the facts is clear and clearly acceptable, but the measures requested and the text adopted will prove to be mere statements of principle. We must act now and concretely to help Christians in the world.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. In the strongest terms, the Resolution condemns the deliberate terrorist attack by Al Shabab on 2 April 2015 in Garissa, in which 147 university students were killed and another 79 injured. We condemn all human rights violations, particularly when people are killed on the basis of their religion, beliefs and ethnicity. Freedom of religion is a fundamental right and we strongly condemn any violence or discrimination on the grounds of religion. I voted in favour of the resolution adopted because violence in Nigeria and Kenya reveals that terrorism is a threat that requires a comprehensive solution. We Socialists believe that the EU should promote religious freedom and interreligious tolerance, and support Kenya and Nigeria to address the root causes of radicalisation. Bombs, suicide bombings, sexual slavery and other forms of violence, as well as abductions by terrorist sects in Africa constitute crimes against humanity.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the persecution of Christians in the world in connection with the murder of students in Kenya by the terrorist group Al-Shabaad because the international community cannot stand by and allow acts of violence such as those in Kenya to re-occur.  Religious freedom is one of the fundamental freedoms of the individual and must therefore be guaranteed everywhere. Unfortunately, today we are witnessing a more intense, more serious, more methodical and ruthlessly ideologised persecutory phenomenon towards Christians than in the past. The international community, as the Pontiff has repeatedly argued, cannot witness this massacre as "silent and inert".

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the persecution of Christians around the world. There is no doubt that some Christian communities suffer persecution in different parts of the world – and this must be recognised and condemned. However, persecution of all and any religious minorities anywhere in the world must be condemned as unacceptable. Unfortunately many of the amendments submitted concerned the persecution of Christian minorities only. While I supported amendments that were factually accurate, it would have been preferable had the amendments concerned the persecution of all religious minorities, all around the world, rather than just Christians, particularly those in the Middle East. Because of the large number of authoritarian regimes in the Middle East and the ongoing conflicts, the rights of many religious minorities, not only Christians, are poorly protected. Indeed, many different religious, ethnic, cultural and linguistic minorities, as well as the LGBT community and refugees, are all extremely vulnerable to violence and oppression. Sinn Féin fully supports the right of all people to freedom of religion and belief, and takes the view that all minorities and vulnerable people need to be strongly protected in law.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because it strongly condemns terrorism in Africa and the actions of Al-Shabaad who is trying to establish the Islamic State in neighboring Somalia.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I wished to support this resolution which strongly condemns the incredible persecution of Christians around the world. The resolution pays tribute to those students who were cowardly murdered in Kenya because they were Christians. I also agree with the willingness to cooperate with African states in the fight against terrorism, as is the case in Nigeria where we support, at least from a humanitarian point of view, the Nigerian authorities but also Chad and Cameroon, in their fight against Boko Haram. Finally, the resolution calls on the main Muslim authorities to publicly condemn this persecution of Christians, an initiative which I support because it is time for some Muslim authorities to clearly position themselves on the subject of terrorism and religious cleansing.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. In recent times we have been faced with an exponential increase in the number of attacks on religious minorities, particularly Christians, around the world. Every day there are Christians who are executed, beaten or detained, especially in some parts of the Arab world, by jihadist terrorists. In accordance with European values, all religious and ethnic minorities have the inalienable right to live in their traditional and historical homelands with dignity, equality and security. In this regard, I confound recent attacks against Christian communities in several countries; support international efforts to combat Islamic State actions. On the other hand, it is necessary to increase humanitarian aid and international assistance to protect the lives of Christians and other religious minorities in conflict zones and refugee camps. I support the need for the Government of Kenya to carry out an investigation and bring to trial all perpetrators of the executions that took place on its territory.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent massacre in Garissa showed that the rise of Islamic terrorist organisations in countries with strong political instability has encouraged the spread of persecution of the Christian minority. I would remind you that religious freedom is an inalienable human right, universally recognised by the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, and as such must be preserved. Therefore, considering it essential to support the Kenyan Government's commitment to tackling the causes of radicalisation and extremism, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 On April 2, 2015, carnage took place on the university campus of Garissa, a massacre against university students by the Islamist group al-Shabaab, Somali extremists affiliated with al-Qaeda. The toll of the terrorist attack was dramatic: 148 students were killed, mostly Christians, while an unspecified number of other students, 300, were taken hostage and there is no longer any news of it. The university is a symbolic place, the centre of the education of the young people who will represent the future ruling class of the country. I could only vote in favour because I believe that the EU must make every effort to guarantee peace and religious freedom.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I share the unequivocal condemnation for this Resolution of the massacre committed on 2 April by the terrorist group Al Shabab in the attack on the university campus of the Kenyan city of Garissa, near the border with Somalia, a massacre in which 148 people, mainly students, were killed.  However, I voted against this text because it does not address the fundamental problem in the area and does not take into account fundamental factors, such as the US military intervention in Somalia in 1992 with disastrous implications still being paid for by the peoples of the region, the responsibility of the former colonial powers in promoting conflict and in plundering the natural resources of the Horn of Africa , land grabbing, high poverty rates, hundreds of thousands of refugees, infant mortality, hunger or malnutrition...   In the majors, it victimizes Christianity, diverting the focus from the source of the problem, and maintains the logic of the "global fight against terrorism" with a military approach that fosters EU military cooperation with the governments of the countries in the area.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 The attack on Garissa University in northern Kenya resulted in 148 deaths and 79 injuries by members of the Al-Shabaab terrorist group, affiliated with Al-Qaida, targeted students who did not belong to the Muslim religion.  We have a duty to support Kenya in the fight against all forms of terrorism. Religious freedom is a fundamental component of human rights and we strongly condemn these terrorist attacks. The EU must provide Kenya with the financial, logistical and expertise necessary for the effective fight against terrorist groups. The European Commission and the SEAE must be part of internationally coordinated efforts to combat the eradication and financing of terrorism in the world - a global threat requires a global response.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution condemns the deliberate terrorist attack perpetrated by Al-Shabaab on 2 April 2015 in Garissa, in which it assassinated 147 young, innocent university students and injured 79 others. It specifically condemns all violations of human rights, especially when people are killed on the basis of their religion, beliefs or ethnic origin. It also calls for the European Union to assist the Kenyan Government, both diplomatically and by helping in military training, in cracking down on Al-Shabaab. I believe that Europe cannot just be a spectator to this massacre and that we should give all required help to end it once and for all. Hence I fully support this resolution and voted in favour of it.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 The terrifying massacre of Christian students by the Somali Islamist group Al Shabaab on the campus of Garissa University in Kenya last April reminds us how much religious freedom in many parts of the world is still too often at risk. It arouses even more bewilderment and disapproval that this happens in places such as university, where young people daily face the challenge of knowledge, experiencing coexistence and mutual listening.  Pope Francis, in his appeals, has repeatedly called on the international community not to remain silent and helpless in the face of such violence, not to look elsewhere.  The resolution expresses the condolences of the European Parliament and our strong support for the Kenyan authorities in combating violence and its deepest causes and in supporting freedom of religion. The bloody persecution by extremist groups, to which Christians in the world are often victims, shakes the European Parliament, which, together with the international community, must not remain helpless. I have therefore voted wholely in favour of this significant joint resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. By this vote, Parliament expressed its concern about the abuses committed by the Al-Shabaab group. Recently, this terrorist group attacked the symbol of education by killing more than a hundred students in Garissa. This group also repeatedly persecutes Christians. The resolution recalls that they are targeted by other jihadist groups in many other countries in Africa and the Middle East.  I welcome this new strong commitment by the European Parliament to denounce these persecutions.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. The massacre of 147 students at Garissa University in Kenya is part of a series of atrocities perpetrated by the terrorist group Al-Shabaab, who has already claimed responsibility for several large-scale attacks in Kenya over the past 20 months, including the attack on Nairobi's Westgate shopping mall, in which 67 people were killed, and two attacks in Mandera County in late 2014 , in which 64 people were killed. I supported the resolution because it condemns these savage killings and, more generally, the violence against Christian minorities today, especially in many countries on the African continent. I also hope that my political group will be more active and determined in denouncing persecution of religious or ethnic minorities.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution condemns the persecution of Christians. As attacks on Christians have reportedly increased in recent months, there is an urgent need for measures to be put in place as quickly as possible to deal with persecution and avoid new ones. The proposal aims to strengthen dialogue with Christians and urges Muslim leaders to condemn terrorist attacks against Christians. It advocates cooperation with African states in the fight against terrorism. To do so, it is implementing the creation of a delegation of mediators and experts specializing in the issue of intercultural and interreligious dialogue in order to stimulate negotiations and mediation of conflicts by United Nations envoys. Above all, it stresses that international jihadist terrorism is financed by money laundering, drug trafficking and corruption and calls on the Commission and Member States to strengthen their cooperation with third countries and to adopt stricter legislation on freezing suspicious assets. Even if the solutions implemented are not yet sufficient, this proposal is an urgent first step for Christians.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 What is happening in Kenya is a christening example of the danger that any Christian or representative of any other religion poses in a region where extreme Islamism is at an all-time high. We have repeatedly discussed the issue of al-Shabab as well as other terrorist organizations in Africa. Obviously, this issue is directly related to the global issue of peace in Africa, respectively, to the problems of illegal immigrants. People are fleeing conflict zones. And they're coming this way to Europe to look for a better life. Al-Shabab is an organization we should not underestimate. We should therefore consider our position and policy, including our actions, as a key element of the Union's internal and external security. Specifically, that group, along with the like, is of course a threat to the Union. A threat that needs to be neutralized as soon as possible.  I argue that we must make such efforts as to lead to the isolation of such structures, and if not to their complete destruction, at least to their significant weakening, so as not to be a threat to Europe.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The attack by al-Shabaab in Garissa killed 147 young and innocent university students and left 79 others injured, violating the most elementary human rights, particularly when people are killed because of their religion, convictions or ethnic origin. The same terrorist group had previously committed other attacks that killed hundreds of people, including Somalia's ambassador to the United Nations.  Appropriate measures must be taken to put an end to the constant violations of human rights and persecution of Christians.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – Terrorist violence in Kenya and the proliferation of terrorist groups such as Al-Shabaab are disturbing phenomena that must be tackled. There is no effective counter-terrorism strategy based on racist and xenophobic presumptions.  The EU has a share of responsibility for the problem – foreign military interventions in many Countries of the Horn of Africa have promoted the radicalisation of these groups. The solution is not militarism, more war, interference and aggression. On the contrary, these policies are abandoned, as we advocate in our alternative resolution.  Relations between the EU and Kenya, such as relations with other African countries, must be based on non-interference, respect for the sovereignty of each country. The EU must end its free trade agreements that only benefit the economic interests of Western multinationals. The social problems at the heart of the problem can be mitigated with policies of genuine cooperation – support for education, health, the economy. And not with policies of exploitation of the weakest countries by the strongest.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Up to 82 countries out of 196 significantly violate freedom of religion and belief. The most persecuted religious minority in the world is Christians. The increase in cases of intolerance, violence or oppression against Christians, especially in some parts of the Arab world, is worrying. We must therefore support international efforts, particularly against ISIS, including the military actions of the international coalition, and we welcome the creation of the Delegation for cultural and religious dialogue as part of UN peacekeeping missions. Freedom of thought, conscience and religion is a fundamental right and it is therefore our duty to protect it.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 We must not only denounce but also stop the massacres of Christians that are taking place in half the world. We can't wait any longer.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, because the European Union must reaffirm its firm condemnation in the face of every new terrorist attack. I also believe that we must support the Kenyan Government in order to ensure that the fight against terrorism does not become a pretext for the repression of the civil rights of the population. Given the objectives of the most recent terrorist attacks, it is essential to reaffirm the central role of culture, education and education in the process of building and developing a democratic society.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the resolution on student killings in Kenya by the terrorist group al-Shabab because I believe that all means have been used and that only a military solution can still be effective.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The lives of human beings in societies devastated by wars, poverty and ignorance seem to have lost their value, and nightmares like the dreadful massacre at Garissa have become reality. It seems that, in the last 10 years, terrorist attacks against schools and universities have become a recurring tactic of global terrorism. This is obviously not a coincidence: terrorists hate education and instruction, probably because some of them have been excluded from it. That is why, if we want to tackle the root causes of terrorism, we must focus on addressing the conditions that make these extremist groups attractive to younger people. These conditions include underdevelopment due to a lack of public and private investment; institutional, economic, social and political discrimination against minorities; brutal repression; and violations of human rights. Rebellion against government and adherence to extremist groups is often connected to poverty, extremely high unemployment rates and a general sense of insecurity. I believe that, if we want to fight the menace of Al Shabaab and other terrorist groups effectively, it is important to cooperate with countries affected by terrorism in order to improve their security strategies. And I would also reiterate the importance of social inclusion processes.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 In the past, not a day has passed without hearing of Christian persecutions. There is terrible news in the media, which unfortunately often speaks of child victims. We also know that thousands of children and women are currently living in refugee camps overnight. We must do everything we can to protect these Christians from the atrocities that evoked the Dark Ages. Children and women deprived of their human rights must be protected from the horrors of wars and weapons anywhere in the world.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. In recent months, we have witnessed on too many occasions the barbarity of jihadist terrorism in Syria, Iraq, Libya and Kenya; a barbarity that focuses on the persecution of religious minorities, especially Christians, on many occasions. The murder of students in Kenya is nothing more than a drop in the ocean of crimes against Christians. Christians are one of the most violent groups of jihadist terrorist groups, so this community, with centuries of history in Iraq and Syria, is forced to flee their countries to save their lives. The question we must ask ourselves is how long we will look the other way, when we will raise our voices for those who do not have it and are persecuted in their countries of origin for their religious status. Peaceful coexistence is not only desirable, but is possible in view of centuries of common history. We must fight with all the tools at our we have to eradicate the scourge of jihadist terrorism and guarantee to all people the right to freedom of thought, conscience and religion.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution because it condemns in the strongest terms the deliberate terrorist attack by Al Shabab on 2 April 2015 in Garissa, in which 147 university students were killed and another 79 injured. I condemn all human rights violations, particularly when murderers justify deaths by religion, belief or ethnicity. Freedom of religion is a fundamental right and we strongly condemn any violence or discrimination on the grounds of religion. Violence in Nigeria and Kenya reveals that terrorism is a threat that requires a global solution. I believe that the EU should promote freedom and religious tolerance and support Kenya and Nigeria to address the root causes of radicalisation. Bombs, suicide bombings, sexual slavery and other forms of violence, as well as abductions by terrorist sects in Africa constitute crimes against humanity.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. In the strongest terms, the Resolution condemns the deliberate terrorist attack by Al Shabab on 2 April 2015 in Garissa, in which 147 university students were killed and another 79 injured. We condemn all human rights violations, particularly when people are killed on the basis of their religion, beliefs and ethnicity. Freedom of religion is a fundamental right and we strongly condemn any violence or discrimination on the grounds of religion. I voted in favour of the resolution adopted because violence in Nigeria and Kenya reveals that terrorism is a threat that requires a comprehensive solution. We Socialists believe that the EU should promote religious freedom and interreligious tolerance, and support Kenya and Nigeria to address the root causes of radicalisation. Bombs, suicide bombings, sexual slavery and other forms of violence, as well as abductions by terrorist sects in Africa constitute crimes against humanity.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
