text: in writing. \u2012 Christians are now victims of unprecedented persecution. In recent years, the European Union has declared itself the champion of all human rights. However, the right to religious freedom is being systematically violated today. Thanks to the PPE's amendments, the resolution voted on today finally speaks for itself and is not afraid to say forcefully that Christians are today the most persecuted religious community in the world. We have said that the defence of Christians must be a priority for the EU and that a military training mission must be set up in Kenya as soon as possible and that the Kenyan authorities must be provided with economic and structural means to combat terrorism. The time has come for Europe to say without fear that we are all Christians.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. Less than a month ago, we all witnessed yet another terrorist group attack on our freedoms. The massacre in Al Shabaab on the Kenyan campus in Garissa, which cost the lives of 149 Christian students, is, unfortunately, a frightening act of repression of freedom of religion and access to education. I welcome the motion for a resolution on the persecution of Christians in the world in connection with the sad event in Kenya, offering full support to the April 2015 declaration by the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, and those of UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon to promote peace actions. , security and stability in Kenya and the excellent work of the African Union missions carried out by AMISOM and the EU Special Representative for the Horn of Africa continues to be supported by all means in our possession.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. U2012 Recent attacks in Kenya require the international community to express its condemnation of such aggressions again. Hence my vote in favour of the Resolution on the persecution of Christians in the world in connection with the murder of students in Kenya by the terrorist group Al Shabab. This terrorist group has put students in their spotlight. The most recent occasion was the attack in Garissa on 2 April, in which 147 students were killed. These young people were victimized for their desire for university studies and for their religious beliefs. We have witnessed a marked increase in terrorist attacks on religious groups around the world, and Al Shabab's attacks were deliberately targeting education and religion, an attack on fundamental human rights. This Resolution provides support to the Kenyan authorities. We need you to continue working to identify and stop the terrorists.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because the latest massacres against Christians are unacceptable and very shocking. Freedom of religion is a fundamental right, and the European Union must act at the international level to defend its Judeo-Christian values, combat Islamist terrorism and help Christians live in peace and security.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I am concerned about the situation of Christians, persecution, murder in Kenya. Attacks are not only on Christians, but also on other religious groups. The violence perpetrated by violent terrorist groups, including al-Shabab, is not only a violation of human rights, but is contrary to human nature. The right to live and carry out his religious activities is a fundamental right. And the international community must respond and provide humanitarian aid.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: in writing. In the strongest terms, the Resolution condemns the deliberate terrorist attack by Al Shabab on 2 April 2015 in Garissa, in which 147 university students were killed and another 79 injured. We condemn all human rights violations, particularly when people are killed on the basis of their religion, beliefs and ethnicity. Freedom of religion is a fundamental right and we strongly condemn any violence or discrimination on the grounds of religion. I voted in favour of the resolution adopted because violence in Nigeria and Kenya reveals that terrorism is a threat that requires a comprehensive solution. We Socialists believe that the EU should promote religious freedom and interreligious tolerance, and support Kenya and Nigeria to address the root causes of radicalisation. Bombs, suicide bombings, sexual slavery and other forms of violence, as well as abductions by terrorist sects in Africa constitute crimes against humanity.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this motion for a resolution and indeed virtually all of the amendments. Some of these amendments referred to other areas, such as the Arab world, and to ISIS atrocities, and were not directly linked to the Kenyan massacre. Nonetheless I was happy to support them, as was the majority of the Parliament, because this sends a strong message about the systematic singling out and killing of Christians by different groups. There is no doubt that the persecution of Christians is intensifying. The Pew Institute in Washington has conducted research in 13 countries and found that Christians face varying degrees of persecution. The International Society for Human Rights has found that 80% of religious freedom violations in the world today are directed against Christians. This resolution sends a strong message.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. U2012 Vote for. Against the persecution of Christians in Africa and anywhere in the world.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because, in my opinion, the tragic situation of Christians in the world, particularly in Africa or the Muslim part of Asia, needs to be publicised. It is high time to understand that we are dealing with a terrible clash of civilizations, in which Christianity is a persecuted, murdered party, and the material achievements of Christianity are destroyed in an unprecedented way. Christians are currently the most persecuted religious group in the world and improving this situation can be a real goal for the European Union.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Voted with a resolution on the latest developments in Kenya, because the tragedy that has befallen Kenya is truly immense. Innocent young victims killed in the massacre of the terrorist group al-Shabaab and all their closest mourners are thus shown the European Parliament's rooster.  It's the least we could do for the great pain of the Kenyan people. I expect the international community to do everything by all means to put an end to the killing of innocent people.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution condemns the persecution of Christians. As attacks on Christians have reportedly increased in recent months, there is an urgent need for measures to be put in place as quickly as possible to deal with persecution and avoid new ones. The proposal aims to strengthen dialogue with Christians and urges Muslim leaders to condemn terrorist attacks against Christians. It advocates cooperation with African states in the fight against terrorism. To do so, it is implementing the creation of a delegation of mediators and experts specializing in the issue of intercultural and interreligious dialogue in order to stimulate negotiations and mediation of conflicts by United Nations envoys. Above all, it stresses that international jihadist terrorism is financed by money laundering, drug trafficking and corruption and calls on the Commission and Member States to strengthen their cooperation with third countries and to adopt stricter legislation on freezing suspicious assets. Even if the solutions implemented are not yet sufficient, this proposal is an urgent first step for Christians.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution in its condemnation of the recent surge in violence and persecution of Christians in Africa and the Middle East, which has seen many people abducted and terrorised, forced to flee their homes, and lose their lives in a brutal and horrifying manner. As enshrined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, all people have the right to freedom of religion and belief and to live in their traditional homelands in conditions of dignify, equality and safety, rights which have been significantly violated by the perpetrators of these acts of violence. I find the recent attack by Al-Shabaab on university students in Kenya particularly abhorrent, in its intention to undermine education and exploit religious difference the country, in order to deprive it of future economic and cultural growth, shake its stability and threaten the dignity of all its citizens. I have therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I condemn in the strongest terms the deliberate terrorist attack perpetrated by Al-Shabaab in Garissa. Terrorism must be condemned whatever the ideology behind it – be it political or under the pretext of religion. Al-Shabaab, ISIS and Al-Qaida clearly target all civilians, no matter what religion. Singling out Christians in Kenya is a tactic aimed at stoking ethnic and religious tensions. The aim is to divide Kenyan religious and ethnic communities and to create conflict between the Muslims and the non-Muslims in the country. Violent extremists and terrorists succeed when people start mistrusting each other because of social boundaries and stereotypes. We cannot allow this to happen. The fight against extremism is not about Christians versus Muslims, or Muslims versus Jews: it is about all citizens versus extremists. We must stop these religious divisions and we must stand together against terror and hatred. We must stand for respect and diversity. We must unite and promote our values of equality, freedom, and democracy.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. We are well aware of the serious events in Kenya, namely on the Garissa university campus. A terrorist group, Somali extremists affiliated with al-Qaeda, has massacred more than 140 Christian students. I whole much support Parliament's voice in condemning the events as a whole, not isolated, incidentally when we consider the raids in Al-Shabaab last summer. I express my deepest condolences to the families of the victims and to the entire population and offer my sincerest solidarity to all Christians persecuted on the African continent. The European Union will be at the forefront of increasing its efforts to promote peace by encouraging mechanisms for conflict resolution.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution because it condemns the massacres of Christians worldwide, including the killings of nearly 150 students by Al-Qaeda in Kenya. It also has the merit of denouncing attacks on churches. Finally, it is realistic in calling on Muslim leaders to condemn the persecution and massacres of Christians.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Vote for. It is absolutely necessary for the European Union to take a stand in condemning the murder of Christian students in that country, since it was Christians who were targeted. This highlights the persecution they are also subjected to in other parts of the world (Copts in Libya, Christians of the East in general, in Iraq, Syria but also in Pakistan...)  The European Union must do all it can to help these Christians by supporting all military actions against Islamist terrorists. All military cooperation, particularly from African countries in the Kenya region, should therefore be supported. Muslim leaders must condemn these crimes against Christians and thus participate in the fight against these terrorists who call themselves Muslims. The European Union must support but leave it to the states with any independence of action because it is used to wanting to impose itself in their political decisions. I am voting for it because it was essential that the European Union condemn the persecution of Christians.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I share the unequivocal condemnation for this Resolution of the massacre committed on 2 April by the terrorist group Al Shabab in the attack on the university campus of the Kenyan city of Garissa, near the border with Somalia, a massacre in which 148 people, mainly students, were killed.  However, I voted against this text because it does not address the fundamental problem in the area and does not take into account fundamental factors, such as the US military intervention in Somalia in 1992 with disastrous implications still being paid for by the peoples of the region, the responsibility of the former colonial powers in promoting conflict and in plundering the natural resources of the Horn of Africa , land grabbing, high poverty rates, hundreds of thousands of refugees, infant mortality, hunger or malnutrition...   In the majors, it victimizes Christianity, diverting the focus from the source of the problem, and maintains the logic of the "global fight against terrorism" with a military approach that fosters EU military cooperation with the governments of the countries in the area.

name: Olle LUDVIGSSON
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats think it is very important that the European Parliament condemns the horrific terrorist attack on the University of Garissa in Kenya, in April this year. We therefore support the european Parliament's joint resolution, but believe that the resolution should have been more inclusive in terms of which groups suffer persecution and violence because of their faith. We are concerned that this type of violence has increased in recent years and we strongly reject any form of discrimination, violence or intolerance that targets people's religious affiliation - regardless of which religious group is affected.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the murder of students in Kenya by the terrorist group Al-Shabab. This one of the bloodiest attacks on the academic community confirms the great determination of terrorists to fight education and strengthen religious divisions. Schools and educational institutions are a frequent target of attacks. According to a 2011 UNESCO report, an estimated 28 million young people have lost access to education as a result of armed conflicts. Attacks on schools are aimed both at highlighting the weaknesses of local authorities in defending civilians and at highlighting the ideological ground that educational institutions promote values incompatible with the religious beliefs of terrorists. Therefore, in response to such attacks, it is crucial to strengthen local authorities and implement a common strategy to combat terrorism. This fight is currently one of the biggest challenges facing the European Union.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I am very concerned about the situation of Christians in some Third World countries where they are being targeted. However, I abstained because I think that the EU must not become a military organisation and train soldiers in Africa. Similar tasks fall under the UN.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The murder of 147 students, Christian believers, at a university in the city of Garissa, Kenya, 3 days before Easter, is just one in a series of attacks on Christians. The topic of refugees we are discussing in Parliament these days is also linked to the persecution of Christians. Muslim refugees have thrown into the sea 12 refugees of the Catholic faith after a religious quarrel on board. There is great concern among all Member States about the atmosphere of intolerance and violence, especially by terrorist groups, and I support all initiatives to promote community dialogue and mutual respect. I supported a resolution offering condolences to the families of all victims and condemning all forms of discrimination on religious grounds. Attacks on the Christian community violate fundamental human rights - the right to freedom of thought and religion.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Freedom of religion is a fundamental human right of every person. Therefore, every democratic country is obliged to condemn any abuse or spread of religion for political, economic, national or other reasons. Christians are among the most persecuted religious minorities, as evidenced in particular by the situation in Africa, where religious intolerance and hatred are the reason for reprehensual acts of terrorism. In doing so, the actors of terrorism themselves abuse the interpretation of their religion in defence of their actions. It is essential and urgent that the Commission and the governments of all democratic countries make use of all available diplomatic means and start an active dialogue with the governments of countries where religious arbitralness and targeted destruction of human lives are taking place.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament of 29 April 2015. This is a resolution that rightly condemns unequivocally the persecution of Christians around the world as well as the murders of students in Kenya by the jihadists of the al-Shabab group.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. In view of the tragedy of 2 April 2014, in which more than 148 people were murdered and several seriously injured after a 15-hour hostage-taking, the majority of whom were students of Christian faith, and the fact that this report condemns the persecution of Christians throughout the world as a whole, I agreed with this request.  It would have been desirable if the European Parliament had also given the reason for these murders by its name. Unfortunately, it was agreed at the last minute to remove the word Islam from the motion.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly condemn the recent terrorist attack on a university in Garissa County in Kenya, in which 147 students were killed and another 79 wounded. This is the most recent large-scale attack perpetrated by the Al-Qaida-affiliated terrorist group Al-Shabaab. It is important to draw attention to the fact that the group is more openly attempting to recruit Kenyans in its fight against the governments of Kenya and Somalia, taking advantage of the growing tensions between religious communities in the peripheral and coastal regions of Kenya.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the persecution of Christians around the world, in relation to the killing of students in Kenya by terror group Al-Shabaab. The resolution condemns in the strongest terms the deliberate terrorist attack perpetrated by Al-Shabaab on 2 April 2015 in Garissa, in which it assassinated 147 young, innocent university students and injured 79 others; and it condemns forcefully all violations of human rights, especially when people are killed on the basis of their religion, beliefs or ethnic origin. The resolution also expresses grave concern at the abuse of religion by the perpetrators of terrorist acts in several areas of the world, and at the proliferation of episodes of intolerance, repression and violence directed against religious groups, including Christians.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution deals with the killing of students in Kenya by the terrorist group Al-Shabaab. It recalls a number of fundamental principles to which every citizen must say he or she is attached. A clear condemnation of the massacre of 2 April 2015 in Garissa, which killed 147 young students and injured 79 injured, is registered.  The act is all the more barbaric because it took place in a higher education institution, a symbol of emancipation. It is also because Christian minorities are the most persecuted in the world, as this resolution reminds us.  That is why I could only vote in favour of this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which strongly condemns the persecution of Christians around the world, particularly in Kenya with the recent murder of Garissa University students by Al-Shabaab terrorists. The number of attacks on religious minorities has increased sharply in recent months, and it is necessary to remember that Christians are the religious minority currently the most persecuted.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We strongly condemn the killing, on 2 April, of 148 students on the campus of Garissa University in Kenya by al-Shabaab militants. We express our strong and heartfelt support for the people, condemning all forms of terrorism in the country and defending the protection of human rights, in particular the right of young people to education, regardless of their religious affiliation.  We therefore call on the Kenyan Government to launch a thorough investigation in order to identify those responsible and bring them to justice. The European Union must commit itself to providing all the necessary support, both financially and logistically, to support and coordinate the fight against terrorist groups in the Sahel region. We need to launch a common strategy to combat radicalisation and terrorist financing in Africa and around the world. Let us remember that terrorism is a global threat and therefore requires a global response.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Religious freedom in many parts of the world is under threat. Today, more than in the past, we are witnessing a more intense, more serious and ruthlessly ideologised persecutory phenomenon in which Christians are the target of attacks by Islamic extremists, either because they are considered a danger to Islam or because they are considered an obstacle to the path towards the Islamisation of Middle Eastern countries. In this context, particularly violent and heinous was the massacre in Kenya by an Islamist commando who broke into a college near Sarissa, killing 147 largely Christian youths. The aim of the extremists was not only to spread terror and blood, but also to impoverish the country of its future and dignity. The international community must react, it cannot stand by and allow acts of violence such as those in Kenya to re-occur. Religious freedom is one of the fundamental freedoms of the person, it must be guaranteed everywhere. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 I do not even remember a plenary session where we would not have held a minute's silence to remember the victims of the unfortunate events of that month. The massacre of 142 students at the University of Garissa in Kenya is of paramount importance, only because they were Christians. It was actually a cultural-conscientious declaration of war. With the Garissa massacre, the attackers wanted to create religious conflict and fear, which could strain relations between Muslims and Christians wherever they live. We must recognize and beware of the principle of collective guilt and hatred, for which it is difficult to present an antidote. Our sense of helplessness must not poison our diverse world, our inevitably shared future. Religious freedom is guaranteed in the Western world, but only a quarter of Christians live in advanced democracies. In the meantime, extremist representatives of religious ideologies are burning the teachings of the Bible with fire and iron, and persecuting their followers. Religious freedom has been declining all over the world for years, and we can't just sit back and watch. Everything from cruel, anti-religious violence to strong discrimination happens. What we need most, and yet it has a downward trend, is tolerance. I would therefore like to draw the attention of all those present to the fact that we should not stand idly by and watch these unacceptable crimes that threaten the most basic human rights. History has often shown that tolerance has been won by well-directed, decisive and consistent action!

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 The most recent terrorist attack in Kenya was unfortunately aimed at young people, students and, by them, clearly affecting the education and education of this people. The terrorist group al-Shabaab has regularly targeted young people, students, schools and other educational institutions in Kenya, Somalia and Uganda, becoming one of the most dangerous in the world.  I signed and voted on this resolution because it strongly condemns these terrorist acts, while stressing the need for action. One of them calls on the EU to implement a programme of military training missions in Kenya and to provide modern equipment, working with and training Kenyan military and police forces to combat terrorism and prevent the expansion of the al-Shabaab group.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported the joint resolution because I believe that barbaric and tendencies religious acts in Kenya should not go unpunished. 148 students were killed in cold blood and nearly 80 others wounded. 148 people who wanted and were prepared to work for the future of their country!  It is unacceptable that the responsible Kenyan authorities have failed to respond to this attack, despite preliminary information that such an attack may take place. I strongly believe that the European Commission must propose effective anti-money laundering and indirect sponsorship schemes for terrorist organisations, because structures such as al-Shabaab are funded through such schemes.  The role of the European Union, especially in this part of the world, which is becoming a source of increasing instability and radicalisation, needs to be strengthened.  Instability in our neighbouring regions will lead to new waves of immigration, especially to the southern EU member states, including my country - Bulgaria. For years now, the Union has been failing to deal effectively with immigrant waves. It is time for effective action, not just promises and strategies on paper.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ The world these days is facing a new kind of menace, one that does not just threaten lives but is harmful to culture and education. These fanatics seek to throw us back into the Dark Ages, to return to times best forgotten. I have voted in favour of this resolution because I firmly believe in our need to stand up to them. The European Union, which in truth is a beacon of democracy, freedom, education and culture in comparison with the rest of the world, should do more to protect others seeking a better life, especially youth and students in third countries. I do hope we will find ways to help the survivors of these attacks, and my heart goes out to the families of the victims!

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. This resolution echoes the recent massacre of young Kenyan Christian students by a terrorist group, Al-Shabaab. They attack not only the youth of this country because of their religious affiliation, but also because the university represents a symbol, that of knowledge, freedom of thought and conscience, freedoms that these extremist groups actively fight. In order to protect persecuted minorities, but also to oppose the barbarity of some fundamentalist groups, I voted in favour of this joint resolution.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. I supported the proposal. All terrorist attacks must be unequivocally condemned and the fight against terrorism must be stepped up. The European Union must work closely with the African Union and African countries to combat extremist groups and protect Christians from attacks. We must also support African peacekeeping capabilities and train police forces and military in Kenya and other African countries. We must ensure that eu development and humanitarian aid reaches those in need and that it is used as efficiently as possible. We must also help fight corruption in Africa.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The JRC condemns the heinous crimes, both of Al Shabaab in Kenya and of all the likes of the criminal groups. It highlights the enormous responsibilities of the EU and its allies, the US and NATO, for equipping and supporting all these groups when they wanted to use them as tools for their imperialist interventions in Syria, Libya, Iraq, Africa and especially Somalia, the Sahel region, Nigeria and elsewhere. We strongly condemn the murders of Christians and persons belonging to other religious, ethnic or ethnic minorities but are opposed to any attempt to separate workers on racial, religious or ethnic grounds, as pursued by the amendments tabled. The resolution is part of an effort to make the protection of Christian populations the new pretext for imperialist interventions and wars by the EU, the US and NATO in the wider region of the South-East Mediterranean, the Middle East and North Africa, in which the Greek co-government is also active on behalf of the bourgeoisie, putting the people at enormous risk. For these reasons, the resolution calls on the EU to take military action and consolidate its military presence in Africa, a presence that the peoples of the region will pay dearly for with their blood.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the number of attacks on religious minorities, and in particular christians, has grown exponentially lately, christians are subjected to beatings and arrests every day, especially in certain areas of the Arab world where jihadist terrorists are located, for these reasons I would vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. Christians are the most provoked group of people in the world today. They are subjected to persecution in more than sixty countries around the world. In the last year compared to the previous year, the number of Christians who died because of their religion has doubled, and this shameful trend continues. It is estimated that more than 150,000 Christians worldwide lose their lives annually.  The main reason for the persecution of Christians today in most countries is Islamic extremism. The brutal murder of 147 Kenyan university students is a continuation of the terror being carried out against Christians that needs to be put to an end. Condemning kenya's massacre and persecution of all religious communities, I supported this resolution that warns of violations of religious freedom. Freedom of religion is a fundamental human right on which our society is based and for the preservation we must fight.  Religious identity is an integral part of a man's identity and everyone must, without exception, be allowed to practice their religion. We must condemn all violence in the name of religion unreservedly, otherwise we participate in it. I believe that the European Parliament must recognise Christians as a persecuted religious community and clearly condemn the violence against them because of their faith in Jesus Christ, which is growing every day, and take effective steps to combat Islamic extremism.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. It is high time that the European Union took an interest in the persecution of Christians. Unfortunately, they are the most persecuted minority in many countries. This is not the case in Kenya, but the crossing of the border by the terrorist group Al-Shabaab poses a serious security problem. The fight against Islamic fundamentalism and its terrorist methods must be a priority in international cooperation. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I fully stand with the Kenyan people in his determination to fight all forms of terrorism in his country and to defend his own human rights, especially the right to education. The Kenyan government should take responsibility and respond to al-Shabaab's violence and its root causes. I regret the delayed police response and welcome the immediate consequences imposed by the Kenyan authorities. Freedom of religion is a fundamental right and therefore any violence or discrimination based on religion must be condemned in the strongest terms. The EU needs to maintain support for AMISOM and continue to fund EUTM Somalia to ensure adequate financial and human resources to support the work of the EU Special Representative for the Horn of Africa and direct access to the EU's ZSOP and development and humanitarian policy structures.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I support the European Parliament's resolution to persecute Christians around the world in connection with the killing of students in Kenya by the Islamist terrorist group al-Shabaab. I strongly condemn the April 4, 2015 terrorist attack carried out by a Somali Islamist group at a university in Garissa in northeastern Kenya, which ended after a 15-hour siege with 148 people killed, most of them Christian students.  I condemn targeted terrorist attacks on educational institutions and facilities in order to undermine the education and dignity of all citizens and create mistrust and disassion between communities. Over the past few months, the world has seen a significantly higher number of attacks on religious minorities, especially Christians who are victims of daily killings, beatings or arrests behind jihadist terrorists, most of them in some parts of the Arab world.  As an MEP, I affirm and support the inaliething right of all religious and ethnic minorities living in Iraq and Syria, including Christians, to continue living in their historical and traditional spaces in a dignified, equal and safe manner.  I urge the Commission, the international community and organisations such as the UN to prevent any attempt to violate the right to freedom of religion and belief through a proactive and preventive approach. I firmly believe that race, religion, citizenship or orientation are irrelevant when we mention human rights.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I am seriously concerned about the increase in attacks on religious minorities in recent times, especially against Christians. We have seen in recent reports that Christians are being attacked by jihadist terrorists, particularly in parts of the Arab world. There are more and more episodes of intolerance and repression towards Christians, such as the recent events in Kenya with the massacre of students on the campus of Garissa University, perpetrated by the terrorist group Al-Shabaab. All religious communities should live in conditions of dignity, equality and security. We must combat international jihadist terrorism, which is one of the main architects of persecution against Christians. The EU must combat this criminal organisation, which is financed by illegal money laundering, extortion, corruption and drug trafficking, by strengthening cooperation with third countries for better exchange of information and for combating together all criminal organisations that undermine the values of our society.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. Following the recent persecution of Christians in Kenya, the European Parliament has decided to react and denounce attacks on this religious group. Attacks targeting Christians have increased sharply in recent months, mainly by jihadist terrorists in parts of the Arab world. After lengthy negotiations in Parliament, MEPs finally recognized Christians as a religious minority. I voted in favour of this report and stress the importance of this resolution. The Christians in the regions of the Arab world were asking for Europe's help and we finally answered their call.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. In recent months, in recent months, we have seen an exponential increase in the number of attacks on religious groups, including Christians, around the world, and innocent people are executed, beaten and detained every day because of their religion or belief. The latest terrorist attack in Garissa, Kenya, perpetrated against young people in particular, poses a threat to education and therefore to the country's future in general. This resolution condemns in the strongest terms the terrorist attack by al-Shabaab which, on 2 April 2015, killed 147 university students in Garissa, leaving 79 injured. It also energetically condemns all violations of human rights, unequivocally repudiating hate crimes, whether motivated by the professed religion, convictions assumed or by the ethnicity concerned. Thus, because I believe that religious freedom is a fundamental human right and because it condemns any kind of violence or discrimination on the basis of faith, I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. On 2 April, in Garissa, Kenya, 147 students were coldly murdered, 79 others wounded, by members of the terrorist group Al-Shabaab. The reasons for the crime? Religion, convictions, origin...  The number of attacks on religious minorities around the world has increased dramatically in recent months. Christians were the target. That is why, this afternoon, I wholeheartedly supported all the amendments tabled by the EPP recalling the relentlessness of the Christian community in the world.   Every day, hundreds of Christians are massacred, beaten and arrested by Islamist terrorists. More than 150,000 of them are murdered every year, just because they are Christians.  The murders of these Christian students reveal, once again, the horror spread by jihadist groups. A reality that shows how committed these armies, in the name of Islam, are in a planned strategy not only of territorial expansion, but of extermination.#MRK

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution in which we strongly condemn the terrorist attack in Kenya by Al-Shabaab that led to the deaths of 147 innocent young students. In this text, we recall that any violations of human rights and any attack on people because of their religion, beliefs or ethnic origin are intolerable.  In the face of these tragedies, the Kenyan authorities must take responsibility by combating violence and protecting the fundamental rights of its people. We also call on the European Union to act by taking coordinated action with other African countries, by collaborating with the African Union or by establishing a military training programme in Kenya. The persecution of Christians around the world is worrying: every day, Christians are massacred, beaten and arrested by terrorists exponentially. Christians like those in Iraq and Syria must be able to continue to live in their homelands. Freedom of religion is a fundamental right and it is the Union's priority to ensure that all religious communities live in safety.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. In the strongest terms, the Resolution condemns the deliberate terrorist attack by Al Shabab on 2 April 2015 in Garissa, in which 147 university students were killed and another 79 injured. We condemn all human rights violations, particularly when people are killed on the basis of their religion, beliefs and ethnicity. Freedom of religion is a fundamental right and we strongly condemn any violence or discrimination on the grounds of religion. I voted in favour of the resolution adopted because violence in Nigeria and Kenya reveals that terrorism is a threat that requires a comprehensive solution. We Socialists believe that the EU should promote religious freedom and interreligious tolerance, and support Kenya and Nigeria to address the root causes of radicalisation. Bombs, suicide bombings, sexual slavery and other forms of violence, as well as abductions by terrorist sects in Africa constitute crimes against humanity.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which condemns the recent attacks on Christian communities in different countries and reaffirms its solidarity with all persecuted Christians in different parts of Africa, including the atrocities committed in Kenya, Libya, Nigeria and Sudan. The number of attacks on religious minorities around the world, especially Christians, has increased exponentially in recent months. The number of Christians murdered each year now exceeds 150,000...

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Although the EPP Resolution was not adopted by 23 votes (296; 319; 19), we voted in favour, as a party group, the Joint Motion of the Political Groups of the Verts/ALE, EFDD, ALDE and S&D, which was thus adopted by a large majority (578;31;34) of the votes cast. While I regret that we were unable to pass a broader Joint Motion, I would like to point out that the vehement and unequivocal condemnation of this horrific massacre of 147 students at Garissa University in Kenya on 2 April last by the Somali-based terrorist group Al-Shabaab (the latest in a series of atrocities committed against Christians by this group) has united this house with one voice, and calls on the Commission and the Member States to support Kenya in its fight against extremism and social exclusion.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I was deeply shocked by the massacre of 147 students on the campus of Garissa University in Kenya and in supporting this text, I strongly condemn this terrorist attack.  It is necessary, in the wake of this tragedy, for the Union to provide the necessary support to Kenya to ensure peace and stability in the country and the region and to fight terrorism and the expansion of Al-Shabaab. EU cooperation with regional organisations such as the African Union is also crucial.  The resolution also condemns the terrorist attacks on Christians and other religious communities that have increased in recent months.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution condemning the atrocities committed in Kenya and, more generally, the persecution that has long afflicted religious and, above all, Christian minorities in the Middle East. For the PPE, however, this is, unfortunately, a half-victory because our text has not passed but the Socialist text in whose original version it was preferred not to point out that most of the persecuted are Christian. There were 14 amendments tabled by the EPP, 13 of which were adopted. That too is good news. It has, however, become quite clear that the term 'Christians' is a rather 'uncomfortable' word and to be forgotten for a large number of elected representatives in the European Parliament.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I share the unequivocal condemnation for this Resolution of the massacre committed on 2 April by the terrorist group Al Shabab in the attack on the university campus of the Kenyan city of Garissa, near the border with Somalia, a massacre in which 148 people, mainly students, were killed.  However, I voted against this text because it does not address the fundamental problem in the area and does not take into account fundamental factors, such as the US military intervention in Somalia in 1992 with disastrous implications still being paid for by the peoples of the region, the responsibility of the former colonial powers in promoting conflict and in plundering the natural resources of the Horn of Africa , land grabbing, high poverty rates, hundreds of thousands of refugees, infant mortality, hunger or malnutrition...   In the majors, it victimizes Christianity, diverting the focus from the source of the problem, and maintains the logic of the "global fight against terrorism" with a military approach that fosters EU military cooperation with the governments of the countries in the area.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today we welcomed the joint motion for a resolution on the killing of students in Kenya by the terror group Al-Shabaab. We condemn in the strongest terms the deliberate terrorist attack perpetrated by Al-Shabaab on 2 April 2015 in Garissa, in which it assassinated 147 young, innocent university students and injured 79 others. Members of the European Parliament call for a thorough, prompt, impartial and effective investigation to be carried out in order to identify those responsible and bring the perpetrators, organisers, financiers and sponsors of these reprehensible acts of terrorism to justice.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – In recent months, the number of attacks on religious minorities around the world, especially Christians, has increased enormously, and christians are murdered, beaten and arrested every day, especially in certain parts of the Arab world. The terrorist attack by the Islamist group al-Shabab on a university in Garissa in northeastern Kenya, which resulted in a 15-hour siege in which 148 people were killed, most of them Christian students, cannot go unnoticed. We are witnessing an increasing incidence of intolerance, oppression and violence against Christians in some parts of the Arab world, even though members of various religious groups in the region have lived together in peace for centuries. Support for international efforts in the fight against ISIS and the advance of jihadists is therefore essential. The UN, the international community and the EU must take a proactive and preventive approach in relation to any violation of freedom of religion and belief, which is enshrined as a fundamental right in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's resolution to persecute Christians around the world in connection with the killing of students in Kenya by the terrorist group al-Shabaab. According to witnesses, the terrorists just singled out Christians for execution. But Kenya is no exception when we talk about attacks on Christians. 70% of Christians in Iraq were forced to flee their homes. Syria's Christian population has fallen from 30% to less than 10% in less than 100 years. Christians today are the most endangered religious minority in the world, and it is especially important to me that the resolution included amendments from the European People's Party that nevertheless put the greatest emphasis on the persecution of Christians as a religious group.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. - I support the proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the persecution of Christians in the world and the attitude towards the killings of students in Kenya. Lately we are witnessing a sharp increase in extremism and terrorism. Attacks on religious minorities, especially Christians, in some parts of the Arab world is a serious problem that we must approach systematically and by agreement.  More than 150,000 Christians are killed each year. But according to the latest developments, we see that extreme Islamism and terrorist attacks are spreading sharply to the rest of the world, especially in Europe. In the immediate vicinity of Croatia is Bosnia and Herzegovina, where the movement of extreme Islamism has taken on worrying proportions. The basis for starting to address violence and threats from Islamists are instruments that will stop the financing of terrorist acts and cut off the terrorist organization's arms supply.  The terrorist group al-Shabaab in kenya's university siege killed at least 147 students, mostly Christians. The terrorist group al-Shabab always carries out strikes, destroying humanitarian convoys, religious facilities and rallies. That is why I welcome the proposed resolution condemning recent attacks on Christian communities in different countries and expressing solidarity with the families of the victims. It is also important to note that freedom of religion and belief has been violated in 82 out of 196 countries.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am very glad that the European Parliament is not relenting in its efforts to defend human rights in general, including freedom of religion. Freedom of religion is a fundamental right. Unfortunately, in recent years, the number of deaths has been rising, killing only for their religion. I therefore fully support the resolution on the persecution of Christians in the world in connection with the murder of students in Kenya by the terrorist group al-Shabaab. The terrorist organization murdered 147 college students, mostly Christians, adding more innocents to the list of victims of its barbaric acts. Al-Shabaab comes from Somalia, has links to Boko Haram and al-Qaeda, and is conducting terrorist operations in Kenya because the Kenyan government is taking part in the fight against terrorism in Somalia as part of an African Union action, along with the Somali government and other regional governments. It uses the composition of Kenyan society, made up of Christians and Muslims, to spread fear and hatred.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We must take measures to combat the problem of persecution of Christians.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported and considered it important to adopt the resolution, not only out of outrage over the brutal murder of Kenyan students, but also because the case shows with great force the global nature of terrorism across countries and politics. This is a matter for the whole international community, also a European matter, which the European Parliament cannot leave unscathed. I take our action for granted because, as a politician, I have always been particularly sensitive to attacks by religious fanatics/terrorists because of their origin, race or, as may be the case, their religious affiliation or even their lack of religion. I welcome the fact that the decision refers to the responsibility of the Kenyan Government and the need for international support so that the authorities can better combat the terrorist threat to the Kenyan population. The responsibility of the international community cannot be avoided either, because this dramatic case proves once again that, in addition to nationalist and religious fanaticism, poverty, social misery and social exclusion are the main breeding ground for international terrorism. For my part, I also support the EU and the EP, with the help of the European External Action Service, to continue to closely monitor the situation and, if necessary, to take the necessary political steps to prevent similar tragedies.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. We cannot accept that people are killed for the sole reason of their faith, regardless of their religion. I therefore voted in favour of this resolution. I would like to share my great concern at the abusive invocation of religion by the perpetrators of terrorist acts in many parts of the world. We cannot fail to denounce the instrumentalization of religion in different conflicts. The growing number of terrorist attacks on churches around the world, including the one that killed 14 people in Pakistan on March 15, 2015, is a cause for concern.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution which condemns the terrorist attacks in Kenya. I support the implementation of an EU military training mission in Kenya that would help the Kenyan authorities to fight terrorism and to prevent the expansion of Al-Shabaab. I also believe that the EU should strengthen its efforts to ensure peace and stability in the country and the region. This should be done in cooperation with the African Union. I voted against all the amendments relating to Da’esh or the military intervention in Syria because they had nothing to do with this dramatic attack and the situation in Kenya. Those are two different issues, which need to be addressed separately.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The world is now witnessing an unprecedented persecution of Christians who die every day under the swords and bullets of a radical Islamism once again conquering. So this initiative is a good thing and I support his vote. Unfortunately, these persecutions are often the consequences of inconsistent policies carried out by the diplomacy of certain member states subject to the will of the United States. The most striking example is that some of the veteran defenders of Christians in this European Parliament are members of the French UMP, which was directly responsible and designed to destabilize some middle Eastern countries, in particular, which subsequently saw their religious minorities persecuted and massacred. I therefore support any idea of combating these persecutions and any international initiative of honest and balanced cooperation in the defence of Christians around the world.  I'm voting FOR.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has a duty to act urgently and firmly to defend barbarously persecuted Christians in the vicinity of the EU borders and increasingly threatened, even on the territory of the Member States. It is a brutal attack on religious freedom, the spirit of tolerance and the values that form the foundation of the democratic world. More than 150,000 Christians fall victim to religious, Islamist terrorism annually, which is on an alarming offensive that commits a coordinated response. The abominable massacres, the kidnappings of people, the devastated churches, the exodus from regions of the Middle East and Africa, the attacks on schools and universities, such as the attack on Kenyan students – are means of religious purification incompatible with the human civilization of the 21st century.  Beyond the protests, I believe that European states have an obligation to act concretely to defend those targeted by jihadist terrorism: from combating radical propaganda and ways of financing international terrorism, to stepping up efforts to stop the Islamic State offensive in a growing area of unleashed terror stretching from Niger to Afghanistan, with its core in Iraq and Syria. All these targeted states must be effectively supported in the face of the growing threat of extremist groups, as part of a broad strategy to counter the global threat of Islamist.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 Action must be taken against terrorism at all levels. The European Parliament's decision states that freedom of religion is a fundamental right and strongly condemns any form of violence or discrimination based on religion. Terrorist attacks in recent months can only be prevented by joint international action. The actual answer in this case should be through joint actions with other African countries. I supported the decision by my vote.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: in writing. In the strongest terms, the Resolution condemns the deliberate terrorist attack by Al Shabab on 2 April 2015 in Garissa, in which 147 university students were killed and another 79 injured. We condemn all human rights violations, particularly when people are killed on the basis of their religion, beliefs and ethnicity. Freedom of religion is a fundamental right and we strongly condemn any violence or discrimination on the grounds of religion. I voted in favour of the resolution adopted because violence in Nigeria and Kenya reveals that terrorism is a threat that requires a comprehensive solution. We Socialists believe that the EU should promote religious freedom and interreligious tolerance, and support Kenya and Nigeria to address the root causes of radicalisation. Bombs, suicide bombings, sexual slavery and other forms of violence, as well as abductions by terrorist sects in Africa constitute crimes against humanity.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I share the unequivocal condemnation for this Resolution of the massacre committed on 2 April by the terrorist group Al Shabab in the attack on the university campus of the Kenyan city of Garissa, near the border with Somalia, a massacre in which 148 people, mainly students, were killed.  However, I voted against this text because it does not address the fundamental problem in the area and does not take into account fundamental factors, such as the US military intervention in Somalia in 1992 with disastrous implications still being paid for by the peoples of the region, the responsibility of the former colonial powers in promoting conflict and in plundering the natural resources of the Horn of Africa , land grabbing, high poverty rates, hundreds of thousands of refugees, infant mortality, hunger or malnutrition...   In the majors, it victimizes Christianity, diverting the focus from the source of the problem, and maintains the logic of the "global fight against terrorism" with a military approach that fosters EU military cooperation with the governments of the countries in the area.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. I voted against this resolution. It is clear that we must condemn terrorist acts and the European Parliament could have done so much earlier for the students of Garissa, whoever the perpetrators, whatever the victims and whatever they are in the world.  However, this resolution seems to me to be very unmanting. Firstly by its title, modified at the last moment to denounce the persecution of Christians all over the world. Then by the many amendments added by the EPP which gives the impression that the massacre in Kenya has become a pretext. So yes, the tragic event of the Garissa attack caused the majority of Christian deaths and I regret all these deaths.  However, it seems to me to recall that at the global level, it is Muslims who are the most victims of terrorism and that other religious minorities are also affected around the world.  I denounce the instrumentalization of this resolution to defend civilizational and belligerent theses to which I am strongly opposed.  This is not how we will fight against the rise of communitarianism. It's quite the opposite.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 While expressing our repudiation and dismay at the massacre of students in Kenya, we cannot fail to demarcate ourselves from the tone of this report which, under the cover of righteous indignation, seeks to spread a message of almost hysterical hatred, completely inversing the roles between the victim and the algoz.  Regardless of ethical and religious motivations, today's victims are the peoples on whom rich capitalist countries drop their "humanitarian" bombs, destroying millennial societies and indiscriminately killing men, women, children and the elderly. Using the pretext of human rights, for which these countries are in charge of a supreme judge, so-called "democratic" governments are paving the way for multinational companies, continuing the saqueand corruption, thus keeping the African continent under the paw of capital.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. The negotiations of this resolution condemning the persecution of Christians in Kenya showed how much Christian is actually in the European Parliament: little. Christians in Europe and the world should realistically adjust their expectations and not expect too much protection and commitment from the EU. The EU does not recognise its own Christian roots. Respect for its Christian foundation, however, is crucial to the identity and unity of Europe. The consequence of this institutional denial of identity is relativism. He is already working in the European Parliament. Only in this way can I explain to myself the slow political opinion-forming, which unfortunately only became inevitable due to the brutal topicality of the day, and the lack of effective aid for the benefit of persecuted Christians in the world. During the negotiations, a majority of the political groups refused to condemn the murder of Christians on the basis of their religious beliefs. This condemnation was only voted into by amendments in plenary with the votes of the ECR Group. Although the joint motion for a resolution fell far short of expectations, the Christian Democrat EPP (CDU/CSU) preferred to support an inadequate draft rather than professing its values and maintaining its own motion for a resolution from the outset. I voted logically in favour of the motion for a resolution, which I tabled on behalf of my ECR Group together with group colleagues, and the amendments to enhance and finally adopt the inadequate joint motion for a resolution.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because attacks on religious groups, and especially against Christians, have increased tremendously around the world. Every day people are slaughtered, beaten and arrested because of their religion and beliefs. This absurdity must be put to an end and the international community must finally react.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The JRC condemns the heinous crimes, both of Al Shabaab in Kenya and of all the likes of the criminal groups. It highlights the enormous responsibilities of the EU and its allies, the US and NATO, for equipping and supporting all these groups when they wanted to use them as tools for their imperialist interventions in Syria, Libya, Iraq, Africa and especially Somalia, the Sahel region, Nigeria and elsewhere. We strongly condemn the murders of Christians and persons belonging to other religious, ethnic or ethnic minorities, but we are opposed to any attempt to separate workers on racial, religious or ethnic grounds, as the amendments tabled seek. The resolution is part of an effort to make the protection of Christian populations the new pretext for imperialist interventions and wars by the EU, the US and NATO in the wider region of the South-East Mediterranean, the Middle East and North Africa, in which the Greek co-government is also active on behalf of the bourgeoisie, putting the people at enormous risk. For these reasons, the resolution calls on the EU to take military action and consolidate its military presence in Africa, a presence that the peoples of the region will pay dearly for with their blood.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 I am glad that, at the beginning of the plenary session, we managed to approve the amendment of the title of the resolution and the debate on murdered students in Kenya. The adjective "Christian" may seem irrelevant to someone, but I am in favour of calling events by their real name. In this case, it was clearly a massacre against Christians. They die because of their faith every hour in different parts of the world, and it is our duty to talk about it.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 Terrorist violence in Kenya is unacceptable, as is the proliferation of terrorist groups such as Al-Shabaab. There is no counter-terrorism strategy based on racist and xenophobic presumptions.  The EU has a large share of responsibility for the problem of Western foreign military interventions in many Countries of the Horn of Africa have promoted the radicalisation of these groups, so instead of strengthened should be abandoned, as we advocated in our alternative resolution.  The paradigm of the EU's relationship with Kenya and all African countries must be based on the principle of non-interference, respect for sovereignty. The EU must end its free trade agreements that only benefit the economic interests of Western multinationals. The social problems that are at the heart of the problem can be mitigated with policies of real cooperation between countries 'u2012' support for education, health, the economy. And not with policies of exploitation of the weakest countries by the strongest.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: – Madam President, I, of course, do not want to compare the victims of human life in Kenya on this point. But this cultural barbarism, on the other hand, has a lot in common, it is about destroying identity, destroying references from the past, which, according to some radical interpretations of Islam, bothers this religion, and in this sense it is necessary to appeal again, although I supported, of course, the motion for this resolution, so it is necessary to appeal to my colleagues, who may not have supported this resolution, I have seen that there have been several colleagues here. to explain this vote. At the same time, I would like to call on the Muslim authorities to comment on this destruction, whether it corresponds to their content of religion. I consider the destruction of cultural monuments, the legacy of ancient generations, to be barbarism.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, the Islamic State has deliberately demolished heritage sites in the Middle East to erase thousands of years of multicultural and multi-linguistic existence.  At greatest risk today is the survival of the Syrian Christian and Yazidi minorities. The destruction of their religious and historical patrimony works in tandem with the direct physical violence against these communities. Their historical presence is being systematically wiped out, as cultural heritage is intertwined with both identity and territory.  According to the protocols of the 1954 Hague Convention and the principles of the Geneva Convention, the deliberate destruction of cultural patrimony is a war crime. UNESCO and Ban Ki-Moon have condemned these acts as such. Parliament should also denounce the destruction of cultural patrimony as a war crime, and urge the international community to develop a renewed protocol for the protection of cultural heritage in times of war.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, cosúil leis an ábhar deireanach cuireann an t-iompar seo déistin orainn go léir. Níl aon teorainn leis an mbarbarthacht agus leis an aineolas a thaispeánann ISIS maidir le daoine agus, go háirithe san ábhar seo, maidir le hionaid oidhreachta cultúrtha. Tá siad á lot agus tá siad ag goid agus mar sin de ar mhaithe leo féin amháin. Níl aon tuiscint acu ar an saibhreas atá ann leis na cianta agus nuair a dhéanann siad scrios ar ionaid oidhreachta cultúrtha bíonn sé imithe go deo; ní féidir é a thabhairt ar ais. Dá bhrí sin, caithfimid comhoibriú go háirithe le Unesco agus NGOs chun troid i gcoinne an iompair bharbartha aineolaigh seo.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, April 30, 2015, the resolution on the destruction of cultural sites by ISIS/Da'ish was voted on. While I strongly condemn the actions of ISIS and agree with several passages of the resolution, which I have largely and actively helped to draft, I have chosen to abstain. As I have already said, the central issue to be addressed and resolved is that of the trafuge and subsequent sale, in the various European black markets, of archaeological finds of enormous value. In fact, the trafficking and illicit trafficking of finds are favored by the state of war which – for objectivity and intellectual honesty must be clarified – rages not only in Syria, Libya and Iraq, but also in other Middle Eastern and African states (but forgotten and abandoned to themselves also by inaction by the EU). What would then be appropriate is to put an immediate end to the armed conflict in those areas and not to intervene militarily and to make the situation even worse. I had asked for such a passage to be inserted by means of an amendment, but unfortunately no other group supported my position. Hence my abstention.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote contained positive elements, such as condemnation of the destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites committed by Islamic State (IS) organization militias in Syria and Iraq, the countries most punished for their activities. Similarly, EU authorities are asked to tie up illegal trafficking in such goods, which is a source of IS funding. However, I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution, as long as it uses EU security and defence policy without recognising or even mentioning the responsibility of EU states in promoting the breeding ground for the situation, promoting conflict and war in Iraq and Syria , and the facilitation of financing and access to armaments that have led to the emergence of IS.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the destruction of cultural sites perpetrated by ISIS/Da’esh. The intentional destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites by ISIS in Syria and Iraq is deplorable and I welcome the condemnation of this in the joint motion. The joint motion points out that the destruction of cultural sites is used as a weapon of war and that this crime needs to be tackled. Such intentional destruction of cultural sites is unjustifiable whether carried out by ISIS or other non-state or state actors. I welcome calls to extend the international law category of ‘crimes against humanity’ so that it encompasses acts which wilfully damage or destroy the cultural heritage of mankind on a large scale.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. I welcome this joint motion for a resolution, given the recent destruction and looting of cultural monuments and sites, particularly in Syria and Iraq. Unesco is already talking about "cultural cleansing", i.e. the deliberate and systematic destruction of cultural diversity. In addition, the proceeds from illegal sales of works of art go directly to terrorist groups, especially IS/Da'isch, and thus become a financial instrument for terrorism.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst agreeing with the sentiment of the motion, I do not agree with the calls for more EU money and therefore abstained on the resolution.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. Recently, extremist groups linked specifically to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIL/Daesh) have targeted numerous archaeological, religious and cultural complexes in Syria and Iraq. Cultural heritage is an important part of the cultural identity and social cohesion of communities, groups and individuals, and its deliberate destruction can have negative consequences for human dignity and human rights. I support the calls for the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to take action to put an end to the illicit trade in cultural goods leaving The territory of Syria and Iraq, thereby preventing their use as a source of funding. I support the calls for the creation of European training programmes for judges, police and customs officials in order to combat the illicit trade in cultural goods. It is important that the government put an end to all forms of violence, including violence against peaceful protesters.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. While I remain vigilant about abuses of interference by the EU, I voted in favour of this text, which recognises and denounces the persecution of Christians.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In recent times, numerous destructions of archaeological monuments have taken place in Iraq, Syria and Tunisia. The vast majority of this destruction was perpetrated by groups linked to the Islamic State. The European Parliament condemns and deplores this cultural cleansing undertaken by the Islamic State in Syria and Iraq. Parliament also calls on the High Representative of the Union to take action to protect the cultural and archaeological heritage in these countries. Finally, Parliament calls on the Commission to support all the initiatives promoted by UNESCO to safeguard and protect Iraqi and Syrian cultural heritage.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The resolution on the destruction of cultural sites by the Islamic State group strongly condemns the real crime against humanity that constitutes this attack on the rich cultural heritage, present in particular in Syria and Iraq. The attacks on heritage are absolutely scandalous in that the aim of the terrorists of the "Islamic State" group is to destroy the memory of a particular people, ethnic group or religious group. Not content with murdering human beings, terrorists aim to completely eliminate a culture that is not their own. In addition, the resolution strongly opposes the illegal trafficking of cultural goods in Europe and proposes to strengthen the means of combating such trafficking. I therefore vote in favour of this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with and support this text condemning the destruction by ISIS of historical sites of great historical importance to humanity and calling for more action by the authorities to combat the illegal trafficking of archaeological artifacts by which these terrorist groups are financed.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Parliament's resolution as it strongly condemns the deliberate destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites perpetrated by the Islamic State in Syria and Iraq, a fact which unesco's Director-General has defined as 'cultural cleansing'. The Resolution calls for a focus on preventing and combating the illegal trafficking of cultural property, especially with regard to objects of cultural heritage illegally exported from Iraq since 6 August 1990, and from Syria since 15 March 2011, as Unesco itself has warned, the looting and smuggling of cultural and religious objects and attractions in Syria and Iraq, in particular by EI/Daesh, is being used to help finance the terrorist activities of that group. It is therefore urgent to take the necessary measures to curb the destruction and looting of heritage and to expand the status of crimes against humanity so as to include acts that deliberately damage or destroy on a large scale the cultural heritage of humanity.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament strongly condemns the deliberate destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious monuments by ISIS in Syria and Iraq. The motion calls on the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to take appropriate policy-level measures to put an end to the illegal trade in cultural goods originating in Syrian and Iraqi territories during the conflict, thereby preventing them from being used as a source of funding. Cultural diplomacy and intercultural dialogue should be used in the reconciliation of different communities and the reconstruction of destroyed sites. Security measures should be applied at the Union's external borders to prevent the smuggling of cultural goods originating in Syria and Iraq into the Union. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Entire devastated archaeological sites, destroyed museums and ancient libraries set on fire: this destruction represents an outrage, a real war crime, a cultural genocide perpetrated by Isis. We know from various sources that the jihadists smuggle the stolen works for self-financing: from Iraq, reaching the border with Turkey, the works are being dismantled in the large squares of the black market in art, namely Tokyo, New York and London. What is more, the real objective of Isis, if it has not yet been understood, is to erase the memories of a civilization, to annihilate humanity, to suppress other cultures. The EU is fully aware of the consequences of this cultural genocide, but what does it do? It confines itself, as always, to condemning, timidly and weakly. Condemnations, demands and intentions are no longer needed. You have to dare and move fast before it's too late. And maybe it already is.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ The historical legacy of Mesopotamian and Levant quaggers has survived thousands of years of teeth of time and human influence, but has not survived the mindlessness and egotism of the so-called Islamic State. The damage caused by their rampage cannot be estimated in either millions or billions of euros because it represents a civilizational loss.  I believe that the conscious forms of destruction of cultural and artistic heritage that are currently taking place in Iraq and Syria should be subject to prosecution as war crimes and as crimes against humanity.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the destruction of cultural sites perpetrated by ISIS/Da’esh. The intentional destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites by ISIS in Syria and Iraq is deplorable and I welcome the condemnation of this in the joint motion. The joint motion points out that the destruction of cultural sites is used as a weapon of war and that this crime needs to be tackled. Such intentional destruction of cultural sites is unjustifiable whether carried out by ISIS or other non-state or state actors. I welcome calls to extend the international law category of ‘crimes against humanity’ so that it encompasses acts which wilfully damage or destroy the cultural heritage of mankind on a large scale.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed this resolution since I believe that it is time we acted to stop the barbaric destruction of cultural sites of inestimable value in Syria and Iraq, which has been perpetrated by ISIS/Da’esh in recent months.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the Rome Statute, the founding act of the International Criminal Court, the deliberate destruction of cultural heritage is a war crime. Numerous archaeological, religious and cultural sites in Syria, Iraq and Tunisia have recently been subjected to punctual destruction by extremist groups linked, in particular, to the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS/Da'esh). These systematic attacks against cultural heritage were defined by UNESCO's Director-General Irina Bokova as "ethnic cleansing". Moreover, it is worrying that the jihadist group Islamic State (IS) is destroying historic sites in Iraq and selling ancient objects for financing, as experts and diplomats said during a UNESCO-organized colloquium on endangered Iraqi heritage. I voted in favour of this resolution, because it strongly condemns these acts of destruction of ISIS's cultural, archaeological and religious sites in Syria and Iraq, and calls on those Member States that have not yet done so, to ratify the UNESCO Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Objects of 1970 and the 1995 UNIDROIT Convention.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure. I condemn the barbaric destruction of archaeological finds and sites by animals without principles such as Isis militants.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. Many cultural sites have been destroyed by the Islamic State in Syria and Iraq. These acts must be seen as a genuine desire to harm a culture, a religion. Cultural diversity is one of the founding elements of the European Union. The Union is the guarantor of this principle both within and outside its borders. These attacks are undeniably attacks on cultural diversity. The Islamic State wants to destroy a religion, a culture and all the elements that make it up. We will not allow such atrocities to continue to happen. Through this resolution, the European Parliament sends a message of unity to the rest of the world. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution 'Destruction of cultural sites by ISIS/Da'esh' because news continues to come from Iraqi and Syrian territories held by Isis, of vandalism against art, duly disseminated to strike the West at the roots of its cultural identity. And all this, not to mention the relentlessness against books and libraries, which continue to burn from Raqqa to Mosul, from Cairo to Tripoli.  Unesco Director-General Irina Bokova calls the destruction of the art sites by Isis a "cultural cleansing" and a "war crime." Unesco itself estimates the proceeds of the illicit trafficking of cultural goods that escape the destructive fury of Isis at 2.200 thousand dollars. Effective action is needed to stop the destruction of works of art by Islamists.
