The international community must work to put an end quickly to this odious terrorist activity and to combat the illegal trafficking in cultural heritage that results from it.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the destruction of cultural sites perpetrated by ISIS/Da’esh. The intentional destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites by ISIS in Syria and Iraq is deplorable and I welcome the condemnation of this in the joint motion. The joint motion points out that the destruction of cultural sites is used as a weapon of war and that this crime needs to be tackled. Such intentional destruction of cultural sites is unjustifiable whether carried out by ISIS or other non-state or state actors. I welcome calls to extend the international law category of ‘crimes against humanity’ so that it encompasses acts which wilfully damage or destroy the cultural heritage of mankind on a large scale.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I felt it appropriate to abstain because I considered it essential to include in the text of the resolution the key amendment tabled by my group which stressed the importance of full respect for international law, human rights and the rule of law in stabilising the situation in regions affected or threatened by ISIS/Da'esh. I believe that the use of force is not a solution to the terrorist threat and I fear that military action may aggravate the humanitarian situation on the ground.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. In recent months we have witnessed the destruction by the Islamic State of priceless works of the historical heritage of the Iraqi and Syrian nations. Looking at these appalling images of demolition of pre-Islamic statues or monuments, one cannot help but think of the giant Buddhas of Bamiyan in Afghanistan, or the mausoleums of Timbuktu. Faced with such destructive madness, the predation systems organized in the 2000s by the American occupying authorities in Iraq from the looting of the Baghdad museum, appear almost as a lesser evil! What is common to all totalitarianisms, to terror, during the French Revolution, and its immense damage to French Christian heritage, to the Maoist Cultural Revolution in China, to the Taliban in Afghanistan, to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, is this same blind faith in the new man, the uprooted man, the product of a religious law or an ideological system. , the man torn from historical times. In the name of human dignity in history, I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Cases of destruction and looting of sites and objects of cultural, archaeological and religious importance are increasingly frequent, especially in Iraq and Syria. Alarming crimes for the often irreparable damage they cause to the cultural heritage of all humanity, as well as to the identity and dignity of the communities and people most directly involved. The looting and smuggling of these goods is extremely serious, all the more so since profits – often made by selling items in Europe – contribute to the financing of terrorism. The resolution identifies and urges concrete measures to combat these phenomena: security measures at the EU's external borders to prevent the illegal import of cultural goods; to give the Commission a coordinating role, in cooperation with national authorities, Europol, Interpol, Unesco and other international organisations; use of satellites to control and catalog sites; support for the activities of Syrian archaeologists; training programmes for those involved in the fight against the smuggling of cultural goods; support for the ICOM International Observatory on Illicit Trafficking in Cultural Heritage; strengthening the relevant Eurojust and Europol services.  For these reasons, while stressing the need for effective sanctions for buyers of stolen goods, I voted in favour.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. 'Numerous sites of archaeological, religious and cultural interest have recently been destroyed in Iraq and Syria by extremist groups linked mainly to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, and the Director-General of UNESCO has defined this destruction as acts of "cultural cleansing". On the other hand, the illicit trade in cultural goods is currently the third most important illegal trade, after drug and arms trafficking, and this trade is dominated by organised crime networks. I strongly condemn the intentional destruction of places of worship and cultural and archaeological interest carried out by the Islamic State in Syria and Iraq. I agree with the need for the EU and the Member States to implement security measures at the EU's external borders to prevent the smuggling of cultural goods. I support the need to include acts that deliberately damage or destroy, on a large scale, humanity's cultural heritage in the category of crimes against humanity.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Attacks by ISIS on archaeological sites recognized as a "cultural heritage of humanity" are not only a worrying attempt to carry out a "cultural cleansing" to the detriment of the people of the region. This deliberate destruction contributes, in fact, to the financing of the conflict and to terrorist activities, through the smuggling of artistic and cultural goods.  I believe it is extremely important to protect the world's artistic heritage and prevent the illicit trafficking of cultural goods by strengthening cooperation with third countries. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. ‒ My abstention on the vote is due to the fact that the following amendment to the resolution was not passed: ‘Underlines the importance of full respect for international law, human rights and the rule of law in stabilising the situation in the regions affected or threatened by ISIS/Da’esh; believes that the use of force does not represent a solution to the terrorist threat’.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote contained positive elements, such as condemnation of the destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites committed by Islamic State (IS) organization militias in Syria and Iraq, the countries most punished for their activities. Similarly, EU authorities are asked to tie up illegal trafficking in such goods, which is a source of IS funding. However, I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution, as long as it uses EU security and defence policy without recognising or even mentioning the responsibility of EU states in promoting the breeding ground for the situation, promoting conflict and war in Iraq and Syria , and the facilitation of financing and access to armaments that have led to the emergence of IS.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the violence that has taken place and is taking place in the region, numerous archaeological, religious and cultural sites in Syria, Iraq and Tunisia have been the target of the terrorist group Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS/Da'esh). These systematic attacks against cultural heritage have been defined as a "cultural cleansing". The European Commission must establish a rapid and efficient exchange of information, an exchange of best practices between Member States in order to effectively combat the illicit trade in cultural objects that have been illegally removed from Iraq and Syria.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution condemns the intentional destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites perpetrated by ISIS in Syria and Iraq. It calls on Vice-President Mogherini to take action, in accordance with the appropriate UN Security Council Resolution, in order to put an end to the illegal trade in cultural property from Syria and Iraq, preventing them from being used as a source of financing. The cultural heritage of Syria and Iraq is part of our common human heritage and we must do all we can to safeguard it. Hence I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution strongly condemns the destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites by IS in Syria and Iraq by the Islamic State. It is particularly shocking to see elements of the heritage of humanity being destroyed in this way intentionally. Considering that the European Union must act with all means at its disposal to combat the illegal sale of cultural property of Syrian or Iraqi origin as a result of these destructions, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The European Parliament condemns in the strongest terms the destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites by Daesh in Syria and Iraq.  These destructions are one of the most abject faces of barbarism. By destroying priceless works such as the pre-Islamic statues of the Mosul Museum in Iraq, Daesh is attacking the very history of peoples and civilizations.  Two international treaties have been established under the aegis of the United Nations: the 1954 Hague Convention for the Protection of Cultural Property in the Event of Armed Conflict and the 1970 Unesco Convention to Prohibit the Import, Export, and Transfer of Illicit Property of Cultural Property. It is urgent that all member states of the European Union ratify them.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament strongly condemns the deliberate destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious monuments by ISIS in Syria and Iraq. The motion calls on the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to take appropriate measures at policy level to put an end to the illegal trade in cultural goods from Syrian and Iraqi territories during the conflict, preventing them from being used as a source of funding. Cultural diplomacy and intercultural dialogue should be used in the reconciliation of different communities and the reconstruction of destroyed sites. Security measures should be applied at the Union's external borders to prevent the smuggling of cultural goods originating in Syria and Iraq into the Union. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. Many archaeological, religious and cultural sites in Syria, Iraq and Tunisia are now being targetedly destroyed by extremist groups linked to the Islamic State group. According to Unesco, these attacks on cultural heritage are a real "cultural cleansing".  They are also crimes against humanity and crimes of persecution. Illicit trade in cultural goods is the third largest illicit market after narcotics and weapons. This trade is dominated by organized criminal networks. It is essential to put an end to it through a European strategy and the help of the Member States. Security measures must be implemented at EU borders to prevent cultural goods from Syria or Iraq from smuggling across EU borders. Every possible means must be used to prevent further looting, destruction and to protect the lives of civilians.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament strongly condemns the deliberate destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious monuments by ISIS in Syria and Iraq. The motion calls on the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to take appropriate measures at policy level to put an end to the illegal trade in cultural goods from Syrian and Iraqi territories during the conflict, preventing them from being used as a source of funding.  Cultural diplomacy and intercultural dialogue should be used in the reconciliation of different communities and the reconstruction of destroyed sites. Security measures should be applied at the Union's external borders to prevent the smuggling of cultural goods originating in Syria and Iraq into the Union.  In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Islamic State is a factor in the Middle East and Africa that we underestimated and are now picking the fruits of our inadequate behavior. I continue to argue that DAESH is a threat to europe's security. It is becoming more and more the scars of a real country. The fight against this extreme Islamism goes directly through limiting its financial resources, to crossing the financial flows that this organization maintains. Islamic State quickly and systematically destroys all cultural scars and values, all artifacts of the civilizations of antiquity. This is no coincidence – on the one hand they trade in antiquities, on the other they remove every sign of past civilizations. To them, these are pagan symbols. For them, everything that was before the birth of the Prophet Muhammad is evil and must be destroyed. We need swift and firm intervention to protect the achievements of ancient civilizations from the clutches of islamists. I stress that their aspiration is to destroy all the archaeological and historical marks of antiquity. We cannot allow this because it is a blow and a loss for civilization. Daesh's cultural genocide must be stopped. They are about to erase entire centuries of world history, literally destroying history. This barbarism must be put to an end. We have to intervene.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We vote in favour because we strongly condemn the destruction of monuments by the Islamic Caliphate. But we will vote against if Amendment No 10 of the Greens (the first on the list) is voted down because they are also trying to involve the Syrian Government, when the reality is quite different.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament strongly condemns the deliberate destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious monuments by ISIS in Syria and Iraq. The motion calls on the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to take appropriate measures at policy level to put an end to the illegal trade in cultural goods from Syrian and Iraqi territories during the conflict, preventing them from being used as a source of funding. Cultural diplomacy and intercultural dialogue should be used in the reconciliation of different communities and the reconstruction of destroyed sites. Security measures should be applied at the Union's external borders to prevent the smuggling of cultural goods originating in Syria and Iraq into the Union. In line with the position of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I voted in favour of the adoption of the motion.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Numerous sites of archaeological, religious and cultural interest in Syria and Iraq have recently been destroyed by extremist groups linked mainly to the Islamic State, which are systematic attacks against cultural heritage. The director-general of UNESCO calls it "cultural cleansing". I vehemently condone the intentional destruction of places of worship and cultural and archaeological interest, including through the deliberate persecution of individuals identified on the basis of their ethnic, religious or cultural origin, combined with deliberate attacks on their places of worship, memory and education.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 The brutal destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites and assets in Syria, Iraq and all other territories that are the subject of terrorist acts is an act to be strongly condemned. Actions aimed at erasing part of that historical-cultural heritage, which is a component of the identity of communities in territories affected or threatened by ISIS/Da'esh, as well as undermining decades of peaceful coexistence between groups and individuals, encourage the illegal trafficking of invaluable objects and artworks. While we believe that the use of force is not a solution to the terrorist threat, it is essential that the European Union and the international community as a whole, including regional partners in the Middle East, adopt the most appropriate strategies both to protect the most vulnerable cultural assets and sites and to stabilise the situation in regions affected or threatened by ISIS/Da'esh, in full respect of international law, human rights and the rule of law.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The pillaging and destruction of historical monuments and artifacts by ISIS/Daesh and other extremist groups in Sulphuria and Iraq is worrying. They are manifestations of cultural cleansing and a deliberate attempt by extremists to destroy the culture, history and traditions of religious and minority groups. The growth of the illegal trade in cultural and religious artefacts, which often serves as a source of financing for terrorist activities, is also worrying. We therefore support the efforts of the UN conventions aimed at protecting cultural and religious heritage and encourage the more effective use of the Interpol database to combat the illicit trade in cultural goods.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution condemning the destruction of archaeological sites and works of art by ISIS. There is also a need for more action in the fight against illegal trafficking in cultural goods.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I strongly condemn the destruction of monuments by the Islamic Caliphate but I am obliged to vote against the resolution because it is also trying to involve the Syrian government, at a time when the reality is completely different.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. The TERRORIST group IS/Daesh is not only perpetrating crimes against humanity in those territories it dominates, it also aims to erase the history of civilization by destroying places of incalculable cultural interest in Syria and Iraq. This cultural cleansing aims to erase every cultural sign of civilizations prior to the rise of Islam, the end of the cultural identity of many communities. As Unesco asserts, the product of looting and smuggling of cultural and religious objects and attractions in Syria and Iraq, in particular, is being used to help finance the group's terrorist activities. The illegal trafficking of cultural goods must be fought to end the smuggling and expoliation of the heritage of Syria and Iraq and to end an important source of financing for jihadist terrorism. Similarly, we must fight to bring to international justice the members of this terrorist group.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 IN Syria and Iraq ISIS is fighting a 360-degree war that aims to erase our millennial culture based on the values of humanism, freedom and democracy. The gruesome images of death are therefore accompanied by those of "cultural cleansing": ISIS is destroying millennial artistic heritage of inestimable cultural value. Alongside the initiatives to save Christians, I have promoted this resolution in which Parliament, with a single voice, calls on the High Representative to take concrete action to protect our culture, specifically indicating some tools that can be used to write the words end to the destruction carried out by ISIS.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. The recent attacks by ISIS on the Bardo Museum in Tunis, Mosul in Iraq and some important historical sites in Syria are real attacks on the history and cultural heritage not only nationally but universally, material raids of archaeological wealth, symbolic demolitions of the origins and identities of many peoples. I therefore declare my vote in favour of Unesco promoting with the UN, in line with its Resolution 2199, interventions and actions that can secure the sites at risk in war zones, safeguarding the common cultural heritage. I therefore offer my full support to safety initiatives, including through the use of the so-called 'blue helmets of culture', and I strongly promote operations to stop the trade in stolen works of art in order to be able to stop a source of funding for ISIS' criminal and war activities.

name: Adam GIEREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution because it draws attention to a global problem. It points to the need to extend the categories of international law to crimes against humanity, which include acts of deliberate vandalism or the destruction of humanity's cultural heritage on a large scale. By adopting this provision, we strongly condemn the deliberate destruction by ISIS of cultural, archaeological and religious objects in Syria and Iraq. Loot looted as a result of the looting of these facilities and smuggled by ISIS/Da'esh has become a kind of fighting tool, as it is used to finance the terrorist activities of this organization. Furthermore, in close cooperation with UNESCO, UN agencies, the International Council of Museums, the International Council for the Protection of Monuments, as well as Europol and Interpol, measures should be taken to stop the looting and illegal trade in cultural goods.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. U2012 The destruction of humanity's common heritage is not only a war crime, but also a crime against humanity. The EU must take haste measures to prevent terrorist groups such as the Islamic State from using the destruction of museums, civil and religious buildings and archaeological sites to destabilize the population and destroy their identity, as is currently happening in Iraq or Syria. In addition, terrorists sometimes use the looting of archaeological property and the illegal trafficking of cultural objects , which has one of the main destinations on the European market – to finance their activities in conflict zones. To combat this phenomenon, coordinated action is needed by the EU, international institutions such as Unesco, the World Customs Organization, Interpol or Europol, and the Member States.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Joint Resolution as we believe it is an important issue, not only because of the issue of the destruction of cultural heritage, but also because of the artifacts that have been looted and subsequently used to finance isIS/Daesh terrorist operations, among others. In this sense, cultural artifacts have been turned into "weapons of war".  In fact, illicit trafficking in cultural goods is the third largest illegal trade in the world – after the trafficking of drugs and weapons – and therefore requires a strong political position on the part of the European Parliament. We believe that the Joint Resolution is in this direction and therefore we join it.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: In writing. On Thursday, April 30, I voted in favour of a text to end the destruction and looting by IS of archaeological sites, historic buildings and cultural works. The recent attacks by the Islamic State group on the Bardo Museum in Tunis and the intentional destruction of the Mosul Museum in Iraq and historic sites in Syria show that these acts are much more than cultural tragedies and could be described as acts of cultural cleansing. The aim of the terrorists is to use the destruction of civilian and religious buildings and archaeological sites that are part of the common heritage of humanity to destabilize populations and destroy their identity. Similarly, looting of archaeological sites and the illicit trafficking of cultural objects are used as an "instrument of war" to finance terrorist activities. It's a disgrace! The deliberate destruction of cultural heritage is a war crime. the European Union must stand up against this barbarism!

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. I supported this resolution because it calls for the international law to be extended to include acts that wilfully damage or destroy the cultural heritage of humanity on a large scale. What is perpetrated by ISIS/Da'esh against cultural and archaeological sites in Syria and Iraq constitutes an unacceptable "cultural cleansing" aimed not only at providing additional funding to this organization of terror, but above all at destroying archaeological sites, cultural and religious symbols and the heritage of people living in these regions, which are essential for the rest of the world. Furthermore, through this resolution, the European Parliament calls on the Commission and Member States to develop awareness campaigns to deter the purchase and sale of cultural goods from the illicit trade in these war-affected regions.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because, in my opinion, cultural heritage does not belong to a single state or group. Cultural heritage, wherever it may be, belongs to all mankind, and the international community must focus its efforts and stop such crimes. It is with regret that extremist groups in Syria and Iraq are destroying and plundering old religious and cultural objects. The EP encourages the mobilization and coordination of international efforts to protect vulnerable sites and objects of cultural, historical and religious heritage from the threat of looting and destruction.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Joint Resolution as we believe it is an important issue, not only because of the issue of the destruction of cultural heritage, but also because of the artifacts that have been looted and subsequently used to finance isIS/Daesh terrorist operations, among others. In this sense, cultural artifacts have been turned into "weapons of war".  In fact, illicit trafficking in cultural goods is the third largest illegal trade in the world – after the trafficking of drugs and weapons – and therefore requires a strong political position on the part of the European Parliament. We believe that the Joint Resolution is in this direction and therefore we join it.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. U2012 Vote for. Against the destruction of cultural attractions at the hands of religious extremists.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Despite the bombings, The Islamic State is growing stronger, occupying more territory both in Syria - most recently in the Damascus region and in Iraq in the city of Ramadi. From the very beginning, his main tool in combat was terror and mindless, blind destruction. After the capture of Mosul, many of the ancient cultural monuments there, including artifacts from the magnificent Assyrian temples, went into private collections. The sale of antiquities from the looted churches of Aleppo and Mosul enriches the Islamists' cash, giving them the necessary resources to continue the war. It can't continue like that. The resolution put to the vote did not contain the most important thesis. Without the support of Turkey, Saudi Arabia and Qatar, it would not be possible to sell antiques. And it is these countries that have the greatest responsibility to fight Islamists. They are responsible for the development of the underground market for the trade in works of art from Syria and Iraq. Therefore, their role in stopping the Islamic State must not be limited to words of condemnation, but must also consist in actively fighting Islamic cells on its territory and withholding funding for IS.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. Wars have always been the result of brutality, in addition to killing people, and destroying symbols of nations and civilizations. This is also the case in the most recent conflicts in the Middle East. The invaluable values of cultural treasures, which have been created for centuries in Asia and Africa, are often the target of insane war campaigns.  The latest destruction of world cultural heritage by ISIS and Da'esh only confirms their unscrupulousness in warfare. The condemnation imposed by the European Parliament is part of my deep beliefs and that is why I voted for this Resolution.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I wholeheartedly support this resolution, which condemns the destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites being perpetrated by ISIS in Syria and Iraq. Our cultural heritage is our identity, and I strongly condemn this intentional and targeted destruction. Culturally, Iraq is one of the richest and most diverse regions in the world, and these sites and artefacts which have stood for centuries exist no longer. It is not just for ideological reasons that these artefacts are being looted, but for economic reasons as well. Goods are being trafficked to finance terrorist activities, and a coordinated approach between the EU, UNESCO and other international organisations is needed, in order to combat this illegal trade.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Nothing is more important than human life. The destruction of cultural heritage pales in comparison to other atrocities that ISIS has committed. It is, nevertheless, cultural cleansing and a war crime. Cultural heritage is a record of our common past and a way of understanding each other. Its destruction represents an attack on our shared civilization. It should therefore be treated as such, even if it is not equal to the human toll that ISIS has inflicted. It is further proof that ISIS has nothing to do with religion. Attacking schools, media and other places of culture – all symbols of freedom of thought and respect for cultural diversity – is part of a strategy to crush free thinking. We must all condemn these acts as war crimes, challenging ISIS’ narrative and working together to preserve our cultural heritage. We must cooperate against illegal trade in cultural property from the occupied territories, which directly funds terrorism. We must stand united in respect for humanity.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. \u2012 It is a sad fact that wars can do damage of unprecedented and sometimes unsuperied proportions. In Syria and Iraq, cultural, archaeological and religious monuments by ISIS fighters are systematically being destroyed. Their barbaric actions are described as a "cultural purge" and can even be considered a crime against humanity, especially if they are directed against members of a religious or ethnic group. Moreover, ISIS uses the smuggling of objects as a financing tool, so that artistic and cultural objects become "weapons of war." UNESCO points out that "cultural heritage is an important part of the cultural identity of communities, groups and individuals, as well as part of social cohesion, implying that its deliberate destruction may have adverse consequences for human dignity and human rights". That is why I therefore support the #Unite4Heritage campaign launched by UNESCO Director-General Irina Bokov in March this year, which aims to gain worldwide support for the protection of cultural heritage through the influence of social networks, and other international civil society projects aimed at protecting and reporting on endangered cultural sites. I hope that, like the conflict in Syria and Iraq, the illegal trade in cultural goods, the destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites will soon be stopped and the protection of the global cultural heritage will be strengthened in order to preserve human rights and human dignity.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. Following the attacks on the Bardo museum in Tunis, the Museum of Mosul in Iraq and historical sites in Syria by ISIS/Da'esh, it was inevitable to address with the Commission the issue of trade in eu Member States of cultural works illegally stolen from those countries. I join Parliament in calling for culture to be given the power to reconcile peoples and play a key role in promoting peace.

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: in writing. ‒ The cultural heritage in Iraq and Syria is an eminent treasure for the peoples and communities in the region and for mankind as a whole. By targeting buildings, sites and artefacts, ISIS attacks cultural identity and terrorises and intimidates individuals identified on the basis of their cultural, ethnic or religious background. I support the resolution with the call to undertake every possible action, including the use of satellite imaging for tracking damaged areas, and to do our utmost to stop illicit trade in cultural goods, which is a source of financing for terrorist organisations. Such acts of deliberate and systematic destruction of the cultural heritage may be considered as crimes against humanity, and those responsible must be brought to justice.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The resolution on the destruction of cultural sites by the Daesh group opposes the systematic destruction of cultural heritage in Syria and Iraq by this terrorist group. These abuses go far beyond mere stupidity and provocation. By systematically destroying the cultural assets of civilizations and cultures other than their value system in the occupied areas, Daesh and its militants are purifying memory. A prerequisite for ethnic cleansing that has already begun for some peoples. The definition of crimes against humanity made by this text is therefore entirely appropriate. On the other hand, the trafficking that results from these destructions cannot be tolerated, it deprives peoples of their heritage, erases the presence of cultures and civilizations in a territory, and finances terrorist and criminal organizations. We cannot be complicit in these horrors or the trade of these stolen goods to peoples. I have therefore joined this resolution, which I co-signed and supported at the time of its adoption.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution because it condemns the destruction of cultural sites by the Islamic State Daesh. It calls for the urgent dismantling of Daesh's arms financing and supply networks.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Vote for. This text highlights the responsibility of Syrian rebels in the destruction of cultural property. In addition, any military action against DAESH groups must be supported and networks that enable the trafficking of cultural goods must be combated. I do not believe that terrorism is at all because of the poverty situation in which some people find themselves. We have with DAESH an organization that has the firm will to conquer to apply their vision of Islam and the destruction of cultural property is part of this vision, as are their crimes. For the destruction of cultural property is not their only misdeed. Cultural rehabilitation initiatives should be supported as this is our common heritage and support any interstate military cooperation to combat the trafficking of cultural property.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote contained positive elements, such as condemnation of the destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites committed by Islamic State (IS) organization militias in Syria and Iraq, the countries most punished for their activities. Similarly, EU authorities are asked to tie up illegal trafficking in such goods, which is a source of IS funding. However, I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution, as long as it uses EU security and defence policy without recognising or even mentioning the responsibility of EU states in promoting the breeding ground for the situation, promoting conflict and war in Iraq and Syria , and the facilitation of financing and access to armaments that have led to the emergence of IS.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. Numerous archaeological, religious and cultural sites in Syria, Iraq and Tunisia have recently been the subject of deliberate destruction by extremist groups linked, in particular, to the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (IS/Daesh). It is true that combating illegal trade in cultural goods is not an EU-specific competence, as it is not included as such in the Treaties, but nevertheless the fight against this illegal trade is included in a number of areas of EU competence, such as the internal market, the area of freedom, security and justice, culture and common foreign and security policy. I therefore voted favourably on this Resolution, calling for a rapid and secure exchange of information and the sharing of best practices among Member States with a view to effectively combating the illegal trade in cultural goods; as well as calling on the EU to take measures, in collaboration with Unesco and the International Criminal Court, to expand the category of crimes against humanity recognised by international law and to include acts that deliberately destroy humanity's cultural heritage on a large scale.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained because, while this resolution recognises the serious problem of extremists destroying cultural sites, it does not offer a solution to the situation. It also makes no mention that Western states, on the one hand, support rebels against governments in Islamic States such as Syria or Egypt, but these rebels are often mentioned extremists.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Since the start of the conflict in Syria and Iraq, this is just one in a series of barbaric acts by the extremist group ISIS. More than 300 cultural, archaeological and religious sites in the conflict area have been destroyed. Videos have also been released showing members of terrorist groups destroying symbols of religions and peoples in the city of Nimruda, one of the cities often referred to as the cradle of civilization. Through its actions, ISIS challenges the international community and shows that I have no respect for the history of other cultures. UNESCO chief Irinia Bokova said "deliberate destruction of cultural heritage is a war crime". Even more tragic is that ISIS is using this crime to finance new attacks by selling monuments, which puts this problem in the broader context of the fight against terrorism.  I supported a resolution to destroy cultural sites committed by the terrorist group ISIS and for which there is no justification whatsood. It's just one form of attack on the identity of cultures and nations. All religious and political leaders are urged to rise up against the barbarity of the Islamic State over the heritage of humanity.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Promoting the preservation of cultural heritage not only in the Countries of the Union, but also in third countries is also proclaimed in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union itself. The destruction and destruction of cultural monuments in Syria and Iraq represents irreversible damage, so all forms of political diplomacy and pressure from all international institutions and organisations must be used to stop this senseless activity.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament of 29 April 2015. This is a resolution that rightly condemns unequivocally the destruction of sites of cultural importance by isis/Da'esh jihadists.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am sincerely sorry that a number of unique archaeological, religious and cultural sites in Syria and Iraq have recently been destroyed by various groups of extremists. This distorts and destroys cultural diversity. According to UNESCO, "cultural heritage is an important part of the cultural identity of communities, groups and individuals, as well as part of social cohesion", so UNESCO launched an emergency plan to save Syria's cultural heritage on 1 March 2014. Another major problem is the development of illicit trade in cultural goods, which is now the third most serious illicit trade in arms and drugs. I fully agree with the need to better coordinate and work closely together to combat this illegal trade in cultural objects in order to promote awareness-raising, information sharing and establish an adequate legal framework. Cultural diplomacy and intercultural dialogue should also be used as a tool for the admission of different communities and the restoration of destroyed monuments. That is why I supported the draft common resolution today.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 Numerous archaeological, religious and cultural sites, located in Syria and Iraq, have become the target of systematic attacks by Islamic extremists. The cultural heritage of a people reflects its identity. Failure to respect places of worship or archaeological sites belonging to the artistic and cultural heritage of a country is therefore an act of terrorism in all respects. For these reasons, I have decided to welcome this resolution, in which the European Parliament has expressed its extreme disappointment at the destructive action taken by ISIS.

name: Georg MAYER
text: Writing. The destruction of cultural monuments by ISIS is highly condemnable. That is why I supported this motion.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this cross-party resolution as it is of utmost importance that the Union takes a firm stand against the destruction of the world’s cultural heritage. The resolution urges the implementation of security checks to prevent cultural goods from Syria and Iraq being smuggled into the Union. I support these measures as they not only aim to protect cultural heritage but also aim to tackle one of ISIS/Da’esh’s sources of revenue.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the resolution on the destruction of cultural sites perpetrated by ISIS. The resolution strongly condemns the intentional destruction by ISIS of cultural, archaeological and religious sites in Syria and Iraq, and calls on the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to take appropriate action at political level, in accordance with UN Security Council Resolution 2199 of 12 February 2015, in order to put an end to the illegal trade in cultural property from the territories of Syria and Iraq during periods of conflict in those territories, thereby preventing the use of such property as a source of financing.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This resolution concerns the destruction of cultural sites by the terrorist group "Islamic State". It strongly condemns this real crime against humanity that is this unacceptable attack on the cultural heritage of Syria or Iraq. The attacks on the heritage of humanity are scandalous, since the very existence of civilizations is being attacked here. It is a question of eradicating all traces, all existence, all memory to replace an ideology of enslavement.  The resolution not only condemns, but also proposes to put an end to the illegal trafficking of cultural goods in Europe and to strengthen the means to combat it.  So I voted for this text.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which condemns the destruction and looting of cultural sites by the Islamic State group in Syria and Iraq. These actions constitute a real cultural genocide that must be stopped. At the same time, the text calls on the Commission to define a common strategy to combat the illicit trade in stolen cultural goods. The illegal trade in cultural goods, orchestrated by organized criminal networks, is the third after that of drugs and weapons.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Numerous archaeological, religious and cultural sites in Syria, Iraq and Tunisia have recently been targeted by some extremist groups linked, in particular, to Islamic State (ISIS/Da'esh). Unesco has defined such acts as actions of "cultural cleansing", a real intentional strategy that aims to destroy cultural diversity through deliberate attacks against individuals identified on the basis of their cultural, ethnic or religious background.  We see cultural heritage as an important component of the cultural identity of communities, groups and individuals. We strongly condemn the smuggling and illegal trade in cultural and religious goods that is used to finance terrorist activities, with the result that artistic and cultural goods are becoming real 'weapons of war'. In this regard, we call for the intervention of the European NETWORK CULTNET, the main objective of which is to improve the exchange of information on the prevention of illicit trafficking in cultural goods, and we call on the High Representative of the European Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to take appropriate measures to put an end to the illegal trade in cultural goods by preventing their use as a source of funding for terrorist activities in all territories.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Following recent Isis/Da'esh attacks on the Bardo museum in Tunis, the Mosul museum in Iraq and historical sites in Syria, this resolution asks the Commission whether it intends to take the necessary measures to ensure that trade in cultural works illegally stolen from these countries in the EU Member States is blocked and whether it sees the possibility of establishing a new mode of cooperation between the EU and UNESCO with the specific aim of protecting cultural heritage in conflict zones? For these reasons, I thought it appropriate to support the resolution. The world archaeological heritage is part of our culture, and as such must be defended by force.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 By Joint Communication to the European Parliament and the Council of 6 February 2015 entitled 'Elements relating to an EU regional strategy for Syria and Iraq, as well as to the threat posed by Daesh', the Commission and the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy recognised the seriousness of the destruction and looting of cultural heritage in the crises in Syria and Iraq and the threat posed by Daesh. I signed and voted on this resolution because it comes with concrete measures to support and restore this cultural heritage.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, I strongly condemn the recent attack on the Bardo Museum in Tunis, as well as the gradual destruction and plundering of the cultural and historical heritage of Syria and Iraq by the Islamic State!  I supported the joint resolution because I believe that we should not look beyond the barbaric outrages of terrorists who irretrievably destroy the world cultural heritage. As a member of the Committee on Culture in the European Parliament, I support the idea of establishing a dedicated unit for the international protection of cultural heritage.  I call on the Commission to take the necessary steps to stop the illegal trafficking of cultural artefacts, because as we know these funds are used to finance the terrorist activity of ISIS/Daesh. If we don't take concrete action now, a whole story will be erased. Thank you.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution and I should think every elected Member of this House has done the same. It is an unbelievably sad loss, what is going on in the ISIS-controlled territories – loss of lives, of culture and world heritage – and it is a proof that fanaticism is toxic to the very nature of human culture. We should step up our efforts to fight against this group and to restore to the people of Iraq and Syria a semblance of normality in their daily lives.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. I supported the joint resolution on the destruction of cultural sites by the Islamic State group, following the destruction of the ancient city of Hatra in northern Iraq, or the destruction of the city of Nimroud, or the ransacking of the Mosul museum. The resolution also strongly condemns the problem of the illicit trade in cultural goods, which partly finance terrorist activities. Like the atrocities committed against the civilian population in Syria or Iraq, these plunderings of the cultural heritage of humanity must stop immediately.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – I supported the proposal. The European Union cannot simply stand by the destruction of cultural sites belonging to the common heritage of mankind and use the proceeds from their sale to finance its terrorist activities. The EU must, among other things, take steps to block trade in cultural goods illegally identified from Syria and Iraq while the country is in a state of war. In cooperation with UNESCO and the International Criminal Court, the category of crimes against humanity should be supplemented in international law in such a way that the widespread and deliberate destruction of cultural heritage also includes it.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 Cultural genocide perpetrated by ISIS is a serious crime against humanity. Preserving the historical heritage also means preserving identity, possible peaceful coexistence and the future of tolerance between peoples. ISIS militants are carrying out a violent fight against images and symbols chronologically preceding the Prophet Muhammad, in an attempt to erase their "own" history. These actions led to the destruction of most of the walls of Nineveh, the ancient capital of the Assyrian Empire, of the eighth century BC. Goods of inestimable historical value and considered a World Heritage Site are sold across borders in Western countries and the proceeds are used to purchase weapons and finance terrorist activities. This revenue is, in fact, the second largest source of income for terrorist groups, immediately after oil. International legislation needs to be reviewed in this regard. I believe that only strong cooperation capable of imposing precise laws can stem and resolve the problem.  For ISIS militants, history is a threat and eliminating it leads to a destabilization necessary to achieve their goal: the elimination of free will.  Let us fight together for the preservation of cultural heritage and freedom of thought. #Unite4Heritage

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Writing. – The JRC strongly and unequivocally condemns the crimes, vandalism and looting of "jihadists" against priceless historical monuments and works of humanity's world culture. The connections of the "jihadists" with the circuits of antiquity for the sale of looted archaeological treasures, with willing buyers within the "artificial" plutocracy, show that the creator of the monster of "jihadists" are the imperialists of the EU-US-NATO, the rot of capitalism. The joint resolution of the European Parliament does not say a word about all this. On the contrary, it is once again using these heinous acts to promote the extension of the eu's network of repressive mechanisms, the interconnection of Europol and Eurojust with Interpol and international cultural organisations, the creation of new repressive networks and monitoring, the expansion of CFSP operations, such as the EU Satellite Centre in Torrejón, the sealing of the EU's external borders , the extension of the powers of the International Criminal Court. Once again, it turns out that this union of capital does not hesitate to use anything to copper new bonds, repression, interventions and wars against the peoples for the interests of monopolies. The only way out for the people is to leave the EU and the capital chains, with wealth producers taking the helm of power and the economy.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank the rapporteur for his work and hope to have made my contribution.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported this resolution, which sends a clear sign to the relevant institutions to undertake all necessary activities to prevent culturecide carried out by the ISIS group. Lately, we have been witnessing an intensification of deliberate and targeted destruction of archaeological, religious and cultural sites in Syria and Iraq, perpetrated by extremist groups affiliated with the Islamic State.  The destruction of cultural heritage is inadmissible and because cultural heritage is part of the identity and history of the people, it testifies to the emergence and development of a civilization. I strongly condemn the actions of ISIS that irreversibly destroyed the priceless treasures of ancient civilizations, thus impoverishing our modern society.  I call on all those responsible to take appropriate measures at political level to put an end to the illicit trade in cultural property from the territories of Syria and Iraq, as well as to implement appropriate security measures at the Union's external borders to prevent the smuggling of cultural goods. I also call on the European Commission to take concrete action to prevent ISIS from further terrorist and vandal activities.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of extending the category of crimes against humanity of international law so that it also includes those crimes that ISIS forces are currently carrying out on cultural sites, damaging and destroying works that are part of our world cultural heritage. The international community must take action to stop the illegal trade in cultural goods used to finance criminal organisations and their destruction. We cannot remain impassed in the face of the strategy of 'cultural cleansing' declared by ISIS, which aims to eliminate religious and cultural symbols, the historical memory of indigenous peoples and at the same time the historical memory of all humanity. By adopting this resolution, Parliament wants to send out an important message that an awareness campaign should also be launched through the use of social networks, which aims to discourage trade in cultural goods from conflict zones, thus undermining the possibility of funding for these organisations and seeking to limit their interest in works of art that are barbarically destroyed.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The European Union has ratified the Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions, which was adopted on 20 October 2005 and is the first international instrument recognising the dual economic and cultural nature of cultural goods and therefore 'must not be treated as having purely commercial value'. I am pleased that on 1 March 2014, thanks to european union funding, UNESCO launched a three-year project with other strategic partners called "Emergency Protection of Syrian Heritage", which aims primarily at ensuring urgent protection for Syrian cultural heritage. While illicit trade in cultural goods is still the third most important area of illicit trade after drug and arms trafficking, and this illicit trade is dominated by organised criminal networks and since the current national and international mechanisms do not have the right equipment or support to tackle the problem, it is terrible that cultural heritage of urremable value is being completely destroyed. I join calls to support UNESCO'#Unite4Heritage campaign with the launch of an information campaign focusing on Iraq and Syria to raise awareness of the importance of their cultural heritage, how plundered heritage is used to finance terrorist activities, and possible penalties for the illegal import of cultural goods from those countries or from third countries, and I support this resolution.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I thank the Chair of the Culture and Education Committee for launching this important issue of the destruction of cultural sites by the terrorist group ISIS/Daesh. The destruction and looting of museums and religious, historical, archaeological and cultural sites in Syria and Iraq, along with the recording and publication of material online, proves that this is a premeditated "scorched earth" war strategy systematically implemented by the terrorist group ISIS. In addition to the psychological dimension of this war strategy aimed at destabilizing the population and destroying identity, the terrorist group ISIS is partly financed by the proceeds from the sale of items from archaeological sites, and therefore it is essential to initiate concrete measures in the fight against this type of barbarity. Therefore, I support a European Parliament resolution demanding a concrete strategy in tackling this type of organised crime, better cooperation between Member States in the fight against illicit trade in cultural goods from war zones, strengthening eurojust and Europol units and making more efficient use of existing international instruments. As a representative from Croatia, I am particularly sensitive to this issue because of the Homeland War in Croatia from 1991 to 1995, during which an identical strategy of the aggressor was implemented in terms of destroying and removing every trace of the existence of Croatian culture, peoples and religion.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has an obligation to take action to stop what is happening in Syria and Iraq, where archaeological and cultural sites of immense value have been destroyed by extremist groups linked to ISIS/Daish. Unesco has described these attacks as a "cultural cleansing." It is a clear strategy aimed at destroying cultural diversity, indirectly pursuing people on the basis of their cultural, ethnic and religious origin and wanting to eliminate the expressions of history and culture that have been in existence for millennia. In addition, looting and smuggling of archaeological works contribute to the financing of ISIS/Daish terrorist activities. That is why I welcome the EU's funding to UNESCO for the three-year project to ensure the emergency protection of Syria's heritage. I am also convinced of the need for Eurojust and Europol to take decisive action with a sound international exchange of information to prevent and stop the illegal trade in cultural goods.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. Unfortunately, we are currently experiencing modern-day barbarism when we have to watch radical Islamists from the so-called Islamic State . For no reason at all, and with a false reference to Islam, the Islamic State is destroying cultural values that have survived for hundreds and thousands of years and are part of the global cultural heritage. Some of these monuments have been under Muslim rule for hundreds of years and have been stored. This is also confirmed by the completely extremist approach of the so-called Islamic State to all human values. The situation affects me all the more because I am myself active in an institution, the Kampa Meda Mládková Museum in Prague, which strives to keep works of art. I therefore clearly support the condemnation resolution as tabled in the EP.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Parliament on Thursday (April 30th) condemned the destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites by the Islamic State in Syria and Iraq. I voted in favour of this resolution, which strongly encourages the Relevant European Institutions to take adequate measures to combat such destruction and against the illegal trade in stolen cultural property in conflict zones in Syria and Iraq.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court, approved on 17 July 1998, recognizes as war crimes intentional attacks, among others, on buildings dedicated to religious worship, education and the arts, as well as historical monuments. In Syria and Iraq, numerous sites of archaeological, religious and cultural interest have recently been destroyed by extremist groups linked mainly to the Islamic State (ISIL/Daech). These systematic attacks on cultural heritage were defined by the Director-General of UNESCO as "cultural cleansing", signalling the cadence and correlation of the same, an intentional strategy that seeks to destroy cultural diversity through the deliberate persecution of individuals identified on the basis of their ethnic, religious or cultural origin. Some of these acts of destruction of cultural heritage were therefore considered, in certain circumstances, crimes against humanity. This resolution strongly condemns the intentional destruction of places of worship and cultural and archaeological interest carried out by ISIL in Syria and Iraq and calls on the EU and the Member States to make every effort to combat the illicit trade in misplaced cultural objects in Iraq and Syria. That's the only way you don't risk undue funding for ISIL. I voted in favour.

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I support this resolution denouncing the destruction of archaeological and religious cultural sites by the Islamic State group in Syria and Iraq.  Hundreds of rare manuscripts or ancient artifacts, belonging to our common cultural heritage, were destroyed by Da'esh. The large-scale degradation of humanity's cultural heritage is a nameless barbarity, and should include crimes against humanity in international law.   The European Union cannot remain silent in the face of this situation. We call on the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs to take appropriate measures to prevent the illegal trade in these cultural goods of Syrian or Iraqi origin. Under no circumstances should works of art from conflict zones be able to be bought or sold in Europe and thus be used as sources of terrorist financing.  It is of course our responsibility to prevent further looting of archaeological sites, as well as to protect the lives of civilians.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Parliament's resolution as it strongly condemns the deliberate destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites perpetrated by the Islamic State in Syria and Iraq, a fact which unesco's Director-General has defined as 'cultural cleansing'. The Resolution calls for a focus on preventing and combating the illegal trafficking of cultural property, especially with regard to objects of cultural heritage illegally exported from Iraq since 6 August 1990, and from Syria since 15 March 2011, as Unesco itself has warned, the looting and smuggling of cultural and religious objects and attractions in Syria and Iraq, in particular by EI/Daesh, is being used to help finance the terrorist activities of that group. It is therefore urgent to take the necessary measures to curb the destruction and looting of heritage and to expand the status of crimes against humanity so as to include acts that deliberately damage or destroy on a large scale the cultural heritage of humanity.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. The intentional destruction of places of worship and cultural and archaeological interest carried out by ISIL in Syria and Iraq must be the subject of the greatest repudiation and deep dismay and concern.  We are faced with real terrorist acts, which aim to destroy not only the patrimonial and cultural identity of peoples, but also to use cultural objects to finance criminal activities, since the illicit trade in cultural goods is the third most important illegal trade, after drug and arms trafficking. For this reason, I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution which seeks to raise awareness of the urgent need to end smuggling and illegal trade in cultural goods from these territories (e.g. through increased control at the external borders) and to develop an integrated cooperation policy that calls on Member States to engage in awareness-raising campaigns together with international bodies relevant to the protection of our cultural and heritage heritage , mainly in these conflict zones.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the destruction of cultural sites by ISIS/Da'ish because I believe it is right that the High Representative should do everything in his power to put an end to the illegal trade in cultural goods from the territories of Syria and Iraq, in order to prevent the proceeds of such sales from financing terrorist organisations. In particular, I believe that there is an urgent need for cooperation which will give the go-ahead for joint action to reconcile the various communities and rebuild the sites that have been destroyed.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Joint Resolution as we believe it is an important issue, not only because of the issue of the destruction of cultural heritage, but also because of the artifacts that have been looted and subsequently used to finance isIS/Daesh terrorist operations, among others. In this sense, cultural artifacts have been turned into "weapons of war".  In fact, illicit trafficking in cultural goods is the third largest illegal trade in the world – after the trafficking of drugs and weapons – and therefore requires a strong political position on the part of the European Parliament. We believe that the Joint Resolution is in this direction and therefore we join it.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote contained positive elements, such as condemnation of the destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites committed by Islamic State (IS) organization militias in Syria and Iraq, the countries most punished for their activities. Similarly, EU authorities are asked to tie up illegal trafficking in such goods, which is a source of IS funding. However, I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution, as long as it uses EU security and defence policy without recognising or even mentioning the responsibility of EU states in promoting the breeding ground for the situation, promoting conflict and war in Iraq and Syria , and the facilitation of financing and access to armaments that have led to the emergence of IS.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the destruction of museums and historic sites by Isis in Syria and Iraq. These acts of intolerance reflect the deliberate attempt to erase all forms of cultural, ethnic and religious diversity. In the light of these facts, I believe that it is extremely urgent to safeguard and protect all those cultural goods present in conflict zones that could be the subject of such barbarism. In addition to defence, I trust that a work will be undertaken to enhance the historical heritage left to us by the civilizations of the past so that we can better appreciate the importance that these goods hold for all the citizens of the world. With this in mind, I hope that the European Union, in cooperation with UNESCO and the International Criminal Court, will take the necessary measures to recognise the systematic and deliberate disintegration of cultural heritage not only as a war crime but also as a crime against humanity as a whole.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ We strongly condemn the intentional destruction by ISIS of cultural, archaeological and religious sites in Syria and Iraq. We have called on the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to take appropriate action at political level, in accordance with UN Security Council Resolution 2199 of 12 February 2015, in order to put an end to the illegal trade in cultural property from the territories of Syria and Iraq during periods of conflict in those territories, thereby preventing the use of such property as a source of financing.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this motion as ISIS threatens the cultural and religious heritage and traditions of the region and, indeed, the wider world. Behind this there is a much more serious problem: the advance of ISIS forces in Iraq and Syria that has led to the enslavement, murder or forced conversion and eviction of thousands of Christians and people from other religions and ethnic minorities.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – I supported the motion for a resolution which strongly condemns the modern barbarity of the deliberate destruction of archaeological sites, religiously and culturally significant monuments perpetrated by groups of extremists linked mainly to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. While such acts linked to the destruction of cultural and historical monuments and objects are not new, they are not limited to the territory of Iraq and Syria, but according to UNESCO, "cultural heritage" is an important part of the cultural identity of communities, groups and individuals. Therefore, its deliberate destruction may have adverse consequences for human dignity and human rights, stressing that the pillaging and smuggling of cultural and religious monuments and objects in Iraq and Syria by ISOS officers is being used to support the financing of ISIS terrorist activities, leading to goods of an artistic and cultural nature becoming 'weapons of war'. Therefore, the destruction, defamation and sale of cultural monuments must be strongly condemned and, where possible, prevented from being destroyed.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's resolution to destroy cultural sites committed by the ISIS/Daesh group. Recently, a number of archaeological, religious and cultural sites in Syria and Iraq have been targeted destruction targets by extremist groups linked specifically to the so-called islamic state. Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, and it was necessary to strongly condemn the deliberate destruction of cultural heritage with the aim of "cultural cleansing".  Furthermore, it was important to call on the Commission, the High Representative, the EU and its Member States to implement more effective security measures at the EU's external borders to prevent the smuggling of cultural goods from Syria and Iraq into the Union, as illicit trade in cultural goods is now the third most important area of illicit trade after drug and arms trafficking, which finances the illicit activities of ISIS.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I support the motion for a resolution over attacks carried out by the ISIS/Daesh group on the Bardo Museum in Tunis and the deliberate destruction of the Mosul Museum in Iraq and historical sites in Syria. Such actions take on a much larger scale than just cultural tragedies, they could be called cultural cleansing. The terrorists' strategy and goal is to destroy what belongs to the common heritage of humanity to destabilize the population and destroy their identity. Under the UNESCO Convention on the Protection and Promotion of the Diversity of Cultural Expressions signed 10 years ago, this common heritage should be "nurtured and preserved for the benefit of all".

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. \u2012 I have expressed my condemnation more than one time of the barbaric actions of members of various terrorist organisations who systematically destroy cultural sites in Syria or Iraq. For me, supporting the resolution on the destruction of cultural sites by ISIS/Daesh means not only this self-evident condemnation of attacks on the cultural identity and history of the inhabitants of all regions affected in this way, but also my agreement to improve the procedures for reducing the illegal trafficking of artefacts used by various terrorist organisations to finance their activities.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We strongly condemn the destruction of monuments by the Islamic Caliphate.  Our primary responsibility is to take measures that will contribute to the protection of cultural heritage.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. Nearly 300 Syrian cultural heritage sites have been destroyed, damaged or looted in more than three years of war. Added to the civil war is the threat posed by the Islamic State (IS) group, which is accused in Iraq of destroying historic sites and, at the same time, selling antiquities to finance itself. IS believes the statues are idolatry, has blown up many churches and other monuments, shrines of Christian, Jewish or Muslim heritage. Let us not forget that IS has mastered the communication slots. It is likely that some of the so-called destroyed works are in fact only copies, the originals, priceless and steeped in history being sold to the highest bidders in order to continue to finance their barbaric terrorism. Finally, I would be remiss if I denounced this cultural extermination, not to mention the human extermination that punctuates the daily lives of Syrians and all living inhabitants, or rather surviving in the entire area of influence of the Islamic State group. All dictatorships have always been based on fear and blackmail. This is no different here. Europe cannot simply watch the United States negotiate with the bloodthirsty Bashar al-Assad or witness the burning of this part of the world!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ More than the smuggling of art (which is carried out not only by Da’esh ), Da’esh destroys cultural sites and thus takes part in real ‘cultural cleansing’. This is not a massacre, not a beheading or a crucifixion of the kind previously perpetrated by Da’esh, but it is a form of violence that hurts in a very special way as it attacks the common history and memory of humanity. Their reflex is to eradicate everything that does not fit their conception of life. These are the reasons why I voted in favour of this resolution, which asks the European Union, together with UNESCO and the International Criminal Court, to extend the international law category of ‘crimes against humanity’ so that it encompasses acts which wilfully damage or destroy the cultural heritage of mankind on a large scale.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Joint Resolution as we believe it is an important issue, not only because of the issue of the destruction of cultural heritage, but also because of the artifacts that have been looted and subsequently used to finance isIS/Daesh terrorist operations, among others. In this sense, cultural artifacts have been turned into "weapons of war".  In fact, illicit trafficking in cultural goods is the third largest illegal trade in the world – after the trafficking of drugs and weapons – and therefore requires a strong political position on the part of the European Parliament. We believe that the Joint Resolution is in this direction and therefore we join it.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. ISIS and more generally the Islamic armed factions that are now active in the countries of the Near and Middle East are not only carrying out massacres of entire and targeted populations, but also the destruction and trafficking of cultural and cultural goods. Property that generally makes the immense wealth of the countries they claim to want to govern as in Syria where heritage is systematically targeted. The return of cultural property that has been trafficked must be a long-term objective. The resolution condemns ISIS, identified as such but should also condemn other armed groups such as the al-Nusra Front, which Minister Fabius recently said "is doing a good job". So I'm voting FOR.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this Joint Resolution as we believe it is an important issue, not only because of the issue of the destruction of cultural heritage, but also because of the artifacts that have been looted and subsequently used to finance isIS/Daesh terrorist operations, among others. In this sense, cultural artifacts have been turned into "weapons of war".  In fact, illicit trafficking in cultural goods is the third largest illegal trade in the world – after the trafficking of drugs and weapons – and therefore requires a strong political position on the part of the European Parliament. We believe that the Joint Resolution is in this direction and therefore we join it.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. It is necessary to condemn and denounce the crime against world cultural heritage that IS/Daesh is perpetrating in the area. This Resolution aims to draw attention to this, as well as to propose solutions to these desponable actions. That is why I vote in favour of that resolution.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The resolution put to the vote contained positive elements, such as condemnation of the destruction of cultural, archaeological and religious sites committed by Islamic State (IS) organization militias in Syria and Iraq, the countries most punished for their activities. Similarly, EU authorities are asked to tie up illegal trafficking in such goods, which is a source of IS funding. However, I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution, as long as it uses EU security and defence policy without recognising or even mentioning the responsibility of EU states in promoting the breeding ground for the situation, promoting conflict and war in Iraq and Syria , and the facilitation of financing and access to armaments that have led to the emergence of IS.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The destruction of the ancient city of Hatra in northern Iraq is symbolic of Daesh's desire to destroy cultural sites and property in Iraq and Syria.  While the extent of the damage in the ancient city is not yet confirmed or known, many other destructions have taken place in recent months, including that of the archaeological city of Nirmoud and some treasures in the Mosul museum.  These destructions, which can be equated with war crimes, irreparably damage the heritage of humanity in this region where the first great civilizations were born. The resolution also denounces the illicit trafficking of Syrian and Iraqi cultural property that funds terrorist groups.  Although I believe that the resolution should also have addressed the destruction committed by all parties to the conflict including the Syrian authorities and the Syrian army, I still voted for it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is very concerned that in Syria, Iraq and Tunisia, numerous sites of archaeological, religious and cultural interest are being destroyed by extremist groups mainly linked to the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria. According to UNESCO, the term 'cultural cleansing' indicates an intentional strategy that seeks to destroy cultural diversity through the deliberate persecution of individuals identified on the basis of their ethnic, religious or cultural origin, combined with deliberate attacks on their places of worship, memory and education. It is too bad that this EU is the same one that contributes decisively to arming and training the fanatical gangs that now lead more these barbaric attacks. As for destabilising countries such as Libya, Syria or Iraq, these same gangs were liberating heroes who were going to impose democracy against regimes that no longer serve the interests of the West. It's a shame! It is the EU, the United States and NATO who should be sitting in the dock who are sure to sit in the dock, who have lied to the peoples of Europe and tied their countries to this absurd war that has already killed millions of innocent people.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution calling for the coverage of "crimes against humanity" to be expanded to the destruction of the artistic heritage by virtue of what is happening in the territories occupied by ISIS. Attacking the artistic heritage of a people means destroying their memory and ending the cultural heritage of an entire region. Millennia of civilization's advancement and millennia of artistic and social innovations and evolutions cannot be attacked by blind and censorious hatred. Europe must promote the idea that attacking culture is an attack on humanity.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
