text: Writing. The resolution illustrates the understanding of policy and consensus in the EP. It is true that the authors of the Joint Resolution admit in recital I that measures against the illegal trade in cultural goods, customs and border surveillance do not explicitly fall within the competence of the EU in that the Treaties do not contain any provisions to that extent. That is absolutely right. However, in the same recital, artificial cross-connections are immediately created in order to restore competences to the EU over seven pages of resolutions! I don't play this game. That is why I voted in favour of motion for a resolution B8-0389/2015, which I myself tabled with a number of colleagues on behalf of the ECR Group. We make it clear that the import of goods, customs duties and excise duties and legislation is primarily the responsibility of individual Member States and third countries. If existing national laws to prevent the import and sale of stolen cultural goods are completely inadequate in some countries, the national legislator must improve, but not the EU Commission. We call for a more effective use of Interpol's database of stolen works of art in order to combat the illegal trade in cultural goods. And we appreciate the efforts of the national police forces (such as the Metropolitan Police's Arts and Antiquities Unit) to tackle criminal activity in this area.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Just as the heinous and horrific crimes ISIS commits against ordinary civilians are a matter not only for Iraqis and Syrians but for humanity at large, so the destruction of these ancient cultural sites is a matter of common human heritage and identity. I voted in favour of the resolution as I think it is right that the international community should move to address these crimes. The resolution calls particularly for efforts to track and document that which has been lost, and for support for the brave Syrian and Iraqi archaeologists who are attempting to document artefacts that have been destroyed, and to prevent looting, at risk to their own lives. The concern for common historic cultural artefacts goes hand in hand with the EU’s moral obligation to support the victims of ISIS’ crimes against humanity, and to come up a moral and humane response to those thousands of refugees fleeing these wars, crossing seas and risking their lives to seek safety. That very same common humanity embodied by our common cultural heritage mandates us to provide a compassionate response to their plight.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Numerous archaeological, religious and cultural sites in Syria and Iraq have recently been targeted by extremist groups linked in particular to the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS/Da'ish). These acts of destruction have been regarded as a real cultural cleansing, or even crimes against humanity. Unfortunately, these acts of barbarism are often not only limited to monuments and buildings, but also lead to violence against ethnic and religious minorities. I hope that the European Union will take the necessary measures as soon as possible, in cooperation with UNESCO and the International Criminal Court, to extend the international law of crimes against humanity, so that it also includes acts that deliberately result in the large-scale damage or destruction of humanity's cultural heritage.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: Writing. – The JRC strongly and unequivocally condemns the crimes, vandalism and looting of "jihadists" against priceless historical monuments and works of humanity's world culture. The connections of the "jihadists" with the circuits of antiquity for the sale of looted archaeological treasures, with willing buyers within the "artificial" plutocracy, show that the creator of the monster of "jihadists" are the imperialists of the EU-US-NATO, the rot of capitalism. The joint resolution of the European Parliament does not say a word about all this. On the contrary, it is once again using these heinous acts to promote the extension of the eu's network of repressive mechanisms, the interconnection of Europol and Eurojust with Interpol and international cultural organisations, the creation of new repressive networks and monitoring, the expansion of CFSP operations, such as the EU Satellite Centre in Torrejón, the sealing of the EU's external borders , the extension of the powers of the International Criminal Court. Once again, it turns out that this union of capital does not hesitate to use anything to copper new bonds, repression, interventions and wars against the peoples for the interests of monopolies. The only way out for the people is to leave the EU and the capital chains, with wealth producers taking the helm of power and the economy.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. \u2012 I find it completely unacceptable that ISIS deliberately destroys and loots cultural, archaeological and religious monuments. Above all, I fear that parts of them are being sold on the black market and thus may to a large extent be a source of funding for ISIS itself. I therefore supported this resolution, which calls, inter alia, on Europol and Eurojust to try to prevent this trade. Here I see great EU added value.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. The resolution voted on condemns the human rights situation in the Maldives, especially with respect to the media and civil society. It also highlights the situation of former President Mohamed Nasheed, who is in prison when anti-terrorism law has been applied to him. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution because it intends to protect that country's political process, including the correlation of forces that must prevail. Europe's experience in this field is extensive, and its results are paupérrimos.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of democracy, transparency and accountability, I would like to place on the record that I abstained on this motion for a resolution.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, in which the European Parliament expresses its deep concern at the growing trend of authoritarian regimes in the Maldives, the crackdown on political opponents, the intimidation of the media and civil society. The EP also expresses its concern at the serious violations in the trial of former President Mohamed Nasheed, urging his immediate release. Mr Nasheed, known as committed to the peaceful fight for human rights, was imprisoned several times during the 30-year dictatorship of President Maumoon Abdul Gayoon and resigned from power in controversial circumstances four years after becoming the first democratically elected President of the Maldives. I support the calls for an immediate end to political interference in the Maldivian judicial system and for its depoliticisation to be ensured. It is important that the EU High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy and the European External Action Service continue to closely monitor the political situation in the Maldives and act actively in the EU's development of bilateral relations with that country.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Without endorsing the practices implicated in this text, I voted against this resolution, which goes too far in interfering.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In view of the recent increase in tension in the Maldives, the European Parliament expresses its concern at the political crisis in which the country is sinking and calls on the High Representative of the Union to monitor the situation with vigilance.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This resolution on the situation in the Maldives refers to serious failures in the Maldives judicial system and several serious breaches of freedom of expression and the democratic game. In addition, there is concern about the increase in the number of Islamist militants in the Maldives, particularly the large number of young men who have reportedly joined the terrorist group "Islamic State".  Nevertheless, considering that the Union and the States do not have to interfere in the internal affairs of other sovereign nations, I abstained on this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted to support this resolution in which we call on the Government of the Maldives to work hard to restore its commitment to democracy and respect for freedom of expression, assembly, due process and religion.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The political situation has deteriorated in the Maldives over the past few months, with constant protests, clashes between protesters and police and dozens of arrests with which the authorities, as reported by organizations such as Amnesty International, are trying to gag peaceful protesters and silence critical media and civil society. Abuses are also being recorded in the judicial system, such as the case of former President Mohamed Nasheed, whose trial began the day after his arrest and whose sentence was handed down after nineteen days of trial. The United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights has not hesitated to criticize the violation of the Maldives' own laws and international standards for a fair trial. In view of this situation, it is urgent that the parties involved avoid any action that could aggravate the situation, that violence against peaceful protests be ended and that those who have perpetrated violent attacks against them be persecuted. It also urges that political forces behave according to democratic standards and that any attempt at intimidation of political opposition to return the Maldives to the path to the transition to democracy ceases.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I express concern about the deepening political crisis in the Maldives and call on all parties to refrain from any action that could further exacerbate the crisis.  Security forces must urgently end violence against peaceful protesters and start protecting them from violent groups.  Furthermore, I would like to point out the serious irregularities in the trial of former President Mohamed Nasheed and call on all parties to work together to remediate the negative consequences of these irregularities, the way to ensure fairness in a fair and transparent judicial process.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted yes to this resolution since I believe that the situation in the Maldives is worrisome and that we should press the Government there to have democracy and the rule of law reinstated.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The resolution notes that the Maldives ranks among the worst countries in the world in terms of attacks, torture and intimidation of opposition MPs. The political unrest comes amid concerns about growing militant Islamism and the number of radicalized young people who are siding with ISIS.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in the Maldives. The authoritarian drift of the Republic is very worrying. Indeed, there is a growing political interference in the judicial system and a consequent deprivation of certain freedoms of civil society and the media. This is particularly worrying. In addition, former President Mohamed Nasheed, a staunch defender of human rights and democratic pluralism, was sentenced to 13 years in prison. The trial of the former president does not respect international judicial rules. Through this resolution, the European Parliament calls on the Maldives to improve considerably.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in the Maldives because the Maldives archipelago is experiencing one of the most turbulent phases in its political history, marked by massive popular protests and fiery judicial controversy. A period of serious political and institutional instability, comparable in some respects to the dramatic events of September 2003 that pushed the country on the road to democracy. The situation remains extremely tense and the risk of a violent degeneration of anti-government demonstrations has been denounced on several occasions by international diplomatic representatives, who have called on the parties concerned to have a constructive dialogue and a peaceful resolution of their differences.  Europe must intervene more fully in the political crisis in the country by exerting the necessary pressure on the local authorities and possibly temporarily suspending cooperation relations with the Maldives, until a return to a situation of normality and respect for human rights.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this joint motion for a resolution calling for the immediate release of former president Mohamed Nasheed, who is being tried on questionable charges in the Maldives. The joint motion calls for respect for the rule of law, due process, an independent judiciary, fair trials and civil and political rights. Furthermore, it calls for an end to violence against protesters, condemns the reintroduction of the death penalty, and calls for a full investigation into the disappearance of a reporter. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I welcomed the resolution's condemnation of the reintroduction of the death penalty in the Maldives and the call for an end to political interference in the judicial system. I also agree with the concern expressed about the repression of the political opposition and intimidation of the media and civil society.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this resolution concerning the situation in the Maldives.  Of course, it is clear that I do not condone certain practices of the Maldives authorities denounced in the report. Thus, I am obviously shocked by this decision of 27 April 2014 taken by the Parliament of the Maldives and which authorizes the conviction of minors from the age of seven, who can be held responsible and executed from their eighteenth birthday and languish in prison until their execution. Despite my personal views on these acts objectively contrary to respect for the human person and the rights of the child, I could not, however, vote in favour of this resolution which calls for full interference in the political and legislative processes of the Maldives. If I am deeply committed to freedom of expression, the right to protest, and freedom at all, it is not for the European institutions to urge a sovereign government to take this or that measure, to carry out a particular reform or to choose a particular political or economic orientation. Because I believe in the balance between convictions and political realism, I chose to abstain.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. The resolution voted on condemns the human rights situation in the Maldives, especially with respect to the media and civil society. It also highlights the situation of former President Mohamed Nasheed, who is in prison when anti-terrorism law has been applied to him. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution because it intends to protect that country's political process, including the correlation of forces that must prevail. Europe's experience in this field is extensive, and its results are paupérrimos.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. \u2012 Political tension is rising in the Maldives, with regular protests and clashes between demonstrators and police. At least 140 protesters were arrested in February, and many of them were limited to taking part in other demonstrations.   Violence against peaceful protesters must stop, security forces have a duty to protect peaceful demonstrators from violent gangs, and perpetrators of such violent attacks must respond to justice. It is very important to ensure a credible political climate, with the participation of all democratic forces, in order to restore order and maintain stability in the Maldives. Political interference in the judiciary must also be stopped and urgent reforms must be approved and implemented to ensure the independence and impartiality of the judiciary.  The European Commission, through the EU's European External Action Service, must continue to monitor the political situation in the Maldives and play an active role in the EU's bilateral relations with the country, in order to contribute to achieving stability and strengthening democracy and the rule of law, and to advocate for full respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms in that country.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution expresses its grave concern about increasing tendencies towards authoritarian rule in the Maldives, the crackdown on political opponents and intimidation of the media and civil society, which could jeopardise gains made in recent years. As a major international player advocating democracy and development, it is Europe’s role to assist and support countries like the Maldives. That is why I supported this resolution.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution expresses the European Parliament's concern at the growing authoritarian excesses in the Maldives as a result of the repression of political opponents, the media and civil society. Moreover, all indications are that the current trial of former President Mohamed Nasheed, elected in 2008 and overthrown in 2012 by a mutiny of the army and police, suffers from serious irregularities. It is also of concern that the death penalty has been reinstated in the Maldives, ending the current moratorium on the practice. Considering these elements that it is necessary for the European Union to make its contribution to a credible and open political process to end the current crisis, with a view to restoring and preserving stability in the Maldives and enabling democratic transition, in accordance with the rule of law and human rights, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. With this resolution, the European Parliament wished to strongly condemn the threats to the rule of law in the Maldives. I strongly insist that the death penalty is by no means a solution. I call on the executive and legislative branches of the Maldives to listen to the demands of the European Parliament.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The situation in the Maldives is deteriorating alarmingly. In the face of growing political tensions, the Maldivian authorities are using methods that undermine the impartiality of justice and the rights of defence, with a view to politically eliminating opponents. Several prominent opposition figures have been jailed, including Mohamed Nasheed, a human rights activist and former president of the republic who was recently sentenced to 13 years in prison for terrorism. The European Parliament resolution calls on all parties in the Maldives to avoid any action that could aggravate the growing authoritarian excesses and respect democracy and the rule of law. The international community must mobilize and put pressure on those responsible to end all forms of violence against peaceful protesters, the critical media and civil society. Finally, the perpetrators of violent attacks must be swiftly brought to justice.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. The Maldives is among the worst countries in the world in terms of torture, intimidation of the opposition, the media and civil society. There are many authoritarian excesses, such as the re-establishment of the death penalty. Currently, in the Maldives, minors can be sentenced as young as seven years of age and executed as early as their eighteenth birthday. In the meantime, they languish in prison. This is an intolerable situation, contrary to international human rights obligations and the Convention on the Rights of the Child. I support the call for the reinstatement of the moratorium on the death penalty. I also deplore the serious irregularities found in the trial of the former Speaker, two former ministers and the former Vice-President of the House. I support the demand that their release and respect for their rights. I support the call for an immediate end to political interference and the depoliticization of the Maldives judicial system. I call for a credible and open political process that brings together all democratic forces to restore and preserve stability in the Maldives and put the country back on the path to democratic transition.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation in the Maldives is highly disturbing and progressively deteriorating. The first democratically elected president, Mr. Mohammed Nasheed, was sentenced to 13 years in prison. on the basis of politically motivated terrorism charges. Despite the UN and EU's call for fairness and transparency of the judicial process, it has in no way met national and international justice standards.  On top of that, civil society organisations and human rights defenders are increasingly facing harassment, threats and attacks, including the Maldives Human Rights Commission, accused by the Supreme Court of treason and undermining the constitution for submitting a report on the human rights situation in the Maldives for the purposes of the UN Human Rights Council's universal periodic review. The European Parliament resolution strongly condemns what is happening in the Maldives and calls for an immediate end to political interference with the Maldives judicial system and its depoliticisation. Urgent reforms are needed to ensure the independence and impartiality of the Maldivian judiciary in order to restore confidence in its functioning inside the country and internationally.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: in writing. This resolution aims to express the EP's discontent with the growing authoritarian impetus in the Maldives, political persecution of opposition leaders and the media, the renewal of the application of the death penalty, the failure to respect the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary, as well as the application of illegitimate coercive violence against peaceful protesters, all calling into question a fragile balance of respect for human rights in the archipelago.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The increased trend towards an authoritarian regime in the Maldives, the repression of political opponents and the intimidation of the media and civil society, which could jeopardise the progress made in recent years in human rights, democracy and the rule of law in the country, are worrying situations. The most elementary basic rights of justice are also not being fully fulfilled, as evidenced by the trial of the former President of the Maldives. A judgment which has raised many doubts for the international community, which insists on its release and full respect for its rights, in particular in judicial proceedings and in compliance with the national Constitution and the international obligations assumed. The reintroduction of the death penalty is reprehensible and the immediate end of all forms of violence, including violence against peaceful demonstrators, must be ensured. National authorities should concentrate their efforts to eliminate trafficking in human beings and to ensure that the country achieves stability, strengthens democracy and the rule of law and ensures full respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent succession of political and judicial events in the Maldives is putting a strain on the democratic principles of the 2008 Constitution, in particular those relating to the independence of the judiciary from political power. The period of serious political and institutional instability is the cause of a resurgence of authoritarian drift and abuse of power. A source of concern is the context of increasing religious radicalism in which political unrest takes place. I strongly condemn the reintroduction of the death penalty, the repression of political opponents and the attacks on freedom of expression and information involved journalists, associations and ordinary citizens. All this has jeopardised the progress made in recent years in terms of human rights, democracy and the rule of law, casting a significant shadow over the current geopolitical balances of the Indian Ocean. It is to be hoped that action will also be taken within the international community to facilitate the socio-political stability of the Maldives.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the tasks of the European Union is also the role of the human rights arbiter in third countries. It is therefore worrying that an unfair trial is being brought against former President Mohammed Nassi in the Maldives. He was denied access to a lawyer at the start of the trial and was subsequently 4 days after the lawyers resigned in protest at the perception of the trial as biased and aimed at ruining the former president's political career. The ongoing escalating violent campaign of intimidation of critics of the government, including the media, is underscoring human rights and violating international obligations under the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the resolution as the Maldives sadly ranks among the worst countries in the world in terms of attacks, torture and intimidation of opposition MPs.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the joint motion for a resolution because it does not propose decisive measures to defend human rights and the principles of the rule of law in the Maldives.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ It is clear that the Maldives are no longer just a paradise for tourists. They have become a place where there is increasing danger posed by fundamentalists, by an inefficient and politicised judiciary and by an erosion of human rights and democratic principles. The ‘show trial’ of former President Mohamed Nasheed is the demonstration of this dysfunctional state of democracy. This so-called trial fails to respect the basic principles of a fair trial and goes against the Maldivian Constitution. We have always been at the forefront in our commitment to and support for consolidating democracy, promoting good governance, strengthening key institutions and helping the Maldives to address social, environmental and transnational challenges. It is important that we continue to play a role in the country’s democratic transition by firmly calling for an end to violence against peaceful protesters and by ensuring that Mr Nasheed’s rights are fully respected in accordance with the Maldives’ international obligations and standards.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. On March 13, 2015, former Maldives President Mohamed Nasheed was sentenced to thirteen years in prison on charges of terrorism for ordering the arrest of the then chief judge of the Criminal Court in January 2012. It is also highly worrying that opposition politicians continue to be routinely intimidated. To these worrying events it should be added that at least 140 peaceful protesters have been arrested since February. We must demand the immediate release of former President Mohamed Nasheed. From the European Parliament we must express our concern about the growing trend towards an authoritarian regime in the Maldives, as well as the crackdown on political opposition.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 On 13 March, the former President of the Maldives was sentenced to 13 years in prison on terrorism charges for the arrest of the then Criminal Court judge in 2012. The circumstances in which the arrest took place, in a state in which the phenomenon of Islamic radicalisation is soaring and in which the judiciary is, according to all the main international observers, collateral to political power, oblige us to make our voice heard. Authoritarian tendencies must be brought to an end and democracy and the rule of law must be re-established as soon as possible. In the resolution we have also called on the High Representative and the EEAS to continue to be vigilant and to do everything in their power to achieve these objectives.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I voted for and helped draft the resolution on the political situation in the Maldives, which expresses great concern at the growing tendencies towards authoritarianism in the country, the repression of the political opposition and intimidation of the media and civil society. These actions risk jeopardising the progress made in recent years in terms of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. I therefore also call on the parties to refrain from actions that could aggravate the crisis and to respect democracy and the rule of law.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because the constitutional crisis in the Maldives is causing problems not only because of the country's fragile situation in a difficult climate zone, but also because of the increasing radicalisation of drug distribution and entrenchment, especially among young people. The EU must therefore assist democratic processes in this country, monitor elections and cooperate with the future democratically elected government of the country.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: Writing. Years ago we went on holiday in the Maldives. Upon arrival, we were immediately taken from a bottle of champagne with which we wanted to pour the New Year. Customs officials justified this unfriendly act with the rules of Islam. Once on the island, we found that the hotel bar was better equipped with all common brands of alcoholic beverages than those in Hamburg. On the island we noticed something else: the service staff lived in poor huts away from the sight of the hotel guests. The government ruled the country as most Islamic countries are governed. There is no sign of democracy and human rights: girls and women in particular are being harassed in almost all countries. A few years ago, a young cosmopolitan prime minister was democratically elected in the Maldives and began to turn the country around. Today, in the European Parliament, I voted with almost all The Members in favour of a resolution which strongly protests against the condemnation of the young hopeful, who has since been disempowered by the mullahs. Under a flimsy pretext, the prime minister, who she overthrew by force, is to be sentenced to 13 years in prison for trying to introduce "Western values" in an Islamic country.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a resolution on the Maldives because it highlights the tense situation in that country caused by the highly suspicious circumstances surrounding the arrest of the former president of the Maldives. The expression of entitlement is logical, as the European Parliament expects a fair trial, the right of access to a lawyer and the possibility to appeal for each person, even more so in the present case. We also expect the Indian authorities to engage in this situation that can destabilize the situation in this island state in the long run.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support this motion which seeks to ensure that the rule of law is given full process in the Maldives. The European Union strives to promote democracy and a pluralistic society around the world. It is therefore imperative that we oppose the manner of the conviction of former Maldivian President Mohamed Nasheed, under anti-terrorist legislation and without access to a fair trial or the appropriate chance to lodge an appeal against the sentence. We must also oppose the decision in the Maldives to break the moratorium on the death penalty in 2014. It is important that we oppose any attempt to reintroduce capital punishment, particularly in nations with legal systems that are still developing and may still be volatile and inconsistent.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. We have debated today what is happening in the Maldives. Former President M. Nasheed was sentenced to 13 years for being guilty of terrorism for having a judge arrested in 2012 accused of corruption and abuse of power. The former President was initially denied the chance to have a lawyer and due process. I therefore join the High Representative and Parliament, in defence of the International Convention on Political and Civil Rights, in asking the Government of the Maldives to guarantee a fair trial, in the knowledge of the impartiality of the law.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. On 23 April, an Amnesty International report was published saying that human rights in the Maldives are in "free fall" and accuses the authorities of gazing peaceful protesters, silencing critical media and civil society, while abusing the judicial system to imprison opposition politicians. There is mention of the emergence of religious vigilante groups – allegedly in collusion with the police – which has led to an increase in abductions and attacks on social gatherings in recent years, particularly against those accused of promoting atheism.  The current situation may also have implications for the country's economy, which is heavily dependent on foreign tourists. The tourism sector is the backbone of the Maldives economy, as it represents an important part of national income and its foreign exchange reserves.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒The Resolution on the Situation in the Maldives highlights problems with the constitutional order and the disregard for hard-scored democracy in the state. The Union participated in the process of democratising the Maldives, but did not continue to exercise strong enough control, resulting in the creation of authoritarian power and violations of the Constitution.  The first democratically elected, now former President Mohamed Nasheed, was sentenced to 13 years in prison without proper legal representation and in violation of his human rights. Media freedom is under threat, there is no rule of law, institutions are politicized and Islamist influences are increasing. I support a resolution highlighting the need for European Union intervention to restore constitutional order, democracy and respect for human rights and international agreements in the Maldives.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech of 29/4/2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament. This is a resolution which rightly condemns the arrest of Mohamed Nasheed, as well as the systematic violation of human rights and democratic rights in general in the Maldives by the authorities of that state.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The lack of political independence and the inadequate functioning of the Maldives judicial system undermine the national and international credibility of this territory. To make this situation worse, there is little respect for fundamental human rights within the country. It is no coincidence that the Maldives is one of the worst countries in the world in terms of attacks, torture and intimidation of opposition Members of Parliament. I voted in favour of this resolution because I hope that urgent reforms will be carried out to ensure the restoration of the rule of law within the country.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution stresses the need for the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and the External Action Service to promote democracy and the rule of law in the Maldives. The level of authoritarianism in the country is of concern and the EU must play a proactive role in tackling human rights abuses. Therefore I chose to support the resolution in the interest of the Maldives’ transition to a functioning democracy.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in the Maldives, which calls for an immediate end to violence against peaceful protesters, and for the perpetrators of such violent attacks to be brought to justice.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution raises concerns about the problems in the Maldives in the judicial system and serious attacks on freedom of expression and the democratic game, fuelled by the dramatic increase in the number of young Islamist militant men in the Maldives who have joined Islamic State terrorists.  While the situation is serious and worrying, interference in the affairs of a sovereign state must not be interfered with. As a result, I abstained in this vote.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the situation in the Maldives. The text points to a decline in the rule of law in this Indian Ocean archipelago and calls for vigilance in the face of several phenomena affecting the country: forced labour, sexual exploitation of children and women, armed militias, an increase in radicalized young men, the restoration of the death penalty by the government, etc.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this motion for a resolution, which has become necessary in view of the escalation of violence and the recent political tensions in the Maldives following the trial of former President Nasheed. Since then, there have been numerous clashes between protesters, gangs and police, and at least 140 opponents have been arrested since February. We call on all parties involved to restore the order and fundamental principles of the rule of law. We consider that the rights of defendants have not been adequately protected in the numerous trials brought against former members of the government. We call for a fair, credible, impartial and inclusive political process, with the participation of all democratic forces. We also express our concern at the current political and social crisis situation and hope that this resolution will be a stimulus for the political authorities in the Maldives to ensure the depoliticisation of the judicial system and adequate protection of the rights of defendants and demonstrators. We also call on the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative to continue to monitor the situation and to play a proactive role in the search for a political solution, in order to strengthen the democratic system in the Maldives and ensure full respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms in the country.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which expresses great concern at the growing tendencies towards authoritarianism in the Maldives, the repression of the political opposition and the intimidation of the media and civil society, which risk jeopardising the progress made in recent years in terms of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. I hope that the High Representative will continue to follow closely the political situation in the Maldives and to play a proactive role in the European Union's bilateral relations with that country, in order to achieve stability, to strengthen democracy and the rule of law, and to ensure full respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 The state of the rule of law, the independence of justice in the Maldives is deficient. The arrest of a Criminal Court judge without good reason is a conclusive example of the frequent intimidation of opposition politicians, highlighted in a recent report by the Committee on the Rights of MPs within the Inter-Parliamentary Union, which placed Maldives among the world's top countries in terms of attacks, torture and intimidation of opposition MPs.  I signed and voted on this resolution because, with the amendments included, it comes with some concrete measures that it proposes to the Maldives authorities, with a view to resolving issues relating to non-compliance with the rule of law.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. I supported the proposal. The regime in the Maldives is increasingly prone to authoritarianism, the judiciary is flawed and not independent, opponents are forcibly suppressed, there are imprisonments, and the media and civil society are being held in fear. The motion for a resolution calls for the removal of these shortcomings in the Maldives and for the rule of law to be respected and compliance with the UN conventions to which the Maldives is a party. The resolution also draws attention to the former President's imprisonment and calls for him to be given an appeal and a fair trial.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank the rapporteur for his work and hope to have made my contribution.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ The human rights situation has deteriorated significantly in the Maldives in recent months. Bearing in mind the problems and difficulties that different countries of the world occasionally go through, as well as the experiences of suffering and pain that the Croatian people went through in the early 1990s in the aggression against Croatia and the bloody war that followed, I cannot be indifferent when I see hints of dangerous events regardless of what corner of the world they are happening in.  I support this resolution with the hope that it will be understood by the competent authorities as an incentive to act responsibly in preserving the constitutional rights and freedoms of their residents. This will certainly not be helped by the lifting of the moratorium on the death penalty, and also for cases involving juvenile offenders. I consider this inadmissible and call on the Government of the Maldives, together with my colleagues, to maintain the existing moratorium.  It is certain that the challenges posed by climate change are even more difficult ahead of the Maldives, and it is important to focus efforts on the common goals and well-being of the whole society. The deteriorating human rights situation and conflicts with each other do not help in any way.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I share concerns about the deepening political crisis in the Maldives and join calls for all parties to refrain from any action that could further exacerbate this crisis and act in a spirit of democracy and the rule of law. An immediate end to violence against peaceful protesters is needed. In doing so, security forces should protect participants in peaceful demonstrations from violent groups as part of their duties. The Maldives needs a credible and inclusive political process with the participation of all democratic forces to restore and preserve stability in the Maldives and to get the country back on the path to a democratic transition, making it of utmost importance to urgently stop intimidating political opponents.  It is high time to end political interference in the Maldives justice system and to depoliticise the judiciary. The Maldives needs urgent reforms to ensure the independence and impartiality of the Maldives judiciary with a view to rebuilding domestic and international trust in its work without further delay.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Following the conviction of former Maldives President Mohamed Nasheed and denial of the right to adequate legal representation at court hearings and access to trial reports necessary for the timely lodging of an appeal, the issue of judicial independence in the Maldives arises. The right to a fair trial and due process is a question of the rule of law and democracy that the European Union insists on in all segments of relations with countries of the world, in accordance with the provisions of the International Agreement on Civil and Political Rights. Given the frequent news of violations of the fundamental principles of democracy, it is important to ensure the conditions of political pluralism, the protection of human rights, democracy, media freedom, freedom of speech and assembly. It is important that the European Union, in cooperation with other international actors, thoroughly monitors the process of democratic transition in the Maldives, and that all available political and diplomatic means influence the taking of concrete measures to respect and protect human rights in that country. Ahead of a meeting of the UN Human Rights Council Working Group on Human Rights in Geneva in May this year, the European Parliament points to the alarming situation in the human rights and democracy segment of the Maldives, urges the establishment of the rule of law, and demands the democratisation of society, so I support this European Parliament resolution.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 Increasing authoritarianism, repression of the political opposition and intimidation of the media and civil society must be a source of concern for those who believe in democracy and freedom of expression. In the Maldives we are seeing a continuous escalation of forms of violence against those who criticise the government and express different views. The judicial system is also not independent and impartial, as we saw in the trial of Mohamed Nasheed, who was very dubiously convicted. It is absolutely essential that President Nasheed has a new credible process, with an independent judiciary and with the participation of all political forces. It is essential that stability and peace are restored in the country, so that the Maldives can be put back on the road to democracy.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. \u2012 Maldives is a symbol of holiday well-being for most of my compatriots, but now there is a real political drama with many features of human rights violations. I am therefore watching with concern the current trials of representatives of the former Maldivian government, which emerged from democratic elections and whose end is still shrouded in confusion. The very fact that former President Nased has been sentenced to 13 years in prison for terrorism, accused of wrongly dismissing the President of the Supreme Court, confirms doubts about the functioning of the rule of law in this Asian country. That is why the resolution under discussion today has received my support.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. MEPs adopted a resolution condemning the current situation in the Maldives and expressed deep concern about the government's authoritarian drift. IN particular, MEPs call for the improvement of the judicial system and the establishment of a depoliticized and more transparent system. I voted in favour of this resolution. MEPs have a duty to defend the EU's core values.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. On March 13, 2015, Mohamed Nasheed, former President of the Maldives, was sentenced to 13 years in prison on terrorism charges for the january 2012 arrest of the then-judge-president of the criminal court. The controversial trial did not respect national and international standards in the field of justice, despite the call by the United Nations and the EU for the judicial proceedings against former President Nasheed to be fair and transparent. This event is symptomatic of a set of violations of the rule of law, democracy and individual freedoms that have occurred lately in the Maldives. Consequently, the report examined here expresses its deep concern at the trends that threaten the democratic regime in the Maldives and regrets the irregularities in the trial of former President Mohamed Nasheed, insisting that it should be released immediately. Thus, if their conviction is appealed, their rights should be fully respected in accordance with the international obligations of the Maldives, its own Constitution and all guarantees of internationally recognised equitable proceedings. So I voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. The political situation has deteriorated in the Maldives over the past few months, with constant protests, clashes between protesters and police, and dozens of arrests with which the authorities, as reported by organizations such as Amnesty International, are trying to gag peaceful protesters and silence critical media and civil society. Abuses are also being recorded in the judicial system, such as the case of former President Mohamed Nasheed, whose trial began the day after his arrest and whose sentence was handed down after nineteen days of trial. The United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights has not hesitated to criticize the violation of the Maldives' own laws and international standards for a fair trial. In view of this situation, it is urgent that the parties involved avoid any action that could aggravate the situation, that violence against peaceful protests be ended and that those who have perpetrated violent attacks against them be persecuted. It also urges that political forces behave according to democratic standards and that any attempt at intimidation of political opposition to return the Maldives to the path to the transition to democracy ceases.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In this resolution, which I co-signed, the European Parliament calls on all parties in the Maldives to avoid any action that could aggravate the growing authoritarian excesses, and to respect democracy and the rule of law. The text calls for a credible and open political process that combines all democratic forces and an immediate halt to intimidation of political opponents and political interference. The text also calls for an immediate end to all forms of violence against peaceful protesters, the critical media and civil society. Parliament also calls for the depoliticization of the Maldives judicial system and "urgent" reforms to ensure the independence and impartiality of the judiciary. Deploring the "serious irregularities" in the trial of former President Mohamed Nasheed, we demanded his immediate release and that his rights be fully respected if his conviction is appealed.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Reports of constant political pressures, intimidation of the media and civil society, lack of independence and credibility of the judiciary in the Maldives are placing serious concerns about the effective progress made over the past few years in terms of advances in the defence of human rights, the principles of democracy and the rule of law. The circumstances surrounding the recent conviction of former President Mohamed Nasheed on terrorism charges and the end of the moratorium on the application of the death penalty raise serious doubts as to what the true rule of law in the Maldives will be. It is therefore extremely important that the European Union monitor future developments in this country and that, in the exercise of its external powers, it will help to restore the foundations for a credible and fair political process, from the very point of being democratic, which is capable of ensuring the principles of the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary and the rights, freedoms and guarantees of citizens , so I voted in favour of this Joint Resolution.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: In writing. I supported this resolution, which denounces the worrying situation in the Maldives and was drafted following the conviction of the former President of the Maldives to 13 years' imprisonment for terrorism.  The situation is worrying given the conduct of the trial and the obstacles that prevented the former president's access to his lawyers and also prevented him from being able to appeal his judgment within the required time frame. At the same time, the overall situation in the country is worrying with the re-establishment last year of the death penalty, including for minors.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 With the joint resolution on the situation in the Maldives, we wanted to strongly criticise the government which, by suppressing the freedom of the press, restricting the right to due process in proceedings that could be to their detriment and reintroducing the death penalty, is implementing a policy that is not at all democratic. To this end, we have asked the High Representative to play an important role in helping that country regain stability and democracy and to restore the rule of law.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. The resolution voted on condemns the human rights situation in the Maldives, especially with respect to the media and civil society. It also highlights the situation of former President Mohamed Nasheed, who is in prison when anti-terrorism law has been applied to him. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution because it intends to protect that country's political process, including the correlation of forces that must prevail. Europe's experience in this field is extensive, and its results are paupérrimos.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ We are concerned about increasing tendencies towards authoritarian rule in the Maldives, the crackdown on political opponents and intimidation of the media and civil society, which could jeopardise the gains made in recent years in establishing human rights, democracy and the rule of law in the country. There must be an immediate end to all forms of violence, including violence against peaceful protesters, and the security forces should be reminded of their duty to protect peaceful demonstrators against violent gangs.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – The situation in the Maldives recently raises serious concerns and concerns about the fates of political opponents, but also about the increasing tendency towards an authoritarian regime in the Maldives, the prosecution of the political opposition, the intimidation of the media and civil society, which could frustrate the progress made in recent years with regard to the implementation of human rights, democracy and the rule of law in that country. Working migrants are subjected to forced labour, the seizure of identity documents and travel documents, the retention or non-payment of wages and debt slavery, and the Maldivian authorities have threatened to expel them for their protests against discrimination and violence following attacks on working migrants. Also, several women from other countries are victims of trafficking in the Maldives, and some Maldivian children are allegedly victims of sexual abuse or forced labour. I therefore support the resolution calling on the Government of the Maldives to put an immediate end to political interference in the justice system and to put an immediate end to all forms of violence, including violence against peaceful demonstrators, and to stabilise the security situation in the country.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The recent conviction of the first democratically elected and now former Maldives president Mohamed Nasheed, to 13 years in prison, raises serious and reasonable doubts about the rule of law and institutions in the Maldives. The trial itself went through with many objections from UN officials. Without entering into the guilt or innocence of former President Nasheed, one should insist on the right to a fair trial. In 2008, the EU played a key role in the Maldives' democratic transition process, when it put intense pressure on democratic elections that ended the 30-year dictatorship. But while the international community's attention was turned elsewhere, in 2012 the first democratically elected President Nasheed resigned in unresolved circumstances. The current president and current government have not continued the democratization process, but have turned to some autocratic tendencies, and seem to have moved closer to Islamic extremist groups.  I therefore supported this resolution by which the European Parliament encourages the VP/HR and the European External Action Service to continue to closely monitor the political situation in the Maldives and to take a proactive role in the EU's bilateral relations with the country and in international multilateral for a with a view to achieving stability, strengthening democracy and the rule of law and ensuring respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms in the country.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's proposal for a resolution on the situation in the Maldives due to a series of events taking place in the country. In fact, former Maldives President Mohamed Nasheed was sentenced to 13 years in prison on terrorism charges for arresting the then chief judge of the criminal court in January 2012.  Worryingly, a trial procedure has been conducted that does not comply with national and international standards. The lack of political independence and education in the Maldives judiciary lacks the credibility of the justice system and opposition politicians and protesters are condemned under suspicious circumstances. Activists and opposition politicians are intimidated and sexual trafficking activities take place in the country. Maldives authorities are urged to ensure all citizens the right to a fair trial, due process and judicial independence in accordance with the provisions of the International Agreement on Civil and Political Rights, and calls for an immediate end to political interference in the Maldives judicial system. We remind the Government of the Maldives that the constitution of that state guarantees the right to protest.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the resolution on the situation in the Maldives, because it is our duty to promote democratic principles in all parts of the world. In the case of the Maldives, we can therefore reiterate the belief that respect for the rule of law, the right to a fair trial, the independence of the judiciary or a credible political process or freedom of the press are a prerequisite for the development of any society. If we have information that the number of Islamic radicals is also increasing in the Maldives, a link can certainly be found between this phenomenon and the unsatisfactory political situation.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Decisive measures are needed to defend human rights as well as the principles of the rule of law in the Maldove region.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which aims to clarify the situation in the maldives. The conviction of former President Mohamed Nasheed for violating anti-terrorism legislation raises very serious questions about the rule of law in the Maldives. Respect for the rule of law, the right to a fair trial, respect for procedure and the independence of the judiciary, in accordance with the provisions of the PIDCP, are essential elements of the democratic process. The citizens of the Maldives, including former President Nasheed, must be treated in accordance with these principles, which are important in a pluralistic society! The European Union must monitor the situation in the Maldives more closely, the issue of respect for the rule of law must be raised at the UN Human Rights Council's Universal Periodic Review of the Maldives

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution calling on all parties in the Maldives to avoid any action that could lead to an increase in authoritarianism in the country, and to respect democracy and the rule of law. The Maldives need an open political process, which involves all the various democratic forces and respects democracy and the rule of law. A democracy cannot tolerate the intimidation of political opponents or political interference in the judicial system. The resolution also calls for an immediate end to all violence against peaceful demonstrators, critical media sources and civil society, and for the perpetrators of violent attacks to be brought to justice.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. The resolution voted on condemns the human rights situation in the Maldives, especially with respect to the media and civil society. It also highlights the situation of former President Mohamed Nasheed, who is in prison when anti-terrorism law has been applied to him. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution because it intends to protect that country's political process, including the correlation of forces that must prevail. Europe's experience in this field is extensive, and its results are paupérrimos.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. This resolution on the situation in the Maldives takes stock of the deterioration of human rights in that country. On 13 March 2015, Mohamed Nasheed, the maldives' first democratically elected president, was sentenced to 13 years in prison on terrorism charges in a controversial trial that failed to comply with national and international judicial standards.  Meanwhile, at least 140 peaceful protesters have been arrested since February.  NGOs and human rights defenders are increasingly facing harassment and various threats and attacks.  The Maldives Human Rights Commission (CDHM) was even referred to the Supreme Court for "high treason" after presenting its report on the human rights situation in the country.  And the death penalty was reinstated after a 30-year moratorium. I voted for this resolution to express my concern about the deteriorating situation in the Maldives, a small country that would need the gathering of all democratic forces to deal with the threats to it because of the rising waters resulting from climate change that is likely to overwhelm most of these islands.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The first democratically elected President of the Republic of maldives, Mohamed Nasheed, was charged with terrorism and sentenced to 13 years in prison on Friday, March 13, 2015.  The UN and the European Union have serious doubts about the impartiality of the Maldives judicial system in this process, given the fact that NGOs consider it to be a way of driving away former President Mohamed Nasheed, elected in 2008. This EU denies the possibility of referendums and, when it fails to prevent its implementation, it does not recognise the result or has it repeated until the result is in line with its interests. This EU deposes governments at its beautiful pleasure, using the blackmail of funding after it has withdrawn monetary sovereignty from national states. It seeks to disown the Greek people, completely disrespecting the will expressed in the elections. This NGO-based EU now wants to teach the world lessons. It's unbelievable! What the EU should do is look in the mirror and recognise that democracy has long since ceased to exist in the EU. Let the people of each country decide their future, without interference and without this deep arrogance of those who think they own reason.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I tabled the motion for a resolution with my colleagues in the ECR Group and Also signed the joint motion for a resolution on behalf of my group. That is why I am voting in favour of this resolution. In it, the European Parliament calls on the Member States to warn of the human rights situation in the Maldives on their travel advice websites. The Maldives is experiencing political unrest, rising militant Islamism, and an increasing number of radicalized young men who are believed to have joined ISIS.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – In the current tense security policy situation, when we are witnessing cold war-like phenomena in Europe, while preserving the unity of the European Union, we must also ensure that European integration remains attractive. This is particularly the case for those western Balkan countries that have prepared for integration over many years, have fulfilled some of the conditions and want to see a clear perspective and a committed intention to join. Of course, Albania still needs to make clear and irreversible progress in meeting the accession criteria in many areas, especially as far as the application of democratic rules is concerned. It is important to give a new impetus to the enlargement process, as Europe will never be complete without the accession of the countries of the Western Balkans.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution because it continues in line with Parliament's views of the candidate countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre is reproduced in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. The resolution under the vote also aims to influence the correlation of political forces involved in the Albanian system. This aspect depends solely and exclusively on the will of the Albanians.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report is the result of the European Union's ideology of enlargement at all costs. The current European Union is already an invasive and disrespectful machine of states, but technocrats persist in continuing on the path they have set out, without ever asking the question of the meaning of their action. Thus Albania is distributed good and bad points in terms of integration, in defiance of the sovereignty of this state. The report thus underlines the "permanent divide of Albanian political forces" and thus interferes in the internal policy of a state without even being a member of the Union.  For all these reasons, I have decided to vote against the adoption of this text, driven by a narrow ideology of the race for enlargement.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of democracy, transparency and accountability I would like to confirm that I voted against this report.  The reason for this is that I do not support EU expansion.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. In the last few years, Albania has made significant progress towards joining the EU, and therefore in June 2014 it has been able to make significant progress. candidate country status. However, there are still problems and, in order to continue to make progress towards EU membership, they need to be addressed quickly and effectively. It is important for Albania to take concrete measures and to demonstrate a sustainable political commitment to implement them in order to address issues related to the consolidation of democratic change and the implementation of the reforms needed to achieve EU membership. Calls on the authorities to step up their fight against corruption, to establish a fair judiciary, to ensure the independence of the judiciary and to strengthen the protection of human rights.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. Not to mention the problems of widespread corruption and organised crime that have plagued Albania for so many years, how can we continue negotiations with Albania, whose Prime Minister has recently again expressed his wish for a Greater Albania with the annexation of Kosovo? Edi Rama made this statement in the presence of Mr. Hashim Thaçi, former head of the terrorist organization UCK. I understand all the less the fierce hostility of the Eurocrats to the natural attachment of Crimea to the Russian Federation, which they have so fiercely supported the independence of Kosovo, the historic cradle of the Serbian nation. However, I note that the report "welcomes the fact that Albania has fully respected the European Union's foreign policy positions, including the restrictive measures against Russia"... The Commission and Parliament have certainly condemned Mr Rama's new provocation, which is likely to have a deleterious effect on the cohesion of neighbouring countries, starting with Macedonia and Montenegro. But Edi Rama has made it known that he has nothing to do with your soft convictions. In these circumstances, why persist in continuing negotiations with Albania?

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. This is the annual follow-up report on Albania on its application for membership. In particular, the European Parliament welcomes the country's status as a candidate country in June 2014. Parliament also welcomes the creation of joint working groups to strengthen, among other things, cooperation in the area of justice, crime control and anti-corruption. Finally, Parliament expressed concern about the ongoing political divide within the country and called for a climate of trust.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This follow-up report aims to report on "spectacular progress on the path to accession" made by Albania. This is clearly a prerequisite, as usual, for a desire to enlargement the European Union. In committee, MEPs welcomed the implementation of the reforms advocated by the Union, the lack of consensus of the political parties in Albania and, finally, they especially welcome Albania's support for the Union following the sanctions it has taken against Russia. This report is a good example of the Union's grip on Albania, both politically, legislatively and judicially. Unfortunately, Albania still remains a territory of concern, particularly because of corruption or organised crime.  I voted against this report.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not agree with what is said in the report analysing Albania's progress as a candidate country for EU membership. I believe that the problems of this state with regard to terrorist infiltration crime and illicit trafficking are still too deep-rooted, and for these reasons I did not intend to support the text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. In June 2014, Albania was granted EU candidate status. In this report, the European Parliament recognises the progress made so far and expresses its support for Albania's integration process. For my part, I welcome the good progress made so far, although efforts must be accelerated in the reform of the public administration and the judiciary, in the fight against corruption and organized crime and in improving the protection of fundamental rights. Ensuring political consensus and the development of true democratic dialogue are of paramount importance. The success of this reform process depends on all political parties cooperating and working constructively to ensure the sustainability of the integration process. In this regard, I encourage, with my vote in favour of this report, the achievement of new results.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Albania has made significant progress in recent years on the road to EU accession and was granted candidate country status in June 2014. At the same time, problems remain, which need to be resolved quickly and effectively in order to further progress towards EU membership. I welcome the joint working groups set up in the framework of the High Level Dialogue on Key Priorities, which aim to build a comprehensive platform for the unhindered implementation of reforms and to monitor progress on the five most important priorities, in particular with regard to public administration reform, strengthening justice, the fight against corruption and organised crime and strengthening the protection of human rights, including the rights of national minorities.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the persistent shortcomings of the judicial system, the high level of corruption, the strong presence of organised crime also involved in trafficking in human beings, the lack of protection of minorities, the lack of transparency in funding and the shortcomings in labour market conditions and also considering that the European Commission does not envisage any new membership of the European Union for the next 5 years , I voted against this resolution.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ I strongly support Albania's European path and think the country is well on its way in the pre-accession process. Albania has made enviable progress in joining the EU over the past few years, and therefore gained candidate status in June 2014, but much effort is still needed from the Albanian side to implement the necessary reforms.  This applies in particular to the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organised crime and media freedom. Such substantive reforms require broad political consensus and therefore I call on all parties to cooperate on the country's European path.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to vote in favour of this resolution since I believe that Albania should, eventually, become a member of the EU and that granting it the status of candidate country will encourage the Albanian Government to intensify its efforts to implement new reforms in order to consolidate the democratic transformation.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the analysis expressed in the text of the resolution that Albania is considered to have the characteristics to join the EU.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 2014 report on Albania's progress, which recorded albania's undoubted progress towards EU membership. This favors the journey and facilitates, with virtuous step, the solution of persistent critical issues and the removal of obstacles. It is still necessary to strengthen the five main priorities, in particular the reform of public administration, the strengthening of the judicial system, the fight against corruption and organised crime, and the strengthening of the protection of human rights. These ambitious objectives can only be supported by the just political will to translate into the most effective of government and administrative actions. "Working towards a political culture" involves professional public administration, real enforcement of the Civil Service Act, increased efficiency, transparency, accountability and financial sustainability. I am therefore happy to join with all those who, in favour of Albania, want reforms to be adopted in order, first and foremost, to combat corruption and to increase the level of public confidence in the judicial system, which is clean, fair and equitable.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr Fleckenstein has done an excellent job with this report and I therefore voted in favour. I very much appreciated the reference to the importance of enforcing the rule of law in Albania and the independence and transparency of judicial institutions. There are many challenges facing the country and there is still a long way to go for accession, but I am confident that Albania will be committed to achieving concrete results.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which, from a view to enlargement, aims to report on "spectacular progress on the path to accession" made by Albania. The parliamentarians in this report, as always when it comes to expanding the European Leviathan ever further, are distributing good and bad points in terms of reform. Thus, if Albania follows the EU's instructions, it is promised a singly tomorrow: "considering that systematic adoption and long-term reforms in the five priority areas contribute to Albania's democratic transformation". There is also the great praise of democracy voted by MEPs in committee, as there is concern about the lack of consensus of political parties in Albania around the reforms imposed by Brussels; not to mention ideological value judgments, as Albania is commended for supporting the EU in its sanctions against Russia: "welcomes Albania's full respect to the European Union's foreign policy positions, including restrictions on Russia". Finally, it goes without saying that the report marks a genuine desire for European interference in the Albanian political, legislative and judicial process.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. Albania, unlike other candidate states, has made great progress that should be inspiring in intensifying the reform efforts of other candidate countries. Efforts to combat trafficking in human beings, the promotion of human rights and the climate of religious tolerance and good interethnic relations in the country should also be praised. However, some problems and challenges that need to be tackled quickly and efficiently remain, such as the independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption and organised crime, freedom of expression and media independence and the fragmentation of the local government system.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 The document we voted on analyses and supports the usefulness of the Albanian integration process. The progress already made by Albania towards the transposition of EU criteria is recognised. At the same time, there are also issues of concern about the polarisation between the political forces in Albania, which could harm both the process of European integration and the integrity of the constitutional resilience of the system. In addition, there is alarm about the phenomenon of corruption, especially if it acts within the ranks of the judiciary. Despite the progress made, reference is also made to the need to combat crime and drug trafficking, which are still able to exert a significant influence on disadvantaged parts of society. The document is quite comprehensive and that is why I am voting in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution because it continues in line with Parliament's views of the candidate countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre is reproduced in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. The resolution under the vote also aims to influence the correlation of political forces involved in the Albanian system. This aspect depends solely and exclusively on the will of the Albanians.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the progress report on Albania because the report welcomes the good progress achieved so far and encourages further efforts and tangible results towards Albania’s European integration process. It is also positive that the report points out the fact that ensuring political consensus and developing a genuine democratic dialogue are elements of utmost importance.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution follows on from the 2014 follow-up report on the progress of the European Union's negotiations with Albania as part of the accession process. The European Parliament expresses its support for Albania's European integration process and also calls for the strengthening of the administrative capacity of the central and local governments and the reform of the rule of law and the judicial system. In addition, efforts must also be made to promote press freedom and human rights. Although Albania's constructive attitude in the region in terms of bilateral and regional cooperation is welcomed, the negotiation process is still far from complete and accession is not expected to take place for many years. In light of these elements and the pre-diagnosis, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I welcome the fact that the integration process with Albania has led to many reforms that are in line with democracy, the rule of law and the appeasement of relations with neighbouring states. I would like to remind you, however, that the European Union must take a lasting break from its enlargement policy.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament adopted by a large majority a parliamentary decision on the 2014 country report on Albania. We have adopted a balanced, realistic decision that illustrates the tasks that albania will have in the coming period. The government must bring about sustainable reforms as soon as possible in the fight against public administration, justice, fundamental freedoms, corruption and organised crime, which remains a major challenge for the country. There are also serious problems in the area of media independence.
