Strong polarisation on the political scene is a major pullback, which could greatly weaken the future EU integration process, so it is important that the government and opposition work together responsibly and effectively. But it is important that recent progress has also been mentioned. The decision commends Albania's status as an EU candidate by fully aligning its foreign policy with the EU's foreign policy position. Progress has also been made in curbing smuggling and the production of narcotics, and progress on economic governance, which is directly linked to the EU integration process and can improve its dynamics, is of paramount importance.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The report before us approves the codification of a legal framework for stabilisation and association agreements between the European Union on the one hand and Albania on the other. By doing so, it would be a matter of confirming the european Union's trade and neighbourhood policy, which I dispute in that it foreshadows the political enlargement of an organisation which is not based on national realities or on the interests of the peoples of Europe. Not wishing to validate this policy, which is also not the subject of serious monitoring and evaluation, I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported albania's 2014 progress resolution as I believe that it is comprehensive and represents very well the progress made, an argument for which is also the granting of status as a candidate country for EU membership.  Furthermore, the resolution pays particular attention to the 5 key areas identified by the Commission – public administration reform, strengthening the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organised crime, and last but not least strengthening fundamental rights and freedoms. I endorse the Commission's intention to link the start of the actual negotiations precisely to progress in these areas, as they are the foundation of any properly functioning rule of law. From a Bulgarian point of view, this report contains a crucial recommendation to Albania, namely to adopt a comprehensive law on minorities to address existing legal gaps in line with the recommendations of the Advisory Committee of the Council of Europe Framework Convention for the Protection of National Minorities. This is of utmost importance for Bulgaria, as according to data of the State Agency for Bulgarians Abroad, about 40 thousand citizens of Bulgarian origin live in Albania. Only by guaranteeing the rights and freedoms of all citizens will Albania show that it is ready for EU membership.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against because Albania is openly promoting the idea of greater Albania and Albanian altruism, with statements by state officials and its own Prime Minister. Moreover, it has made no progress on the rule of law, social justice and freedom of expression.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. Albania has made remarkable progress in recent years on its path to EU membership and has therefore been granted candidate country status. The opening of accession negotiations has become a driving force for EU-related reforms in Albania. I therefore congratulate the reform efforts that Albania is making and I express my support for albania's integration process. I also recognise that concrete measures and a sustained political commitment are needed to implement these measures, successfully address the challenges of consolidating the process of democratic transformation and pursue EU-related reforms.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – This motion for a resolution presents a wide range of recitals on albania's eu integration process. The evaluation of the process that is carried out here and the list of advanced conditions denote the extent of the interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of EU membership, in particular on issues such as the economic organization of the State, Justice, public administration, the requirement of alignment of that country's positions with those of the EU , in particular with regard to foreign and border policy.  We consider unacceptable the manor stance with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts relating to the integration of the country are unacceptable, removing from the peoples the legitimate right to decide their future, where the free and sovereign choice of EU membership is inscribed, but also the strategies of economic and social development. For these reasons, we voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Obtaining candidate status should encourage Albania to step up reform efforts and take action to address the challenges of successfully consolidating democratic transition. These are, in particular, key priorities aimed at creating a comprehensive platform ensuring the smooth running of reforms and monitoring progress in public administration, the fight against corruption and organised crime, strengthening justice systems, but also strengthening the protection of human rights. Albania deserves recognition, in particular, for its efforts to combat trafficking in people, which is a serious problem.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote no as the EU's enlargement policy has been wrong in the past and will be wrong again. The inconveniences created and still in place will only be widened by this out-of-the-way policy.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the 2014 progress report on Albania. Albania openly promotes the idea of greater Albania and Albanian altruism, with statements by state officials and its own Prime Minister. Moreover, it has made no progress on the rule of law, social justice and freedom of expression.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the European integration process for Albania. I welcome the good progress achieved so far and I would encourage further efforts and tangible results. I believe that the opening of accession negotiations with Albania will constitute a major incentive for the country to accelerate the necessary efforts on public administration reform and reform of the judiciary, in the fight against corruption and organised crime and in enhancing the protection of fundamental rights. The success of the reform process depends on the existence of a democratic political environment. To secure the sustainability of the integration process, all political parties need to cooperate and work constructively together. Moreover, I believe that ensuring political consensus and developing a genuine democratic dialogue are elements of the utmost importance. I would like to thank and praise the rapporteur, Knut Fleckenstein, and the shadow rapporteurs for the great job they have done.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. 2012 Albania has undoubtedly made very important progress in recent years on the road to EU membership, although we must not ignore the continuing challenges to which it is necessary to respond quickly and efficiently in order to continue on the path of EU membership. Albania must continue to work for a democratic political culture based on democratic political processes, taking into account the worrying political polarization that exists in the country. From the European Parliament we must continue to emphasize the need to strengthen the rule of law, reform justice and combat the high level of corruption and organised crime.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. The report that we have just adopted – which I supported – praises Albania for having gained candidate status. I too believe that this important recognition should be seen as an encouragement to further intensify the reform efforts. It is also up to Europe to support this path and to have an open and dialoguing attitude.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the progress report on Albania in 2014. I recently visited the country and was able to see for myself the progress of work towards full European integration. The efforts made by the Albanian authorities to fully adapt their legislation in line with the Demands of the European Union, which is a prerequisite for accession, are tangible. The recent adoption of the National Plan for European Integration 2014-2020 makes concrete Albania's desire to take further steps forward in this direction, through the implementation of economic, political and judicial criteria.  The Albanian Government has demonstrated the political will to act to combat corruption and organised crime. In many areas, the intensification of legislation in this area has shown a positive trend, especially in the fight against drugs and trafficking in human beings. In general, the rights of disabled people, LGBTI people, children and minorities are basically respected, although more efforts are needed in this regard.  There are certainly many problems to be managed, such as, for example, the environmental problem and the diversification of energy sources, which are vital to ensuring economic development and increasing transparency, especially in the management of public finances.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because, over the last few years, Albania has made impressive progress in its accession to the EU, and therefore in June 2014 it will be able to make an impact. candidate country status. I am convinced that the continued adoption and effective implementation of reforms in the five main priority areas helps Albania to bring about democratic change and enables accession negotiations to begin. In addition, the EU accession process has become a driving force for EU-related reforms in Albania. The opening of accession negotiations would give impetus to EU-related reforms, ensuring a clear and credible EU perspective. I have no doubt that this status should be seen as an incentive to step up the implementation of reforms and means continued support for Albania's integration processes into the EU, including the guarantee of human rights and economic reforms.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this Resolution which underlines the points on which Albania should focus if it wishes to become a Member State of the European Union.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ We have to show strong support for Albania’s European integration process. We have to recognise the country’s achievements and encourage it to consolidate the reforms. The opening of the accession negotiations will constitute a major incentive towards achieving these aims.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Albania, as a candidate country for entry into the European Union, has made strides forward. However, the tense political and unenviable economic situation in Albania is not in favour of faster progress by the Republic of Albania.  Until political parties in Albania find a better way to communicate with each other, especially when it comes to the European Union and Albania's future membership, rapid progress is not possible. Since I believe that the European Union has no alternative and when it comes to albania's future, I voted for this resolution.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This report is the result of the European Union's ideology of enlargement at all costs. The current Union is already an invasive and disrespectful machine of nation states, but technocrats persist in continuing on the path they have set out, without ever asking the question of the meaning of their action. Thus Albania is distributed good and bad points in terms of integration, in defiance of the sovereignty of this state. The report thus underlines the "permanent divide of Albanian political forces" and thus interferes in the internal policy of a state without even being a member of the Union.  For all these reasons, I have decided to vote against the adoption of this text, driven by a narrow ideology of the race for enlargement.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the process of integration of Albania into the EU which includes social and economic improvement of the country. I support the motion for a resolution as it outlines the progress made by Albania throughout 2014 in terms of religious harmony, good inter-ethnic relations, regional and bilateral cooperation. However, the progress needs to continue and the constitutional and institutional reforms are still required.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support Albania’s European integration process, I welcome the good progress achieved so far and I would encourage further efforts and tangible results. The opening of accession negotiations with Albania will constitute a major incentive for the country to step up the pace. Ensuring political consensus and developing a genuine democratic dialogue are elements of the utmost importance. Albania plays an important role in the Western Balkans region. We recognise its constructive and pro-active stance on regional security and stability and cooperation with neighbouring states, and we discourage statements that can send wrong signals. The future of Albania and of all the other countries of the Western Balkans is in the EU.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. With a positive vote, I expressed my support for Albania's progress in its integration process with the European Union to be increasingly fruitful. It stresses the need for public administration reform to implement all other planned reforms, in particular those concerning the rule of law and the judicial system, and calls for cooperation with European agencies and EU Member States in the fight against drug trafficking.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Vote against. The National Front opposes any form of enlargement. We do not believe that membership is the only future for a country. The European Union also continues its policy of interfering in the political and administrative institutions of the accession countries. Albania has an important role to play in the region, but this does not have to be done within the European Union. It wants to apply a form of democratic centralism which has the consequence of an obligation for member states to obey and to have a uniform position, faithful to that defended by the European Union. I therefore oppose this text and the enlargement that is looming with Albania and this dirigiste posture of the European Union which criticises the policies of that country in order to guide them.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The report recognises the progress made so far and expresses the European Parliament's support for Albania's eu integration process. It notes that opening up accession negotiations would be an incentive and would drive the reform process. Albania must accelerate its efforts in the reform of public administration, in the reform of the judiciary, in the fight against corruption and organized crime and in improving the protection of fundamental rights. The success of the reform process depends on the existence of a democratic political environment. To ensure the sustainability of the integration process, all political parties have to cooperate and work together constructively. The S&D Group supports Albania's European integration process. It celebrates the good progress made so far and encourages new efforts and tangible results. It is believed that the opening of accession negotiations with Albania will be the main incentive for the country to move faster. Ensuring political consensus and the development of true democratic dialogue are of paramount importance.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution because it continues in line with Parliament's views of the candidate countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre is reproduced in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. The resolution under the vote also aims to influence the correlation of political forces involved in the Albanian system. This aspect depends solely and exclusively on the will of the Albanians.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. Albania has made very significant progress in recent years on the road to EU membership, so it was a candidate country in June 2014. Even so, challenges remain that need to be answered quickly and efficiently in order to move forward on the path of EU membership, such as on corruption through the development of a strong register of investigations, prosecutions and convictions at all levels. Education and training, particularly among young people, should also be improved. I voted in favour of this Resolution, considering that the coherent adoption and effective implementation of sustainable reforms in the key priority areas contribute to Albania's democratic transformation and pave the way for the opening of EU accession negotiations.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The Republic of Albania went to great lengths to gain candidate status in June 2014, a further boost to its path to the European Union. Of the 12 areas defined as priorities by the European Commission, five areas remain where reforms have not yet been implemented.  The Republic of Albania is expected to thoroughly implement public administration and local self-government reforms as preconditions for implementing other reforms. Further work is needed on reforms of education, health, the judiciary and the fight against corruption and organised crime and work to ensure basic human rights, jobs and media freedom. The resolution welcomes the establishment of joint working groups, which is progress in regional co-operation, and includes co-operation with Croatia and planning the construction of a 1,100km Adriatic-Ionian highway. The motorway is important for economic development and transport connecting Western and Central Europe with Southeast Europe.  I support the Republic of Albania on its European path and a resolution on its progress. The priority of the Republic of Albania should certainly be not only to fulfil its obligations to the Union, but economic growth and development and to ensure a better standard of living for its citizens.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The Republic of Albania is one of the less economically developed countries in Europe. Nevertheless, it has managed to achieve some political stability, which is a prerequisite for its gradual transformation and integration into the European Union. Albania has a lot of work to do on this path in all areas of political, economic and economic life, including the establishment of fundamental democratic processes in the field of public life, the strengthening of the rule of law and human rights.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the 2014 progress report on Albania for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech of 29 April 2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament. I disagree with any prospect of Albania joining the EU since that country brutally violates the rights of the Greek ethnic minority of the Northern Continent and at the same time its leadership revives Albanian nationalism and the redeeming idea of great Albania claiming a change of borders in the Balkans and territories belonging to Greece.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. As is often the case here, it is a question of preparing Albania to join the European Union by encouraging it to reform its political, legislative and judicial institutions. This interference by the Union is not acceptable and we are against this forced enlargement.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. \u2012 It must be acknowledged that Albania has made impressive progress towards EU membership in recent years, thus obtaining candidate status in June 2014. Albania also plays an essential role in strengthening stability in the region, and its political will to improve relations with Serbia and its overall commitment to good neighbourly relations, which will lead to even greater stabilisation of the entire region, should also be appreciated. However, it is more than clear that certain problems remain in the country, I can only mention the need for judicial reform, the fight against corruption and organised crime, as well as the effective functioning of the civil service. Our job is not just to criticize this country. Even in the knowledge of all the remaining problems, I believe that it is our task to provide Albania with all possible support and assistance on our part. Dialogue and constructive cooperation should play a decisive role in this respect. I abstained in today's vote on the report because I cannot consider this report to be overall balanced.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report is the result of the European Union's ideology of enlargement at all costs. The current Union is already an invasive and disrespectful machine of nation states, but the technocrats persist in continuing on the path they have set out, without ever asking the question of the meaning of their action. Thus Albania is distributed good and bad points in terms of integration, in defiance of the sovereignty of this state. The report thus underlines the "permanent divide of Albanian political forces" and thus interferes in the internal policy of a State without even being a member of the Union.  Therefore, I voted AGAINST.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution regarding the progress that Albania made in 2014. The rapporteur notes that the growing level of political polarisation in Albania may prove to be a hurdle in further EU integration efforts. The resolution comments on the need to improve Albania’s record of investigations, prosecutions and convictions at all levels, as this will contribute to the country’s efforts to combat organised crime. Lastly, the resolution also notes the positive steps that Albania has made in relation to religious tolerance, which is crucial for long-term stability.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on Albania’s European integration process. The report welcomes the good progress achieved so far and encourages further efforts and tangible results. It asserts that the opening of accession negotiations with Albania will constitute the major incentive for the country to speed up the process. Ensuring political consensus and developing a genuine democratic dialogue are elements of the utmost importance.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This 2014 follow-up report on Albania shows a bias in the progress made by Albania. There is talk of dramatic progress on the path to Albania's accession. However, the reality is much darker. Widespread corruption and the high presence of organized crime are tainting this picture.  One wonders why the Union persists in wanting to expand its 'borders' almost infinitely? Why is it promising Albania a future accession when it is clear that the country does not meet any criteria and that the pace of progress is far too low to allow accession even in the medium term.  This report is also biased, since it shows that the only indicator taken into account to show Albania's sincerity in its approach remains the support of sanctions against Russia.   So I voted against this report.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs support the European integration process of Albania. Whilst we welcome the good progress achieved so far we also encourage further efforts and believe that the opening of accession negotiations can provide the incentive to produce tangible results.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the follow-up to Albania's application to join the European Union. The text welcomes the reforms undertaken in the country, which became an official candidate in June 2014, while highlighting the many difficulties that remain and constitute obstacles to achieving the criteria necessary to start negotiations.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 Although Albania has made enormous progress and efforts on its way to EU membership, gaining candidate status last year, challenges still remain to be answered quickly and effectively. Surely the formal opening of accession negotiations would be a strong incentive to launch further reforms. As always, the European Union places respect for the rule of law at the centre of all consideration.  We express our concern at the lack of real independence of the media and the lack of transparency in media ownership and funding. We believe that EU membership is an inclusive process that belongs to the whole country and to all its citizens, so we want a constructive and sustainable political dialogue on EU-related reforms, conducted in a spirit of cooperation and compromise between the main political forces. The process of European integration, if it is to be successful, will have to enjoy broad political consensus and broad democratic support from all Albanian citizens.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which shows albania's progress over the last year. The resolution encourages the country to continue the European path and the reform process. In particular, the need to strengthen the rule of law and reform the judicial system is highlighted and cooperation with European agencies and EU Member States in the fight against drug trafficking is recommended. Finally, the text calls for a climate of religious tolerance and good inter-ethnic relations and encourages Albania to ensure a more professional and actionable working environment for journalists.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 In June 2014, Albania acquired the status of candidate country for the European Union. I signed and voted for this resolution because it welcomes the efforts that this country is making to strengthen the rule of law, justice reform, the fight against organised crime and corruption. Also, in its text, the resolution also highlights the still vulnerable points of that State, and the measures that should be taken further.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution on Albania because I believe that, like every country in Europe, Albania deserves a clear sign along the way of its European integration. However, I believe that provocative statements, such as That of Mr. Rama since the beginning of April, are a hindrance along this path. The peace process in the Balkans is a long and complex process and requires many compromises. Such statements constitute only greater obstacles to laying the foundations for the full integration of the whole region into European structures. At the same time, however, I would like to express my disapproval of paragraph 29 and, in particular, of the promotion of sanctions against Russia. This is a geopolitical choice that Europe has made, but the consequences for countries that are not fully integrated into the European single market are much more dangerous, and instead of helping citizens of candidate countries, they pose a threat to their prosperity and potential. In response to the sanctions imposed by Albania, Russia included the country to the countries with banned - a measure from which ordinary citizen farmers suffer. They must not bear the consequences of geopolitical decisions taken in Brussels.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I know how important it is for countries in the Western Balkans to keep receiving our positive signals, especially if they are balanced by adequate reports on still more needed reforms. Albania has come a long way in the past years and, while I believe the road for integration is still long, I believe this country needs Europe, quite a lot and we should not abandon it.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank the rapporteur for his work and hope to have made my contribution.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I supported a resolution on Albania's 2014 progress report. A year, because Albania made significant progress in that year and received candidate status. I support all progress in achieving reforms and it is necessary for the authorities to step up their work on effective sustainable reforms in the area of five key priorities, in particular in reforming public administration, strengthening the judiciary, fighting corruption and organised crime, and strengthening the protection of human rights and ensuring their implementation.  This will require ensuring a constructive and inclusive political dialogue that enables key reforms to be adopted and implemented. It is important to continue to work towards the establishment of the rule of law and judicial reform to ensure the trust of citizens and the business community in the justice system. Particular attention should be paid to eliminating the possibility of politicisation, corruption and ensuring the independence, efficiency and accountability of the judiciary.  Serious efforts should be made to combat organised crime and trafficking in human beings and to combat the support of international terrorist activities. While I supported the resolution, I do not support paragraph 22, which goes beyond the competences of the EU, as it enters the field of marriage and family regulation, which is the exclusive competence of the Member States.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ I welcome efforts by Albanian institutions to boost co-operation on smuggling problems, but also stress that more reforms are needed in the fight against organised crime. I hope that these efforts will turn into a sincere political dialogue that is not yet there, because the political consensus on the issue of accession to the European Union and the joint work of all on it is an absolute precondition for a successful Euro-integration process.  I also hope that Prime Minister Rama's recent remarks were just a careless coincidence and I want to believe that Albania will maintain its constructive position in the region.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that Albania has made enormous progress in its path to EU membership and that the country is moving towards a stable form of democracy, thanks also to the start of the implementation of reforms. The acquisition of candidate country status must encourage and intensify reform efforts. In order to achieve full European integration, Albania must make a firm commitment to the independence of the judiciary and the fight against corruption and organised crime, and the political forces must participate and cooperate in this process. The consolidation of democratic transformation and the implementation of the reforms required by the EU must be a path made together by all the actors involved in change in Albania.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. \u2012 Similar to Bosnia and Herzegovina, albania and its preparations for EU accession also apply. Countries are making progress, but there are still areas where improvements are needed. In my opinion, the report reflects this situation in a balanced way, and i therefore support it.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In June 2014, Albania was granted candidate status for the European Union. The Albanian government has made dramatic progress, but some difficulties remain and reforms are still needed before joining the Union. In particular, the Commission and Parliament encourage Albania to continue its efforts in the area of political cooperation.  The European Parliament adopted the 2014 follow-up report for Albania. I support the reforms undertaken by this country. However, I reaffirm my wish to establish a five-year moratorium on any new membership.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. – Albania has made remarkable progress in recent years towards EU membership and was therefore granted candidate country status in June 2014. The opening up of EU accession negotiations depends on consistent adoption and the effective implementation of sustainable reforms on the five key priorities, namely the reform of public administration, strengthening the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organised crime, and strengthening the protection of human rights. This resolution, while deploring the persistent shortcomings in the functioning of the judiciary and the high levels of corruption, congratulates Albania on obtaining candidate country status and considers that this should be seen as an incentive to persevere in its reformist efforts. It also expresses its continued support for albania's eu integration process and recommends harmonising the future timetable of meetings of the EU-Albania Stabilisation and Association Parliamentary Committee and Association and the High Level Dialogue on Key Priorities with a view to strengthening parliamentary oversight of the EU membership process. I voted, for those reasons, in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. In July 2014, European Commission President-elect Jean-Claude Juncker declared in the Chamber that "there will be no further enlargement in the next five years". A common-sense proposal that was high on the agenda of the MR programme during the last European elections. This need to solidify the House Europe before expanding it does not mean that the ongoing negotiations with the countries of the near vicinity like Albania must stop. This country, which was granted candidate status in June 2014, certainly needs a European perspective, but it does not meet European standards today. The difficult economic and social situation facing the EU requires increased vigilance. European decision-makers want to pay much more attention to chapters 23 ("judicial apparatus and fundamental rights") and 24 ("justice, freedom, security"). As such, the 2014 monitoring report on Albania shows significant progress to be made in five priority areas, reform of public services, strengthening the judiciary, combating corruption and organised crime, and improving the protection of human rights. These are all areas that are at the heart of the rule of law.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. In June 2014, Albania was granted EU candidate status. In this report, the European Parliament recognises the progress made so far and expresses its support for Albania's integration process. For my part, I welcome the good progress made so far, although efforts must be accelerated in the reform of the public administration and the judiciary, in the fight against corruption and organized crime and in improving the protection of fundamental rights. Ensuring political consensus and the development of true democratic dialogue are of paramount importance. The success of this reform process depends on all political parties cooperating and working constructively to ensure the sustainability of the integration process. In this regard, I encourage, with my vote in favour of this report, the achievement of new results.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In this follow-up resolution, MEPs called on the ruling coalition and the opposition in Albania to cooperate responsibly and constructively. Parliament has also noted that the fight against organised crime remains a major challenge in the country. Albania should also do more to ensure the independence, efficiency and accountability of the judicial system and to ensure the independence of the public broadcaster, the resolution says.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on the 2014 Progress Report on Albania, which reflects well the efforts that albania has made towards European integration, well demonstrated by its current status as a candidate for the European Union. However, as the report rightly points out, there are still many areas that need greater and deeper intervention, such as reform of the judicial system, the fight against drug trafficking and greater freedom of the press. However, I would also like to point out the progress made in promoting religious tolerance and the good relationship between the different ethnic groups in this country, as well as the excellent work done by the Ombudsman, which is, per se, a sign of the constructive and proactive stance that Albania intends to adopt on its path to European integration.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Writing. In today's vote, I supported the 2014 Progress Report on Albania, which focuses on democracy development and the rule of law as an important part of the country's integration process. For this reason, however, it should not be forgotten that paragraph 27, which calls for the halt of all projects involving the renewable energy source water, is contrary to paragraph 26, which advocates the expansion of renewables and the diversification of energy sources in Albania. I am therefore clearly opposed to the call for a halt to sustainable hydropower in paragraph 27, as this call is neither objectively justified nor in line with the EU's energy and environmental objectives. As Europeans, we cannot, as it were, push for the expansion of renewables and a reduction in energy imports if, at the same time, we call for a halt to sustainable projects, despite compliance with the strictest EU environmental requirements. The European Commission is therefore urged to ensure the compatibility of energy and environmental objectives in practice. Growth zones for the energy industry and Natura 2000 projects must not conflict with each other. A win-win situation is possible and must be made possible. I am very much in favour of this. This progress report cannot therefore be seen as a progress report for renewable energies and a sustainable future in the energy sector.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2014 progress report on Albania because I want to give a signal of support to Albania's European integration process, stressing the need for public administration reform to implement all other reforms, and also hoping for a climate of religious tolerance and good inter-ethnic relations in order to encourage albania to ensure a more professional and actionable working environment for journalists.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I voted against because I consider any attempt to enlarge the European Union to be insane.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution because it continues in line with Parliament's views of the candidate countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre is reproduced in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. The resolution under the vote also aims to influence the correlation of political forces involved in the Albanian system. This aspect depends solely and exclusively on the will of the Albanians.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the 2014 Progress Report on Albania, which sends a strong, clear message in favour of Albania’s aspirations for greater European integration. Albania’s EU membership ambition has the capacity to contribute to the democracy and stability of the country and the region as a whole. Constructive political dialogue now needs to take place, alongside cooperation from all sides, in order to bring about the reforms that are needed.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the 2014 resolution on Albania's progress. This resolution contains many inspiring and concrete proposals, which I consider to be beneficial. At the same time, however, it places undue emphasis on the specific needs of one particular group, namely LGBTI, and exerts undue political pressure to amend national legislation, which, even within the EU, falls within the exclusive competence of individual Member States. There are also calls for anti-discrimination legislation in a form that could lead to discrimination against citizens with different views in this area in the fight against homophobia.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I support the 2014 Resolution on Albania's Progress Report, which has made enviable progress in joining the EU over the past few years and has been granted candidate status for this reason. Accession to the European Union is an inclusive process that belongs to the whole country and all its citizens, so I think Albania needs a national consensus on a reform plan. It is commendable that Albania has a constructive relationship with its neighbours and its alignment with EU foreign policy serves as an example. Albania has made significant progress in political criteria, but with a view to better progress towards the process of opening accession negotiations, Albania will have to make sustained efforts to implement reforms in key areas with a particular focus on public administration and judicial reform, fighting corruption and organised crime and strengthening the protection of basic human rights. The trend in the fight against drug trafficking and production should be commended, but it is still evident that fighting organised crime is a major challenge. Albania needs to do much more to ensure an independent, efficient and responsible judiciary and must better guarantee the independence and freedom of public media.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – Albania – a small country with a population of less than 3 million, has made remarkable progress on the road to EU accession in recent years. He was therefore granted candidate status in June 2014. Nevertheless, there are still areas where Albania needs to take fundamental steps – it is, above all, the reform of the judicial system, the fight against corruption and organised crime. Albania's integration efforts may be jeopardised by the current constant polarisation of political forces in the country and by persistent corruption, which also encroaches on the justice system, thereby losing citizens' confidence in a fair justice system. The business environment and the pursuit of a functioning market economy have improved recently, but the government must continue to address shortcomings in the enforcement of treaties and the rule of law and combat the informal economy. The people of Albania will also have to make sacrifices and strutes in the process of integration with various government measures, but they will certainly understand that this is essential so that Albania can also be an equal member of the EU in the future.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. The resolution is well-written and balanced, covering all relevant aspects and there is a clear support for Albania's membership of the EU in the future and if it remains on track as before. The status of candidate for membership should continue to promote and monitor Albania on track with successful reforms and the establishment of a strong democratic state. For many years, Albania has made little progress compared to other countries in the Balkans. Over the last three years, however, there has been a lot of improvement and effort to rectify the situation in the country and move forward. In June 2014, Albania was granted eu membership candidate status. Since then, Albania's main objectives have been as follows: reform of public administration; the fight against corruption and organised crime; protection of human rights and strengthening the judiciary. Albania has good potential and I support its so far very well-planned and successful path. For this reason, I supported the European Parliament resolution on Albania's progress in 2014.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 I firmly believe that Albania will continue to implement reforms that will enable it to move closer to the EU. In addition to democratising society, fighting corruption and streamlining public administration, it is essential to establish constructive and sustainable political dialogue and to intensify Albania's cooperation with the European Union.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ Albania has made progress in the last few years on the road to EU accession, and was therefore granted candidate status in June 2014. Challenges for Albania remain and need to be addressed swiftly and efficiently in order to make further progress on the road to EU membership.  In particular, the rule of law needs to be strengthened and the judiciary reformed in order to foster the trust of citizens and the business community in the judicial system and to improve the fight against corruption and crime. Professional public administration is necessary for the successful implementation of all other reforms, so it is necessary to continue reforms in this area as well.  I welcome Albania's proactive stance in regional and bilateral co-operation, which is important for regional stability, and therefore support the report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ As the report recognises the progress achieved so far and expresses Parliament’s continuing support for Albania’s EU integration proces, I voted in favour of this resolution. I welcome the positive progress achieved, but I would also encourage further efforts. The opening of accession negotiations can provide the incentive to produce tangible results in Albania.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Each people has the right to choose their own course and determine their future. For this reason, we respect the will of the Albanian people and their government for closer cooperation with the EU. But we cannot agree with the attempt to force the Albanian government to align its foreign policy with the EU's foreign policy. We also think it is wrong to try to impose on Albania the neoliberal economic policies of the EU that have led the peoples of Europe to impoverishment. For these reasons we have chosen abstention.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. I supported the proposal. Albania has initiated various reforms and is driven in many ways by the prospect of EU accession. At the same time, there remain problems with corruption, organised crime and the functioning of the judiciary. Albania must more effectively protect the rights of minorities, media freedom and improve the situation of minors in the country. Albania's willingness to improve relations with Serbia is positive.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Albania is openly promoting the idea of greater Albania and Albanian altruism with statements by state officials and its Own Prime Minister, while at the same time making no progress whatsoever on the rule of law, social justice and freedom of expression.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text. It is to be welcomed that Albania has been granted candidate status. This step should be seen as an incentive to continue reform efforts. It is necessary to take concrete measures and to demonstrate a long-term political commitment to consolidate democratic transformation and successfully pursue the reforms inherent in the accession process to the European Union. We must remain attentive to the results of these reforms.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. From a view to enlargement, this follow-up report aims to report on Albania's "dramatic progress towards accession". The parliamentarians in this report, as always when it comes to expanding the European Union, are distributing good and bad points on reform. Finally, it goes without saying, the report marks a genuine European will in the Albanian political, legislative and judicial process. I have opposed both any further enlargement of the European Union and the moralising nature of this text, which is once again intrusive in the internal affairs of any state.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal, agreeing with the Commission's proposal, amended in accordance with the recommendations of the Advisory Working Group of the Legal Services of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, which contains a simple consolidated structure of existing texts without any substantive amendment.

name: Vladimir URUTCHEV
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported albania's 2014 progress report as it gives an objective assessment of what has been achieved and the need for further progress efforts in the five key priority areas.  The government in Tirana should continue on the path of reforms at an unrelenting pace and focus on fulfilling the conditions for membership. Political dialogue and the proper functioning of the institutions are an important part of the political criteria for accession and a prerequisite for a normal course of the negotiation process. A crucial element is constructive dialogue and consensus between the government and the opposition. I expect to find a fair approach to national minorities and recognition of the rights of persons from Bulgarian ethnic origin. Bulgaria has always expressed its consistent support for Albania's European integration. In June 2014, our country approved albania's granting status as a candidate country for EU membership. The Bulgarian government has proposed the conclusion of a Memorandum of Cooperation in the field of European integration. Albania should make further efforts to implement strategic connectivity infrastructure projects in the Balkans, including pan-European Transport Corridor 8. Albania's positive role as rotating President of the SEE Cooperation Process shows the potential to make the country a stability factor and a constructive partner in the Western Balkans region.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I strongly believe in Albania’s future as a Member State of the European Union. The country has made good progress in meeting the political criteria for EU integration and has improved its relations with its neighbours. Notably, it has maintained a pro-active stance in regional and bilateral cooperation and has shown political will to intensify its dialogue with Serbia. Moreover, Albania’s foreign policy is now fully aligned with EU foreign and defence policy. Sustainable reforms in the priority areas of public administration, reinforcement of the judiciary and the fight against corruption and organised crime have been adopted and are being implemented effectively. The opening of EU accession negotiations would boost new reforms and consolidate existing ones by offering Albania a credible European perspective.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution because it continues in line with Parliament's views of the candidate countries, in which a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre is reproduced in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. The resolution under the vote also aims to influence the correlation of political forces involved in the Albanian system. This aspect depends solely and exclusively on the will of the Albanians.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Regardless of the need to work on the basis of today's reality, which stems from only part of the countries being integrated into the EU, it is not possible to pass this debate without mentioning, on the one hand, the ROLE of the EU in the Yugoslavia crisis and, in particular, the role of Germany which, in fostering Croatian nationalism, has stirred up a conflict still with open scars within Europe and in all the Balkans , involving Kosovo and Albania. We also criticise the EXPANSIONIST EU policy which seeks, under the cover of free trade, to conquer new markets and offset the weak domestic demand that stems from years of austerity policies.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on Albania's European integration process because I am convinced that the European Union, and Parliament in particular, must support and reward the efforts made by that country in recent months. I hope that the recognition of the results achieved will encourage the political class to continue along the path of combating corruption and reforms, first and first of all those of the public administration and the judicial system.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted against this resolution because it is a concrete step towards Albania's EU membership. This objective was irrevocably expressed in the Thessaloniki Agenda for the Western Balkans: Towards European Integration (European Council conclusions of 19-20 June 2003 on the Western Balkans). The Heads of State or Government of the Member States have already decided in Brussels that Serbia, Albania, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Macedonia and Montenegro should become EU Member States in the very foreseeable future. Taxpayers' money is now being made available to reform the Western Balkans at all costs as 'EU compatible'. However, the AfD's EU election manifesto states: "First consolidation, then enlargement." That is what I am sticking to.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. \u2012 I consider this report to be very positive, especially when I take into account the fact that Albania has the same foreign policy vision that fully coincides with the EU's positions. I also very much appreciate the will to deepen the stability of relations with Serbia. I believe that Albania will continue in this right direction and thus become one of the EU Member States.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution presents a wide range of recitals on albania's eu integration process. In addition to the evaluation of the process, it points to a wide range of constraints for membership, which confirm the extent of the interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of EU membership, in particular on issues such as justice, public administration, the requirement to align that country's positions with those of the EU, in particular with regard to foreign and border policy.  We consider unacceptable the manor stance with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts relating to the integration of the country are unacceptable, removing from the peoples the legitimate right to decide their future, where the free and sovereign choice of EU membership is inscribed, but also the strategies of economic and social development. For these reasons, we voted against it.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution on the Progress Report of Bosnia and Herzegovina, since it continues in line with Parliament's views of the applicant countries, reproducing a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. The text presented also seeks to protect the political and institutional exit of a country with chronic problems in its governance, the culpability of which lies precisely with many EU Member States.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. I voted against this 2014 follow-up report on Bosnia and Herzegovina because it is fully part of a forced enlargement ideology, based on the complete interference of Brussels in the institutions of the State concerned. Note, for example, the alignment of the country with the diplomacy of Brussels, as well as the consecration of ethnic and sexual communitarianisms.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ In the interests of democracy, transparency and accountability, I would like to confirm that I voted against this report on the grounds that I do not believe in EU expansion.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the progress report of Bosnia and Herzegovina. The European Union helps the country to renew its reform process, improve the socio-economic situation and move closer to the European Union. Corruption, fragmented public administration, problems with legal systems, weak mechanisms for cooperation with civil society remain widespread in the country, media are polarised, equal rights are guaranteed to all major nations and not all citizens. The country should address social and economic problems, improve the business environment, institutional structure, the rule of law, strengthen judicial institutions, fight corruption, and reform the public administration. I support the calls for the High Representative and the EU Member States to maintain a coherent position on the integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This 2014 follow-up report on Bosnia and Herzegovina is once again part of a forced enlargement ideology, based on the complete interference of Brussels in the institutions of the State concerned. The authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina, for example, are invited "in an urgent way to amend the penal code" and are also reprimanded for daring to pursue a "foreign policy of the country which is always characterized by divergent positions, which results in a low rate of alignment with the Union's positions". A real questioning of the prerogatives of any sovereign state over its foreign policy. As in most reports on the prospects for enlargement, the State is called upon to reform all its institutions, to carry out a policy in line with the wishes of Brussels, particularly in relation to the consecration of ethnic and sexual communitarianism. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. This is the annual follow-up report on Bosnia and Herzegovina on its application for membership. The European Parliament welcomes the Council's response to its call for a review of the EU's approach to Bosnia and Herzegovina. Parliament also calls on the country's political leaders to avoid any nationalist rhetoric that increases divisions within Bosnian society. Finally, Parliament remains concerned about the inefficiency of the judicial system and the importance of corruption within the country.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. The situation in Bosnia-Herzegovine remains more than a concern. After a meeting of the UN Security Council in 2013 corroborated by the EU's follow-up reports, the lack of progress in the implementation of political and economic reforms, the repeated use of separatist rhetoric and deep divisions between political parties are all factors that run counter to the efforts of those who would like to see Bosnia and Herzegovina become a stable and viable state. Moreover, 20 years after the beginning of the war in this region, national minorities remain excluded from participation in national politics. Finally, Bosnia and Herzegovina has made little progress in the fight against corruption, which remains a major problem, as has organised crime. The country is still a source of arms supply for criminal groups in the EU. As it stands, it is inconceivable that any accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the EU should be envisaged until it has succeeded in overcoming these obstacles, which are likely to quickly turn into a powder keg.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not intend to support this report on Bosnia's progress in its EU accession process with my vote. I believe that the problems facing this country are more entrenched and more complex than what emerges from this text, which I think is too optimistic.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. This Resolution reiterates the EU's unequivocal commitment to Bosnia and Herzegovina and to the territorial integrity, sovereignty and unity of the country, although it is stressed that the country will not be a candidate for EU membership until adequate institutional conditions have been established. A constitutional reform is therefore calling for a comprehensive, effective and functional constitutional reform of Bosnia and Herzegovina, together with the revitalization of the reform process. Political leaders are also urged to refrain from the nationalist and secessionist rhetorical division that polarized society, emphasizing that citizens' socio-economic needs should be the priority. For all this, I support this Resolution and the EU's renewed approach to Bosnia and Herzegovina, which I understand as a new opportunity to resume its reform process and improve the country's social and economic situation. This opportunity should not be missed. Ensuring a better life for citizens must be the political priority of Bosnia and Herzegovina as part of its process of European integration.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I supported the proposed report on the progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina by my colleague Preda, as it represents the situation in BiH in a very balanced way. This situation is far from ideal, and the reasons for this are multifaceted.  BiH is a very complex country with a bloody history that arose from a flawed but only possible, Dayton agreement in wartime. Since its inception or since the end of the war, the country has been in a spiral of a functioning political system, inter-party conflicts, corruption and economic problems that make any significant progress of the country impossible.  The dysfunctional rule of law, corruption that prevents the normal functioning of the market economy makes BiH a completely inoperceous country for young people - worryingly high, as much as 59% youth unemployment. And what is even more worrying is that such situations are becoming the optimal breeding ground for crime and terrorism. But this is happening not thousands of miles away from us, but in our immediate vicinity.  The main burden of resolving all the problems accumulated in BiH over the years is on the shoulders of the BiH authorities themselves, and the EU must help them at all times.  I am convinced that, with the prospect of a more positive EU approach to resolving the situation in BiH and a greater willingness of the BiH authorities to deal with the problems, progress is possible.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ This report highlights the European Parliament's unequivocal support for the European perspective of Bosnia and Herzegovina as a full and sovereign state.  The renewal of the accession process is a positive step forward that must be followed by sincere and in-depth reform efforts in the country itself. Here I mean political, but also socio-economic reforms since there is no progress in one without the other.  BiH will be a successful candidate country once certain institutional conditions are met and constitutional reforms are implemented that will enable it to become an inclusive, efficient and fully functioning state for all its citizens and peoples.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed this resolution because the European Union should utilise its soft power to push Bosnia and Herzegovina to take the path towards reform. We should encourage the country to end the ethnic disputes and to fight corruption at all levels.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against. I am opposed to the stabilisation and association agreements with the Balkan countries. The commercial privileges granted to them are very harmful to our goods and products and we have no gain in return.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the 2014 progress report on Bosnia and Herzegovina because the progress bosnia and herzegovina is making is leading the country towards meeting the expectations of the European Union and is therefore introducing it with increasing conviction into the European path.  A great deal of progress has been made, although much more remains to be done. I believe that the Government of Bosnia-Herzegovina must not stop, but is, on the contrary, obliged to pursue with greater emphasis the path of institutional reform that has begun, which is absolutely essential in order to improve the socio-economic situation and continue the process of rapprochement with the European Union.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ In view of the advances being made in Bosnia and Herzegovina, especially on aspects of reform at all levels of governance, on strengthening administrative policy and in relation to a concrete roadmap for a broad and inclusive reform agenda to advance the country on its path towards the EU, I have voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I appreciated the fact that the resolution stressed the urgent need for Bosnia and Herzegovina to adapt to European legislation.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. This 2014 follow-up report on Bosnia and Herzegovina is part of the logic of forced enlargement, total interference and unfortunately does not take into account the political and economic reality of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is why I had to vote against it. We want to integrate into the European Union a country where 45% of the population is unemployed and where a third of the population works in public administration; a country whose 300 citizens are jihadists in Syria and which was still the scene, on Tuesday 28 April 2015, of a tragic Islamist attack in Zvornik, which killed a policeman and two others, all from the Serb minority, a Serb minority which, it must be said, is particularly affected by the country's political and economic instability.  It is time to abandon illusions and work on interstate cooperation that will make a positive difference for the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the new opportunity given to Bosnia and Herzegovina to resume the reform process, improve its social and economic situation and get closer to the European Union, some structural problems remain to be solved. This resolution consistently calls on bosnian authorities and leaders to refrain from using nationalist and divisive rhetoric, to implement the structural economic and social reforms necessary to improve the lives of their citizens, based on respect for human rights, the principle of the rule of law and the principle of equitable and direct universal suffrage.  The fight against corruption and inefficiency of the judicial system should also be a priority, with concern the constantly high number of missing persons and the weak progress made in this area. Equally worrying is the fact that it remains a country of origin, transit and destination of trafficking in human beings. I agree that it is essential to promote an inclusive and tolerant society that protects the rights of minorities and vulnerable groups.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the 2014 progress report on Bosnia and Herzegovina, sharing satisfaction with the progress made in some areas as well as the concerns expressed in many other situations. In particular, I am pleased that all the political forces in the country have signed up to the commitment to eu integration and, therefore, to implement those reforms that are essential for this to happen.  However, given that an efficient public administration forms the backbone of the integration process in Bosnia and Herzegovina and any country that aspires to become an EU Member State, I express my concern at the fragmentation, politicisation and dysfunction of public administration. I also find the inefficiency of the judicial system, where the risk of political interference in proceedings remains very high, equally worrying, and I therefore hope that the fight against corruption will become one of the top priorities.  I share the concern about the large number of missing persons, as well as the continuing presence of organised criminal groups. I repeat the report's call for the necessary action to stop radicalism and combat drug trafficking and trafficking in human beings.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the difficulties that Bosnia and Herzegovina is experiencing in its democratisation process, I believe that we need to encourage the drive for progress towards the democratisation of the country. This is only possible if the modernisation and proper management of resources is used. The fight against corruption and the fight against organised crime must not stop. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution on the Progress Report of Bosnia and Herzegovina, since it continues in line with Parliament's views of the applicant countries, reproducing a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. The text presented also seeks to protect the political and institutional exit of a country with chronic problems in its governance, the culpability of which lies precisely with many EU Member States.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution because I believe that this is a new opportunity for Bosnia and Herzegovina to resume the EU reform process and improve the social and economic situation in the country. Ensuring a better life for all citizens needs to be the priority for the political class in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. Draft resolution on the 2014 follow-up report on Bosnia and Herzegovina This resolution follows on from the 2014 follow-up report on the progress of eu negotiations in Bosnia and Herzegovina. In this text, Parliament expresses its support for the new framework programme of reforms in Bosnia and Herzegovina signed on 23 February. It also welcomes the process of constitutional reform that must be continued in order to eventually establish a functioning state and a democratisation of the institutional system. Although the fight against corruption, organized crime and terrorism has made positive progress, the negotiation process is still far from complete and accession is not expected to take place for many years. In light of these elements and the pre-diagnosis, I voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The 2014 European Parliament Decision on Bosnia and Herzegovina realistically presents the country's current situation, its shortcomings, its future tasks and any progress already made. For bosnia and herzegovina to bring swift and sustainable political reforms to strengthen the rule of law, social security and public administration, it is essential for the successful continuation of the EU accession process. Greater progress is also needed in the fight against corruption and structural, institutional and economic reforms. Political leaders must stand firmly and unquestionably on the European path and carry out the necessary reforms as soon as possible. There is also concern that the country is at a political stale, its institutional structure is unstable and inefficient, the relationship between political leaders is bad. All of these factors have a negative impact on the stability and development of the country. However, the decision acknowledges that the government in the country has been successfully formed, and that the elections have taken place without major complications. It is also important to mention that at the beginning of this year Bosnia and Herzegovina made a written commitment to EU integration, but in order to ensure that this is not just a fact, it needs to be successfully implemented as soon as possible and a complex draft reform is prepared, which is why it is necessary for the EP to continue to monitor Bosnia and Herzegovina and its development.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I voted against this 2014 follow-up report on Bosnia and Herzegovina because it is fully part of a forced enlargement ideology, based on the complete interference of Brussels in the institutions of the State concerned. Note, for example, the alignment of the country with the diplomacy of Brussels, as well as the consecration of ethnic and sexual communitarianisms.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the BiH progress report in 2014. and as shadow rapporteur, I can conclude that, thanks to the work of Mr Preda and the other shadow rapporteurs, we have been able to achieve a truly moderate and comprehensive resolution that very well represents the problems facing the country.  Many of the problems in the country stem from the complex state structure, which is the main reason the reform process is so slow. By insisting on a change in the constitution of the state, we must not forget that the design of Bosnia and Herzegovina was designed precisely to reduce the risk of inter-ethnic conflicts. Any change in the state's device must be duly agreed with absolutely all communities in the country, so as not to witness another civil war in Europe. As much criticism as we make to Bosnia and Herzegovina, I personally believe that the country's path of development is only towards EU membership. That is why, with our work and constructive criticism, we must give a clear sign that we welcome the country's efforts on the path to European integration.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot become a member of the EU because of the insurmountable problems it faces at federation level. Organised crime, the existence of extremist Muslim elements and corruption feed into the current socio-political situation.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The EU has been giving Bosnia and Herzegovina opportunities for the country to resume the reform process, improve the social and economic situation and move closer to the European Union. However, insufficient cooperation and coordination between bosnia and herzegovina's political leaders and all levels of administration, the absence of a common vision and political will, as well as ethnocentric attitudes, are seriously affecting the country's progress. I agree with the need to examine the country's application for the country, but Bosnian leaders will have to commit themselves to implementing the institutional, economic and social reforms necessary to improve the lives of citizens and to make significant progress in implementing the reform programme, including the Pact for Growth and Jobs.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. – This motion for a resolution presents a wide range of recitals on the process of integrating Bosnia and Herzegovina into the EU. The evaluation of the process that is carried out here and the list of advanced conditions denote the extent of the interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of EU membership, in particular on issues such as the economic organization of the State, the internal and political organization of the country, the imposition of reforms such as the Pact for Growth and Jobs , justice, public administration, the requirement to align the positions of that country with those of the EU, in particular with regard to foreign and border policy.  We consider unacceptable the manor stance with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts relating to the integration of the country are unacceptable, removing from the peoples the legitimate right to decide their future, where the free and sovereign choice of EU membership is inscribed, but also the strategies of economic and social development. For these reasons, we voted against it.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Bosnia and Herzegovina, as a potential candidate country, needs to be assessed on the basis of results and the timetable for accession should determine the speed and quality of reforms. The European Parliament supports the European integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina and we believe that, among other things, the European Union's enhanced engagement should focus on socio-economic issues, the rule of law, the fight against corruption, public administration reform, the business environment or civil society, and the conditionality of accession to the European Union should not be changed. It is therefore important to adopt a unified and coherent position of the European Union and to demonstrate that the integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina into the European Union is a priority for the European Union.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote no as the EU's enlargement policy has been wrong in the past and will be wrong again. The inconveniences created and still in place will only be widened by this out-of-the-way policy.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the 2014 progress report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot become a member of the EU because of insurmountable problems at federation level. Organised crime, the existence of extremist Muslim elements, corruption feed into the current socio-political situation.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I support the European Union’s renewed approach to Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH). The report calls for the revitalisation of the reform process, underlining the need for political commitment and genuine ownership. It urges political leaders to refrain from divisive nationalistic and secessionist rhetoric that polarises society, and it calls for the efficient implementation of the Written Commitment to EU Integration. It stresses that addressing citizens’ socioeconomic needs – as manifested in the social protests of last year – must be the priority. It also emphasises that BiH will not be a successful candidate for EU membership until appropriate institutional conditions have been established, and it calls for constitutional reform to make it an inclusive, effective and fully functional state. I am especially pleased that the matters raised in the amendments proposed by my group, the Socialists and Democrats, regarding the inclusion of social and human rights issues, are satisfactorily covered. This is a new opportunity for resumption of the EU reform process and for improvement in the social and economic situation in the country, and it must not be lost. Ensuring a better life for each and every citizen needs to be the priority for the political elites in BiH and within the European integration process.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. Bosnia and Herzegovina must deal with the prolonged political stalemate, which is a serious impediment to the country's stabilization and development. Bosnia and Herzegovina must commit fully to the institutional, economic and social reforms necessary to improve the living conditions of the country's citizens and move forward on the road to EU membership. The fight against organized crime and corruption is critical to countering attempts to infiltrate criminals into the political, legal and economic systems There is no doubt that addressing the socio-economic needs of citizens should be the priority for the authorities. Bosnia and Herzegovina is ahead of a long way in its process of being part of the EU, but from the European Parliament and the other EU institutions we must support the country in the necessary reform agenda.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I strongly support, as the report adopted puts it, the European integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina. As the rapporteur does, I too believe that the EU's enhanced commitment should also focus closely on socio-economic issues, the business environment and society's participation in the reform process.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the progress report on Bosnia and Herzegovina in 2014 and I fully share its concerns. Unfortunately, we have to note, once again, that progress in implementing a sustainable and functional institutional system remains insufficient and limited.
