The disagreement between the political parties and the different ethnic groups in the implementation of the reform system fully blocks the path towards European integration. This political climate has produced little in the area of public administration and judicial reform, where corruption affects entire public sectors and the fight against organised crime is weak. The lack of respect for human rights, freedom of the press and freedom of thought and the rights of LGBTI people, children and minorities are still a matter of great concern.  With regard to the implementation of the economic criteria, the country has taken small steps forward. Although economic growth has been on a fairly positive trend, the recovery remains fragile and public enterprises are still too weak. The labour market reflects high rates of unemployment and, above all, the rate of young people out of work is worrying. Unfortunately, the lack of will and coordination on European issues continues to have a negative impact on Bosnia and Herzegovina's rapprochement with the European Union.

name: Juan Carlos GIRAUTA VIDAL
text: in writing. Today I supported the Resolution on the 2014 Bosnia Herzegovina Progress Report. In order to see genuine progress, this report underlines the essential reforms that are necessary to improve the lives of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina. While great progress has been made in terms of reconstruction and reconciliation over the past twenty years, further work is needed to have a functioning market economy and a tolerant society, free of political and ethnic rhetoric. These are the main suggestions in the report. Let us not forget that the February 2014 protests were a clear sign that socio-economic reforms are fundamental. I do not want to end without apvaluing positively the EU's continued support for Bosnia and Herzegovina, as well as the EU's willingness to meet the requirements necessary to be a member of the EU.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote on the 2014 Bosnia and Herzegovina Progress Report, as we believe that the approach to this report does not correspond to the perspective we have in relation to the Balkan countries. One of the reasons has to do with the insistence of the different parliamentary groups (contrary to our position) to increase the pressure on Bosnia and Herzegovina to carry out structural reforms in the economic, social and political spheres. We reject these reforms as a precondition for their future access to the European Union. However, despite this, the report includes a commitment that goes in line with intensifying regional cooperation, mainly in the face of disasters and natural disasters affecting Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote on the 2014 Bosnia and Herzegovina Progress Report, as we believe that the approach to this report does not correspond to the perspective we have in relation to the Balkan countries. One of the reasons has to do with the insistence of the different parliamentary groups (contrary to our position) to increase the pressure on Bosnia and Herzegovina to carry out structural reforms in the economic, social and political spheres. We reject these reforms as a precondition for their future access to the European Union. However, despite this, the report includes a commitment that goes in line with intensifying regional cooperation, mainly in the face of disasters and natural disasters affecting Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: in writing. U2012 I am voting in favour of this document which urges the leaders of Bosnia and Herzegovina to commit themselves fully to the institutional, economic and social reforms necessary to improve the living conditions of the country's citizens and to move on the road to EU membership.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ We have to support fully Bosnia and Herzegovina’s European prospects. This represents a opportunity to resume the EU reform process and improve the social and economic situation in the country. It is important that improvement is further maintained, and I am sure the country will achieve clear and sustainable results in these fields in the near future.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. After a recent visit by The High Representative of Ms Mogherini, Bosnia and Herzegovina opened a new European perspective. A positive expression of interest and intentions of Bosnian and Herzegovinian politicians during and after the visit of the High Representative. We expect that Bosnia and Herzegovina will finally embark on its European journey. All Balkan countries should become members of the European Union as a guarantee for the stability of the restive Balkans, including Bosnia and Herzegovina. I voted for this resolution because I believe it will allow Bosnia and Herzegovina to become a more stable and secure state.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I voted against this 2014 follow-up report on Bosnia and Herzegovina because it is fully part of a forced enlargement ideology, based on the complete interference of Brussels in the institutions of the State concerned. Note, for example, the alignment of the country with the diplomacy of Brussels, as well as the consecration of ethnic and sexual communitarianisms.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the process of integrating Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH) into the EU, which includes social and economic improvement in the country. I supported the motion for a resolution as it outlines the progress made by BiH throughout 2014 in terms of fighting organised crime and terrorism, and with regard to legal provisions for freedom of expression and regional cooperation. However, the progress needs to continue, and constitutional and institutional reforms are still required.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome the long awaited entry into force of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, scheduled for 1 June this year. I urge the new leaders to refrain from divisive nationalistic and secessionist rhetoric that polarises society and to commit fully to carrying out the reforms necessary to improve the lives of all citizens and move forward in the EU integration process. Addressing the socioeconomic needs of the people of Bosnia – as manifested in the social protests of last year – must be the priority. Economic prosperity is, however, possible only if it is based on a democratic and inclusive society. Fighting corruption is another must as it affects all sectors, even health and education, exploiting the most vulnerable people. Pressure for change in Bosnia is coming from all sides, not only from the EU but also, and more importantly, from the citizens themselves. Transparency in the process of planning and implementing reforms is crucial, and civil society must be included in the reform process. We remain fully committed to Bosnia and Herzegovina being part of the EU.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I strongly supported the motion for a resolution because I believe that the process of European integration must also pass through Bosnia-Herzegovina. The written commitment made by the Bosnian Presidency is a clear sign in favour of this process. This resolution underlines the progress made in the fight against crime and terrorism, which are clearly important results. However, the need remains to initiate lines of reform and democratization of the political system, while paying particular attention to possible political and financial pressures in the media sector.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Written. 'We are not voting in favour of this resolution because we do not share the underlying denial of the constituent peoples as the main component of the state of a multi-nation state. On the one hand, we also believe that efficiency gains should be sought when each tier of government is acting. On the other hand, we believe that the negation of the different policy preferences of the constituent peoples does not contribute to the further peaceful development of a multi-nation state, in which the memories of a violent conflict have yet to heal.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The Resolution reiterates the EU's unequivocal commitment to the European perspective of Bosnia and Herzegovina and to the territorial integrity, sovereignty and unity of the country. It welcomes and supports the EU's renewed approach to Bosnia and Herzegovina and calls for the revitalization of the reform process, underlining the need for political commitment and genuine appropriation. The S&D Group fully supports the EU's renewed approach to Bosnia and Herzegovina. This is a new opportunity to resume the preocess of reforms in Bosnia and Herzegovina and to improve the social and economic situation in the country. This opportunity should not be missed. Ensuring a better life for citizens must be the priority of Bosnia and Herzegovina's political elites and in the process of European integration.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution on the Progress Report of Bosnia and Herzegovina, since it continues in line with Parliament's views of the applicant countries, reproducing a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. The text presented also seeks to protect the political and institutional exit of a country with chronic problems in its governance, the culpability of which lies precisely with many EU Member States.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ In a series of worrying developments in Bosnia and Herzegovina, I would like to highlight the two that have occurred in the last week. Terrorist attacks and violations of fundamental human rights have become the everyday life of our society, and the idea of democracy is under threat. I offer my condolences to the family of the slain police officer in the terrorist attack on the Zvornik police station. The attack was carried out by a young man of just 24 belonging to the Wahhabi movement.  In the context of this attack, Croatia, as the neighbour with whom BiH shares the largest border, strongly supports the territorial integrity of the country and the eliance of constituent peoples. A key moment, which gives a positive impetus for achieving the end goal, is the signing of the BiH Presidency's statement on a new approach to the Union in February this year. This statement allowed the Council to adopt a decision on the conclusion of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement due to enter into force on 1 June 2015. I support the resolution on the progress of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which calls on the Union and Bosnia and Herzegovina to make additional efforts to define common political and economic goals, implement reforms, foster regional cooperation and cooperation with civil society and solve many other problems. The perspective of BiH's membership in the European Union is of utmost importance for the stability and development of the state.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 Bosnia and Herzegovina is one of the countries with the most difficult and complicated history after the Second World War, marked by semitic, religious, ethnic and territorial divisions. All this so far has been marked by its complicated and more difficult implementation of the necessary measures towards European integration. It will be very important what positions the newly elected institutions take on these issues and how they will seize the opportunity to restore the country's access to the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I disagree with any future accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the EU for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament of 29 April 2015 and therefore voted against the 2014 progress report on Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this report. The aim here is to prepare Bosnia and Herzegovina for future integration by taking its own place in its affairs: the European Union is questioning Bosnia and Herzegovina's prerogatives over its foreign policy, inviting it to reform its institutions, pursuing a policy in line with the wishes of Brussels and imposing the opinion of institutions considered to be moral authorities, in this case the Hague Tribunal. This is an attack on the sovereignty of states that we formally oppose.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. This report is fully in line with an ideology of forced enlargement, based on the complete interference of Brussels in the institutions of the State concerned. Note, for example, the alignment of the country with the diplomacy of Brussels, as well as the consecration of ethnic and sexual communitarianisms. I voted AGAINST.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it urges the new political leaders in Bosnia and Herzegovina to move away from the divisive nationalistic and secessionist rhetoric of the past and to continue along the path of institutional, economic and social reform that will lead to EU membership.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the European Union’s renewed approach to Bosnia and Herzegovina. This is a new opportunity for Bosnia and Herzegovina to resume the EU reform process and improve the social and economic situation in the country, and it must not be lost. Ensuring a better life for each and every citizen needs to be the priority for the Bosnia and Herzegovina political elites and within the European integration process.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The 2014 monitoring report of Bosnia and Herzegovina shows that the situation of that country, which has been a candidate for EU membership since 2003, remains worrying, since, from the point of view of both the United Nations and the Union, there can be no progress in implementing political and economic reforms. Moreover, the resurgence of separatist sentiment, divisions between political parties and the exclusion of minorities appear to undermine the viability of the State of Bosnia and Herzegovina.  This never-ending quest for the enlargement of the Union, without seeking the opinion of the peoples of the Member States, when it has been unable to absorb previous accessions, seems dangerous to me. So I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the European Union’s renewed approach to Bosnia and Herzegovina. It represents a new opportunity for the country to improve its social and economic conditions and to advance towards EU membership, and that opportunity must not be lost. For too long there has been no progress, and we need to break this deadlock. It is high time the political leaders refrained from divisive nationalistic and secessionist rhetoric that polarises society, and high time that they engaged seriously in reforms to improve the lives of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s citizens. Ensuring a better life for each and every citizen needs to be the priority for Bosnia and Herzegovina and within the European integration process.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which calls on Bosnia and Herzegovina to continue its efforts to reach the criteria for possible accession negotiations to the European Union. The text reminds us that Bosnia and Herzegovina, like all other candidate countries, must be judged on the quality and speed of the institutional, economic and social reforms required and on which the timetable will depend.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this motion for a resolution, which has become necessary as the European Union has reaffirmed its commitment to the European perspective of Bosnia and Herzegovina, based on a coordinated approach aimed at enabling the country to resume its reform process and to improve the social and economic situation, and considering that EU membership is an inclusive process, belonging to the whole country and all its citizens, and requires a national consensus on the reform programme. With regard to the process of bringing Bosnia and Herzegovina closer to the EU, we express our concern about the World Bank's indicators that Bosnia and Herzegovina is the European country with the lowest rate in terms of ease of doing business. It is one of the countries in the lowest positions in the corruption perception index ranking and has the highest youth unemployment rate in Europe. We therefore call on the new political leaders of Bosnia and Herzegovina to refrain from divisive nationalist and secessionist rhetoric that polarises society, and to engage seriously in reforms that will improve the lives of their citizens, create a democratic, inclusive and functioning state and bring the country even closer to the European Union.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution, which shows the progress bosnia and herzegovina has made over the last year. The resolution encourages the country to continue the European path and the reform process and welcomes the Written Commitment to European Integration, adopted by the Bosnian Presidency and signed by all political leaders on 23 February 2015. The resolution stresses the progress made in the fight against organised crime and terrorism and calls for the fight against corruption to be made a top priority. It also considers it crucial to proceed in parallel with policies for reforming and democratising the political system.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has provided a new opportunity for Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH), aimed at helping the country resume its reform process, improve its social and economic situation and get closer to the European Union.  I voted and signed this resolution because, in its text, it reminds BiH that respect for the rule of law, the independence of justice, the fight against corruption and "a professional, effective and merit-based public administration is a cornerstone of the integration process for BiH and for any country that aspires to become a member state of the European Union".

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on bosnia and Herzegovina's progress because it constitutes a balanced report. I believe that BiH has made some progress, but there are still a lot of problems to be solved before it can be considered that this state is actually ready to become a member of the EU. There are still problems with democracy, justice and, above all, socio-economic problems, but all this can be solved if BiH continues its European journey and is given to it. In this respect, I believe that the report encourages this journey, but drawing attention to the problems that still exist, which is why I also supported this report by voting.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. I supported the proposal. It is important to support the perspective of Bosnia and Herzegovina's eu-accession perspective. This is a motivation for reform. At the same time, the resolution also reflects the problems in the country, which increasingly need to be addressed. The development of this country is thus damaged by political and ethnic disagreements and high levels of corruption, high unemployment, restrictions on freedom of expression, a lack of an independent judiciary and many other problems. Bosnia and Herzegovina must take serious action on combating trafficking in human beings and to end ethnic segregation in schools. I consider it important to abolish the EU visa requirement for the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work and hope that I have made my contribution.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the adoption of a resolution on Bosnia and Herzegovina's 2014 progress report. The report brings a new opportunity for BiH to continue reforms, improve the social and economic situation through a coordinated approach, and calls for ensuring eliance between the three constituent peoples. Special attention is required for the protection of Croats who have been literally eradicated in the territory of the Republika Srpska entity and many municipalities of the Federation of BiH, and must be provided with education in Croatian as well as a TV channel in Croatian.  The report also calls for a more efficient institutional set-up, co-operation and co-ordination of BiH political leaders, the fight against corruption, confronting politicians with citizens' needs and other important priorities for the country. My amendments that were adopted sent an invitation to the BiH authorities to respect EU environmental legislation related to the problems of cross-border air pollution as a result of the operation of the refinery in Bosanski Brod, thus problematized this topic for the first time in such reports.  An invitation was also sent to BiH to respect international conventions related to the protection of the Neretva and Trebišnjica rivers due to the possible dangers of the "Upper Horizons" project, endangering the drinking water supply of residents and irrigation of agricultural areas in the Neretva River and the possible negative impact on the ecological system of the Bay of Mali Ston.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. This report, a prelude to enlargement, calls on Bosnia and Herzegovina to renounce its sovereign state prerogatives in order to submit to the goodwill of the European institutions. Since I am opposed to any enlargement and any infringement of sovereignty, I have of course voted against this report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The new resolution on BiH is a reflex of the changed relationship of the EU institutions towards post-election BiH. It is no longer just a list of demands and objections to stagnation in the implementation of reforms, but expresses a clear attitude towards the European perspective of BiH, a new approach and a list of priorities that BiH, like any other country currently in the "waiting room" for the EU, must meet.  I am particularly pleased with the imminent start of the application of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement of BiH to the European Union, which enters into force on 1 June. Until a co-ordination mechanism is in place for BiH to speak with one voice in its communication with Brussels, it is difficult to talk about the effects of documents adopted outside BiH itself. We cannot support the continuation of the finging of reforms in a country that has, unfortunately, become synonymous with economic-social stagnation.  And BiH will not be a successful candidate for EU membership, as long as the proper institutional conditions are not met, which means upgrading the Dayton Agreement and ensuring the constitutional eliance of all constituent peoples. It is obvious that the model of conduct by officials in BiH in the last twenty years has not led to and does not lead to the desired progress, both domestically and internationally in BiH. The message is clear and I hope those to whom it was intended will hear it.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I hope that Bosnia and Herzegovina will make the most of the opportunity offered to it by the European Union to have a European perspective by implementing the necessary reforms and putting aside the quarrels between the political leaders that lead to a stalemate that prevents the stabilisation and development of the country. This situation of political instability leads to a slowdown in development, high unemployment and widespread corruption. The country's new leaders must strive for the institutional, economic and social reforms necessary to improve the quality of life of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina and to enable the required progress on the road to EU membership to be carried out.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Writing. \u2012 I have long supported the enlargement of the European Union to the number of countries that are ready to meet the entry conditions. For this reason, I am closely following preparations in countries such as Bosnia and Herzegovina. On the one hand, this Balkan country is making some progress, but the report rightly points to areas where further reforms are necessary for Bosnia and Herzegovina. I wish Bosnia and Herzegovina success and I am voting in favour of the report submitted.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In 2008, Bosnia and Herzegovina signed a stabilization and association agreement with the European Union. However, the country's internal difficulties and protracted political stalemate prevent the country from carrying out the necessary reforms. The situation of the rule of law remains very fragile and the government must make considerable efforts if it is to comply with European requirements. The European Parliament adopted the 2014 follow-up report for Bosnia and Herzegovina and congratulates the country on its commitment to possible European integration. I encourage this country to undertake the desired reforms. However, I reaffirm my wish to establish a moratorium of 5 to 10 years for any new membership.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 The Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and Bosnia and Herzegovina, of the other part, was signed on 16 June 2008. The EU has given Bosnia and Herzegovina a new opportunity on the basis of a coordinated approach designed to help the country resume the reform process, improve the social and economic situation and get closer to the Union. This resolution strongly supports the European integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina and believes that the EU's enhanced commitment should focus, inter alia, on socio-economic issues, the business environment, the institutional framework, the rule of law and governance, law enforcement policy, the independence of the judiciary, the fight against corruption, public administration reform, civil society and youth. It also urges the authorities to make combating corruption an absolute priority and notes the progress made in the fight against organised crime and terrorism. Finally welcomes the written commitment to EU integration adopted by the Presidency of Bosnia and Herzegovina, signed by the leaders of all political parties and supported by the Parliament of Bosnia and Herzegovina on 23 February 2015. I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. In July 2014, European Commission President-elect Jean-Claude Juncker declared in the Chamber that "there will be no further enlargement in the next five years". A common-sense proposal that was high on the agenda of the MR programme during the last European elections. This need to solidify the House of Europe before it is enlarged does not mean that the ongoing negotiations with the countries of the near neighbourhood such as Bosnia and Herzegovina must stop. This country, which has been a potential candidate for membership of the European Union since 2003, certainly needs a European perspective, but it is still far from European standards. The difficult economic and social situation facing the EU requires increased vigilance. European decision-makers want to pay much more attention to chapters 23 ("judicial apparatus and fundamental rights") and 24 ("justice, freedom, security"). As such, the 2014 follow-up report on Bosnia and Herzegovina highlights the country's eternal state of the day, regarding its European integration. Progress still needs to be made in political and economic matters, but also in taking into account the interests of the citizen. Concrete action must be taken without delay at several national levels.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. This Resolution reiterates the EU's unequivocal commitment to Bosnia and Herzegovina and to the territorial integrity, sovereignty and unity of the country, although it is stressed that the country will not be a candidate for EU membership until adequate institutional conditions have been established. A constitutional reform is therefore calling for a comprehensive, effective and functional constitutional reform of Bosnia and Herzegovina, together with the revitalization of the reform process. Political leaders are also urged to refrain from the nationalist and secessionist rhetorical division that polarized society, emphasizing that citizens' socio-economic needs should be the priority. For all this, I support this Resolution and the EU's renewed approach to Bosnia and Herzegovina, which I understand as a new opportunity to resume its reform process and improve the country's social and economic situation. This opportunity should not be missed. Ensuring a better life for citizens must be the political priority of Bosnia and Herzegovina as part of its process of European integration.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. In this resolution on the 2014 follow-up report on Bosnia and Herzegovina that we adopted, we called on the new leaders of Bosnia and Herzegovina to agree with the European Union on a well-defined roadmap for a broad and open reform agenda. And encouraged these leaders to make a full commitment to the necessary institutional, economic and social reforms. As such, the reform of the justice system and that of fragmented, politicized and dysfunctional public administration is paramount. Moreover, the political impasse, the overly complex and inefficient institutional architecture, and the lack of cooperation between policy makers are currently seriously hampering the country's stabilization and development.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a Bosnian progress report. The document is a very important topic and is being discussed at a particularly relevant time, at a time when Bosnia and Herzegovina is still working to ensure both internal stability and its European orientation. Moreover, despite some of the political groups' softening of the tone of the document, the document retains the key points that are important to us: the mention and call for action on the 20th anniversary of the Srebrenica massacre and the call for measures to be taken in this regard, and the call for the EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina to continue. Unfortunately, we, the Group of the Greens, have failed to introduce a number of very important amendments relating to some interpretations of historical events of a particularly nationalist nature. We have also unfortunately not received the support of our colleagues for our proposal for a much broader eu agreement in relation to negotiations with Bosnia, which I very much hope will not spoil the good trends that are emerging at the current stage of relations with this country.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. As the rapporteur points out, the Union has offered a new opportunity for Bosnia and Herzegovina to resume its process of political, social and economic reform with a view to its European integration. However, what this report still shows us is that there is a long way to go, in particular as to the need for Bosnia and Herzegovina to make progress towards implementing the reform programme contained in the Pact for Growth and Jobs. I note that some progress has been made in the meantime, especially in the fight against organised crime and terrorism, but areas such as gender equality, social protection and the environment where progress has been greatly limited remain, but there are still areas such as gender equality, social protection and the environment where progress has been greatly limited. It is absolutely essential that this country is able to carry out a set of reforms to curb corruption, guarantee freedom of the press and transform Bosnia and Herzegovina into an effective and functional democratic rule of law.  As such, on their way to the EU, political priorities must invariably go through the ability to implement institutional, economic and social reforms to improve the living conditions of citizens, businesses and the state itself, as well as the legislative framework of their activities.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the progress report on Bosnia and Herzegovina because it is right to applaud a state that is trying to improve its negative standards in terms of combating organised crime and terrorism. However, this is not enough because we need more efforts to combat corruption, just as we need policies to democratise the political system.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote against because Bosnia and Herzegovina is believed to have made progress towards future MEMBERSHIP of the European Union in 2014, despite the fact that it is noted that corruption is widespread, public administration is fragmented, different legal systems represent a challenge, mechanisms for cooperation with civil society remain weak, the media structure is polarised and no equal rights are guaranteed for all peoples and citizens.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We abstained in the vote on the 2014 Bosnia and Herzegovina Progress Report, as we believe that the approach to this report does not correspond to the perspective we have in relation to the Balkan countries. One of the reasons has to do with the insistence of the different parliamentary groups (contrary to our position) to increase the pressure on Bosnia and Herzegovina to carry out structural reforms in the economic, social and political spheres. We reject these reforms as a precondition for their future access to the European Union. However, despite this, the report includes a commitment that goes in line with intensifying regional cooperation, mainly in the face of disasters and natural disasters affecting Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution on the Progress Report of Bosnia and Herzegovina, since it continues in line with Parliament's views of the applicant countries, reproducing a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. The text presented also seeks to protect the political and institutional exit of a country with chronic problems in its governance, the culpability of which lies precisely with many EU Member States.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 Today we expressed our full support for the European integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina. At the same time, we stressed that greater involvement is needed in the following areas: socio-economic issues, business environment, institutional framework, rule of law and governance, law enforcement policy, independent justice, the fight against corruption, public administration reform, as well as civil society and youth. At the same time, it is important to maintain the conditionality of EU accession unchanged.  Constitutional reform aimed at consolidating, unifying and strengthening the institutional framework remains crucial for transforming Bosnia and Herzegovina into an effective, pluralistic and fully functional state. Future constitutional reform should also take into account the principles of federalism, decentralisation, subsidiarity and legitimate representation in order to ensure the effective and efficient integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina into the EU. That is why we call on all political leaders in Bosnia and Herzegovina to work towards the necessary changes. Economic prosperity will only be possible on the basis of a democratic and pluralistic society and state institutions, and Bosnia and Herzegovina will not become a certain candidate for EU membership unless it provides adequate institutional conditions.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the 2014 Progress Report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. It sends out a strong, clear message in favour of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s aspirations for greater European integration. Bosnia and Herzegovina’s EU membership ambition has the capacity to contribute to the democracy and stability of the country and the region as a whole. Political dialogue and cooperation now need to take place to encourage the necessary reforms.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the resolution on Bosnia and Herzegovina's progress for 2014. This resolution contains many inspiring and concrete proposals, which I consider to be beneficial. At the same time, however, it places undue emphasis on the specific needs of one particular group, namely LGBTI. The text also calls for anti-discrimination legislation to be adopted in a form that could lead to discrimination against citizens with different views in this area in the fight against homophobia.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report on Bosnia and Herzegovina's progress towards EU membership in the hope that it would also boost biH's reform processes. The EU has repeatedly stated its unequivocal commitment to The European BiH perspective and its territorial integrity, sovereignty and unity.  I expect that Bosnia and Herzegovina will accept and implement the adjustments to the trade part of the Interim Agreement and the Stabilisation and Association Agreement with regard to Croatia's accession to the EU, based on traditional trade between the two neighbouring states. I would focus on the necessity of reforms in establishing functioning and stable institutions, addressing a very high youth unemployment rate and helping the population in a state of need following the severe floods of May 2014. It is also important to enforce the Ruling of the European Court of Human Rights in the Sejdic-Finci case, as BiH continues to violate its international obligation.  Unfortunately, the lack of coherence with EU requirements in the areas of agriculture and rural development, food safety, veterinary and phytosanitary policy and fisheries continues to prevent exports of animal goods in the EU. Sectoral strategies in areas such as transport, energy and the environment covering the whole country have not yet been agreed, and I believe they constitute a precondition for financial assistance.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – Bosnia and Herzegovina has expressed an interest in European integration by approving a written commitment approved by the BiH Parliamentary Assembly on 23 February 2015. This is a very good road, although with the ongoing problems in Bosnia and Herzegovina, it will also be a long road. The complex and inefficient structure of the authorities, the lack of cooperation and coordination of political leaders, corruption, civil unrest, high unemployment and, last but not least, the nationalist and separatist rhetoric of political leaders polarise society in the state and do not contribute to stability. Bosnia and Herzegovina's government must prepare the social and economic reforms in the country very precisely, the reform of the labour market in order to tackle high unemployment rates, to introduce an effective judicial system, to make the fight against corruption a priority, because that is what controls key sectors such as health, education and public administration. The calculation of the problems is much greater, but if Bosnia and Herzegovina means it sincerely with European integration, I believe that we are all ready to help and advise them. I am thinking, below all of them, of the Commission, of MEPs and certainly of the individual Member States.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: Writing. \u2012 Bosnia and Herzegovina is undoubtedly one of the most complex states in the world, but I would like to recall that it was laid down in the Dayton Peace Agreement of 1995, which concluded the Bosnian War. The performance of Bosnian, Croatian and Serbian politicians can be criticised, but it would be an illusion for the European Union to expect everyone in Bosnia and Herzegovina to define themselves as Bosnians, not Bosnians, Croats or Serbs, i.e. to completely overturn the model based on the cooperation of the three state-forming peoples. I do not agree with the resolution that 'ethnocentric attitudes are hampering the country's progress'. The problem is not with ethnocentrism – ethnocentrism cannot be avoided in a multi-ethnic state – but with the efficiency of the functioning of the state, which can and must be improved. At the same time, I welcome the fact that the motion emphasises the importance of a joint, objective study of history. I am convinced that this should also be a good practice for many EU Member States.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. - Bosnia and Herzegovina needs to be treated differently from the other countries of the Western Balkans, as it has a specific situation. The divisiveness and division of the country can be felt at every turn, and it is necessary to give people time to integrate and one day feel like a unified nation. The European Parliament resolution is encouraging, balanced and positive. It was struggling for the rapporteur, Mr Preda, and everyone else involved in the negotiations. I support the constructive criticism, as well as the efforts of all those who wish to help Bosnia and Herzegovina improve the situation in the country. However, the country and its people also need to be listened to and understood. After all, the very high unemployment rate, the poor economic situation, the excessive level of corruption and many other problems they face clearly indicate that Bosnia and Herzegovina and its citizens do not need further blows, but a hand of assistance. The European Parliament must help to establish a better economic and political situation and help Bosnia and Herzegovina on the path to the desired progress. For this reason, I supported the resolution and voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 It is important that Bosnia and Herzegovina continues to push for reforms in the economic, political and legislative fields. Progress will result in a convergence towards integration into European structures. EU cooperation with Bosnia and Herzegovina in the economic field, namely in trade and trade matters, can contribute to consolidating the economic situation in that country and also ensure development and economic growth.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it gives a balanced view of the progress made in Bosnia and Herzegovina. It covers the most important issues, such as reform of the judiciary, the fight against corruption, media pluralism, and the need for socioeconomic reforms and for an inclusive and non-discriminatory education system.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We are not opposed to the accession of any state to the EU, since this is the wish of its people and if it also meets the criteria for accession. Unfortunately, however, the report proposes to promote economic reforms within the framework of a neoliberal policy. The major socio-economic problems facing Bosnia, such as the issue of unemployment, which is merely a rudimentary reference, are also ignored. For the above reasons we have chosen to abstain.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Bosnia and Herzegovina cannot currently become a member of the EU because of insurmountable problems at federation level. Organised crime, the existence of extremist Muslim elements, corruption feed into the current socio-political situation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted for the resolution. I encourage the new politicians to avoid any conflicting nationalist and separatist rhetoric that polarizes society, to undertake serious reforms to improve the lives of the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina, to create a democratic, plural and operational state and to bring the country closer to the European Union. Otherwise, nothing will be possible.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. This 2014 follow-up report on Bosnia and Herzegovina is once again part of a forced enlargement ideology, based on the complete interference of Brussels in the institutions of the State concerned. The authorities of Bosnia and Herzegovina, for example, are invited "in an urgent way to amend the penal code" and are also reprimanded for daring to pursue a "foreign policy of the country which is always characterized by divergent positions, which results in a low rate of alignment with the Union's positions". A real questioning of the prerogatives of any sovereign state over its foreign policy. As in most reports on the prospects for enlargement, the State is called upon to reform all its institutions, to carry out a policy in line with the wishes of Brussels, particularly in relation to the consecration of ethnic and sexual communitarianism. Finally, note the virtual prohibition by the Union to challenge the legitimacy of certain institutions. I vote AGAINST this text written by amateurs who ignore the political, economic and ethnic reality of this country.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it strongly supports Bosnia and Herzegovina’s European integration while, at the same time, clearly highlighting the numerous challenges that the country still faces and needs to address swiftly in the interest of its citizens. Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH) is plagued by overly complex and inefficient institutional architecture, which enhances the existing divide along ethnic lines and severely hampers the decision-making process. The lack of cooperation among political elites prevents the adoption of much-needed reforms to fight the high levels of corruption and unemployment, while public administration remains fragmented and costly. The Written Commitment to EU integration, signed by all political leaders and adopted by the BiH Presidency in February 2015, represents a positive step towards reversing this tendency. With the entry into force of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement, on which the Council agreed in March 2015, the leaders of BiH and the EU will need jointly to set out a roadmap for urgent reforms to advance the country on its path towards EU membership.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this Resolution on the Progress Report of Bosnia and Herzegovina, since it continues in line with Parliament's views of the applicant countries, reproducing a colonial relationship between a rich and powerful centre in the face of an impoverished and obedient periphery. The text presented also seeks to protect the political and institutional exit of a country with chronic problems in its governance, the culpability of which lies precisely with many EU Member States.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. Bosnia and Herzegovina, like five other Western Balkan countries, was selected as a "potential candidate" for EU membership at the European Summit in Thessaloniki in 2003.  Since then, the Council and the European Commission have monetized visa facilitation agreements and the status of "candidate for European integration" in exchange for the famous structural economic reforms.  The message in this resolution is clear: Bosnia would not have made sufficient efforts to move towards a "functional market economy".  While the GUE/NGL had tabled a number of amendments in committee to have EU pressure on the matter removed, none of them were supported.  The social situation in Bosnia and Herzegovina is explosive and the development of a rule of law and equality among citizens has yet to progress. If I support the prospect of integration of the countries of the Western Balkans, since the people of the countries concerned are in favour of it, I refuse to allow this to be met with economic blackmail and to the detriment of the citizens. I abstain, including not to mix my vote with those who see Bosnia and Herzegovina above all as a country with a strong Muslim majority to which any prospect of integration must be denied.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the launch of the process of complete destabilisation and disaggregation of Yugoslavia, Stabilisation and Association Agreements have been concluded with all the western Balkan countries concerned, with the exception of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Kosovo. In May 2014, negotiations for a Stabilisation and Association Agreement with Kosovo were concluded and the Agreement was initialled in July 2014. Regardless of the need to work on the basis of today's reality, which stems from only part of the countries being integrated into the EU, it is not possible to pass this debate without mentioning, on the one hand, the EU's role in the Yugoslavia crisis and, in particular, the role of Germany which, in fostering Croatian nationalism, has stirred up a conflict still with open scars within Europe. We also criticise the EXPANSIONIST EU policy which seeks, under the cover of free trade, to conquer new markets and offset the weak domestic demand that stems from years of austerity policies.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the European integration process in Bosnia and Herzegovina because I firmly believe that the future of that country is in the European Union. The EU, born after a war that destroyed the continent, must set an example, demonstrating that reconciliation is possible. Our motto 'Unity in diversity' must help to overcome its internal divisions. It is unacceptable for citizens to pay the highest price for this lack of political will.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted against this resolution because it is a concrete step towards Bosnia and Herzegovina's EU membership. This political objective was irrevocably expressed in the Thessaloniki Agenda for the Western Balkans: Towards European Integration (European Council conclusions of 19-20 June 2003 on the Western Balkans). The Heads of State or Government of the Member States have already decided in Brussels that Serbia, Albania, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Macedonia and Montenegro should become EU Member States in the very foreseeable future. Taxpayers' money is now being made available to reform the Western Balkans at all costs as 'EU compatible'. However, the AfD's EU election manifesto states: "First consolidation, then enlargement." That is what I am sticking to.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support the European Union’s renewed approach to Bosnia and Herzegovina. It represents a new opportunity for the country to improve its social and economic conditions and to advance towards EU membership, and that opportunity must not be lost. For too long there has been no progress, and we need to break this deadlock. It is high time the political leaders refrained from divisive nationalistic and secessionist rhetoric that polarises society, and high time that they engaged seriously in reforms to improve the lives of Bosnia and Herzegovina’s citizens. Ensuring a better life for each and every citizen needs to be the priority for Bosnia and Herzegovina and within the European integration process. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Theodoros ZAGORAKIS
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2014 progress report on Bosnia and Herzegovina, which reflects the problems and difficulties facing the candidate country. We all want to put the country back on track for EU membership, but for that to happen, its authorities must be bold in implementing the reforms.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. \u2012 This motion for a resolution presents a wide range of recitals on the process of integrating Bosnia and Herzegovina into the EU. In addition to the evaluation of the process, it points to a wide range of conditionalities for membership, which confirm the extent of the interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of EU membership, in particular on issues such as justice, the country's internal and political organization, the imposition of reforms such as the Pact for Growth and Jobs 2012 and we know well what is behind these aggression pacts , the requirement to align that country's positions with those of the EU.  We consider unacceptable the manor stance with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts relating to the integration of the country are unacceptable, removing from the peoples the legitimate right to decide their future, where the free and sovereign choice of EU membership is inscribed, but also the strategies of economic and social development. For these reasons, we voted against it.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I would particularly like to support this proposal. While it emphasises that the EIB is not a commercial bank, it does have a very important role to play in financing very important developments and enterprises in Europe.  I must also compliment the President and the Directors, because they facilitated a visit by my colleagues from Fine Gael in the EPP Group to Luxembourg a few months ago. They were very open and supportive and that is something that we appreciate. I am also very pleased to see emphasis being put on the role they can play, particularly in financing SMEs. It is part of the wider Juncker investment plan and I think more and more people are realising the important role the EIB plays and that it will play an even greater role in the future. I welcome their openness and their good work.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it contains important positive elements, such as the need to strengthen credit support for small and medium-sized enterprises; strengthening the EIE's governance and administrative resources to prevent a repeat of the financial and fiscal scandals it has starred in in the past; to vehicular funds towards job creation, energy efficiency improvement or research and development initiatives. Nevertheless, significant risks remain in the EI's action, especially because of its association with the Juncker Plan (a public guarantee that seems designed to encourage private speculation in large transport or energy projects, as has already happened with the EEST's activity in Castor) or its unre transparent relationship with cohesion and development policies, which will require greater oversight of its activity by Parliament.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. ‒ This report contained several positive elements. In particular, it provided a critique of EU austerity, coupled with a call to put public investment back at the core of economic policy. In addition, it contained a critique of the European Investment Bank’s involvement in corruption cases, failed infrastructure projects and dangerous gas projects. In particular, it called for more investment in renewables and for the phasing-out of all energy projects in fossil fuels, and it also called for investment in regions with high unemployment and low GDP. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: Writing. The most important point at the moment with regard to the EIB is the creation of the Structural and Investment Fund (ESIF). The aim of this fund is to transfer funds to vulnerable regions, especially those with high unemployment and low economic growth. It will therefore also be necessary to develop the workforce. The report also emphasises that the EIB is not a bank with commercial interests, but a catalyst for financing sound public and long-term private investment. I welcome the European Investment Bank's annual report for 2013.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This report raises a number of shortcomings. On the one hand, the EIB has not committed sufficient investment financing for small and medium-sized enterprises. This report demonstrates the European Investment Bank's priority to focus on European projects. It is then legitimate to question the real possibilities of French companies to access these funds. On the other hand, I regret the scale of international funding at a time when the Member States of the European Union are in great need of it. My abstention therefore means the need for the European Investment Bank to review its priorities and to stop endorsing ill-conceived European projects.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I felt it necessary to oppose this report because of the readiness of the ECB to purchase EIB bonds, and because of the calls for the Commission to take action – these principles do not accord with those of UKIP.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this 2013 EIB Annual Report, an indispensabble tool for reviving economic growth in Europe.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for the Annual Report of the European Investment Bank 2013. The EIB's financial activities increased by 37% in 2013 to EUR 75.1 billion. Eib resources shall be mobilised to increase public and private investment, promote competitiveness, restore sustainable growth, and promote the creation of quality jobs and infrastructure. It is important that the EIB and the European funds cooperate, in particular in member states and regions, in order to carry out productive public investment and major infrastructure projects. It is essential that the Commission's new investment plan promotes and facilitates access to finance for Member States and regions with high unemployment and gdp per capita below the EU average. I agree that priority should be given to projects with European added value that have the greatest impact in terms of job creation. It is important to pay more attention to higher-risk projects that find it difficult to obtain bank funding.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. In this matter, we have thought about how to change the EIB, since in the coming months the role of this institution in the European economy will be even more important.   It will be responsible for managing the billions of euros of the Juncker Plan: more than 300 billion euros that will be invested in the European economy to boost activity and create jobs. As a representative on this issue for the Socialist Group, I insisted that the EIB make sustainable investments; I am thinking of buildings that consume little energy.  I have also focused on something that is very damaging to the European economy. As part of its investments, the EIB does not invest directly in projects, it relies on financial intermediaries. And unfortunately, sometimes these intermediaries are based in tax havens, in Luxembourg, in the Cayman Islands or Mauritius. This is obviously not acceptable and the EIB will have to avoid these intermediaries in the future.  These recommendations will, I hope, enable us to invest sustainably in the future and to revive the European economy.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: in writing. The Beaver project was approved in 2008 as a natural gas tank. The project never worked due to the earthquakes recorded, and the Government of Spain approved compensation of 1.35 billion to the company and the extinction of the concession of exploitation of the warehouse. The EI, through the PBCE (Project Bond Credit Enhancement) programme, supported the project by improving its credit rating and thus enabled capital market financing to be obtained. We consider that the EI and the Commission did not take into account the risk of increased seismic activity linked to gas injection, despite studies clearly alerting to the potential dangers of this operation. We therefore urge the Commission and the EI to take action to prevent Spanish citizens from having to pay EUR 1.3 billion in compensation for a project preceded by a disastrous assessment by increasing energy costs.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This report is related to the 2013 annual report on the European Investment Bank.  I believe that Europe should be given priority in implementing the EIB's financing policy and that the EIB should reduce the provision of financing to investments outside the European Union. Finally, financial support for SMEs/SMEs should be strengthened. This report on the EIB is a perfect example of the Union's mentality. It rightly deplores the 27% drop in private and public investment since 2009, but at the same time it is constantly advocating a policy of austerity in order to save the euro and to go ever further down the path of federalism.  It is the whole economic policy that needs to be reviewed, not just the EIB's guidelines! Moreover, the EIB's investment allocation system leaves little room for Member States to manoeuvre, although they are better able to determine the relevance of local projects.  Considering this, I have decided to abstain.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 While the report is acceptable in some of its passages in which it criticises and comments on the activities of the European Investment Bank, the fact remains that it insists on not noting that the cause of the crisis is the Euro itself and calls for a greater contribution from the EIB itself. That is why I abstained in this vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the increase in EES financing activities by 37%, but also concern about economic stagnation in the EU and, in particular, the significant decline in public and private investment and the dizzying 35% fall in credit to SMEs between 2008 and 2013 , which drags economic recovery, job creation and reducing inequality and poverty.  The report contains recommendations on how the EI can play a key role in incentivising investment in Europe. Thus, it points out that the european Fund for Strategic Investments prioritizes the financing of projects with European value-added, with positive cost-benefit analyses and that they have a maximum impact on job creation. It also urges the EEB to analyse the decline in funding for SMEs and to continue to increase its lending capacities for SMEs and innovative start-ups. It also regrets the E BLESSED and Commission's poor risk assessment in the Beaver project and urges both to take steps to prevent Spanish citizens from having to pay EUR 1.3 billion for this failed project. Finally, greater transparency is demanded.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: Writing. – The European Union is dealing with difficult economic conditions and rising unemployment, which has serious consequences for our society, especially for young people. Extraordinary times obviously require extraordinary measures and a consistent European response to overcome the crisis. As a bank of the European Union, the EIB must play a key role in financing investment in growth and jobs. It is to be welcomed that the EIB has always responded to the specific needs of the regions most affected by the crisis and, according to its report, intends to continue to do so. In many cases, this bank is the only financier capable to play this role to a significant extent. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I welcome the fact that in 2013 the EIB focused primarily on a countercyclical role and that it acted as a reliable partner in economically reasonable investments both inside and outside the European Union. In agreement with the rapporteur, I believe that investments with their funding can make a real difference to people's lives, whether it is jobs for hundreds of thousands of small businesses making progress in infrastructure investments in the regions most affected by the crisis, or maintaining cutting-edge innovations to help europe maintain its global competitiveness and supporting clean energy, so I supported the constructive proposals contained in the report in the final vote of 30 April 2015.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ The EIB is an instrument designed to support social cohesion and assist Member States in the face of social and economic difficulties. All possible resources from Member States and the EU, including EIB funds, should be effectively mobilised without delay to foster and improve public and private investment, increase competitiveness, restore sustainable and inclusive economic growth and boost job and infrastructure creation. This report deserves our support, but I think it necessary to warn that the EIB needs to work more on the transparency of the decision-making process.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: in writing. ‒ This report contained several positive elements. In particular, it provided a critique of EU austerity, coupled with a call to put public investment back at the core of economic policy. In addition, it contained a critique of the European Investment Bank’s involvement in corruption cases, failed infrastructure projects and dangerous gas projects. In particular, it called for more investment in renewables and for the phasing-out of all energy projects in fossil fuels, and it also called for investment in regions with high unemployment and low GDP. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since I believe that the European Investment Bank’s support for SMEs has been of key importance in the most troubled times of the crisis. Nonetheless, the EIB should do more to support our enterprises, mainly by helping to foster investment in higher-risk projects that do not easily qualify for bank financing.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU 2020 strategy sets ambitious targets aimed at smart, sustainable and inclusive growth by boosting competitiveness, job creation and sustainable investment. The EIB provides effective financial instruments that contribute to the implementation of investments in the public domain, with the necessary expertise to implement projects with significant economic added value and measurable social impact. The decline in public and private investment in recent years requires measures aimed at attracting private financing into public investment. I am convinced that the presence of private capital in public investment increases the responsibility for expenditure, and the Juncker Plan will have the capacity to guarantee private investment in the public domain.  I believe that the EIB's investments should take into account the level of development of the regions, so I have expressed myself in favour of this report, because I am convinced that the priority of investment must also take into account the economic and social context of the place where it takes place.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained. The report comments and comments on the EIB's activities, but its premise persists in concealing the fact that the cause of the crisis, in order to emerge from which the EIB is calling for greater input, is the euro and nothing else.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. The European Investment Bank (EIB) is a very important body of the European Union. We need his impulse more than ever. Indeed, the lack of investment in Europe is very worrying. To return to growth, we need to increase investment. That is the objective of the Juncker Plan. In this respect, the role of the European Investment Bank will be essential, particularly with regard to the European Fund for Strategic Investments. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the European Investment Bank's 2013 annual report.  The report stressed that all possible resources from Member States and the EU, including those of the EIB, must be mobilised efficiently and without delay to encourage and incentivise public and private investment, promote competitiveness, restore sustainable and inclusive growth and stimulate the creation of quality employment and infrastructure in line with the Europe 2020 strategy. The considerations of the EIB report are also a good one, which should continue to play the fundamental role of catalyst for financing healthy public and private investment in the long term, but which must not be an alternative to the structural reforms and economic policy geared to sustainable growth and job creation that the Member States must pursue.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report contained several positive elements. In particular, it provided a critique of EU austerity, coupled with a call to put public investment back at the core of economic policy. In addition, it contained a critique of the European Investment Bank’s involvement in corruption cases, failed infrastructure projects and dangerous gas projects. In particular, it called for more investment in renewables and for the phasing-out of all energy projects in fossil fuels, and it also called for investment in regions with high unemployment and low GDP. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The European Investment Bank Annual Report showed us that, in 2013, the EIB focused more than ever on issues pertaining to employment and social affairs. The EUR 9.1 billion spent on promoting skills training and employment opportunities for young people represents a 50% increase on the original spending target. When one considers the staggering youth unemployment Europe is facing, one could argue that this is still not enough. On the other hand, when one takes into consideration the projects that focus on micro-financing and SME support, it is clear that we are on track. Having been shadow rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Annual Report on the European Investment Bank (EIB) as I share the recognition of the important work done by the EIB to support the Union's economy and its fundamental role as a catalyst for medium and long-term investment and as a promoter of social cohesion that can provide assistance to the states most in difficulty. I agree with the suggestions made to the European Investment Bank contained in this document. I support, in particular, the need to mobilise efficiently and without delay those resources that are essential to encourage economic recovery, promote competitiveness and stimulate the creation of quality employment and infrastructure. I also agree with the suggestions made to the EIB regarding the leading role it will take in the new European Fund for Strategic Investments. I regret the continuing difficulty faced by SMEs in accessing credit and welcome the report's insistence on broadening efforts to finance the activities of SMEs, in particular micro-enterprises, which are the backbone of the European economy and which, as such, should be one of the main beneficiaries of investment.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it contains important positive elements, such as the need to strengthen credit support for small and medium-sized enterprises; strengthening the EIE's governance and administrative resources to prevent a repeat of the financial and fiscal scandals it has starred in in the past; to vehicular funds towards job creation, energy efficiency improvement or research and development initiatives. Nevertheless, significant risks remain in the EI's action, especially because of its association with the Juncker Plan (a public guarantee that seems designed to encourage private speculation in large transport or energy projects, as has already happened with the EEST's activity in Castor) or its unre transparent relationship with cohesion and development policies, which will require greater oversight of its activity by Parliament.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The European Investment Bank provides finance and expertise for sound and sustainable investment projects which contribute to furthering EU policy objectives. This analysis deals with its 2013 Annual Report. There is reference to an increase in the Group’s financing activities by 37 %.  However, there is concern at the current situation of economic stalling in the EU, a significant decline in public and private investment and by the staggering 35 % drop in SME lending between 2008 and 2013. The report underlines that such a decline represents a massive hurdle for a sustainable recovery. The report also points out that national projections demonstrate that nearly half of all Member States will not achieve their national targets on education schemes and greenhouse gas reductions by 2020, while employment and poverty reduction trends are even worse. While I voted in favour of this report it is imperative that the EU and Member States acknowledge and act upon the given recommendations.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution notes the European Investment Bank's annual report for 2013. The European Investment Bank, the European Union's armed arm in terms of private and public sector financing, has largely expanded its activities with a 37% increase in its financing activities to the amount of EUR 75.1 billion, in the context of the economic crisis in order to compensate for the weakness of public and private investment. Considering that this institution is one of the key parts of the Juncker plan, since it is expected to contribute up to 16 billion to the recovery of investment in energy and climate, infrastructure, research and innovation and employment, it should be given all the political support necessary in its difficult mission. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the European Investment Bank. It is indeed a step in the right direction, focusing on the link between investment and employment in Europe, as well as on helping SMEs.  I take this opportunity to renew my support for the Commission's initiative on the European Fund for Strategic Investments.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – The 2013 European Investment Bank (EIB) Annual Report is very important as it considers the activities of the EIB as the largest public investor in the European economy and a catalyst for long-term private and public investment. I voted in favour of the report because it had the right focus in the current environment: the focus on SMEs, investments and governance is crucial for sustainable economic growth. The report also includes a strong section on transparency and financial intermediation and it correctly reflects the situation around climate and energy. A less positive element was the excess detail included on some areas that do not belong in the report – for instance, the detailed information around the European Fund for Strategic Investment belongs in the EFSI Regulation, which is still being negotiated in trilogues. Going forward, the report should increasingly consider the EIB’s evolving role in an evolving landscape. The EIB must strengthen its competitive position in the global market and must adapt itself to meet the needs of the market. We shall follow the EIB closely to see if it is executing its role in a less bureaucratic way and more in line with market practice.

name: Andor DELI
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is dealing with difficult economic conditions and rising unemployment, which has serious consequences for our society, especially for young people. Extraordinary times obviously require extraordinary measures and a consistent European response to overcome the crisis. As a bank of the European Union, the EIB must play a key role in financing investment in growth and jobs. It is to be welcomed that the EIB has always responded to the specific needs of the regions most affected by the crisis and, according to its report, intends to continue to do so. In many cases, this bank is the only financier capable to play this role to a significant extent. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I welcome the fact that in 2013 the EIB focused primarily on a countercyclical role and that it acted as a reliable partner in economically reasonable investments both inside and outside the European Union. In agreement with the rapporteur, I believe that investments with their funding can make a real difference to people's lives, whether it is jobs for hundreds of thousands of small businesses making progress in infrastructure investments in the regions most affected by the crisis, or maintaining cutting-edge innovations to help europe maintain its global competitiveness and supporting clean energy, so I supported the constructive proposals contained in the report in the final vote of 30 April 2015.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is dealing with difficult economic conditions and rising unemployment, which has serious consequences for our society, especially for young people. Extraordinary times obviously require extraordinary measures and a consistent European response to overcome the crisis. As a bank of the European Union, the EIB must play a key role in financing investment in growth and jobs.  It is to be welcomed that the EIB has always responded to the specific needs of the regions most affected by the crisis and, according to its report, intends to continue to do so. In many cases, this bank is the only financier capable to play this role to a significant extent. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I welcome the fact that in 2013 the EIB focused primarily on a countercyclical role and that it acted as a reliable partner in economically reasonable investments both inside and outside the European Union. In agreement with the rapporteur, I believe that investments with their funding can make a real difference to people's lives, whether it is jobs for hundreds of thousands of small businesses making progress in infrastructure investments in the regions most affected by the crisis, or maintaining cutting-edge innovations to help europe maintain its global competitiveness and supporting clean energy, so I supported the constructive proposals contained in the report in the final vote of 30 April 2015.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the European Investment Bank's 2013 Annual Report. It raises a number of shortcomings. On the one hand, the EIB has not committed sufficient investment financing for small and medium-sized enterprises. Indeed, this report demonstrates the priority of the European Investment Bank to focus on European projects. It is then legitimate to question the real possibilities of French companies to access these funds. On the other hand, I regret the scale of international funding at a time when the States of the European Union are in great need of it. My abstention therefore means the need for the European Investment Bank to review its priorities and to stop endorsing ill-conceived European projects.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Overall, the annual report of the European Investment Bank (EIB) shows quite positive characteristics, highlighting the fact that strengthening EIB financing instruments should not be a substitute for national economic policy and structural reforms in the Member States or that small and medium-sized enterprises are the backbone of the European economy and should in principle be an investment objective. I also agree with the thesis of greater efficiency, less regulation and more flexibility in the allocation of EIB funds. However, there remain things that are affected in this report that I agree less on – the EIB cannot be responsible for creating a new tax policy, it is entirely national sovereignty. That's why I abstained in the final vote.
