name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because this report clearly demonstrates the scope of the EIB's activities, its objectives, the problems and difficulties it faces and the areas where it should be improved and given greater weight.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is dealing with difficult economic conditions and rising unemployment, which has serious consequences for our society, especially for young people. Extraordinary times obviously require extraordinary measures and a consistent European response to overcome the crisis. As a bank of the European Union, the EIB must play a key role in financing investment in growth and jobs. It is to be welcomed that the EIB has always responded to the specific needs of the regions most affected by the crisis and, according to its report, intends to continue to do so. In many cases, this bank is the only financier capable to play this role to a significant extent. As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I welcome the fact that in 2013 the EIB focused primarily on a countercyclical role and that it acted as a reliable partner in economically reasonable investments both inside and outside the European Union. In agreement with the rapporteur, I believe that investments with their funding can make a real difference to people's lives, whether it is jobs for hundreds of thousands of small businesses making progress in infrastructure investments in the regions most affected by the crisis, or maintaining cutting-edge innovations to help europe maintain its global competitiveness and supporting clean energy, so I supported the constructive proposals contained in the report in the final vote of 30 April 2015.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The EIB's annual report for the financial year 2013 shows a 37% increase in the Group's financing activities to EUR 75.1 billion and the implementation of the EIB capital increase in 2013, highlighting its concern about the current situation of economic stagnation in the EU and, in particular, the significant decrease in public and private investment. SMEs are the backbone of the European economy and, as such, should be one of the main targets for investment. I welcome the increase in support for SMEs in the European Union, which amounted to EUR 21.9 billion, thus allowing access to finance to more than 230 000 SMEs.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: in writing. The European Investment Bank (EI) is a key European institution, particularly in this context of low private investment, and for its role in the Investment Plan for Europe.  However, the EI cannot act under the logic of a private investment bank, which means that its main objective should not be to maintain triple A, but to act as a true development bank, investing in the most depressed areas, providing capital and enhanced technical assistance.  It is also important to monitor and assess more thoroughly the impact of the financed projects, so that we can identify their contribution to the macroeconomic table of the Member States.  I would also like to stress that EI debt issuances are the only example to date of European public debt. It would be very positive if the EEEA issued government debt securities with retail tranches, particularly under the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EIE). Finally, it is important that the culture of greatest risk-taking to be attributed to the EIE impedes the EI, not the other way around.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 We follow this report in a number of respects. The EIB should, yes, pay more attention to SMEs, take into account the geographical distribution of the funds it lends (meeting the needs of the countries most affected by the crisis), pay attention to investments in research and development. We also follow the rapporteur's position when he says that the EIB should have a more transparent management. However, this report should go deeper into criticism of this institution, which is better known for the scandals surrounding its business than for its role in development aid. The EIB is accused of acting opacityly, without satisfactory social and environmental standards and of being involved in controversial projects – such as the Tenke Fungurume mining project in the Democratic Republic of congo (DRC), just one example among many. The EIB is not playing its role as a development bank. In Latin America, more than 90% of EIB funding is granted to subsidiaries of European companies or large multinationals. Within the EU, the EIB is now associated with the huge public-private partnership programme, called the Juncker Plan, and, to that extent, moved away from support for public investment. In the past, we have denounced restrictions on cooperativeaccess to EIB funding. All issues ignored by this report.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Investment Bank spent €9.1 billion in 2013 to promote skills acquisition and job creation for young people. The projects selected and financed by the EIB should offer an opportunity not only to restore jobs and growth, but also to address problems such as climate change, energy independence and growing inequality. Eib financing could make a decisive contribution to job creation and growth. We welcome the support that is being given to SMEs in areas with high unemployment rates, namely that the EIB has increased funding by 50% compared to 2012.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 I do not support the report with a favourable vote despite the fact that there are a number of comments and comments on the EIB's activities. However, there is a complete lack of blame for the real evil in the analysis of the crisis: the euro.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the European Investment Bank and the annual report for 2013. This report clearly demonstrates the scope of the EIB's activities, its objectives, problems and difficulties, without, however, ignoring the areas in need of improvement and greater weight.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the significant decline in public and private investment that severely affected European SMEs, I welcome the fact that the report was adopted in committee by a huge majority. It is indeed necessary to strike a new balance between better evaluation and the best possible investment, and to steer the economy towards a path of sustainable growth and a job-rich recovery. The report puts forward a set of recommendations on the European Investment Bank’s operational methodology, in terms of how the Bank should be ready to play its role in relation to the Investment Package, how investment needs to target more specifically the backbone of the European economy, namely SMEs, and how EIB investment projects should be increasingly aimed towards sustainable energy and climate change, as well as infrastructure investments important for jobs and growth. I also appreciated the fact that there is a lot of emphasis on the need for the EIB to become more transparent and accountable. Considering how these recommendations can have a very positive impact on SMEs and on the European economy in general, I would like to state my support for the adoption of the report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Fidesz-KDNP Group, I welcome the fact that in 2013 the EIB focused primarily on a kind of countercyclical role and that it acted as a reliable partner in economically reasonable investments both inside and outside the European Union. As a bank of the European Union, the EIB must play a key role in financing investment in growth and jobs. It is to be welcomed that the EIB has always responded to the specific needs of the regions most affected by the crisis and, according to its report, intends to continue to do so. In many cases, this bank is the only financier capable to play this role to a significant extent. In agreement with the rapporteur, I believe that investments with their funding can make a real difference to people's lives, whether it is jobs for hundreds of thousands of small businesses making progress in infrastructure investments in the regions most affected by the crisis, or maintaining cutting-edge innovations to help europe maintain its global competitiveness and supporting clean energy, so I supported the constructive proposals contained in the report in the final vote of 30 April 2015.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. In the face of the serious economic crisis suffered by much of the EU States, it is imperative that all possible resources of the Member States and the EU, including those of the EI, be effectively mobilized in order to promote and strengthen public and private investment and boost competitiveness. The EI is an instrument designed to strengthen social cohesion and provide valuable support to Member States. The EI should continue to play its catalyst role in financing long-term public and private secure investments. More efforts should also be made to finance SMEs. We must remember that the EI is called upon to play a decisive role in the financing of the Investment Plan for Europe, with the allocation of EUR 5 billion for the creation of the new European Fund for Strategic Investments. With reference to Spain, the European Parliament approved the report with a clear criticism of the Government for the cost of the failed Castor project, and urged the Commission and the EI to take action to prevent Spanish citizens from having to pay EUR 1.3 billion in compensation.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Especially in times of crisis such as the one we are unfortunately still experiencing, the European Investment Bank proves to be one of the decisive instruments for the lives of millions of European citizens, in particular for employment and growth. The figures speak of an increase in contributions to SMEs, the soul of the European economy, but also of funds directly aimed at young people. The amount of this funding has been increased and we ask that the increases be able to follow in the coming years. We are calling for less bureaucratisation and greater flexibility and simplicity, a 'European bank' that knows how to be the back-up on which citizens know that they can count in times of difficulty.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. With the report that has just been adopted, Parliament is calling on the EIB to make a strategic effort to accompany the implementation of the Commission communication on an investment plan for Europe. With a view to revitalising the EU economy through the mobilisation of EUR 315 billion over the next three years, the EIB is called upon to fulfil fully its mandate as an investment campaigner in Europe. The hope is that this institution will finally become more proactive and act as a driving force for growth, as provided for in its Statute.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, which critically examines the role that the EI has played in financing projects that have been beneficial to a majority, and detrimental to social majorities. In particular, it mentions the Castor project and the compensation approved by the Congress of DEputies to ACS (Florentino Pérez) for cost oversteals arising from technical and business mismanagement, which will make citizens pay, dangerously increasing energy poverty.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported a number of amendments to this report, including Amendment 33 on the failed Castor project. This project, at a cost of EUR 1.35 billion to the taxpayer, was ill thought through, with risk assessments side-lined by the Spanish Government. The European Investment Bank did not carry out sufficient due diligence on the project and the result was a huge waste of taxpayers’ money. I also supported recitals B, which states that the economic and financial crisis, coupled with austerity policies, has seriously undermined economic growth in many Member States, and A, asserting that the EIB is an instrument designed to support social cohesion.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report which critically examines the role that the EI has played in financing projects that have been beneficial to a majority, and detrimental to social majorities. In particular, it mentions the Castor project and the compensation approved by the Congress of DEputies to ACS (Florentino Pérez) for cost oversteals arising from technical and business mismanagement, which will make citizens pay, dangerously increasing energy poverty.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the European Investment Bank’s Annual Report, which has many good recommendations. The EIB has a crucial role in the European economy. The report rightly underlines that investment needs to target more specifically the backbone of the European economy, namely SMEs.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Investment Bank Report for 2013.  The report confirms the role and importance of the EIB on a European and global scale. Eib activities are very important for preserving the stability of the European economy, but I expect all these activities to be strengthened in synergy with the Juncker Fund in the coming years. This can significantly contribute to faster growth of the European economy and job creation.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. I abstained in the vote on the report on the 2013 annual report of the European Investment Bank. It raises a number of shortcomings. On the one hand, the EIB has not committed sufficient investment financing for small and medium-sized enterprises. Indeed, this report demonstrates the priority of the European Investment Bank to focus on European projects. It is then legitimate to question the real possibilities of French companies to access these funds. On the other hand, I regret the scale of international funding at a time when the States of the European Union are in great need of it. My abstention therefore means the need for the European Investment Bank to review its priorities and to stop endorsing ill-conceived European projects.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that the annual report on the European Investment Bank emphasises the importance of access to funding for SMEs, which are the backbone of the European economy. In addition, I welcome the important articles on transparency, especially when dealing with financial intermediaries in third countries. While this report is perhaps too long-winded, it encompasses a number of important priorities which the EIB should use as guidelines in the future.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased to support this report. It rightly stresses that the EIB is not a commercial bank but highlights the important role it plays as catalyst for financing sound public and private long term investment. I am pleased to see emphasis put on SMEs in the report as they are drivers of our economic growth and should be given good access to finance.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report by my colleague Ernest Urtasun on the annual report of the European Investment Bank (EIB). I believe that it should continue to act as a catalyst for public and private funds and to implement prudential banking best practices, thus maintaining its strong capital position.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The report proposes a number of recommendations on the EI's operational methodology, on how the EI can play an important role in incentivising investment in Europe. It also notes the importance of the EI being able to finance SMEs, highlighting the relevance of investments in strategic infrastructures and projects aimed at sustainable energy and in the fight against climate change. Finally, from Spain's point of view, it should be noted that a criticism of the failed Castor project has been included in the report, the first project implemented with those known as "project bonds" which has resulted in multimillion-dollar compensation by the Spanish Treasury to the awarding company. In accordance with these considerations, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it contains important positive elements, such as the need to strengthen credit support for small and medium-sized enterprises; strengthening the EIE's governance and administrative resources to prevent a repeat of the financial and fiscal scandals it has starred in in the past; to vehicular funds towards job creation, energy efficiency improvement or research and development initiatives. Nevertheless, significant risks remain in the EI's action, especially because of its association with the Juncker Plan (a public guarantee that seems designed to encourage private speculation in large transport or energy projects, as has already happened with the EEST's activity in Castor) or its unre transparent relationship with cohesion and development policies, which will require greater oversight of its activity by Parliament.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The EI is not a commercial bank and should continue to play its essential role as a catalyst to finance long-term public and private secure investments, while continuing to apply banking prudential best practices in order to maintain its strong position in terms of capital, with the consequent positive implications for borrowing conditions. I voted in favour of this proposal calling on the EI TO commit, together with Parliaments, Governments and the social partners, to a structured communication process in order to periodically identify specific job creation initiatives to increase European competitiveness sustainably, as well as to the contribution to growth and employment , and in particular youth employment.

name: Petr MACH
text: Writing. \u2012 Competitiveness is not created by a greater redistribution of state money. On the contrary, the more taxpayers' money is collected and redistributed, the more competitiveness of the states concerned and of Europe as a whole decreases. The solution to the crisis is to free up the environment for entrepreneurship and the employment of people, not more subsidies and state investment.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: in writing. "U2012 My vote in favour of a critical report with the European Investment Bank, even after the 'brushing' of edges typical of parliamentary logic. Without such 'brushing', the question would be whether the EI fulfils its founding mission when, on the basis of not taking risks, it does not adequately evaluate the projects and ends up giving money to those who do not need it or to whom it assumes the possible losses in the event of failure. We fear that the Beaver project will not be the exception, but the EI rule.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Investment Bank's 2013 annual report on the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech of 30 April 2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the 2013 European Investment Bank Annual Report. The report pays significant attention to the Commission proposal to establish the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), as the EIB is one of the decisive players in ensuring its efficiency. The success of the EFSI is of paramount importance for sustainable growth and job creation in Europe. Therefore, it is important that the EIB should continue to play the important role of catalyst for financing sound public and private long-term investments, while carrying on with implementing best prudential banking practices in order to maintain its very strong capital position. The report provides relevant input in that direction.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic and financial crisis, exacerbated by policies based on the principle of austerity, has significantly undermined economic growth in many Member States of the European Union. In this context, the European Investment Bank, whose mandate is to ensure cohesion and adequate assistance to the Member States most affected by the crisis, can play an important role.  I voted in favour of the Urtasun report, as I share the view that the financing instruments implemented by the EIB are not an alternative to structural reforms geared to sustainable growth and job creation.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. \u2012 This report presents very positive elements.  It draws attention to the disastrous consequences of the economic crisis, as well as the implementation of austerity measures.  It stresses that a new balance needs to be struck between better valuation and the best possible investment, as well as moving the economy to sustainable growth and job-creating recovery. It regrets that ppps with disabilities have become an expensive public financing system for the private sector, generating public debt. It regrets that the EIB has financed the 'Passante di Mestre' motorway section and the Castor project. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. The EIB is an opaque institution. It funds projects that are unrelated to the needs needed to ensure the ecological transition and without social criteria. This naïve report proposes to us to approve its activity report by adding some criticisms. Thus, the report considers that the European Commission's investment plan "will encourage and facilitate access to finance in the Member States" while admitting that "the guarantees that the Commission plans to put in place for the EFSI are not fuelled by fresh money, but by resources that have been reallocated". Similarly, the text provides "cautious" support for the development of public-private partnerships (PPPs). I vote against this hypocritical text.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it notes that the projects selected by the European Investment Bank should have a high innovation-based potential and should meet all the necessary criteria. It also stresses the need to take into account the employment potential of the projects selected in those EU countries worst affected by mass unemployment.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the European Investment Bank Annual Report 2013, which puts forward a set of recommendations on the EIB’s operational methodology, in terms of how the EIB should be ready to play its role under the Investment Package, how investment needs to target more specifically the backbone of the European economy, namely SMEs, and how EIB investment projects need to be aimed increasingly towards sustainable energy and climate as well as infrastructure investments important for jobs and growth. Finally there is a lot of emphasis on the EIB becoming more transparent and accountable.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: In writing. The EIB's action should be clarified, and loans to projects outside the European Union are better regulated.  Too often, the EIB funds projects that could be financed by the private sector, in particular with the aim of maintaining its rating and being able to finance itself cheaply.  It must maintain its vocation, which is to correct imbalances.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. The debate on the EIB shows us all the political and economic schizophrenia of the Union. On the one hand, the annual activity report rightly deplores a 27% collapse in private and public investment since 2009. On the other hand, the European institutions, report after report, are constantly advocating a policy of austerity, in the name of the euro, the sacred cow of Brussels, a policy which is well known that it kills investment and hinders the financing of SMEs.  To be effective, the EIB must act within a completely re-founded economic framework where the Union and its policies no longer have a place. There will be no sustainable investment if the Union persists in a policy that has deindustrialized the continent and demoralized entrepreneurs. Moreover, the EIB's investment allocation system seems to us to be very perfect, as it leaves almost no room for manoeuvre for the Member States, which are best able to determine the relevance of the projects. For example, the Juncker plan will retain only the most profitable projects, to the benefit of a few large metropolises and towns and at the expense of rurality and medium-sized cities.  I have decided to abstain.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the European Investment Bank’s Annual Report because the EIB performs a crucial role in the European economy.  In 2013, the EIB invested EUR 5.8 bn in the UK – the largest annual investment ever, and nearly 10% of its total European investments.  The role of the EIB is only going to become more important as the EUR 315 bn European Fund for Strategic Investment is implemented and the EIB selects which projects will benefit from the fund.  So it is right that this report focuses on areas where the EIB could improve – providing more help for SMEs, increasing its transparency and accountability, and ensuring that it invests in projects that deliver strong social and environmental returns.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the 2013 annual report of the European Investment Bank, which plays a key role in supporting public and private investment by Member States and the EU, but also in the implementation of the 315 billion euro Juncker Investment Plan. In the difficult economic context we are experiencing, the EIB's involvement helps to maintain social cohesion by stimulating job creation and infrastructure creation.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 We wish to highlight the valuable role played by the EIB in supporting social cohesion in the EU. We call for its resources to be mobilised in order to encourage and encourage public and private investment, promote competitiveness, restore sustainable and inclusive growth and stimulate the creation of quality employment in line with the Europe 2020 strategy.  The EIB should continue to act as a catalyst for financing long-term public and private investment, with consequent positive effects on lending conditions. We expect the investment plan promoted by Juncker to facilitate access to finance in Member States and regions with high levels of unemployment and a GDP per capita below the EU average, bearing in mind in this regard that it is essential for the EIB to cooperate with European funds so as to enable productive public investment and key infrastructure projects to be carried out.  We expect priority to be given to projects with clear European added value, in accordance with the principle of additionality, and a positive cost-benefit analysis. We stress the importance of implementing projects that could have the greatest impact in terms of job creation, higher-risk projects that could not be financed otherwise.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this resolution because it underlines the need to implement much-needed and even very urgent measures with regard to the future of the European Investment Bank. More specifically, 'the Commission's investment plan is expected to encourage and facilitate access to finance for Member States and regions with high levels of unemployment and GDP per capita below the EU average'. The resolution recalls that 'it is essential for the EIB to cooperate with European funds, in particular in these Member States and regions, so that productive public investments and key infrastructure projects can be made'. The resolution also considers that priority should be given to projects with European added value and positive cost-benefit analysis.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. The European Investment Bank's 2013 annual report reports the 37% increase in EIB financing activities, the decline in public and private investment by 18%, including a 35% decrease in borrowing from SMEs over the 2007-2013 period. The report suggests the orientation of investments towards activities with European added value, and on the potential for job creation especially in countries with the highest unemployment rates, as well as in research and social affairs, and suggests improving governance and transparency of investment. I voted for this report, which I think is a step in the right direction and would correct some errors in the EIB's investment strategy.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The resolution takes note of the 2013 report of the European Investment Bank, which shows that the group's financial activities have increased by 37% and that eib capital was increased in 2013. At the same time, there is a worrying economic stagnation in the EU and a significant reduction in public and private investment. The resolution calls for improvements and facilitation of access to money in Member States and regions with high unemployment and gdp per capita below the EU average. It also calls, inter alia, on the EIB to cooperate more closely with national banks.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: in writing. The annual report on the European Investment Bank highlights the importance of this institution and its decisive role in facilitating access to finance for European companies, as well as the need for an increase for SMEs. From UPyD we call for an urgent review of the rules on project evaluation and control mechanisms so that failures as sound as that of the Beaver project do not happen again. We also call on the European Commission to investigate the aid granted by the Spanish Government to the Beaver project.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that all possible resources from Member States and the EU, including those of the EIB, must be mobilised efficiently and without delay to encourage and encourage public and private investment, promote competitiveness, restore sustainable and inclusive growth and stimulate the creation of quality employment and infrastructure in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, and that the EIB is an instrument designed to support social cohesion and is able to provide a effective assistance to Member States in difficulty in the current critical social and economic situation that needs to be addressed; Given that the EIB is not a commercial bank and should continue to play the key role of catalyst for financing healthy public and private investment in the long term, while continuing to apply prudential banking best practices in order to safeguard its very strong capital position, with consequent positive effects on lending conditions, I would therefore vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ I am concerned about a significant 18% drop in public and private investment below 2007 levels – and a staggering 35% drop in lending to SMEs between 2008 and 2013, the EIB has been invited to play a key role in financing the Investment Plan for Europe by obliging €5 billion to establish a new European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). The European Commission's investment plan should boost, facilitate and facilitate access to finance in Member States and regions with high levels of unemployment and GDP per capita below the EU average. It is therefore important to prioritise projects with European added value and positive cost-benefit analyses with significant innovation potential.  I am committed to supporting projects that could have maximum impact in terms of job creation, especially those that are in line with sustainable development frameworks. In particular, I consider it important to provide funding for agricultural projects and those aimed at securing communal, social and social infrastructure in rural areas.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: In writing. The report proposes that priority be given to projects with European added value. However, many high value-added investments have a national, not a European, dimension. This prioritization criterion will once again make it difficult for SMEs and local authorities to access EIB funding. In addition, the financing of projects domiciled in third countries in the European Union is a problem in times of scarcity of financing instruments for the real economy. In 2013, the EIB financed EUR 8 billion of projects domiciled in third countries. The non-EU EIB financing share should be redirected to SMEs in the internal market. Finally, the geographical distribution of funding provided by the EIB reveals significant differences in lending to individual Member States. In 2013, France received 276 million euros in loans compared to 537 million for Germany and 2.3 billion euros for Italy. These distribution issues raise questions about the transparency of procedures and the criteria chosen by the EIB's Governance Committee. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ All possible funds from Member States and the EU, including EIB funds, needs to be effectively mobilised without delay to foster and improve public and private investment, increase competitiveness, restore sustainable and inclusive economic growth and foster job and infrastructure creation, in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, taking into account that the EIB is an instrument designed to support social cohesion and is able to provide valuable assistance to Member States facing difficulties in a critical social and economic situation we're facing.  The EIB is not a commercial bank and should continue to play a key catalyst role for financing reasonable public and private long-term investment, but also continue to implement best prudential banking practices to maintain a very stable state of its capital, which consequently has a positive impact on lending conditions. The EIB should play an important role in financing the Investment Plan for Europe by allocating EUR 5 billion to establish a new European Fund for Strategic Investments, so I join calls on the Council, the Commission and the EIB Board of Governors to properly assess whether the new tasks assigned to the EIB under this plan are in line with EIB funds. When allocating funds from the new European Fund for Strategic Investments, countries most affected by the financial crisis should be prioritised.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The EIB has a key role to play in supporting economic growth and competitiveness. That is why I think it is right that the EIB's activities should follow the EU's key medium- and long-term priorities. The key objectives for the EU of job creation, the drive for competitiveness, research and development, support for SMEs, the financing of strategic infrastructure and the efficient use of resources must be fully supported and strengthened. EIB support for projects of various kinds in the EU is crucial to boosting the economy, and I am pleased that the EIB has increased its lending capacity compared to the past. In the light of this, I hope that the EIB will be able to find and use additional sources of finance to fuel economic recovery and growth.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. MEPs adopted the European Investment Bank's annual report for the 2013 financial year. I have spoken in favour of this report. However, I deplore the dramatic decline in lending to SMEs and stress the importance in the future of providing more support to SMEs to encourage investment in Europe, and indeed to stimulate the recovery of growth.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution concerns the European Parliament's 2013 Annual Report on the European Investment Bank (EIB). The EIB is not a commercial bank and should continue to play the key role of a catalyst for sound public and private financing investments for long-term investments, and should also ensure the effective implementation of best banking practices in prudential matters in order to maintain its strong capital position, with subsequent positive impacts on lending conditions. Thus, according to the Report, efforts should be made to extend joint interventions for the financing of SMEs or sustainable, tangible or intangible infrastructure, recognising that one of the reasons for the drop in investment and credit is the loss of competitiveness of member states' economies. Therefore, it is to welcome the establishment of a working group, led by the Commission and the EIB, as well as legislative proposals on the establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), the objective of which is to facilitate access to finance from Member States and regions with high levels of unemployment and with a GDP per capita below the EU average. I voted in favour.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the increase in EES financing activities by 37%, but also concern about economic stagnation in the EU and, in particular, the significant decline in public and private investment and the dizzying 35% fall in credit to SMEs between 2008 and 2013 , which drags economic recovery, job creation and reducing inequality and poverty. The report contains recommendations on how the EI can play a key role in incentivising investment in Europe. Thus, it points out that the european Fund for Strategic Investments prioritizes the financing of projects with European value-added, with positive cost-benefit analyses and that they have a maximum impact on job creation. It also urges the EEB to analyse the decline in funding for SMEs and to continue to increase its lending capacities for SMEs and innovative start-ups. It also regrets the E BLESSED and Commission's poor risk assessment in the Beaver project and urges both to take steps to prevent Spanish citizens from having to pay EUR 1.3 billion for this failed project. Finally, greater transparency is demanded.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which considers that all possible resources of member states and the European Union, including those of the EIB, must be effectively mobilised without delay to support public and private investment, boost competitiveness, restore sustainable and inclusive economic growth and promote the creation of quality jobs and infrastructure, , in line with the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy and taking into account the fact that the EIB has a mission to support social cohesion and is able to provide significant support to Member States facing difficulties in the difficult socio-economic context we are currently experiencing.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament issues an annual own-initiative report on the annual report of the European Investment Bank, whose essential function is to serve as a catalyst for the financing of long-term public and private investments (contributing, for example, with EUR 5 billion to the creation of the new European Fund for Strategic Investments). On this exhaustive and well-detailed report which I voted in favour of, I would just like to highlight a few ideas. From the outset, 2013 was a year in which there was an increase in its funding activity and a great deal of support given predominantly to European SMEs that doubled that year. It should also be recalled that much of the Bank's work has been channelled to member states hit hardest by the crisis, providing important aid to Member States, especially those facing economic and financial difficulties. I would like to stress the importance of the EIB following the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and also stressing that the European Fund for Strategic Investments should take due account of the overall objectives of territorial, social and economic cohesion policy, as well as sustainability and energy efficiency.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Investment Bank's 2013 annual report has given ample space, despite the fact that reference is made to 2013 activity, to the EIB's role in the EFSI (European Investment Fund or Junker Plan). In particular, the need to facilitate access to credit was noted, especially in regions with high unemployment or low per capita income and for SMEs. The report as a whole therefore draws attention to the eib's role as a catalyst for public and private funds and will continue to play. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report which critically examines the role that the EI has played in financing projects that have been beneficial to a majority, and detrimental to social majorities. In particular, it mentions the Castor project and the compensation approved by the Congress of DEputies to ACS (Florentino Pérez) for cost oversteals arising from technical and business mismanagement, which will make citizens pay, dangerously increasing energy poverty.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. ‒ Despite now being directly involved in the European Fund for Strategic Investments, the European Investment Bank, under its statute, has a limited horizon for its investment initiatives, which inhibits it from taking the initiative in launching projects rated below AAA. The instruments that can assume this role on a European basis backed by a network of national institutions are deficient. The time has come for an investment bank, funded at both European and national levels, that will be enabled to mobilise risk capital for public and private projects – especially at the cutting edge of technology, with a significant risk component – for start-ups in national economies by SMEs, inventors and established corporations. Considerations of state aid should not be allowed, in this context, to restrict the operations of such a ‘merchant’ banking system. Such a system is increasingly required in Europe, beyond the horizons of the EFSI and the EIB, to stimulate entrepreneurship and new productive activity, such as in sustainable energy project: climate-related as well as infrastructure investments are important for jobs and growth. There should be no reservations about public money assuming its part of risk and then of return, as is happening in other segments of the globalised economy.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it contains important positive elements, such as the need to strengthen credit support for small and medium-sized enterprises; strengthening the EIE's governance and administrative resources to prevent a repeat of the financial and fiscal scandals it has starred in in the past; to vehicular funds towards job creation, energy efficiency improvement or research and development initiatives. Nevertheless, significant risks remain in the EI's action, especially because of its association with the Juncker Plan (a public guarantee that seems designed to encourage private speculation in large transport or energy projects, as has already happened with the EEST's activity in Castor) or its unre transparent relationship with cohesion and development policies, which will require greater oversight of its activity by Parliament.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 It is important to stabilise the role of EIB operations to support robust projects across the EU and beyond as part of an increased lending capacity of up to EUR 75 billion, an increase of 37% compared to 2012. In addition, it is important to identify, acquire and use additional sources of funding to stimulate recovery and growth. Priority should be given, within the framework of eib lending activities, to projects with clear results and a clear impact on economic growth. Economic recovery and employment must continue to be a fundamental guiding principle, as must anticipating post-crisis challenges by increasing support for Europe's re-industrialisation projects.  A regular structured dialogue between the President of the EIB and the European Parliament should be sought to ensure increased parliamentary oversight of eib activities and to strengthen cooperation and coordination between the two institutions. We also stress the need for an individual approach by the European Investment Bank, which should adapt financial solutions to the specific needs of the Member States.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in support of the European Investment Bank’s 2013 Annual Report. The economic and financial crisis, coupled with austerity policies, has seriously undermined economic growth in many Member States, leading to rapidly worsening social conditions, steadily growing inequalities and imbalances between European regions, and failure to achieve the objective of social cohesion and real convergence, thereby destabilising European integration and democracy.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: Written. ‒ I supported the 2013 Annual Report report of the European Investment Bank.  In particular, I would like to highlight the many untapped opportunities for SMEs (SMEs) across the European Union referenced by the report. It is redundant to mention the fact that the EU is in a time of economic crisis, but it should still be insisted that small and medium-sized enterprises are the path to economic recovery.  Despite these two facts, the lack of credit for SMEs in some Member States is the main cause of the slow economic recovery. The five-year period from 2008 to 2013 saw a 35 per cent drop in SME loans, an obstacle to the Union's economic progress, but also an obstacle to achieving Europe's 2020 targets.  The current European support for SMEs is €21.9 billion, allowing more than 230,000 SMEs to be financed. I would also like to point out that the European Investment Bank should certainly focus its attention on investments that will enable ambitious climate goals to be achieved as much as possible. In this sense, I would certainly point out that this is the right opportunity for Croatia, which has a natural predisposition to investments in environmentally sustainable projects.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – I consider the European Investment Bank to be a flexible and efficient source of financing for eu Member States' projects. I am glad that the EIB also plays an active role in financing long-term investment projects in Slovakia. I would like to take this opportunity to thank the representatives of the EIB for ensuring sustainable growth and employment, thanks to its loans, which have been allocated to Slovakia since 1992. It is true, and this has to be said openly, that, despite all the positives, the EIB failed to fulfil all the required tasks in 2013. In my speech, I would like to refer in particular to the financing of small and medium-sized enterprises, which fell by up to 35% in 2008-2013, to the disparity in lending to individual countries, to low transparency and, in particular, to a significant decrease in public and private investment. On the contrary, I appreciate that in 2013 the EIB spent EUR 9.1 billion to promote skills acquisition and job creation for young people, a capital increase of EUR 10 billion in 2013 and a high quality of EIB assets. At the same time, I expect that the measures put forward in the resolution will ensure a real shift by the EIB towards meeting the objectives of the EU 2020 strategy.

name: Bart STAES
text: Written. I have very much approved Mr Urtasun's report. Although the EIB has already made efforts to improve its operation, I remain concerned about the functioning of the bank, including the lack of transparency and accountability. Given the important role that the EIB will play in the development of the Juncker Plan, these shortcomings need to be addressed as a matter of urgency. The report we have adopted today is rightly concerned about some of the projects receiving support from the EIB, both in terms of their added value to the economy and in terms of environmental sustainability. Instead of investing in controversial fossil fuel projects (such as the Castor gas storage plant in Catalonia) or road construction (such as the "Passante di Mestre" motorway in Italy, where there was a suspicion of mafia interference), the EIB should go all out to support small-scale renewable and energy-efficient projects, and stop financing non-renewable forms of energy. We also call for the European Fund for Strategic Investment (EFSI), in which the EIB will play an important role, to invest in those areas where employment benefits are greatest, taking into account strict social and environmental standards.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The creation of new jobs and economic growth are the main objectives of the ambitious Investment Plan for Europe. It is important to mobilise private and public investment and the creation of a European Fund for Strategic Investments is intended to help this. In this respect, I stress the important role of the European Investment Bank in creating this fund. I call for priority areas to be taken into account in investment projects, namely energy, the digital single market and the focus of projects on small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒ The economic and financial crisis, coupled with austerity policies, have seriously undermined the economic growth of many Member States, leading to rapid deterioration of social conditions, persistent growth of inequalities and imbalances between European regions and failure to achieve the objective of social cohesion and genuine convergence.  I call on the Commission and the EIB to work together to include investments with a clear societal benefit, including increasing the level of employment, to encourage measures to reduce unemployment through lending, focusing in particular on creating employment opportunities for young people and supporting public and productive investments and necessary infrastructure projects, especially in Member States with high unemployment and GDP that is below average.  I welcome the launch of the Growth Finance Initiative (GFI) procedures and recall the importance of providing adequate funding for research and innovation projects and innovative start-ups, and therefore support the report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the European Investment Bank’s Annual Report because the EIB performs a crucial role in the European economy. In 2013, the EIB invested EUR 5.8 billion in the UK – the largest annual investment ever, and nearly 10% of its total European investments. The role of the EIB is only going to become more important as the EUR 315 billion European Fund for Strategic Investments is implemented and the EIB selects which projects will benefit. So it is right that this report focuses on areas where the EIB could improve – providing more help for SMEs, increasing its transparency and accountability, and ensuring that it invests in projects that deliver strong social and environmental returns.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the adoption of this report as I fundamentally disagree with many of its provisions. This report calls on the European Investment Bank in various ways to redistribute, with the aim of once again promoting growth and employment, and possibly, paradoxically, strengthening competitiveness. As if that were not enough, the report also calls, for example, for priority to be given to projects with 'European added value', and virtually any redistribution can be justified with such abstract objectives.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Some of the points in our report are in agreement. It is important to refer to the contradiction between the increase in the capital of the BANK on the one hand, and the reduction of its investments in the EU on the other. An equally important point is that the M START is being asked to give more weight to public and productive investment. Finally, the report expresses Parliament's concern that the new project financing bonds plan will reduce the cost of private investment rather than promote public interest investments. Unfortunately, however, the EPP has passed amendments with the help of the Liberals, who find us strongly opposed. Such examples are the amendments to avoid scandals financed with the help of the MIP, but also the elimination of part of the report that criticised the socialisation of debts and the privatisation of profits in various major investments of the MIP, such as in the case of Castor. For these reasons we have observed abstention

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This report clearly demonstrates the scope of the EIB's activities, its objectives, the problems and difficulties it faces and the areas where it should be improved and given greater weight.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the 2013 Annual Report of the European Investment Bank. Nevertheless, I would like to draw attention to what is rightly mentioned in the report itself, namely that we must bear in mind the importance of supporting SMEs, the pursuit of innovation and sustainability. However, the primary objective of investment must be to create quality jobs. The projects supported should have a greater impact on job creation, which can be really useful if it means quality jobs where a well-skilled workforce is needed. Otherwise, there will be no one to expect from the creation of new SMEs and innovative start-ups. In order not to lose more generations, the EIB must invest in measures to create sustainable jobs for the younger generation, in addition to the YOUTH Employment Initiative, and this must be edibly eded out with the appropriate education/training systems, which are clearly lacking in some Member States. Vice-President Katainen's commitment to increase the EIB's potential in the field of youth employment and education is to be welcomed. We look forward to reporting on the results in the next annual report. However, we cannot rely solely on the Commission and the EIB in this area, the responsibility of the Member States is indisputable. The EIB's activities are not a substitute for economic policy and structural reforms in the Member States aimed at creating jobs.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. On the advice of the experts in my political group, I voted in favour of the text. However, improving the EIB's financial instruments is not a substitute for national economic and structural policy reforms to promote sustainable growth and job creation.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Access to funding for SMEs is essential for the European economy and this is clearly underlined in this annual report. I also welcome the emphasis on the need for transparency. For these reasons, I supported and voted in favour of this report on the European Investment Bank.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report which critically examines the role that the EI has played in financing projects that have been beneficial to a majority, and detrimental to social majorities. In particular, it mentions the Castor project and the compensation approved by the Congress of DEputies to ACS (Florentino Pérez) for cost oversteals arising from technical and business mismanagement, which will make citizens pay, dangerously increasing energy poverty.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the resolution on the annual report of the European Investment Bank, in particular because of the significant role of the EIB in the current economic context, through the European Fund for Strategic Investments. In this regard, I consider it necessary to concentrate efforts and resources to improve access to finance for the EU Member States most affected by unemployment and reduced economic growth. Especially in countries that have recently joined the Union, boosting public investment in sustainable infrastructure projects can help create new jobs. Cooperation between the EIB, national banks and the European Commission must therefore, as a matter of priority, aim at reducing development gaps between Union states – as a factor for cohesion and boosting economic competitiveness. At the same time, I believe that particular attention should be paid to small and medium-sized enterprises, unfortunately affected by the reduction of appropriations by more than a third between 2008 and 2013. Facilitating SMEs' access to finance on favourable terms and public tenders can help to reduce unemployment, including among young people – the age group most affected by the crisis.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report which critically examines the role that the EI has played in financing projects that have been beneficial to a majority, and detrimental to social majorities. In particular, it mentions the Castor project and the compensation approved by the Congress of DEputies to ACS (Florentino Pérez) for cost oversteals arising from technical and business mismanagement, which will make citizens pay, dangerously increasing energy poverty.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. The Urtasun resolution on the 2013 EIB report blatantly rejects the work of the European institution on charges of lack of transparency and insufficient control in the projects financed, finally bringing out at institutional level the very serious critical issues linked to the EIB's work. The adoption of Parliament by a large majority is an important success for all those who for years have been denouncing the high risks of corruption and fraud which, often due to the inertia of the institutions, hide behind the financing of major projects.  My final vote was determined above all by the inclusion of an explicit reference, very critical and crucial for us, to the Passante di Mestre, in Veneto, a project financed despite the corruption and fraud scandal, as well as to the disastrous Castor project in Spain. It was also crucial for us to include in the text the request to block the project bond for the Passer-by, which the EIB announced to issue by the summer, and to adopt in general a policy of zero tolerance towards projects affected by fraud, corruption and mafia infiltration. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the resolution, hoping that it will trigger a strong reaction from the EIB and the other European institutions to ensure that at least projects financed by Europe are managed transparently and cleanly.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because I believe it contains important positive elements, such as the need to strengthen credit support for small and medium-sized enterprises; strengthening the EIE's governance and administrative resources to prevent a repeat of the financial and fiscal scandals it has starred in in the past; to vehicular funds towards job creation, energy efficiency improvement or research and development initiatives. Nevertheless, significant risks remain in the EI's action, especially because of its association with the Juncker Plan (a public guarantee that seems designed to encourage private speculation in large transport or energy projects, as has already happened with the EEST's activity in Castor) or its unre transparent relationship with cohesion and development policies, which will require greater oversight of its activity by Parliament.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. The European Investment Bank (EIB) is a European financial institution that funds infrastructure, energy, research and innovation projects in Europe and third countries. The European Parliament's annual report on the EIB's activities in 2013 calls for support for public and private investment and contains some criticism of the investment plan launched by the Juncker Commission in July 2014, including the fact that part of the funding allocated is taken from other projects. So it's a pure illusionist game! In addition, the report deplores the fact that half of the Member States will not meet their national targets for education and greenhouse gas reduction by 2020. And it's worse when it comes to employment and poverty. Austerity policies are being questioned in terms of their effects on economic growth, the sharp deterioration of social conditions, the increase in imbalances between European regions and their democratic consequences. I could therefore only vote in favour of such a report, even if the most likely is that it has no effect on the policies conducted.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. We follow this report on a number of aspects that point to the EIB devoting more attention to SMEs, paying more attention to the geographical distribution of funds it lends or devoting attention to R&D investments. However, this report should go deeper into criticising this institution which is better known for the scandals involving its business esand than for its role in development aid. Among the known criticisms, the EIB is accused of acting opacity, without satisfactory social and environmental standards and of being involved in controversial projects. The Tenke Fungurume mining project in the Democratic Republic of congo (DRC) is just one example among many. The EIB is not playing its role as a development bank. In Latin America, more than 90% of EIB funding is granted to subsidiaries of European companies or large multinationals. Within the EU, the EIB is bound by European standards. But in the South it is not subject to any specific regulation: practices refer to a multitude of vague principles, without operational procedures, or the application of EU law in accordance with 'local conditions'. This is a point we would like to see dealt with properly.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I rejected the report on the annual report of the European Investment Bank. Among other things, it indicates that Parliament welcomes the ECB's willingness to buy bonds issued by the EIB and the EFSI as part of its objective of expanding its balance sheet. I am against any bond purchase by the European Central Bank. In doing so, it is illegally exceeding its mandate. Parliament must not welcome this, because it makes itself an accomplice.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the European Investment Bank’s Annual Report because the EIB performs a crucial role in the European economy. In 2013, the EIB invested EUR 5.8 billion in the UK – the largest annual investment ever, and nearly 10% of its total European investments. The role of the EIB is only going to become more important as the EUR 315 billion European Fund for Strategic Investments is implemented and the EIB selects which projects will benefit. So it is right that this report focuses on areas where the EIB could improve – providing more help for SMEs, increasing its transparency and accountability, and ensuring that it invests in projects that deliver strong social and environmental returns.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 Again this year, the European Parliament presented an own-initiative report analysing aspects of the activities of the EIB, the European Investment Bank.  The text we have adopted today contains many critical points, which I share, such as the condemnation of the management of the Castor project in Spain and the Passante di Mestre in Italy. I regret the fact that the EIB financed the section of motorway known as the Passante di Mestre, after the Italian authorities had publicly announced the arrest of the chief executive of the main subcontractor for tax fraud. I therefore believe that the EIB must ensure that the 'zero tolerance' policy towards fraud is implemented when it examines the use of bond loans for project financing. I am therefore pleased that these points have been included in the report which I supported.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. We follow this report on a number of aspects that point to the EIB devoting more attention to SMEs, paying more attention to the geographical distribution of the funds it lends or of paying attention to R&D investments. However, this report should go deeper into criticism of this institution which is better known for the scandals involving its business es and for its role in development aid and cohesion. Among the known criticisms, the EIB is accused of acting opacity, without satisfactory social and environmental standards and of being involved in controversial projects. In Latin America, more than 90% of EIB funding is granted to subsidiaries of European companies or large multinationals. We abstained.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am sorry to speak in a virtually deserted Chamber, perhaps we should as Members take on a different costume and a greater presence during explanations of vote. I come now to my explanation of vote. Eni, an Italian company, has been accused of land grabbing and exploitation for years. From research carried out by ActionAid, FAO and Grain, he appeared among the Italian companies involved in large projects to rent agricultural land, 180 000 hectares in the Democratic Republic of congo intended for the cultivation of oil palms to be used for biofuel. These plantations cause the forest to shrink and local farmers see their land destroyed. In 2011, the chairman of another multinational, Nestlé, Peter Brabeck, said he was potentially not opposed to the creation of a water exchange. These two cases have one thing in common: these two multinationals are both partners of Expo 2015, for these reasons, Madam President, I voted against the Expo resolution, approved today, and for these reasons I will be present tomorrow at the 'May Day No Expo' demonstration, against precarious work, against the exploitation of the planet. Now and always: May Day.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, seo an óráid dheireanach domsa faoi na hábhair seo inniu.  I welcome and, obviously, voted in favour of these resolutions and actually I am very pleased to have voted with my Group on all votes today – particularly on this one. It does highlight two very important, almost contradictory elements in relation to food. Firstly, malnutrition and people dying of poverty around the world; and then, on the other hand, the growth in obesity from people often not taking enough exercise and eating too much food. So putting an emphasis on this, particularly proper agricultural practices, and on the target of trying to eliminate poverty is something we should certainly propose and support; and I think we all do. Therefore, I think there is an opportunity for us to identify where we can be effective and tackle the two problems on either end of the spectrum: obesity and malnutrition.

name: Marco AFFRONTE
text: in writing. \u2012 "A year ago the word to associate with the Expo was scandal. I thank those who have managed to turn this event into an opportunity during this period," Matteo Renzi said on February 7. Do you know how to define the mental process of those who forget problems as they never existed? Removal. He even admitted: "We deleted the word scandal." Then comes incalza's arrest, and the doubts related also to the Palazzo Italia of the Expo. Too early to remove the "Expo-Scandal" association. I don't have another term to define an Expo that should teach the world proper nutrition, and instead it has among its main sponsors Coca-Cola and McDonald's, two gigantic brands that represent junk food in the world, not healthy eating. I have no other term for defining a fair that should encourage the mixing of different thoughts, but that instead will silence and alienate the discordant voices, because the decision taken by the government is that "no bad figures can be made, so we are also ready for regulatory measures". I have no other term than scandal for an Expo that is supposed to 'feed the planet' and instead has eaten 1 000 hectares of agricultural land. He devoured a huge portion of land from which food was obtained, killing it with concrete.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution comes from an oral question to the European Commission posed on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture. The events concern the holding of the 2015 Expo in Milan under the title "Feed the planet, energy for life". The Resolution focuses on different aspects of this Expo related to the idea of improving food production and distribution, tacking food waste and promoting new approaches to meet the challenge of malnutrition.  But it does not include such important issues as the human right to water, food sovereignty or the right to land. That is why I voted against it, because I cannot hold events in which many multinationals are organizing and launching, such as the Barilla Foundation or Nestlé, which, far from fighting to 'feed the planet', are rather struggling to fuel their economic benefits. Thus, the Expo is presented as the gateway of food multinationals, but only those that have control of food worldwide, which produce globalized junk food simultaneously creating millions of hungry and millions of obese people.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution hides the hypocrisy of the EU's food and agricultural policy authorities behind good intentions. It aims to promote "a reliable and sustainable agricultural sector throughout the UNION, a prosperous and diversified rural economy, a clean environment, as well as family farms supported by a dynamic, fairer, more sustainable and properly financed common agricultural policy." In particular, there is a call for essential food security. However, "small-scale" farming models cannot be imposed in France or the United States, where 48 million people are struggling to feed themselves and receiving food aid. Food sovereignty is essential for food security and the models advocated in this resolution do not participate. Moreover, these very good intentions are far out of step with the actual policy pursued by the Union. So I voted against it.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ The report uses the Milan Expo as the vehicle to detail a ‘wishlist’ which will extend EU and Commission activity at taxpayers’ expense.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because this event will be an opportunity to nurture the debates necessary for the sustainability of our planet.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the 2015 world exhibition in Milan: "Feed the planet. The energy of life." This event can seriously stimulate the debate on improving food production and distribution, tackling food waste, promoting and developing existing positive approaches to address food shortages and malnutrition and nutrition, and finding a balance between the available and the resources consumed. I agree that a strong and sustainable agricultural sector across the EU, a thriving and diversified rural economy, a clean environment and family farms are of particular importance in order to address the problem of food security. I support the calls for the Commission and the Member States to use the exhibition to establish commitments to ensure the right to adequate, healthy, sustainable and knowledge-based food consumption. The Commission should set binding targets to encourage Member States to take action against food waste.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. Considering that the theme of the 2015 World Expo in Milan - Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life - provides an opportunity to address global food challenges and imbalances, including waste, undernutrition, obesity and global warming, the European Parliament calls on the Commission and Member States to take action to ensure respect for the right to adequate food , healthy, sustainable and based on reliable information.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution aims to strengthen the security of the food supply, combat waste, develop third world agriculture or protect soils. This is a non-binding resolution, which takes the opportunity of the 2015 World Expo in Milan to encourage the Union to promote these actions. This report testifies to the schizophrenia of the Union, which, on the one hand, promotes free trade—global and free and undistorted competition, thus promoting an "Americanised society" right down to its food, and which, on the other hand, complains of food insecurity in the Union, in particular the situation of 80 million people living below the poverty line, of whom nearly 3 million die each year from food-related diseases.  Finally, this text makes no mention of a change in the agricultural model based on productivity and does not call into question treaties such as TTIP, which encourages the importation of bad sanitary or food practices such as GMOs into the Union.  So I decided to vote against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote the resolution that analyzes "Milano Expo 2015". Although only in the coming months can we actually evaluate its effects, I believe that this showcase will be fundamental for Lombardy, Veneto and the whole of Italy.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Resolution on the 2015 Universal Exhibition "Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life", which will open in Milan in May 2015. The EU will have a significant presence with its flag and, through this Resolution, the Commission is challenged about the measures envisaged to improve the security of food production and supply, combating the scarcity of natural resources and promoting sustainable research and forms of agriculture; combat food waste throughout the agri-food supply chain, with ambitious, clear and binding goals, and promote healthy foods and quality standards in the field of nutrition, both in terms of research and education—incentivating responsible and healthy lifestyles—and through policy development to help eradicate malnutrition and prevent obesity.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. I was pleased to support expo resolution 2015, as it really raises the most important issues in the field of agriculture and food production in the world. Agriculture is undoubtedly one of the cornerstones of the EU economy and, as such, must make every effort to eradicate hunger in the world. The right to food is a universal right for the people, and I am pleased that the resolution puts this finding at the heart of it. As the world's population grows, food needs will grow and the global economy must be prepared for this. At the same time, the problem of food wasted must be seriously tackled. The current amount of food wasted in the world would feed hundreds of millions of hungry people, so action must be taken here and now. I am also pleased to see a sincere recognition of the role of small farmers and family farms in tackling persistent hunger and ensuring global food security. Without them, there is no sustainable agriculture. I also consider it very important to see a resolution call for greater transparency in the food chain and an end to unfair trading practices. Farmers must be guaranteed a fair return, fair prices and fair profits, this must be ensured along the whole chain. I believe that this year's EXPO 2015 world exhibition in Milan, which will begin tomorrow, will give the world and all of us a new impetus to improve the situation on our beautiful planet.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. \u2012 I support this resolution, as it calls for the inclusion of the female dimension in all policies dealing with food unavailability. Furthermore, the resolution calls for improved working and living conditions for rural women in developing countries.  It is necessary to define clear goals in the fight against food waste and in the sustainability of the complete food chain. In conclusion, I believe that education is crucial in promoting healthy eating habits and the use of traditional and local food products.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution since I believe that Expo Milano 2015 is a great opportunity not only for Italy but also for the European continent as a whole. The event focuses mainly on the agriculture sector, which remains one of the key sectors of the European economy. Therefore the European Parliament should endorse this event.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. The role of Expo will be fundamental for Milan, Lombardy and Piedmont, and the whole of Italy.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the World Expo 2015 in Milan. The theme of this exhibition is "Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life". It focuses on the paradox between the serious problems of malnutrition in some countries of the world and the growing phenomenon of obesity in other countries. Therefore, the resolution emphasizes the importance of agriculture adapted to global challenges. I stress that fishing, alongside agriculture, has an important role to play in addressing these challenges.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution "Expo Milano 2015: Feeding the planet, energy for life". With this text, Parliament wanted to stress the importance of the Expo as a point of reference for achieving objectives that will make it possible to assert the right to adequate and nutritious food. I voted to send out a strong message that would raise awareness of the imminent need to solve the problems of food distribution and consumption, to address the issue of food waste and to combat malnutrition.  I therefore hope that Parliament's position expressed through this resolution and the very strong scope of Expo 2015 will really contribute to the change in a world in which hunger and waste live in, in which the production of biofuels and feed does not take into account the scarcity of water and food, and in which obesity and malnutrition go hand in hand.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. \u2012 My negative vote is due to the strong critical issues related to Expo 2015. Exploited workers, opaque contracts, the preference of some foods over others without proper explanation and other problems related to exposure led me to vote against.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I had to vote against this motion for a resolution because, while it is full of good intentions - namely to feed the planet while protecting the climate - the proposed solutions and measures evade the real issues and the solutions advocated tend towards total unrealism. Thus, if food security is a real issue, to defend its principle without defending that of food sovereignty is to want to use barrels pierced to transport water. On the other hand, while I welcome the defence made in this proposal of organic and family-scale agriculture, I can only see the complete contradiction that exists between this proposal and the TTIP negotiations, as well as the fact that the reality of the models now imported into Europe is evaded; it is indeed the American-style model of industrial agriculture that tends to be predominant, as we see with the end of milk quotas decided by the EU. Therefore, I voted against this motion for a resolution made of wishful thinking but in real denial of reality.

name: Lara COMI
