text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on Expo 2015 which, among other points, calls on the Commission and the Member States to use the theme of the Expo to affirm the right to adequate, healthy, sustainable and informed food. The Milan World's Fair develops a theme of fundamental importance, not only for Europe but for the whole world. Feeding the planet is, in fact, one of the greatest challenges we are facing and it is necessary to prepare quickly all measures to guarantee food security, both from the point of view of production and supply. Personally, I believe that there can be no food safety without good labelling and traceability rules, which are essential both for consumers to be aware of what they buy and for the creation of a effectively competitive and transparent market. Convinced that the Expo is, on the one hand, a moment of union and sharing and a means of enrichment and reflection and, on the other, an instrument of economic recovery and employment, I strongly condemn any irrational gesture aimed at hindering its success. I hope that my region, my country and the European Union will make the most of the opportunity that the exhibition offers them to improve the quality of life of all the citizens of the world.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. I did not vote in favour of the Expo Milano 2015 resolution because those amendments calling for the principles of transparency, sustainability and protection of small agricultural producers to be included in the resolution did not pass.  I voted in favour of those amendments which emphasise the need to promote a food regime that succeeds in ensuring a more rational and sustainable consumption of food resources. So no to those foods with a high caloric content, rich in fat, sugar and salt and low in micronutrients and that represent the main causes of obesity. I regret, in fact, that the amendments highlighting the scandalous sponsorship of the multinationals (McDonald, Coca Cola and Nestlé Ferrero), the first producers of junk food, known for not guaranteeing sustainable food, did not pass. Expo should be an opportunity to discuss and share best practices in sustainable agriculture and promote small farms. I voted in favour of the amendment denouncing the mismanagement of contracts by allowing criminal organisations to be infiltrated into infrastructure works. I also voted in favour of the amendment which includes respect for social and labour rights within the principle of sustainability. It is not acceptable for paid jobs to be replaced by precarious and 'voluntary' jobs.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution comes from an oral question to the European Commission posed on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture. The events concern the holding of the 2015 Expo in Milan under the title "Feed the planet, energy for life". The Resolution focuses on different aspects of this Expo related to the idea of improving food production and distribution, tacking food waste and promoting new approaches to meet the challenge of malnutrition.  But it does not include such important issues as the human right to water, food sovereignty or the right to land. That is why I voted against it, because I cannot hold events in which many multinationals are organizing and launching, such as the Barilla Foundation or Nestlé, which, far from fighting to 'feed the planet', are rather struggling to fuel their economic benefits. Thus, the Expo is presented as the gateway of food multinationals, but only those that have control of food worldwide, which produce globalized junk food simultaneously creating millions of hungry and millions of obese people.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution stresses that in order to tackle the food security challenge in such a discussion we need to continue promoting the following: a strong and sustainable agricultural sector across the EU, a thriving and diversified rural economy, a clean environment, and family farms, supported by a robust, fairer, internationally sustainable and appropriately financed common agricultural policy. As I agree with the general approach to sustainable living highlighted in the resolution I voted in favour of it.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. \u2012 On the eve of the inauguration of Expo 2015, I voted in favour of the resolution on the issues covered by the Milan World's Fair.  This resolution has the merit of clearly highlighting key challenges in the food sector, such as the need to ensure high food safety standards, to promote sustainable food practices, and to take effective action in the fight against food waste and malnutrition in the world.  Today there are some serious paradoxes in the international agri-food supply chains that we have a duty to fight with the ultimate objective of a more sustainable and effective management of scarce natural resources and greater transparency, traceability and equity of the food supply chain.  Expo 2015 will be a great showcase for our country and for Europe, but it must above all be a platform for meeting and exchanging good practices between countries and a concrete opportunity to make new commitments for greater sustainability, quality and security of food supply chains.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution. It is a public health issue, but also an economic, environmental and geopolitical challenge, for today, but also for future generations. The Milan World's Fair offers us the opportunity to create a highlight around this subject.  At European level, we need to pool our best practices and our research and development capabilities in agronomy, in order to invest for the future.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The 2015 Milan World's Fair opened its doors on May 1st with the theme "Feeding the Planet". This issue, of course, concerns Europeans, but also the citizens of the world. European food security policy must be part of a global vision. With a major challenge: to be able to meet the doubling of food needs by 2050, in a context marked by water scarcity, a decrease in arable land and a new energy situation dictated by the fight against climate change.  The global organization of agricultural markets must be rethought by taking into account the two main inspirations of the common agricultural policy, guaranteeing food security and saving the living fabric of farmers and their families, both here and in the poorest countries.  There is also a need to create a targeted global system of food stocks, consisting of emergency stocks to reduce hunger and stocks to regulate commodity prices. The system should be managed by the UN through its global food and agriculture organization, FAO.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Written. \u2012 Tomorrow the 34th World's Fair will start. This Expo not only offers many economic opportunities but can, through the selected theme choice, also be a catalyst for tackling various global challenges, in particular the demand for healthy, sustainable and high-quality food. Flanders, the region I represent, will be prominent at the World Expo to put its innovation, creativity and entrepreneurship firmly on the map. I recently attended the press conference at which the Flemish actions were presented and I was very impressed. Flemish expertise is highlighted for the entire food chain: from production, space use and food safety to surplus food and packaging to waste disposal. Thanks to the commitment of many partners, the Flemish craftsmanship, which offers creative solutions to the challenges of tomorrow, is perfectly presented. This also connects with a theme that we are currently discussing in the EU, namely the transition to a circular economy that deals more efficiently with raw materials and considers waste to be a material. I am therefore pleased to announce that I can offer a forum in September to highlight some of these Flemish best practices in the European Parliament.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. The motion for a resolution hides the hypocrisy of the EU's food and agricultural policy authorities behind good intentions. It aims to promote "a reliable and sustainable agricultural sector throughout the UNION, a prosperous and diversified rural economy, a clean environment, as well as family farms supported by a dynamic, fairer, more sustainable and properly financed common agricultural policy." In particular, there is a call for essential food security. However, "small-scale" farming models cannot be imposed in France or the United States, where 48 million people are struggling to feed themselves and receiving food aid. Food sovereignty is essential for food security and the models advocated in this resolution do not participate. Moreover, these very good intentions are far out of step with the actual policy pursued by the Union. So I voted against it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. \u2012 Milan EXPO 2015 between 1 May and 30 October will serve as a platform for the European Union and its institutions to present their policies to combat the food crisis, promote the fight against food waste, promote healthy eating, etc.  I supported the proposed resolution on the subject. Rather, its scope would be defined as broad, aimed at showing what can be achieved at expo 2015.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: in writing. I voted against the resolution adopted today by the European Parliament, because the Milanese demonstration was born as the highest moment of reflection on the issue of nutrition, but behind the 'green' façade of the EXPO lie the usual logic of profit and exploitation of resources, the environment and people. In particular, an important amendment proposed by my political group was rejected, as it criticised the choice of multinationals as official sponsors of expo, whose policies and products are in stark contrast to the promotion of healthy and sustainable eating. Nor has our call on the Commission to direct the Union's food policies towards forms of greater sustainability throughout the supply chain, favouring organic and biodynamic production and zero-kilometre distribution. It is clear that a resolution of this kind, which does not want to take account of economically and environmentally sustainable production, which is not intended to favour local production, which does not take sides against multinationals and genetically modified products, the main enemies of our quality food, cannot be supported by the M5S.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 Having as the theme of the Expo "Feeding the Planet: Energy for Life", it is important to significantly boost the debate on improving food production and distribution, combating food waste, promoting and developing existing positive strategies to address the challenge of food insecurity, malnutrition and food imbalances, as well as creating a balance between availability and consumption of resources. The Milanese fair offers an opportunity to discuss the various approaches, finding solutions to the paradoxes of a globalized world where, on the one hand, there are about 870 million people who are malnourished and who are victims of hunger and, on the other hand, about 2.8 million people die due to health problems linked to incorrect nutrition, obesity and overweight.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Expo was touted as a world showcase to prepare for the relaunch of a country, Italy, in a strong crisis. New concrete flows have been preferred to the recovery, re-evaluation and enhancement of what is already present in the territory. Waste has been preferred to sustainability and resource optimization. This is for the benefit of the few, as evidenced by investigations and investigations that have revealed cases of corruption, mafia infiltration and squandering of public money. It is easy to compare them with those multinationals that speculate on a globalised food system away from a healthy, balanced and sustainable food style, which contribute to penalising local economies and small producers in the agri-food sector. It is the latter who suffer from the excessive power of the large economic groups that monopolize large-scale distribution and which sponsor this international event. This unequal relationship of strength is made even more evident and amplified by the Expo: yet another missed opportunity.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution is the result of the decision of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development on the EU's participation in the Milan Expo in 2015.  The EU will be represented at Expo Milan with a flag under the topic 'Feeding the Planet: Energy for Life'. After several hearings in the Committee on Agriculture on this topic, it was agreed that topics such as food security, the fight against food waste and the promotion of healthy eating and nutrition requirements would be raised and focused on in order to help prevent and eradicate malnutrition and prevent obesity. Some important aspects are lacking in the resolution, such as the defence of small farms and sustainable agriculture against intensive production methods, soil erosion, deforestation, lack of water and loss of biodiversity, which lead precisely to the lack of food on the planet. There are still references to the struggle of farmers, to the right to produce. There is a lack of reference to the right to water.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Theme of Expo 2015 exhibition in Milan: To feed the planet, energy for life is important to use to set goals for fulfilling the right to sufficient, healthy, sustainable and conscious food consumption. The European Union Pavilion at EXPO 2015 is intended to ensure that awareness is increased about the need to address problems throughout the food chain, including food waste, poor diet, the fight against malnutrition and obesity. Only an appropriate institutional, regulatory and monitoring framework can support the environment for developing strong, fair and accessible agricultural market systems.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution can be supported as it is a detailed manifesto of the main "key issues" in the agri-food sector. The main 'political' issues relating to food and its agricultural production are mentioned without, however, going into the substance.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the Milan International Exhibition 2015: Food for the Planet, Energy as a Source of Life, because all sectors of production need more know-how and greater respect for wealth management rules.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Expo Milano, which will open its doors on 1 May, deals with a theme that is one of the biggest challenges for today’s world: how to feed the increasingly growing world population in the years to come. I appreciate the fact that the main focus of this resolution is food security and how to tackle the threats that put food security at risk. Being a member of the Committee on Development, I am especially concerned with how the issues of land grabbing, land loss and degradation will be dealt with in the future. I believe that, in the coming decades, we will have to deliver a global strategy that must include sustainability in farming systems and in global food production through sustainable small-scale farming, organic, high-natural-value or tree-based agriculture, as well as better resource efficiency and increased crop diversity. I congratulate my colleague Paolo De Castro on an outstanding job.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. The Milan Expo 2015 could serve to significantly boost the debate on improving food production and distribution and combating food waste, given that there are some 870 million hungry malnourished people worldwide, as well as FAO estimates, showing that the increase in the world's population from 7 billion to 9.1 billion people will force increased supplies of 70% by 2050. The right to food is a basic human right that will not be effective until everyone has access to adequate food. The EU must work, together with the United Nations and other international actors, to ensure proper food for the entire world's population.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Milan Expo will be a great showcase for Italy and For Europe. It will be an opportunity to combat food waste and fraud and to promote food education based on a healthy and balanced lifestyle. In this regard, I would like to stress that our challenge is not only against food scarcity, which naturally remains a top priority, but also against the abundance of food. Finally, and I want to say this in particular to those who dispute, the Expo will also be an extraordinary opportunity for the poorest countries, which will be present with clusters in which they will present their products. The Nepal Pavilion, completed thanks to the free work of the other workers, is in particular the symbol of a union of peoples that together knows how to overcome even the most difficult challenges.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. I am pleased to support the motion for a resolution on Expo Milano 2015, which my colleague Paolo De Castro has carried out with great skill and expertise, considering the issue of food security and the right to food already mentioned in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in 1948, which are now very priority and topical and considering the Milan Expo to be a great opportunity to inform , to promote and reflect on everything that is necessary and possible, at national and European level, for better and proper management of resources to combat hunger and malnutrition, deplorable food waste, unemployment and economic recession, through solid support for agriculture and fisheries, fundamental sectors of employment and food security in many areas, especially in the developing world. in the world.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the Resolution highlighting the objectives of the Milan Expo, such as improving food production and distribution, or ending food waste, or promoting new approaches to ending malnutrition, because these objectives go into deep contradiction with the practices of multinationals sponsoring the event.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the theme of the world exhibition EXPO 2015 in Milan is "Feed the planet. The energy of life" is exclusively relevant today around the world. The high-profile event can seriously stimulate the debate on improving food production and distribution, tackling food waste, promoting and developing existing positive approaches to address food shortages and malnutrition and nutrition, and finding a balance between the amount of resources available and consumed. Urges the Commission and the Member States to take advantage of the theme of the milan global exhibition EXPO 2015 "Feed the planet. I welcome such initiatives.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the Resolution highlighting the objectives of the Milan Expo, such as improving food production and distribution, or ending food waste, or promoting new approaches to ending malnutrition, because these objectives go into deep contradiction with the practices of multinationals sponsoring the event.

name: Robert Jarosław IWASZKIEWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted against this resolution because Parliament unjustifiably demands that the fundamental principles of a free economy be bent on a utopian left-wing worldview. The provisions of this resolution are native to the communist slogans calling for 'women on tractors'. The improvement of the world's food situation will not be achieved through legal orders and prohibitions, but by the release of human energy, natural entrepreneurship and preventability.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the RESOLUTION on EXPO 2015, which is being held in Milan. The theme of this edition of expo is: feed the planet, energy for life! Both of these topics are crucial for the survival of humanity both in the right way and at the right moment this resolution and the EXPO itself draw the attention of the world public to them. I think expo 2015 will be a new impulse for innovative solutions in the food and energy industry that will take into account the need to protect the environment and fight climate change.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution hides the hypocrisy of the EU's food and agricultural policy authorities behind good intentions. It aims to promote "a reliable and sustainable agricultural sector throughout the UNION, a prosperous and diversified rural economy, a clean environment, as well as family farms supported by a dynamic, fairer, more sustainable and properly financed common agricultural policy." In particular, there is a call for essential food security. However, "small-scale" farming models cannot be imposed in France or the United States, where 48 million people are struggling to feed themselves and receiving food aid. Food sovereignty is essential for food security and the models advocated in this resolution do not participate. Moreover, these very good intentions are far out of step with the actual policy pursued by the Union. So I voted against it.

name: Jarosław KALINOWSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The resolution addresses one of the most sensitive, in addition to the depletion of drinking water supplies, the problems of the modern world and future generations. The demographic situation does not improve the outlook. An ageing population will reduce labour resources, and high natural growth in the least developed countries could cause a food crisis around the world. That is why Europe, as one of the leaders, must face these challenges and try to prevent a looming catastrophe. The document touches on many important aspects and proposes a number of solutions that need to be implemented successively. It is necessary to educate the public and to implement social campaigns for environmental protection, water conservation or food waste. Particular attention should be paid to the specific role of rural areas, which play a key role in food policy. Funding is needed to ensure the sustainable development of these sites and to maximise their potential. It is also important to ensure the development of small farmers, organic farms and small and medium-sized producers who provide food access to local communities.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I enthusiastically support this Motion for Resolution. The theme of the Milan Expo 2015 represents an excellent opportunity to put forward the debate on improving food production and distribution, tackling waste and promoting sustainable agricultural practices to combat the challenge of malnutrition. With 870 million people in the world malnourished and 2.8 million suffering from obesity, I welcome this chance to bring equilibrium to the supply and consumption of food worldwide. This resolution also promotes sustainable farming and agricultural practices, and encourages research and innovation in the world’s agriculture industry. It is only through careful, intelligent innovation and investment in the agriculture sector that we can hope to eliminate hunger and malnutrition around the world, as well as ensure the environmental benefits from ecologically sound food production

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. I am sure that the motion for a resolution on Expo Milano 2015 'Feeding the planet, energy for life' represents a great opportunity to relaunch Italy and Europe and to enhance its many production, technological and scientific excellences. There are several topics covered: food production and distribution, the problem of food waste, the protection of biodiversity, the great challenge of sustainability, malnutrition and land grabbing. Therefore, EXPO 2015 will allow us to address these issues at the highest level of scientific knowledge.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I voted against it. The will to fight hunger in the world is a great goal. The report points out that 925 million people are suffering from hunger on this planet, including in Europe, where 79 million people live below the poverty line. Parliament has decided to promote with this text traditional agriculture on a human scale, creating jobs and social links, which is based on a low use of chemicals, and wants to promote organic. But these objectives, in which I can find myself, do not correspond at all to the model that the European Union supports in Europe. In France, more and more factory farms are being built, and the transatlantic partnership hoped for by the European Union will endanger our health standards. These are more demanding and safe than those in the United States. What will become of organic? So there is a complete contradiction here. Added to this is the fact that there can be no food security without national sovereignty, which is always undermined in Parliament's plans to take on the role of international prime contractor.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: in writing. The EU will have a significant presence with its pavilion at the World's Fair "Feed the Planet". Energy for Life" which will open in Milan in May 2015 (Milan Expo 2015). The Commission is challenged on the measures it envisages to: 1. Improve the security of food production and supply, combating the scarcity of natural resources and promoting sustainable research and forms of agriculture; 2. Combat food waste throughout the agri-food supply chain, with ambitious, clear and binding targets; 3. Promote healthy foods and quality standards in the field of nutrition, both in terms of research and education – encouraging responsible and healthy lifestyles – and through the development of policies to help eradicate malnutrition and prevent obesity.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution comes from an oral question to the European Commission posed on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture. The events concern the holding of the 2015 Expo in Milan under the title "Feed the planet, energy for life". The Resolution focuses on different aspects of this Expo related to the idea of improving food production and distribution, tacking food waste and promoting new approaches to meet the challenge of malnutrition.  But it does not include such important issues as the human right to water, food sovereignty or the right to land. That is why I voted against it, because I cannot hold events in which many multinationals are organizing and launching, such as the Barilla Foundation or Nestlé, which, far from fighting to 'feed the planet', are rather struggling to fuel their economic benefits. Thus, the Expo is presented as the gateway of food multinationals, but only those that have control of food worldwide, which produce globalized junk food simultaneously creating millions of hungry and millions of obese people.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. The right to food is a basic human right that will not be effective until everyone has access to adequate, safe and nutritious food to meet their nutritional needs and lead a healthy and active life. I believe that the Milan Expo 2015, organized around the theme "Feeding the planet, energy for life", could significantly boost the debate on improving food production and distribution, the fight against food waste, the promotion of new approaches and the development of existing positive approaches to solving food shortages , malnutrition and hyponutrition, and the search for a balance between demand and consumption. I voted in favour of this proposal by urging the Commission and the Member States to support the theme of the Milan Expo 2015, 'Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life', to define commitments that would effectively confer on the right to balanced, healthy, sustainable and knowledgeable food consumption.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The EXPO 2015 World Exhibition will be held in Milan and will be dedicated to nutrition and environmental protection. EXPO is visited by more than 20 million people and is therefore a great way to represent the state. I am sorry that this year the Republic of Croatia will not participate in the exhibition. In its resolution, the European Parliament wants to encourage reflection on the Millennium Goals, the millions of malnourished and hungry in the world, and the Sustainable Development Goals of the agricultural and food sectors.  I support the resolution to raise awareness and initiate discussions on issues relevant to people's livelihoods and healthy lives. We should bear in mind that 89 million tonnes of food are wasted annually in the Union and that 870 million people are hungry. We need an international strategy for adequate, healthy and sustainable food consumption and a strong agricultural, rural and fishing sector and environmental care.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report on the Milan International Exhibition 2015 - Food for the planet as a Source of Life for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech of 30 April 2015 to the plenary of the European Parliament. Furthermore, the report is inadequate and does not address the current challenges in feeding the world's poverty-stricken populations, but instead advocates for mutated food and organisms (GMOs).

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I voted against this motion for a resolution. It is worth noting a very strong gap between this report and reality: although it is commendable to want to fight malnutrition this project does not take into account the sovereignty of the Member States and defends a model far removed from the reality of agriculture as practiced in Europe.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: in writing. \u2012 The theme of this year's EXPO 2015 in Milan is "food for the planet, energy for life". The aim of the exhibition in this way is to stimulate the debate on improving food production and distribution, solving food waste problems and finding solutions to other burning issues such as malnutrition and improper nutrition. It should be borne in mind that food insecurity also affects the EU, where 79 million people still live below the poverty line and 24.8% of the population is at risk of poverty or social exclusion. This number is constantly increasing compared to previous years. I consider expo to be an appropriate opportunity to reflect and discuss various approaches to addressing the paradoxes of a globalised world, where, on the one hand, 870 million people are malnourished and hungry and, on the other hand, around 2.8 million people are dying as a result of health problems linked to poor nutrition, obesity and overweight. The Commission's estimates that 30% of food is lost or wasted worldwide are also alarming. Since it is clear that it is absolutely necessary to discuss these problems at least and to urgently seek solutions to them, and since I consider expo to be an appropriate space for such a debate, I supported the draft text in today's vote.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Milan Expo 2015 offers the opportunity for the entire international community to reflect on the great issues related to nutrition, the environment and research. Through this resolution, the European Parliament has sought to demonstrate its willingness to be involved in this great debate. The problems of food scarcity and the unstoppable increase in the world's population require special attention. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this text which, among other things, calls for the correct and conscious use of food and environmental resources.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. In 2015, the World Expo on "Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life" is held in Milan. Hunger and malnutrition are the leading cause of death and the main threat to world peace and security. Unfortunately, this universal exhibition is a showcase for large groups in productivist agriculture, from GMOs to pesticide manufacturers to junk food companies. Mac Donald is the second sponsor of this exhibition. This model does not provide a sustainable food for humanity because it destroys agricultural ecosystems. The resolution makes a rather fair statement about the food situation. And the proposed solutions such as the promotion of "small-scale agriculture, organic farming with high natural value or agroforestry" are adapted and effective. Unfortunately, these are not the ones highlighted in Milan. The stated support of this resolution for an exhibition that contradicts its principles is therefore strange. I abstain.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. It is worth noting a very strong gap between this report and reality: although it is commendable to want to fight malnutrition, this project does not take into account the sovereignty of the Member States and defends a model far removed from the reality of agriculture as practised in Europe. I voted AGAINST this motion for a resolution.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ In light of the detrimental effects of climate change on the global food system, I chose to support this resolution as it urges the Commission to give greater support and attention to research on land management and sustainable intensification through more efficient use of nutrients, water and energy. It also calls for more research into improving crop yields without increasing the environmental impact of agriculture.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on Expo Milano 2015. The title themes of Feeding the Planet – Energy for Life are crucial and bring together many aspects of EU policy, both internally and externally focused. Combating food waste and promoting efficient, environmentally sustainable food production and land use are essential measures to combat poverty and malnutrition in the years to come.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution aims to strengthen the security of the food supply, combat waste, develop third world agriculture and protect soils. It is a non-binding resolution that takes the opportunity of the 2015 World Expo in Milan to encourage the Union to promote these actions.  On the one hand, the Union promotes global free trade and austerity that promotes junk food behaviour. On the other hand, it complains about the remaining food security flaws in the EU and the 79 million people who still live below the poverty line, while 2.8 million people die from food-related diseases, such as obesity.  There is therefore no mention at any time of food sovereignty, the only condition for food security. Moreover, this proposal supports an agricultural model that does not correspond to the evolution of agriculture in the Union. However, the resolution does not go so far as to call into question the turning point taken since 1992.  For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. Bearing in mind that the final draft text includes positive references to sustainable agriculture, limiting food waste and tackling hunger worldwide, the resolution as tabled can send a strong political signal about Parliament's concerns regarding food and farming worldwide.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the joint resolution on the 2015 Milan World Expo, the theme of which is 'Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life'. While the Millennium Development Goals are to be achieved this year, this resolution reminds us that agriculture and food security are major elements in achieving the poverty reduction goal. According to FAO, 898 million people worldwide are undernourished, while at the same time waste is still high in industrialized countries. The resolution calls for measures to improve food security in developing countries and calls on the Commission to set binding targets for member states to combat waste throughout the food supply chain.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 This will be a very important week for Lombardy, Italy and the European Union: expo 2015 will finally be inaugurated in Milan on Friday.  The event, already significant in itself, takes on particular importance both for the chosen theme and for the particular historical moment in which it takes place. The motto "Feeding the planet, energy for life" wants to focus, through a series of themed exhibition pavilions, on culture and traditions related to food, raising the much-needed debate on sustainable global growth based on strengthening food security, preserving biodiversity and combating waste, malnutrition and infant mortality.  At the same time as Expo, the adoption of the Milan Charter, an international agreement that aims to combat the problem of environmental sustainability, is a clear example of the fact that the mission of the event will not end on 31 October next, but that on the contrary Expo Milano wants to be the beginning of a long journey with high objectives. Due to the peculiar structure of the Expo exhibition, it can be considered a real European event: for six months it will not be the city of Milan that will host the pavilions of 137 countries, but the European Union as a whole.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that the theme of Expo Milano 2015 is "Feeding the planet, energy for life" and that the event can give a strong boost to the debate aimed at improving food production and distribution, addressing the problem of food waste, promoting and developing positive approaches already existing to meet the challenge of food insecurity, malnutrition and improper nutrition, as well as creating a balance between availability and consumption of resources , I have decided to support the resolution, I believe that the fight against malnutrition and the guarantee of universal access to nutrition with adequate nutrient intake should continue to be one of the main objectives of the post-2015 agenda as part of the objective of eliminating hunger, specifically calling for an end to all forms of malnutrition by 2030.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted and signed this resolution because, through the amendments tabled, It urges the Commission and the Member States to take advantage of the Expo Milano 2015 theme – 'Feeding the planet, energy for life' – in order to make commitments on 'respect for the right to adequate, healthy, sustainable food consumption'. It also stresses that 'the fight against malnutrition and ensuring universal access to adequate nutritious nutrition should remain one of the most important objectives of the post-2015 agenda with a view to eliminating hunger', with the main objective of eradicating malnutrition by 2030 .

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution because I believe that Europe must speak with a single and strong voice in combating the challenges of food production and redistribution and in combating their waste. We must promote positive initiatives to meet the challenges facing the sector.  Nearly 900 million people worldwide suffer from hunger or malnutrition, while nearly 1.4 billion suffer from overweight. These statistics signal the need for clear and concrete policies to address these two problems, with a common root - a lack of sufficiently clear state policies in food production and redistribution.  Given the projections that the world's population will reach nearly 9 billion by 2050, which in turns will generate an increase of 70% of the need for food supplies over the same period - the need for such policies is becoming more pressing.  I believe that the European Union, as a leader in upholding high standards in the field of agriculture, must set a strong example, especially in those areas related to unfair trade practices or the circular economy.  I join the call on the European Commission to conclude an ambitious international agreement, including food and its policy, as measures aimed at mitigating the effects of climate change.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal because it addresses various concerns relating to the production and consumption of food in the world. In a situation where 870 million people suffer from malnutrition and hunger and, on the other hand, around 2.8 million people die from problems related to poor diet, obesity and overweight, the event of the Milan World Exhibition is a good opportunity to promote people's knowledge in this area, to give new impetus to discussions on how to improve food production and distribution, to reduce food waste and to promote existing measures and to find good solutions to food insecurity. malnutrition and poor nutrition, and to strike the right balance between supply and consumption. The motion for a resolution calls, inter alia, for addressing the link between the problem of climate change and food production and the promotion of small agriculture.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Parliament's resolution because the theme of the 2015 World's Fair gives the European Union an opportunity to reflect on the current food landscape. Almost a billion people live in malnutrition, while a third of the world's food is wasted. In the light of this striking contrast, I believe that Europe must make food safety one of its priorities, especially in conjunction with the European Year of Development. The Member States must act on two fronts: introducing measures for more sustainable agriculture and measures to reduce food waste, in order to eradicate hunger and ensure a fair extension of the human right to food.  I am convinced that the Milan Expo can represent an important meeting forum, which favors the generation of ideas and the exchange of good practices between European and global voices.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 I thank the rapporteur for his work and hope to have made my contribution.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. \u2012 As much as 1.3 billion tonnes of food, which is a third of the total food produced on the globe, is wasted annually worldwide, of which 100 million tonnes are wasted on the territory of EU countries. On the other hand, 850 million hungry people are looking for help. From this it is quite clear that the issue of hunger is not a question of food, but a matter of politics.  I have signed a written statement to take all necessary action against food waste at every level of the food supply chain, from production all the way to consumption, to make unsold edible food available to the poor and charities before the expiry date. It is necessary to familiarize society with agriculture and properly evaluate local products and specialties. Education for healthy eating should be carried out at all levels. It is necessary to support, finance and develop family farms and bring agriculture back to the forefront.  In light of the amendment to European legislation governing member states' rights to decide independently on the introduction of live GMOs into the environment, I would like to stress that this right must in no way be undermined. The natural richness and quality of European food is recognized worldwide. The release of live GMOs into the environment can jeopardize food production in the traditional way, and for this reason an initiative has been launched to establish an Alpe-Adria region free of GMO.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Expo Milano 2015, in addition to representing a great opportunity to relaunch for the city of Milan and for the whole of Italy, must represent first of all a great opportunity to relaunch the international fight against hunger, against the problem of malnutrition, poor nutrition and obesity. I voted in favour of this resolution to call on the European Commission, the Council and all the states participating in the exhibition to use the theme of expo 'Feeding the planet, energy for life' to set commitments that will allow the right to adequate, healthy, sustainable and informed food to be asserted. The European Union, which will take part in the exhibition with its own pavilion, must do more to seek solutions to the urgent problems affecting the entire food supply chain. Too many people in Europe and around the world still live below the poverty line, but at the same time 30% of the world's food is wasted and hunger coexists with paradoxical levels of obesity. The EU must make real contributions to the global food security challenge from the Milan event.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. In addition to this year's EXPO, I agree that tackling food insecurity is essential: a strong and sustainable agricultural sector across the EU, a successful and diverse rural economy, a clean environment and family farms supported by a robust, fairer, internationally sustainable and adequately funded agricultural policy.  Environmental sustainability and efforts to adapt to climate change and mitigate climate change will only be successful if farms are economically viable and farmers have access to land, debt and upskilling. Appropriate institutional, regulatory and supervisory frameworks can promote an environment dedicated to the development of stable, sustainable, emancy, accessible and diversified agricultural market systems. Current inequalities in the food supply chain pose a threat to the sustainability of food production and calls for greater transparency and fairness in the food supply chain, as well as the elimination of UTPs and other market distortions to ensure fair profits for farmers, fair profits and pricing under the food supply chain, as well as a sustainable agricultural sector that will offer food security. For this reason, I support this resolution and join calls that it is necessary to vigorously combat land loss and the abandonment of marginal agricultural areas to ensure food security. Rural development is essential for the economic and social growth of these areas, which is why we need to provide additional support to young farmers.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒The theme of this year's world exhibition in Milan is that food becomes the right of all people especially when we have a burning problem of hunger in a world where huge amounts of food are thrown away on the one hand and on the other hand it enjoys intemperateness. A common agricultural policy is needed with a view to sustainable development, changing eating habits and focusing on promoting a healthy lifestyle.  The food problem is a global problem and a challenge where we need to create preconditions for sustainable food production due to limited resources and reducing world hunger. Therefore, I believe that it is necessary to develop frameworks and strategies for coordinated action and a successful solution to the problem of nutrition. A sustainable development policy for safe food supply while changing the awareness of individuals is the key to success.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The theme chosen for the Expo is extremely important to make everyone aware of the absolute priority importance of food and food for the planet. I hope that solutions will be found to improve food production and distribution, that the waste that exists in the industrialised countries will be reduced and that the challenges of food security, malnutrition and the balance between the availability and consumption of resources will be consciously confronted. The Expo is a global and global platform where the different actors involved are given the opportunity to confront each other to find valid solutions to the great challenges of nutrition and nutrition in a world where there are still strong contradictions between people who are undernourished and others who suffer from health disorders due to excessive nutrition. Let us remember that, according to fao estimates, the world's population will increase dramatically and the increase in food production will not be enough to guarantee food security for all. This is the main challenge that needs to be addressed and resolved.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. On the occasion of the opening of the 2015 World Expo in Milan, the theme of which is "feeding the planet, energy for life", MEPs wanted to express themselves on the importance of this year's theme. I am pleased to have voted in favour of this resolution. This exhibition will raise the important issues of population growth and how to ensure the long-term food needs of citizens in Europe and around the world. These issues also raise environmental and health issues and invite Member States and European and international bodies to come up with new ideas.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. – The universal exhibition in Milan will take place from 1 May to 30 October 2015, being devoted to the theme "Feeding the Planet: Energy for Life". The themes of the Expo focus mainly on the agricultural sector, which remains a key sector of the Union economy, as agricultural exports account for two thirds of all its external trade. The Union remains the world's largest agricultural exporter and the EU food industry generates an annual turnover of approximately EUR 1 trillion, employing more than 4 million people. The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) also expects the world's population to grow from 7 to 9.1 billion, requiring a 70% increase in food supply by the year 2050. To address the challenge of food security, this resolution considers that the following components are essential: a strong and sustainable agricultural sector in the EU, a prosperous and diversified rural economy, a clean environment and family farms ensured by a sound, fair, sustainable common agricultural policy at international level and properly financed. I voted in favour.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. Five years after Shanghai, the World's Fair, on the very well-chosen theme of world food, will open tomorrow in Milan and last until 31 October. Under the slogan "Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life", the 2015 World Expo focuses on one of the world's most important themes to avoid growing imbalances on the planet.  Indeed, the beginning of the 21st century is characterized by a worrying double phenomenon: on the one hand, nearly 900 million people worldwide suffer from undernourishment and, on the other, about 1 billion people, mainly in the richest countries, are affected by overweight and obesity. For six months, for this international event, which involves 145 countries and where 53 national pavilions have been built, to inform and raise awareness among industry, citizens and the media on the issues of sustainable consumption, nutritional diversity and food waste.  Let us hope that the Milan exhibition, beyond the beauty of the pavilions, the meeting between tradition and agricultural modernity, will provide an early answer to the question: How to feed two billion more people by 2030?

name: Robert ROCHEFORT
text: In writing. I voted in favour of our resolution on the holding of the Milan World's Fair "Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life". In this text, we recall that, in a world in which the population continues to grow, food security remains a major issue, and that there are still places in the world where people are unable to feed themselves sufficiently and properly. This is all the more scandalous when we know that 30% of the food produced around the world is finally wasted! 2016 should be designated the European Year to Combat Food Waste and Member States should be called upon to take action to reduce this scourge.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. To solve the problem of food security, strong and viable agricultural and fishing sectors must be established throughout the European Union, a prosperous and diversified rural economy, a clean environment, and family farms supported by a dynamic, fairer, sustainable internationally and properly financed common agricultural policy. This is, in essence, what the European Parliament has requested when it adopted a resolution on the 2015 World Expo in Milan, which opened on Friday 1 May. Parliament stressed the importance of implementing a sustainable and adequately funded CFP (Common Fisheries Policy), ensuring consistency between EU trade and fisheries policies and increasing the fight against illegal fishing.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I endorse this motion for a resolution on EU participation in the 2015 Universal Exhibition in Milan entitled 'Feeding the Planet: Energy for Life', which will take place between 1 May and 30 October 2015, as I believe that this is a unique opportunity for the EU to massively disseminate its main achievements in the fields of food and sustainability. It should be noted that this initiative coincides with the year of closure of the Millennium Development Goals and the beginning of a post-2015 framework that will also address the Sustainable Development Goals. At the same time, the Europe 2020 strategy will also be in the middle of its implementation period, so Expo Milan will serve not only as a channel for presenting the interim results of the Strategy, but also to disseminate its objectives for the future, especially in the areas of food security and sustainability. As such, the EU's participation in this exhibition represents a unique opportunity to strengthen its role as a global player in the development of future initiatives on food, health and food safety and to communicate with citizens and raise awareness of current challenges and future sustainability objectives.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the resolution, which I voted in favour of, stems from the European Parliament's desire to give a strong stimulus to the debate to improve food production and distribution. That is why we have asked the European Commission to deal more concretely with the problem of food waste, malnutrition and the balance between the food available and its consumption. We are in a world where many people are starving and many others are suffering from the reverse problem and this should not happen.

name: Matteo SALVINI
text: in writing. I have chosen to vote in favour because the resolution is a detailed manifesto of the main 'key issues' in the agri-food sector and mentions the main 'political' issues relating to food and its agricultural production. Having said that, several unknowns remain on Expo, starting with how much it will be able to respond to the "real" theme, to chart a path for a sustainable response to the theme of food supply, towards which innovation is urgently needed on the part of the agricultural and agro-industrial supply chain. The imbalances between the different players in the supply chain and access to food for the populations of developing countries should be some of the issues that need to be addressed very seriously.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the Resolution highlighting the objectives of the Milan Expo, such as improving food production and distribution, or ending food waste, or promoting new approaches to ending malnutrition, because these objectives go into deep contradiction with the practices of multinationals sponsoring the event.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution comes from an oral question to the European Commission posed on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture. The events concern the holding of the 2015 Expo in Milan under the title "Feed the planet, energy for life". The Resolution focuses on different aspects of this Expo related to the idea of improving food production and distribution, tacking food waste and promoting new approaches to meet the challenge of malnutrition.  But it does not include such important issues as the human right to water, food sovereignty or the right to land. That is why I voted against it, because I cannot hold events in which many multinationals are organizing and launching, such as the Barilla Foundation or Nestlé, which, far from fighting to 'feed the planet', are rather struggling to fuel their economic benefits. Thus, the Expo is presented as the gateway of food multinationals, but only those that have control of food worldwide, which produce globalized junk food simultaneously creating millions of hungry and millions of obese people.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on Expo Milano 2015, to ask the Commission to use this event as a time for the dissemination of European best practices in the field of nutrition and food safety, also in view of the fact that agriculture is a strategic sector of the EU that commits many of the Community's resources.  Today we have the opportunity to make known to the world the very high safety standards of European production, as well as the quality and wholesomeness of our food. I also call on the Eu ropean Union to continue to promote and implement sustainable agri-food policies that encourage the reduction of production costs, the reduction of food waste, the transfer of technological innovations and the efficient use of energy resources.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour and i greet the rapporteur Paolo de Castro. The motto of Milan's universal exhibition is food security at a time when there are 870 million malnourished people in the world. The target set at the 1996 World Food Summit, which was intended to reduce the number of hungry people by 2015, remains largely out of reach. It's good that the Milan EXPO will warn you about this. In parallel with hunger and malnutrition, food waste and obesity also grow. We produce more food than we need, contributing concomitantly to the degradation of the environment. This diachrony is the basis of social conflicts and injustices. There is an urgent need to take on a paradigm shift. Investment in fishing and farming practices should be invested in preserving natural resources for future generations. Food security for all also means creating local and regional subsistence capacities and contributing to a better allocation of resources and production on a global scale. I regret that Portugal, my country, is not officially present at this important event. As a congressman, I will be present.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Expo 2015 is an opportunity to reflect on the contradictions we face in the modern world and to seek solutions to the problems facing our civilization. The issue of hunger is still a pressing problem. On the other hand, mortality from mal-eating diseases is increasing (around 2.8 million people suffer from obesity or overweight conditions). In addition, around 1.3 billion tonnes of food are wasted every year. This data shows the importance of developing solutions that involve making informed policy choices and promoting the development of a sustainable lifestyle.  The slogan "Feed the planet: energy for life" is particularly important for agriculture and the common agricultural policy. The CAP is an intermediary between the agricultural expectations of EU citizens and the needs of farmers facing economic and environmental challenges. During the current parliamentary term, the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development has already held several debates on these issues, which have resulted in valuable proposals.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission estimates that 30% of food worldwide is lost or wasted and that by 2020 annual food waste in the European Union, currently approximately 89 million tonnes (179 kg per capita), will rise to approximately 126 million tonnes – a 40 % increase – unless preventive actions or measures are taken. Better management of the food sector would mean more efficient land use, better water resource management and positive effects on the whole agricultural sector worldwide, while also furthering the fight against undernourishment and poor diets in the developing world.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on Expo 2015 in Milan, as I consider it necessary to have a debate on improving food production and distribution, combating food waste, as well as the problem of food shortages, malnutrition and poor diets, and striking a balance between supply and consumption. In the framework of this resolution, I therefore also voted in favour of the amendment so that genetic manipulation techniques are under no circumstances used in soil research.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – Between 1 May and 30 October 2015, the opportunity at the EXPO 2015 World Exhibition in Milan will be to present the EU's positions on serious issues in the fight against food waste, on agriculture as a key sector of the EU economy, to addressing food security and the use of agricultural production to eliminate hunger in the world. Currently, around 870 million people suffer from malnutrition and hunger, while on the other hand, some 2.8 million people die annually as a result of health problems related to bad nutrition, obesity and overweight. According to the European Commission's estimate, up to 30% of food is lost or thrown away worldwide, and unless effective measures are taken, this amount increases enormously every year. The EU Pavilion at EXPO 2015 should raise awareness of the need to address pressing challenges throughout the food chain, including the sustainability of food production, distribution and consumption, in order to tackle food waste and combat malnutrition, poor diet and obesity.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. \u2012 The economic development of society goes hand in hand with environmental development. It is therefore important that we focus not only on economic factors, but also contribute to the development of the environment. The theme of EXPO Milan 2015 "Feed the Planet, Energy for Life" provides impetus in the debate on improving food production and distribution, combating food waste, promoting and developing already existing positive approaches to tackling food shortages, malnutrition and poor diets, and striking a balance between supply and consumption. All these topics concern us and sustainable solutions need to be found.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. \u2012 The idea of the World Expo 2015 exhibition in Milan "Feeding the planet – energy for life" is that this event can give an important impetus to the debate on improving food production and distribution, tackling food waste, promoting and elaborating already existing positive approaches to addressing food insecurity, malnutrition and poor diets, while establishing a balance between supply and consumption.  It is also an opportunity to ponder and discuss different approaches to addressing the paradoxes of a globalised world where, on the one hand, around 870 million people are malnourished and hungry, while around 2.8 million, on the other hand, die as a result of health problems associated with poor diet, obesity and overweight, and therefore supported the report.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution includes positive references to sustainable agriculture, limiting food waste and tackling hunger worldwide. The resolution could have included clearer references to the UN Special Rapporteur on the Right to Food, more positive references to principles of agro-ecology, problems with food distribution and the protection of traditional markets in developing countries. Nonetheless, as the resolution sends a strong political signal of the European Parliament’s concerns regarding food and farming worldwide I voted in favour.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: Writing. \u2012 I did not support the report because I believe it is full of intentions that may lead to the exact opposite of the intended objectives. These include, for example, highlighting the common agricultural policy in tackling food security, the sustainability of the agricultural sector, a better environment and so on. However, the fact is that the EU's common agricultural policy is in direct contradiction with these objectives, and in particular its designation as an instrument intended to make agriculture more sustainable is absurd in view of its functioning.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the Milan International Exhibition 2015 deals at all with the root causes of hunger, poverty and the exploitation of land resources. As far as the organisation of the report is concerned, there are also many questions about the lack of transparency. Unfortunately, the report promotes and promotes the interests of the organisers, who are private companies and multinationals, but, at the same time, there are also a number of positive reports which we cannot ignore.  Firstly, the report calls for measures to be implemented to achieve the Millennium Development Goals, secondly, highlights the right to healthy eating, housing, property and education and highlights the need to safeguard these rights; thirdly, recognises that investment and trade agreements have a devastating effect on food security when the long-term rental or sale of arable land to private investors results in the removal from local populations of access to productive resources and, finally, states that the eradication of hunger in a sustainable way will not only take place by providing enough food for all but only when small-scale farmers are allowed to maintain and cultivate their land.  However, since the positive aspects of the report are not sufficient to balance its shortcomings, we have finally chosen abstention.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We need to put more emphasis on know-how and respect wealth management rules.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the Milan World's Fair, which provides practical incentives to the Commission and the Member States and summarises the most important issues affecting the event in a complex way. I think it is important for the European Parliament to address the global challenge of food security. I consider this subject to be of particular importance, as one of my main objectives in my work is to make as much useful progress as possible on food here in the European Union. The Milan Expo provides a unique opportunity to discuss food safety issues internationally. Addressing the scarcity of natural resources set out in the motion, promoting sustainable forms of healthy food, research and agriculture, reducing food waste and reducing malnutrition all improve the security of food production and supply. This event also provides an opportunity to discuss other topics, such as food taxation or the suppression of food fraud. In my opinion, the practice of high tax content fully depletes the concept of overtrawing, against which I am also calling for an EU-wide solution in the TAXE Special Committee. I must note that sustainability is also called into question by the high tax content, since one of the main objectives of the common agricultural policy is to provide food to the consumer at affordable prices.

name: Dario TAMBURRANO
text: in writing. \u2012 I did not vote in favour of the resolution on Expo Milano 2015 because those amendments calling for the principles of transparency, sustainability and protection of small agricultural producers to be included in the resolution have not passed. I voted in favour of those amendments which stressed the need to promote a food regime that can guarantee a more rational and sustainable consumption of food resources. So no to those foods with a high caloric content, rich in fat, sugar and salt and low in micronutrients and that represent the main causes of obesity. I regret, therefore, that the amendments highlighting the scandalous sponsorship of the multinationals (McDonald, Coca Cola and Nestlé Ferrero), the first producers of junk food, known for not guaranteeing sustainable food, did not pass.  Expo should be an opportunity to discuss and share best practices in sustainable agriculture and promote small farms. I voted in favour of the amendment denouncing the mismanagement of contracts by allowing criminal organisations to be infiltrated into infrastructure works. I also voted in favour of the amendment which includes respect for social and labour rights within the principle of sustainability. It is not acceptable for paid jobs to be replaced by precarious and 'voluntary' jobs.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. The greatest challenge of hunger in the world is to ensure that everyone can feed themselves and, above all, feed themselves with healthy food. In Europe, more than 22 million children are overweight, while adolescents consume on average only 30-50% of the recommended daily serving of fruits and vegetables.  In light of these figures, I believe it is essential to promote a healthy and balanced diet from an early age, while re-learning how to learn about food and where it comes from and how it tastes and texture. Only through education will we promote responsible and healthy lifestyles.  It is in this sense that my report, which was recently adopted by the AGRI Committee on the distribution of fruit, vegetables and milk in schools, goes. The new programme must be understood as both a school distribution programme and a food education programme and must be accompanied by a clearly defined health objective: reducing obesity among children and encouraging the consumption of fruits, vegetables and milk.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: In writing. As part of the Milan World Expo "Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life", the European Parliament wanted to reflect on food security.  A majority of MEPs stressed the importance of improving food security through new, more sustainable production models to better produce in Europe and in all regions of the world. Every region of the world must be able to develop its own agriculture.  We also affirm the need to combat food waste throughout the agri-food supply chain, setting ambitious, clearly defined and binding targets.  On the other hand, volatile food market prices pose both serious food security problems, which can have considerable geopolitical implications and problems with the sustainability of jobs and incomes.  The Socialists recalled that the Common Fisheries Policy, the CAP's historic sister, also feeds Europeans and the world's population, providing them with a secure supply of protein and jobs. Fishing, like agriculture, must respond to sustainability logics, both for the preservation of the natural resource and for the health of the people it feeds.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the Resolution highlighting the objectives of the Milan Expo, such as improving food production and distribution, or ending food waste, or promoting new approaches to ending malnutrition, because these objectives go into deep contradiction with the practices of multinationals sponsoring the event.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The will to fight hunger in the world is a great goal. The report points out that 925 million people worldwide are hungry, including in Europe, where 79 million people live below the poverty line. Parliament has decided with this text to promote traditional agriculture on a human scale, creating jobs and social links, which is based on a low use of chemicals, and wants to promote organic. But these objectives, which I can find myself on, do not correspond at all to the model that the European Union supports in Europe. In France, more and more factory farms are being built, and the transatlantic treaty, hoped for by the European Union, will endanger our health standards. These are more demanding and safe than those applied in the United States. So there is a complete contradiction here. In addition, there can be no food security without sovereignty, which is always undermined in Parliament's plans. I'm voting AGAINST.

name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. \u2012 After the plenary session, the next World's Fair opens in Milan, the main idea of which is "Food for the Planet – Energy for Life". The adopted EP Decision encourages the European Commission and the Member States to use this opportunity, with the active involvement of the EP, to give everyone full access to healthy food and to find a solution to the issue of food waste. I supported the adoption of the decision.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. I voted against supporting this Expo, a propaganda event in favour of the most aggressive agri-food industry with the environment, dependence on agrochemicals and the pouring of EU waste in the rest of the world and the invisibilisation of local and quality agriculture.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. I voted against the motion for a resolution because three very important key points have not passed. Parliament did not censure the fact that Expo 2015 is sponsored by international companies such as McDonald's and Coca Cola that produce foods that are high in fat and at the same time low in micronutrients, contrary to the need to promote healthier eating behaviour. The amendment proposed by our group, which was initially passed in the Committee on Agriculture and deleted in plenary, called on the Commission to steer EU food policies towards forms of greater sustainability throughout the supply chain, favouring 'zero kilometre' distribution and organic and biodynamic production. Finally, we called for an explicit reference to the need not to resort to techniques involving genetic manipulation, an amendment which was also rejected in plenary. For the above reasons I did not support the report.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. This motion for a resolution comes from an oral question to the European Commission posed on behalf of the Committee on Agriculture. The events concern the holding of the 2015 Expo in Milan under the title "Feed the planet, energy for life". The Resolution focuses on different aspects of this Expo related to the idea of improving food production and distribution, tacking food waste and promoting new approaches to meet the challenge of malnutrition.  But it does not include such important issues as the human right to water, food sovereignty or the right to land. That is why I voted against it, because I cannot hold events in which many multinationals are organizing and launching, such as the Barilla Foundation or Nestlé, which, far from fighting to 'feed the planet', are rather struggling to fuel their economic benefits. Thus, the Expo is presented as the gateway of food multinationals, but only those that have control of food worldwide, which produce globalized junk food simultaneously creating millions of hungry and millions of obese people.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it calls on the Commission to help achieve, at global level, the goals of the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation in order to support the development of agricultural, environmental and social policies that encourage sustainable family farming.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Next May the EU will be represented at Expo Milan with a pavilion under the topic "Feeding the Planet, Energy for Life". After several hearings in the Committee on Agriculture on this topic, it was agreed that topics such as food security, the fight against food waste and the promotion of healthy eating and nutrition requirements would be raised and focused on, by promoting research and education, which help prevent and eradicate malnutrition and prevent obesity. Some important aspects such as the defence of small farms, such as the defence and promotion of sustainable agriculture against extensive production methods of large farms that cause, among other problems, soil erosion, deforestation, promote climate change, lack of water and biodiversity loss, which lead precisely to the lack of food on the planet, are lacking in the resolution. There are still references to the struggle of farmers, and their right to cultivate, which are deprived of access to water and land, and several parts of resources are sold to major economic interests.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I voted against this resolution. The European Parliament calls on the Commission and the Member States to use the motto of Expo 2015 in Milan ("Feeding the planet, energy for life") to "establish commitments to ensure the right to an adequate, healthy, sustainable and conscious diet". It is indeed true that Brussels dictates how the enlightened person has to feed himself! It goes without saying that a healthy and balanced diet is advisable, including support for local products and traditional dietary habits. But this should not be chewed up by Brussels! His diet is a matter for every single citizen whom I trust to choose the right choice for him or her.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is frankly inappropriate that the Expo in Milan, whose theme is "Feeding the planet: energy for life", uses As sponsor Mc Donald's, a company that offends and ridicules the flagship of Italian gastronomy and that is certainly not one of the symbols of adequate, healthy, sustainable and informed nutrition promoted by the Expo.  This universal exhibition could have been an excellent opportunity for Italy, a way to attract investment and boost the economy, but unfortunately there were soon criminal infiltrations, lobbyist interests and contracts under investigation. The initial project appeared to be designed to create a widespread and sustainable Expo, unfortunately this was not the case: more than two million square meters of land and hundreds of kilometers of motorways were cemented, when instead I would have expected more renovations and the reuse of abandoned buildings, the redevelopment of abandoned areas and the use of existing exhibition spaces. It could have been an opportunity to turn Milan into an example for others, to which citizens could contribute with pride, but it is proving to be a speculative finance operation.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I voted in favour of the Milano Expo 2015 resolution, a document that addresses food issues with a multidimensional approach. I think it is appropriate to call on the Commission to present policies that guarantee stability and sustainability to agricultural production systems and promote more effective use of resources.  I would like to end by expressing the hope that the Commission, together with the FAO Agency, will spend time on encouraging the worldwide implementation of the Guidelines for Responsible Governance of Land, Fisheries and Forest Ownership Regimes in the context of national food security.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 Expo 2015 will soon open its doors and is expected to welcome more than 20 million visitors. With the media watching exhibitors for the next six months, the whole world will be able to see innovations, technologies and new ways to feed and save our planet. It is inconceivable that in the 21st century we should combat hunger and poverty while throwing away an average of 30% of food a year. Expo 2015 may play an important role in consumer education, but I believe it will also activate many states to change legislation.
