National governments, food chains, but also ordinary households should bear in mind every day that in 2050 we will need 70% more food supplies than we do today.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. I voted against the resolution on EXPO 2015 because the final text is unfortunately unsatisfactory in many respects. In view of the reference to correct principles such as environmental and social sustainability and the promotion of healthier lifestyles, I regret, however, that Parliament did not have the courage to accept my group's proposal to include a clear censure of the fact that, paradoxically, multinationals such as Mc Donald's and Coca Cola are among the sponsors of this initiative. , companies that are an expression of precisely those eating habits that you would like to correct. Similarly, an amendment explicitly calling for gmos not to be used when it comes to innovation in the sector was rejected, and our amendment, already approved by the AGRI Committee, which aimed to support the organic and biodynamic chain, was also rejected. I cannot support this approach.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, how does one rebuild a society where violence has become part of everyday life? How does a country overcome structural problems such as poverty, systemic corruption and severe human and minority rights violations? Nigeria has one of the largest populations of young people and is one of the most ethnically diverse countries in Africa. The country is regionally divided between Christians and Muslims. The violence, after the 2011 elections and the Boko Haram killing sprees, further contributed to the instability of the country.  In short: all ingredients are there for a potential new civil war. The European Union trades with Nigeria, mainly for oil and gas, and in return we provide development aid. But I would like to see the EU engage more with Nigeria in long-term projects that aim at overcoming these structural issues. I believe herein lies the real key for stability and prosperity.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: in writing. This resolution strongly condemning the violence perpetrated by the terrorist group Boko Haram in Nigeria emphasizes the social and economic causes of the conflict in the country with the largest economy on the African continent, which, however, is one of the most unequal in the world, in which less than 10% of the population controls 90% of the wealth. It therefore calls for combating poverty, inequality, lack of educational opportunities and access to health through the promotion of an equitable distribution of oil revenues.  It also congratulates the Nigerian people on the holding of their last elections, urges the release of people abducted by Boko Haram, in particular more than 2,000 women and girls, denounces the recruitment of child soldiers and urges women victims of sexual violence to receive access to adequate sexual and reproductive health services, as well as to ensure the necessary medical assistance to the sick and injured without distinction. It also reiterates its call for the repeal of the law criminalizing homosexuality and the death penalty. For these reasons I supported this text with my vote.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution condemns the recent atrocities in northern Nigeria and urges the Nigerian authorities to fight Boko Haram. It welcomes military cooperation between Chad, Cameroon and Niger and supports regional cooperation in Africa. However, there are many elements that prevent me from voting in favour of this text. The proposal presescies the member states' assumption of African migrants. It calls on the international community to set up a European system to manage flows.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst agreeing with the sentiment of this resolution, I do not believe that calls for heavy EU involvement will make matters better and therefore I abstained on the resolution.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. The scourge of terrorism has left very deep marks in Nigeria. Despite being Africa's largest economy and also the largest country in terms of population, differences in ethnic and religious terms, as well as disparities in economic and social terms, fuel the violence that seriously threatens this state. The actions of the terrorist group Boko Haram have been condemned internationally, but unfortunately the initial response of the Nigerian authorities was not adequate, contributing to the distancing of the population from government institutions. This terrorist group has used the most atrocious and ignoble means to achieve its objectives and to spread terror not only in Nigeria but also in neighbouring countries. Its announced intention to combine efforts with the forces of the so-called Islamic State only reinforces the need for extended cooperation against those who want to spread terror.  It is important that efforts to combat terrorism are effective and supported. Only with the return of normality can we hope that Nigeria can resume the path of democracy and consolidate the steps it has tried to implement to establish a rule of law for all its inhabitants.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution condemning the massacre spree in Boko Haram in Nigeria. It calls on the Nigerian authorities to stop the attacks in the country as soon as possible. Nigeria's neighbours and international society are also encouraged to cooperate to prevent Boko Haram from receiving revenue. Once again, it is stressed that everything is needed to free 276 girls who were abducted from school more than a year ago. The newly elected President of Nigeria, Mr Buhari, is also being called upon to allocate funds and forces to fight Boko Haram, restoring security and stability in the country.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution poses more problems (interference) in my view than it solves, the support being purely moral. I therefore abstained on this text.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. The increasingly violent actions of Boko Haram and the increase in geographical areas controlled by this group raise fears of the worst for Nigeria, the most populous and ethnically diverse country on the African continent. The European Parliament condemns this violence and deplores the massacres of innocent people in the country. Parliament also calls on the international community to support the new Nigerian President in his fight against the Islamic group. However, Parliament notes that this fight against terrorism must be done with respect for human rights and the rule of law.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: In writing. This resolution aims to condemn the Boko Haram massacres and strengthen international cooperation with Nigeria. The situation is more than urgent: since 2009, 22,000 people have died as a result of Boko Haram, 2,000 women have been abducted, 1.5 million people have been displaced and 300,000 Nigerians have fled to escape the violence. In addition, the Boko Haram group has recently pledged allegiance to the terrorist group "Islamic State", and it is essential to stem its advance in the world.  The resolution supports the Nigerian government and calls for the strengthening of the army and multilateral cooperation between states, including to stop the flow of arms with neighbouring countries.  Nevertheless, this resolution applies the principle of interference, which I oppose in the name of the sovereignty of the nations.  I have therefore decided to abstain on this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution is balanced and unde controversy. I strongly condemn the violence perpetrated by Boko Haram in Nigeria and urge Europe and the international community to assist the Government of nigeria in the fight against Islamic terrorism.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. U2012 April 14 marked the first anniversary of the abduction of 276 Chibok schoolchildren for which little progress has been made in their release. Boko Haram's cruel actions have made him a real regional threat, which has led to a strengthening of cooperation between Nigeria, Cameroon, Chad and Niger.  The numbers are alarming, with more than 10,000 dead since 2009, more than half of them in 2014. In the recent presidential election there has been a shift in power and the former generation Muhammadu Buhari, who has prioritized the fight against violence, has been elected. The EU is committed to supporting regional efforts in combating this threat that has led to large movements of refugees and internally displaced persons. The fundamental issue of combating barbarism has led me to support this resolution, which, among other issues, calls on the Nigerian Government to promote women's participation in the public sphere and political life, and reiterates the European Parliament's call for the rule of the law against homosexuality and the death penalty.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: Written. ‒ Nigeria is the most poised and ethnically diverse country in Africa, characterised by north-south divisions and serious economic and social inequalities. Despite heavy oil supplies and economic potential, Nigeria has been extremely volatile in recent years and at one time did not control much of its territory.  Attacks by the terrorist group Boko Haram have left 1.5 million people in the states of Borno, Yobe and Adamawa, while more than three million people are suffering the effects of the insurgency. The situation is serious, but a peaceful tranision of power should be welcomed after a democratic election in which the opposition All-Presidential Congress candidate, General Muhammadu Buhari, won. I call on the President-elect to keep his campaign promises and use all resources to end Boko Haram's violence, bring back stability and security throughout the country and respond to the root causes of terrorism.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution because I strongly believe that it is our duty to take action against the barbaric terrorist activities of Boko Haram and, therefore, that we must support the people of Nigeria in their effort to fight all forms of terrorism in their country.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: in writing. \u2012 The recent elections in Nigeria showed victory for the leader of the Nigerian opposition, Muhammadu Buhari, a former governor, minister of oil and natural resources and head of the Supreme Military Council. He became the sixth President of the Federal Republic of Nigeria. As stated during the campaign, it will have to take firm action against the terrorist group Boko Haram. Boko Haram has killed more than 7,300 civilians in Nigeria and neighbouring countries since the beginning of 2014, 1,000 of them this year alone, reaching a worrying figure of 15,000 people from 2009 to today, a United Nations official announced earlier this month. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Nigeria, because urgent intervention is being sought on the nearly 300 girls kidnapped from the city of Chibok, only a few of whom managed to escape, and the Government and the Nigerian authorities, together with the Council of the African Union on Peace and Security, must do their utmost to rescue those kidnapped girls and fight terrorist groups through concrete actions in the Sahel region.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. Against Boko Haram and against the violence inflicted on Christians in Nigeria.

name: Alain CADEC
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on the situation in Nigeria. The country's democratic progress is undeniable. The recent election of opposition candidate President Muhammadu Buhari is a case in point. However, the threat from the terrorist group Boko Haram is growing by the day. The group even went so far as to claim its allegiance to the Islamic State. The disappearance of more than 270 female students is a tragedy that cannot be repeated. Boko Haram is seriously damaging the political stability of Nigeria and the entire region. This resolution highlights the importance for the international community to ally itself against Boko Haram and terrorism. By remaining united, we will be able to fight this scourge.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the motion for a resolution on the situation in Nigeria to call on the newly elected President Muhammadu Buhari to mobilise all necessary resources to put an end to the violence perpetrated by Boko Haram, restore stability and security throughout the country and address the root causes of terrorism, in particular by taking stronger action to combat internal corruption , mismanagement and inefficiencies within public institutions and the army, which are at the heart of its inability to cope with the scourge of Boko Haram in the north of the country. I also call on the international community to do more to assist the Nigerian Government in the fight against Boko Haram. In this respect, I support Chancellor Merkel's proposal that the EU should work together to finance an African military mission in Nigeria to combat Boko Haram jihadist terrorism.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution, which calls for an international response to the atrocities committed by Boko Haram. These actions are utterly deplorable and need to be condemned by all right-minded people. However, there were a number of roll call votes in which I tabled a negative vote as they were calling for a militaristic intervention. Sinn Féin has long rejected participation in any military alliance or foreign interference. We have consistently called for a greater focus on solving the causes of conflict, such as political and economic inequality and instability and the absence of democracy. Our own experience of conflict and conflict resolution has taught us that the path to peace is not to be found in increasing military intervention but in dialogue, inclusivity and equality. There is now a moral responsibility on us all, as societies, to show the same outrage at, and invest the same resources in addressing the causes and consequences of, an atrocity in Nigeria as we would if it were happening anywhere else, but that does not mean increased military intervention.

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: In writing. I preferred to abstain on this resolution. Indeed, Boko Haram has turned Nigerians into real cannon fodder. On 10 January, a 10-year-old girl was used to carry out a suicide attack, killing 10 people. The next day, two women also carried out an attack, killing four people and injuring more than 40. This is what we recognize an ideology: in the name of total war, we dehumanize, human life no longer counts and the culture of death becomes religious creed. I would like to express my full support to the Nigerian people in this war they must wage every day against terrorism. Because I support Nigeria, I will continue to respect the sovereign will of the Nigerian authorities not to call on international military assistance to fight Boko Haram.  Through its President Jonathan Goodluck, Nigeria has proudly and freely expressed its commitment to free itself from the terrorist yoke, calling for UN member states to contribute to the much-needed humanitarian aid and social reconstruction that Nigerians need.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 Nigeria plays a key role in regional and African policy and is a driver of regional integration through the Economic Community of West African States. However, due to the violence perpetrated by boko haram's terrorist organisation and the great social disparity, the region is still highly destabilised.  Therefore, welcoming the strengthening of cooperation with the Nigerian authorities in the fight against terrorism, I have decided to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly agree with the position of this Parliament when it states that Boko Haram cannot be defeated only with military interventions and that social integration measures are fundamental and must be promoted.  As Europeans we can play an important role in this sense. We can do more than just ask European oil companies based in Nigeria to respect international standards, to respect the local population and to avoid damaging the environment.  We have to be sure that the double standards effect is avoided.  One way to obtain this is to make a company liable and legally responsible not only before Nigerian courts but also before  European courts. This would set a positive example in the country and help promote social integration.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: in writing. This resolution strongly condemning the violence perpetrated by the terrorist group Boko Haram in Nigeria emphasizes the social and economic causes of the conflict in the country with the largest economy on the African continent, which, however, is one of the most unequal in the world, in which less than 10% of the population controls 90% of the wealth. It therefore calls for combating poverty, inequality, lack of educational opportunities and access to health through the promotion of an equitable distribution of oil revenues.  It also congratulates the Nigerian people on the holding of their last elections, urges the release of people abducted by Boko Haram, in particular more than 2,000 women and girls, denounces the recruitment of child soldiers and urges women victims of sexual violence to receive access to adequate sexual and reproductive health services, as well as to ensure the necessary medical assistance to the sick and injured without distinction. It also reiterates its call for the repeal of the law criminalizing homosexuality and the death penalty. For these reasons I supported this text with my vote.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: in writing. Although it does not enjoy the same "media coverage" as Islamic State, Nigeria's extremist group Boko Haram has killed between 10,500 and 18,000 people in the past four years, making it the most dangerous terrorist organization in the world, much higher than those committed by Islamic State (approximately 6,000). The violence committed by the Islamist group Boko Haram in northeastern Nigeria has also caused serious food crises, making it very difficult for humanitarian activists to reach the affected population. The humanitarian needs in Nigeria are enormous and, for this year, they amount to 922 million euros. The EU and its Member States must fulfil their commitment to provide political, humanitarian and development support to Nigeria and its citizens in combating the Boko Haram threat and ensuring the country's development.  It is important for the new Nigerian authorities to adopt a roadmap on social and economic development, to address the problems of poverty and inequality, promoting the equitable distribution of oil revenues in the context of decentralisation, as they are a cause of violence.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as the recent Boko Haram attacks and the growing violence in certain regions of the country are forcing persons to flee the country due to the instability in the region.  This is deplorable considering that Nigeria is the largest economy within the African continent and can help Africa’s overall economy to substantially grow. Further development in the area can also help to solve the immigration crisis that both continents are facing, at source.  Only by ensuring stability and security in the region can we also ensure that Nigeria addresses the high inequality and poverty rates which can act as a major economic push factor for irregular immigration.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This resolution strongly condemns the abuses committed in Nigeria by the terrorist group Boko Haram against civilian, governmental and military targets that could constitute crimes against humanity and expresses its solidarity with the People of Niger in the face of such barbarism. Considering that the European Union must mobilise all the means at its disposal to provide political, development and humanitarian assistance to Nigeria in order to end the threat posed by Boko Haram and ensure the country's development and democratic consolidation. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: In writing. Since 2009, Boko Haram's criminal activities have reportedly resulted in the deaths of 20,000 people. An estimated 300,000 Nigerian refugees have fled the violence. The terrorist sect indiscriminately targets all groups of the Nigerian population and pledged allegiance to the Islamic State group in the first half of 2015.  In this chaotic context, Nigerian power now appears to be weakened. That is why the European Parliament has a role in supporting the consolidation of parliamentary democracy in this country. I would particularly like to support the desire to do everything possible to prevent radicalisation and its root causes.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: In writing. The unprecedented violence perpetrated by Boko Haram has killed more than 22,000 people since 2009. The United Nations estimates that 1.5 million people, including 800,000 children, have been displaced as a result of violence in Borno, Yobe and Adamawa states. More than 300,000 Nigerians have taken refuge in northwestern Cameroon and southwestern Niger. The European Parliament's resolution condemns these acts of barbarism in the strongest possible terms.  Nigeria's newly elected President Muhammad Buhari will have to keep his campaign promises and deploy all the means at his disposal to restore stability and security throughout the country and address the root causes of this unspeakable terror.  Finally, it must be added that Europe must constantly denounce the atrocities perpetrated against women by Boko Haram, both physical violence and the prohibitions that strike them, including access to education.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. Nigeria Violence perpetrated by the terrorist group Boko Haram in Nigeria has already claimed more than 22,000 lives since 2009. The United Nations estimates that 1.5 million people (including 800,000 children) are displaced. I supported the resolution condemning the atrocities committed by Boko Haram. Nigeria's new president must deploy all necessary means to restore stability and security throughout the country. This includes strong action against internal corruption, mismanagement and inefficiency in public institutions and the military. The fight against terrorism is never an isolated fight. It is therefore the entire Economic Community of West African States and the African Union that must step up their response to Boko Haram terrorism and coordinate the fight against terrorist groups in the Sahel region. Without large-scale cooperation, violence will continue. The international community must help Nigerians who have fled to neighbouring countries. Every effort must also be made to free the 2,276 women and girls abducted by Boko Haram since last year.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution condemns the recent atrocities in northern Nigeria and urges the Nigerian authorities to fight Boko Haram. It welcomes military cooperation between Chad, Cameroon and Niger and supports regional cooperation in Africa. However, there are many elements that prevent me from voting in favour of this text. The proposal presescies the member states' assumption of African migrants. It calls on the international community to set up a European system to manage flows.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. Boko Haram is currently believed to control more than 50,000 square kilometres of northeastern Nigeria. There has been escalating violence - including the use of children as suicide bombers - threatening the security of West Africa as a whole. Along with the fight against Boko Haram, Nigeria faces numerous other challenges, including widespread corruption, poverty and a huge gap in economic inequality. As a result, nigeria's elections are crucial at a time in Nigeria's turbulent history, as they mark the first peaceful transition of power since britain declared independence in 1960. I think we need to give a good signal about what is happening in Nigeria, and that is why I supported the resolution.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. The situation of Christians in north-eastern Nigeria, the elections held at the end of March, the use of children as human bombs, the abduction of women and girls and the measures to be taken by the international community are problems that everyone should make us reflect. The local government has not been able to stop the atrocities that are being committed by Boko Haram, a group known as extremist. Its eradication is crucial because the group is seen as a threat to Africa's peace and security and global peace and security, even if there is a need to activate the Common Security and Defence Policy, defending the people of Nigeria and helping to eradicate Boko Haram.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. The situation in Nigeria is inseparable from the exploitation of its natural resources, in particular oil. Discovered in 1956, oil now accounts for 95% of export revenues and 80% of Nigeria's income. Run by six large multinational companies in partnership with the state, oil extraction does not all benefit in the same way. The country, the continent's third-largest economic power, ranks 158th in the UN Human Development Index.  70% of Nigerians live below the poverty line. Local employment is increasingly a mirage because once important resources, such as fishing or hunting, are increasingly at stake because of the impact of oil exploration and deforestation. Pollution has turned the Niger Delta into one of the most polluted places on the planet. This dramatic situation has created tensions in the region. In the early 1990s, conflicts broke out between multinationals and the various communities demanding fair compensation. The repressive and brutal response to these communities triggered other, increasingly radical responses, putting the country in a permanent state of war. Once again, we have the economic interests of capital at the root of conflicts in one of the richest countries on the African continent.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 We condemn the ongoing and increasingly brutal violence in Nigeria, including the use of children as suicide bombers. It is regrettable that the international community has so far taken no action to provide useful support to the Nigerian people in its fight against increasing violence and in solving social and economic problems. We must call for a thorough investigation into all allegations of human rights violations, including extrajudicial killings, torture or abuses in connection with extortion. We call for the unconditional release of more than 200 girls kidnapped by Boko Haram from a government school in chibok in April 2014.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution rightly condemns the violence perpetrated by Boko Haram which aims to establish a fully Islamic state in northern Nigeria with the introduction of sharia law. But the EU needs to do much more!

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the situation in Nigeria in its entirety because while an effort is needed to solve this serious problem, the report is spent on minor issues.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Terrorism is a global threat but the global community’s efforts to do more against Boko Haram in Nigeria depended to some degree on the full measure of credibility, accountability and transparency of the elections there. The electoral process was welcomed by international observers and it is now a national, regional and global responsibility to put all existing resources to use to bring an end to Boko Haram. Education, women’s rights, social justice and a fair distribution of state revenues in society, as well as the fight against corruption, must be at the forefront of the newly elected President’s political action, for they are key to fighting fundamentalism, violence and intolerance. The international community, including the EU, must provide the necessary support to the Nigerian Government, as the stability of the country is crucial for the whole region, the continent and, globally, the whole world. I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of the report.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: in writing. Nigeria is undoubtedly a country of contrasts: Africa's most populous country, with huge oil reserves, but whose wealth is not enjoyed by much of the population. It is also a country with a great ethnic and religious diversity, suffering the horrors of terrorism in the north of the country by the actions of the terrorist group Boko Haram, a serious threat to the security of the entire region. Nigeria's new president must fight terrorism firmly, as well as work for the social and economic development of northern and southern states to address the problems of poverty, inequality, educational opportunities and access to health, which are one of the causes of the spiral of violence. For our part, the EU must provide political, humanitarian and development assistance in all areas to Nigeria, as well as in the fight against Boko Haram.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. By adopting the resolution on the situation in Nigeria, I too would like to reiterate my strong condemnation of the continuing and increasingly alarming acts of violence perpetrated against the helpless populations, which have resulted in thousands of deaths and injuries and hundreds of thousands of displaced persons. I sympathise with the Nigerian people in their determination to combat all forms of terrorism in the country, after such tragic incidents that have spared no children, women and the elderly and have hit minorities, particularly Christian minorities, so hard.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Nigeria by condemning this the growing wave of violence suffered by the country over the actions of Boko Haram, which are producing a large number of civilian casualties. The Resolution also recognizes the importance of mobilizing domestic resources through fair tax systems that allow wealth and the benefit of natural resources to be redistributed as a key element in eliminating inequality and ensuring the good governance and reduction of violence that inequality itself generates. In addition, the Resolution recognizes the importance of defending the rights of women and LGBT groups threatened by the growing situation of violence.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because the EU, as one of the largest international organisations joining democratic states, must express its firm stance on the intolerable human rights violations that take place in Nigeria. The responsible Nigerian officials must take measures to stop any repression on the basis of religion or ethnic differences. The EU must immediately take measures in Nigeria to reconcile diplomacy and long-term development cooperation in order to ensure peace, security, good governance and respect for human rights.

name: Pablo IGLESIAS
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Nigeria by condemning this the growing wave of violence suffered by the country over the actions of Boko Haram, which are producing a large number of civilian casualties. The Resolution also recognizes the importance of mobilizing domestic resources through fair tax systems that allow wealth and the benefit of natural resources to be redistributed as a key element in eliminating inequality and ensuring the good governance and reduction of violence that inequality itself generates. In addition, the Resolution recognizes the importance of defending the rights of women and LGBT groups threatened by the growing situation of violence.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Nigeria is another African country that is under the tragic consequences of war conflicts in constant fear of attacks by ISIS-linked terrorist groups Boko Haram. The mass killings and tragedies that have occurred, especially in northern Nigeria, require immediate intervention by the international community. In the hope and faith that this Resolution of the European Parliament can only help to solve the situation in Nigeria and elsewhere in the world, I voted for the resolution in fact.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This motion for a resolution condemns the recent atrocities in northern Nigeria and urges the Nigerian authorities to fight Boko Haram. It welcomes military cooperation between Chad, Cameroon and Niger and supports regional cooperation in Africa. However, there are many elements that prevent me from voting in favour of this text. The proposal presescies the member states' assumption of African migrants. It calls on the international community to set up a European system to manage flows.

name: Seán KELLY
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support this motion for a resolution. Whilst newly elected president General Muhammadu Buhari is to be congratulated, along with all others who have successfully gained office in peaceful, democratic elections, the recent violence in Nigeria must be strongly condemned. The extreme violence perpetrated by Islamist jihadi extremist group Boko Haram that has resulted in thousands of deaths and destruction of properties since the turn of the year represents a great humanitarian atrocity which the EU must take a firm stance against. I give full support to the Nigerian authorities in committing all resources to ending the violence of Boko Haram, and in ensuring the release of the 287 missing Chibok school girls and other kidnapped persons. Such efforts will help to restore stability in Nigeria and its surrounding regions.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The continuous wave of violent acts committed by the terrorist sect Boko Haram constitutes a crime against humanity. Education, women’s rights, social justice and a fair distribution of state revenues in society, as well as the fight against corruption, must be at the forefront of the newly elected President’s political action, for they are key to fighting fundamentalism, violence and intolerance. We call on the European Union and its Member States to fulfil their commitment to providing a comprehensive range of political, development and humanitarian support to Nigeria and its people in tackling the Boko Haram threat and ensuring the development of the country.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. Abstention. National Front MEPs support the Nigerian authorities in their fight against Boko Haram Islamists, as well as any form of military aid that may be provided to it. We therefore welcome the regional military cooperation of Chad, Cameroon and Niger. But we reject the european Union's desire for interference, which appears in this resolution. In particular, it asks to take "... more aggressive measures..." to combat alleged corruption of the Nigerian army. There is clearly a willingness on the part of the European Union to take advantage of this conflict to try to put pressure on the Nigerian state authorities. I therefore abstain for that reason.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: in writing. This resolution strongly condemning the violence perpetrated by the terrorist group Boko Haram in Nigeria emphasizes the social and economic causes of the conflict in the country with the largest economy on the African continent, which, however, is one of the most unequal in the world, in which less than 10% of the population controls 90% of the wealth. It therefore calls for combating poverty, inequality, lack of educational opportunities and access to health through the promotion of an equitable distribution of oil revenues.  It also congratulates the Nigerian people on the holding of their last elections, urges the release of people abducted by Boko Haram, in particular more than 2,000 women and girls, denounces the recruitment of child soldiers and urges women victims of sexual violence to receive access to adequate sexual and reproductive health services, as well as to ensure the necessary medical assistance to the sick and injured without distinction. It also reiterates its call for the repeal of the law criminalizing homosexuality and the death penalty. For these reasons I supported this text with my vote.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Written. ‒ Nigeria has a population of more than 170 million according to 2013 data, and the population continues to grow. The problem in Nigerian society is regional, religious and social divisions. The state is divided north and south, and society into the extremely rich and extremely poor. I supported the European Parliament's resolution on the situation in Nigeria, which supports the commitment of all parties to democracy and the peaceful handover of power after the elections in March this year. The president-elect is expected to deliver on campaign promises and commit to fighting violence, and from the newly elected Government to commit to a social and economic development plan for northern and southern states and to conduct thorough investigations into human rights violations. In parallel, the resolution expresses Parliament's concern over serious human rights violations and armed and bombings, suicide bombings, kidnappings and other forms of violence by the Boko Haram terrorist sect. More than 1.5 million people have been displaced as a result of these attacks, and more than 3 million are suffering the effects of the attack.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: Writing. \u2012 The political situation in Nigeria increases economic and social tensions in the country while ingerising the security of the entire West African continent. Nigeria is also one of Africa's largest economies. By 2013, the European Union had provided this country with EUR 700 million, almost a third of which was for combating poverty and for consolidating peace and stability. The Government of Nigeria must urgently, with the help of international organisations and institutions, stop the activities of a terrorist Islamist organisation that is purposefully destroying Christians and exploiting people of its faith to achieve its political objectives. It should be stressed that the penetration of the activities of this terrorist organisation into other countries also poses a danger to the countries of the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution because I believe that the resolution fully describes the situation in Nigeria.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained. There is a need to fight Boko Haram and their massacres, and we support the Nigerian authorities in their actions. However, we also condemn the European interference suggested by this motion for a resolution.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing. \u2012 The Boko Haram terrorist group has taken control of several towns in northeast Nigeria. Since 2009, more than 22 000 people have died as a result of the violence. I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is necessary for the European Parliament not to miss an opportunity to express its outrage at any action that is attentive to the safety and well-being of citizens throughout the world. In particular, I supported the appeal made to the newly elected President of Nigeria, who had undertaken, during the election campaign, to mobilise all possible resources in the name of an end to the violence perpetrated by Boko Haram. The hope of the European Parliamentary Assembly is that he will honour his commitment, without reservation.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. Presidential elections have just ended in Nigeria despite Boko Haram attacks and intimidation. The resolution calls on the new government to establish more regional cooperation to combat the terrorist group. It highlights the root causes of Nigeria's problems (inequality, human rights, poverty, corruption, education, health, resource sharing and especially oil) rather than seeing it as a mere interfaith conflict. But it also calls for support for the Chadian army, local religious leaders and the EU's crisis management instrument. Nothing will be said about the EU's responsibility in these same crises. The Cotonou agreements are even described as ensuring the development of the country. The government's battle is primarily the fight against growing inequality that facilitates the recruitment by Boko Haram, including child soldiers.  Beyond Europe, it is the responsibility of the international community and the United Nations to determine the responsibilities of third countries in the organization and financing of terrorist groups in the region and the responsibility of multinationals and governments, including European ones, in the grabbing of wealth and the economic, social and cultural deepening of tensions that favours Boko Haram and its ally Daesh.   I abstain

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. It is necessary to fight Boko Haram and their massacres, and we support the Nigerian authorities in their actions. However, we also condemn the European interference suggested by this motion for a resolution.  I abstained.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ This joint resolution calls on the newly elected President of Nigeria to live up to his pledge to continue the fight against Boko Haram and defeat the militant group. It also urges religious leaders, both Christian and Muslim, not only to work together to combat radicalisation but also to work with civil society and public authorities. I applaud the efforts of the military coalition created by Nigeria and its neighbours, which has made significant gains against the terrorist group.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ Terrorism is a global threat but the global community’s efforts to do more against Boko Haram in Nigeria depended to some degree on the full measure of credibility, accountability and transparency of the elections there. The electoral process was welcomed by international observers and it is now a national, regional and global responsibility to put all existing resources to use to bring an end to Boko Haram. However, I voted against on the second part of paragraph 15, on sexual and reproductive health.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This resolution aims to condemn the massacres of Boko Haram while strengthening international cooperation with Nigeria. The situation is indeed urgent: since 2009, 22,000 people have died as a result of Boko Haram, 2,000 women have been abducted, 1.5 million people have been displaced, 300,000 Nigerians have taken refuge to escape the violence...  The resolution supports the Nigerian government and calls for military reinforcement and multilateral cooperation between states, including stopping arms flows with countries bordering Nigeria. MEPs also are encouraging the Nigerian authorities to cut off all Boko Haram resources in order to suffocate it.  However, in keeping with a long tradition of this Parliament, the resolution is not devoid of interference. There are some points of the point of injunctions to put pressure on the Nigerian government in a way that is favourable to it.  Respectful of the principle of non-interference, I have decided to abstain.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution on the situation in Nigeria, which condemns the massacre of innocent civilians by the Islamist sect Boko Haram. The text recalls that these terrorists engage in armed attacks, suicide bombings, sexual violence and kidnappings against civilian, governmental and military targets. Since the abduction last year of 276 schoolgirls, most of them Christian girls, an additional 2,000 women have been kidnapped. The resolution calls on the Nigerian government and the international community to mobilize to find and release the abductees. It also calls on the newly elected president to deploy all means at his disposal to neutralize Boko Haram.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. \u2012 A year ago, more than 270 girls were abducted from a public school in Chibok by the Boko Haram terrorist group. Since then, there has been constant violence and kidnapping in the country, which have bloodied the last months of the election campaign. We strongly condemn all the violence, the thousands of dead, injured and displaced. We deplore the massacre of men, women and children. We call on the newly elected President to keep all his election promises, putting an end to boko haram violence, re-establishing security throughout the country and, in particular, taking stronger action in the fight against internal corruption, mismanagement and inefficiencies in public institutions and the army.  We call on the new Nigerian authorities to adopt a roadmap for the social and economic development of the northern and southern states, to tackle the problems of poverty and inequality, to promote a fair distribution of oil revenues, which are often a cause of spiralling violence. The European Union must use all its instruments to promote these measures, including the possibility of using crisis management instruments, taking into account the key role that Nigeria plays in that regional context.

name: Alessandra MUSSOLINI
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering that nigeria's peace and stability are increasingly threatened by the Islamist militant group Boko Haram, which has been causing destruction in the country since 2009 by carrying out attacks, assassinations and kidnappings in an attempt to impose a strict form of Sharia law, overthrow the government and create an Islamic state, I have decided to vote in favour of the resolution because I believe that the international community must react and not stand still in the face of acts of violence such as these. Finally, I believe that the European Union and its Member States must respect their commitment to providing various forms of aid – political, development and humanitarian – to that country and its people and not leave them alone in the fight against the threat of Boko Haram.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. Nigeria was once famous for being at peace with 40% of the Christian population and 60% of muslims, and religious tolerance was a reality of everyday life. Then, a few years ago, the terrorist organization BOKO HARAM exploded, aiming to de-Christianize the country beyond overthrowing the government. A few years ago, no one would have believed that they would truly cause such chaos and tragedy to this country. The main Christian church leaders said the other day that what is happening is already beyond the limit that a person can withstand. I believe that Europe has a particular responsibility to help the persecuted Christians of the world. Since Europe is the cradle of Christianity, we are bound to these people by a religious and cultural thread that increases our responsibility to help. That is why I urge us to find ways to help and to support the already displaced at the place of persecution. It is our moral duty to actively and by all means help those in need.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. \u2012 Nigeria is the country with the largest population and ethnic diversity in Africa. It also has important regional and religious divisions, marked by a fracture between north and south characterized by serious economic and social disparities, with a young and fragile democracy, shaken by terrorist acts, but also extremist. I signed and voted on this resolution because, through its text, it introduces a number of measures that should be taken to support this State in the fight against terrorism and poverty, but also to support its economic development and ensure the decent living of its inhabitants.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: in writing. – I supported this joint resolution because I believe that the Boko Haram phenomenon poses a direct security threat not only to central but also to North Africa, but from there to the European Union.  Since Boko Haram's actions, more than 3 million civilians have been affected by their actions and more than 1.5 million have been forced to displace. More than 300,000 Nigerians have fled to neighbouring countries, some of them risking their lives by taking migrant routes to the EU in the hope of better economic and secure living conditions.  I am very concerned about Boko Haram's pledge of allegiance to the Islamic State, because apart from a common ideology, I fear that a moment of common action will come. Actions that have so far targeted local populations, including many Christians. I fear that the attacks could also be redirected to citizens of the European Union.  As a co-winner of the joint resolution, I also call on the European Commission to investigate Boko Haram's funding and to pay attention to trade in resources and goods that could originate in the areas where the organisation operates.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Resolution on events in Nigeria because I consider the atrocities committed by Boko Haram to be unacceptable. I believe that the European Parliament and the EU must react and condemn harsh atrocities such as suicide attacks in which children are used. I support this resolution, which calls on government authorities to intervene promptly against terrorists by taking measures to help educate the population and combat poverty and corruption.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: In writing. The resolution on the situation in Nigeria highlights the root causes of problems in Nigeria such as inequality, human rights, poverty, corruption, problems in education, health, or the issue of resource sharing, including oil. Mention is also made of the recent elections, which have gone rather well, as well as problems related to pollution, equality between men and women or anti-homosexual laws. I voted in favour of this relevant and balanced resolution.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution. The situation in Nigeria is dire. Attacks by the terrorist group Boko Haram have been increasing. They have kidnapped hundreds of women and children who cannot be found, torture and kill men and the elderly, use 10-year-old children to detonate bombs on marketplaces and attack schools, killing hundreds of people. Boko Haram must be stopped, and it will require nigeria's newly elected president to effectively engage in both the fight against terrorism and corruption. In order to combat Boko Haram, effective cooperation is also needed with the countries bordering Nigeria and with the African Union, and the European Union must make every effort to do so.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 Having viewed the statements by the Vice-President/High Representative on the situation in Nigeria, Whereas Nigeria is the largest economy on the African continent and one of the EU's main trading partners, and whereas between 2009 and 2013 EU aid to Nigeria amounted to around EUR 700 million, of which EUR 200 million was earmarked for the consolidation of peace and stability, the fight against poverty and the creation of employment opportunities for young people (former militants) in the Niger Delta, for these reasons I would vote in favour.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒ While the eyes of the world were on France and the terrorist attack on the newsroom of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo, Nigerian terrorists from Boko Haram killed 2,000 people, mostly Christians, and this news remained completely ignored in the world's media and in political circles. The massacre in Nigeria had the scale of genocide, with many Nigerians fleeing their homes in front of terrorists.  No one has talked about it and no one has organised a protest, and the numbers are frightening: around 13,000 killed since 2009 - more than half of that number during 2014, 1.5 million internally displaced people in Nigeria, 155,000 refugees in Niger, 37,000 in Cameroon and 11,000 in Chad. In 2014, More than 200 girls were abducted by Boko Haram, and in 2015 400 women and children lost all trace. Regardless of its natural resources, Nigeria remains one of the countries with the highest inequalities in the world.  Peace and stability in Nigeria have been constantly threatened by the Boko Haram group since 2009, with most of their victims being children, women and the elderly. I believe that the High Representative must propose concrete measures that the EC will take to protect human rights in Nigeria until it is too late.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 Attacks by Boko Haram's fundamentalist militiamen between January 3 and January 8, 2015, targeting the city of Baga and sixteen surrounding towns and villages in northeast Nigeria, destroying nearly 3,700 structures and killing more than 2,000 people, represented the terrorist group's bloodiest massacre, the protagonist of a full-faceted war with the Nigerian government. This resolution expresses a total condemnation of the barbarity and atrocities that the Nigerian population, without any discrimination – Christians, Muslims, teachers, students, farmers, traders, women and children – has been forced to endure for far too long, and expresses support for the new government and president Buhari elected on 14 February, whose victory represents a turning point for Nigeria and for the whole of Africa. The EU will support the new government to take greater responsibility for taking concrete action to combat terrorism, corruption, poverty and inequality in the country and to restore a future and hope to the Nigerian people.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ The current growing violence in Nigeria in which thousands have been killed and wounded and hundreds of thousands more displaced is absolutely unacceptable which is why I join in my expressions of regret over the massacre committed against innocent men, women and children and support for the Nigerian people in its determination to fight all forms of terrorism in its state. I hope that the president-elect will keep his campaign promises and use all resources to end Boko Haram's violence, bring back stability and security throughout the country and respond to the root causes of this terrorism and, in particular, act more decisively in the fight against internal corruption, mismanagement and inefficiency in public institutions and the military that have rendered them unable to fight boko haram's sedum in the north of the country. , and will adopt measures to deprive Boko Haram of its source of illicit income, in particular in relation to smuggling and illicit trafficking.  Regional cooperation will be of utmost importance, which is why I welcome the determination shown by the 13 participating countries at the Niamey Regional Summit on 20 and 21 January 2015. The European Union also needs to fulfil its commitments and provide comprehensive political, development and humanitarian support to Nigeria and its population in combating the threat posed by Boko Haram and ensuring the development of that state.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. ‒ The serious deterioration of the security situation in Nigeria over the past two years is worrying. Strengthening the fundamentalist Islamist group Boko Haram in the north of the country, and in particular in the countries of Borno, Yobe and Adamawa, is a challenge that goes beyond the Nigerian state with its seriousness and its stoppage is also of utmost importance for the European Union.  Continuing attacks on civilian facilities, churches, villages, systematic persecution of Christians, still unadjusted 270 schoolgirls abducted from a school in the town of Chibok a year ago, the January massacre in the town of Baga with hundreds of civilians killed, more than 15,000 lives lost, over a million displaced persons and refugees testifying to the urgent need to stifle the insurgency. Unfortunately, the Nigerian military does not appear to have the financial, technical and operational capabilities to independently stop the jihadist group from operating. President-elect Buhari, who takes office on May 29th, therefore has high expectations. In addition to the priority issue of counter-terrorism, the new administration will also have to seriously address the issue of extremely widespread corruption and weak state institutions that impede the more efficient use of development aid and the use of abundant natural resources. Building an effective administration and state institutions is a prerequisite for ensuring peace, stability and growth.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 I am very concerned about the escalation of violence that has recently taken place in Nigeria by the Boko Haram terrorist sect, which chooses civilian, government and military targets indiscriminately with attacks carried out with firearms and bombs causing massacres of men, women and children and a large number of displaced persons. The newly elected President must take drastic action to put an end to the violence perpetrated by the Boko Haram sect in the country. Nigeria needs to restore a climate of stability and security and to take measures to combat corruption and inefficiencies in public institutions, which are one of the main causes of boko haram's spread. I hope that the Nigerian authorities will react decisively to the terrorist threat and address the issues of primary need for the country, such as poverty and existing inequality, child labour and access to health care, by establishing a roadmap for a more uniform development of the southern and northern parts of the country.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on the situation in Nigeria because I consider the rampage of the terrorist organisation Boko Haram to be scandalous. We are witnessing the murder, rape, abduction and burning of churches or schools. The victims are mainly Nigerian Christians, but unfortunately the criminal acts of extremists also suffer from muslim citizens of Nigeria and surrounding states. I believe that the new Nigerian Government will take further steps to combat Boko Haram and will do so with respect for human rights.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. In the face of the very worrying situation currently destabilizing Nigeria, the European Parliament wished to denounce the atrocity of the situation. With this resolution, which I strongly support, MEPs have condemned by a very large majority the current violence in Nigeria, including the use of children for the purpose of violence. Parliament calls on the international community to respond and organize itself to help these people and to organise firm action to put an end to this violence and to combat the threat posed by Boko Haram.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. Nigeria is the most populous and ethnically diverse country in Africa, and is also characterised by regional disparities and religious divides, as well as a North-South divide marked by severe economic and social disparities. Nevertheless, despite the impending economic crisis, Nigeria occupies a top place in the economy of the African continent and is therefore an important trading partner of the EU. It does not, however, enjoy a consolidated democracy and a history that will give it a long time. In this context, the attacks by Boko Haram between 3 and 8 January 2015 against Baga and sixteen neighboring towns and towns caused the destruction of 3,700 structures and the deaths of thousands of people, ushering in a climate of continued violence and permanent insecurity. This resolution strongly condemns the crimes, suffering and damage inflicted by the Boko Haram sect, and also calls on the new Nigerian authorities to take up a roadmap for social and economic development. I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, which calls on the EU and its Member States to honour their external commitments in the political and humanitarian aid indispensable to Nigeria's development.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: In writing. At noon, the EP gave its support to Nigeria's new President in his fight against Boko Haram. His challenge is daunting: to put an end to the violence of the rebel group and bring security and serenity back to his country. Nigeria is the largest economy on the African continent. Despite immense resources, it is one of the most unequal countries in the world: more than 70% of its population lives on less than $1.25 a day when 10% controls more than 90% of the wealth. Since 2009, the country has been at a blood, teetering on the face of the madness of the terrorist movement Boko Haram.  Anyone who does not adhere to his extreme dogmatic convictions is executed, beaten, raped, sequestered.  In April 2014, the world was moved by the abduction of more than 270 girls from a public school in the city of Chibok. We remember that, the poignant awareness campaign #bringbackourgirls. But how many more since then?  Nigeria needs help. The international community will need to redouble its efforts to combat the root causes of this form of terrorism: corruption, trafficking, embezzlement,...  The recent rescue of nearly 300 girls and women in the Sambisa forest gives hope...#MRK

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. U2012 April 14 marked the first anniversary of the abduction of 276 Chibok schoolchildren for which little progress has been made in their release. Boko Haram's cruel actions have made him a real regional threat, which has led to a strengthening of cooperation between Nigeria, Cameroon, Chad and Niger.  The numbers are alarming, with more than 10,000 dead since 2009, more than half of them in 2014. In the recent presidential election there has been a shift in power and the former generation Muhammadu Buhari, who has prioritized the fight against violence, has been elected. The EU is committed to supporting regional efforts in combating this threat that has led to large movements of refugees and internally displaced persons. The fundamental issue of combating barbarism has led me to support this resolution, which, among other issues, calls on the Nigerian Government to promote women's participation in the public sphere and political life, and reiterates the European Parliament's call for the rule of the law against homosexuality and the death penalty.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: In writing. This resolution, which I supported, strongly condemns the wave of armed and bomb attacks, suicide bombings, sexual slavery and other forms of sexual violence, abductions and other acts of violence committed by Boko Haram against civilian, governmental and military targets in Nigeria. Since 2009, Boko Haram violence has killed more than 22,000 people. The United Nations estimates that 1.5 million people, including 800,000 children, have been displaced by violence in Nigeria. Parliament called on the Nigerian authorities to do all they can to end the violence and combat the root causes of terrorism, including corruption. He also urged neighbouring countries and the international community to cooperate to cut off Boko Haram's financial resources. The text also reminds us that every step must be done to find and free the 276 girls that Boko Haram abducted from a school near Chibok more than a year ago, and the 2,000 or so additional girls and women who have since been abducted.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 Following our previous Resolutions on Nigeria, notably our last debate in the plenary session of 14/01 last, we have once again seen to condemn the appalling actions of Boko Haram, who pass, as described in this Joint Resolution by slavery practices, forced marriages, sexual violence, abductions, forced and massive displacement of populations, recruitment of children for terrorist acts and their use as suicide bombers, horrendous inhuman acts, which have been extended to neighbouring countries such as Chad or Cameroon, and which have to be put to an immediate stop. Therefore, our support for the initiatives of the Council for Peace and Security of the African Union, the determination expressed by the 13 countries participating in the Regional Summit of Niamey (last January) and, in particular, the military commitment made by Chad, Cameroon and Nigeria to fight Boko Haram. I also support the new Nigerian President, whom we expect to take firm action against these criminals, and the Nigerian people, for their democratic enthusiasm and their recent mobilisation in the electoral process. And our constant appeal to the European Commission and the Member States to use all means at their disposal to end these inhuman atrocities.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 What is happening in Nigeria is so serious that the European Parliament could not fail to intervene. To this end, I have contributed by voting in favour of this resolution, which condemns the various attacks carried out by Boko Haram and their willingness to establish an entirely Islamic state, when not all people are. We must think that Nigeria is the largest economy on the African continent and a state cannot be destroyed because of the atrocities committed by these terrorists. Parliament therefore called on the new President, among other things, to keep all the fine promises he made during the election campaign and to put an end to the atrocities perpetrated by Boko Haram.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Nigeria by condemning this the growing wave of violence suffered by the country over the actions of Boko Haram, which are producing a large number of civilian casualties. The Resolution also recognizes the importance of mobilizing domestic resources through fair tax systems that allow wealth and the benefit of natural resources to be redistributed as a key element in eliminating inequality and ensuring the good governance and reduction of violence that inequality itself generates. In addition, the Resolution recognizes the importance of defending the rights of women and LGBT groups threatened by the growing situation of violence.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing. This resolution strongly condemning the violence perpetrated by the terrorist group Boko Haram in Nigeria emphasizes the social and economic causes of the conflict in the country with the largest economy on the African continent, which, however, is one of the most unequal in the world, in which less than 10% of the population controls 90% of the wealth. It therefore calls for combating poverty, inequality, lack of educational opportunities and access to health through the promotion of an equitable distribution of oil revenues.  It also congratulates the Nigerian people on the holding of their last elections, urges the release of people abducted by Boko Haram, in particular more than 2,000 women and girls, denounces the recruitment of child soldiers and urges women victims of sexual violence to receive access to adequate sexual and reproductive health services, as well as to ensure the necessary medical assistance to the sick and injured without distinction. It also reiterates its call for the repeal of the law criminalizing homosexuality and the death penalty. For these reasons I supported this text with my vote.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted in support of the joint motion for a resolution on the situation in Nigeria. We condemn the ongoing and increasingly disturbing violence, including the continuing wave of gun and bomb attacks, suicide bombings, sexual slavery and other sexual violence, kidnappings and other violent acts committed by the terrorist sect Boko Haram against civilian, government and military targets in Nigeria, which have led to thousands of deaths and injuries and have displaced hundreds of thousands of people, and which could constitute crimes against humanity.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this motion. The idea behind the motion is good but unfortunately it had mistaken elements in it – calling, for example, for sexual and reproductive rights. Therefore I could not vote in favour.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – Nigeria is the largest economy on the African continent and an important trading partner of the EU, so recent atrocities in northern Nigeria cannot leave us indifferent. Between 2009 and 2013, the EU provided around EUR 700 million to Nigeria, which was designed to consolidate peace and stability, combat poverty and create new jobs for young people. More recently, peace and stability in Nigeria have been increasingly threatened by the militant Islamist group Boko Haram, which has been causing devastation since 2009 in the form of a series of bombings, murders and kidnappings, while trying to enforce a strict form of Sharia law, overthrow the government and create an Islamic State. The ongoing and escalating violence in Nigeria must be strongly condemned and joint international efforts must focus on ending the bloodshed. The Nigerian Government, with the support of the EU, but also with the support of the international community, must take measures to combat the threat posed by Boko Haram, but these measures must comply with international law.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: Writing. Nigeria has been battling large-scale violence in the country by the fundamentalist Islamist organisation Boko Haram since 2009. The latter killed more than 22,000 civilians between 2009 and 2015. Terrorist attacks and violence take place mainly in the northern part of Nigeria. By the end of 2014, more than 1.5 million people had fled conflict zones. Boko Haram wants to establish an Islamic state in Nigeria that will practice Shiite law and where education will be banned. The 90th-2016 election, the 9th-seeded Nigeria crisis, the security problem has only made it worse. In addition, the differences between the northern and southern parts of the country are constantly growing, which are developing very unevenly. The unemployment rate and poverty are much higher in the northern part of the country than in the southern part. I strongly condemn any attacks on innocent people in Nigeria, kidnappings, killings and other types of violence. It should be made clear that the European Parliament is strongly opposed to all types of acts of violence, and I, too, supported that resolution and voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Written. ‒Between January 3 and January 8, 2015, the terrorist group Boko Haram carried out an attack on the Nigerian city of Baga and 16 nearby towns and villages, with nearly 3,700 structures destroyed and thousands killed, according to satellite images. More than 22,000 people have died as a result of the violence caused by Boko Haram since 2009. The attack on Baga was also an attack on European values, with Boko Haram establishing a caliphate in northern Nigeria becoming a global threat such as jihadists in Syria, Iraq or Libya.  I supported this resolution, which strongly condemns the ongoing violence in Nigeria, which is taking on increasingly horrific proportions, including a large number of armed and bombing attacks, suicide bombings, sexual slavery and other forms of sexual violence, kidnapping and other forms of violence that are responsible for the terrorist group Boko Haram, targeting civilians, the government and military targets in Nigeria, and in which hundreds of thousands of people have been killed , wounded or displaced, which could lead to crimes against humanity.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on the situation in Nigeria, as I believe that the European Parliament must also make a clear statement on the current situation and condemn the violence of the terrorist organisation Boko Haram, which has sworn allegiance to the so-called 'terrorist organisation'. The Islamic State, which is killing thousands of people in northern Nigeria, not just Christians, but everyone else who opposes its extreme inhuman ideology of violence and hatred and its efforts to create a Sharia-based state in northern Nigeria. At the same time, the European Parliament expresses its support for the democratically elected authorities of Nigeria and calls on them to combat all forms of discrimination, to continue to build a democratic society and to prevent widespread corruption, which, inter alia, prevents the effective use of the armed forces against terrorist organisations. The European Parliament is also right to appeal to the use of all forms of international development aid in order to improve living conditions in nigeria's less developed regions and cooperation between the countries of the region.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The proposed solutions inflate rather than lead to the resolution of the problem. Such an approach will allow illegal immigration to continue to flourish and will create further problems in Europe.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution. We strongly condemn the increasingly destabilizing violence currently against Nigeria, including the use of children to carry out suicide bombings in which thousands of people have been killed or injured and hundreds of thousands more displaced. The massacres of innocent men, women and children cannot go unpunished and we, alongside the Nigerian people, are determined to fight all forms of terrorism in the country. We call for concerted international action to end the bloodshed, but we nevertheless believe that such action must be driven by increased regional cooperation between States and other stakeholders!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Boko Haram’s violence has led to more than 22 000 deaths since 2009. Moreover, according to the UN, the violence in Borno, Yobe and Adamawa states has displaced 1.5 million people, including 800 000 children, and more than 3 million people have been affected by the insurgency. In this context of extreme violence and instability, I supported the resolution condemning the wave of violent acts committed by Boko Haram against civilian, government and military targets in Nigeria. The resolution is also a reminder that everything must be done to find and free the more than 200 girls still missing after they were abducted by Boko Haram from their school in Chibok, as well as all the persons abducted since then. By supporting this resolution, I urge the Nigerian authorities to do their utmost to end the violence and tackle the root causes of the terrorism, including corruption, and I call on Nigeria’s neighbours and the international community to cooperate to fight against Boko Haram.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Nigeria by condemning this the growing wave of violence suffered by the country over the actions of Boko Haram, which are producing a large number of civilian casualties. The Resolution also recognizes the importance of mobilizing domestic resources through fair tax systems that allow wealth and the benefit of natural resources to be redistributed as a key element in eliminating inequality and ensuring the good governance and reduction of violence that inequality itself generates. In addition, the Resolution recognizes the importance of defending the rights of women and LGBT groups threatened by the growing situation of violence.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: In writing. The resolution condemns the massacres perpetrated by Boko Haram. I support this initiative but strongly condemn the various obvious attempts to interfere in the internal affairs of this sovereign country. It becomes infuriating to study these sanctimonious texts. I choose the ABSTENTION.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: in writing. In 2012 We voted in favour of the Resolution on the situation in Nigeria by condemning this the growing wave of violence suffered by the country over the actions of Boko Haram, which are producing a large number of civilian casualties. The Resolution also recognizes the importance of mobilizing domestic resources through fair tax systems that allow wealth and the benefit of natural resources to be redistributed as a key element in eliminating inequality and ensuring the good governance and reduction of violence that inequality itself generates. In addition, the Resolution recognizes the importance of defending the rights of women and LGBT groups threatened by the growing situation of violence.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: in writing. We note with concern the events taking place in North Africa and the emergence of terrorist groups such as Boko Haram or the Islamic State. It is necessary to prevent any coordination or cooperation of these groups. In this respect, the situation in Nigeria must be followed carefully, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of resolutions such as these, which draw attention to a problem of great interest to Europe.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: in writing. This resolution strongly condemning the violence perpetrated by the terrorist group Boko Haram in Nigeria emphasizes the social and economic causes of the conflict in the country with the largest economy on the African continent, which, however, is one of the most unequal in the world, in which less than 10% of the population controls 90% of the wealth. It therefore calls for combating poverty, inequality, lack of educational opportunities and access to health through the promotion of an equitable distribution of oil revenues.  It also congratulates the Nigerian people on the holding of their last elections, urges the release of people abducted by Boko Haram, in particular more than 2,000 women and girls, denounces the recruitment of child soldiers and urges women victims of sexual violence to receive access to adequate sexual and reproductive health services, as well as to ensure the necessary medical assistance to the sick and injured without distinction. It also reiterates its call for the repeal of the law criminalizing homosexuality and the death penalty. For these reasons I supported this text with my vote.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: In writing. Nigeria is the most populous and ethnically heterogeneous country in Africa.  The abuses of Boko Haram and in particular violence against women must of course be firmly condemned. But far from being satisfied with this condemnation, the text raises the question of the root causes of the problems in Nigeria. Among them are inequality in a country where 10% of the population controls 90% of the country's wealth and in particular oil.  Poverty, corruption, human rights violations, including those of women and homosexuals, the death penalty and deep gaps in education and health keep people in poverty. As we know, misery is the breeding ground for radicalization.  I voted in favour of this resolution, which also calls for a regional response in accordance with international law and welcomes the good conduct of the presidential elections.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. The problem of oil exploration is the true source of the current crisis in Nigeria. Discovered in 1956, oil now accounts for 95% of export revenues and 80% of Nigeria's income.
