Run by six large multinational companies in partnership with the state, oil extraction does not all benefit in the same way The country, the third economic power of the continent, ranks 158th in the Human Development Index. We're talking about one of the biggest organized outings. 70% of Nigerians live below the poverty line. Local employment is increasingly a mirage because once important resources, such as fishing or hunting, are increasingly at stake because of the impact of oil exploration and deforestation. Pollution has turned the Niger Delta into one of the most polluted places on the planet. This dramatic situation has created tensions in the region. In the early 1990s, conflicts broke out between multinationals and the various communities demanding fair compensation. The state's extremely brutal response fueled increasingly radical responses, putting the country in a state of permanent war. Once again, we have the economic interests of capital at the root of conflicts in one of the richest countries on the African continent.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. I tabled the eCR group's motion for a resolution and also signed the joint motion for a resolution on behalf of my group. That is why I agree with this resolution. The concrete Islamist terror threat in Germany, Europe and the world forces a social debate about the relationship between Islam and violence. However, the EU is not well equipped to discuss Islam, because, despite many lip service to supposedly Western values, it has a very unexplained relationship with the Christian-cultural roots of Europe. For example, of all things – but not unexpectedly – EP President Martin Schulz (SPD) is highly official denying Europe's Christian heritage. For Christians: No violence in the name of religion. This was made clear by Pope Benedict XVI, head of the largest religious community in the world, in his "Lectio magistralis" in Regensburg on 12 September 2006. We should all stick to this.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Writing. \u2012 The situation in Nigeria cannot be summarized on a few lines or pages. Last year alone, the terrorist organisation Boko Haram killed more than 4000 people and kidnapped 900. It's not just some numbers, but behind every number is the fate of a particular person. The tragedy not only affects individuals, but families suffer. So it's the stories of families who are being kidnapped by daughters and sons to become child soldiers. Women and girls become sex slaves. Presidential elections in Nigeria could be a good signal of change. Political leaders have a unique chance to start addressing the country's deep-rooted social and economic problems, but at the same time they must ensure that their army is equipped with all available means. Changes in attitude concern the whole region. Even the surrounding states can no longer pretend that they are not affected by Boko Haram. All the more so when the organization declared an alliance with the Islamic State in March 2015.

name: Inês Cristina ZUBER
text: in writing. The problem of oil exploration is the true source of the current crisis in Nigeria. Discovered in 1956, oil now accounts for 95% of export revenues and 80% of Nigeria's income. Run by six large multinational companies in partnership with the state, oil extraction does not all benefit in the same way. The country, the continent's third-largest economic power, ranks 158th in the Human Development Index. We're talking about one of the biggest organized outings. 70% of Nigerians live below the poverty line. This dramatic situation has created tensions in the region. In the early 1990s, conflicts broke out between multinationals and the various communities demanding fair compensation. The state's extremely brutal response fueled increasingly radical responses, putting the country in a state of permanent war. Once again, we have the economic interests of capital at the root of conflicts in one of the richest countries on the African continent, conflicts that eu interference has sharpened.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the extraordinary debate on the death penalty in Indonesia (2015/2687(RSP)." I would point out to Members that there is no catch-the-eye procedure in this debate and that no blue cards are adopted.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I welcome the opportunity of this emergency debate. The execution of the eight prisoners in Indonesia has disappointed and saddened us, as well as the wider international community. I am sure honourable Members will join in expressing our profound disappointment. The EU holds a strong and principled position against the death penalty, in all cases and in all circumstances, and works towards the abolition of the death penalty worldwide. This is a top EU foreign policy objective and priority in our external human rights policy. It is also evidenced by the commitments in the EU Guidelines on the death penalty, the first ever human rights guidelines adopted by the Council in 1998 and subsequently revised, most recently in 2013.  The European Union believes that the death penalty is cruel and inhuman and has not been shown in any way to act as a deterrent to crime. The European Union regards the abolition of the death penalty as essential for the protection of human dignity, as well as for the progressive development of human rights. Any miscarriage of justice – which is inevitable in any legal system – is irreversible. These latest executions are particularly outrageous, since, according to the United Nations, drug offences do not meet the definition of serious crimes. Through its foreign policy, the European Union contributes to worldwide efforts towards abolition. Between 1993 and 2012, the number of countries that abolished the death penalty by law for all crimes grew from 55 to 97. As of December 2012, 140 countries – more than two-thirds of the countries of the world – were abolitionist in law or practice. Unfortunately, the picture is mixed in Asia. Pakistan is the most recent worrying example: since the breach of the longstanding moratorium and the resumption of executions on terrorism perpetrators, executions have already reached 100 this year. The wider region comprises countries like China, Iraq, Iran and Saudi Arabia – ranking among the highest worldwide in terms of executions – whilst a large majority of Asian countries legally retain the death penalty. Five Asian countries have abolished the death penalty: Bhutan, Cambodia, Nepal, Mongolia and the Philippines. This contrasting regional picture is marked by movements both towards restricting the use of death penalty – in China, Singapore and Thailand – and towards resuming executions – in India, Indonesia, Malaysia, Pakistan and Vietnam – or re—strengthening the legal base for the death penalty – in Brunei and the Maldives.  Indonesia, as a successful example of transition to democracy, has a particularly important role in South East Asia. Indonesia is the key player and ‘swing state’ in ASEAN, representing some 40% of its GDP and population. It is an emerging global player and a member of the G20 with one of the fastest growing middle classes in the world, as well as the world’s largest Muslim population. Indonesia has the world’s fourth largest population (250 million people), is the third largest democracy and one which shares most, but unfortunately not all, of our values.  The irony is that these executions have been carried out in the full democratic glare of a country that is arguably one of the freest and most democratic countries in South East Asia with a powerful and active parliament and a vibrant and dynamic civil society. It has been agonising for the prisoners and their families as the events unfolded in slow motion.  Turning now to what concrete activities we have undertaken, the High Representative has made three statements deeply regretting the use of the death penalty in Indonesia, and the European Union has worked closely together with the Member States which have nationals on death row. The High Representative/Vice-President has called on the Indonesian authorities to stop all pending executions and move towards a definitive moratorium. The EU authorities have also used all our different diplomatic channels to raise the issue of the death penalty with their Indonesian counterparts. We also intend to launch shortly a regional awareness campaign entitled ‘moving away from the death penalty in South East Asia’ which will be led by local civil society organisations and individuals. I also know that honourable Members of this House have been active in trying to persuade the Indonesian Government of the need to abolish the death penalty and in efforts to prevent further executions.  We have been clear in all our interventions that we fully respect Indonesia’s sovereignty. We have also offered political support and practical assistance in combating the trade in narcotics and other criminal activities, which pose challenges to Indonesian society and beyond. Let me assure you that we will continue to engage with the Indonesian authorities on the use of the death penalty. I very much look forward to hearing the views of the honourable Members.  Thank you for your attention.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, we are not magistrates, judges or lawyers here, so it is not up to us to decide the guilt or innocence of the defendants who are tried by the Indonesian justice system. But we are public officials, elected in our nations by citizens to represent values, who today command us to demand that the Indonesian authorities, like all litigants, have the right to fair trials, respecting the law and procedures of the defence, all things that have not been granted to a French national now threatened with execution in Indonesia. We are elected public officials who have a duty to condemn the death penalty, as you have just done. The death penalty is banned by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. We are also elected officials and human beings who have a duty to be outraged at the macabre scenes that are now accompanying the execution of convicts in Indonesia, as in other countries you have quoted, Commissioner. We're running out of time. The European Union is a partner of Indonesia. Last November, we held a dialogue on human rights between the European Union and Indonesia in Jakarta. We have an agreement on cooperation and partnership with Indonesia. We provide Indonesia, through regional funds, with funds for its higher education, for its good governance. We cannot fail to be heard by the Indonesian authorities. I therefore call on European officials - some of whom should be in Jakarta today to defend European nationals - to go further than extremely polite and dignified diplomatic communiqués or approaches, which have not yet produced their effects. This issue is absolutely essential today for European nationals who ask for our help. I count on you to convey to the Indonesian authorities a message of firmness, which does not in any way violate their sovereignty or their right to fight narcotics and drugs. However, it is not by applying the death penalty to a French citizen, as the Indonesian justice system is doing today, that this fight will be brought to an end.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: – Mr President, I just want to ask under Rule 162(6) how you cancel ‘catch-the-eye’, because it says the remaining parts of a debate ‘shall’ be allocated not ‘may’ be allocated. I am not making a stale technical point here. I wanted to raise the case of a lady in my constituency who is currently on death row in Indonesia for very similar charges to the recent executions and she was sentenced to death, despite the prosecution having asked for only a prison sentence. So I do want to raise that point if possible please.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Arnott, I would like to thank Mr Arnott for his work We have rules here, and the rules mean that we now have an extraordinary debate here. It was decided that we do not have a catch-the-eye procedure and no blue card. The Rules of Procedure also state that, when you raise a point of order, you should only raise a point of order and not on the content. Otherwise, I will take the floor from you much more quickly in the future.

name: Edouard MARTIN
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Mr. President, a country is great not only in its power but, beyond that, in the brilliance of the ideas, causes and generosity it intends to bring to the privileged moments of its history. Ladies and gentlemen, this statement is not mine: it is signed by Robert Badinter when he was guard of the Seals of France in 1981. Well, it is the same message that I want to send, on behalf of the European Parliament, to the Indonesian authorities.  Yes, Mr. President Widodo, you can be great, your generosity can burst in the face of the world, if your power serves life. You wanted to send a strong message to Indonesian citizens and the rest of the world? It's done. No one can doubt your fierce desire to eradicate drugs and its trafficking. You have just executed eight citizens of the world: two Australians, one Brazilian, four Africans and one Indonesian. According to the association Together Against the Death Penalty, there are about 100 prisoners on death row in Indonesia.  What else do you want to prove? Do you know the level of suffering and intense psychological torture suffered by death row inmates and their families? Endless years waiting for a trial that is not really one, years hoping for a glimmer of humanity in the eyes of their tormentors, years of hoping for an awakening of justice's conscience, so that it is just and determined to bring out the truth. Unbearable seconds when the prosecutor rejects all appeals and announces the sentence, cruel, frigid, filthy: death!  I would like to send a message to Serge Atlaoui, a French citizen living in my department, who is currently on probation. Serge has been experiencing this unbearable psychological suffering for ten years. His jailers have already killed him a little psychically to the point that he feels guilty about being still alive. No, Serge, you are not guilty, not guilty of wanting to live, not guilty of wanting justice, not guilty of wanting to see your four children again, not guilty of the suffering you and yours are suffering. It is to you, Serge, that I think of, your wife, your children and your family, who are waiting for you. Hold on, Serge, France is with you, Europe must be with you. This is the message I want to send you.  Jean Jaurès said: the death penalty is contrary to what humanity, for two thousand years, has thought of higher and dreamed of the noblest. In Europe as elsewhere in the world, because no man is totally responsible... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – The execution of the eight death row inmates earlier this week caused a worldwide stir. The ECR Group also shares in this outrage and condemns the implementation of this barbaric punishment, on principle and because of Article 2 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. To remind all of us, and in particular the European head of government who has apparently lost sight of the EU view on the death penalty, of Article 2, I repeat here: 'Right to life: Everyone has a right to life. No one is sentenced to death or executed." We respect Indonesia's sovereignty and its power to draw up its own criminal laws. We fully understand the fight against global drug trafficking. It is a modern country with impressive economic development, but the moral aspect must not be forgotten. This is reflected in many areas: from freedom of the press to freedom of expression to respect for fundamental human rights. The execution of the death penalty violates those human rights and is not a weapon for exercising authority. An appropriate response would have been to convert the death penalty to a life sentence or to a long prison sentence. Those involved belong in prison but don't deserve to be killed. On behalf of the ECR Group, my colleague Charles Tannock and I have written to the Indonesian government pleading for mercy. It's been to no avail. I hope Indonesia hears our signal today. Stop the executions, please!

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, we strongly condemn this week’s cruel executions by firing squad of eight people in Indonesia, seven of whom were not even Indonesian citizens. Not only has the European Union, along with Australia, strongly appealed to the authorities not to go ahead with the executions, the EU also offered assistance to the Indonesian authorities in tackling drug trafficking. Punishing convicted criminals can be done in more humane ways and must always be preceded by a fair trial. We call for a halt to all pending executions in Indonesia.  Colleagues, it is quite ironic, and actually shameful that on the day that we heard the appalling news of Indonesia’s executions, Viktor Orbán, whose party still remains a member of the PPE Group, suggested that the death penalty would be reinstated in Hungary. Such proposals are entirely inappropriate. As Mr Orbán knows very well, the death penalty is banned in Europe. I think we should be proud of that, as well as of our international efforts to end the death penalty, to limit its application and to seek countries putting a moratorium on this cruel and inhumane punishment. We have set the bar, as Europe, and intend to keep it rising, as liberal democracies. It would strengthen the voice of democracies in making appeals to countries such as Indonesia if the United States would stand side by side with Europe and would also outlaw the death penalty. We will – and we must – continue our efforts globally by working with governments and civil society organisations to ensure that the death penalty will soon belong to the past.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank all the political groups for agreeing to put this debate requested by the GUE/NGL group on our agenda. Many of us here are committed to the fight against the death penalty. We would have failed in our responsibility by not reacting immediately. On Tuesday night, eight people were actually executed, one Indonesian and seven foreigners. Fourteen executions have taken place since the beginning of the year, up from the number of executions in 2014 and only five in 2013, after a five-year moratorium. In Indonesia, as in other countries, the death penalty is again used, mainly for drug trafficking. According to Indonesia's Attorney General, the country is waging a war against horrific crimes that threaten the nation's survival. However, there is no justification for the use of this barbaric punishment, especially since lampists, small smugglers who are often poor and vulnerable, often foreign and deprived of basic rights of consular assistance and translation, are being attacked. There are few drug lords on death row. Worse, Indonesia's Constitutional Court agreed to consider the appeal of the two Australians executed on Tuesday on 12 May. 125 death row inmates are languishing in Indonesian prisons today. 57 for drug trafficking. Among them, 27 foreigners, including 4 Europeans, all convicted of drug trafficking. The case of Serge Atlaoui is emblematic. A 51-year-old welder employed in an Indonesian laboratory, he denies knowing that the laboratory was making ecstasy. His Indonesian bosses requested a review of their trial and obtained it. They are therefore not threatened with execution, at least in the short term. The same goes for the five Chinese, who were also sentenced to death in the same case. Several testimonies, including police officers, tend to exonerate Mr. Atlaoui, but these testimonies were not taken into account. The Indonesian president is an intransigent nationalist, who wants to give the image of someone who refuses to give in to international pressure. However, he did so, in extremis, for a Filipino national. In Indonesia, the case of Serge Atlaoui has reignited the debate on the death penalty in the press, particularly in the Jakarta Globe, Indonesia's leading newspaper, which questions the price Indonesia will have to pay in terms of image as a result of these executions. Yes, this fight is universal: in Indonesia, the United States and also in Europe, where Viktor Orban now says he is in favour of the reinstatement of the death penalty. So it's important that we react together and continue to do so.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Two days ago, eight people were executed in Indonesia. Unfortunately, 14 people have already been executed this year after Indonesia failed to execute in 2014. All those executed had been convicted of drug offences, although the death penalty – where it exists – can only be carried out for the most serious crimes, according to international standards. Recent cases of executions in Indonesia also show serious violations of internationally recognised standards for the implementation of the death penalty. For example, some of the detainees had insufficient access to lawyers or translators during their detention. One of the executed, Rodrigo Gularte, was diagnosed with schizophrenia and the execution took place, although international law prohibits the execution of people with intellectual disabilities and mental illnesses. The Indonesian government sees the executions as a deterrent to drug traffickers. However, there is no evidence that the death penalty contributes to preventing crime. A UN study also shows that the death penalty has no greater deterrent effect than, for example, a life sentence. We therefore call on the Indonesian Government to suspend all further planned executions, and we call for a moratorium to be reintroduced as an essential step towards the abolition of the death penalty. Indonesia could thus send an important signal to the other states in the region.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Nusa Kambangan, this island is probably not on indonesia's tourist brochures, and it is precisely here that, in the so-called valley of death, the condemned are escorted from maximum security cells; they wear white tuts and are placed in front of the firing squad, they can then choose whether to have blindfolded, sit, kneel or stand, this is the humanity that is granted to them.  You see, we cannot judge the trials, but we can judge the death penalty as a sanction and i therefore condemn it as An Italian, as a European but above all as a human being. There is no commercial interest that must and can be sacrificed to a strenuous and continuous struggle not only for a moratorium against it, but for its abolition, because as Rémy de Gourmont said in his unpublished thoughts, it is quite clear that those who support the death penalty today have much more affinity with the murderers of those who fight it.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this has been a very engaging exchange and I thank the honourable Members for the clarity and purpose of their interventions. Let me assure you that the European Union remains fully committed to engage in Indonesia with the government, local campaigners and other stakeholders to work for the abolition of the death penalty in Indonesia. To this end, we will make full use of the various instruments at our disposal – statements, demarches and dialogue – to make our voices heard, but also to listen and understand some of the obstacles to change so as to address them more effectively. As friends of Indonesia, we call on the authorities and the President of Indonesia to declare an immediate moratorium on the use of the death penalty.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on the Nadiya Savchenko case (2015/2663 (RSP)."

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: Author. – Mr President, First of all, I want to express my satisfaction, because, finally, we can today debate and, after, vote on a resolution on the case of Nadia Savchenko. This is the third time our political group has proposed this topic for emergency resolutions. Twice, the Socialists blocked the discussion of the Savchenko case in the European Parliament, perhaps to avoid strong and well-founded criticism of Moscow and its relationship with the war in Ukraine. Indeed, the Savchenko case shows us Russia's duplicity in the war that is going on in the vicinity of the European Union. Russia is holding in prison, investigating and recently filed charges against Nadia Savchenko, captured in eastern Ukraine, when fighting pro-Russian separatists. Although Savchenko is in Moscow's prisons, Russia does not consider itself part of this war. Moreover, the Minsk agreements in February, which Russia signed, provide for the release of all prisoners captured in the war that has been going on for more than a year in Ukraine. Despite Russia promising the liberation of Nadia Savchenko, this did not happen. Last week, on April 24, the investigative committee finalised a list of allegations against Nadia Savchenko. Russia therefore has duplicitous behavior: it is part of the war in Ukraine, without assuming it, claims to support the Minsk agreements, but does the opposite of what these agreements provide, and Nadiya Savchenko is caught up in this duplicitous game of Moscow. We call on Vladimir Putin to release both Savchenko and the other prisoners of the Ukrainian conflict, which he is illegally holding in Russian prisons. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 149(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, when we meet here to talk about urgency, we all agree, all in the same fight. Dozens of cases could be dealt with every Thursday during the emergency debates in Strasbourg, so could you refrain from making political comments in the future on the choice of topics? Of course, there are priorities. Once three cases are chosen, we must all be behind the same cause. Could you refrain from those comments in the future?

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, dear Marc Tarabella, there are moments that should not be missed. I do believe that to postpone the debate on Savchenko twice is a mistake that the S and D group must accept. The group has refused to put on the Agenda of the European Parliament a subject that is being debated by all the public opinion in Europe and which they want to understand. We haven't taken a position so far and I... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Preda, you do not have the floor. Mr Tarabella, that was not a question, that was a statement. For once, I would like mr Preda to respond to this nonetheless.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: Author. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In the eastern archives of the Polish karta center are the testimonies of Polish women soldiers of the National Army, who fought against the German occupation during World War II. A member of the NKVD, who interviewed one of them at a time when the free world was already enjoying the hope of the second half of 1945, said, "we will not kill you, we will send you where you want to die."  It was Stalin's time. The current justice system in the Russian Federation is a simple continuation of that system, confirmed by Vladimir Putin. Nadia Savchenko is a prisoner of such a system. In support of the resolution, we must know that this is not all, that we cannot escape the hope of the Michan agreements, similar to that of Yeręto.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: author. – Mr President, the detention of Nadiya Savchenko is unlawful and inhumane. The Minsk Agreements must be respected in full.  This was still being pointed out by 61 Members of this House back on 17 October of last year, when we co-signed the first public appeal to President Putin. In addition, for the last three months, on every single day, yet another Member of the European Parliament sends a letter to the Russian Ambassador in Brussels. Sixty letters have been sent up to now. It is not that we expect to get any kind of reply; what we expect is for Russia to act in a civilised and 21st century European manner. It is appalling that President Putin chooses to keep Nadiya Savchenko detained as his personal prisoner. As a consequence, the Savchenko List, together with the Magnitsky List, are becoming tools for dealing with Putin’s Russia, and this is very sad.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the The case of Nadiya Savchenko should not actually exist. She was kidnapped as a member of the Ukrainian army by self-proclaimed separatist military units. She was deported to Russia under questionable circumstances, a state that is not officially involved in these wars. She has been held as a prisoner of war in a prison for almost a year without a legal basis. This is contrary to the Geneva Convention, and that is illegal. She also enjoys immunity as a Member of Parliament. The list of these illegal inconsistencies could be continued. The crucial thing now in this situation is that Nadiya Savchenko is in danger of dying, that her health is being attacked to the extreme. It is therefore a question of working for the immediate release of Nadiya Savchenko. This is a necessary condition for the much-needed dialogue with Russia. If the Russian side really takes the Minsk agreement seriously, we must release this woman immediately. Savchenko, however, is not an isolated case. It is a particularly tragic case here. There are also a number of other cases that we must also deal with.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. – Mr President, while we must not politically exploit Nadiya Savchenko’s story, and though her case is extremely grave as it appears that there are serious human rights violations, Parliament must not use it as an excuse to attack and condemn Russia for other reasons. On the contrary, it is a chance to reaffirm and promote a strong belief in the principle of fair trials and human and dignified conditions of detention. This does not seem to be guaranteed in this case.  Savchenko is protesting with passive resistance from prison. In her most recent letter, dated 27 April 2015, she says ‘please do not write letters asking me to live and eat. Hunger is the only way I have to fight the lawlessness of the Russian authorities. So do not ask me to lay it down’. So let us defend the principle of fair trial and the rule of law. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Do you think that keeping Mrs. Savchenko in prison is something that is illegal, something that violates human rights and something that proves that since she was imprisoned in Moscow, she nevertheless makes it clear that Russia has fingers involved in this case in Ukraine?

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: Answer to a blue card question. I believe, My colleague, that we unfortunately use the debates on human rights to bring out political cases that are very different according to the reference nation. So any violation which, for heaven's sake, is to be condemned and which concerns Russia is exaggerated abnormally. If we talk about other states that are our partners because they make as many violations, it is better not to talk about them. That is the criticism I was making. We try to maintain a constant opinion of everyone.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Nadiya Savchenko was a military pilot and member of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe. In June 2014, Nadiya was captured by the Russians and illegally transferred to the Russian Federation. According to the Geneva Convention, she is a prisoner of war. Nadiya cannot be criminally investigated because her case is a matter of applicable war law, ius in bellum, and must be investigated by an independent tribunal, not the Russians. Nadiya Savchenko has been on hunger strike for three months, protesting her illegal arrest. Her health is getting worse by the day! We demand that she be released immediately! We call on Russia to respect its international immunity, being a member of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, and we ask Russia to respect its international commitments. Of course, we don't think Russia will respect them. I saw that the Russian Federation has no respect for the law, I saw how it invaded eastern Ukraine. Putin has no respect for the law, no respect for life, no respect for anyone and nothing. It has only thirst for power and wants to become the second world force.  I ask: why does Putin need a victim in the collection of those already killed, tortured, kidnapped, trapped?

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, Commissioner, we are here gathered around the case of Nadya Savchenko, whose unconditional release we are calling for, because this is both a humanitarian and a political case.  A humanitarian case, since Nadya Savchenko has been on a hunger strike that has been jeopardising her health for more than three months now, but also a political case, since she was kidnapped in Ukraine, detained as a prisoner of war in Russia and, within the framework of the European Union, we made specific demands in the Minsk agreements. These demands have just been renewed at the summit between the European Union and Ukraine, they were made by the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini, they are clearly relayed, now, by all the political families of this Assembly. We expect Russia to make a gesture, as a promise to implement the measures taken to enable the Minsk agreements to become a reality. It is also a signal of what the policy of the European Union is, which is also supported and validated by the United Nations.  We therefore ask that the President of this Assembly address President Putin so that Nadya Savchenko can finally be released and regain the autonomy of her means in order to return to her country, in Ukraine.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. I too am pleased that the European Parliament can finally speak out on the Nadia Savchenko case. Nadia's not doing well. Her health has deteriorated dramatically in a very short time. The day before yesterday, she was rushed to a hospital and she is not being treated well there, according to her lawyer. Nadia is being held by the Russian authorities for political reasons. The burden of proof is a joke and can be refuted from the first to the last word. She doesn't know when she'll finally face trial. Painful for a country that calls itself a superpower. The signal that will come from this House may be directed directly at the leader in the Kremlin. Mr. President, what does this woman's senseless incarceration bring to Russia? Nadia Savchenko has become a symbol. You know you can't break symbols anymore. We know by now that you are a "strong" leader. You are therefore loved in your own country. But now also show that you are a 'great' leader. That means showing magnanimity. You are also aware that this conflict is not leading us anywhere. Give Nadia back her freedom! What an impressive and hopeful gesture that would be!

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner. Nadiya Savchenko was the only Ukrainian soldier on a peace mission in Iraq, the first pilot of Ukraine's armed forces, an example of determination and progress for her country. Nadiya is a Member of the Ukrainian Parliament and a member of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe: she is entitled to immunity and diplomatic privileges. Nadiya is the victim of a purely political detention in violation of the European Convention on Human Rights, signed by Russia, in particular the right to freedom and security and the right to a fair trial. Implementing the Minsk Agreements involves releasing all hostages and detainees in connection with the Ukraine conflict. What are international protocols and agreements for? We can't give in to anyone's blackmail or we'll lose credibility and raison d'etion. The European Union and the Member States must immediately require the Russian Federation to comply unreservedly with all its international commitments, including the Minsk Agreements, to immediately release Ms Savchenko and return her to her homeland. Nadiya means hope. Let's give her reasons to have her here.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, my Group very strongly supports this resolution and I would echo the comments made by a number of previous colleagues and very much share them. The situation of Ms Savchenko is outrageous and, crucially, entirely within the control of the Russian authorities. She is also emblematic and it is important to remember that she is not alone; she is not the only illegally held Ukrainian national within Russia, director Oleg Sentsov is in a similar situation and there are others. These are all covered within the Minsk Agreements and, let us be clear, Russia is in breach of the Minsk Agreements. Ms Savchenko is being illegally held and we must urge our Member States’ leaders and Foreign Ministers to play a much more vocal role within these discussions and raise her case and others at the next meeting of the contact group. I hope, Commissioner, you will take these points on board.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, we are here because of Nadiya Savchenko, a woman who served in her country's army and, as a pilot, was guilty of nothing more than defending Ukraine's territorial integrity. Her introduction abroad and imprisonment in Russia is an unprecedented violation of international law. It has been dragged out of the territory of the sovereign state of Ukraine, whose borders are and are to be inviolable, do not respect its parliamentary immunity and its membership of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe. They're forcing her to admit that she came to Russia illegally on her own, and they're offering her a forced pardon for it. They are putting pressure on her in the face of forced psychiatric treatment, which is still being used as an instrument of state power pressure, just as it was in times of dark Stalinism. This terrorist abduction and abuse of a foreign national citizen associated with the coercives of a false confession in court is worthy of the strictest possible condemnation and consequence. International law and human rights are an untouchable principle of our civilisation, and Russia must be forced to respect them.  (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question. – I would like to ask my colleague Svoboda the question himself, although I could actually do so for any Member of the People's Party. A large delegation of the Hungarian Fidesz sits in the ranks of your party family. How can you make a living with them? When their boss, Viktor Orban, makes a pledge of allegi00 to Putin and his regime every day, what's more, he does all sorts of business with him?

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. - My colleague probably has better information than I do. We're here today because of Nadi Savchenko and not hungary.

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: – Mr President, the kidnapping and illegal detention of Ukrainian officer Nadiya Savchenko, despite widespread international protest, is really a cynical and inhuman gesture by the Russian Federation. It is clear that Russia is violating the Geneva Convention and is not fulfilling its responsibilities under the Minsk Agreements. Nadiya Savchenko is an extreme case, but not the only one. This is quite typical of the present Russian regime. Let us recall that, similarly to Nadiya Savchenko’s case, Russia is ignoring our protests against the kidnapping and detention of Estonian security officer, Eston Kohver, and also many other cases. At the same time, Russia is strengthening its military pressure on the eastern border of the European Union, threatening and provoking the Baltic and Nordic countries. The Russian leadership is obviously hoping that, overwhelmed by the tragedies in the Mediterranean, Europe will not take seriously the hybrid threat that is emerging on its eastern borders.  Let us prove together – not competing with each other but together – that this is not the case. Russia must respect peace and security and human rights in order to be recognised as a respected member of the international community. The unconditional release of Nadiya Savchenko would be a step in this direction but hopefully there will also be other steps.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, human rights are one. Their use for only political purposes destroys them. We must denounce human rights violations on both sides. We cannot use it politically and in a way. Otherwise, we are hurting human rights. With regard to the technical issue of parliamentary immunity, I understand that Mrs Savchenko was subsequently elected as a Member of Parliament when she was already in prison, but I may be wrong. Of course, you have to follow the situation. I just want to say that, having gone to the Donbass as a parliamentarian myself, I have been accused of being a terrorist and I do not know what they have done with my parliamentary immunity. As far as Minsk is concerned, I have the prisoners' figures. The figures of the so-called "separatist" prisoners are more important than the figures of the ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, we all know what happened in Eastern Europe recently: Russia seized Crimea. Russia also supported, and continues to support, the separatists from Eastern Ukraine, in each and every case breaking and not respecting international law and treaties that Russia previously signed. How is it possible in the 21st century to have a situation in which a country that we were cooperating with, a country that is so involved in international affairs and which is a member of the Security Council of the United Nations, does not respect international law? Now a Ukrainian citizen, who like us is also a parliamentarian – a parliamentarian of the Council of Europe – was seized and taken prisoner by the Russian Federation. It seems that we have to appeal to the United Nations, or some other organisation, in order for Nadiya Savchenko to be set free.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! The story of Nadia Savchenko is both a story of modern heroism and an example of powerlessness and Ukraine and the West against russian unlawful actions. The detention, or basically the kidnapping of this ukrainian air force officer by the Russians, breaks all international human rights standards. If Moscow, ladies and gentlemen, had the courage to take responsibility for the military action in Donbass, instead of waging a cowardly war with the hands of terrorists, Nadia Savchenko would be protected by conventions governing the rights of prisoners of war. However, even the Russians refuse to do so, treating a soldier defending his own borders as a common criminal. Well, this is apparently russian tradition.  It is very outrageous that Nadia Savchenko is imprisoned, even though she enjoys parliamentary immunity. It is, after all, a member of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe, the same Council of which Russia is also a member. And I would like to refer in one sentence to what Mr Corrao said... (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: For the catch-the-eye procedure that follows, I have much more speeches than are actually envisaged. We actually have two minutes. I ask for your indulgence that I do not take into account those who have already spoken in today's debate. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Mr. President, Nadiya Savchenko was imprisoned by pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine as she tried to pull the wounded from the battlefield. She is currently in prison in Russia, on trial for crimes she did not commit. Although Russia claims not to be involved in the war in Ukraine, the situation with Nadiya Savchenko and other prisoners denies their allegations.  The European Parliament also spoke out about the case early this year with a Resolution on the Situation in Ukraine, explicitly requesting the exchange of all prisoners, including Nadiya Savchenko. To date Nadiya Savchenko has not been released from prison. This case of Nadiya Savchenko reminds me of the case of Croatian defender Veljko Maric, who was seeded by Serbian authorities under the same model and has been held in prison for 5 years.  Serbian authorities are judging Veljko Maric, although they do not have the power to do so, as Russian authorities are judging Nadiya Savchenko even though they do not have the power to do so. Both Nadiya Savchenko and Veljko Maric are in poor health. I ask that Nadiya Savchenko and Veljko Maric be released as a matter of urgency, as both are mounted political processes and human rights violations.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In catch the eye mode, if possible. (The President has received the speaker's vote)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Czarnecki, I would like to thank Mr Czarnecki for his work You are Vice-President, you know exactly what is going on here. You have already carried out catch-the-eye procedures yourself. Have you given the floor to someone under the catch-the-eye procedure on a point of order? No! You also know that we have a great many speeches here. I have announced that I can actually take two. Two colleagues have not appeared, so I will call four and you are not there.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to stress that we are dealing with a unified resolution, which is the most important thing, so mr Preda's polemic towards the Socialists is incomprehensible because I consider it to be an unnecessary polemic.  The case of Nadija Savchenko is emblematic of the Russian attitude in the Ukrainian conflict. Captured by pro-Russian militiamen in eastern Ukraine, she reappeared captive in Russia, she is accused of aiding the murder of two journalists and according to the Russian press all defence rights have been respected, and that is not true. Even the accusations themselves do not seem to be justified at all. We must therefore react and we are doing so seriously with this resolution, fully calling for the implementation of the Minsk agreement and the release of Savchenko without conditions. That is what we are asking for as a Parliament, and I think it is useful to emphasise this.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I accept your ruling, but I just would suggest that, rather than taking blue cards in the next two debates, you might allow more time for ‘catch the eye’; because a lot of the blue cards seem to me to be spurious and irrelevant.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I will take due account of what you have said.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, since June 2014 Nadiya Savchenko has been in custody without any legal justification or any evidence presented against her by the Russian Investigative Committee so far. This detention violates the right to freedom, security and a fair trial guaranteed by the European Convention on Human Rights, to which the Russian Federation is a signatory. It also calls into question the agreement agreed in Minsk on 12 February on the release of all detainees during the armed conflict in Ukraine and disrespects the immunity of the members of the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe to which Savchenko is delegated. After 83 days of hunger strike, which severely deteriorated their health, I call for the immediate release of Nadiya Savchenko, as well as all other Ukrainian citizens detained illegally, in the name of international legality and for humanitarian reasons.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Mr President, I want to join what my colleagues have said here. I am very pleased, and I am always pleased, that there is, in principle, a united voice across all factions, and we all agree that Mrs Savchenko should be released. This story clearly shows how Russia is violating international treaties, international law, and also its own internal law, because the way the trial in Russia is pending is also contrary to Russian criminal law. It clearly shows that Mrs Savchenko's introduction was in breach of international law, it clearly shows that there is no attempt to carry out a fair trial. So if anyone is talking about letting the courts in Russia decide, then they are very naïve and a dreamer. In short, if Russia wanted to solve the case, it could have been made clear that Mrs Savchenko was innocent and could have been released long ago. If this is a judicial monster trial and Mrs Savchenko is the victim of it, it is therefore a good thing that we are adopting this resolution today in support of it.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, a hundred and thirty-eight days have passed since Nadiya Savchenko started a hunger strike in protest against her illegal detention in Russia.  Let me be very clear from the outset and convey once again, in front of this House, the message that we have repeatedly delivered to Russian interlocutors: Russia should immediately release Ms Savchenko.  Firstly, let us recall that Ms Savchenko was captured in Ukraine by Russian-backed separatists. She was subsequently formally charged last Friday by the Russian Investigative Committee of being complicit in the deaths of two Russian journalists. The material evidence pointing to her innocence was never allowed to be produced in court. It is absurd to charge her with illegally crossing the border when she was already captive before being transferred to Russia.  Secondly, the ongoing investigation and possible trial of Ms Savchenko in Russia are surrounded by irregularities, as well as raising the issue of the competence of Russian courts to judge a Ukrainian Member of the Rada, and furthermore a Member the Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe. The EU Delegation in Moscow is in frequent contact with Ms Savchenko’s lawyers and is regularly present in the Court to follow her proceedings.  Thirdly, the intention of the Russian authorities to put her on trial in Russia is not in keeping with the Minsk Agreements and the commitment to release all hostages and detained persons related to the conflict in Ukraine.  Finally, the situation of Ms Savchenko, at such an advanced stage of her hunger strike, is a humanitarian issue. Russia bears responsibility for her fragile health. The situation is unbearably difficult for her family, as many of you will also have heard from meetings with her sister, Vira.  The situation of Nadiya Savchenko raises two key issues: firstly, it sheds light on the situation regarding the rule of law and human rights in Russia, which this House has repeatedly discussed. On this, our message is clear: Russia should live up to its international obligations in the field of human rights. We will stand behind those who protect human rights in Russia.  Secondly, the case of Ms Savchenko, who was initially kidnapped in Donbass, is a reminder of the situation in eastern Ukraine. Freedom for Nadiya Savchenko and for all illegally detained Ukrainian citizens held in Russia, such as Oleg Sentsov, would be a step towards the resolution of the conflict. This is once again why I, on behalf of the Commission and the High Representative, join this House in calling for their immediate and unconditional release. (Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place following the following two debates. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Gabrielius LANDSBERGIS
text: Writing. – On 17 June 2014, a terrorist group took hostage nadežd Savchenko, a former pilot of the Ukrainian Air Force (KOP) in the Lugansk region. On 24 June 2014, she was illegally transported to Russia, where the Russian Interrogation Committee brought criminal charges against her. In not only illegally detained and removed from Ukrainian territory, it has been prosecuted on the basis of unfounded accusations of numerous serious violations of law, fundamental human rights and human dignity, including forced psychiatric treatment. After a long-term hunger campaign, Savchenko's health is in a very poor condition. Mr Savchenko was supposed to be on the prisoner exchange in the prisoner exchanges provided for under the Minsk agreements, but the Russian side rejected that possibility. The European Parliament strongly condemns the Russian Federation for the abduction and illegal detention of Mr Savchenko, which has been going on for years, and demands her immediate release.

name: Julia PITERA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " The modern world has set standards for the protection of human rights. 47 Council of Europe countries, including Russia, have ratified the European Convention on Human Rights, which entered into force in 1953 and is a sine qua non for accession to the Council. It appears that even Russia's ratification on 5 May 1998 of such a fundamental and momentous international act, on the date of its accession to the Council of Europe, is not capable of stopping russia from violating its signature standards.  One of the dramatic manifestations of Russia's disregard for international norms is the situation of Nadia Savchenko. This Ukrainian military, lieutenant, navigator pilot, member of the Supreme Council of Ukraine, the hero of Ukraine shows extraordinary courage and determination in fighting not only for his rights, but for respect for human rights. Russia has so far failed to comply with the Minsk 2 agreement, in which it declared its release. The world is following with great concern the struggle that has been going on for many months. That is why it is so important to involve MEPs in the Informal Friends of Ukraine Group, which, by putting pressure on the Russian authorities, supports Nadia Savchenko in the fight for the highest values of freedom, justice and democracy.

name: Andrej PLENKOVIĆ
text: Written. – With this resolution, we provide clear support to Nadiya Savchenko. As chairman of the Parliamentary Committee for The Accession of Ukraine and the European Union, I express concern, because I believe that the mounted trial will try to strongly condemn the person who has become a symbol of resistance in Ukraine.  A Union that promotes democracy and human rights, freedom and the rule of law has a duty to continuously include respect for these values in all segments of its relations with Russia. It is important that the EU, in cooperation with other international actors, obtains the release of Ukrainian heroin by all available political and diplomatic means.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: Writing. – Nadežda Savchenko's case – I support the resolution calling on Russia to release all illegally imprisoned citizens of Ukraine, including Member of the VerchovNa Council and The Parliamentary Assembly of the Council of Europe Nade Savchenko. It is unacceptable for the Russian authorities to refuse to release people who have in most cases been kidnapped from Ukrainian territory by separatists, and the Russian Federation therefore has no legal relationship with them. I consider the detention of Nade Savchenko as a prisoner of war in a Russian prison to be a violation of the Geneva Convention. I have long advocated the immediate release of Savchenko through activities on the ground of the European Parliament, the chain hunger strike that we have been on hunger strike with other colleagues in the EP, as well as my participation in events in support of Nade and ukraine's independence.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the situation of the Yarmouk refugee camp in Syria (2015/2664 (RSP)).

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Mr President, Yarmouk is a symbol: first of all, that of the Palestinian resistance. Built to accommodate some of the 800,000 Palestinian refugees deported following the Nakba in 1948 and the vote on UN Resolution 194 on the right of return of Palestinian refugees, this camp has become a veritable city, with a population of up to 180,000, with schools, hospitals, public buildings and commercial arteries, and with UNRWA's support in health and education. Particular. Yarmouk had also become a symbol of social diversity, as many poor Syrians benefited from the camp's social facilities. It is also a symbol of the damage and international cost of non-settlement of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Symbol still of the damage of the Syrian conflict and its consequences on Palestinian refugees: as early as 2011, the majority of Yarmouk refugees fled elsewhere, the camp being very close to Damascus. Symbol of the situation of half a million Palestinian refugees in Syria, half of whom have been displaced and 80,000 have taken refuge in neighbouring countries, which now host nearly 4 million refugees from Syria. Symbol also of the imbroglios between the forces present in Syria, because the fighters of the group "Islamic State" could not enter this camp without the complicity of the forces of Al-Nusra and probably also without that of the Syrian army. Yes, today the situation of the Palestinians in Yarmouk is dramatic, since they are deprived of any humanitarian aid. UNRWA, whose funds have been significantly reduced, no longer has access to the camp. The shortage of water, food and medicine adds to the devastation of the fighting. Today, at least 170 people have died of starvation in Yarmouk. Yes, the international community must react, and the European Union must put all its weight in the balance so that the Palestinians in the Yarmouk camp do not bear the brunt of a conflict which is not theirs and from which they must be protected.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: author. – Mr President, I will start by congratulating the rapporteurs and colleagues for the very constructive way in which we put this motion together. I think there is a great deal to be recommended within it.  I very much support our previous speaker who set out the background to the Yarmouk refugee camp. Even the way it is described is slightly misleading; this is a long-established Palestinian settlement on the outskirts of Damascus, more of a suburb of a city rather than a camp in its own right. It has been in existence since 1957. It was supposed, of course, to be temporary, but until Palestinian refugees can go home they remain particularly vulnerable. That is where this resolution is important. The Palestinian people are particularly vulnerable within Syria, with upwards of 480 000 Palestinian refugees scattered across 60 camps throughout the wider region. Ninety-five percent of these people rely on UNRWA for their daily needs. The camp was besieged by the Assad regime forces, creating a humanitarian disaster, and then became a battleground for various other factions, and remains so now. The chaos is a humanitarian crisis unfolding on the very outskirts of the Syrian capital. We must see, as we have expressed in paragraph 9, humanitarian pauses in the fighting as proposed by UN Special Envoy De Mistura. We must also see the EU, as we state in paragraph 10, play a much greater role in brokering a political solution within Syria, and I would also add Palestine to give the refugees a home to go to.  We welcome, of course, Commissioner, the humanitarian aid the EU has given, but in this case the criticism of the EU as a payer rather than a player has never been more just. We must, for the people in the region and indeed ourselves, do better to foster a political solution.

name: Ramona Nicole MĂNESCU
text: Author. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to thank all the colleagues who have been involved in drafting this resolution and to stress that the final document reflects the common opinion of all parliamentary groups on the seriousness and urgency of the situation in the Yarmouk refugee camp.  I would like to welcome the European Commission's allocation of EUR 2.5 million, which has contributed directly and immediately to the saving of human lives. It is absolutely necessary for the European Union and the Member States to increase their financial effort in allocating the funds that the UN Refugee Working Agency needs, and on this occasion I would like to welcome the Agency and congratulate it on the extraordinary work it is doing. I strongly condemn the atrocities committed against civilians in Yarmouk. I believe that we have an obligation not to remain indifferent and to act urgently to ensure the safety of civilians and their right to a better life. This refugee camp is neutral and this neutrality must be respected, by ensuring the protection of the lives of civilians and, above all, of the most vulnerable among them, women and children, and by ensuring access to the camp in order to provide humanitarian support to refugees. I welcome the announced Geneva talks and hope that they will lead as soon as possible to a sustainable solution to ending the conflict. I also believe that the European Union must take the diplomatic and political initiative in an effort to stabilise the area and end the armed conflict.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. – Mr President, there is an ongoing denial of humanitarian access to the refugees living in the Yarmouk camp by the Syrian regime and other belligerents. The situation is worsened by the fact that UNRWA is gravely undermined by chronic underfunding for humanitarian interventions in Yarmouk.  With this resolution Parliament calls for the European Union to contribute to joint efforts to mitigate the humanitarian crisis and play a role in helping neighbouring countries to provide shelter for refugees fleeing the conflict in Syria. A fundamental step in this direction is to take measures to avoid people risking their lives on boats in the Mediterranean Sea, and to create safe ways for them to reach Europe, such as humanitarian visas and corridors.

name: Javier NART
text: Author. – Mr President, solidarity is not a schizophrenic concept , it depends on where it occurs, but the same. Yarmuk has been in siege for three years, with a very harsh partial blockade by the Syrian government, bombed for three years, causing hundreds of dead: 160,000 Palestinians as a result of ethnic cleansing in northern Palestine. Gaza has been in a total blockade for more than ten years with unmisericoly bombings that have resulted in thousands of dead. The difference is that in one case it is because of a criminal regime and a terrorist organization and, in the other, by a regime that acts in a similar way, but which we call democratic. Blocking and bombing civilians is an equal crime, whoever does it, and solidarity must be the same: in Yarmuk and Gaza. I hope – and despair – that in this Parliament we will have the same sensitivity to Gaza as we have for Yarmuk, a solidarity of which I welcome it.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the Yarmouk is one of those places in the world where all suffering seems to be concentrated and where humanity distorts into inhumanity. People who have had to flee their country – from Palestine – or have been expelled have found a makeshift home here, without being able to hope that they will ever get out of this temporary arrangement again. They have fallen between the fronts, and they have been captured by the worst enemy imaginable – the Da'ish/IS. A UN representative called this situation beyond inhumane. I believe that this resolution is a first important step, that this will not be forgotten. We must also have the means to help people as soon as it is possible again. Above all, however, we must ensure that everything is done, that when this horror is over, prosecution will be possible.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I just want to say that I welcome the motion for a resolution that is being debated here. I think the proposal is balanced enough. Of course, it is necessary to write and call on the parties to the civil war in Syria to stop attacking Camp Yarmouk, which objectively is now one of the darkest, saddest places on the planet and is experiencing a huge humanitarian disaster. But I'm afraid he's more likely to stay with words. What is important and what I consider to be concrete support and assistance is that the European Union, namely the European Commission, is releasing EUR 2.5 million and that this money will be used to support people suffering from the civil war in Syria and specifically in Camp Yarmouk. It is a question of how much this amount is sufficient, I think that it should be debated in the future whether this amount should be increased further, and we should call very hard and call – and this is also the case in the document – for the mainly opposing parties to allow international humanitarian organisations to use the money that is so mobile for specific humanitarian aid and to deliver it to those who need this humanitarian aid. Otherwise, it will remain only with words, there will be money, but concrete assistance for them will not be provided. I therefore welcome and support the motion for a resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, in the Yarmouk camp, the refugee situation has been humanly unbearable for more than three years.  This resolution certainly serves to alert international public opinion to this dramatic situation that is too little known. It also has an interest in the context of a conflict that is far from being resolved in Syria. It is indicative of the role of the European Union, which, alongside other powers, must be able to act in the Syrian conflict, which itself is at the root of many problems, such as that of refugees and their catastrophic humanitarian situation, but also forced migration, which is synonymous with human tragedies that should be alleviated.  That is why this resolution is relevant, and I hope that it will be supported by all colleagues.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the people in Yarmouk, Syria, face a particularly horrible situation, as do many other innocent people in Syria. They are attacked by the nihilist jihadists of Da’esh and with barrel bombs and other attacks by the murderous regime of President Assad. The war in Syria must be stopped and the EU must lead efforts, diplomatic and otherwise.  Humanitarian aid will require much more money, not only from the EU but especially from Arab countries and others who have not taken up their share of the burden. We have heard the massive outcry after the horrible and tragic deaths in the Mediterranean; I share the sense of sorrow. And the immense misery of the people in and from Syria and the rest of the Middle East region must be met with a more forceful answer from Europe.  When we speak of shelter in the region, at least the most basic of needs must be provided for and it must be safe for people. Indeed – and I agree with my colleague, Josef Weidenholzer – we must bring to justice the perpetrators of these atrocious crimes and attacks against innocent people.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President. The population of Yarmuk has been under siege by Bachar el Asad forces and, since April, from the so-called Islamic State. A humanitarian catastrophe that shows the inability of the international community to stop the killings and navigate the siege of Yarmuk. Yarmuk symbolizes the absence of international support for democratic processes in Syria and the rest of the region, which has reinforced both dictatorships and extremist groups. It also symbolizes the lack of a solution to the occupation of Palestine, which would, among other measures, be caused by compliance with the United Nations Resolution urging Israel to accept the return of Palestinian refugees. Any solution must begin with the lifting of the regime-imposed blockade, the entry of humanitarian aid and dialogue between Palestinian militias. The international community and the United Nations must fulfil their responsibilities. In this sense, the European Union must take responsibility for refugees arriving from Syria on our shores.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, yesterday I spoke in this Chamber about the attacks on Christians in Kenya and elsewhere, and there were comments on social media asking why I mentioned that and not other religions. But of course that is what yesterday’s debate was about, and today we are discussing a humanitarian crisis at the Yarmouk refugee camp, which has actually grown to be an awful lot more than just a camp. I would like to assure this House and others that I utterly condemn the way in which the Palestinian people have been treated, every bit as much as I condemned yesterday. As these injustices continue across that part of that world, day in and day out, I am saddened by the thought that so much of this has its roots in a militarily interventionist foreign policy which has failed in its attempt to protect vulnerable people. In healthcare there is a principle: first do no harm, and that principle goes all the way back to the Hippocratic Oath. Perhaps that principle should be considered by governments over their foreign policies.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: Mr President, I am opposed to this resolution because it does not reflect the reality of the situation at all. It is not acceptable to put all forces in the same way. The Palestinian refugee camp of Yarmouk is the victim of the occupation of Islamist armed groups, be it the Islamic State group, the Al-Nusra Front or other rebel groups, most of whose members are neither Syrians nor Palestinians, but jihadists from all over the world.  You cite the Palestinian group Ansar Bait al-Maqdis among the rebel groups, but you do not seem to know that on 19 April this group agreed to join the loyalist Syrian forces in their fight against terrorism. This text is therefore indicative of the lack of knowledge we have of the situation on the ground. That is why, rather than voting on unnecessary and one-sided resolutions, it might be more desirable for a delegation of MEPs to go there to talk to the various local actors.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, the people who remain in the Yarmouk refugee camp are, as Ban Ki-Moon described it, in the ‘deepest circle of hell’ resulting from Syria’s four-year-long civil war. It is almost unimaginable what these people have gone through prior to April 2015, but what is taking place now in Yarmouk is gruesome. It is also symptomatic of the complexity of the conflict in the region, as these people are caught between the al-Nusra front, the Syrian army, ISIS and many more violent groups and actors. The European Union provided emergency funding to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees (UNRWA) at the beginning of April. I would hereby like to call on the European Union and the Commission’s Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection department (ECHO) to develop special measures that are aimed at supporting the most vulnerable groups in conflict-ridden societies: children, women, elderly people, disabled people and ethnic and religious minorities.

name: Ana GOMES
text: – Mr President, Yarmouk is an agrarunhante indictment of our civilisation and the obsolete system of international regulation that we have not reformed by failure of leadership at European and global level. Yarmouk shows the unsecurity council's inability to at least enforce the humanitarian principle of protecting civilians in wartime by letting terrorist groups opposed to assad's terrorist regime forces face off violently in a camp where only civilians, refugees, are still victims of an even older conflict. It is unbearable that three years later, humanitarian access and support to Palestinian refugees from Yarmouk is still not guaranteed. It is unbearable that the permanent members of the Security Council, other States or the European Union itself have not yet secured adequate financial support for UNRWA so that it can maintain aid from next summer. Yarmouk calls our consciences: where is Europe? Where is the responsibility to protect in Syria? Why have we abandoned not only the doctrine that required us to intervene humanely, but indeed because we abandoned the Syrian people and the refugees that Syria welcomed?

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: – Mr President, several areas of Yarmouk, syria's largest Palestinian refugee camp, were taken over by the jihadists of the self-proclaimed Islamic State with the collaboration of Al-Nusra, the Syrian arm of al-Qaeda, on 1 April. Some 18,000 Palestinian and Syrian civilians, including 3,500 children, are besieged in a totally catastrophic humanitarian situation after two years of a virtually total siege imposed by the Syrian regime. Without running water, food or access to medicines, and now transformed into true human shields by jihadists, their situation is tragic. It is urgent that the camp be recognised as neutral territory in the Syrian conflict and that the entry of officials from UNRWA, the UN agency for Palestinian refugees, and other international humanitarian organisations, in Yarmouk is allowed to provide protection and assistance to civilians in the camp and the opening of a humanitarian corridor to evacuate those who wish to leave the site.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it seems a destiny that Yarmouk must be a place marked by history.  Almost 1 400 years ago, there was a decisive battle between the Byzantines and the real Caliphate, today there is a much more perverse one in which the parties are increasingly confused. To find out what it feels like in Yarmouk, turn off the light, the water, the heating, eat once a day and live in the dark, so a refugee rightly tells the daily life in that field.  The EU guarantees only 2.5 of the 30 million needed, according to UNRWA estimates, to finance the management of the ongoing humanitarian crisis. We are suffering and dying in Yarmouk, and the fact that our Arab states and arab states are not fulfilling their commitments is a disgrace that weighs like a boulder on our consciences, but I would also remind you that if we had enforced the UN resolutions, if we had really pushed as the Union to resolve the Palestinian question and the shame of Gaza with a two-state solution, we would have had to implement the UN resolutions. , Yarmouk would not be there today, and so perhaps we also have so much to challenge our conscience.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The crisis in Yarmouk is an insult to our humanity and a cause for great shame. The camp, home to some 18,000 refugees, mostly Palestinians, is an arena of fighting between government forces and ISIS Islamists backed by fighters from the radical al-Nusra Front group. The situation inside the camp is serious, refugees lack food, medicine and fresh water. There is famine, and the area is regularly bombarded by Syrian air power. Further destabilisation of conditions in the conflict area could lead to an outbreak.  I am concerned about the deteriorating security situation, and I would therefore like to call for an end to attacks on civilians and, above all, for compliance with international humanitarian law. It is therefore important to implement UN Security Council resolutions throughout Syria. I also call on all parties involved in the conflict to allow international aid organisations free access to the Yarmouk camp in order to allow immediate and unconditional humanitarian assistance. The Union should take further diplomatic initiatives to resolve the Syrian crisis.  I welcome the commitments made by the Member States of the Union and the aid funds for the future. However, I would point out that humanitarian aid is still irregular, it is only a drop in the sea of needs. Basic humanitarian needs remain unmet. It is therefore very important to increase support for international activities in the area of conflict.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Once again, I have much more to say for the catch-the-eye procedure that follows. We will confine ourselves to three. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I think that in this day and age most people would expect that people would be at least safe in a refugee camp, that they would have access to fresh water and have the basic requirements of food and clothing. Unfortunately, it is not so in this camp which has seen its numbers diminish from 150 000 to 18 000 and which has been described as beyond humane, inhumane. It was also described by U.N. Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon as a ‘circle of hell’. This is terrible. It has emerged in recent times, as a result of ISIS in particular, that there is no limit to what people are prepared to do in pursuit of violence and their objectives. So we have to try to get all the authorities to respect the neutrality of the camp and try to get good conditions there for the unfortunate occupants.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: – Mr President, if the difficult situation following the conflict in Syria is one of the greatest humanitarian disasters of our time, the situation in Camp Yarmouk only illustrates this. Anyone who was interested in the situation or even visited the camp witnessed it. We have been watching helplessly for four years the situation in Syria in the civil war, and I think that our only task or goal is for the UN Relief and Works Agency to receive our greatest possible financial, diplomatic and political support. The EU must be one of the main pillars of humanitarian aid in the region. This is not only because of the situation in Camp Yarmouk, but also because it should be one of the means of preventing migration throughout the region.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 150 000 Palestinians have taken refuge in the Yarmouk refugee camp on the outskirts of Damascus in Syria since 1957.  On 1 April, the camp was occupied by Isis guerrillas and refugees have been living under government missiles for days and in the terror that Islamic State militants are sowing among the starving and fearful population. The situation in the refugee camp is beyond inhumane. Since the fighting started, no food, water and medicines have arrived, thousands of Palestinians, including hundreds of children, are at risk of dying of hunger and thirst, not to mention the summary executions of the last few days.  Unicef says it is concerned about the fate of 3 500 children still inside the camp.
