The UN and the international community must ensure that they provide protection and meet the humanitarian needs of Palestinian refugees in Yarmouk and all other camps. Europe and the international community must quickly ensure that all parties to the conflict reach a cease-fire that will allow aid to be brought within Yarmouk and children and families injured to be evacuated.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, on behalf of the High Representative I would like to thank you for adding this important and very sad subject to this week’s plenary agenda. The European Union is seriously concerned at the continued deterioration of the security and humanitarian situation in Syria. The conditions in the Palestinian refugee camp in Yarmouk in particular have become critical and need to be addressed with utmost urgency. After three years of besiegement by the Syrian regime, the recent escalation of violence by different fighting sides is putting the camp’s population at serious risk. The continued denial of humanitarian access by the Syrian regime and armed opposition groups to the refugees living in Yarmouk is unacceptable. The High Representative made this clear in her statement on behalf of the European Union of 18 April as well as in her Joint Statement with Commissioner Stylianides. The UN Security Council issued a Presidential Statement along the same lines on 20 April. All sides should cease hostilities to ensure immediate and unhindered humanitarian access to those in need inside the camp and to provide safe passage for all civilians who wish to leave the camp, in accordance with UN Security Council Resolutions 2139, 2165 and 2191. We urge all parties to use their influence over the fighting groups to ensure that these fundamental principles of international humanitarian law, including the protection of civilians inside the camps, are fully respected. We commend the UN Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian Refugees (UNRWA) for the important work it is doing and we will continue to work together with UNRWA Commissioner-General Pierre Krähenbühl, and all other partners to help alleviate the suffering of the people in greatest need. The Commission released immediate emergency funding of EUR 2.5 million to UNRWA’s operation to deliver lifesaving assistance to Palestinian refugees in Syria through cash and emergency relief items, and it stands ready to scale it up if needed. This emergency decision came in addition to a EUR 10 million contribution to UNRWA in December last year.  More generally, as part of the European Union’s 2015 humanitarian funding for Syria, the European Union’s support will continue to reinforce the capacity of partner organisations on the ground in order to enable them to provide a rapid humanitarian response in the case of a sudden deterioration of the situation. This funding extends to all parts of Syria affected by the conflict, with specific focus on the recent violence in Yarmouk, Idlib, Dara’a and Aleppo. This emergency funding also goes together with the EUR 33 million contribution to UNRWA provided since 2011 from the European Neighbourhood Instrument to sustain assistance to Palestinian refugees in Syria in cash assistance, education and health. We also called on the UN Special Envoy, Staffan de Mistura, to work with all parties towards the comprehensive implementation of the Geneva Communiqué of 30 June 2012 leading to a genuine political transition that meets the legitimate aspirations of the Syrian people and enables them independently and democratically to determine their own future. We will continue to fully support the victims of the Syria crisis.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the next debate. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – Syria’s bloody conflict has killed 200 000 people so far. In addition, the life of thousands of civilians from the Yarmouk camp is threatened because of the fighting between the Syrian government and IS militants.  The EU recently imposed a travel ban and an EU asset freeze on 7 persons who provide money to the Syrian regime, but this is not enough. I call upon the EU to totally isolate and defeat the IS militants as a terrorist organisation by completely cutting their funds by imposing additional EU asset freezes. I encourage the EU to create an autonomous sanctions regime to supplement the UN al-Qaeda sanction regime.  The only way to help Syria’s citizens is to seek international consensus at the level of the UNSC and to provide support for a Syrian-led political process leading to peace in accordance with the Geneva Communiqué of 30 June 2012. I therefore urge Syria to immediately implement the UNSC Resolution 2139/2014. I welcome EU’s financial efforts to provide humanitarian aid to the region, especially because the EU has been the leading international donor in response to the Syrian crisis with more than EUR 3.3 billion.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – As recent events have shown, Russia’s backing of the Assad regime had disastrous consequences in Syria. Analogically, France should not prop up Russia’s current expansionist authoritarian regime by providing it with Mistral class warships. It is important to note that although the Mistral deal has been placed on hold due to the situation in Ukraine, the contract has not yet been terminated. This means that potentially the option of delivering those warships to Russia is still on the table, which is totally unacceptable, and can be seen as an insult towards the people who have died in, or been adversely affected by the conflict in Ukraine. Europe has to take a firm stance regarding this conflict, and the most elementary step would be to refrain from providing the aggressor with additional weapons.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the detention of human rights and labour rights activists in Algeria (2015/2665(RSP)).

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Mr President, Algeria is a great country, a strategic country. I am French and Franco-Algerian relations remain marked by France's colonial past. (comment by Dominique MARTIN: "not a colonial past") Algeria was not a French colony, perhaps? The denial of the facts at this point... There are limits, though! Algerian authorities are facing an unprecedented social movement against shale gas. Hydraulic fracturing is likely to cause unprecedented damage in the south of the country, where water shortages are already severe. The water table is no longer renewed due to lack of rain. It is therefore the life and survival of the people of this region that are at stake. We do not respond to such mobilization through repression. The Algerian authorities must hear it. The criminalization of illegal assembly or pressure on the magistrates is contrary to Algeria's international commitments. It is time for this country to respect freedom of association, freedom of association and the right to protest. In Algeria, as elsewhere, dialogue with the European Union on human rights should not be a simple word. The Algerian authorities must release all peaceful protesters, human rights activists and labour activists. This is a signal that we are waiting for, because social mobilizations will continue around these essential issues for the planet. Believing that shale gas will replace oil is an illusion, from which some countries have already returned. On the eve of COP21, this message must also be heard by the Algerian authorities.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. – Mr President, as regards Algeria, we are talking about a country where the state of emergency was lifted in 2011. However, there are still serious human rights violations with regard to the freedom of expression, the freedom of association and the freedom of assembly.  Unauthorised demonstrations are still equated to ‘illegal gatherings’ and participants can be taken to Court and can be sentenced to prison for terms ranging from 2 months to 5 years. This is why we strongly condemn the arrests and ask for the immediate release of all human rights defenders and activists that have been jailed, including the ones who were protesting against shale gas operations. The geographical importance of Algeria makes stability and the full respect of human rights even more essential as the country can be fundamental to guaranteeing political stability in the whole North African region. This is a historical moment in which it is necessary to have proper certainties in that area.

name: Alyn SMITH
text: author. – Mr President, if we are in any doubt about the impact of this House with its urgency procedures we need only take into account the actions of the Algerian authorities in relation to this motion, and the fairly mild criticism therein.  Algeria is an important friend of the European Union, an important partner in our ‘near abroad’, so it is all the more important that that partnership is frank and honest, and based upon our values and the rule of law. Algeria has signed up to all the international agreements on human rights, labour rights and social rights that we could ask for, and they need to be implemented fully and genuinely. So in paragraph 1 we are right to highlight and condemn the ongoing detention of eight peaceful activists. Their actions were peaceful and legitimate and they should be released now. Paragraph 5 is the key one for my Group. I will read it out: it calls on the Algerian authorities to implement their obligations to protect ‘the right to freedom of expression, association and peaceful assembly, and to take appropriate steps to ensure the safety and security of civil society activists and human rights defenders and their freedom to pursue their legitimate and peaceful activities’. We are right to expect our friends to live up to their humanitarian commitments, and presently Algeria is not adequately doing so. As a friend of Algeria, we must encourage them to do better; I believe we can.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: Author. – I come from a country where freedom of expression and freedom of assembly have been taboo for decades. Even during the aforementioned Communist regime, such speeches were suppressed and punished. I'm glad that's not the case today. The emblem of a democratic country is that its people have these rights guaranteed. The progress made by Algeria on the road to democracy in recent years cannot be denied. However, respect for the right to free assembly remains, in my view, its weak point. I was alarmed by the recent imprisonment of human rights activists who took part in a peaceful demonstration. I believe that Algeria, a country to which I have a very close relationship since I grew up there, will respond to our resolution not only by immediately releasing the activists in particular, but also, in accordance with its Constitution, guaranteeing fair trials for the future, as well as guaranteeing the right to peaceful assembly.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Mr President, my faction is very supportive of Algeria and its citizens on the road to democracy. And I personally want the EU to strengthen its cooperation with Algeria not only in the field of economic and counter-terrorism, but also in the area of civil ity. It is therefore essential that the internal political situation in Algeria remains stable in the future in order to improve the protection of human rights and democratic values.  In my view, a close partnership between the government and civil society will clearly contribute to this, with the aim of ensuring the universal security of citizens, respect for human rights, especially in the light of regional unrest. Here I see closer cooperation and integration into the Maghrebu Group as essential. On behalf of the European People's Party, I would also like to call on the Algerian authorities to open up more cooperation with the UN in the area of human rights. And I would ask you, my dear colleagues, to support the amendments prepared by the European People's Party. I think that they complement the text and move the text very fundamentally to ensure that friendly relations with Algeria continue to be maintained.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the We have close historical, economic and political relations with Algeria as the European Union. We also have an association agreement. And, of course, under this association agreement, there is actually a human rights dialogue. But it is frozen. The Commission stated in its last report that the independence of the judiciary is still a problem and, in particular, freedom of assembly is a huge problem where independent organisations are concerned. This is about independent trade unions. In this context, it is perhaps not wrong to point out that even Amnesty International is unfortunately illegal in Algeria. The activists we are talking about today are trade unionists who have campaigned for unemployed people, who have demonstrated peacefully, who have been sentenced to long prison terms for peaceful activity. These are activities for which Algeria has known itself as legal and legitimate activities under the international instruments that it has ratified. These people must be released and our human rights dialogue must be improved.

name: Ana GOMES
text: Author. – Mr President, despite promises of reforms since 2011, the human rights situation in Algeria remains worrying. Renewed legal pressure swells this year against trade unionists and labor rights activists in the south of the country, increasing restrictions on freedoms of assembly, expression and association. I call for the unconditional and immediate release of these activists.  The law on associations must be replaced by a regulation in accordance with the international covenants on civil and political rights and economic, social and cultural rights ratified by Algeria, which must ensure the right to fair and equitable judgments, the right of all others.  The fact that in this Parliament and in the European Union we value the strategic cooperation maintained with the Algerian authorities in various areas and in particular in regional security and the fight against terrorism cannot silence us in the face of pressure from peaceful public protests, as well as arbitrary arrests and judicial pressure snags against those who exercise the right to meet, of expression , of protest, duly recognised by Algerian law.  Repression, in fact, makes the game of extremists. What can distinguish us most in the European Union and Algeria from terrorists is precisely respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, the rule of law and the rules of democracy.  That is why I ask High Representative Mogherini to ensure that the future Eu-Algeria Action Plan includes timed and specific human rights objectives by ensuring genuine, transparent cooperation mechanisms and monitoring that we parliamentarians can scrutinise. This is what is asked of in the resolution that we will adopt.

name: Seán KELLY
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa PPE. – A Uachtaráin, ar dtús is dócha gur ceart dúinn aitheantas a thabhairt don Ailgéir as ucht an dul chun cinn atá déanta ag an tír sin agus as an bpáirt nach beag atá ag an Ailgéir maidir le síocháin agus cothromaíocht a bheith i dtuaisceart na hAfraice i gcoitinne.  Maidir leis na hábhair a bhíonn os ár gcomhair anseo gach Déardaoin ó thaobh sceimhlitheoireachta agus foréigin de gach saghas, ar an scála óna haon go dtína deich, is dócha go bhfuil an t-ábhar seo ag bun an scála sin. Ach ag an am céanna, tá sé tábhachtach go bpléifimid é seo agus a chur in iúl d’údaráis na hAilgéire nach bhfuil sé ceart go mbeadh na póilíní, mar shampla, ag cur cosc ar an bpobal dul go dtí na cúirteanna go háirithe nuair atá siad ag tabhairt fianaise ar son daoine atá os comhair na gcúirteanna; ní féidir triail fhéaráilte a bheith ag daoine ansin.  Níl sé ceart ach oiread go bhféadfaí duine a chaitheamh isteach i bpríosún ar feadh bliain amháin toisc gur ghlac sé páirt i mórshiúl síochánta. Is ceart, mar chairde, é sin a chur in iúl don Ailgéir agus brú a chur orthu cearta daonna bunúsacha a thabhairt do gach duine san Ailgéir.

name: Gilles PARGNEAUX
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is important to recall the crucial role that Algeria is currently playing in the fight against terrorism in the Sahel. It is also important to remember that Algeria is an indispensable economic partner for the European Union.  Yet we must tell the truth to Algerians: no, you cannot continue to have a policy on human rights and justice like the one you are pursuing. Algeria is a great country, Algerians are a great people. The activity and liveliness of this Algerian society are important. The Algerian state must therefore take this vivacity into account and allow a policy in favour of human rights.  I ask the Commissioner that we include a subcommittee on human rights in the European Union-Algeria Association Agreement. That is how we can advance the Algerian state.

name: Fernando MAURA BARANDIARÁN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, as in many countries in our neighbourhood, the human rights situation and fundamental freedoms in Algeria must improve, as must many countries of the European Union.  I must also say that the wave of conflict and change currently shaking Europe's southern border requires strengthening and deepening ties with our neighbours for the sake of security and stability. In this regard, I would like to underline Algeria's important political, economic and strategic weight which makes it a key, decisive reference in the European Union's neighbourhood policy. We, the European Union, must take on as our own the challenges facing our neighbour and consolidate its position as a pole of development and stability on the southern border. Algeria is a reference in the containment of Islamic terrorism, clandestine immigration, as well as a strategic partner of Europe in terms of energy supply. Let us accompany Algeria in a process of improving respect for human rights. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – "Portugal sets an example for Europe, enjoy this immense glory beforehand. Europe will imitate Portugal." These words were written by Victor Hugo about 150 years ago, when Portugal became the second country to abolish the death penalty in Europe. The question I ask you, Mr, is: how can Europe demand that Algeria guarantee the rule of law, when at the same time we have voices in the European Union, such as Viktor Orbán, who are calling for the re-application of the death penalty? This measure is certainly far more serious than the violation of human rights at the moment in Algeria, which is a very serious case.

name: Fernando MAURA BARANDIARÁN
text: "blue card" response. – I, rather than answer that question, should say that I fully agree with the wording you are making in the question. I believe that we, before giving lessons to other countries, should in some cases consider solutions to our own problems. That is why I wanted to make an intervention by placing Algeria in the context in which I believe that Algeria should be placed, which is a strategic partner for the European Union.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD group. Mr President, I would like to speak this time in French, and it will not be to make the language of wood. What is happening in Algeria today? Europe's problem is that when we think of Algeria, we often think of security and energy, but we forget about human rights. Four years after the so-called Arab Spring, the country's human rights defenders are suffering in their struggle for democracy. We can't tolerate it anymore. Freedom of expression, freedom of opinion, association, all political and social freedoms are not options. These are categorical imperatives. That is why we must push our dialogue, our partnership, our association agreement on both sides of the Mediterranean. But we must also send a very clear message to the Algerian government and the Algerian people. The message to the government is that it must fulfil its international obligations and follow the path of criminal, constitutional, economic and social reforms. The message to the Algerian people is very simple and very strong: you are not alone!

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: In order for us to get to the votes, I shall only call two colleagues in the catch-the-eye procedure that follows. Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Mr President, the right to protest is a fundamental right: the possibility of peacefully expressing one's displeasure, whether with regard to the power in power in place, in support of an international cause or for the recognition of its specificities. This right is one of the best means of communication and action of civil society and the political world. It is under the pretext of unarmed gatherings that the Algerian justice system has decided to imprison nine workers' rights activists. They were sentenced to between six and 18 months in prison, solely for publicly and peacefully expressing their support for workers and unemployed people.  We must demand the unconditional release of these activists who defend their legitimate rights. We must also repeal Law 91-19, which prohibits the right to peaceful assembly and Article 97 of the Algerian Penal Code, which criminalizes it. These laws are used as a pretext to cover up the abuses of Algerian justice and violate The commitments made by Algeria under the international pact on civil and political rights, as well as the African Charter of Human and Peoples' Rights.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mr Tarabella. Mr Castaldo is usually very quick. He speaks French today. Today, the lamp has been constantly flashing at you that the interpreters are not coming along. Perhaps you should try Italian, as Mr Castaldo does today with French.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Mr. President, Dear Mr. Commissioner Mimica, none of us here in the hall has any doubt that Algeria is an extremely important country for the European Union, for the Member States. Some have better cooperation, greater cooperation, historical cooperation. Some have slightly less, but certainly that we care that Algeria remains a stable country, that we do not have the tragedies that we witness in neighboring countries, especially in Libya, and I believe that in this way we also show seriousness when we talk about the importance of Algeria.  But on the other hand, precisely because we are friends and partners we have the right to ask the leadership of Algeria to respect what the values of the European Union are. We have deep cooperation with them, we want to continue deep economic cooperation, but on the other hand we definitely need to let people out of prison and basic human and trade union rights should be respected.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Blue card question. The question I wanted to ask you is this: in view of the serious human rights situation in the country, with which I think we all agree, what do you think of the protest that has been made by many inhabitants of Algeria, especially in the south against shale gas? Would he agree with me that this is a fair and proper protest and that the people rightly have the right to choose the country's energy policy?

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Answer to a blue card question. I do not know whether you are referring to other cases that are perhaps also in the Adriatic, I do not know what your idea is, I must say it sincerely, but I am convinced that everyone can protest. So if someone doesn't accept something, they can protest, then if it's a person or thousands of people, we have to make sure that when we talk about these things we understand what those who protest want. I am convinced that the protests about another kind of energy that we certainly need will certainly always have my support.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, Algeria is one of the EU’s closest neighbours. We are formally linked by an Association Agreement and by a series of cooperation programmes. We have been negotiating an Action Plan since 2012 in the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy.  We share common challenges, ranging from regional security to unemployment. Our peoples have similar aspirations to welfare, human rights, democracy and prosperity. We ought to face those challenges and meet those aspirations through cooperation.  Our discussions with Algeria on human rights have allowed us to identify areas of concern, notably freedom of association, the right to peaceful assembly and the right to establish independent trade unions. We have conveyed those concerns to our Algerian partners in our Political Dialogue Subcommittee, our Social Affairs Subcommittee and our Association Committee. We will continue to do so in the future.  We are conscious of Algeria’s interest in social dialogue. That is why we are concerned by the severity of the sentence given by an Algerian court against several labour activists. Even if it is not a governmental decision, such a ruling could only undermine Algeria’s reputation and elicit criticism from human rights defenders, associations and other stakeholders.  In this context, the EU and Algeria have agreed to work on the reform of the justice system. The aim is to improve access to justice, reinforce the independence of the courts and further professionalise the actors in this sector. Similarly, the EU could support Algeria in its implementation of the International Labour Organisation’s Convention 87.  The EU aims to develop a democratic, stable and prosperous neighbourhood, based on a commitment to fundamental values, including the rule of law and human rights. We look forward to continuing our cooperation with Algeria in this framework.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place at the end of the debate.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item is the vote. (For results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr Lambsdorff has announced an oral amendment to the original text. First of all, we have Amendment No 2. The services tell me that the oral amendment would also be compatible with Amendment No 2. I would therefore now ask him to present it. Before the vote on Amendment No 2:

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: – Mr President, the reason why it would also apply to the text if Amendment 2 were adopted is because it is purely technical; the date of the sentence of Mohamed Rag was confirmed upon appeal not on 15 April but on 18 March. That is the only change, it is simply a change of date, and has been made in consultation with our other colleagues.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the That's right. This, too, has been discussed in advance with colleagues. It is a question of removing the names of Youssef Sultani, Abdelhamid Brahimi and Ferhat Missa from the text in recital B because it does not apply in the wording in which it is written here. The activists concerned are at different stages of their respective procedures. In this respect, these three names would have to be deleted. This too has already been discussed.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Mr! Are you sure you want to apply for this? I think it now refers to the upper part of your hand. I believe that a date must be exchanged.

name: Alexander Graf LAMBSDORFF
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the You are right, that is the request I have just made. Recital B is, in fact, the question of the date at issue. Paragraph 1 referred to the activists already mentioned, which had just been discussed. I hope that we will then be able to apply this in the same way. Thank you!

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned. (The sitting was closed at 5.15 p.m.)
